ChronologyEntries.article: AM 0:  <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H0121G' clickHandler>Adam</jLink> marks the beginning of human history according to biblical chronology, being the first human created by God (Gen.1:26-5:5). Created uniquely in God's image and given dominion over all creation, <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H0121G' clickHandler>Adam</jLink> was formed from the dust of the earth and received the divine breath of life. His creation establishes the foundation for biblical understanding of humanity's special relationship with God and sets the theological framework for themes of fall, redemption, and covenant that permeate Scripture. <jPara></jPara> <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H0121G' clickHandler>Adam</jLink>'s life span of 930 years encompasses the entire early period of human civilization, during which he witnessed the births of his sons <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H7014B' clickHandler>Cain</jLink>, <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H1893' clickHandler>Abel</jLink>, and <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H8352' clickHandler>Seth</jLink>, as well as <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H1893' clickHandler>Abel</jLink>'s murder and the subsequent birth of <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H8352' clickHandler>Seth</jLink> as a replacement. His disobedience to God's command regarding the tree of the knowledge of good and evil introduced sin into the world, profoundly affecting all subsequent human history. <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H0121G' clickHandler>Adam</jLink>'s genealogical significance extends throughout biblical narrative, as he serves as the progenitor of the human race and the starting point for the carefully documented lineages that connect creation to later biblical events.
events: AM 0: God forms <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H0121G' clickHandler>Adam</jLink> from dust and breathes life into him
AM 0: God places <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H0121G' clickHandler>Adam</jLink> in the Garden of <jLink data-type='L' data-strong='H5729' clickHandler>Eden</jLink> to work and care for it

AM 0: God creates <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H2332' clickHandler>Eve</jLink> from <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H0121G' clickHandler>Adam</jLink>'s rib as his companion and <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H0121G' clickHandler>Adam</jLink> names her "woman"
AM 0: <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H0121G' clickHandler>Adam</jLink> disobeys God's command about the tree of the knowledge of good and evil

ChronologyEntries.article: AM 130:  <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H8352' clickHandler>Seth</jLink> was born in AM 130 as the third son of <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H0121G' clickHandler>Adam</jLink> and <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H2332' clickHandler>Eve</jLink>, serving as a divinely appointed replacement for <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H1893' clickHandler>Abel</jLink>, who had been murdered by his brother <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H7014B' clickHandler>Cain</jLink> (Gen.4:25-26; 5:3-7). His birth represents a crucial turning point in early human history, as his lineage would carry forward the righteous heritage in contrast to the line of <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H7014B' clickHandler>Cain</jLink>. <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H8352' clickHandler>Seth</jLink>'s name, meaning "appointed" or "granted," reflects his role as the one through whom God's covenant promises would continue. <jPara></jPara> Living for 912 years, <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H8352' clickHandler>Seth</jLink> witnessed significant developments in early human civilization and spiritual life. His genealogical importance extends far beyond his own lifetime, as the biblical narrative traces the line of faith through <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H8352' clickHandler>Seth</jLink> rather than through <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H7014B' clickHandler>Cain</jLink>, emphasizing the preservation of godly heritage through his descendants who would eventually include figures such as <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H0583' clickHandler>Enosh</jLink>, <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H5146' clickHandler>Noah</jLink>, and ultimately the Messianic line. The biblical account presents <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H8352' clickHandler>Seth</jLink>'s line as the continuation of proper worship and relationship with God during humanity's earliest centuries.
events: AM 130: <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H0121G' clickHandler>Adam</jLink> and <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H2332' clickHandler>Eve</jLink> have <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H8352' clickHandler>Seth</jLink> as a divinely appointed replacement for <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H1893' clickHandler>Abel</jLink>

AM 130: <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H0121G' clickHandler>Adam</jLink> names his son <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H8352' clickHandler>Seth</jLink> as another offspring in place of <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H1893' clickHandler>Abel</jLink>

AM 130: <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H2332' clickHandler>Eve</jLink> acknowledges <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H8352' clickHandler>Seth</jLink> as the child given by God to replace <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H1893' clickHandler>Abel</jLink> killed by <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H7014B' clickHandler>Cain</jLink>

ChronologyEntries.article: AM 235:  <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H0583' clickHandler>Enosh</jLink>, the son of <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H8352' clickHandler>Seth</jLink> and grandson of <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H0121G' clickHandler>Adam</jLink>, was born in AM 235 and lived for 905 years (Gen.4:26; 5:6-11). His lifetime marks a significant development in the spiritual history of early humanity, as the biblical text specifically notes that during <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H0583' clickHandler>Enosh</jLink>'s era, "people began to call upon the name of the Lord" (Gen.4:26). This development is interpreted by biblical scholars as marking either the beginning of organized worship, public invocation of God's name, or a renewal of spiritual devotion among humanity. <jPara></jPara> <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H0583' clickHandler>Enosh</jLink>'s place in the genealogical line from <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H0121G' clickHandler>Adam</jLink> through <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H8352' clickHandler>Seth</jLink> underscores the continuity of the righteous lineage that would eventually lead to <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H5146' clickHandler>Noah</jLink> and beyond. His birth occurred when <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H0121G' clickHandler>Adam</jLink> was still alive (<jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H0121G' clickHandler>Adam</jLink> lived until AM 930), meaning multiple generations coexisted during this early period of human history. The spiritual awakening associated with <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H0583' clickHandler>Enosh</jLink>'s time suggests that his generation may have played a crucial role in establishing patterns of worship and divine relationship that would influence subsequent biblical history.
events: AM 235: <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H8352' clickHandler>Seth</jLink> begets his son <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H0583' clickHandler>Enosh</jLink>, <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H0121G' clickHandler>Adam</jLink>'s grandson
AM 235: People begin calling upon the name of the Lord

ChronologyEntries.article: AM 325:  <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H7018' clickHandler>Kenan</jLink>, born in AM 325 as the son of <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H0583' clickHandler>Enosh</jLink>, continued the righteous genealogical line (Gen.5:9-14) living for 910 years until AM 1235. His birth occurred during the overlapping lifetimes of his great-grandfather <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H0121G' clickHandler>Adam</jLink> (who lived until AM 930) and grandfather <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H8352' clickHandler>Seth</jLink> (who lived until AM 1042), demonstrating the extended lifespans and multi-generational family structures of the antediluvian period. <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H7018' clickHandler>Kenan</jLink>'s inclusion in the carefully preserved genealogical record emphasizes the biblical emphasis on maintaining the lineage through which God's covenant promises would be transmitted. <jPara></jPara> As part of the genealogical chain from <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H0121G' clickHandler>Adam</jLink> through <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H8352' clickHandler>Seth</jLink> and <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H0583' clickHandler>Enosh</jLink>, <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H7018' clickHandler>Kenan</jLink> represents the continuation of the faithful line that would eventually produce <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H5146' clickHandler>Noah</jLink> and survive the coming flood judgment. His 910-year lifespan places him among the long-lived patriarchs of the pre-flood era, and his life would have spanned significant developments in early human civilization and spiritual history. While the biblical record provides limited details about <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H7018' clickHandler>Kenan</jLink>'s individual accomplishments, his genealogical position underscores the theological importance of covenant continuity through successive generations leading toward God's redemptive plan for humanity.
events: AM 325: <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H0583' clickHandler>Enosh</jLink> begets his son <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H7018' clickHandler>Kenan</jLink>

ChronologyEntries.article: AM 395:  <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H4111G' clickHandler>Mahalalel</jLink> was born in Anno Mundi 395 and lived for 895 years, placing his death in AM 1290 according to the biblical chronology. He was the son of <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H7018' clickHandler>Kenan</jLink> and became the father of <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H3382G' clickHandler>Jared</jLink> at the age of 65, continuing the righteous lineage from <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H0121G' clickHandler>Adam</jLink> through <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H8352' clickHandler>Seth</jLink> (Gen.5:12-17). <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H4111G' clickHandler>Mahalalel</jLink> represents the fifth generation from <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H0121G' clickHandler>Adam</jLink> in the Sethite genealogy, serving as a crucial link in the antediluvian patriarchal chain that would eventually lead to <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H5146' clickHandler>Noah</jLink>. <jPara></jPara> His lifespan of 895 years falls within the typical range of the pre-flood patriarchs, reflecting the extraordinary longevity attributed to humans before the great deluge. The name <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H4111G' clickHandler>Mahalalel</jLink> means "praise of God" or "God shines forth," which may reflect the theological significance placed on maintaining faithfulness to God during this early period of human history. His role in the genealogy emphasizes the continuity of the covenant line and the faithful transmission of divine promises through successive generations.
events: AM 395: <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H7018' clickHandler>Kenan</jLink> fathers his son <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H4111G' clickHandler>Mahalalel</jLink> at age 70

ChronologyEntries.desc: <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H3382G' clickHandler>Jared</jLink>, lives 962 or 847 yrs
ChronologyEntries.article: AM 460:  <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H3382G' clickHandler>Jared</jLink> was born in Anno Mundi 460 and lived for either 962 or 847 years, with this discrepancy arising from differences between ancient manuscript traditions. <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H3382G' clickHandler>Jared</jLink> was the son of <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H4111G' clickHandler>Mahalalel</jLink> and became the father of <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H2585H' clickHandler>Enoch</jLink> at the age of 162 (Gen.5:15-20). The Masoretic Text records his lifespan as 962 years, while the Septuagint and some other ancient sources give the alternative figure of 847 years, illustrating the complex history of biblical textual transmission. <jPara></jPara> <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H3382G' clickHandler>Jared</jLink>'s significance extends beyond his impressive longevity to his role as the father of <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H2585H' clickHandler>Enoch</jLink>, one of the most remarkable figures in biblical history. His death would have occurred around AM 1422, placing him among the long-lived antediluvian patriarchs who witnessed the early development of human civilization before the flood. The variations in his recorded age reflect the challenges scholars face when working with ancient manuscripts, where such discrepancies are common in the genealogical records of Genesis.
events: AM 460: <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H4111G' clickHandler>Mahalalel</jLink> fathers his son <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H3382G' clickHandler>Jared</jLink> at age 65

ChronologyEntries.article: AM 622:  <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H2585H' clickHandler>Enoch</jLink> was born in Anno Mundi 622 and lived for 365 years, making him unique among the antediluvian patriarchs for his relatively short lifespan. <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H2585H' clickHandler>Enoch</jLink> was the son of <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H3382G' clickHandler>Jared</jLink> and the father of <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H4968' clickHandler>Methuselah</jLink>, but his account differs dramatically from other patriarchs in the genealogy (Gen.5:18-24). The text emphasizes twice that <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H2585H' clickHandler>Enoch</jLink> "walked with God," highlighting his exceptional piety and close relationship with the divine, a phrase used exclusively for him in this genealogical record. <jPara></jPara> Most remarkably, <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H2585H' clickHandler>Enoch</jLink>'s account states that "he was not, for God took him," indicating that he bypassed death and was taken directly by God. This extraordinary departure from earthly life makes <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H2585H' clickHandler>Enoch</jLink> one of only two individuals in the Hebrew Bible (alongside <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H0452G' clickHandler>Elijah</jLink>) described as not experiencing death in the conventional sense. His unique status has made him a significant figure in later Jewish and Christian literature, where his righteousness and divine translation have been subjects of extensive theological reflection and extrabiblical elaboration.
events: AM 622: <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H3382G' clickHandler>Jared</jLink> fathers his son <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H2585H' clickHandler>Enoch</jLink> at age 162

ChronologyEntries.desc: <jChronDurationLink style='color:black'>▼</jChronDurationLink><jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H4968' clickHandler>Methuselah</jLink>, lives 969 or 720 yrs
ChronologyEntries.article: AM 687:  <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H4968' clickHandler>Methuselah</jLink> was born in Anno Mundi 687 and lived for either 969 or 720 years, with 969 years being the figure from the Masoretic Text and widely accepted as the longest human lifespan recorded in the Bible. <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H4968' clickHandler>Methuselah</jLink> was the son of the remarkable <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H2585H' clickHandler>Enoch</jLink> and became the father of <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H3929G' clickHandler>Lamech</jLink>, continuing the genealogical line that would lead to <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H5146' clickHandler>Noah</jLink> (Gen.5:21-27). The alternative lifespan of 720 years appears in some Septuagint manuscripts and other ancient sources, reflecting textual variations that developed during centuries of manuscript transmission. <jPara></jPara> <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H4968' clickHandler>Methuselah</jLink>'s extraordinary longevity has made his name synonymous with great age, and his death holds particular chronological significance as it occurred in AM 1656, the very year of the great flood. This timing has led to theological speculation about whether his death served as a divine signal for the impending judgment, with his name possibly meaning "when he dies, it shall come" or "man of the dart/spear." His life span bridges nearly the entire antediluvian period, making him a witness to the development and corruption of early human civilization that ultimately necessitated divine judgment through the flood.
events: AM 687: <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H2585H' clickHandler>Enoch</jLink> fathers his son <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H4968' clickHandler>Methuselah</jLink> at age 65

ChronologyEntries.desc: <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H3929G' clickHandler>Lamech</jLink>, lives 777, 753 or 653 yrs
ChronologyEntries.article: AM 874:  <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H3929G' clickHandler>Lamech</jLink> was born in Anno Mundi 874 and became the father of <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H5146' clickHandler>Noah</jLink>, making him a pivotal figure in biblical history as the penultimate antediluvian patriarch. <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H3929G' clickHandler>Lamech</jLink>'s lifespan is recorded with notable variation across ancient manuscript traditions: 777 years in the Masoretic Text, 753 years in the Septuagint, and 653 years in the <jLink data-type='L' data-strong='H8111' clickHandler>Samaritan</jLink> Pentateuch (Gen.5:25-31). These discrepancies reflect the complex transmission history of biblical genealogies, where scribal variations and different textual families preserved different numerical traditions. <jPara></jPara> <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H3929G' clickHandler>Lamech</jLink>'s significance extends beyond his remarkable longevity to his prophetic role as <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H5146' clickHandler>Noah</jLink>'s father, as he declared at <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H5146' clickHandler>Noah</jLink>'s birth that his son would "comfort us in the work and painful toil of our hands" (Gen.5:29). His death occurred in AM 1651, just five years before the great flood, positioning him as the last of the long-lived antediluvian patriarchs to die before the divine judgment that would reshape human history. The variations in his recorded age demonstrate the textual challenges scholars face when studying ancient genealogies, yet his essential role in linking the pre-flood world to <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H5146' clickHandler>Noah</jLink>'s generation remains consistent across all traditions.
events: AM 874: <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H3929G' clickHandler>Lamech</jLink> is born to <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H4968' clickHandler>Methuselah</jLink>

ChronologyEntries.article: AM 930:  The death of <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H0121G' clickHandler>Adam</jLink> in Anno Mundi 930 marked the end of the first human life according to biblical chronology (Gen.1:26-5:5). <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H0121G' clickHandler>Adam</jLink> lived exactly 930 years, witnessing the birth and early lives of his descendants through multiple generations, including his great-great-great-great-grandson <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H2585H' clickHandler>Enoch</jLink>, who was born when <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H0121G' clickHandler>Adam</jLink> was 622 years old. This extraordinary lifespan allowed <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H0121G' clickHandler>Adam</jLink> to serve as a living link between the original creation and the developing antediluvian civilization, potentially transmitting direct knowledge of God's original commands and the circumstances of humanity's fall from <jLink data-type='L' data-strong='H5729' clickHandler>Eden</jLink>. <jPara></jPara> <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H0121G' clickHandler>Adam</jLink>'s death represents a foundational moment in biblical history, as it fulfilled the divine warning that disobedience would result in death (Gen.2:17), while simultaneously demonstrating God's mercy in allowing <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H0121G' clickHandler>Adam</jLink> to live for nearly a millennium despite his transgression. His passing occurred 57 years before <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H2585H' clickHandler>Enoch</jLink>'s translation and 112 years before <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H8352' clickHandler>Seth</jLink>'s death, meaning that the first generation of humanity overlapped significantly with subsequent patriarchal generations. This chronological framework establishes <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H0121G' clickHandler>Adam</jLink> as the patriarch from whom all subsequent biblical genealogies flow, making his death a pivotal transition point from the original created order to the continuing human narrative under the conditions of mortality.
events: AM 930: <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H0121G' clickHandler>Adam</jLink> dies at age 930

ChronologyEntries.article: AM 987:  <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H2585H' clickHandler>Enoch</jLink> "was not, for God took him" (Gen.5:24), indicating that he did not experience death in the conventional sense. After living 365 years—significantly shorter than his contemporaries—<jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H2585H' clickHandler>Enoch</jLink> was translated directly to heaven without dying, making him one of only two individuals in the Hebrew Bible (alongside <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H0452G' clickHandler>Elijah</jLink>) to bypass normal mortality. The phrase "<jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H2585H' clickHandler>Enoch</jLink> walked with God" occurs twice (Gen.5:22-24), emphasizing his exceptional righteousness and intimate relationship with the divine that distinguished him from other antediluvian patriarchs. <jPara></jPara> <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H2585H' clickHandler>Enoch</jLink>'s translation occurred when <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H0121G' clickHandler>Adam</jLink> was 987 years old and just 57 years before <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H0121G' clickHandler>Adam</jLink>'s death, suggesting that the first generation of humanity witnessed this remarkable demonstration of divine favor. The symbolic significance of <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H2585H' clickHandler>Enoch</jLink>'s 365-year lifespan, corresponding to the solar year, has prompted scholarly speculation about cosmic or universal meaning in his life and departure. His unique fate established him as a prototype of divine favor toward the righteous and influenced extensive later Jewish and Christian literature, including pseudepigraphic works that elaborate on his heavenly journey and role as an intermediary between God and humanity.
events: AM 987: <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H2585H' clickHandler>Enoch</jLink>'s earthly life ends after 365 years
AM 987: God takes <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H2585H' clickHandler>Enoch</jLink> directly to heaven

ChronologyEntries.article: AM 1042:  <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H8352' clickHandler>Seth</jLink> died in Anno Mundi 1042 after living 912 years, concluding the life of <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H0121G' clickHandler>Adam</jLink>'s third son who had been appointed by God to continue the righteous lineage after <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H1893' clickHandler>Abel</jLink>'s murder. <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H8352' clickHandler>Seth</jLink> was born when <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H0121G' clickHandler>Adam</jLink> was 130 years old, and through him the genealogical line was preserved that would eventually lead to <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H5146' clickHandler>Noah</jLink> and beyond (Gen.4:25-26; 5:3-7). <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H8352' clickHandler>Seth</jLink>'s name, meaning "appointed" or "placed," reflected <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H2332' clickHandler>Eve</jLink>'s recognition that God had given her another son in place of <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H1893' clickHandler>Abel</jLink>, establishing him as the patriarch through whom the promised seed would be transmitted. <jPara></jPara> <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H8352' clickHandler>Seth</jLink>'s death occurred 112 years after <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H0121G' clickHandler>Adam</jLink>'s passing and 55 years before <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H2585H' clickHandler>Enoch</jLink>'s translation, positioning him as a crucial bridge between the first generation and the continuing antediluvian civilization. His 912-year lifespan placed him among the long-lived patriarchs whose extraordinary longevity characterized the pre-flood period, and his descendants continued the practice of calling upon the name of the Lord that began during his lifetime (Gen.4:26). Through <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H8352' clickHandler>Seth</jLink>'s lineage, the covenant promises and knowledge of God were preserved through the generations leading to <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H5146' clickHandler>Noah</jLink>, making his death a significant transition point in the transmission of divine revelation and human history.
events: AM 1042: <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H8352' clickHandler>Seth</jLink> dies at age 912

ChronologyEntries.article: AM 1056:  <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H5146' clickHandler>Noah</jLink> was born in Anno Mundi 1056 as the son of <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H3929G' clickHandler>Lamech</jLink>, who prophetically declared at his birth that <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H5146' clickHandler>Noah</jLink> would "comfort us in the work and painful toil of our hands" caused by the divine curse upon the ground. <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H5146' clickHandler>Noah</jLink>'s extraordinary 950-year lifespan extended from AM 1056 to AM 2006, encompassing the most pivotal events in antediluvian history (Gen.5:29-10:1). His birth occurred during the lifetime of several long-lived patriarchs, including his grandfather <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H4968' clickHandler>Methuselah</jLink>, who would die in the very year of the flood, and <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H0121G' clickHandler>Adam</jLink>'s son <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H8352' clickHandler>Seth</jLink>, who had died just 14 years earlier in AM 1042. <jPara></jPara> <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H5146' clickHandler>Noah</jLink>'s significance transcends his remarkable longevity to encompass his role as the preserver of human and animal life through the great flood. Described as a righteous man who "walked with God," <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H5146' clickHandler>Noah</jLink> received divine instructions to build an ark in preparation for the deluge that would judge the wickedness of his generation. After surviving the flood with his wife, three sons (<jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H8035' clickHandler>Shem</jLink>, <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H2526G' clickHandler>Ham</jLink>, and <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H3315' clickHandler>Japheth</jLink>), God established an everlasting covenant with <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H5146' clickHandler>Noah</jLink>, promising never again to destroy them by flood and giving the rainbow as a perpetual sign of this covenant (Gen.9:8-17). Through his three sons, <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H5146' clickHandler>Noah</jLink> became the ancestor of all nations, making his birth in AM 1056 the beginning of a new chapter in human history.
events: AM 1056: <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H5146' clickHandler>Noah</jLink> is born to <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H3929G' clickHandler>Lamech</jLink>

AM 1056: <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H3929G' clickHandler>Lamech</jLink> prophetically declares <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H5146' clickHandler>Noah</jLink> will comfort them from divine curse

ChronologyEntries.article: AM 1140:  <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H0583' clickHandler>Enosh</jLink> died in Anno Mundi 1140 after living 905 years, marking the end of the third generation from <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H0121G' clickHandler>Adam</jLink> and closing a significant chapter in early human spiritual development. As the son of <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H8352' clickHandler>Seth</jLink> and grandson of <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H0121G' clickHandler>Adam</jLink>, <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H0583' clickHandler>Enosh</jLink> represented the continuation of the righteous lineage established after <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H1893' clickHandler>Abel</jLink>'s death and <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H7014B' clickHandler>Cain</jLink>'s exile. His death occurred during <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H5146' clickHandler>Noah</jLink>'s 84th year of life, bridging the early patriarchal period with the generation that would witness the great flood. <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H0583' clickHandler>Enosh</jLink> became the father of <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H7018' clickHandler>Kenan</jLink> at age 90 and lived to see multiple generations of his descendants (Gen.5:6-11). <jPara></jPara> The era of <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H0583' clickHandler>Enosh</jLink>'s lifetime holds particular theological significance because "at that time people began to call upon the name of the Lord" (Gen.4:26), indicating either the beginning of organized worship or a renewal of spiritual devotion among early humanity. This spiritual awakening during <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H0583' clickHandler>Enosh</jLink>'s generation suggests that his 905-year lifespan coincided with the formalization of humanity's relationship with God and the development of religious practices. His death in AM 1140 occurred 516 years before the flood, during a period when the world was transitioning from the early righteous generations toward the corruption that would ultimately necessitate divine judgment through <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H5146' clickHandler>Noah</jLink>'s flood.
events: AM 1140: <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H0583' clickHandler>Enosh</jLink> dies at age 905

ChronologyEntries.article: AM 1235:  <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H7018' clickHandler>Kenan</jLink> died in Anno Mundi 1235 after living 910 years, concluding the life of the fourth patriarch in the genealogical line from <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H0121G' clickHandler>Adam</jLink> through <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H8352' clickHandler>Seth</jLink>. <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H7018' clickHandler>Kenan</jLink> was the son of <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H0583' clickHandler>Enosh</jLink> and the father of <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H4111G' clickHandler>Mahalalel</jLink>, serving as a crucial link in the antediluvian genealogy that would eventually lead to <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H5146' clickHandler>Noah</jLink> (Gen.5:9-14). His death occurred during <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H5146' clickHandler>Noah</jLink>'s 179th year of life, placing him among the long-lived patriarchs whose extraordinary lifespans characterized the pre-flood world. <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H7018' clickHandler>Kenan</jLink>'s 910-year lifespan exceeded that of his father <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H0583' clickHandler>Enosh</jLink> by five years, continuing the pattern of remarkable longevity that distinguished the early generations of humanity. <jPara></jPara> <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H7018' clickHandler>Kenan</jLink>'s significance lies primarily in his role as a genealogical bridge in the biblical narrative, maintaining the unbroken line from <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H0121G' clickHandler>Adam</jLink> to <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H5146' clickHandler>Noah</jLink> that forms the backbone of early Genesis chronology. His inclusion in both Old and New Testament genealogies (1Ch.1:2; Luk.3:37-38), underscores his importance in biblical tradition as a testament to the continuity of God's covenant through successive generations. His death in AM 1235 occurred 421 years before the flood and just 55 years before his son <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H4111G' clickHandler>Mahalalel</jLink>'s death, representing the gradual passing of the early patriarchal generation as the antediluvian world moved toward its climactic judgment under <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H5146' clickHandler>Noah</jLink>'s leadership.
events: AM 1235: <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H7018' clickHandler>Kenan</jLink> dies at age 910

ChronologyEntries.article: AM 1290:  <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H4111G' clickHandler>Mahalalel</jLink> died in Anno Mundi 1290 after living 895 years, bringing to a close the life of the fifth patriarch in the Sethite genealogy from <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H0121G' clickHandler>Adam</jLink> to <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H5146' clickHandler>Noah</jLink>. <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H4111G' clickHandler>Mahalalel</jLink> was the son of <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H7018' clickHandler>Kenan</jLink> and the father of <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H3382G' clickHandler>Jared</jLink>, positioning him as an essential link in the righteous lineage that preserved the knowledge of God through the antediluvian period (Gen.5:12-17). His death occurred during <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H5146' clickHandler>Noah</jLink>'s 234th year of life, making him one of the patriarchs whose lifespan overlapped significantly with <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H5146' clickHandler>Noah</jLink>'s early years before the flood. The name <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H4111G' clickHandler>Mahalalel</jLink>, meaning "praise of God" or "God shines forth," may reflect the theological significance placed on maintaining faithfulness to God during this period of early human history. <jPara></jPara> <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H4111G' clickHandler>Mahalalel</jLink>'s death in AM 1290 occurred 366 years before the great flood, marking a generational transition as the long-lived antediluvian patriarchs gradually passed away. His 895-year lifespan, while shorter than his father <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H7018' clickHandler>Kenan</jLink>'s 910 years, still placed him among the remarkably long-lived figures who characterized the pre-flood era and who served as witnesses to the development of early human civilization. As the great-great-great-grandfather of <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H5146' clickHandler>Noah</jLink>, <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H4111G' clickHandler>Mahalalel</jLink>'s role in preserving the covenant line was crucial for the continuation of God's promises through the generations, demonstrating the theological importance of genealogical continuity in the biblical narrative leading up to the flood and humanity's new beginning through <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H5146' clickHandler>Noah</jLink>'s family.
events: AM 1290: <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H4111G' clickHandler>Mahalalel</jLink> son of <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H7018' clickHandler>Kenan</jLink> and father of <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H3382G' clickHandler>Jared</jLink> dies at age 895

ChronologyEntries.article: AM 1422:  <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H3382G' clickHandler>Jared</jLink> died in Anno Mundi 1422 after living either 962 or 847 years, according to different manuscript traditions (Gen.5:15-20). As the father of <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H2585H' clickHandler>Enoch</jLink> and grandfather of <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H4968' clickHandler>Methuselah</jLink>, <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H3382G' clickHandler>Jared</jLink> represented a crucial link in the antediluvian patriarchal chain that connected <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H0121G' clickHandler>Adam</jLink> to <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H5146' clickHandler>Noah</jLink> through the righteous Sethite lineage. His extraordinarily long lifespan allowed him to witness the early development of human civilization and potentially serve as a repository of divine knowledge transmitted from earlier generations. The variation in his recorded age reflects the complex textual history of biblical manuscripts, where the Masoretic Text records 962 years while some Septuagint and other ancient sources preserve the alternative figure of 847 years. <jPara></jPara> <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H3382G' clickHandler>Jared</jLink>'s death occurred approximately 234 years before the great flood, positioning him among the long-lived patriarchs who died during the final centuries of the antediluvian period. His passing marked a significant generational transition, as he was one of the last patriarchs to have potentially known <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H0121G' clickHandler>Adam</jLink>'s immediate descendants and to have witnessed the spiritual conditions that would eventually necessitate divine judgment through the flood. Through his son <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H2585H' clickHandler>Enoch</jLink>, who "walked with God" and was translated without experiencing death, <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H3382G' clickHandler>Jared</jLink>'s lineage contributed to preserving the knowledge of righteousness that would be crucial for <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H5146' clickHandler>Noah</jLink>'s generation.
events: AM 1422: <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H3382G' clickHandler>Jared</jLink> father of <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H2585H' clickHandler>Enoch</jLink> and grandfather of <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H4968' clickHandler>Methuselah</jLink> dies at age 962 or 847

ChronologyEntries.desc: <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H3315' clickHandler>Japheth</jLink>, <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H5146' clickHandler>Noah</jLink>'s firstborn
ChronologyEntries.article: AM 1556:  <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H3315' clickHandler>Japheth</jLink> was born in Anno Mundi 1556 as <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H5146' clickHandler>Noah</jLink>'s firstborn son (Gen.5:32; 10:21). His birth occurred when <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H5146' clickHandler>Noah</jLink> was 500 years old, marking the beginning of the final generation before the great flood that would reshape human civilization. As one of only eight people who would survive the worldwide deluge, <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H3315' clickHandler>Japheth</jLink>'s birth represents a pivotal moment in biblical history, as he would become one of the progenitors of post-flood humanity. The designation of <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H3315' clickHandler>Japheth</jLink> as the "elder" or firstborn among <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H5146' clickHandler>Noah</jLink>'s sons (Gen.10:21) establishes his priority in the genealogical record and his role in the repopulation of the earth following the flood. <jPara></jPara> According to later biblical tradition (Gen.10:2-5) <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H3315' clickHandler>Japheth</jLink> became the ancestor of numerous nations, particularly those associated with the "coastlands of the nations" or "isles of the <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H1471G' clickHandler>Gentiles</jLink>". These descendants are traditionally linked to peoples who spread across Europe and parts of <jLink data-type='L' data-strong='G0773' clickHandler>Asia</jLink>, making <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H3315' clickHandler>Japheth</jLink> a significant figure in biblical ethnology and the table of nations. His birth in AM 1556, exactly 100 years before the flood, positioned him to be a mature adult witness to the increasing wickedness that would prompt divine judgment, while also preparing him to help establish the new world order that would emerge after the flood waters receded.
events: AM 1556: <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H3315' clickHandler>Japheth</jLink> is born as <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H5146' clickHandler>Noah</jLink>'s firstborn son

ChronologyEntries.article: AM 1558:  <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H8035' clickHandler>Shem</jLink> was born in Anno Mundi 1558, two years after his elder brother <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H3315' clickHandler>Japheth</jLink>, as one of <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H5146' clickHandler>Noah</jLink>'s three sons destined to survive the great flood. <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H8035' clickHandler>Shem</jLink> lived exactly 600 years, making him one of the longest-lived individuals in the post-flood era and bridging the antediluvian and post-diluvian periods of human history (Gen.5:32; 11:11). His birth occurred when <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H5146' clickHandler>Noah</jLink> was 502 years old, positioning him as a crucial figure in the preservation and continuation of the human race through the catastrophic flood that would occur when he was 98 years old. <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H8035' clickHandler>Shem</jLink>'s remarkable longevity allowed him to witness both the destruction and the gradual repopulation and development of the new world order. <jPara></jPara> <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H8035' clickHandler>Shem</jLink>'s significance extends far beyond his impressive lifespan to encompass his role as the ancestor of the Semitic peoples, including the crucial lineage that would lead to <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H0085' clickHandler>Abraham</jLink>, <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H3327' clickHandler>Isaac</jLink>, <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='G2384G' clickHandler>Jacob</jLink>, and ultimately the nation of Israel. The genealogical record (Gen.11:10-26) traces the direct line from <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H8035' clickHandler>Shem</jLink> through <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H0775' clickHandler>Arphaxad</jLink>, <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H7974' clickHandler>Shelah</jLink>, <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H5677G' clickHandler>Eber</jLink>, <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H6389' clickHandler>Peleg</jLink>, <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H7466' clickHandler>Reu</jLink>, <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H8286' clickHandler>Serug</jLink>, <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H5152G' clickHandler>Nahor</jLink>, and <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H8646G' clickHandler>Terah</jLink> to <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H0085' clickHandler>Abraham</jLink>, establishing <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H8035' clickHandler>Shem</jLink> as the patriarchal foundation for God's covenant people. His 600-year lifespan meant that he lived to see the birth of <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H0085' clickHandler>Abraham</jLink> and potentially could have transmitted firsthand knowledge of the pre-flood world and the flood experience to the father of the faithful, making him a vital link in the preservation of divine revelation and covenantal promises.
events: AM 1558: <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H8035' clickHandler>Shem</jLink> is born as <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H5146' clickHandler>Noah</jLink>'s second son two years after <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H3315' clickHandler>Japheth</jLink>

AM 1558: <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H8035' clickHandler>Shem</jLink>'s birth begins the patriarchal line leading to <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H0085' clickHandler>Abraham</jLink> <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H3327' clickHandler>Isaac</jLink> <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='G2384G' clickHandler>Jacob</jLink> and Israel

ChronologyEntries.article: AM 1651:  <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H3929G' clickHandler>Lamech</jLink> died in Anno Mundi 1651 after living either 777, 753, or 653 years, according to different manuscript traditions (Gen.5:25-31). As the father of <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H5146' clickHandler>Noah</jLink> and the son of <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H4968' clickHandler>Methuselah</jLink>, <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H3929G' clickHandler>Lamech</jLink> represented the penultimate generation of the antediluvian patriarchs, and his death occurred precisely five years before the great flood in AM 1656. His name and prophetic declaration at <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H5146' clickHandler>Noah</jLink>'s birth—that his son would "comfort us concerning our work and the toil of our hands, because of the ground which the Lord has cursed"—proved remarkably prescient, as <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H5146' clickHandler>Noah</jLink> would indeed bring a form of comfort through his righteousness and obedience in preserving human and animal life through the flood. The variations in <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H3929G' clickHandler>Lamech</jLink>'s recorded lifespan reflect different ancient textual traditions, with 777 years appearing in the Masoretic Text while the Septuagint and <jLink data-type='L' data-strong='H8111' clickHandler>Samaritan</jLink> Pentateuch preserve alternative figures. <jPara></jPara> <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H3929G' clickHandler>Lamech</jLink>'s death marked a critical transition point in biblical chronology, as it removed the last of the pre-flood patriarchs who had directly known the earlier generations and experienced the gradual corruption of antediluvian society. His passing left <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H5146' clickHandler>Noah</jLink> as the primary representative of righteousness in a world that had become so wicked that divine judgment was imminent. The timing of <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H3929G' clickHandler>Lamech</jLink>'s death, occurring just five years before the flood, suggests a providential arrangement whereby he was spared from witnessing the complete destruction of the world he had known, while ensuring that <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H5146' clickHandler>Noah</jLink> would bear the full responsibility for responding to God's command to build the ark and preserve life through the coming deluge.
events: AM 1651: <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H3929G' clickHandler>Lamech</jLink> father of <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H5146' clickHandler>Noah</jLink> and son of <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H4968' clickHandler>Methuselah</jLink> dies at age 777 753 or 653

ChronologyEntries.desc: <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H4968' clickHandler>Methuselah</jLink> dies. The Flood
ChronologyEntries.article: AM 1656:  <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H4968' clickHandler>Methuselah</jLink> died in Anno Mundi 1656 after living 969 years (according to the Masoretic Text), making him the longest-lived human recorded in biblical history. His death occurred in the same year as the great flood (Gen.6-9) creating a significant chronological convergence that marks the end of the antediluvian era. As the grandfather of <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H5146' clickHandler>Noah</jLink> and son of <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H2585H' clickHandler>Enoch</jLink>, <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H4968' clickHandler>Methuselah</jLink> represented the final link to the earliest generations of humanity, and his passing symbolically closed the chapter on the pre-flood world characterized by extraordinary human longevity and increasing wickedness. <jPara></jPara> The flood itself represents the most catastrophic divine judgment in biblical history, triggered by humanity's pervasive corruption and violence (Gen.6:5-13). God instructed <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H5146' clickHandler>Noah</jLink> to build an ark to preserve his family and representatives of all animal kinds through the deluge that lasted for over a year (Gen.7:11-8:14). The convergence of <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H4968' clickHandler>Methuselah</jLink>'s death with the flood's onset suggests providential timing, as the last of the long-lived patriarchs departed just as God's judgment began to reshape human civilization. Following the flood, God established an everlasting covenant with <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H5146' clickHandler>Noah</jLink> and his family, promising never again to destroy them by water and setting the rainbow as a perpetual sign of this promise (Gen.9:8-17).
events: AM 1656: <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H4968' clickHandler>Methuselah</jLink> son of <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H2585H' clickHandler>Enoch</jLink> and grandfather of <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H5146' clickHandler>Noah</jLink> dies at age 969

AM 1656: <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H5146' clickHandler>Noah</jLink> his wife <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H8035' clickHandler>Shem</jLink> <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H2526G' clickHandler>Ham</jLink> <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H3315' clickHandler>Japheth</jLink> and their wives enter the ark as God commanded
AM 1656: The flood begins on the seventeenth day of the second month of <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H5146' clickHandler>Noah</jLink>'s six hundredth year
AM 1656: The waters prevail on earth for 150 days destroying pre-flood civilization
AM 1656: The flood ends and God's rainbow after <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H5146' clickHandler>Noah</jLink>'s sacrifice demonstrates new covenant

ChronologyEntries.desc: <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H0775' clickHandler>Arphaxad</jLink>, lives 438 or 565 yrs
ChronologyEntries.article: AM 1658:  <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H0775' clickHandler>Arphaxad</jLink> was born in Anno Mundi 1658, exactly two years after the great flood, as the son of <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H8035' clickHandler>Shem</jLink> and one of the first post-diluvian patriarchs. <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H0775' clickHandler>Arphaxad</jLink> lived either 438 or 565 years, with this variation reflecting differences between ancient manuscript traditions such as the Masoretic Text and the Septuagint (Gen.10:22-24; 11:10-13). His birth marks the beginning of the genealogical line that would lead from <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H5146' clickHandler>Noah</jLink>'s family through <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H8035' clickHandler>Shem</jLink> to <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H0085' clickHandler>Abraham</jLink>, making him a crucial link in the covenant lineage that God would use to bless all nations. <jPara></jPara> As a key figure in the Table of Nations (Gen.10) and the genealogy leading to <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H0085' clickHandler>Abraham</jLink> (Gen.11), <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H0775' clickHandler>Arphaxad</jLink> represents the continuation of God's purposes through the Semitic line after the flood's destruction of the antediluvian world. His birth two years after the flood suggests the time needed for <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H5146' clickHandler>Noah</jLink>'s family to establish themselves in the post-flood world. Through <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H0775' clickHandler>Arphaxad</jLink>'s descendants, including <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H7974' clickHandler>Shelah</jLink>, <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H5677G' clickHandler>Eber</jLink>, <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H6389' clickHandler>Peleg</jLink>, and eventually <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H8646G' clickHandler>Terah</jLink> and <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H0085' clickHandler>Abraham</jLink>, the biblical narrative establishes the genealogical foundation for the Hebrew people and God's covenant promises to <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H0085' clickHandler>Abraham</jLink>'s posterity.
events: AM 1658: <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H0775' clickHandler>Arphaxad</jLink> is born to <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H8035' clickHandler>Shem</jLink> as first post-diluvian patriarch leading to <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H0085' clickHandler>Abraham</jLink>

ChronologyEntries.desc: <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H7974' clickHandler>Salah</jLink>, lives 433 or 460 yrs
ChronologyEntries.article: AM 1693:  <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H7974' clickHandler>Salah</jLink> (also spelled <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H7974' clickHandler>Shelah</jLink>) was born in Anno Mundi 1693 as the son of <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H0775' clickHandler>Arphaxad</jLink> and lived either 433 or 460 years according to different manuscript traditions (Gen.10:24; 11:12-15). His birth occurred 37 years after the flood, continuing the crucial genealogical line from <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H8035' clickHandler>Shem</jLink> through <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H0775' clickHandler>Arphaxad</jLink> that would eventually lead to <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H0085' clickHandler>Abraham</jLink> and the Hebrew nation. As a third-generation post-flood patriarch, <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H7974' clickHandler>Salah</jLink> represents the gradual establishment of stable human civilization following the catastrophic judgment that had reset human history. <jPara></jPara> <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H7974' clickHandler>Salah</jLink>'s primary significance lies in his role as an essential genealogical link between the immediate post-flood generation and the later patriarchs who would carry God's covenant promises. His inclusion in both the ethnographic table of Gen.10 and the focused genealogy of Gen.11 underscores his importance in biblical chronology as a preserver of the Semitic line. Through his son <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H5677G' clickHandler>Eber</jLink>, <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H7974' clickHandler>Salah</jLink>'s lineage would continue the unbroken chain of descent that validates the Hebrew people's identity as inheritors of God's promises to <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H5146' clickHandler>Noah</jLink> and his descendants, demonstrating the faithfulness of divine providence in preserving the covenant line through successive generations.
events: AM 1693: <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H7974' clickHandler>Salah</jLink> is born to <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H0775' clickHandler>Arphaxad</jLink> continuing genealogical line toward <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H0085' clickHandler>Abraham</jLink> and Hebrew nation
AM 1693: <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H0775' clickHandler>Arphaxad</jLink> becomes father of <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H7974' clickHandler>Salah</jLink> per Genesis 10:24 and 11:12

ChronologyEntries.article: AM 1723:  <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H5677G' clickHandler>Eber</jLink> was born in Anno Mundi 1723 as the son of <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H7974' clickHandler>Salah</jLink> and lived 464 years (Gen.10:21-25; 11:14-17). His name holds special significance in biblical tradition as it is etymologically connected to the term "Hebrew" (<jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H5681' clickHandler>Ibri</jLink>), making him the probable eponymous ancestor of the Hebrew people. <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H5677G' clickHandler>Eber</jLink>'s birth occurred 67 years after the flood during the early post-diluvian period when <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H5146' clickHandler>Noah</jLink>'s descendants were spreading across the earth and establishing the foundations of human civilization that would lead to the events at Babel. <jPara></jPara> <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H5677G' clickHandler>Eber</jLink> represents a crucial branching point in post-flood genealogy, as his descendants included both <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H6389' clickHandler>Peleg</jLink> (through whom the line continued to <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H0085' clickHandler>Abraham</jLink>) and <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H3355' clickHandler>Joktan</jLink> (ancestor of various <jLink data-type='L' data-strong='H6152B' clickHandler>Arabian</jLink> tribes mentioned in Gen.10:26-30). The biblical text notes that "in his days was the earth divided" (Gen.10:25), which traditionally refers to the linguistic division at Babel. Through <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H6389' clickHandler>Peleg</jLink>'s line, <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H5677G' clickHandler>Eber</jLink>'s legacy extends directly to <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H0085' clickHandler>Abraham</jLink>, <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H3327' clickHandler>Isaac</jLink>, <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='G2384G' clickHandler>Jacob</jLink>, and the nation of Israel, making him a foundational figure in Hebrew identity and the continuation of God's covenant promises through the Semitic peoples.
events: AM 1723: <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H5677G' clickHandler>Eber</jLink> is born to <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H7974' clickHandler>Salah</jLink> as probable ancestor of Hebrew people

AM 1723: <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H7974' clickHandler>Salah</jLink> becomes father of <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H5677G' clickHandler>Eber</jLink> continuing Semitic line from <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H5146' clickHandler>Noah</jLink> through <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H8035' clickHandler>Shem</jLink> <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H0775' clickHandler>Arphaxad</jLink> toward <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H0085' clickHandler>Abraham</jLink>

ChronologyEntries.desc: <jChronDurationLink style='color:black'>▼</jChronDurationLink><jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H6389' clickHandler>Peleg</jLink>, lives 239 or 339 yrs. Babel.
ChronologyEntries.article: AM 1757:  <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H6389' clickHandler>Peleg</jLink> was born in Anno Mundi 1757 as the son of <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H5677G' clickHandler>Eber</jLink> and lived either 239 or 339 years, according to different manuscript traditions (Gen.10:25; 11:16-19). His name holds profound chronological significance because "in his days the earth was divided" (Gen.10:25), a phrase that has generated considerable scholarly discussion regarding its precise meaning. Traditionally this refers to the division to the Tower of Babel event, which probably occurred in the same year, suggesting that <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H6389' clickHandler>Peleg</jLink>'s birth coincided with this linguistic and geographical dispersion. Alternative scholarly interpretations propose that the "division" refers to territorial allocation among <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H5146' clickHandler>Noah</jLink>'s descendants, though the chronological alignment with Babel strongly supports the linguistic division theory. <jPara></jPara> The Tower of Babel event represented one of the most significant interventions in human history following the great flood. Everyone in the plain of <jLink data-type='L' data-strong='H8152' clickHandler>Shinar</jLink> (likely in <jLink data-type='L' data-strong='H0763G' clickHandler>Mesopotamia</jLink>), spoke a single language. They they decided to build a city and tower "with its top in the heavens" to make a name for themselves and prevent their scattering across the earth. This construction project likely resembled the ziggurats of ancient <jLink data-type='L' data-strong='H0763G' clickHandler>Mesopotamia</jLink> such as the famous Etemenanki in <jLink data-type='L' data-strong='H0894' clickHandler>Babylon</jLink>, which was indeed constructed as connection to the divine realms. God confused their language so they could no longer understand one another and scattered them across the face of the earth, giving the place the name "Babel" because there the Lord "confused" (Hebrew: balal) their language.
events: AM 1757: <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H6389' clickHandler>Peleg</jLink> is born to <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H5677G' clickHandler>Eber</jLink> marking division of the earth
AM 1757: Humanity in <jLink data-type='L' data-strong='H8152' clickHandler>Shinar</jLink> builds city and tower to heaven creating Babel where Lord confused language
AM 1757: God confuses language at Babel and scatters humanity from <jLink data-type='L' data-strong='H8152' clickHandler>Shinar</jLink> across earth

ChronologyEntries.desc: <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H7466' clickHandler>Reu</jLink>, lives 239 or 339 yrs
ChronologyEntries.article: AM 1787:  <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H7466' clickHandler>Reu</jLink> was born in Anno Mundi 1787 as the son of <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H6389' clickHandler>Peleg</jLink> and lived either 239 or 339 years according to the manuscript variations (Gen.11:18-21). His birth occurred thirty years after the Tower of Babel event and his father <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H6389' clickHandler>Peleg</jLink>'s birth, positioning him in the immediate post-Babel generation when humanity was establishing new settlements and developing distinct cultural identities following the great linguistic dispersion. <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H7466' clickHandler>Reu</jLink>'s lifespan, whether calculated at 239 or 339 years, continued the pattern of declining human longevity that characterized the post-flood era, representing a significant reduction from the nearly thousand-year lifespans of the antediluvian patriarchs. <jPara></jPara> <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H7466' clickHandler>Reu</jLink>'s primary significance lies in his role as an essential genealogical link in the covenant lineage from <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H5146' clickHandler>Noah</jLink> through <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H8035' clickHandler>Shem</jLink> to <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H0085' clickHandler>Abraham</jLink>, serving as the great-great-great-grandfather of the patriarch who would receive God's promises regarding the land of <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H3667G' clickHandler>Canaan</jLink> and a great nation. His position in the genealogy demonstrates the continuity of God's purposes through successive generations, even during the period of cultural fragmentation and geographical dispersion that followed Babel. Through his son <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H8286' clickHandler>Serug</jLink>, <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H7466' clickHandler>Reu</jLink>'s lineage maintained the unbroken chain of descent that would culminate in <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H0085' clickHandler>Abraham</jLink>'s call and the establishment of the Hebrew people as God's chosen nation.
events: AM 1787: <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H7466' clickHandler>Reu</jLink> is born to <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H6389' clickHandler>Peleg</jLink> continuing genealogical line from <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H5146' clickHandler>Noah</jLink> through <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H8035' clickHandler>Shem</jLink> toward <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H0085' clickHandler>Abraham</jLink>
AM 1787: <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H6389' clickHandler>Peleg</jLink> becomes father of <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H7466' clickHandler>Reu</jLink> at age 30 in post-Babel generation

ChronologyEntries.desc: <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H8286' clickHandler>Serug</jLink>, lives 230 or 330 yrs
ChronologyEntries.article: AM 1819:  <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H8286' clickHandler>Serug</jLink> was born in Anno Mundi 1819 as the son of <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H7466' clickHandler>Reu</jLink> and lived either 230 or 330 years (Gen.11:20-23), with the variation reflecting different ancient textual traditions. His birth occurred 62 years after the Tower of Babel event, placing him firmly in the post-dispersion era when the scattered descendants of <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H5146' clickHandler>Noah</jLink> were establishing distinct tribal and national identities across the ancient world. <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H8286' clickHandler>Serug</jLink>'s lifespan represents a further decline in patriarchal longevity compared to his predecessors, continuing the trend toward shorter lifespans that began after the flood and accelerated following the linguistic confusion at Babel. <jPara></jPara> As the great-grandfather of <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H0085' clickHandler>Abraham</jLink>, <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H8286' clickHandler>Serug</jLink> occupies a crucial position in biblical genealogy, serving as one of the final links in the pre-Abrahamic lineage through which God would fulfill His covenant promises. His role in maintaining the Semitic line from <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H5146' clickHandler>Noah</jLink> to <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H0085' clickHandler>Abraham</jLink> underscores the theological importance of genealogical continuity in biblical narrative, demonstrating how God preserved the chosen family line through generations of cultural change and geographical dispersion. Through his son <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H5152G' clickHandler>Nahor</jLink> and grandson <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H8646G' clickHandler>Terah</jLink>, <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H8286' clickHandler>Serug</jLink>'s lineage would produce <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H0085' clickHandler>Abraham</jLink>, making him an ancestor of the Hebrew nation and ultimately of <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='G2424G' clickHandler>Jesus</jLink> Christ according to the genealogies preserved in both the Old and New Testaments.
events: AM 1819: <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H8286' clickHandler>Serug</jLink> is born to <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H7466' clickHandler>Reu</jLink> continuing genealogical line from <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H5146' clickHandler>Noah</jLink> through <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H8035' clickHandler>Shem</jLink> toward <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H0085' clickHandler>Abraham</jLink>
AM 1819: <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H7466' clickHandler>Reu</jLink> becomes father of <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H8286' clickHandler>Serug</jLink> in post-dispersion era

ChronologyEntries.desc: <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H5152G' clickHandler>Nahor</jLink>, lives 148 or 304 yrs
ChronologyEntries.article: AM 1849:  <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H5152G' clickHandler>Nahor</jLink> was born in Anno Mundi 1849 as the son of <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H8286' clickHandler>Serug</jLink> and lived either 148 or 304 years according to different ancient manuscript traditions (Gen.11:22-25). The significant variation in his recorded lifespan reflects the complex textual history of biblical genealogies, with the Masoretic Text recording 148 years while the Septuagint tradition preserves 304 years, likely reflecting different scribal practices and chronological systems used by ancient translators and copyists. As the father of <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H8646G' clickHandler>Terah</jLink> and grandfather of <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H0085' clickHandler>Abraham</jLink>, <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H5152G' clickHandler>Nahor</jLink> occupies a crucial position in the genealogical chain leading from <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H5146' clickHandler>Noah</jLink>'s son <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H8035' clickHandler>Shem</jLink> to the patriarch who would receive God's covenant promises. <jPara></jPara> <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H5152G' clickHandler>Nahor</jLink>'s birth occurred during the post-Babel period when humanity was establishing new settlements and developing distinct cultural identities following the great linguistic dispersion that had occurred 92 years earlier. His role as a direct ancestor of <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H0085' clickHandler>Abraham</jLink> makes him essential to the preservation of the Semitic line through which God's covenant purposes would be fulfilled, demonstrating the continuity of divine providence even during the era of reduced human longevity that characterized the post-flood world. The textual variations in his lifespan represent broader scholarly discussions about the relationship between the Hebrew Masoretic tradition and the Greek Septuagint, particularly regarding the intentional or unintentional alterations that may have occurred during the translation and transmission process.
events: AM 1849: <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H5152G' clickHandler>Nahor</jLink> is born to <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H8286' clickHandler>Serug</jLink> continuing genealogical line from <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H5146' clickHandler>Noah</jLink> through <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H8035' clickHandler>Shem</jLink> toward <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H0085' clickHandler>Abraham</jLink>

AM 1849: <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H8286' clickHandler>Serug</jLink> becomes father of <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H5152G' clickHandler>Nahor</jLink> as grandfather of <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H0085' clickHandler>Abraham</jLink>

ChronologyEntries.desc: <jChronDurationLink style='color:black'>▼</jChronDurationLink><jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H8646G' clickHandler>Terah</jLink>, lives 205, 275 or 145 yrs
ChronologyEntries.article: AM 1878:  <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H8646G' clickHandler>Terah</jLink> was born in Anno Mundi 1878 as the son of <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H5152G' clickHandler>Nahor</jLink> and lived either 205, 275, or 145 years according to the Hebrew, Greek and <jLink data-type='L' data-strong='H8111' clickHandler>Samaritan</jLink> traditions (Gen.11:24-32). As the father of three sons—<jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H0085' clickHandler>Abram</jLink> (later <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H0085' clickHandler>Abraham</jLink>), <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H5152G' clickHandler>Nahor</jLink>, and <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H2039G' clickHandler>Haran</jLink>—<jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H8646G' clickHandler>Terah</jLink> represents the immediate pre-Abrahamic generation and plays a crucial role in the transition from the post-Babel world to the era of the patriarchal covenants. <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H8646G' clickHandler>Terah</jLink> and his ancestors "served other gods," indicating that he participated in the polytheistic religious practices common in <jLink data-type='L' data-strong='H0763G' clickHandler>Mesopotamia</jLink>, which provides important context for understanding <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H0085' clickHandler>Abraham</jLink>'s later call to follow the one true God (Jos.24:2). <jPara></jPara> <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H8646G' clickHandler>Terah</jLink>'s significance extends beyond his genealogical role to include his migration from <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H0218A' clickHandler>Ur</jLink> of the <jLink data-type='L' data-strong='H3778' clickHandler>Chaldeans</jLink> toward the land of <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H3667G' clickHandler>Canaan</jLink>, though he settled in <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H2039G' clickHandler>Haran</jLink> instead of completing the journey. This migration (Gen.11:31) established the family in <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H2039G' clickHandler>Haran</jLink>, a center of moon-god worship similar to <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H0218A' clickHandler>Ur</jLink>, from which <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H0085' clickHandler>Abraham</jLink> would later receive his divine call to continue to the promised land. His death in AM 2083 marked the end of an era and coincided with <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H0085' clickHandler>Abraham</jLink>'s departure for <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H3667G' clickHandler>Canaan</jLink>, symbolically representing the transition from the old polytheistic world to the new covenant relationship with the God of Israel.
events: AM 1878: <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H8646G' clickHandler>Terah</jLink> is born to <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H5152G' clickHandler>Nahor</jLink>

ChronologyEntries.article: AM 1948:  <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H2039G' clickHandler>Haran</jLink> was born in Anno Mundi 1948 as the son of <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H8646G' clickHandler>Terah</jLink> and brother of <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H0085' clickHandler>Abram</jLink> and <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H5152G' clickHandler>Nahor</jLink>, according to the genealogical record (Gen.11:26; 50:13). His birth represents the completion of <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H8646G' clickHandler>Terah</jLink>'s family unit and establishes him as the father of <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H3876G' clickHandler>Lot</jLink>, who would become a significant figure in the patriarchal narratives following <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H2039G' clickHandler>Haran</jLink>'s premature death. The unusual circumstance of <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H2039G' clickHandler>Haran</jLink> dying before his father <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H8646G' clickHandler>Terah</jLink> created the family dynamic whereby his son <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H3876G' clickHandler>Lot</jLink> was raised by his uncle <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H0085' clickHandler>Abram</jLink>, leading to <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H3876G' clickHandler>Lot</jLink>'s eventual accompaniment of <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H0085' clickHandler>Abraham</jLink> on the journey from <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H0218A' clickHandler>Ur</jLink> to <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H3667G' clickHandler>Canaan</jLink> and his subsequent involvement in the destruction of <jLink data-type='L' data-strong='H5467' clickHandler>Sodom</jLink> and <jLink data-type='L' data-strong='H6017' clickHandler>Gomorrah</jLink>. <jPara></jPara> <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H2039G' clickHandler>Haran</jLink>'s early death, which occurred while his father <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H8646G' clickHandler>Terah</jLink> was still living, represents an anomaly in the biblical genealogical records and had profound narrative consequences for the developing patriarchal story. Through his son <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H3876G' clickHandler>Lot</jLink>, <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H2039G' clickHandler>Haran</jLink>'s lineage would continue to play important roles in biblical history, including the eventual origins of the <jLink data-type='L' data-strong='H4124G' clickHandler>Moabite</jLink> and <jLink data-type='L' data-strong='H5983' clickHandler>Ammonite</jLink> nations through <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H3876G' clickHandler>Lot</jLink>'s daughters following the destruction of the cities of the plain.
events: AM 1948: <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H2039G' clickHandler>Haran</jLink> is born to <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H8646G' clickHandler>Terah</jLink> as brother of <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H0085' clickHandler>Abram</jLink> and <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H5152G' clickHandler>Nahor</jLink>

AM 1948: <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H8646G' clickHandler>Terah</jLink> becomes father of <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H2039G' clickHandler>Haran</jLink> completing family with sons <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H0085' clickHandler>Abram</jLink> <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H5152G' clickHandler>Nahor</jLink> and <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H2039G' clickHandler>Haran</jLink>
AM 1948: <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H8646G' clickHandler>Terah</jLink>'s family completed with third son <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H2039G' clickHandler>Haran</jLink>

ChronologyEntries.article: AM 1996:  <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H6389' clickHandler>Peleg</jLink> died in Anno Mundi 1996 after living either 239 or 339 years, according to the manuscript variations (Gen.11:19). His death marked the end of a generation directly associated with the division of the earth: "in his days the earth was divided" (Gen.10:25), commonly interpreted as referring to the linguistic and geographical dispersion that occurred at the Tower of Babel in AM 1757. <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H6389' clickHandler>Peleg</jLink>'s passing occurred precisely ten years before <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H5146' clickHandler>Noah</jLink>'s death in AM 2006 and twelve years before <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H0085' clickHandler>Abraham</jLink>'s birth in AM 2008, positioning him at a crucial chronological transition point between the immediate post-flood patriarchs and the emergence of the Abrahamic covenant. <jPara></jPara> The timing of <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H6389' clickHandler>Peleg</jLink>'s death represents the closing of an era that had witnessed both the great flood and the subsequent scattering of humanity at Babel, making him one of the last links to these foundational events in biblical history. His significantly shorter lifespan compared to earlier patriarchs continued the pattern of declining human longevity that had begun after the flood and accelerated following the Babel dispersion, reflecting the increasing effects of divine judgment on human mortality. Through his genealogical line extending to <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H0085' clickHandler>Abraham</jLink>, <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H6389' clickHandler>Peleg</jLink>'s death cleared the way for the next phase of biblical history, in which God would call <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H0085' clickHandler>Abraham</jLink> to become the father of a chosen nation and the recipient of covenant promises that would reshape the relationship between God and humanity.
events: AM 1996: <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H6389' clickHandler>Peleg</jLink> died at age 239 or 339 ending his role as patriarch from <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H5146' clickHandler>Noah</jLink> to <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H0085' clickHandler>Abraham</jLink>

ChronologyEntries.article: AM 1997:  <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H5152G' clickHandler>Nahor</jLink> died in Anno Mundi 1997 after living 148 years or 304 years in the Greek traditions (Gen.11:25). As the father of <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H8646G' clickHandler>Terah</jLink> and grandfather of <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H0085' clickHandler>Abraham</jLink>, <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H5152G' clickHandler>Nahor</jLink>'s death marked a crucial generational transition in the genealogical line leading from <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H5146' clickHandler>Noah</jLink>'s son <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H8035' clickHandler>Shem</jLink> to the patriarch who would receive God's covenant promises. His passing occurred just nine years before <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H5146' clickHandler>Noah</jLink>'s death and eleven years before <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H0085' clickHandler>Abraham</jLink>'s birth, positioning his death at the intersection between the post-flood patriarchal era and the emergence of the Abrahamic covenant period. <jPara></jPara> The significant variation in <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H5152G' clickHandler>Nahor</jLink>'s recorded lifespan—ranging from 148 to 304 years depending on whether one follows the Masoretic Text or Septuagint tradition—reflects the ongoing textual challenges found throughout the post-Babel genealogies. His death represented the end of the seventh generation from <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H5146' clickHandler>Noah</jLink> through <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H8035' clickHandler>Shem</jLink>, completing his role in preserving the Semitic lineage through which God's covenant purposes would be fulfilled. Through his son <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H8646G' clickHandler>Terah</jLink>, who lived in the polytheistic environment of <jLink data-type='L' data-strong='H0763G' clickHandler>Mesopotamia</jLink>, <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H5152G' clickHandler>Nahor</jLink>'s legacy continued to the generation that would witness <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H0085' clickHandler>Abraham</jLink>'s revolutionary call to follow the one true God, making his death a symbolic conclusion to an era before the establishment of monotheistic covenant faith.
events: AM 1997: <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H5152G' clickHandler>Nahor</jLink> died at age 148 (Masoretic Text) or 304 (Septuagint) as father of <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H8646G' clickHandler>Terah</jLink> and grandfather of <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H0085' clickHandler>Abraham</jLink>
