ChronologyEntries.article: AM 2006:  <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H5146' clickHandler>Noah</jLink> died in Anno Mundi 2006 after living 950 years (Gen.9:28-29), concluding the most significant life in post-diluvian biblical history. His death occurred exactly 350 years after the great flood, during which time he had witnessed the repopulation through his three sons—<jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H8035' clickHandler>Shem</jLink>, <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H2526G' clickHandler>Ham</jLink>, and <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H3315' clickHandler>Japheth</jLink>—and the establishment of God's covenant promises. <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H5146' clickHandler>Noah</jLink>'s passing came just two years before <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H0085' clickHandler>Abraham</jLink>'s birth, creating a remarkable chronological bridge between the flood narrative and the patriarchal period, with <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H5146' clickHandler>Noah</jLink> potentially serving as a living repository of pre-flood knowledge and divine revelation for the early post-flood generations. <jPara></jPara> The timing of <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H5146' clickHandler>Noah</jLink>'s death holds particular significance as it occurred during the lifetime of several key figures who would shape subsequent biblical history, including his son <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H8035' clickHandler>Shem</jLink>, who lived 600 years and would have overlapped with <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H0085' clickHandler>Abraham</jLink> for many centuries. <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H5146' clickHandler>Noah</jLink>'s 950-year lifespan made him one of the longest-lived humans recorded in Scripture, exceeded only by the antediluvian patriarch <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H4968' clickHandler>Methuselah</jLink>, and his death marked the end of direct human connection to the catastrophic judgment that had reset human civilization. His legacy continued through the <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H5270' clickHandler>Noahic</jLink> Covenant, which established the rainbow as an eternal sign of God's promise never again to destroy them by flood, and through his role as the second father of humanity, from whom all subsequent nations descended according to the Table of Nations (Gen.10).
events: AM 2006: <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H5146' clickHandler>Noah</jLink> died at age 950 concluding the most significant post-diluvian life

ChronologyEntries.article: AM 2008:  <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H0085' clickHandler>Abraham</jLink> was born in Anno Mundi 2008 and lived 175 years, according to the chronological framework (Gen.11:26; 50:13). His birth occurred just two years after <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H5146' clickHandler>Noah</jLink>'s death, creating a remarkable historical continuity whereby knowledge of the great flood and God's covenant with <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H5146' clickHandler>Noah</jLink> could have been transmitted directly through overlapping generations, particularly through <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H5146' clickHandler>Noah</jLink>'s son <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H8035' clickHandler>Shem</jLink>, who lived 600 years and would have been alive during <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H0085' clickHandler>Abraham</jLink>'s early centuries. <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H0085' clickHandler>Abraham</jLink>'s birth marked the beginning of the patriarchal era and the transition from the post-Babel period of scattered nations to God's specific calling of one man through whom all nations would be blessed. <jPara></jPara> Born into the family of <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H8646G' clickHandler>Terah</jLink> in <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H0218A' clickHandler>Ur</jLink> of the <jLink data-type='L' data-strong='H3778' clickHandler>Chaldeans</jLink>, <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H0085' clickHandler>Abraham</jLink> (originally named <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H0085' clickHandler>Abram</jLink>) grew up in a polytheistic environment where his ancestors "served other gods," (Jos.24:2), making his later monotheistic faith all the more remarkable. His 175-year lifespan would encompass his migration from <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H0218A' clickHandler>Ur</jLink> to <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H2039G' clickHandler>Haran</jLink> and eventually to <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H3667G' clickHandler>Canaan</jLink>, his covenant relationships with God, the birth of <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H3327' clickHandler>Isaac</jLink> in his old age, and the establishment of the foundations for the Hebrew nation. The question mark accompanying his lifespan notation suggests some textual uncertainty, though 175 years is consistently recorded across manuscript traditions, and his death in AM 2183 would occur during the lifetime of his grandson <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='G2384G' clickHandler>Jacob</jLink>, ensuring the direct transmission of covenant promises through multiple generations.
events: AM 2008: <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H0085' clickHandler>Abraham</jLink> originally named <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H0085' clickHandler>Abram</jLink> was born to <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H8646G' clickHandler>Terah</jLink> in <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H0218A' clickHandler>Ur</jLink> of the <jLink data-type='L' data-strong='H3778' clickHandler>Chaldeans</jLink>

AM 2008: <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H8646G' clickHandler>Terah</jLink> became father of <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H0085' clickHandler>Abraham</jLink> continuing the genealogical line from <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H5146' clickHandler>Noah</jLink> through <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H8035' clickHandler>Shem</jLink>

ChronologyEntries.article: AM 2018:  <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H8283' clickHandler>Sarah</jLink> was born in Anno Mundi 2018, ten years after <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H0085' clickHandler>Abraham</jLink>'s birth (Gen.17:17) where her age is specifically mentioned in relation to the promise of <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H3327' clickHandler>Isaac</jLink>'s birth. Her birth positioned her as <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H0085' clickHandler>Abraham</jLink>'s contemporary and eventual wife, though the biblical narrative also indicates that she was his half-sister, sharing the same father (<jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H8646G' clickHandler>Terah</jLink>) but having a different mother (Gen.20:12) during <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H0085' clickHandler>Abraham</jLink>'s encounter with <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H0040G' clickHandler>Abimelech</jLink>. <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H8283' clickHandler>Sarah</jLink>'s birth occurred during the early post-<jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H5270' clickHandler>Noahic</jLink> period when the descendants of the flood survivors were establishing new civilizations and developing distinct cultural identities following the linguistic dispersion at Babel, which had taken place 261 years earlier. <jPara></jPara> <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H8283' clickHandler>Sarah</jLink>'s significance extends far beyond her role as <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H0085' clickHandler>Abraham</jLink>'s wife to encompass her crucial position in the covenant narrative as the mother of <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H3327' clickHandler>Isaac</jLink>, the son of promise through whom God's covenant with <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H0085' clickHandler>Abraham</jLink> would continue. Her initially barren condition, lasting well into her old age, created the dramatic tension that highlighted the miraculous nature of <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H3327' clickHandler>Isaac</jLink>'s birth when she was 90 years old, demonstrating God's power to fulfill His promises despite seemingly impossible circumstances. Through her son <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H3327' clickHandler>Isaac</jLink> and her grandson <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='G2384G' clickHandler>Jacob</jLink> (later renamed Israel), <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H8283' clickHandler>Sarah</jLink> became the matriarch of the Hebrew nation, making her birth in AM 2018 a foundational moment in the establishment of God's chosen people and the continuation of the covenant line that would eventually produce the Messiah.
events: AM 2018: <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H8283' clickHandler>Sarah</jLink> was born to <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H8646G' clickHandler>Terah</jLink> ten years after <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H0085' clickHandler>Abraham</jLink> as his contemporary and eventual wife

AM 2018: <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H8646G' clickHandler>Terah</jLink> became father of <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H8283' clickHandler>Sarah</jLink> establishing her as <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H0085' clickHandler>Abraham</jLink>'s half-sister by the same father

ChronologyEntries.article: AM 2026:  <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H7466' clickHandler>Reu</jLink> died in Anno Mundi 2026 after living 239 years, or 339 years in the Greek tradition (Gen.11:20-21). As the son of <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H6389' clickHandler>Peleg</jLink> and father of <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H8286' clickHandler>Serug</jLink>, <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H7466' clickHandler>Reu</jLink> represented the eighth generation from <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H5146' clickHandler>Noah</jLink> through <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H8035' clickHandler>Shem</jLink> and served as a crucial link in the genealogical chain leading from the post-flood patriarchs to <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H0085' clickHandler>Abraham</jLink>. His birth in AM 1787 had occurred thirty years after the Tower of Babel event, positioning him firmly in the post-dispersion era when humanity was establishing distinct cultural and linguistic identities following the great confusion of languages. <jPara></jPara> <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H7466' clickHandler>Reu</jLink>'s death marked a significant generational transition in the declining pattern of patriarchal longevity that characterized the post-Babel period. His passing occurred eighteen years after <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H0085' clickHandler>Abraham</jLink>'s birth in AM 2008, ensuring that <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H0085' clickHandler>Abraham</jLink> could have received direct transmission of post-flood knowledge and family history through his great-great-grandfather, thereby maintaining the continuity of covenant promises and divine revelation through successive generations leading to the establishment of the Hebrew nation.
events: AM 2026: <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H7466' clickHandler>Reu</jLink> died at age 239 (Hebrew tradition) or 339 (Greek tradition) as son of <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H6389' clickHandler>Peleg</jLink> and father of <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H8286' clickHandler>Serug</jLink>

ChronologyEntries.article: AM 2049:  <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H8286' clickHandler>Serug</jLink> died in Anno Mundi 2049 after living 230 years, or 330 years in the Greek tradition (Gen.11:22-23). As the son of <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H7466' clickHandler>Reu</jLink> and father of <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H5152G' clickHandler>Nahor</jLink>, <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H8286' clickHandler>Serug</jLink> occupied a crucial position in the biblical genealogy as the great-grandfather of <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H0085' clickHandler>Abraham</jLink>, serving as one of the final links in the pre-Abrahamic lineage through which God would fulfill His covenant promises. His birth in AM 1819 had occurred during the post-Babel period when the scattered descendants of <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H5146' clickHandler>Noah</jLink> were developing distinct tribal and national identities across the ancient world, and his lifespan represented a further decline in patriarchal longevity compared to his predecessors. <jPara></jPara> <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H8286' clickHandler>Serug</jLink>'s death occurred forty-one years after <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H0085' clickHandler>Abraham</jLink>'s birth and thirty-one years after <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H8283' clickHandler>Sarah</jLink>'s birth, positioning him as a potential source of family history and genealogical knowledge for the emerging patriarchal generation. Through his son <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H5152G' clickHandler>Nahor</jLink> and grandson <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H8646G' clickHandler>Terah</jLink>, <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H8286' clickHandler>Serug</jLink>'s lineage would produce <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H0085' clickHandler>Abraham</jLink>, making him an ancestor of the Hebrew nation and ultimately of the Messianic line according to both Old and New Testament genealogies. His role in maintaining the Semitic line from <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H5146' clickHandler>Noah</jLink> to <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H0085' clickHandler>Abraham</jLink> underscores the theological importance of genealogical continuity in biblical narrative, demonstrating how God preserved the chosen family line through generations of cultural change and geographical dispersion following the linguistic confusion at Babel.
events: AM 2049: <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H8286' clickHandler>Serug</jLink> died at age 230 (Hebrew tradition) or 330 (Greek tradition) as son of <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H7466' clickHandler>Reu</jLink> and father of <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H5152G' clickHandler>Nahor</jLink>

ChronologyEntries.desc: <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H8646G' clickHandler>Terah</jLink> dies. <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H0085' clickHandler>Abraham</jLink> goes to <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H3667G' clickHandler>Canaan</jLink>
ChronologyEntries.article: AM 2083:  <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H8646G' clickHandler>Terah</jLink> died in Anno Mundi 2083 which is also 2091 BC. He lived either 205, 275, or 145 years according to the Hebrew, Greek and <jLink data-type='L' data-strong='H8111' clickHandler>Samaritan</jLink> traditions (Gen.11:24-32). As the father of three sons—<jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H0085' clickHandler>Abram</jLink> (later <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H0085' clickHandler>Abraham</jLink>), <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H5152H' clickHandler>Nahor</jLink>, and <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H2039G' clickHandler>Haran</jLink>—<jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H8646G' clickHandler>Terah</jLink> represented the immediate pre-Abrahamic generation and played a crucial role in the transition from the post-Babel world to the era of the patriarchal covenants. <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H8646G' clickHandler>Terah</jLink> and his ancestors "served other gods," indicating that he participated in the polytheistic religious practices common in <jLink data-type='L' data-strong='H0763G' clickHandler>Mesopotamia</jLink>, which provides important context for understanding <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H0085' clickHandler>Abraham</jLink>'s later call to follow the one true God (Jos.24:2). His migration from <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H0218A' clickHandler>Ur</jLink> of the <jLink data-type='L' data-strong='H3778' clickHandler>Chaldeans</jLink> toward the land of <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H3667G' clickHandler>Canaan</jLink>, though he settled in <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H2039G' clickHandler>Haran</jLink> instead of completing the journey, established the family in a center of moon-god worship similar to <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H0218A' clickHandler>Ur</jLink>. <jPara></jPara> Following <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H8646G' clickHandler>Terah</jLink>'s death, <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H0085' clickHandler>Abraham</jLink> departed from <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H2039G' clickHandler>Haran</jLink> and traveled to <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H3667G' clickHandler>Canaan</jLink> in response to God's call (Gen.12:1-9) where God promised to make him a great nation and bless all families of the earth through him. <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H0085' clickHandler>Abraham</jLink>'s journey took him through the land of <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H3667G' clickHandler>Canaan</jLink> to significant locations including <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H7927G' clickHandler>Shechem</jLink>, where God appeared to him and promised to give the land to his descendants, and between <jLink data-type='L' data-strong='H1008G' clickHandler>Bethel</jLink> and <jLink data-type='L' data-strong='H5857G' clickHandler>Ai</jLink>, where he built altars to worship the Lord. This migration occurred during the Middle Bronze Age I period when <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H3667G' clickHandler>Canaan</jLink> consisted of fragmented city-states and rural settlements, providing the historical context for <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H0085' clickHandler>Abraham</jLink>'s arrival as a semi-nomadic patriarch in a land that would become central to God's covenant purposes.
events: AM 2083: <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H8646G' clickHandler>Terah</jLink> died in <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H2039G' clickHandler>Haran</jLink> at age 205, 275, or 145 as father of <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H0085' clickHandler>Abraham</jLink>, <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H5152H' clickHandler>Nahor</jLink>, and <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H2039G' clickHandler>Haran</jLink>

AM 2083: <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H0085' clickHandler>Abraham</jLink> journeyed to <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H3667G' clickHandler>Canaan</jLink> and traveled to <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H7927G' clickHandler>Shechem</jLink> in the Promised Land

AM 2083: God appeared to <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H0085' clickHandler>Abraham</jLink> at <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H7927G' clickHandler>Shechem</jLink> and promised the land to his descendants as <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H0085' clickHandler>Abraham</jLink> built an altar

AM 2083: <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H0085' clickHandler>Abraham</jLink> traveled between <jLink data-type='L' data-strong='H1008G' clickHandler>Bethel</jLink> and <jLink data-type='L' data-strong='H5857G' clickHandler>Ai</jLink> building another altar and calling on the Lord

ChronologyEntries.desc: <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H0085' clickHandler>Abraham</jLink> goes to <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H4714H' clickHandler>Egypt</jLink>
ChronologyEntries.article: 2090 BC:  <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H0085' clickHandler>Abraham</jLink> traveled to <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H4714H' clickHandler>Egypt</jLink> due to a severe famine that had afflicted the land of <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H3667G' clickHandler>Canaan</jLink> (Gen.12:10-20). This journey occurred just one year after his arrival in the promised land, demonstrating the environmental challenges that characterized the ancient Near East and necessitated temporary migrations to more stable regions like <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H4714H' clickHandler>Egypt</jLink>. The famine compelled <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H0085' clickHandler>Abraham</jLink> to seek refuge in <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H4714H' clickHandler>Egypt</jLink>, where he encountered significant challenges that tested his faith and revealed both his human weaknesses and God's protective providence. <jPara></jPara> During his sojourn in <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H4714H' clickHandler>Egypt</jLink>, <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H0085' clickHandler>Abraham</jLink> faced a complex situation involving his wife <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H8283' clickHandler>Sarah</jLink> and <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H6547G' clickHandler>Pharaoh</jLink>, in which he presented <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H8283' clickHandler>Sarah</jLink> as his sister rather than his wife, fearing for his own safety. This deception led to <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H8283' clickHandler>Sarah</jLink> being taken into <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H6547G' clickHandler>Pharaoh</jLink>'s house, but God intervened by afflicting <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H6547G' clickHandler>Pharaoh</jLink> and his household with great plagues, ultimately leading to the discovery of the truth and <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H0085' clickHandler>Abraham</jLink>'s dismissal from <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H4714H' clickHandler>Egypt</jLink> with great wealth. The historical context of this period shows <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H4714H' clickHandler>Egypt</jLink> during the First Intermediate Period (c. 2181-2055 BC), characterized by political fragmentation and decentralized authority, yet still maintaining sufficient prosperity and resources to attract migrants during times of regional famine.
events: 2090 BC: Severe famine in <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H3667G' clickHandler>Canaan</jLink> caused <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H0085' clickHandler>Abraham</jLink> to travel to <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H4714H' clickHandler>Egypt</jLink> for refuge

2090 BC: <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H0085' clickHandler>Abraham</jLink> presented <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H8283' clickHandler>Sarah</jLink> as his sister to <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H6547G' clickHandler>Pharaoh</jLink> and <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H8283' clickHandler>Sarah</jLink> was taken into <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H6547G' clickHandler>Pharaoh</jLink>'s house

2090 BC: God afflicted <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H6547G' clickHandler>Pharaoh</jLink> with plagues because of <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H8283' clickHandler>Sarah</jLink> and <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H6547G' clickHandler>Pharaoh</jLink> dismissed <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H0085' clickHandler>Abraham</jLink> with wealth after learning the truth

ChronologyEntries.desc: <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H0085' clickHandler>Abraham</jLink> leaves <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H4714H' clickHandler>Egypt</jLink>
ChronologyEntries.article: 2088 BC:  <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H0085' clickHandler>Abraham</jLink> departed from <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H4714H' clickHandler>Egypt</jLink> and returned to <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H3667G' clickHandler>Canaan</jLink> with his wife <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H8283' clickHandler>Sarah</jLink>, his nephew <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H3876G' clickHandler>Lot</jLink>, and considerable wealth acquired during their <jLink data-type='L' data-strong='H4714G' clickHandler>Egyptian</jLink> sojourn, including livestock, silver, and gold (Gen.13). His return journey took him back to the area between <jLink data-type='L' data-strong='H1008G' clickHandler>Bethel</jLink> and <jLink data-type='L' data-strong='H5857G' clickHandler>Ai</jLink>, where he had previously built an altar and called upon the name of the Lord, demonstrating his desire to restore his worship relationship with God after the challenges experienced in <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H4714H' clickHandler>Egypt</jLink>. This homecoming marked not only <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H0085' clickHandler>Abraham</jLink>'s physical return to the promised land but also his renewed commitment to the covenant relationship that God had established with him before the <jLink data-type='L' data-strong='H4714G' clickHandler>Egyptian</jLink> detour. <jPara></jPara> The prosperity that both <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H0085' clickHandler>Abraham</jLink> and <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H3876G' clickHandler>Lot</jLink> had gained in <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H4714H' clickHandler>Egypt</jLink> soon created practical difficulties, as the land could not support their combined herds and possessions, leading to strife between their respective herdsmen. To resolve this conflict peacefully and maintain family harmony, <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H0085' clickHandler>Abraham</jLink> generously offered <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H3876G' clickHandler>Lot</jLink> the first choice of territory, with <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H3876G' clickHandler>Lot</jLink> selecting the well-watered plain of the <jLink data-type='L' data-strong='H3383' clickHandler>Jordan</jLink> near <jLink data-type='L' data-strong='H5467' clickHandler>Sodom</jLink> while <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H0085' clickHandler>Abraham</jLink> remained in the land of <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H3667G' clickHandler>Canaan</jLink> proper. <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H0085' clickHandler>Abraham</jLink> received renewed divine promises regarding his inheritance of the land and countless descendants, while positioning the narrative for future developments involving <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H3876G' clickHandler>Lot</jLink>'s residence near the wicked cities of <jLink data-type='L' data-strong='H5467' clickHandler>Sodom</jLink> and <jLink data-type='L' data-strong='H6017' clickHandler>Gomorrah</jLink>, thus establishing the geographical and relational framework for subsequent biblical events.
events: 2088 BC: <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H0085' clickHandler>Abraham</jLink> <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H8283' clickHandler>Sarah</jLink> and <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H3876G' clickHandler>Lot</jLink> left <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H4714H' clickHandler>Egypt</jLink> with wealth including livestock silver and gold

2088 BC: <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H0085' clickHandler>Abraham</jLink> returned to the area between <jLink data-type='L' data-strong='H1008G' clickHandler>Bethel</jLink> and <jLink data-type='L' data-strong='H5857G' clickHandler>Ai</jLink> where he had built an altar

2088 BC: Strife arose between <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H0085' clickHandler>Abraham</jLink>'s and <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H3876G' clickHandler>Lot</jLink>'s herdsmen due to their great possessions

2088 BC: <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H0085' clickHandler>Abraham</jLink> offered <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H3876G' clickHandler>Lot</jLink> first choice of land to resolve the conflict peacefully

ChronologyEntries.article: 2082 BC:  The year 2082 BC witnessed two pivotal events in <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H0085' clickHandler>Abraham</jLink>'s life that established his role as both a military leader and recipient of divine promises. When <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H3876G' clickHandler>Lot</jLink>, <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H0085' clickHandler>Abraham</jLink>'s nephew, was captured during a regional conflict involving four <jLink data-type='L' data-strong='H0763G' clickHandler>Mesopotamian</jLink> kings who had defeated five <jLink data-type='L' data-strong='H3667A' clickHandler>Canaanite</jLink> kings near the Dead Sea, <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H0085' clickHandler>Abraham</jLink> mobilized 318 trained men from his household and successfully pursued and defeated the coalition, rescuing <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H3876G' clickHandler>Lot</jLink> along with the captured people and goods. Upon his victorious return, <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H0085' clickHandler>Abraham</jLink> encountered <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H4442' clickHandler>Melchizedek</jLink>, king of <jLink data-type='L' data-strong='H3389' clickHandler>Salem</jLink> and priest of God Most High, who blessed him and received a tithe of the recovered spoils, while <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H0085' clickHandler>Abraham</jLink> refused any reward from the king of <jLink data-type='L' data-strong='H5467' clickHandler>Sodom</jLink> to avoid being indebted to him. <jPara></jPara> Following this military triumph, God appeared to <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H0085' clickHandler>Abraham</jLink> in a vision and formalized the first covenant, addressing <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H0085' clickHandler>Abraham</jLink>'s concerns about remaining childless by promising that his own offspring would be his heir and that his descendants would be as numerous as the stars. This covenant was sealed through a ritual involving the sacrifice of specific animals, during which God revealed that <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H0085' clickHandler>Abraham</jLink>'s descendants would sojourn in a foreign land for four hundred years before being delivered with great possessions. The events of 2082 BC thus established <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H0085' clickHandler>Abraham</jLink> as both a formidable leader capable of international military intervention and the recipient of unconditional divine promises that would shape the destiny of his lineage and the broader biblical narrative.

ChronologyEntries.desc: <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H0085' clickHandler>Abraham</jLink> sleeps with <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H1904' clickHandler>Hagar</jLink>
ChronologyEntries.article: 2081 BC:  In 2081 BC, <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H0085' clickHandler>Abraham</jLink> entered into a surrogate motherhood arrangement with <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H1904' clickHandler>Hagar</jLink>, <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H8283' clickHandler>Sarah</jLink>'s <jLink data-type='L' data-strong='H4714G' clickHandler>Egyptian</jLink> maidservant (Gen.16:1-14). This decision arose from <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H8283' clickHandler>Sarah</jLink>'s prolonged infertility and her initiative to provide <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H0085' clickHandler>Abraham</jLink> with an heir through her servant, a practice that was legally recognized and socially accepted throughout the ancient Near East during this period. Such arrangements were documented in contemporary <jLink data-type='L' data-strong='H0763G' clickHandler>Mesopotamian</jLink> legal texts, including the Code of Hammurabi and Nuzi tablets, which established the rights and obligations of all parties involved, with the resulting child being considered the legitimate offspring of the primary wife rather than the surrogate mother. <jPara></jPara> The union between <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H0085' clickHandler>Abraham</jLink> and <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H1904' clickHandler>Hagar</jLink> occurred approximately one year after God's covenant promises regarding countless descendants, representing a human attempt to facilitate the divine plan rather than waiting for God's timing through <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H8283' clickHandler>Sarah</jLink>. This arrangement reflected the cultural importance of producing heirs and securing family lineage in ancient Near Eastern society, where infertility was often viewed as a crisis requiring immediate resolution. The events of 2081 BC thus demonstrate both the historical authenticity of biblical narratives within their cultural context and the tension between human initiative and divine sovereignty that would characterize the patriarchal period.
events: 2081 BC: <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H8283' clickHandler>Sarah</jLink> gave her <jLink data-type='L' data-strong='H4714G' clickHandler>Egyptian</jLink> maidservant <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H1904' clickHandler>Hagar</jLink> to <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H0085' clickHandler>Abraham</jLink>
2081 BC: <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H1904' clickHandler>Hagar</jLink> conceived and despised <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H8283' clickHandler>Sarah</jLink>
