2081 BC: <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H1904' clickHandler>Hagar</jLink> named the Lord "You are the God who sees me" and the well was called <jLink data-type='L' data-strong='H0876G' clickHandler>Beer</jLink> Lahai Roi

ChronologyEntries.article: 2080 BC:  <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H3458G' clickHandler>Ishmael</jLink> was born in 2080 BC as <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H0085' clickHandler>Abraham</jLink>'s first son through <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H1904' clickHandler>Hagar</jLink>, <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H8283' clickHandler>Sarah</jLink>'s <jLink data-type='L' data-strong='H4714G' clickHandler>Egyptian</jLink> maidservant, marking a significant moment in both biblical and Near Eastern history (Gen.16:15-16). His birth represented both a partial fulfillment and a complication of God's covenant promises to <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H0085' clickHandler>Abraham</jLink>, as it provided the long-desired heir while also creating the foundation for future family tensions that would affect subsequent biblical narratives. <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H0085' clickHandler>Abraham</jLink> was eighty-six years old at the time of <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H3458G' clickHandler>Ishmael</jLink>'s birth, and the child's name, meaning "God hears," reflected the divine response to <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H1904' clickHandler>Hagar</jLink>'s distress during her pregnancy when she fled from <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H8283' clickHandler>Sarah</jLink>'s harsh treatment. <jPara></jPara> <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H3458G' clickHandler>Ishmael</jLink>'s birth carries profound historical significance extending far beyond the immediate biblical context, as he became the ancestor of numerous nomadic tribes in the Near East and is regarded in later Jewish, Christian, and Islamic traditions as a foundational figure. In Islamic tradition particularly, <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H3458G' clickHandler>Ishmael</jLink> is revered as a prophet and considered an ancestor of the <jLink data-type='L' data-strong='H0694' clickHandler>Arab</jLink> peoples and of Muhammad, making his birth in 2080 BC a pivotal moment that would influence religious, cultural, and ethnic identities across millennia. Although God's covenant would ultimately be established through <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H3327' clickHandler>Isaac</jLink>, <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H8283' clickHandler>Sarah</jLink>'s future son, <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H3458G' clickHandler>Ishmael</jLink> nevertheless received divine blessing and the promise that he would become the father of a great nation, demonstrating God's care for all of <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H0085' clickHandler>Abraham</jLink>'s offspring while maintaining the distinct covenant line through <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H8283' clickHandler>Sarah</jLink>.
events: 2080 BC: <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H1904' clickHandler>Hagar</jLink> bore <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H0085' clickHandler>Abraham</jLink> a son
2080 BC: <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H0085' clickHandler>Abraham</jLink> named his son <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H3458G' clickHandler>Ishmael</jLink>

ChronologyEntries.article: 2078 BC:  <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H0775' clickHandler>Arphaxad</jLink> died in 2078 BC after living 438 years, or 565 years according to Greek tradition (Gen.11:13). As a crucial genealogical link between <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H5146' clickHandler>Noah</jLink> and <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H0085' clickHandler>Abraham</jLink>, <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H0775' clickHandler>Arphaxad</jLink> served as the son of <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H8035' clickHandler>Shem</jLink> and father of <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H7974' clickHandler>Salah</jLink> (<jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H7974' clickHandler>Shelah</jLink>), positioning him as an essential figure in the post-flood lineage that would eventually produce the Hebrew nation. <jPara></jPara> <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H0775' clickHandler>Arphaxad</jLink>'s death occurred just two years after <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H3458G' clickHandler>Ishmael</jLink>'s birth and four years after <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H0085' clickHandler>Abraham</jLink>'s first covenant with God, marking the passing of one of the final direct links between the immediate post-flood generation and the emerging patriarchal period. His genealogical significance as an ancestor of <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H0085' clickHandler>Abraham</jLink> underscores the continuity of God's covenant purposes through successive generations, even as human lifespans continued to decline from the extraordinary longevity characteristic of the immediate post-diluvian era. The chronological proximity of <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H0775' clickHandler>Arphaxad</jLink>'s death to the establishment of <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H0085' clickHandler>Abraham</jLink>'s covenant line suggests the providential timing by which the older genealogical framework gave way to the new covenant relationship that would define biblical history through the Hebrew patriarchs.
events: 2078 BC: <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H0775' clickHandler>Arphaxad</jLink> died after living 438 years

ChronologyEntries.desc: <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H0085' clickHandler>Abraham</jLink>'s 2nd covenant. <jLink data-type='L' data-strong='H5467' clickHandler>Sodom</jLink>
ChronologyEntries.article: 2067 BC:  The year 2067 BC marked a pivotal period in <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H0085' clickHandler>Abraham</jLink>'s life, encompassing three significant events that would shape biblical history. God appeared to <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H0085' clickHandler>Abraham</jLink> and established a second covenant (Gen.17), in which He changed <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H0085' clickHandler>Abram</jLink>'s name to <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H0085' clickHandler>Abraham</jLink>, meaning "father of many nations," and reaffirmed His promises that <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H0085' clickHandler>Abraham</jLink> would be exceedingly fruitful with nations and kings descending from him. As a perpetual sign of this everlasting covenant, God instituted circumcision for <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H0085' clickHandler>Abraham</jLink> and all his male descendants, creating a physical marker of the covenant relationship that would distinguish the Hebrew people throughout their history. <jPara></jPara> This same year witnessed the dramatic destruction of <jLink data-type='L' data-strong='H5467' clickHandler>Sodom</jLink> and <jLink data-type='L' data-strong='H6017' clickHandler>Gomorrah</jLink> (Gen.19) when God rained down burning sulfur upon these cities as divine judgment for their grave wickedness. <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H0085' clickHandler>Abraham</jLink>'s nephew <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H3876G' clickHandler>Lot</jLink> and his family were rescued by two angels, though <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H3876G' clickHandler>Lot</jLink>'s wife was transformed into a pillar of salt for disobeying the command not to look back during their escape. Additionally, <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H0085' clickHandler>Abraham</jLink>'s encounter with <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H0040G' clickHandler>Abimelech</jLink>, king of <jLink data-type='L' data-strong='H1642' clickHandler>Gerar</jLink>, demonstrated both human weakness and divine protection when <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H0085' clickHandler>Abraham</jLink> deceived the king by claiming <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H8283' clickHandler>Sarah</jLink> was his sister rather than his wife, leading to God's intervention through a warning dream that resulted in <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H8283' clickHandler>Sarah</jLink>'s return and <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H0085' clickHandler>Abraham</jLink>'s receipt of gifts and land. These events of 2067 BC illustrate the tension between divine faithfulness and human frailty that characterizes the patriarchal narratives.
events: 2067 BC: God appeared to <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H0085' clickHandler>Abram</jLink> and established a second covenant
2067 BC: God changed <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H0085' clickHandler>Abram</jLink>'s name to <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H0085' clickHandler>Abraham</jLink>
2067 BC: God changed Sarai's name to <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H8283' clickHandler>Sarah</jLink>

2067 BC: God instituted circumcision as the covenant sign and <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H0085' clickHandler>Abraham</jLink> circumcised himself <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H3458G' clickHandler>Ishmael</jLink> and all household males

2067 BC: Two angels arrived in <jLink data-type='L' data-strong='H5467' clickHandler>Sodom</jLink> and stayed with <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H3876G' clickHandler>Lot</jLink> while men of <jLink data-type='L' data-strong='H5467' clickHandler>Sodom</jLink> surrounded his house demanding the visitors

ChronologyEntries.article: 2066 BC:  <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H3327' clickHandler>Isaac</jLink> was born in 2066 BC to <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H0085' clickHandler>Abraham</jLink> and <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H8283' clickHandler>Sarah</jLink>, representing the miraculous fulfillment of God's covenant promise that <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H0085' clickHandler>Abraham</jLink> would have a son through <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H8283' clickHandler>Sarah</jLink> despite their advanced age. This birth (Gen.21) marked <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H3327' clickHandler>Isaac</jLink> as the child of promise through whom God's covenant with <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H0085' clickHandler>Abraham</jLink> would continue, establishing him as the primary heir who superseded <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H3458G' clickHandler>Ishmael</jLink> and became central to the lineage that would eventually develop into the nation of Israel. <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H3327' clickHandler>Isaac</jLink>'s significance extended far beyond his birth to encompass his role as a bridge between <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H0085' clickHandler>Abraham</jLink> and the next generation of patriarchs, as his 180-year lifespan would span crucial events in patriarchal history. <jPara></jPara> The events of <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H3327' clickHandler>Isaac</jLink>'s life (Gen.21-35), included his near-sacrifice at Mount <jLink data-type='L' data-strong='H4179' clickHandler>Moriah</jLink> when God tested <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H0085' clickHandler>Abraham</jLink>'s faith, his marriage to <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H7259' clickHandler>Rebekah</jLink>, and the birth of his twin sons <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H6215G' clickHandler>Esau</jLink> and <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='G2384G' clickHandler>Jacob</jLink>, whose rivalry would shape the future of the covenant lineage. God renewed His covenant directly with <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H3327' clickHandler>Isaac</jLink>, promising him descendants and land, thus continuing the divine promises made to <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H0085' clickHandler>Abraham</jLink> and ensuring the perpetuation of the chosen line through <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H3327' clickHandler>Isaac</jLink>'s son <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='G2384G' clickHandler>Jacob</jLink>, who would later be renamed Israel. <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H3327' clickHandler>Isaac</jLink>'s birth in 2066 BC therefore represents not merely the arrival of a long-awaited heir, but the continuation of God's redemptive plan through the patriarchal line that would culminate in the formation of the Hebrew nation.
events: 2066 BC: <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H3327' clickHandler>Isaac</jLink> was born to <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H0085' clickHandler>Abraham</jLink> and <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H8283' clickHandler>Sarah</jLink>
2066 BC: <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H0085' clickHandler>Abraham</jLink> circumcised <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H3327' clickHandler>Isaac</jLink> on the eighth day
2066 BC: <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H3327' clickHandler>Isaac</jLink> became <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H0085' clickHandler>Abraham</jLink>'s primary heir

ChronologyEntries.desc: <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H1904' clickHandler>Hagar</jLink> sent away. <jLink data-type='L' data-strong='H0884' clickHandler>Beersheba</jLink> treaty
ChronologyEntries.article: 2061 BC:  The year 2061 BC witnessed two significant events that resolved family tensions and established territorial agreements in <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H0085' clickHandler>Abraham</jLink>'s household and region. Following <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H3327' clickHandler>Isaac</jLink>'s weaning celebration, <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H8283' clickHandler>Sarah</jLink> observed <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H3458G' clickHandler>Ishmael</jLink> mocking <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H3327' clickHandler>Isaac</jLink> and demanded that <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H0085' clickHandler>Abraham</jLink> send away <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H1904' clickHandler>Hagar</jLink> and her son to prevent <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H3458G' clickHandler>Ishmael</jLink> from sharing in <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H3327' clickHandler>Isaac</jLink>'s inheritance (Gen.21:8-21). Though distressed by this request, <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H0085' clickHandler>Abraham</jLink> complied after God assured him that <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H3458G' clickHandler>Ishmael</jLink> would also become a great nation because he was <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H0085' clickHandler>Abraham</jLink>'s offspring, and <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H0085' clickHandler>Abraham</jLink> provided <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H1904' clickHandler>Hagar</jLink> and <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H3458G' clickHandler>Ishmael</jLink> with bread and water before sending them into the wilderness. When their provisions were exhausted and <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H1904' clickHandler>Hagar</jLink> feared for her son's life, God heard <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H3458G' clickHandler>Ishmael</jLink>'s cries and provided a well of water, renewing His promise that <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H3458G' clickHandler>Ishmael</jLink> would become the father of a great nation and grow up in the wilderness of <jLink data-type='L' data-strong='H6290G' clickHandler>Paran</jLink>. <jPara></jPara> Later in the same year, <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H0085' clickHandler>Abraham</jLink> entered into the <jLink data-type='L' data-strong='H0884' clickHandler>Beersheba</jLink> treaty with <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H0040G' clickHandler>Abimelech</jLink>, king of <jLink data-type='L' data-strong='H1642' clickHandler>Gerar</jLink>, to resolve a dispute over water rights (Gen.21:22-34). The conflict arose when <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H0040G' clickHandler>Abimelech</jLink>'s servants seized a well that <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H0085' clickHandler>Abraham</jLink> had dug, prompting <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H0085' clickHandler>Abraham</jLink> to give <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H0040G' clickHandler>Abimelech</jLink> sheep and cattle as signs of agreement while setting aside seven ewe lambs as witnesses that he had dug the well. The place was named <jLink data-type='L' data-strong='H0884' clickHandler>Beersheba</jLink>, meaning "well of the oath" or "well of seven," to commemorate this covenant, which secured <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H0085' clickHandler>Abraham</jLink>'s rights to the well and established peaceful relations between the two leaders. These events of 2061 BC demonstrate both the providential care of God for all of <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H0085' clickHandler>Abraham</jLink>'s descendants and the practical diplomatic skills that <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H0085' clickHandler>Abraham</jLink> employed to maintain stability in the region.
events: 2061 BC: <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H3327' clickHandler>Isaac</jLink>'s weaning celebration took place

2061 BC: <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H8283' clickHandler>Sarah</jLink> observed <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H3458G' clickHandler>Ishmael</jLink> mocking <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H3327' clickHandler>Isaac</jLink> and demanded <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H0085' clickHandler>Abraham</jLink> send away <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H1904' clickHandler>Hagar</jLink> and <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H3458G' clickHandler>Ishmael</jLink>

2061 BC: <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H0085' clickHandler>Abraham</jLink> was distressed but received divine assurance provided <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H1904' clickHandler>Hagar</jLink> and <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H3458G' clickHandler>Ishmael</jLink> with supplies and they departed into the wilderness

2061 BC: God heard <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H3458G' clickHandler>Ishmael</jLink>'s cries provided water and renewed His promise about <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H3458G' clickHandler>Ishmael</jLink>
2061 BC: <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H3458G' clickHandler>Ishmael</jLink> settled in the wilderness of <jLink data-type='L' data-strong='H6290G' clickHandler>Paran</jLink>

ChronologyEntries.article: 2048 BC:  <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H7974' clickHandler>Shelah</jLink> died in 2048 BC after living 433 years, or 460 years according to Greek traditions (Gen.11:15). As the son of <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H0775' clickHandler>Arphaxad</jLink> and father of <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H5677G' clickHandler>Eber</jLink>, <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H7974' clickHandler>Shelah</jLink> represented the third generation from <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H5146' clickHandler>Noah</jLink>'s son <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H8035' clickHandler>Shem</jLink> and served as a crucial genealogical link in the post-flood lineage that would eventually lead to <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H0085' clickHandler>Abraham</jLink> and the Hebrew nation . <jPara></jPara> His death occurred during the period when the early post-diluvian patriarchs were passing away, marking another step in the gradual transition from the immediate post-flood generation to the era that would witness God's specific calling of <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H0085' clickHandler>Abraham</jLink> and the establishment of the covenant relationship with the Hebrew people.
events: 2048 BC: <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H7974' clickHandler>Shelah</jLink> died after living 433 years

ChronologyEntries.desc: <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H0085' clickHandler>Abraham</jLink> & <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H3327' clickHandler>Isaac</jLink> at Mount <jLink data-type='L' data-strong='H4179' clickHandler>Moriah</jLink>
ChronologyEntries.article: 2041 BC:  <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H0085' clickHandler>Abraham</jLink> faced the most severe test of his faith when God commanded him to take his beloved son <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H3327' clickHandler>Isaac</jLink> to the land of <jLink data-type='L' data-strong='H4179' clickHandler>Moriah</jLink> and offer him as a burnt offering on a mountain that would be divinely designated. According to Jewish traditions, this event, called "Akedah", occurred just before the death of <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H8283' clickHandler>Sarah</jLink> and perhaps caused it. In 2041, a date that is also reasonable, <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H3327' clickHandler>Isaac</jLink> would have been twenty-five years old. <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H0085' clickHandler>Abraham</jLink> demonstrated extraordinary obedience by rising early, preparing the necessary materials for sacrifice, and journeying three days to reach the appointed location, even as <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H3327' clickHandler>Isaac</jLink> innocently asked about the absence of a sacrificial lamb. <jPara></jPara> At the crucial moment when <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H0085' clickHandler>Abraham</jLink> raised the knife to slay his son, an angel of the Lord intervened, commanding him to halt the sacrifice and providing a ram caught in a nearby thicket as a substitute offering. This divine intervention established a theological principle that would resonate throughout biblical history: God's rejection of child sacrifice and His provision of acceptable alternatives. Mount <jLink data-type='L' data-strong='H4179' clickHandler>Moriah</jLink> is traditionally identified with the site of the future Temple Mount in <jLink data-type='L' data-strong='H3389' clickHandler>Jerusalem</jLink>, making this location eternally significant in Jewish, Christian, and Islamic traditions. The event serves as a profound demonstration of faith, divine provision, and foreshadowing of later sacrificial systems, while marking a decisive departure from the child sacrifice practices common among ancient Near Eastern peoples.
events: 2041 BC: God called <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H0085' clickHandler>Abraham</jLink> to sacrifice <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H3327' clickHandler>Isaac</jLink> at Mount <jLink data-type='L' data-strong='H4179' clickHandler>Moriah</jLink>
2041 BC: <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H0085' clickHandler>Abraham</jLink> returned to his young men at <jLink data-type='L' data-strong='H0884' clickHandler>Beersheba</jLink>
2041 BC: <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H0085' clickHandler>Abraham</jLink> received news about his brother <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H5152G' clickHandler>Nahor</jLink>'s family

ChronologyEntries.article: 2029 BC:  <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H8283' clickHandler>Sarah</jLink> died in 2029 BC at the remarkable age of 127 years, making her the only woman in Scripture whose age at death is specifically recorded. Her passing occurred in <jLink data-type='L' data-strong='H2275A' clickHandler>Hebron</jLink> (also called <jLink data-type='L' data-strong='H2275A' clickHandler>Kirjath</jLink> <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H0704' clickHandler>Arba</jLink>), twelve years after the Mount <jLink data-type='L' data-strong='H4179' clickHandler>Moriah</jLink> incident and three years before <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H3327' clickHandler>Isaac</jLink>'s marriage to <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H7259' clickHandler>Rebekah</jLink>, positioning her death during a transitional period in the patriarchal narrative. <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H0085' clickHandler>Abraham</jLink> mourned <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H8283' clickHandler>Sarah</jLink>'s death according to ancient Near Eastern customs, which involved formal expressions of grief and public recognition of the loss, demonstrating both his personal devotion and adherence to cultural practices of the time. <jPara></jPara> The negotiation for <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H8283' clickHandler>Sarah</jLink>'s burial site represents a pivotal moment in <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H0085' clickHandler>Abraham</jLink>'s relationship with the land of <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H3667G' clickHandler>Canaan</jLink>, as he conducted formal negotiations with the <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H2845' clickHandler>Hittites</jLink> to purchase the cave of <jLink data-type='L' data-strong='H4375' clickHandler>Machpelah</jLink> near <jLink data-type='L' data-strong='H2275A' clickHandler>Hebron</jLink>. Following established legal procedures, <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H0085' clickHandler>Abraham</jLink> publicly requested a burial site at the city gate, was offered his choice of tombs by the local leaders, but insisted on paying the full price of four hundred shekels of silver to <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H6085G' clickHandler>Ephron</jLink> the <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H2845' clickHandler>Hittite</jLink> to ensure legitimate and irrevocable ownership. This transaction, witnessed by all who entered the city gate, established the first piece of the Promised Land legally owned by <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H0085' clickHandler>Abraham</jLink> and his descendants, creating a permanent foothold in <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H3667G' clickHandler>Canaan</jLink> that would serve as the family burial ground for <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H0085' clickHandler>Abraham</jLink>, <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H3327' clickHandler>Isaac</jLink>, <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='G2384G' clickHandler>Jacob</jLink>, and their wives.
events: 2029 BC: <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H8283' clickHandler>Sarah</jLink> died at age 127 years in <jLink data-type='L' data-strong='H2275A' clickHandler>Hebron</jLink>

2029 BC: <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H0085' clickHandler>Abraham</jLink> approached the <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H2845' clickHandler>Hittites</jLink> at the city gate to purchase the cave of <jLink data-type='L' data-strong='H4375' clickHandler>Machpelah</jLink> from <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H6085G' clickHandler>Ephron</jLink> the <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H2845' clickHandler>Hittite</jLink>

ChronologyEntries.desc: <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H3327' clickHandler>Isaac</jLink> marries <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H7259' clickHandler>Rebekah</jLink>
ChronologyEntries.article: 2026 BC:  <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H3327' clickHandler>Isaac</jLink> married <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H7259' clickHandler>Rebekah</jLink> in 2026 BC following an elaborate matrimonial arrangement initiated by <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H0085' clickHandler>Abraham</jLink>, who dispatched his most trusted servant to <jLink data-type='L' data-strong='H0763G' clickHandler>Mesopotamia</jLink> to find a suitable wife for his forty-year-old son. The servant's mission, guided by specific prayer for divine direction, led him to the well outside <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H5152H' clickHandler>Nahor</jLink>'s city, where he encountered <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H7259' clickHandler>Rebekah</jLink> drawing water for her family's camels. Her kindness in offering water not only to the servant but also to his ten camels fulfilled the servant's prayer for a sign, demonstrating both her character and God's providential guidance in the selection process. <jPara></jPara> The marriage negotiation followed ancient Near Eastern customs, including the presentation of costly gifts—gold jewelry and fine clothing—to <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H7259' clickHandler>Rebekah</jLink> and her family, formal discussions with her brother <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H3837A' clickHandler>Laban</jLink> and father <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H1328A' clickHandler>Bethuel</jLink>, and ultimately <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H7259' clickHandler>Rebekah</jLink>'s personal consent to leave her homeland. This union proved strategically crucial for maintaining the covenant lineage, as <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H7259' clickHandler>Rebekah</jLink> came from <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H0085' clickHandler>Abraham</jLink>'s extended family in <jLink data-type='L' data-strong='H6307' clickHandler>Paddan</jLink> <jLink data-type='L' data-strong='H0758I' clickHandler>Aram</jLink>, preserving the bloodline and faith heritage necessary for fulfilling God's promises. When <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H3327' clickHandler>Isaac</jLink> brought <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H7259' clickHandler>Rebekah</jLink> into his deceased mother <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H8283' clickHandler>Sarah</jLink>'s tent, he found comfort after his mother's loss three years earlier, while their marriage established the foundation for the next generation of patriarchs through their future twin sons, <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H6215G' clickHandler>Esau</jLink> and <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='G2384G' clickHandler>Jacob</jLink>.
events: 2026 BC: <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H0085' clickHandler>Abraham</jLink> dispatched his most trusted servant to <jLink data-type='L' data-strong='H0763G' clickHandler>Mesopotamia</jLink>

2026 BC: <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H7259' clickHandler>Rebekah</jLink> departed <jLink data-type='L' data-strong='H6307' clickHandler>Paddan</jLink> <jLink data-type='L' data-strong='H0758I' clickHandler>Aram</jLink> with the servant
2026 BC: <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H3327' clickHandler>Isaac</jLink> married <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H7259' clickHandler>Rebekah</jLink>

ChronologyEntries.desc: <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H0085' clickHandler>Abraham</jLink> marries <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H6989' clickHandler>Keturah</jLink>
ChronologyEntries.article: 2023 BC:  <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H0085' clickHandler>Abraham</jLink> married <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H6989' clickHandler>Keturah</jLink> six years after <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H8283' clickHandler>Sarah</jLink>'s death, when he was approximately 137 years old, demonstrating his continued vitality and desire to expand his family lineage. <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H6989' clickHandler>Keturah</jLink>, whose name means "incense" or "fragrance," bore <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H0085' clickHandler>Abraham</jLink> six sons: <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H2175' clickHandler>Zimran</jLink>, <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H3370' clickHandler>Jokshan</jLink>, <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H4091' clickHandler>Medan</jLink>, <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H4080G' clickHandler>Midian</jLink>, <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H3435' clickHandler>Ishbak</jLink>, and <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H7744' clickHandler>Shuah</jLink>, who became the progenitors of various tribes and peoples distinct from <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H3327' clickHandler>Isaac</jLink>'s covenant line. These sons established nations that would later interact with the <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H3478' clickHandler>Israelites</jLink> throughout biblical history, most notably the <jLink data-type='L' data-strong='H4080H' clickHandler>Midianites</jLink> through <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H4080G' clickHandler>Midian</jLink>, who would play significant roles during the periods of <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H4872' clickHandler>Moses</jLink> and the Judges. <jPara></jPara> <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H0085' clickHandler>Abraham</jLink>'s careful distribution of his inheritance ensured that <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H3327' clickHandler>Isaac</jLink> remained the sole heir of his primary estate and covenant promises, while simultaneously providing for his other sons through substantial gifts before sending them eastward, away from <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H3327' clickHandler>Isaac</jLink>. This arrangement, completed while <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H0085' clickHandler>Abraham</jLink> still lived, prevented future conflicts over inheritance and maintained the theological distinction between the child of promise (<jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H3327' clickHandler>Isaac</jLink>) and <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H0085' clickHandler>Abraham</jLink>'s other offspring. The eastward migration of <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H6989' clickHandler>Keturah</jLink>'s sons contributed to the ethnographic complexity of the ancient Near East, as their descendants established trading networks and tribal confederations that would later encounter the Hebrew people during their wilderness wanderings and conquest of <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H3667G' clickHandler>Canaan</jLink>.
events: 2023 BC: <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H0085' clickHandler>Abraham</jLink> married <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H6989' clickHandler>Keturah</jLink> six years after <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H8283' clickHandler>Sarah</jLink>'s death

ChronologyEntries.article: 2016 BC:  <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H8035' clickHandler>Shem</jLink> died in 2016 BC after living 600 years (Gen.11:11), marking the end of one of the most significant genealogical bridges between the antediluvian and post-flood worlds. As one of <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H5146' clickHandler>Noah</jLink>'s three sons and a survivor of the great flood, <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H8035' clickHandler>Shem</jLink> represented the crucial link in the covenant lineage that would eventually produce <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H0085' clickHandler>Abraham</jLink> and the Hebrew nation. His death occurred eight years before <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H0085' clickHandler>Abraham</jLink>'s birth in 2008 BC, though his extraordinarily long lifespan meant that he could have potentially overlapped with <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H0085' clickHandler>Abraham</jLink>'s early years, serving as a living repository of flood-era knowledge and divine revelation for subsequent generations. <jPara></jPara> <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H8035' clickHandler>Shem</jLink>'s genealogical significance extends beyond his personal lifespan to his role as the progenitor of the Semitic peoples, with his name becoming the etymological root for the term "Semitic" that describes the linguistic and ethnic families descending from him. Through his son <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H0775' clickHandler>Arphaxad</jLink> and the subsequent patriarchal line including <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H7974' clickHandler>Shelah</jLink>, <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H5677G' clickHandler>Eber</jLink>, <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H6389' clickHandler>Peleg</jLink>, and eventually <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H0085' clickHandler>Abraham</jLink>, <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H8035' clickHandler>Shem</jLink>'s lineage preserved the covenant promises originally given to <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H5146' clickHandler>Noah</jLink> and transmitted them to the generation that would witness God's specific calling of <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H0085' clickHandler>Abraham</jLink> as the father of a chosen nation. His death in 2016 BC thus marked the conclusion of the immediate post-diluvian era and the transition toward the patriarchal period that would define biblical history through the Hebrew covenant relationship.
events: 2016 BC: <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H8035' clickHandler>Shem</jLink> died after living 600 years

ChronologyEntries.desc: <jChronDurationLink style='color:black'>▼</jChronDurationLink><jLink data-type='P' data-strong='G2384G' clickHandler>Jacob</jLink> and <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H6215G' clickHandler>Esau</jLink> born
ChronologyEntries.article: 2006 BC:  <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='G2384G' clickHandler>Jacob</jLink> and <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H6215G' clickHandler>Esau</jLink> were born as twins in 2006 BC to <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H3327' clickHandler>Isaac</jLink> and <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H7259' clickHandler>Rebekah</jLink>, following a period of barrenness that was resolved through <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H3327' clickHandler>Isaac</jLink>'s prayer to God on behalf of his wife (Gen.25:19-26). The pregnancy proved tumultuous for <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H7259' clickHandler>Rebekah</jLink>, with the twins struggling within her womb, prompting her to inquire of the Lord about the unusual circumstances she was experiencing. God's response contained a prophetic oracle that would shape the future relationship between the brothers and their descendants: "Two nations are in your womb, and two peoples from within you shall be divided; the one shall be stronger than the other, the older shall serve the younger". <jPara></jPara> The birth itself fulfilled this prophecy in dramatic fashion, as <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H6215G' clickHandler>Esau</jLink> emerged first with a red and hairy appearance, followed immediately by <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='G2384G' clickHandler>Jacob</jLink>, who was grasping <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H6215G' clickHandler>Esau</jLink>'s heel—an action that resulted in his name <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='G2384G' clickHandler>Jacob</jLink>, meaning "heel-grasper" or "supplanter". This prophetic birth occurred twenty years after <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H3327' clickHandler>Isaac</jLink>'s marriage to <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H7259' clickHandler>Rebekah</jLink> in 2026 BC and established the foundation for the perpetual rivalry between the <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H3478' clickHandler>Israelites</jLink> (descendants of <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='G2384G' clickHandler>Jacob</jLink>) and the <jLink data-type='L' data-strong='H0123G' clickHandler>Edomites</jLink> (descendants of <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H6215G' clickHandler>Esau</jLink>) that would characterize much of subsequent biblical and ancient Near Eastern history. The divine oracle's declaration that "the older shall serve the younger" represented a reversal of normal ancient Near Eastern succession practices and foreshadowed <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='G2384G' clickHandler>Jacob</jLink>'s eventual acquisition of both <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H6215G' clickHandler>Esau</jLink>'s birthright and his father's blessing.
events: 2006 BC: <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H6215G' clickHandler>Esau</jLink> born as the first twin to <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H3327' clickHandler>Isaac</jLink> and <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H7259' clickHandler>Rebekah</jLink>

2006 BC: <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='G2384G' clickHandler>Jacob</jLink> born as the second twin to <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H3327' clickHandler>Isaac</jLink> and <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H7259' clickHandler>Rebekah</jLink>

ChronologyEntries.article: 1991 BC:  <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H0085' clickHandler>Abraham</jLink> died in 1991 BC at the age of 175 years (Gen.25:7-11), concluding the life of the foundational patriarch through whom God established the covenant that would define the Hebrew nation and, according to biblical theology, provide blessing to all nations of the earth. His death occurred during a period of established prosperity and family stability, having witnessed the birth of his grandson twins <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='G2384G' clickHandler>Jacob</jLink> and <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H6215G' clickHandler>Esau</jLink> fifteen years earlier in 2006 BC, and having provided for his various descendants through his marriages to <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H8283' clickHandler>Sarah</jLink> and <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H6989' clickHandler>Keturah</jLink>. <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H0085' clickHandler>Abraham</jLink>'s final years were marked by his successful arrangement of <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H3327' clickHandler>Isaac</jLink>'s marriage to <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H7259' clickHandler>Rebekah</jLink> and his careful distribution of his inheritance to ensure that <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H3327' clickHandler>Isaac</jLink> remained the primary heir of the covenant promises while his other sons received substantial gifts before being sent eastward. <jPara></jPara> The burial of <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H0085' clickHandler>Abraham</jLink> by both his sons <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H3327' clickHandler>Isaac</jLink> and <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H3458G' clickHandler>Ishmael</jLink> in the cave of <jLink data-type='L' data-strong='H4375' clickHandler>Machpelah</jLink> demonstrated the enduring respect both branches of his family held for their father, despite the earlier tensions that had led to <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H1904' clickHandler>Hagar</jLink> and <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H3458G' clickHandler>Ishmael</jLink>'s departure. This burial site, which <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H0085' clickHandler>Abraham</jLink> had purchased from <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H6085G' clickHandler>Ephron</jLink> the <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H2845' clickHandler>Hittite</jLink> for four hundred shekels of silver, represented the first piece of the Promised Land legally owned by <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H0085' clickHandler>Abraham</jLink>'s family and served as the patriarchal burial ground where <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H8283' clickHandler>Sarah</jLink> had already been interred in 2029 BC. <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H0085' clickHandler>Abraham</jLink>'s death marked the end of an era in which God had called him from <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H0218A' clickHandler>Ur</jLink> of the <jLink data-type='L' data-strong='H3778' clickHandler>Chaldeans</jLink>, led him through <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H4714H' clickHandler>Egypt</jLink> and <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H3667G' clickHandler>Canaan</jLink>, tested his faith at Mount <jLink data-type='L' data-strong='H4179' clickHandler>Moriah</jLink>, and established through him the covenant that would shape the destiny of his descendants for millennia to come.
events: 1991 BC: <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H0085' clickHandler>Abraham</jLink> died at age 175

1991 BC: <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H3327' clickHandler>Isaac</jLink> and <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H3458G' clickHandler>Ishmael</jLink> buried <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H0085' clickHandler>Abraham</jLink> in the cave of <jLink data-type='L' data-strong='H4375' clickHandler>Machpelah</jLink>

ChronologyEntries.article: 1987 BC:  <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H5677G' clickHandler>Eber</jLink> died in 1987 BC after living 464 years (Gen.11:17), concluding the life of the patriarch whose name is etymologically connected to the term "Hebrew" and who served as a crucial genealogical link between <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H5146' clickHandler>Noah</jLink>'s son <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H8035' clickHandler>Shem</jLink> and <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H0085' clickHandler>Abraham</jLink>. As the son of <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H7974' clickHandler>Shelah</jLink> and father of <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H6389' clickHandler>Peleg</jLink>, <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H5677G' clickHandler>Eber</jLink> occupied a significant position in the post-flood lineage, and his death occurred just four years after <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H0085' clickHandler>Abraham</jLink>'s passing in 1991 BC, marking the end of another direct connection between the immediate post-diluvian generations and the established patriarchal covenant line. His extraordinarily long lifespan, characteristic of the early post-flood patriarchs though significantly shorter than the antediluvian lifespans, positioned him as a potential source of historical knowledge spanning from the era of Babel's linguistic confusion through the establishment of <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H0085' clickHandler>Abraham</jLink>'s covenant with God. <jPara></jPara> The significance of <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H5677G' clickHandler>Eber</jLink>'s name extends beyond his personal biography to encompass the ethnic and religious identity of his descendants, as biblical tradition identifies the <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H3478' clickHandler>Israelites</jLink> as "<jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H5680' clickHandler>Hebrews</jLink>" specifically because they descended from <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H5677G' clickHandler>Eber</jLink> through <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H0085' clickHandler>Abraham</jLink>. This connection first appears in Scripture when <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H0085' clickHandler>Abraham</jLink> is described as "<jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H0085' clickHandler>Abraham</jLink> the Hebrew" (Gen.14:13), establishing the ethnonym that would distinguish the covenant people throughout biblical history. <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H5677G' clickHandler>Eber</jLink>'s death in 1987 BC thus marked not merely the passing of an individual patriarch, but the conclusion of the life of the eponymous ancestor whose name would become the defining ethnic designation for God's chosen people, demonstrating the profound theological significance attached to genealogical continuity in biblical narrative and the preservation of covenant identity through successive generations.
events: 1987 BC: <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H5677G' clickHandler>Eber</jLink> died at age 464
1987 BC: The life of the Hebrew people's eponymous ancestor concluded

ChronologyEntries.desc: <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H3327' clickHandler>Isaac</jLink> with <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H0040G' clickHandler>Abimelech</jLink>
ChronologyEntries.article: 1974 BC:  <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H3327' clickHandler>Isaac</jLink>'s interactions with <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H0040G' clickHandler>Abimelech</jLink>, king of the <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H6430H' clickHandler>Philistines</jLink> in <jLink data-type='L' data-strong='H1642' clickHandler>Gerar</jLink>, occurred in 1974 BC during a period of regional famine that compelled <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H3327' clickHandler>Isaac</jLink> to seek refuge outside the promised land (Gen.26:1-33). Following a pattern established by his father <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H0085' clickHandler>Abraham</jLink> in similar circumstances, <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H3327' clickHandler>Isaac</jLink> presented his wife <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H7259' clickHandler>Rebekah</jLink> as his sister to protect himself from potential harm, though <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H0040G' clickHandler>Abimelech</jLink> discovered this deception when he observed <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H3327' clickHandler>Isaac</jLink> and <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H7259' clickHandler>Rebekah</jLink> together and subsequently warned his people against harming them. <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H3327' clickHandler>Isaac</jLink>'s agricultural and pastoral activities in <jLink data-type='L' data-strong='H1642' clickHandler>Gerar</jLink> proved extraordinarily successful, with his crops yielding a hundredfold and his livestock multiplying significantly, leading to envy among the <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H6430H' clickHandler>Philistines</jLink> who responded by stopping up the wells that <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H0085' clickHandler>Abraham</jLink> had previously dug. <jPara></jPara> The conflict over water rights ultimately prompted <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H3327' clickHandler>Isaac</jLink> to relocate to <jLink data-type='L' data-strong='H0884' clickHandler>Beersheba</jLink>, where God appeared to him and reaffirmed the covenant promises originally given to <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H0085' clickHandler>Abraham</jLink>, assuring <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H3327' clickHandler>Isaac</jLink> of divine blessing, multiplication of descendants, and possession of the land. Recognizing <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H3327' clickHandler>Isaac</jLink>'s evident prosperity and divine favor, <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H0040G' clickHandler>Abimelech</jLink> traveled from <jLink data-type='L' data-strong='H1642' clickHandler>Gerar</jLink> with his advisor <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H0276' clickHandler>Ahuzzath</jLink> and military commander <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H6369' clickHandler>Phichol</jLink> to propose a formal peace treaty, acknowledging that "the Lord has been with you" and seeking to establish mutual non-aggression. The agreement was sealed with an oath and commemorated by naming the well at <jLink data-type='L' data-strong='H0884' clickHandler>Beersheba</jLink>, meaning "well of the oath," though it should be noted that archaeological evidence does not support the presence of <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H6430H' clickHandler>Philistines</jLink> in this region during the early second millennium BC, suggesting the term may reflect later editorial perspectives rather than contemporary ethnic designations.
events: 1974 BC: A regional famine began prompting <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H3327' clickHandler>Isaac</jLink> to seek refuge in <jLink data-type='L' data-strong='H1642' clickHandler>Gerar</jLink>

1974 BC: <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H3327' clickHandler>Isaac</jLink> achieved extraordinary agricultural success in <jLink data-type='L' data-strong='H1642' clickHandler>Gerar</jLink>

1974 BC: <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H3327' clickHandler>Isaac</jLink> relocated from <jLink data-type='L' data-strong='H1642' clickHandler>Gerar</jLink> to <jLink data-type='L' data-strong='H0884' clickHandler>Beersheba</jLink> due to water rights conflicts

ChronologyEntries.desc: <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H6215G' clickHandler>Esau</jLink> marries <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H3067' clickHandler>Judith</jLink> and <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H1315G' clickHandler>Basemath</jLink>
ChronologyEntries.article: 1966 BC:  <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H6215G' clickHandler>Esau</jLink> married two <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H2845' clickHandler>Hittite</jLink> women in 1966 BC when he reached forty years of age: <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H3067' clickHandler>Judith</jLink>, daughter of <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H0882G' clickHandler>Beeri</jLink> the <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H2845' clickHandler>Hittite</jLink>, and <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H1315G' clickHandler>Basemath</jLink>, daughter of <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H0356J' clickHandler>Elon</jLink> the <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H2845' clickHandler>Hittite</jLink> (Gen.26:34-35). These marriages represented a significant departure from the established family pattern of seeking wives from among <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H0085' clickHandler>Abraham</jLink>'s relatives in <jLink data-type='L' data-strong='H0763G' clickHandler>Mesopotamia</jLink>, as demonstrated by <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H0085' clickHandler>Abraham</jLink>'s careful arrangement of <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H3327' clickHandler>Isaac</jLink>'s marriage to <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H7259' clickHandler>Rebekah</jLink> from the family of <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H5152H' clickHandler>Nahor</jLink>. <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H6215G' clickHandler>Esau</jLink>'s decision to marry locally available women from the <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H2845' clickHandler>Hittite</jLink> population reflects the broader challenge of maintaining distinct ethnic and religious identity while living among the diverse peoples of <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H3667G' clickHandler>Canaan</jLink>. <jPara></jPara> The marriages proved to be "a grief of mind to <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H3327' clickHandler>Isaac</jLink> and <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H7259' clickHandler>Rebekah</jLink>," indicating significant family tension over these unions with women from the local <jLink data-type='L' data-strong='H3667A' clickHandler>Canaanite</jLink> population. This parental distress likely stemmed from concerns about religious and cultural assimilation, as intermarriage with <jLink data-type='L' data-strong='H3667A' clickHandler>Canaanite</jLink> peoples posed potential threats to the preservation of the covenant faith and practices that distinguished <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H0085' clickHandler>Abraham</jLink>'s lineage. The narrative context suggests these marriages contributed to the family dynamics that would later influence <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H3327' clickHandler>Isaac</jLink>'s preference for <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='G2384G' clickHandler>Jacob</jLink> over <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H6215G' clickHandler>Esau</jLink> and the circumstances surrounding the transfer of the patriarchal blessing, demonstrating how matrimonial decisions in ancient Near Eastern society carried profound implications for family unity and covenant continuity.
events: 1966 BC: <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H6215G' clickHandler>Esau</jLink> reached forty years of age

1966 BC: <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H3327' clickHandler>Isaac</jLink> and <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H7259' clickHandler>Rebekah</jLink> experienced grief over <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H6215G' clickHandler>Esau</jLink>'s marriages

ChronologyEntries.article: 1943 BC:  <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H3458G' clickHandler>Ishmael</jLink> died in 1943 BC at the age of 137 years, concluding the life of <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H0085' clickHandler>Abraham</jLink>'s first son through <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H1904' clickHandler>Hagar</jLink>, <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H8283' clickHandler>Sarah</jLink>'s <jLink data-type='L' data-strong='H4714G' clickHandler>Egyptian</jLink> maidservant (Gen.25:17-18). His death occurred forty-eight years after his father <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H0085' clickHandler>Abraham</jLink>'s passing in 1991 BC, during which time <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H3458G' clickHandler>Ishmael</jLink> had established himself as the progenitor of twelve sons who became tribal leaders throughout the <jLink data-type='L' data-strong='H6152B' clickHandler>Arabian</jLink> Peninsula. According to biblical genealogy, these twelve sons included <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H5032' clickHandler>Nebaioth</jLink>, <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H6938' clickHandler>Kedar</jLink>, <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H0110' clickHandler>Adbeel</jLink>, <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H4017H' clickHandler>Mibsam</jLink>, <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H4927G' clickHandler>Mishma</jLink>, <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H1746G' clickHandler>Dumah</jLink>, <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H4854' clickHandler>Massa</jLink>, <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H2301' clickHandler>Hadad</jLink>, <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H8485G' clickHandler>Tema</jLink>, <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H3195G' clickHandler>Jetur</jLink>, <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H5305' clickHandler>Naphish</jLink>, and <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H6929' clickHandler>Kedemah</jLink>, who founded distinct tribes that would later interact with the <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H3478' clickHandler>Israelites</jLink> throughout biblical history. <jPara></jPara> <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H3458G' clickHandler>Ishmael</jLink>'s descendants settled in the region "from <jLink data-type='L' data-strong='H2341J' clickHandler>Havilah</jLink> to <jLink data-type='L' data-strong='H7793' clickHandler>Shur</jLink>, which is east of <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H4714H' clickHandler>Egypt</jLink>," establishing themselves across the northwestern <jLink data-type='L' data-strong='H6152B' clickHandler>Arabian</jLink> Peninsula in a territory that extended from the northeastern border of <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H4714H' clickHandler>Egypt</jLink> eastward across the northern <jLink data-type='L' data-strong='H6152B' clickHandler>Arabian</jLink> desert. The biblical record notes that they "lived in hostility toward all their relatives," suggesting a pattern of independence and periodic conflict with the descendants of <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H3327' clickHandler>Isaac</jLink> that would characterize relations between Arabic and Hebrew peoples throughout subsequent history. This settlement pattern reflects the nomadic and semi-nomadic lifestyle typical of <jLink data-type='L' data-strong='H6152B' clickHandler>Arabian</jLink> tribal confederations, with <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H3458G' clickHandler>Ishmael</jLink>'s death marking the conclusion of the founding generation that had established the tribal framework through which God's promise that <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H3458G' clickHandler>Ishmael</jLink> would become "a great nation" would be fulfilled.

ChronologyEntries.desc: <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='G2384G' clickHandler>Jacob</jLink> flees; marries <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H3812' clickHandler>Leah</jLink> & <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H7354' clickHandler>Rachel</jLink>
ChronologyEntries.article: 1930 BC:  <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='G2384G' clickHandler>Jacob</jLink> fled to <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H2039G' clickHandler>Haran</jLink> in 1930 BC to escape the murderous anger of his brother <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H6215G' clickHandler>Esau</jLink> following his deception of their father <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H3327' clickHandler>Isaac</jLink> to obtain the patriarchal blessing (Gen.27-30). This flight, ostensibly undertaken to find a wife from among his mother <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H7259' clickHandler>Rebekah</jLink>'s relatives, brought <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='G2384G' clickHandler>Jacob</jLink> to the household of his uncle <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H3837A' clickHandler>Laban</jLink> in <jLink data-type='L' data-strong='H6307' clickHandler>Paddan</jLink> <jLink data-type='L' data-strong='H0758I' clickHandler>Aram</jLink>, where he fell in love with <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H7354' clickHandler>Rachel</jLink>, <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H3837A' clickHandler>Laban</jLink>'s younger daughter, and agreed to work seven years as bride-service for her hand in marriage. However, <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H3837A' clickHandler>Laban</jLink> deceived <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='G2384G' clickHandler>Jacob</jLink> by substituting <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H3812' clickHandler>Leah</jLink>, the elder daughter, on the wedding night, compelling <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='G2384G' clickHandler>Jacob</jLink> to work an additional seven years to marry <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H7354' clickHandler>Rachel</jLink> as well, demonstrating the complex marriage negotiations and customs that characterized ancient Near Eastern society. <jPara></jPara> <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='G2384G' clickHandler>Jacob</jLink>'s fourteen years of service to <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H3837A' clickHandler>Laban</jLink> established him as a skilled shepherd and herdsman while his two wives, along with their servants <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H1090A' clickHandler>Bilhah</jLink> and <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H2153' clickHandler>Zilpah</jLink>, began producing the children who would become the twelve tribes of Israel. During this period in <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H2039G' clickHandler>Haran</jLink>, <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='G2384G' clickHandler>Jacob</jLink>'s family expanded through the births of <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H7205' clickHandler>Reuben</jLink>, <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H8095G' clickHandler>Simeon</jLink>, <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H3878' clickHandler>Levi</jLink>, and Judah through <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H3812' clickHandler>Leah</jLink>, while <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H7354' clickHandler>Rachel</jLink> remained initially barren, creating household tension that reflected the competitive dynamics common in polygamous marriages. The narrative of <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='G2384G' clickHandler>Jacob</jLink>'s time in <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H2039G' clickHandler>Haran</jLink> illustrates both the preservation of covenant lineage through endogamous marriage within the extended family and the complex family relationships that would shape the future tribal structure of the Hebrew nation, with <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='G2384G' clickHandler>Jacob</jLink>'s eventual prosperity in <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H3837A' clickHandler>Laban</jLink>'s service preparing him for his return to <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H3667G' clickHandler>Canaan</jLink> as the inheritor of <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H0085' clickHandler>Abraham</jLink>'s covenant promises.
events: 1930 BC: <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='G2384G' clickHandler>Jacob</jLink> deceived his father <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H3327' clickHandler>Isaac</jLink> in <jLink data-type='L' data-strong='H0884' clickHandler>Beersheba</jLink> to obtain the patriarchal blessing intended for <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H6215G' clickHandler>Esau</jLink>

1930 BC: <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='G2384G' clickHandler>Jacob</jLink> departed from <jLink data-type='L' data-strong='H0884' clickHandler>Beersheba</jLink> and began his journey toward <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H2039G' clickHandler>Haran</jLink>

1930 BC: <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='G2384G' clickHandler>Jacob</jLink> stopped at <jLink data-type='L' data-strong='H1008G' clickHandler>Bethel</jLink> during his journey where he had a dream of a ladder reaching to heaven and received God's promise of blessing and protection

1930 BC: <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='G2384G' clickHandler>Jacob</jLink> arrived in <jLink data-type='L' data-strong='H6307' clickHandler>Paddan</jLink> <jLink data-type='L' data-strong='H0758I' clickHandler>Aram</jLink> and came to the household of his uncle <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H3837A' clickHandler>Laban</jLink>

1930 BC: <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='G2384G' clickHandler>Jacob</jLink> fell in love with <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H7354' clickHandler>Rachel</jLink> and was welcomed into <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H3837A' clickHandler>Laban</jLink>'s household

ChronologyEntries.desc: <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H7205' clickHandler>Reuben</jLink> born to <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='G2384G' clickHandler>Jacob</jLink>
ChronologyEntries.article: 1928 BC:  <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H7205' clickHandler>Reuben</jLink> was born in 1928 BC as the firstborn son of <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='G2384G' clickHandler>Jacob</jLink> and <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H3812' clickHandler>Leah</jLink>, approximately two years after <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='G2384G' clickHandler>Jacob</jLink>'s arrival in <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H2039G' clickHandler>Haran</jLink> and his marriage to <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H3812' clickHandler>Leah</jLink> through <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H3837A' clickHandler>Laban</jLink>'s deception (Gen.29:32). <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H3812' clickHandler>Leah</jLink> named him <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H7205' clickHandler>Reuben</jLink>, meaning "behold, a son," expressing her hope that bearing <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='G2384G' clickHandler>Jacob</jLink>'s first son would earn her husband's love, since <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='G2384G' clickHandler>Jacob</jLink> had preferred her younger sister <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H7354' clickHandler>Rachel</jLink>. As the firstborn, <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H7205' clickHandler>Reuben</jLink> was entitled to the privileges of primogeniture in ancient Near Eastern culture, including leadership authority within the family and a double portion of inheritance, positioning him as the natural heir to <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='G2384G' clickHandler>Jacob</jLink>'s covenant blessings and the continuation of the patriarchal line established through <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H0085' clickHandler>Abraham</jLink> and <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H3327' clickHandler>Isaac</jLink>. <jPara></jPara> <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H7205' clickHandler>Reuben</jLink>'s birth marked the beginning of what would become the twelve tribes of Israel, establishing him as the progenitor of the tribe of <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H7205' clickHandler>Reuben</jLink> that would later settle east of the <jLink data-type='L' data-strong='H3383' clickHandler>Jordan</jLink> River during the conquest of <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H3667G' clickHandler>Canaan</jLink>. However, his privileged status as firstborn would ultimately be forfeited due to his later transgression with <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H1090A' clickHandler>Bilhah</jLink>, his father's concubine, leading to the transfer of leadership to Judah and the double portion to <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H3130G' clickHandler>Joseph</jLink>'s sons <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H0669G' clickHandler>Ephraim</jLink> and <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H4519G' clickHandler>Manasseh</jLink>. Despite losing his birthright, <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H7205' clickHandler>Reuben</jLink> demonstrated protective instincts toward his younger brother <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H3130G' clickHandler>Joseph</jLink>, attempting to save him from his brothers' murderous intentions and later offering his own sons as surety for <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H1144G' clickHandler>Benjamin</jLink>'s safety during the family's encounters with <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H3130G' clickHandler>Joseph</jLink> in <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H4714H' clickHandler>Egypt</jLink>.

1928 BC: <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H3812' clickHandler>Leah</jLink> named her son <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H7205' clickHandler>Reuben</jLink> expressing her hope that bearing <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='G2384G' clickHandler>Jacob</jLink>'s first son would earn her husband's love

ChronologyEntries.desc: <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H8095G' clickHandler>Simeon</jLink> born to <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='G2384G' clickHandler>Jacob</jLink>
ChronologyEntries.article: 1927 BC:  <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H8095G' clickHandler>Simeon</jLink> was born in 1927 BC as the second son of <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='G2384G' clickHandler>Jacob</jLink> and <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H3812' clickHandler>Leah</jLink>, following closely after <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H7205' clickHandler>Reuben</jLink>'s birth the previous year (Gen.29:33). <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H3812' clickHandler>Leah</jLink> named him <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H8095G' clickHandler>Simeon</jLink>, meaning "hearing" or "one who hears," because she believed that the Lord had heard that she was unloved by <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='G2384G' clickHandler>Jacob</jLink> and had therefore given her another son to strengthen her position in the household. This birth occurred during the ongoing rivalry between <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H3812' clickHandler>Leah</jLink> and <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H7354' clickHandler>Rachel</jLink> for <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='G2384G' clickHandler>Jacob</jLink>'s affection, with <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H3812' clickHandler>Leah</jLink>'s fertility serving as a source of both comfort and strategy in her competition with her barren sister. <jPara></jPara> <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H8095G' clickHandler>Simeon</jLink>'s significance extends beyond his birth to his role as ancestor of the tribe of <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H8095G' clickHandler>Simeon</jLink>, though his tribal inheritance would later be absorbed into the territory of Judah in southern <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H3667G' clickHandler>Canaan</jLink>. Along with his brother <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H3878' clickHandler>Levi</jLink>, <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H8095G' clickHandler>Simeon</jLink> would participate in the violent revenge against the men of <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H7927G' clickHandler>Shechem</jLink> following the violation of their sister <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H1783' clickHandler>Dinah</jLink>, an action that would earn <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='G2384G' clickHandler>Jacob</jLink>'s rebuke and result in a prophetic declaration that <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H8095G' clickHandler>Simeon</jLink>'s descendants would be scattered within Israel. This prophecy was fulfilled when the tribe of <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H8095G' clickHandler>Simeon</jLink> became integrated into Judah's territory and eventually lost its distinct tribal identity, demonstrating how individual actions could have lasting consequences for entire tribal lineages in biblical history.

ChronologyEntries.desc: <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H3878' clickHandler>Levi</jLink> born to <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='G2384G' clickHandler>Jacob</jLink>, lives 137 yrs
ChronologyEntries.article: 1926 BC:  <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H3878' clickHandler>Levi</jLink> was born in 1926 BC as the third son of <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='G2384G' clickHandler>Jacob</jLink> and <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H3812' clickHandler>Leah</jLink>, continuing the pattern of consecutive annual births that characterized this period of <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='G2384G' clickHandler>Jacob</jLink>'s growing family in <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H2039G' clickHandler>Haran</jLink> (Gen.29:34). <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H3812' clickHandler>Leah</jLink> named him <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H3878' clickHandler>Levi</jLink>, meaning "attached" or "joined," expressing her hope that bearing three sons would finally cause <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='G2384G' clickHandler>Jacob</jLink> to become emotionally attached to her and strengthen their marital relationship. <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H3878' clickHandler>Levi</jLink> lived for 137 years, positioning his lifespan to encompass the family's return to <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H3667G' clickHandler>Canaan</jLink>, the descent into <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H4714H' clickHandler>Egypt</jLink> during the famine, and the early period of <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H3478' clickHandler>Israelite</jLink> presence in <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H4714H' clickHandler>Egypt</jLink> before the eventual enslavement. <jPara></jPara> Despite participating with <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H8095G' clickHandler>Simeon</jLink> in the massacre at <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H7927G' clickHandler>Shechem</jLink> that earned <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='G2384G' clickHandler>Jacob</jLink>'s disapproval, <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H3878' clickHandler>Levi</jLink>'s descendants would ultimately receive a unique and elevated position within <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H3478' clickHandler>Israelite</jLink> society as the priestly tribe. The tribe of <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H3878' clickHandler>Levi</jLink> was set apart for religious service, with the descendants of <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H0175' clickHandler>Aaron</jLink> serving as priests and the broader <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H3878' clickHandler>Levitical</jLink> family managing temple duties and religious instruction throughout Israel. Rather than receiving a territorial inheritance like other tribes, the <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H3878' clickHandler>Levites</jLink> were distributed among designated cities throughout the promised land, emphasizing their role as spiritual leaders and teachers of the law, thus transforming what initially appeared to be a curse into a blessing that made the <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H3878' clickHandler>Levites</jLink> central to <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H3478' clickHandler>Israelite</jLink> religious life.

ChronologyEntries.desc: Judah born to <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='G2384G' clickHandler>Jacob</jLink>
ChronologyEntries.article: 1925 BC:  Judah was born in 1925 BC as the fourth son of <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='G2384G' clickHandler>Jacob</jLink> and <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H3812' clickHandler>Leah</jLink>, completing the first quartet of sons who would become the founding fathers of Israel's most significant tribes (Gen.29:35). <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H3812' clickHandler>Leah</jLink> named him Judah, meaning "praise," declaring "this time I will praise the Lord," suggesting a shift in her perspective from seeking <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='G2384G' clickHandler>Jacob</jLink>'s love through childbearing to acknowledging God's blessings regardless of her marital circumstances. This birth occurred during <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='G2384G' clickHandler>Jacob</jLink>'s extended residence in <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H2039G' clickHandler>Haran</jLink>, where he was fulfilling his fourteen-year service commitment to <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H3837A' clickHandler>Laban</jLink> in exchange for his daughters <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H3812' clickHandler>Leah</jLink> and <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H7354' clickHandler>Rachel</jLink>, with Judah's arrival marking the completion of <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H3812' clickHandler>Leah</jLink>'s initial period of fertility before <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H7354' clickHandler>Rachel</jLink> began to conceive. <jPara></jPara> Judah would emerge as the most prominent among <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='G2384G' clickHandler>Jacob</jLink>'s sons, eventually receiving the leadership role that originally belonged to <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H7205' clickHandler>Reuben</jLink> and founding the tribe that would produce the Davidic royal line and, according to biblical tradition, the Messiah. His leadership qualities were demonstrated during the family crisis involving <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H3130G' clickHandler>Joseph</jLink> in <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H4714H' clickHandler>Egypt</jLink>, where Judah interceded for his brothers and offered himself as a substitute for <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H1144G' clickHandler>Benjamin</jLink>, displaying the kind of sacrificial leadership that would characterize his tribal legacy. The tribe of Judah became the dominant force in the southern kingdom of Israel, controlling <jLink data-type='L' data-strong='H3389' clickHandler>Jerusalem</jLink> and maintaining the Davidic covenant even after the northern kingdom's destruction, making Judah's birth in 1925 BC a pivotal moment in the establishment of Israel's royal and messianic lineage.
events: 1925 BC: Judah was born to <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='G2384G' clickHandler>Jacob</jLink> and <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H3812' clickHandler>Leah</jLink> in <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H2039G' clickHandler>Haran</jLink> as <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='G2384G' clickHandler>Jacob</jLink>'s fourth son
1925 BC: <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H3812' clickHandler>Leah</jLink> named her son Judah and declared "this time I will praise the Lord"

ChronologyEntries.desc: <jChronDurationLink style='color:black'>▼</jChronDurationLink><jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H3130G' clickHandler>Joseph</jLink> born to <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='G2384G' clickHandler>Jacob</jLink>
ChronologyEntries.article: 1915 BC:  <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H3130G' clickHandler>Joseph</jLink> was born in 1915 BC to <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='G2384G' clickHandler>Jacob</jLink> and <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H7354' clickHandler>Rachel</jLink>, marking the miraculous resolution of <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H7354' clickHandler>Rachel</jLink>'s prolonged barrenness and her restoration within the competitive dynamics of <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='G2384G' clickHandler>Jacob</jLink>'s polygamous household in <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H2039G' clickHandler>Haran</jLink>. After years of infertility while her sister <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H3812' clickHandler>Leah</jLink> bore multiple sons, <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H7354' clickHandler>Rachel</jLink>'s conception is specifically attributed to divine intervention: "God remembered <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H7354' clickHandler>Rachel</jLink>; he listened to her and enabled her to conceive" (Gen.30:22). <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H7354' clickHandler>Rachel</jLink> named her son <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H3130G' clickHandler>Joseph</jLink>, meaning "may he add," expressing both gratitude for this child and hope that God would grant her another son, which would be fulfilled seven years later with <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H1144G' clickHandler>Benjamin</jLink>'s birth. <jPara></jPara> <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H3130G' clickHandler>Joseph</jLink>'s birth occurred during <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='G2384G' clickHandler>Jacob</jLink>'s extended residence with his uncle <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H3837A' clickHandler>Laban</jLink> in <jLink data-type='L' data-strong='H6307' clickHandler>Paddan</jLink> <jLink data-type='L' data-strong='H0758I' clickHandler>Aram</jLink>, approximately fifteen years after <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='G2384G' clickHandler>Jacob</jLink>'s arrival in 1930 BC and his marriages to <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H3812' clickHandler>Leah</jLink> and <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H7354' clickHandler>Rachel</jLink>. This birth represented a pivotal moment in the patriarchal narrative, as <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H3130G' clickHandler>Joseph</jLink> would become <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='G2384G' clickHandler>Jacob</jLink>'s favored son and ultimately serve as the instrument through which God would preserve the Hebrew family during the severe famine that would drive them to <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H4714H' clickHandler>Egypt</jLink>. The timing of <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H3130G' clickHandler>Joseph</jLink>'s birth, following the births of ten older brothers between 1928-1918 BC, positioned him as the eleventh son whose future dreams and interpretation abilities would dramatically alter the course of biblical history and establish the foundation for Israel's sojourn in <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H4714H' clickHandler>Egypt</jLink>.
