ChronologyEntries.desc: <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='G2384G' clickHandler>Jacob</jLink> leaves <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H3837A' clickHandler>Laban</jLink>. <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H1783' clickHandler>Dinah</jLink>
ChronologyEntries.article: 1909 BC:  In 1909 BC, <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='G2384G' clickHandler>Jacob</jLink> departed from <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H2039G' clickHandler>Haran</jLink> after twenty years of service to his uncle <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H3837A' clickHandler>Laban</jLink>, taking with him his wives <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H3812' clickHandler>Leah</jLink> and <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H7354' clickHandler>Rachel</jLink>, their servants <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H1090A' clickHandler>Bilhah</jLink> and <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H2153' clickHandler>Zilpah</jLink>, eleven sons, one daughter <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H1783' clickHandler>Dinah</jLink>, and substantial flocks acquired through his shrewd negotiations regarding speckled and spotted livestock. The departure involved complex negotiations with <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H3837A' clickHandler>Laban</jLink> over wages and property rights, culminating in a covenant sealed at <jLink data-type='L' data-strong='H1568G' clickHandler>Gilead</jLink> where both men established boundary stones and invoked divine witness to their mutual non-aggression pact. <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='G2384G' clickHandler>Jacob</jLink>'s westward journey toward <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H3667G' clickHandler>Canaan</jLink> included his dramatic encounter with angels at <jLink data-type='L' data-strong='H4266' clickHandler>Mahanaim</jLink> and his wrestling match with a divine messenger at <jLink data-type='L' data-strong='H6439G' clickHandler>Peniel</jLink>, where he received the name Israel, meaning "he who wrestles with God.". <jPara></jPara> During this transitional period, <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='G2384G' clickHandler>Jacob</jLink>'s daughter <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H1783' clickHandler>Dinah</jLink> was violated by <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H7927G' clickHandler>Shechem</jLink>, son of <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H2544' clickHandler>Hamor</jLink> the <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H2340' clickHandler>Hivite</jLink> prince, in the city of <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H7927G' clickHandler>Shechem</jLink>, creating a crisis that would test family honor and tribal relations in <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H3667G' clickHandler>Canaan</jLink>. When <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H7927G' clickHandler>Shechem</jLink> genuinely sought to marry <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H1783' clickHandler>Dinah</jLink> and proposed intermarriage between the <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H2340' clickHandler>Hivites</jLink> and <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='G2384G' clickHandler>Jacob</jLink>'s family, <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H1783' clickHandler>Dinah</jLink>'s brothers <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H8095G' clickHandler>Simeon</jLink> and <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H3878' clickHandler>Levi</jLink> deceived the <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H7928H' clickHandler>Shechemites</jLink> by requiring their circumcision, then massacred all the males while they were recovering from the procedure. This violent retaliation, motivated by their sister's defilement, earned <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='G2384G' clickHandler>Jacob</jLink>'s rebuke for jeopardizing the family's security among the <jLink data-type='L' data-strong='H3667A' clickHandler>Canaanite</jLink> peoples and would later result in <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='G2384G' clickHandler>Jacob</jLink>'s prophetic curse upon both tribes, leading to their eventual scattering within Israel rather than receiving consolidated territorial inheritances.

ChronologyEntries.desc: <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='G2384G' clickHandler>Jacob</jLink> at <jLink data-type='L' data-strong='H1008G' clickHandler>Bethel</jLink>. <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H1144G' clickHandler>Benjamin</jLink> born
ChronologyEntries.article: 1902 BC:  <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='G2384G' clickHandler>Jacob</jLink> returned to <jLink data-type='L' data-strong='H1008G' clickHandler>Bethel</jLink> in obedience to God's command, where he built an altar and experienced a divine reaffirmation of the covenant promises originally given to <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H0085' clickHandler>Abraham</jLink> and <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H3327' clickHandler>Isaac</jLink>, including the confirmation of his new name Israel and the assurance that kings would descend from his lineage. This sacred site, where <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='G2384G' clickHandler>Jacob</jLink> had earlier dreamed of a ladder reaching to heaven during his flight from <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H6215G' clickHandler>Esau</jLink> in 1930 BC, served as the location for spiritual renewal and the purging of foreign gods from his household. The return to <jLink data-type='L' data-strong='H1008G' clickHandler>Bethel</jLink> marked a significant moment of covenant continuity, as God reiterated the promises of land inheritance and countless descendants while establishing <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='G2384G' clickHandler>Jacob</jLink>'s role as patriarch of the chosen people. <jPara></jPara> The journey from <jLink data-type='L' data-strong='H1008G' clickHandler>Bethel</jLink> toward <jLink data-type='L' data-strong='H1035G' clickHandler>Ephrath</jLink> (<jLink data-type='L' data-strong='H1035G' clickHandler>Bethlehem</jLink>) proved tragic when <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H7354' clickHandler>Rachel</jLink> went into difficult labor and died giving birth to <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H1144G' clickHandler>Benjamin</jLink>, whom she initially named Ben-oni ("son of my sorrow") before <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='G2384G' clickHandler>Jacob</jLink> renamed him <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H1144G' clickHandler>Benjamin</jLink> ("son of my right hand"). <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H7354' clickHandler>Rachel</jLink>'s death at approximately age 40 represented the loss of <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='G2384G' clickHandler>Jacob</jLink>'s beloved wife and marked the completion of his family with the birth of his twelfth son, thereby establishing the patriarchal foundation for the twelve tribes of Israel. <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='G2384G' clickHandler>Jacob</jLink> erected a pillar over <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H7354' clickHandler>Rachel</jLink>'s tomb, which remained a recognizable landmark for centuries, while <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H1144G' clickHandler>Benjamin</jLink>'s birth as the second son of <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H7354' clickHandler>Rachel</jLink> positioned him as <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H3130G' clickHandler>Joseph</jLink>'s full brother and future ally during the family's eventual crisis in <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H4714H' clickHandler>Egypt</jLink> when <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H3130G' clickHandler>Joseph</jLink> would test his brothers' character and loyalty.

ChronologyEntries.desc: <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H3130G' clickHandler>Joseph</jLink> in <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H4714H' clickHandler>Egypt</jLink> with <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H6318' clickHandler>Potiphar</jLink>
ChronologyEntries.article: 1898 BC:  <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H3130G' clickHandler>Joseph</jLink> was sold into <jLink data-type='L' data-strong='H4714G' clickHandler>Egyptian</jLink> slavery in 1898 BC when he was seventeen years old, following his brothers' conspiracy to eliminate the favored son whose dreams of future dominance and colorful coat had inflamed their jealousy. When <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='G2384G' clickHandler>Jacob</jLink> sent <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H3130G' clickHandler>Joseph</jLink> to check on his brothers tending flocks near <jLink data-type='L' data-strong='H7927G' clickHandler>Shechem</jLink>, they initially planned to kill him but were persuaded by <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H7205' clickHandler>Reuben</jLink> to cast him into a pit instead. However, when a caravan of <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H3458G' clickHandler>Ishmaelite</jLink> traders passed by en route to <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H4714H' clickHandler>Egypt</jLink>, Judah convinced his brothers to sell <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H3130G' clickHandler>Joseph</jLink> for twenty shekels of silver rather than shed his blood directly, though they deceived <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='G2384G' clickHandler>Jacob</jLink> by presenting <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H3130G' clickHandler>Joseph</jLink>'s bloodied coat as evidence of his death by wild animals. <jPara></jPara> In <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H4714H' clickHandler>Egypt</jLink>, <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H3130G' clickHandler>Joseph</jLink> was purchased by <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H6318' clickHandler>Potiphar</jLink>, an officer of <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H6547H' clickHandler>Pharaoh</jLink> and captain of the guard, positioning him within the household of a high-ranking official who likely served as commander of the royal bodyguard or prison system. Despite the traumatic circumstances of his arrival, <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H3130G' clickHandler>Joseph</jLink> quickly distinguished himself through his administrative abilities and integrity, earning <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H6318' clickHandler>Potiphar</jLink>'s trust and being promoted to oversee the entire household. However, his refusal to commit adultery with <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H6318' clickHandler>Potiphar</jLink>'s wife led to false accusations and imprisonment, ironically positioning him to interpret dreams for <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H6547H' clickHandler>Pharaoh</jLink>'s officials and eventually <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H6547H' clickHandler>Pharaoh</jLink> himself. This period of slavery and imprisonment, lasting approximately thirteen years until his elevation in 1885 BC, served as divine preparation for <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H3130G' clickHandler>Joseph</jLink>'s future role as <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H4714H' clickHandler>Egypt</jLink>'s administrator during seven years of abundance followed by seven years of severe famine.
events: 1898 BC: <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H3130G' clickHandler>Joseph</jLink> was sold to <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H3458G' clickHandler>Ishmaelite</jLink> traders and taken from <jLink data-type='L' data-strong='H7927G' clickHandler>Shechem</jLink> to <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H4714H' clickHandler>Egypt</jLink>

1898 BC: <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H6318' clickHandler>Potiphar</jLink> purchased <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H3130G' clickHandler>Joseph</jLink> and promoted him to oversee his household

1898 BC: <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H6318' clickHandler>Potiphar</jLink>'s wife falsely accused <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H3130G' clickHandler>Joseph</jLink> after he refused her advances
1898 BC: <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H3130G' clickHandler>Joseph</jLink> was imprisoned due to <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H6318' clickHandler>Potiphar</jLink>'s wife's false accusations

ChronologyEntries.desc: Judah and <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H8559G' clickHandler>Tamar</jLink>. <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H3130G' clickHandler>Joseph</jLink> in prison
ChronologyEntries.article: 1897 BC:  Two significant parallel narratives would shape the future of <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='G2384G' clickHandler>Jacob</jLink>'s family lineage. Judah, <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='G2384G' clickHandler>Jacob</jLink>'s fourth son, separated from his brothers and settled among the <jLink data-type='L' data-strong='H3667A' clickHandler>Canaanites</jLink>, where he married the daughter of a man named <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H7770' clickHandler>Shua</jLink> and fathered three sons: <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H6147G' clickHandler>Er</jLink>, <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H0209' clickHandler>Onan</jLink>, and <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H7956' clickHandler>Shelah</jLink>. When <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H6147G' clickHandler>Er</jLink> married <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H8559G' clickHandler>Tamar</jLink> but died due to his wickedness, his brother <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H0209' clickHandler>Onan</jLink> was obligated by levirate marriage customs to provide offspring for his deceased brother, but <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H0209' clickHandler>Onan</jLink>'s refusal to fulfill this duty also resulted in his death. After Judah failed to give <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H8559G' clickHandler>Tamar</jLink> his youngest son <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H7956' clickHandler>Shelah</jLink> as promised, she disguised herself as a prostitute and conceived twins by Judah himself, leading to his acknowledgment that she was "more righteous than I" when the deception was revealed. This incident produced <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H6557' clickHandler>Perez</jLink> and <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H2226I' clickHandler>Zerah</jLink>, with <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H6557' clickHandler>Perez</jLink> becoming an ancestor in the messianic lineage through the tribe of Judah. <jPara></jPara> Simultaneously, <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H3130G' clickHandler>Joseph</jLink> remained imprisoned in <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H4714H' clickHandler>Egypt</jLink> following his false accusation by <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H6318' clickHandler>Potiphar</jLink>'s wife, where he encountered <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H6547H' clickHandler>Pharaoh</jLink>'s chief cupbearer and chief baker who had been incarcerated for offenses against their royal master. When both officials experienced troubling dreams, <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H3130G' clickHandler>Joseph</jLink> interpreted them through divine assistance: the cupbearer would be restored to his position within three days, while the baker would be executed. <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H3130G' clickHandler>Joseph</jLink>'s accurate interpretations demonstrated his God-given ability to understand divine communications through dreams, and he requested that the cupbearer remember him and mention his case to <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H6547H' clickHandler>Pharaoh</jLink> upon his release. However, the cupbearer forgot <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H3130G' clickHandler>Joseph</jLink> for two additional years, extending his imprisonment until 1885 BC when <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H6547H' clickHandler>Pharaoh</jLink>'s own dreams would require interpretation and lead to <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H3130G' clickHandler>Joseph</jLink>'s dramatic elevation to second-in-command over all <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H4714H' clickHandler>Egypt</jLink>.
events: 1897 BC: Judah settled among the <jLink data-type='L' data-strong='H3667A' clickHandler>Canaanites</jLink> and married <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H7770' clickHandler>Shua</jLink>'s daughter

1897 BC: Judah fathered three sons <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H6147G' clickHandler>Er</jLink>, <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H0209' clickHandler>Onan</jLink>, and <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H7956' clickHandler>Shelah</jLink> through his <jLink data-type='L' data-strong='H3667A' clickHandler>Canaanite</jLink> wife
1897 BC: <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H6147G' clickHandler>Er</jLink> married <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H8559G' clickHandler>Tamar</jLink> and died due to his wickedness

1897 BC: <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H0209' clickHandler>Onan</jLink> was obligated by levirate marriage customs to marry <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H8559G' clickHandler>Tamar</jLink> for his brother <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H6147G' clickHandler>Er</jLink>
1897 BC: <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H0209' clickHandler>Onan</jLink> died for refusing to fulfill his levirate obligation to <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H6147G' clickHandler>Er</jLink>

ChronologyEntries.article: 1886 BC:  <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H3327' clickHandler>Isaac</jLink> died in 1886 BC at the age of 180 years, concluding the life of the second patriarch in the covenant lineage established through <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H0085' clickHandler>Abraham</jLink> (Gen.35:23-29). His death occurred after he had witnessed significant developments in his family, including the birth and early lives of his twin grandsons <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='G2384G' clickHandler>Jacob</jLink>'s twelve sons, who would become the progenitors of the twelve tribes of Israel. <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H3327' clickHandler>Isaac</jLink>'s longevity, though considerably shorter than his father <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H0085' clickHandler>Abraham</jLink>'s 175 years, positioned him to see the foundational generation that would establish the Hebrew nation, and his passing marked the end of the patriarchal generation that had direct personal experience with the covenant promises originally given to <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H0085' clickHandler>Abraham</jLink>. <jPara></jPara> Both <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H3327' clickHandler>Isaac</jLink>'s sons, <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H6215G' clickHandler>Esau</jLink> and <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='G2384G' clickHandler>Jacob</jLink>, united to bury their father despite their earlier rivalry over the birthright and patriarchal blessing, demonstrating the respect and familial obligation that transcended their personal conflicts. This joint burial occurred at the family tomb in the cave of <jLink data-type='L' data-strong='H4375' clickHandler>Machpelah</jLink> near <jLink data-type='L' data-strong='H2275A' clickHandler>Hebron</jLink>, where <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H0085' clickHandler>Abraham</jLink> and <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H8283' clickHandler>Sarah</jLink> had previously been interred, establishing continuity in the patriarchal burial site that would later house <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='G2384G' clickHandler>Jacob</jLink> and <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H3812' clickHandler>Leah</jLink> as well. <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H3327' clickHandler>Isaac</jLink>'s death in 1886 BC occurred during the period when <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H3130G' clickHandler>Joseph</jLink> was imprisoned in <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H4714H' clickHandler>Egypt</jLink>, eleven years before <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H3130G' clickHandler>Joseph</jLink>'s elevation to power and twelve years before the severe famine that would ultimately bring <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='G2384G' clickHandler>Jacob</jLink>'s entire family to <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H4714H' clickHandler>Egypt</jLink>, making <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H3327' clickHandler>Isaac</jLink>'s passing a transitional moment between the <jLink data-type='L' data-strong='H3667A' clickHandler>Canaanite</jLink> patriarchal period and the <jLink data-type='L' data-strong='H4714G' clickHandler>Egyptian</jLink> sojourn that would define the next phase of Hebrew history.
events: 1886 BC: <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H3327' clickHandler>Isaac</jLink> died at age 180 in <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H3667G' clickHandler>Canaan</jLink>

1886 BC: <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H6215G' clickHandler>Esau</jLink> and <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='G2384G' clickHandler>Jacob</jLink> buried <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H3327' clickHandler>Isaac</jLink> in <jLink data-type='L' data-strong='H4375' clickHandler>Machpelah</jLink> cave near <jLink data-type='L' data-strong='H2275A' clickHandler>Hebron</jLink>

ChronologyEntries.desc: <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H3130G' clickHandler>Joseph</jLink> stores grain for 7 years
ChronologyEntries.article: 1885 BC:  <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H3130G' clickHandler>Joseph</jLink>'s interpretation of <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H6547H' clickHandler>Pharaoh</jLink>'s dreams in 1885 BC led to his dramatic elevation from prisoner to vizier of <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H4714H' clickHandler>Egypt</jLink>, second in authority only to <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H6547H' clickHandler>Pharaoh</jLink> himself, initiating a comprehensive grain storage program that would preserve <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H4714H' clickHandler>Egypt</jLink> and surrounding nations during an impending seven-year famine. <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H6547H' clickHandler>Pharaoh</jLink>'s two dreams—of seven fat cows devoured by seven lean cows, and seven full grain heads consumed by seven withered heads—revealed God's plan for seven years of unprecedented abundance followed by seven years of severe scarcity throughout the region. <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H3130G' clickHandler>Joseph</jLink>'s divine interpretation impressed <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H6547H' clickHandler>Pharaoh</jLink> so greatly that he immediately appointed him to oversee the collection and storage of surplus grain during the years of plenty, recognizing that "there is no one so discerning and wise" as <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H3130G' clickHandler>Joseph</jLink>, in whom "the Spirit of God" clearly resided. <jPara></jPara> The administrative system <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H3130G' clickHandler>Joseph</jLink> implemented during the seven years of abundance (1885-1878 BC) demonstrated remarkable foresight and organizational capability, as he established storage centers throughout <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H4714H' clickHandler>Egypt</jLink> and collected one-fifth of all agricultural produce during the bumper harvest years. This massive undertaking required sophisticated logistics, including the construction or adaptation of granaries, the development of preservation techniques, and the creation of a bureaucratic system capable of managing resources on a national scale. Historical evidence from Middle Kingdom <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H4714H' clickHandler>Egypt</jLink> (c. 1900-1870 BC) shows that the administrative capabilities and agricultural surplus management described in the <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H3130G' clickHandler>Joseph</jLink> narrative align with known <jLink data-type='L' data-strong='H4714G' clickHandler>Egyptian</jLink> practices during this period, when pharaohs such as Senusret II and Senusret III maintained strong centralized control and implemented significant economic reforms. <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H3130G' clickHandler>Joseph</jLink>'s appointment at age thirty marked the beginning of his role as <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H4714H' clickHandler>Egypt</jLink>'s chief administrator, a position that would prove crucial not only for <jLink data-type='L' data-strong='H4714G' clickHandler>Egyptian</jLink> survival but also for the preservation of his own family when the famine would drive them from <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H3667G' clickHandler>Canaan</jLink> to <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H4714H' clickHandler>Egypt</jLink> seeking relief.
events: 1885 BC: <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H6547H' clickHandler>Pharaoh</jLink> dreamed of seven fat cows devoured by seven lean cows and seven full grain heads consumed by seven withered heads
1885 BC: <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H3130G' clickHandler>Joseph</jLink> was summoned from prison to interpret <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H6547H' clickHandler>Pharaoh</jLink>'s dreams

1885 BC: <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H6547H' clickHandler>Pharaoh</jLink> elevated <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H3130G' clickHandler>Joseph</jLink> from prisoner to vizier of <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H4714H' clickHandler>Egypt</jLink>
1885 BC: <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H3130G' clickHandler>Joseph</jLink> initiated a grain storage program for the impending seven-year famine

ChronologyEntries.article: 1878 BC:  The seven-year famine that began in 1878 BC affected not only <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H4714H' clickHandler>Egypt</jLink> but all surrounding lands, fulfilling the prophetic warning contained in <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H6547H' clickHandler>Pharaoh</jLink>'s dreams that <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H3130G' clickHandler>Joseph</jLink> had interpreted seven years earlier. As predicted, the years of abundance ended abruptly, and the carefully stored grain reserves that <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H3130G' clickHandler>Joseph</jLink> had accumulated throughout <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H4714H' clickHandler>Egypt</jLink> became the difference between survival and starvation for all the people. The famine's severity and regional scope drove populations from <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H3667G' clickHandler>Canaan</jLink>, <jLink data-type='L' data-strong='H0758I' clickHandler>Syria</jLink>, and other neighboring territories to seek relief in <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H4714H' clickHandler>Egypt</jLink>, where <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H3130G' clickHandler>Joseph</jLink>'s administrative foresight had created the only reliable food supply in the ancient Near East during this period of widespread agricultural failure. <jPara></jPara> <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H3130G' clickHandler>Joseph</jLink>'s management of the famine demonstrated both his administrative genius and his understanding of economic principles, as he initially sold grain to both <jLink data-type='L' data-strong='H4714G' clickHandler>Egyptians</jLink> and foreigners for silver, then accepted livestock when money was exhausted, and finally acquired land for <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H6547H' clickHandler>Pharaoh</jLink> when all other assets were depleted. This systematic approach resulted in <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H6547H' clickHandler>Pharaoh</jLink> gaining ownership of virtually all privately held land in <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H4714H' clickHandler>Egypt</jLink> except that belonging to the priests, while the people became tenant farmers obligated to provide one-fifth of their annual produce to the royal treasury. The famine's impact extended beyond immediate survival needs to reshape <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H4714H' clickHandler>Egypt</jLink>'s entire social and economic structure, concentrating land ownership under <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H6547H' clickHandler>Pharaoh</jLink>'s control and establishing a taxation system that would endure for generations. This crisis would ultimately bring <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H3130G' clickHandler>Joseph</jLink>'s own family from <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H3667G' clickHandler>Canaan</jLink> to <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H4714H' clickHandler>Egypt</jLink> in search of grain, setting the stage for the dramatic reunion with his brothers and the eventual settlement of all seventy members of <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='G2384G' clickHandler>Jacob</jLink>'s household in the land of <jLink data-type='L' data-strong='H1657G' clickHandler>Goshen</jLink>, thus fulfilling God's earlier promise to <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H0085' clickHandler>Abraham</jLink> that his descendants would sojourn in a foreign land for four hundred years.
events: 1878 BC: The seven years of abundance ended in <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H4714H' clickHandler>Egypt</jLink>
1878 BC: The seven-year famine began in <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H4714H' clickHandler>Egypt</jLink> and surrounding lands

1878 BC: <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H3130G' clickHandler>Joseph</jLink> opened grain storehouses and distributed stored reserves throughout <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H4714H' clickHandler>Egypt</jLink>
1878 BC: <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H3130G' clickHandler>Joseph</jLink> sold grain to <jLink data-type='L' data-strong='H4714G' clickHandler>Egyptians</jLink> and foreigners for silver

ChronologyEntries.desc: <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H3130G' clickHandler>Joseph</jLink>'s brothers visit <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H4714H' clickHandler>Egypt</jLink> twice
ChronologyEntries.article: 1877 BC:  <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H3130G' clickHandler>Joseph</jLink>'s brothers made two crucial journeys to <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H4714H' clickHandler>Egypt</jLink> in 1877 BC during the ongoing seven-year famine that had begun the previous year (Gen.42-45). During their first visit, ten of <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='G2384G' clickHandler>Jacob</jLink>'s sons (excluding <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H1144G' clickHandler>Benjamin</jLink>) traveled to <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H4714H' clickHandler>Egypt</jLink> to purchase grain, unknowingly encountering <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H3130G' clickHandler>Joseph</jLink>, who had risen to become <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H6547H' clickHandler>Pharaoh</jLink>'s vizier but whom they failed to recognize after twenty years of separation. <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H3130G' clickHandler>Joseph</jLink>, however, immediately recognized his brothers and chose to test their character by accusing them of being spies, imprisoning them for three days before releasing all except <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H8095G' clickHandler>Simeon</jLink>, whom he held as surety until they returned with their youngest brother <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H1144G' clickHandler>Benjamin</jLink> as proof of their honesty. The brothers returned to <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H3667G' clickHandler>Canaan</jLink> with grain but were distressed to discover that their payment silver had been secretly returned in their sacks, creating fear about their reception should they return to <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H4714H' clickHandler>Egypt</jLink>. <jPara></jPara> When the grain was exhausted and the famine persisted, <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='G2384G' clickHandler>Jacob</jLink> reluctantly permitted <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H1144G' clickHandler>Benjamin</jLink> to accompany his brothers on their second journey to <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H4714H' clickHandler>Egypt</jLink>, despite his fears of losing <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H7354' clickHandler>Rachel</jLink>'s remaining son as he believed he had lost <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H3130G' clickHandler>Joseph</jLink>. Upon their arrival, <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H3130G' clickHandler>Joseph</jLink> hosted them with unexpected hospitality, released <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H8095G' clickHandler>Simeon</jLink>, and tested them further by secretly placing his silver cup in <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H1144G' clickHandler>Benjamin</jLink>'s sack before accusing them of theft. When Judah offered himself as a substitute for <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H1144G' clickHandler>Benjamin</jLink>, demonstrating the brothers' transformed character and genuine concern for their father's wellbeing, <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H3130G' clickHandler>Joseph</jLink> was overcome with emotion and revealed his true identity, declaring "I am <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H3130G' clickHandler>Joseph</jLink>! Is my father still alive?" This dramatic revelation led to reconciliation between the brothers and <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H3130G' clickHandler>Joseph</jLink>'s invitation for the entire family to relocate to <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H4714H' clickHandler>Egypt</jLink>, where he promised to provide for them during the remaining five years of famine.
events: 1877 BC: Ten of <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='G2384G' clickHandler>Jacob</jLink>'s sons traveled from <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H3667G' clickHandler>Canaan</jLink> to <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H4714H' clickHandler>Egypt</jLink> excluding <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H1144G' clickHandler>Benjamin</jLink> to purchase grain

1877 BC: <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='G2384G' clickHandler>Jacob</jLink> reluctantly permitted <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H1144G' clickHandler>Benjamin</jLink> to accompany his brothers to <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H4714H' clickHandler>Egypt</jLink>

1877 BC: <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H3130G' clickHandler>Joseph</jLink> released <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H8095G' clickHandler>Simeon</jLink> when his brothers arrived with <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H1144G' clickHandler>Benjamin</jLink>

ChronologyEntries.desc: <jChronDurationLink style='color:red'>▼</jChronDurationLink><jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H4714H' clickHandler>Egypt</jLink> - new home for <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='G2384G' clickHandler>Jacob</jLink>'s family
ChronologyEntries.article: 1876 BC:  <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='G2384G' clickHandler>Jacob</jLink>, also known as Israel, migrated with his entire household to <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H4714H' clickHandler>Egypt</jLink> in 1876 BC after receiving confirmation that his beloved son <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H3130G' clickHandler>Joseph</jLink> was not only alive but had become the second most powerful man in <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H4714H' clickHandler>Egypt</jLink> (Gen.46:1-47:11; Exo.1:1-7). This momentous relocation occurred during the third year of the seven-year famine that had devastated <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H3667G' clickHandler>Canaan</jLink> and the surrounding region, compelling <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='G2384G' clickHandler>Jacob</jLink> to accept <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H3130G' clickHandler>Joseph</jLink>'s invitation to settle in <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H4714H' clickHandler>Egypt</jLink> where food security was guaranteed through <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H3130G' clickHandler>Joseph</jLink>'s administrative foresight. Before departing from <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H3667G' clickHandler>Canaan</jLink>, <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='G2384G' clickHandler>Jacob</jLink> stopped at <jLink data-type='L' data-strong='H0884' clickHandler>Beersheba</jLink> to offer sacrifices to God, where he received divine reassurance in a vision that this journey to <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H4714H' clickHandler>Egypt</jLink> was part of God's providential plan, with the promise that God would make his descendants into a great nation there and eventually bring them back to the promised land. <jPara></jPara> The migration involved seventy persons from <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='G2384G' clickHandler>Jacob</jLink>'s household, representing a significant demographic movement that would establish the foundation for the future nation of Israel during its four-hundred-year sojourn in <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H4714H' clickHandler>Egypt</jLink>. Upon arrival, <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H3130G' clickHandler>Joseph</jLink> arranged for his family to settle in the land of <jLink data-type='L' data-strong='H1657G' clickHandler>Goshen</jLink>, a fertile region in the eastern <jLink data-type='L' data-strong='H2975G' clickHandler>Nile</jLink> Delta that was ideal for their livestock and pastoral lifestyle, while also keeping them somewhat separated from <jLink data-type='L' data-strong='H4714G' clickHandler>Egyptian</jLink> society. <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H6547H' clickHandler>Pharaoh</jLink> personally welcomed <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='G2384G' clickHandler>Jacob</jLink> and granted official permission for the settlement, even appointing some of <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='G2384G' clickHandler>Jacob</jLink>'s sons as chief herdsmen over the royal livestock due to their expertise with animals. The historical context of Middle Kingdom <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H4714H' clickHandler>Egypt</jLink> (c. 1876 BC) under strong pharaohs like Senusret II and III provided the stable administrative framework that made such arrangements possible, as this period was characterized by centralized governance, agricultural prosperity, and relative openness to Semitic-speaking peoples from <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H3667G' clickHandler>Canaan</jLink> who could contribute to <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H4714H' clickHandler>Egypt</jLink>'s economy.
events: 1876 BC: <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='G2384G' clickHandler>Jacob</jLink> learned <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H3130G' clickHandler>Joseph</jLink> was alive and the second most powerful man in <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H4714H' clickHandler>Egypt</jLink>

1876 BC: <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='G2384G' clickHandler>Jacob</jLink> accepted <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H3130G' clickHandler>Joseph</jLink>'s invitation to settle in <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H4714H' clickHandler>Egypt</jLink>

1876 BC: <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='G2384G' clickHandler>Jacob</jLink> received divine reassurance at <jLink data-type='L' data-strong='H0884' clickHandler>Beersheba</jLink> before departing <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H3667G' clickHandler>Canaan</jLink>

1876 BC: <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='G2384G' clickHandler>Jacob</jLink> migrated with seventy household members from <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H3667G' clickHandler>Canaan</jLink> to <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H4714H' clickHandler>Egypt</jLink>
1876 BC: <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H3130G' clickHandler>Joseph</jLink> arranged for his family to settle in <jLink data-type='L' data-strong='H1657G' clickHandler>Goshen</jLink>

ChronologyEntries.article: 1859 BC:  <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='G2384G' clickHandler>Jacob</jLink> died in <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H4714H' clickHandler>Egypt</jLink> at the age of 147 years, concluding a life that had spanned from the patriarchal period in <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H3667G' clickHandler>Canaan</jLink> through the family's settlement in <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H4714H' clickHandler>Egypt</jLink> during <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H3130G' clickHandler>Joseph</jLink>'s administration (Gen.47:28-49; 50:1-21). During his final years in <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H4714H' clickHandler>Egypt</jLink>, <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='G2384G' clickHandler>Jacob</jLink> experienced both the satisfaction of reunion with his beloved son <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H3130G' clickHandler>Joseph</jLink> and the prosperity of seeing his family multiply in the fertile land of <jLink data-type='L' data-strong='H1657G' clickHandler>Goshen</jLink>, living seventeen years beyond the family's arrival in <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H4714H' clickHandler>Egypt</jLink>. Before his death, <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='G2384G' clickHandler>Jacob</jLink> summoned his twelve sons to receive his final blessings and prophecies concerning their future tribal destinies, including his significant pronouncement that the scepter would not depart from Judah until the coming of <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H7886' clickHandler>Shiloh</jLink>, establishing the messianic lineage through the tribe of Judah rather than through the firstborn <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H7205' clickHandler>Reuben</jLink>, who had forfeited his birthright. <jPara></jPara> <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='G2384G' clickHandler>Jacob</jLink>'s deathbed instructions emphasized his desire to be buried with his ancestors in the cave of <jLink data-type='L' data-strong='H4375' clickHandler>Machpelah</jLink> in <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H3667G' clickHandler>Canaan</jLink>, the burial site that <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H0085' clickHandler>Abraham</jLink> had purchased from <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H6085G' clickHandler>Ephron</jLink> the <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H2845' clickHandler>Hittite</jLink> for four hundred shekels of silver, where <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H0085' clickHandler>Abraham</jLink>, <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H8283' clickHandler>Sarah</jLink>, <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H3327' clickHandler>Isaac</jLink>, and <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H7259' clickHandler>Rebekah</jLink> were already interred. <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H3130G' clickHandler>Joseph</jLink> mourned his father's death according to both Hebrew and <jLink data-type='L' data-strong='H4714G' clickHandler>Egyptian</jLink> customs, with the grief period extending for seventy days as befitted a person of high standing in <jLink data-type='L' data-strong='H4714G' clickHandler>Egyptian</jLink> society. The patriarch's death marked not only the end of the founding generation of the twelve tribes but also the conclusion of the period when the Hebrew people maintained direct personal connection to the promised land, as subsequent generations would be born and raised in <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H4714H' clickHandler>Egypt</jLink> during the centuries leading to their eventual enslavement and the Exodus under <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H4872' clickHandler>Moses</jLink>.
events: 1859 BC: <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='G2384G' clickHandler>Jacob</jLink> blessed his twelve sons and pronounced the scepter would remain with Judah until <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H7886' clickHandler>Shiloh</jLink> comes
1859 BC: <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='G2384G' clickHandler>Jacob</jLink> established the messianic lineage through Judah and blessed his twelve sons
1859 BC: <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='G2384G' clickHandler>Jacob</jLink> died in <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H4714H' clickHandler>Egypt</jLink> at age 147

1859 BC: <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H3130G' clickHandler>Joseph</jLink> mourned <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='G2384G' clickHandler>Jacob</jLink>'s death with a seventy-day Hebrew and <jLink data-type='L' data-strong='H4714G' clickHandler>Egyptian</jLink> grief period

ChronologyEntries.desc: <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='G2384G' clickHandler>Jacob</jLink> entombed in <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H3667G' clickHandler>Canaan</jLink>
ChronologyEntries.article: 1857 BC:  <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='G2384G' clickHandler>Jacob</jLink>'s burial in <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H3667G' clickHandler>Canaan</jLink> followed an elaborate funeral procession from <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H4714H' clickHandler>Egypt</jLink> to the cave of <jLink data-type='L' data-strong='H4375' clickHandler>Machpelah</jLink> near <jLink data-type='L' data-strong='H2275A' clickHandler>Hebron</jLink> (Gen.50:4-14). After the seventy-day mourning period in <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H4714H' clickHandler>Egypt</jLink>, <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H3130G' clickHandler>Joseph</jLink> requested permission from <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H6547H' clickHandler>Pharaoh</jLink> to fulfill his father's dying wish by transporting <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='G2384G' clickHandler>Jacob</jLink>'s embalmed body to the ancestral burial site in <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H3667G' clickHandler>Canaan</jLink>. The funeral cortege included not only <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H3130G' clickHandler>Joseph</jLink> and his brothers but also <jLink data-type='L' data-strong='H4714G' clickHandler>Egyptian</jLink> officials, elders, and military escorts, demonstrating the high regard in which <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='G2384G' clickHandler>Jacob</jLink> was held due to <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H3130G' clickHandler>Joseph</jLink>'s position in the <jLink data-type='L' data-strong='H4714G' clickHandler>Egyptian</jLink> government and creating a procession so impressive that the <jLink data-type='L' data-strong='H3667A' clickHandler>Canaanites</jLink> named the mourning site <jLink data-type='L' data-strong='H0329G' clickHandler>Abel-mizraim</jLink>, meaning "meadow of <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H4714H' clickHandler>Egypt</jLink>.". <jPara></jPara> The burial ceremony at <jLink data-type='L' data-strong='H4375' clickHandler>Machpelah</jLink> represented both the fulfillment of <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='G2384G' clickHandler>Jacob</jLink>'s final request and a powerful affirmation of the family's enduring connection to the promised land despite their current residence in <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H4714H' clickHandler>Egypt</jLink>. This cave, originally purchased by <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H0085' clickHandler>Abraham</jLink> as the first piece of legally owned property in <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H3667G' clickHandler>Canaan</jLink>, served as a tangible link to God's covenant promises regarding land inheritance for <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H0085' clickHandler>Abraham</jLink>'s descendants. The elaborate nature of <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='G2384G' clickHandler>Jacob</jLink>'s burial, involving <jLink data-type='L' data-strong='H4714G' clickHandler>Egyptian</jLink> embalming techniques and a large international funeral procession, illustrates the cultural synthesis that had occurred during the Hebrew family's residence in <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H4714H' clickHandler>Egypt</jLink> while maintaining their distinct identity and covenant obligations. Following the burial, <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H3130G' clickHandler>Joseph</jLink> and his brothers returned to <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H4714H' clickHandler>Egypt</jLink>, where they would continue to prosper until a new pharaoh arose "who did not know <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H3130G' clickHandler>Joseph</jLink>," setting the stage for the eventual enslavement of the Hebrew people that would necessitate their deliverance under <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H4872' clickHandler>Moses</jLink> centuries later.
events: 1857 BC: <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H3130G' clickHandler>Joseph</jLink> requested <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H6547H' clickHandler>Pharaoh</jLink>'s permission to transport <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='G2384G' clickHandler>Jacob</jLink>'s body to <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H3667G' clickHandler>Canaan</jLink>

1857 BC: <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H3130G' clickHandler>Joseph</jLink> led an elaborate funeral procession carrying <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='G2384G' clickHandler>Jacob</jLink>'s body to <jLink data-type='L' data-strong='H4375' clickHandler>Machpelah</jLink> cave near <jLink data-type='L' data-strong='H2275A' clickHandler>Hebron</jLink>

1857 BC: The procession mourned at <jLink data-type='L' data-strong='H0329G' clickHandler>Atad</jLink> east of <jLink data-type='L' data-strong='H3383' clickHandler>Jordan</jLink> where <jLink data-type='L' data-strong='H3667A' clickHandler>Canaanites</jLink> named the site <jLink data-type='L' data-strong='H0329G' clickHandler>Abel-mizraim</jLink>

1857 BC: <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='G2384G' clickHandler>Jacob</jLink> was buried in <jLink data-type='L' data-strong='H4375' clickHandler>Machpelah</jLink> cave near <jLink data-type='L' data-strong='H2275A' clickHandler>Hebron</jLink>

ChronologyEntries.article: 1805 BC:  <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H3130G' clickHandler>Joseph</jLink> died in <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H4714H' clickHandler>Egypt</jLink> in 1805 BC at the age of 110 years, concluding a remarkable life that had transformed from slavery to becoming <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H6547H' clickHandler>Pharaoh</jLink>'s vizier and preserving both <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H4714H' clickHandler>Egypt</jLink> and his own family during seven years of severe famine (Gen.50:22-26). Before his death, <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H3130G' clickHandler>Joseph</jLink> reassured his brothers that God would fulfill His covenant promises to bring the <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H3478' clickHandler>Israelites</jLink> out of <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H4714H' clickHandler>Egypt</jLink> and into the land promised to <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H0085' clickHandler>Abraham</jLink>, <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H3327' clickHandler>Isaac</jLink>, and <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='G2384G' clickHandler>Jacob</jLink>, demonstrating his unwavering faith in divine faithfulness despite decades of residence in a foreign land. <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H3130G' clickHandler>Joseph</jLink>'s final request that his bones be carried out of <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H4714H' clickHandler>Egypt</jLink> when God accomplished this deliverance reflected both his confidence in the eventual exodus and his desire to be buried in the promised land alongside his ancestors. <jPara></jPara> <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H3130G' clickHandler>Joseph</jLink>'s death occurred during <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H4714H' clickHandler>Egypt</jLink>'s Second Intermediate Period, a time of political fragmentation following the decline of the Middle Kingdom and the rise of the Hyksos in northern <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H4714H' clickHandler>Egypt</jLink>. This transitional era, characterized by weakened central authority and increasing foreign influence, provided the historical context for <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H3130G' clickHandler>Joseph</jLink>'s rise to power and the initial prosperity of the Hebrew people in <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H4714H' clickHandler>Egypt</jLink>. His passing marked the end of direct Hebrew access to <jLink data-type='L' data-strong='H4714G' clickHandler>Egyptian</jLink> royal favor and began a period during which the memory of <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H3130G' clickHandler>Joseph</jLink>'s contributions would gradually fade from <jLink data-type='L' data-strong='H4714G' clickHandler>Egyptian</jLink> consciousness, setting the stage for the dramatic reversal of Hebrew fortunes that would occur centuries later under a new pharaoh who "did not know <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H3130G' clickHandler>Joseph</jLink>.".
events: 1805 BC: <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H3130G' clickHandler>Joseph</jLink> requested his bones be taken from <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H4714H' clickHandler>Egypt</jLink> when God delivers the <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H3478' clickHandler>Israelites</jLink>
1805 BC: <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H3130G' clickHandler>Joseph</jLink> died in <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H4714H' clickHandler>Egypt</jLink> at age 110

ChronologyEntries.article: 1789 BC:  <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H3878' clickHandler>Levi</jLink> died, marking the passing of <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='G2384G' clickHandler>Jacob</jLink>'s third son and one of the final links to the patriarchal generation that had witnessed both the family's descent into <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H4714H' clickHandler>Egypt</jLink> and <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H3130G' clickHandler>Joseph</jLink>'s extraordinary rise to power (Exo.6:16). As the progenitor of the <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H3878' clickHandler>Levites</jLink>, <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H3878' clickHandler>Levi</jLink>'s death carried profound significance for the future religious structure of Israel, since his descendants would eventually be set apart as the priestly tribe responsible for temple service, religious instruction, and the maintenance of covenant worship practices. Despite his earlier involvement with <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H8095G' clickHandler>Simeon</jLink> in the violent revenge against <jLink data-type='L' data-strong='H7927G' clickHandler>Shechem</jLink>, which had earned <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='G2384G' clickHandler>Jacob</jLink>'s rebuke, <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H3878' clickHandler>Levi</jLink>'s tribal legacy would ultimately be transformed into a blessing through his descendants' sacred calling. <jPara></jPara> <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H3878' clickHandler>Levi</jLink>'s death occurred sixteen years after <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H3130G' clickHandler>Joseph</jLink>'s passing and approximately 257 years before the onset of Israel's oppression in <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H4714H' clickHandler>Egypt</jLink>, representing the gradual transition from the generation that had personally experienced God's covenant promises to their descendants who would face slavery and eventual deliverance. The timing of his death during the continuing prosperity of the Hebrew people in <jLink data-type='L' data-strong='H1657G' clickHandler>Goshen</jLink> underscores the lengthy period of favor that followed <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H3130G' clickHandler>Joseph</jLink>'s administration, during which the <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H3478' clickHandler>Israelites</jLink> multiplied significantly and became established as a distinct community within <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H4714H' clickHandler>Egypt</jLink>. This demographic growth, facilitated by the peaceful conditions during <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H3878' clickHandler>Levi</jLink>'s lifetime and beyond, would ultimately contribute to the <jLink data-type='L' data-strong='H4714G' clickHandler>Egyptian</jLink> perception of the <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H3478' clickHandler>Israelites</jLink> as a potential threat that would justify their later oppression.
events: 1789 BC: <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H3878' clickHandler>Levi</jLink> died in <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H4714H' clickHandler>Egypt</jLink>, marking the passing of <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='G2384G' clickHandler>Jacob</jLink>'s third son and one of the last patriarchal links.

ChronologyEntries.article: 1532 BC:  When forced labor failed to diminish the Hebrew population, <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H6547H' clickHandler>Pharaoh</jLink> escalated his persecution by commanding the Hebrew midwives <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H8236' clickHandler>Shiphrah</jLink> and <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H6326' clickHandler>Puah</jLink> to kill all newborn Hebrew boys while allowing girls to live, attempting to eliminate the next generation of Hebrew males who could pose a military threat. The midwives' courageous refusal to obey this genocidal order, motivated by their fear of God, frustrated <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H6547H' clickHandler>Pharaoh</jLink>'s plan and led to his final decree that all <jLink data-type='L' data-strong='H4714G' clickHandler>Egyptians</jLink> should throw Hebrew male infants into the <jLink data-type='L' data-strong='H2975G' clickHandler>Nile</jLink> River. <jPara></jPara> This period of oppression occurred during <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H4714H' clickHandler>Egypt</jLink>'s transition from the Second Intermediate Period to the New Kingdom, when pharaohs like Ahmose I were consolidating power after expelling the Hyksos rulers and may have viewed any Semitic population with suspicion due to their association with the former foreign occupiers.
events: 1532 BC: <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H6547H' clickHandler>Pharaoh</jLink> of <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H4714H' clickHandler>Egypt</jLink> commanded Hebrew midwives <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H8236' clickHandler>Shiphrah</jLink> and <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H6326' clickHandler>Puah</jLink> to kill all newborn Hebrew male babies during delivery.

ChronologyEntries.article: 1529 BC:  <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H0175' clickHandler>Aaron</jLink> was born in 1529 BC as the brother of <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H4872' clickHandler>Moses</jLink> and <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H4813G' clickHandler>Miriam</jLink>, entering the world during the third year of Israel's oppression under the pharaoh who sought to eliminate Hebrew male infants through drowning in the <jLink data-type='L' data-strong='H2975G' clickHandler>Nile</jLink> River. His birth occurred at a time when Hebrew families faced the constant terror of losing their sons to <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H6547H' clickHandler>Pharaoh</jLink>'s genocidal decree, making the preservation of any Hebrew male child an act of both courage and faith on the part of his parents. <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H0175' clickHandler>Aaron</jLink>'s survival during this period of systematic infanticide positioned him to play a crucial role in God's future plan for Israel's deliverance, though this divine purpose remained hidden during the dangerous early years of his life. <jPara></jPara> <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H0175' clickHandler>Aaron</jLink> would later emerge as the first high priest of Israel and serve as <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H4872' clickHandler>Moses</jLink>' spokesman and partner in confronting <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H6547H' clickHandler>Pharaoh</jLink> and leading the <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H3478' clickHandler>Israelites</jLink> out of <jLink data-type='L' data-strong='H4714G' clickHandler>Egyptian</jLink> bondage, roles that would establish him as one of the most significant figures in Hebrew religious history. His birth three years into the oppression period represents God's providential preparation of leadership for the eventual exodus, demonstrating how divine plans unfold even during the darkest periods of persecution. The timing of <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H0175' clickHandler>Aaron</jLink>'s arrival, when Hebrew survival seemed most precarious, foreshadows the theological theme that God raises up deliverers during times of greatest need and that His covenant faithfulness persists even through centuries of suffering.
events: 1529 BC: <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H0175' clickHandler>Aaron</jLink> was born in <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H4714H' clickHandler>Egypt</jLink> as the brother of <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H4872' clickHandler>Moses</jLink> and <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H4813G' clickHandler>Miriam</jLink> during Hebrew oppression.

ChronologyEntries.desc: <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H6547I' clickHandler>Pharoah</jLink> kills male babies
ChronologyEntries.article: 1528 BC:  In 1528 BC, the ruling <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H6547H' clickHandler>Pharaoh</jLink> of <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H4714H' clickHandler>Egypt</jLink> issued a devastating decree commanding the death of all male Hebrew babies (Exo.1:15-22). This oppressive measure was implemented in response to the rapidly growing population of the <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H3478' clickHandler>Israelites</jLink> in <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H4714H' clickHandler>Egypt</jLink>, which the <jLink data-type='L' data-strong='H4714G' clickHandler>Egyptian</jLink> leadership perceived as a significant threat to their security and dominance over the region. The decree specifically targeted male infants while allowing female children to survive, representing a calculated attempt to weaken the Hebrew people by preventing the birth of future warriors and leaders. <jPara></jPara> This royal edict established the historical context for the extraordinary events that would follow, including the miraculous preservation of <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H4872' clickHandler>Moses</jLink> two years later in 1526 BC. The decree reflects the increasing tension between the <jLink data-type='L' data-strong='H4714G' clickHandler>Egyptian</jLink> authorities and the Hebrew population, setting in motion the circumstances that would eventually lead to the Exodus narrative. The policy demonstrates the systematic nature of <jLink data-type='L' data-strong='H4714G' clickHandler>Egyptian</jLink> oppression against the <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H3478' clickHandler>Israelites</jLink> during this period of their bondage.
events: 1528 BC: <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H6547H' clickHandler>Pharaoh</jLink> commanded all <jLink data-type='L' data-strong='H4714G' clickHandler>Egyptians</jLink> to throw every newborn Hebrew boy into the <jLink data-type='L' data-strong='H2975G' clickHandler>Nile</jLink> River while allowing girls to live.

ChronologyEntries.article: 1526 BC:  <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H4872' clickHandler>Moses</jLink> was born in 1526 BC during the height of <jLink data-type='L' data-strong='H4714G' clickHandler>Egyptian</jLink> persecution against the Hebrew people, just two years after <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H6547H' clickHandler>Pharaoh</jLink>'s decree to kill all Hebrew male infants. <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H4872' clickHandler>Moses</jLink>' mother courageously hid him for three months to protect him from the royal death sentence (Exo.2:1-10). When concealment was no longer possible, she placed the infant in a waterproofed basket and set it among the reeds along the bank of the <jLink data-type='L' data-strong='H2975G' clickHandler>Nile</jLink> River, with <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H4872' clickHandler>Moses</jLink>' sister positioned nearby to observe the outcome. <jPara></jPara> In a remarkable turn of providence, <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H6547H' clickHandler>Pharaoh</jLink>'s daughter discovered the basket while bathing and took pity on the crying child, deciding to adopt him despite recognizing he was Hebrew. <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H4872' clickHandler>Moses</jLink>' sister approached and offered to find a Hebrew woman to nurse the baby, resulting in <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H4872' clickHandler>Moses</jLink>' own mother being employed to care for him during his early years. When <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H4872' clickHandler>Moses</jLink> was older, he was formally brought to <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H6547H' clickHandler>Pharaoh</jLink>'s daughter and became her son, receiving his name because she "drew him out of the water." This dramatic rescue established <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H4872' clickHandler>Moses</jLink> as a figure who would bridge both <jLink data-type='L' data-strong='H4714G' clickHandler>Egyptian</jLink> and Hebrew cultures, positioning him uniquely for his future role as the deliverer of Israel.
events: 1526 BC: <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H4872' clickHandler>Moses</jLink> was born to Hebrew parents in <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H4714H' clickHandler>Egypt</jLink> during severe persecution.

1526 BC: <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H4872' clickHandler>Moses</jLink>' mother concealed him for three months in <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H4714H' clickHandler>Egypt</jLink> to protect him from <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H6547H' clickHandler>Pharaoh</jLink>'s death sentence.

1526 BC: <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H4872' clickHandler>Moses</jLink>' mother placed him in a waterproofed basket among the reeds of the <jLink data-type='L' data-strong='H2975G' clickHandler>Nile</jLink> River in <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H4714H' clickHandler>Egypt</jLink>, where <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H6547H' clickHandler>Pharaoh</jLink>'s daughter found and pitied him.

ChronologyEntries.article: 1491 BC:  <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H3091G' clickHandler>Joshua</jLink> was born during a period when the <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H3478' clickHandler>Israelites</jLink> remained under severe <jLink data-type='L' data-strong='H4714G' clickHandler>Egyptian</jLink> oppression. His birth occurred in the generation that would witness both the intensification of Hebrew suffering and the early development of <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H4872' clickHandler>Moses</jLink>' leadership, experiences that would profoundly shape <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H3091G' clickHandler>Joshua</jLink>'s character and worldview. Growing up during this era of bondage, <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H3091G' clickHandler>Joshua</jLink>'s formative years were marked by the harsh realities of forced labor and the ongoing threat of <jLink data-type='L' data-strong='H4714G' clickHandler>Egyptian</jLink> persecution that had begun with <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H6547I' clickHandler>Pharaoh</jLink>'s infanticide decree decades earlier. <jPara></jPara> These challenging circumstances during <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H3091G' clickHandler>Joshua</jLink>'s youth would prove instrumental in preparing him for his eventual role as <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H4872' clickHandler>Moses</jLink>' successor and the leader who would guide the <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H3478' clickHandler>Israelites</jLink> into the Promised Land. The timing of his birth positioned <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H3091G' clickHandler>Joshua</jLink> to become part of the generation that would experience the Exodus and inherit the responsibility of conquering <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H3667G' clickHandler>Canaan</jLink>, making him a crucial bridge between the period of <jLink data-type='L' data-strong='H4714G' clickHandler>Egyptian</jLink> bondage and the establishment of Israel in their ancestral homeland.
events: 1491 BC: <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H3091G' clickHandler>Joshua</jLink> son of <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H5126' clickHandler>Nun</jLink> was born in <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H4714H' clickHandler>Egypt</jLink> to Hebrew parents during severe oppression.

ChronologyEntries.desc: <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H4872' clickHandler>Moses</jLink> flees to <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H4080G' clickHandler>Midian</jLink>
ChronologyEntries.article: 1486 BC:  In 1486 BC, <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H4872' clickHandler>Moses</jLink> fled <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H4714H' clickHandler>Egypt</jLink> after killing an <jLink data-type='L' data-strong='H4714G' clickHandler>Egyptian</jLink> taskmaster who was beating a Hebrew slave, an act that forced him into forty years of exile when <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H6547I' clickHandler>Pharaoh</jLink> sought his life (Exo.2:11-22). This pivotal event occurred when <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H4872' clickHandler>Moses</jLink> was forty years old, marking the end of his privileged life in <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H6547I' clickHandler>Pharaoh</jLink>'s household and the beginning of his preparation in the wilderness for his future calling as Israel's deliverer. Upon reaching the land of <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H4080G' clickHandler>Midian</jLink>, <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H4872' clickHandler>Moses</jLink> encountered seven daughters of <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H3503' clickHandler>Reuel</jLink> (also called <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H3503' clickHandler>Jethro</jLink>), the priest of <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H4080G' clickHandler>Midian</jLink>, at a well where he defended them from hostile shepherds and assisted them in watering their father's flock. <jPara></jPara> Impressed by <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H4872' clickHandler>Moses</jLink>' intervention and character, <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H3503' clickHandler>Jethro</jLink> invited him to remain with his family, leading to <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H4872' clickHandler>Moses</jLink>' marriage to <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H6855' clickHandler>Zipporah</jLink>, one of <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H3503' clickHandler>Jethro</jLink>'s daughters. This union produced a son named <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H1647G' clickHandler>Gershom</jLink>, whose name reflected <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H4872' clickHandler>Moses</jLink>' sense of being "a foreigner in a strange land." The forty-year period in <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H4080G' clickHandler>Midian</jLink> transformed <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H4872' clickHandler>Moses</jLink> from an impulsive young man into a seasoned shepherd and leader, while his relationship with <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H3503' clickHandler>Jethro</jLink>, an experienced priest and tribal leader, provided him with valuable wisdom about leadership and spiritual matters that would prove essential during the Exodus.
events: 1486 BC: <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H4872' clickHandler>Moses</jLink> killed an <jLink data-type='L' data-strong='H4714G' clickHandler>Egyptian</jLink> who was beating a Hebrew slave in <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H4714H' clickHandler>Egypt</jLink>.

1486 BC: <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H4872' clickHandler>Moses</jLink> escaped <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H4714H' clickHandler>Egypt</jLink> to avoid <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H6547I' clickHandler>Pharaoh</jLink>'s death sentence.

1486 BC: <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H4872' clickHandler>Moses</jLink> reached <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H4080G' clickHandler>Midian</jLink> during his flight from <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H4714H' clickHandler>Egypt</jLink> and protected <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H3503' clickHandler>Reuel</jLink>'s seven daughters at a well.

1486 BC: <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H4872' clickHandler>Moses</jLink> married <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H6855' clickHandler>Zipporah</jLink>, one of <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H3503' clickHandler>Reuel</jLink>'s daughters, in <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H4080G' clickHandler>Midian</jLink>.

1486 BC: <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H1647G' clickHandler>Gershom</jLink> was born to <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H4872' clickHandler>Moses</jLink> and <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H6855' clickHandler>Zipporah</jLink>, his name reflecting <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H4872' clickHandler>Moses</jLink> as "a foreigner in a strange land."

ChronologyEntries.article: 1485 BC:  <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H3612G' clickHandler>Caleb</jLink> was born in 1485 BC, during the height of <jLink data-type='L' data-strong='H4714G' clickHandler>Egyptian</jLink> oppression over the <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H3478' clickHandler>Israelites</jLink>. <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H3612G' clickHandler>Caleb</jLink> would later recount that he was forty years old when <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H4872' clickHandler>Moses</jLink> sent him from Kadesh-barnea as one of the twelve spies to scout the Promised Land, making his birth date approximately forty-five years before the Exodus (Jos.14:7; 14:10). His birth occurred during a generation that experienced the full severity of Hebrew bondage in <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H4714H' clickHandler>Egypt</jLink>, positioning him among those who would witness both the miraculous deliverance under <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H4872' clickHandler>Moses</jLink> and the eventual conquest of <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H3667G' clickHandler>Canaan</jLink>. <jPara></jPara> <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H3612G' clickHandler>Caleb</jLink>'s significance extends far beyond his birth year, as he became one of only two spies (alongside <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H3091G' clickHandler>Joshua</jLink>) who returned from <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H3667G' clickHandler>Canaan</jLink> with a faithful report, trusting in God's promise despite the formidable challenges ahead. God preserved <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H3612G' clickHandler>Caleb</jLink> throughout the wilderness wandering, allowing him to reach eighty-five years of age at the time of Israel's inheritance of the land (Jos.14:10). His longevity and unwavering faith made him a model of perseverance and divine blessing, ultimately earning him a special inheritance in the hill country of <jLink data-type='L' data-strong='H2275A' clickHandler>Hebron</jLink> as a reward for his faithful service to the Lord.
events: 1485 BC: <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H3612G' clickHandler>Caleb</jLink> son of <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H3312G' clickHandler>Jephunneh</jLink> was born in <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H4714H' clickHandler>Egypt</jLink> to Hebrew parents during oppression.

ChronologyEntries.desc: <jChronDurationLink style='color:red'>▼</jChronDurationLink>Wilderness where <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H4872' clickHandler>Moses</jLink> leads Israel
ChronologyEntries.article: 1446 BC:  The year 1446 BC marks one of the most pivotal events in Hebrew history: the Exodus from <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H4714H' clickHandler>Egypt</jLink> under <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H4872' clickHandler>Moses</jLink>' leadership, as detailed in Exodus chapters 3 through 39. This monumental deliverance began with God's appearance to <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H4872' clickHandler>Moses</jLink> in the burning bush at Mount <jLink data-type='L' data-strong='H5514G' clickHandler>Horeb</jLink>, where He commissioned the reluctant shepherd to confront <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H6547I' clickHandler>Pharaoh</jLink> and demand the release of the <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H3478' clickHandler>Israelites</jLink>. The narrative encompasses <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H4872' clickHandler>Moses</jLink>' initial resistance to his calling, his return to <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H4714H' clickHandler>Egypt</jLink> with his brother <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H0175' clickHandler>Aaron</jLink>, and their repeated confrontations with <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H6547I' clickHandler>Pharaoh</jLink>, who hardened his heart against releasing the Hebrew slaves. <jPara></jPara> The climax of this divine intervention came through ten devastating plagues that systematically dismantled <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H4714H' clickHandler>Egypt</jLink>'s power and religious system, culminating in the death of every firstborn in <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H4714H' clickHandler>Egypt</jLink> while the <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H3478' clickHandler>Israelites</jLink> were protected through the institution of the <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H6453' clickHandler>Passover</jLink>. Following this final catastrophe, <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H6547I' clickHandler>Pharaoh</jLink> expelled the <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H3478' clickHandler>Israelites</jLink>, who departed in haste with their possessions and <jLink data-type='L' data-strong='H4714G' clickHandler>Egyptian</jLink> wealth. The miraculous parting of the Red Sea allowed them to cross on dry ground while destroying <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H6547I' clickHandler>Pharaoh</jLink>'s pursuing army when the waters returned. This supernatural deliverance established the foundation for Israel's national identity and their covenant relationship with <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H3068G' clickHandler>Yahweh</jLink>, transforming them from slaves into a chosen people destined for the Promised Land.
events: 1446 BC: God appeared to <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H4872' clickHandler>Moses</jLink> in the burning bush at Mount <jLink data-type='L' data-strong='H5514G' clickHandler>Horeb</jLink> and commissioned him to lead the <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H3478' clickHandler>Israelites</jLink> out of <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H4714H' clickHandler>Egypt</jLink>, appointing <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H0175' clickHandler>Aaron</jLink> as his spokesman.

1446 BC: <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H4872' clickHandler>Moses</jLink> and <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H0175' clickHandler>Aaron</jLink> confronted <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H6547I' clickHandler>Pharaoh</jLink> in <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H4714H' clickHandler>Egypt</jLink> demanding the release of Hebrew slaves, but <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H6547I' clickHandler>Pharaoh</jLink> refused and increased their labor.

1446 BC: <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H4872' clickHandler>Moses</jLink> and <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H0175' clickHandler>Aaron</jLink> turned the <jLink data-type='L' data-strong='H2975G' clickHandler>Nile</jLink> and all water sources in <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H4714H' clickHandler>Egypt</jLink> to blood, but <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H6547I' clickHandler>Pharaoh</jLink>'s heart remained hardened.

1446 BC: Frogs covered <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H4714H' clickHandler>Egypt</jLink>, <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H6547I' clickHandler>Pharaoh</jLink> promised release but reneged after relief.

1446 BC: Dust became gnats in <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H4714H' clickHandler>Egypt</jLink>, magicians declared it "the finger of God" but <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H6547I' clickHandler>Pharaoh</jLink>'s heart remained hardened.

ChronologyEntries.desc: From <jLink data-type='L' data-strong='H5514G' clickHandler>Sinai</jLink> to the edge of <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H3667G' clickHandler>Canaan</jLink>
ChronologyEntries.article: 1445 BC:  Following the completion and dedication of the Tabernacle at Mount <jLink data-type='L' data-strong='H5514G' clickHandler>Sinai</jLink> in 1445 BC, the <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H3478' clickHandler>Israelites</jLink> began their anticipated journey toward the Promised Land (Exo.40 through Num.14). This period marked a crucial transition from the law-giving and covenant-making phase at <jLink data-type='L' data-strong='H5514G' clickHandler>Sinai</jLink> to the practical preparation for conquest and settlement in <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H3667G' clickHandler>Canaan</jLink>. The journey commenced with a comprehensive census that organized the twelve tribes around the central Tabernacle, with the <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H3878' clickHandler>Levites</jLink> receiving special assignments for transporting and maintaining the sacred structure. Additional laws governing purity, offerings, and community conduct were established to maintain order and holiness as the nation prepared for both travel and warfare. <jPara></jPara> The expedition progressed under divine guidance through the pillar of cloud and fire, but was marked by repeated complaints about hardships, food, and leadership challenges that tested <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H4872' clickHandler>Moses</jLink>' authority. The most significant crisis occurred when twelve spies were sent to reconnoiter <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H3667G' clickHandler>Canaan</jLink> from Kadesh-barnea, with ten returning to deliver a discouraging report that emphasized the strength of the inhabitants and the impossibility of conquest. Only <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H3612G' clickHandler>Caleb</jLink> and <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H3091G' clickHandler>Joshua</jLink> maintained faith in God's promise, urging the people to proceed with confidence in divine assistance. The nation's rejection of their faithful counsel and refusal to enter the land resulted in God's decree that the entire adult generation, except for <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H3612G' clickHandler>Caleb</jLink> and <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H3091G' clickHandler>Joshua</jLink>, would die in the wilderness before their children could inherit the promise.
events: 1445 BC: Israel and the mixed multitude journeyed to Mount <jLink data-type='L' data-strong='H5514G' clickHandler>Sinai</jLink>.
1445 BC: The <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H3478' clickHandler>Israelites</jLink> complained about lack of water and meat and received a flock of quail.
1445 BC: Manna began to be given for daily food.

1445 BC: <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H4872' clickHandler>Moses</jLink> ascended Mount <jLink data-type='L' data-strong='H5514G' clickHandler>Sinai</jLink> to collect the Ten Commandments on two tablets.
1445 BC: All except the tribe of <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H3878' clickHandler>Levi</jLink> worshipped a golden calf while waiting.
