ChronologyEntries.article: 1444 BC:  The year 1444 BC initiated the prolonged period of wilderness wandering that would extend for forty years, as divine judgment upon Israel's faithlessness at the border of <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H3667G' clickHandler>Canaan</jLink>, with the relevant laws and experiences (Num.15:1-19:22). This phase began immediately after God's decree that the current generation would not enter the Promised Land due to their lack of faith and rebellion against His promise. During this extended period, God continued to provide laws and regulations to govern community life, including detailed instructions regarding offerings, procedures for atonement of unintentional sins, and guidelines for maintaining ritual purity in the camp. <jPara></jPara> The wilderness years were characterized by both divine provision and recurring episodes of rebellion that demonstrated the consequences of disobedience while preparing the next generation for eventual inheritance of <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H3667G' clickHandler>Canaan</jLink>. This period served as both punishment and preparation, as the <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H3478' clickHandler>Israelites</jLink> learned dependence upon God through daily provision of manna, water from rocks, and protection from enemies, while the rebellious generation gradually died off as decreed. The ongoing development of Israel's legal and religious framework during their nomadic existence, established precedents for worship, community governance, and covenant faithfulness (Num.15:1-19:22). These would guide them when they finally entered the Promised Land under <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H3091G' clickHandler>Joshua</jLink>'s leadership.
events: 1444 BC: A man gathering sticks on the <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H7676' clickHandler>Sabbath</jLink> was stoned to death outside the camp.

1444 BC: <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H0175' clickHandler>Aaron</jLink> and <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H4813G' clickHandler>Miriam</jLink> revolted against <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H4872' clickHandler>Moses</jLink> and his <jLink data-type='L' data-strong='H3568A' clickHandler>Kushite</jLink> wife, and <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H4813G' clickHandler>Miriam</jLink> was punished with temporary leprosy.

ChronologyEntries.article: 1426 BC:  The most serious challenge to <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H4872' clickHandler>Moses</jLink>' leadership occured during this journey. The primary rebellion was led by <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H7141I' clickHandler>Korah</jLink>, a <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H3878' clickHandler>Levite</jLink>, along with <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H1885' clickHandler>Dathan</jLink> and <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H0048G' clickHandler>Abiram</jLink> from the tribe of <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H7205' clickHandler>Reuben</jLink>, who were joined by 250 prominent community leaders in directly challenging the exclusive authority of <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H4872' clickHandler>Moses</jLink> and <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H0175' clickHandler>Aaron</jLink>. These rebels accused <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H4872' clickHandler>Moses</jLink> and <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H0175' clickHandler>Aaron</jLink> of exalting themselves above the Lord's congregation and questioned their monopoly on leadership and priestly functions, representing both a political and religious revolt against the established order. <jPara></jPara> Divine intervention provided a dramatic resolution to this crisis, as God caused the earth to open and swallow <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H7141I' clickHandler>Korah</jLink>, <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H1885' clickHandler>Dathan</jLink>, <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H0048G' clickHandler>Abiram</jLink>, and their households alive, while simultaneously sending fire to consume the 250 men who had offered unauthorized incense. When the entire <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H3478' clickHandler>Israelite</jLink> community grumbled the following day, blaming <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H4872' clickHandler>Moses</jLink> and <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H0175' clickHandler>Aaron</jLink> for these deaths, a plague broke out among the people that was only halted when <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H0175' clickHandler>Aaron</jLink> interceded with incense between the living and the dead. To permanently establish <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H0175' clickHandler>Aaron</jLink>'s divine appointment as high priest, God caused <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H0175' clickHandler>Aaron</jLink>'s staff to miraculously bud, blossom, and produce almonds overnight, distinguishing it from the staffs of all other tribal leaders and serving as an enduring sign of his chosen status. This series of supernatural judgments effectively silenced opposition to <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H4872' clickHandler>Moses</jLink>' leadership and confirmed the divinely ordained structure of Israel's religious and civil authority.
events: 1426 BC: <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H7141I' clickHandler>Korah</jLink>, <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H1885' clickHandler>Dathan</jLink>, and <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H0048G' clickHandler>Abiram</jLink> led a rebellion against <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H4872' clickHandler>Moses</jLink> and <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H0175' clickHandler>Aaron</jLink>, and the earth swallowed them and their households while fire consumed 250 men offering unauthorized incense.

1426 BC: God sent a plague among the <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H3478' clickHandler>Israelites</jLink> after the rebellion, and <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H4872' clickHandler>Moses</jLink> and <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H0175' clickHandler>Aaron</jLink> interceded to stop it, but 14,700 <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H3478' clickHandler>Israelites</jLink> died.
1426 BC: <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H0175' clickHandler>Aaron</jLink>'s staff budded, blossomed, and produced almonds in the Tabernacle as a sign of his priestly authority.

ChronologyEntries.desc: Water from a rock at <jLink data-type='L' data-strong='H6946G' clickHandler>Kadesh</jLink> (<jLink data-type='L' data-strong='H4809H' clickHandler>Meribah</jLink>)
ChronologyEntries.article: 1408 BC:  In 1408 BC, while the <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H3478' clickHandler>Israelites</jLink> were encamped at <jLink data-type='L' data-strong='H6946G' clickHandler>Kadesh</jLink>, a severe water shortage led to renewed complaints against <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H4872' clickHandler>Moses</jLink> and <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H0175' clickHandler>Aaron</jLink>'s leadership (Num.20:1-13). The people expressed their frustration by questioning why they had been brought into the wilderness to die and lamenting their departure from <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H4714H' clickHandler>Egypt</jLink>, where they had enjoyed abundant water, figs, grapes, and pomegranates. In response to their crisis, God instructed <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H4872' clickHandler>Moses</jLink> to take his staff, gather the assembly, and speak to a specific rock to bring forth water for both the people and their livestock. <jPara></jPara> However, <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H4872' clickHandler>Moses</jLink> acted in disobedience to God's explicit command by striking the rock twice with his staff instead of merely speaking to it, an action that demonstrated a lack of trust in God's word and failed to properly sanctify the Lord before the people. Although water abundantly flowed from the rock, providing for the community's immediate needs, this act of disobedience resulted in the most severe consequence imaginable for <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H4872' clickHandler>Moses</jLink> and <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H0175' clickHandler>Aaron</jLink>: both leaders were barred from entering the Promised Land. The location was subsequently named <jLink data-type='L' data-strong='H4809H' clickHandler>Meribah</jLink>, meaning "quarreling" or "strife," commemorating both the people's complaints and the leaders' failure, and this incident became a lasting symbol in biblical literature of the serious consequences that follow when even the most faithful servants fail to trust completely in God's instructions.
events: 1408 BC: <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H3478' clickHandler>Israelites</jLink> encamped at <jLink data-type='L' data-strong='H6946G' clickHandler>Kadesh</jLink> experienced severe water shortage, and God instructed <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H4872' clickHandler>Moses</jLink> to strike a rock for water at <jLink data-type='L' data-strong='H4809H' clickHandler>Meribah</jLink>.

1408 BC: God barred <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H4872' clickHandler>Moses</jLink> and <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H0175' clickHandler>Aaron</jLink> from entering the Promised Land for their disobedience.

ChronologyEntries.desc: New generation prepares to enter <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H3667G' clickHandler>Canaan</jLink>
ChronologyEntries.article: 1407 BC:  The year 1407 BC marked a crucial transitional period as the new generation of <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H3478' clickHandler>Israelites</jLink> prepared for the conquest of <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H3667G' clickHandler>Canaan</jLink> (Num.20:14-27:11). This preparation phase began with diplomatic efforts, as <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H4872' clickHandler>Moses</jLink> requested permission from the king of <jLink data-type='L' data-strong='H0123G' clickHandler>Edom</jLink> to allow peaceful passage through their territory, promising to stay on the main road without consuming local water or crops, but the <jLink data-type='L' data-strong='H0123G' clickHandler>Edomites</jLink> refused and threatened military action, forcing the <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H3478' clickHandler>Israelites</jLink> to take a longer route around their borders. The period was marked by significant leadership losses, most notably the death of <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H0175' clickHandler>Aaron</jLink> at Mount Hor, where <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H4872' clickHandler>Moses</jLink> transferred the high priestly garments to <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H0175' clickHandler>Aaron</jLink>'s son <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H0499G' clickHandler>Eleazar</jLink> in the presence of the entire congregation, officially establishing the continuation of the Aaronic priesthood. <jPara></jPara> Military victories characterized much of this year as the <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H3478' clickHandler>Israelites</jLink> engaged <jLink data-type='L' data-strong='H3667A' clickHandler>Canaanite</jLink> opposition, defeating King <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H6166B' clickHandler>Arad</jLink> of the <jLink data-type='L' data-strong='H5045G' clickHandler>Negev</jLink>, completely destroying his cities, and then achieving decisive victories over <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H5511' clickHandler>Sihon</jLink>, king of the <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H0567' clickHandler>Amorites</jLink>, and <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H5747' clickHandler>Og</jLink>, king of <jLink data-type='L' data-strong='H1316' clickHandler>Bashan</jLink>, securing substantial territory east of the <jLink data-type='L' data-strong='H3383' clickHandler>Jordan</jLink> River. A comprehensive census of the new generation was conducted to organize the tribes for both military purposes and future land distribution, while important legal frameworks were established regarding offerings, vows, and inheritance rights that would govern life in the Promised Land. During this period, <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H4872' clickHandler>Moses</jLink> began preparing for the leadership transition by receiving instructions about <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H3091G' clickHandler>Joshua</jLink>'s succession, ensuring continuity of command as the original wilderness generation passed away and the conquest-ready generation assumed responsibility for fulfilling God's promise to the patriarchs.
events: 1407 BC: <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H4872' clickHandler>Moses</jLink> requested passage through <jLink data-type='L' data-strong='H0123G' clickHandler>Edom</jLink> but was refused by the <jLink data-type='L' data-strong='H0123G' clickHandler>Edomites</jLink>.
1407 BC: <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H3478' clickHandler>Israelites</jLink> took a longer route around <jLink data-type='L' data-strong='H0123G' clickHandler>Edom</jLink>'s borders.
1407 BC: <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H0175' clickHandler>Aaron</jLink> died at Mount Hor.

1407 BC: <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H4872' clickHandler>Moses</jLink> transferred high priestly garments to <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H0499G' clickHandler>Eleazar</jLink>, who became the new high priest.

1407 BC: <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H3478' clickHandler>Israelites</jLink> defeated King <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H6166B' clickHandler>Arad</jLink> of the <jLink data-type='L' data-strong='H5045G' clickHandler>Negev</jLink>.

ChronologyEntries.desc: <jChronDurationLink style='color:black'>▼</jChronDurationLink>Conquest of the land led by <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H3091G' clickHandler>Joshua</jLink>
ChronologyEntries.article: 1406 BC:  Following <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H4872' clickHandler>Moses</jLink>' death, 1406 BC inaugurated the conquest of <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H3667G' clickHandler>Canaan</jLink> under <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H3091G' clickHandler>Joshua</jLink>'s leadership (Num.28 through Jos.12 and Jdg.2:7). <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H3091G' clickHandler>Joshua</jLink>'s leadership began with the miraculous crossing of the <jLink data-type='L' data-strong='H3383' clickHandler>Jordan</jLink> River, where God demonstrated His support for the new leader by causing the waters to stand in a heap, allowing the entire nation to cross on dry ground in a manner reminiscent of the Red Sea crossing. The conquest commenced with the dramatic fall of <jLink data-type='L' data-strong='H3405G' clickHandler>Jericho</jLink>, where the city's walls collapsed after the <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H3478' clickHandler>Israelites</jLink> followed God's unusual battle plan of marching around the city for seven consecutive days, with the walls falling on the seventh day after the priests blew their trumpets and the people shouted. <jPara></jPara> The systematic military campaign that followed involved numerous battles against coalitions of <jLink data-type='L' data-strong='H3667A' clickHandler>Canaanite</jLink> kings throughout both the southern and northern regions of the land, with <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H3091G' clickHandler>Joshua</jLink> leading strategic operations that resulted in the defeat of major city-states and the subjugation of the promised territory. The conquest period was marked not only by military success but also by spiritual faithfulness. Israel served the Lord faithfully throughout <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H3091G' clickHandler>Joshua</jLink>'s lifetime and during the tenure of the elders who outlived him and had personally witnessed God's mighty works (Jdg.2:7). This era established Israel's presence in <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H3667G' clickHandler>Canaan</jLink> and fulfilled the ancient promises made to <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H0085' clickHandler>Abraham</jLink>, <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H3327' clickHandler>Isaac</jLink>, and <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='G2384G' clickHandler>Jacob</jLink>, transforming the descendants of the Hebrew patriarchs from wilderness wanderers into the possessors of their divinely promised inheritance.
events: 1406 BC: <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H3091G' clickHandler>Joshua</jLink> became leader of Israel after <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H4872' clickHandler>Moses</jLink>' death.

1406 BC: <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H3091G' clickHandler>Joshua</jLink> led the <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H3478' clickHandler>Israelites</jLink> across the <jLink data-type='L' data-strong='H3383' clickHandler>Jordan</jLink> River as God parted the waters.

1406 BC: The <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H3478' clickHandler>Israelites</jLink> conquered <jLink data-type='L' data-strong='H3405G' clickHandler>Jericho</jLink> after marching around it for seven days and the walls collapsed.

1406 BC: <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H3091G' clickHandler>Joshua</jLink> led a systematic military campaign against <jLink data-type='L' data-strong='H3667A' clickHandler>Canaanite</jLink> kings, defeating major city-states.

1406 BC: <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H3091G' clickHandler>Joshua</jLink> and the <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H3478' clickHandler>Israelites</jLink> defeated thirty-one <jLink data-type='L' data-strong='H3667A' clickHandler>Canaanite</jLink> kings, establishing control over the Promised Land.

ChronologyEntries.article: 1405 BC:  The year 1405 BC marked a momentous milestone in <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H3478' clickHandler>Israelite</jLink> history as the nation experienced their first harvest in the Promised Land and began observing the agricultural festivals (Exo.23:10-11). This inaugural harvest represented the practical fulfillment of God's promise to bring Israel into "a land flowing with milk and honey," transitioning the people from decades of dependence on supernatural provision through manna to the cultivation of their own crops in <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H3667G' clickHandler>Canaan</jLink>. The observance of these festivals established a foundational rhythm of agricultural and religious life that would define <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H3478' clickHandler>Israelite</jLink> culture for generations to come. <jPara></jPara> The implementation of the sabbatical year laws (Exo.23:10-11) demonstrated Israel's commitment to integrating divine commands with practical land management, requiring that fields be cultivated for six years but allowed to rest in the seventh year, with the natural growth being available to the poor and wild animals. This agricultural-religious framework emphasized both social justice and ecological stewardship, creating a distinctive system that set Israel apart from surrounding nations and reinforced their covenant relationship with <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H3068G' clickHandler>Yahweh</jLink> through the very cycles of planting and harvest that sustained their daily existence.
events: 1405 BC: <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H3478' clickHandler>Israelites</jLink> celebrated their first harvest in <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H3667G' clickHandler>Canaan</jLink>, eating the land's produce instead of manna.
1405 BC: Israel began observing agricultural festivals as commanded by God.
1405 BC: The <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H3478' clickHandler>Israelites</jLink> implemented sabbatical year laws, letting the land rest every seventh year.

ChronologyEntries.article: 1400 BC:  The systematic division of <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H3667G' clickHandler>Canaan</jLink> among the twelve tribes of Israel was completed under <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H3091G' clickHandler>Joshua</jLink>'s leadership (Jos.13-21) representing one of the most significant administrative achievements in biblical history. The allocation process began with the recognition of territories already granted east of the <jLink data-type='L' data-strong='H3383' clickHandler>Jordan</jLink> River to the tribes of <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H7205' clickHandler>Reuben</jLink>, <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H1410G' clickHandler>Gad</jLink>, and the half-tribe of <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H4519G' clickHandler>Manasseh</jLink> by <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H4872' clickHandler>Moses</jLink>, while the remaining nine and a half tribes received their inheritances through a formal casting of lots at <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H7886' clickHandler>Shiloh</jLink>, overseen by <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H3091G' clickHandler>Joshua</jLink>, <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H0499G' clickHandler>Eleazar</jLink> the priest, and tribal leaders. The southern territory was assigned to Judah, including the strategic location of <jLink data-type='L' data-strong='H3389' clickHandler>Jerusalem</jLink>, while <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H0669G' clickHandler>Ephraim</jLink> and the remaining half-tribe of <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H4519G' clickHandler>Manasseh</jLink> received central regions, and the northern tribes of <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H2074' clickHandler>Zebulun</jLink>, <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H3485G' clickHandler>Issachar</jLink>, <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H0836' clickHandler>Asher</jLink>, and <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H5321G' clickHandler>Naphtali</jLink> were established in the <jLink data-type='L' data-strong='H1551' clickHandler>Galilee</jLink> region. <jPara></jPara> Special provisions were made for unique circumstances, with the tribe of <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H3878' clickHandler>Levi</jLink> receiving cities and surrounding pasturelands distributed throughout all tribal territories rather than a contiguous inheritance, reflecting their role as priests and temple servants whose inheritance was service to the Lord. <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H3612G' clickHandler>Caleb</jLink>, the faithful spy from the wilderness period, was granted <jLink data-type='L' data-strong='H2275A' clickHandler>Hebron</jLink> as a personal inheritance in recognition of his unwavering trust in God's promises, while the establishment of cities of refuge and <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H3878' clickHandler>Levitical</jLink> cities ensured both justice and religious service throughout the land. This comprehensive territorial organization provided the structural foundation for Israel's national life and fulfilled the ancient promises made to <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H0085' clickHandler>Abraham</jLink>, <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H3327' clickHandler>Isaac</jLink>, and <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='G2384G' clickHandler>Jacob</jLink> regarding their descendants' possession of the land.
events: 1400 BC: <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H3667G' clickHandler>Canaan</jLink> was systematically divided among the twelve tribes of Israel by <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H3091G' clickHandler>Joshua</jLink>, <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H0499G' clickHandler>Eleazar</jLink>, and tribal leaders.
1400 BC: Cities of refuge were established throughout the land for those who committed unintentional manslaughter.
1400 BC: <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H3878' clickHandler>Levitical</jLink> cities were assigned within the territories of the other tribes.

ChronologyEntries.article: 1399 BC:  Following the successful conquest and initial settlement of <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H3667G' clickHandler>Canaan</jLink>, 1399 BC witnessed the return of the eastern tribes—<jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H7205' clickHandler>Reuben</jLink>, <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H1410G' clickHandler>Gad</jLink>, and the half-tribe of <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H4519G' clickHandler>Manasseh</jLink>—to their allocated territories beyond the <jLink data-type='L' data-strong='H3383' clickHandler>Jordan</jLink> River (Jos.22; Jdg.2:6). These tribes had faithfully fulfilled their commitment to cross the <jLink data-type='L' data-strong='H3383' clickHandler>Jordan</jLink> and fight alongside their fellow <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H3478' clickHandler>Israelites</jLink> to secure the western territories of <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H3667G' clickHandler>Canaan</jLink>, demonstrating remarkable unity and cooperation in the collective effort to possess the Promised Land. <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H3091G' clickHandler>Joshua</jLink> commended these eastern tribes for their loyalty and obedience, blessing them and sending them home with considerable wealth and spoils from the conquest, acknowledging their sacrificial service in leaving their own settlements to assist in the broader military campaign. <jPara></jPara> The return journey was marked by a significant incident when the eastern tribes constructed a large altar by the <jLink data-type='L' data-strong='H3383' clickHandler>Jordan</jLink> River, which initially alarmed the western tribes who feared it represented religious apostasy or the establishment of an alternative worship center. However, diplomatic communication resolved the misunderstanding when the eastern tribes explained that the altar was intended as a witness and memorial to their shared faith and covenant relationship with the God of Israel, ensuring that future generations would remember their common heritage despite geographical separation. This peaceful resolution reinforced the importance of religious unity among the tribes and established precedents for maintaining spiritual fellowship across tribal boundaries, while the successful return home marked the completion of a major phase in Israel's conquest and settlement of the Promised Land.
events: 1399 BC: Eastern tribes returned to their territories beyond the <jLink data-type='L' data-strong='H3383' clickHandler>Jordan</jLink> River.
1399 BC: Eastern tribes constructed a large altar by the <jLink data-type='L' data-strong='H3383' clickHandler>Jordan</jLink> River.
1399 BC: Precedents were established for maintaining spiritual fellowship across tribal boundaries.

ChronologyEntries.article: 1381 BC:  <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H3091G' clickHandler>Joshua</jLink>, son of <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H5126' clickHandler>Nun</jLink> and <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H4872' clickHandler>Moses</jLink>' chosen successor, died in 1381 BC at the remarkable age of 110 years (Jos.23-24; Jdg.2:7-8). In his final years, <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H3091G' clickHandler>Joshua</jLink> delivered powerful farewell addresses. His second major address occurred at <jLink data-type='L' data-strong='H7927G' clickHandler>Shechem</jLink>, where he gathered all the tribes and recounted Israel's entire history, challenging the people to choose whom they would serve. <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H3091G' clickHandler>Joshua</jLink> was buried at <jLink data-type='L' data-strong='H8556A' clickHandler>Timnath-Serah</jLink> in the hill country of <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H0669G' clickHandler>Ephraim</jLink>. Israel served the Lord throughout <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H3091G' clickHandler>Joshua</jLink>'s lifetime and during the tenure of the elders who outlived him who had personally witnessed God's mighty works for Israel (Jdg.2:7-8). <jPara></jPara> Thus started a turbulent period characterized by persistent opposition from various <jLink data-type='L' data-strong='H3667A' clickHandler>Canaanite</jLink> groups (Jdg.1). This established the foundation for Israel's subsequent spiritual and political difficulties, as the incomplete expulsion of <jLink data-type='L' data-strong='H3667A' clickHandler>Canaanite</jLink> inhabitants led to ongoing syncretism and covenant unfaithfulness. This period of "various opposition" represents both the immediate military challenges faced by individual tribes and the longer-term theological crisis that would define the entire era of the Judges, where Israel's failure to maintain complete separation from <jLink data-type='L' data-strong='H3667A' clickHandler>Canaanite</jLink> culture and religion would repeatedly result in cycles of apostasy, oppression, and divine intervention.
events: 1381 BC: <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H3091G' clickHandler>Joshua</jLink> delivered farewell addresses to Israel.
1381 BC: <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H3091G' clickHandler>Joshua</jLink> died at the age of 110 years.

1381 BC: <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H3091G' clickHandler>Joshua</jLink> was buried at <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H8556A' clickHandler>Timnath-Serah</jLink> in <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H0669G' clickHandler>Ephraim</jLink>.
1381 BC: The era of faithful elders who witnessed God's works ended.
1381 BC: A turbulent period began with persistent <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H3667A' clickHandler>Canaanite</jLink> opposition.

ChronologyEntries.desc: Oppressed by <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H3573' clickHandler>Cushan-rishathaim</jLink> 8 yr
ChronologyEntries.article: 1371 BC:  In 1371 BC, the <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H3478' clickHandler>Israelites</jLink> began an eight-year period of oppression under <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H3573' clickHandler>Cushan-rishathaim</jLink>, king of <jLink data-type='L' data-strong='H0758I' clickHandler>Aram</jLink> <jLink data-type='L' data-strong='H0763H' clickHandler>Naharaim</jLink> (northern <jLink data-type='L' data-strong='H0763G' clickHandler>Mesopotamia</jLink>), as divine judgment for their apostasy and disobedience to the covenant (Jdg.3:8). This foreign ruler, whose name literally means "<jLink data-type='L' data-strong='H3572' clickHandler>Cushan</jLink> of double wickedness," represents the first major oppressor in the cyclical pattern that would characterize the era of the Judges, where Israel's spiritual unfaithfulness consistently resulted in political subjugation by surrounding nations. The oppression by a <jLink data-type='L' data-strong='H0763G' clickHandler>Mesopotamian</jLink> ruler demonstrates the far-reaching consequences of Israel's covenant breaking, extending their vulnerability beyond immediate neighboring peoples to distant powers. <jPara></jPara> Archaeological evidence for direct <jLink data-type='L' data-strong='H0763G' clickHandler>Mesopotamian</jLink> political or military control in <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H3667G' clickHandler>Canaan</jLink> during this period remains limited, with no clear material indication of administrative installations or military campaigns from <jLink data-type='L' data-strong='H0758I' clickHandler>Aram</jLink> <jLink data-type='L' data-strong='H0763H' clickHandler>Naharaim</jLink> in the late 14th century BC. However, the biblical account emphasizes the theological significance of this oppression as the beginning of a recurring cycle where Israel's abandonment of exclusive worship of <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H3068G' clickHandler>Yahweh</jLink> led to foreign domination, establishing the pattern that would define the entire period of the Judges and demonstrating the covenant consequences outlined in Deuteronomy's blessings and curses.
events: 1371 BC: Eight-year oppression by <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H3573' clickHandler>Cushan-rishathaim</jLink>, king of <jLink data-type='L' data-strong='H0758I' clickHandler>Aram</jLink> <jLink data-type='L' data-strong='H0763H' clickHandler>Naharaim</jLink>, began.

ChronologyEntries.desc: <jChronDurationLink style='color:black'>▼</jChronDurationLink><jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H6274' clickHandler>Othniel</jLink> judge in Judah
ChronologyEntries.article: 1363 BC:  Following Israel's cry for deliverance from <jLink data-type='L' data-strong='H0763G' clickHandler>Mesopotamian</jLink> oppression, God raised up <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H6274' clickHandler>Othniel</jLink>, son of <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H7073I' clickHandler>Kenaz</jLink> and younger brother of <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H3612G' clickHandler>Caleb</jLink>, as the first judge and deliverer in 1363 BC, inaugurating a forty-year period of peace (Jdg.3:9-11). <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H6274' clickHandler>Othniel</jLink>'s selection as deliverer connected him directly to the faithful generation of the conquest, as his brother <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H3612G' clickHandler>Caleb</jLink> had been one of only two spies who trusted God's promise to give Israel victory over the inhabitants of <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H3667G' clickHandler>Canaan</jLink>. The Spirit of the Lord came upon <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H6274' clickHandler>Othniel</jLink>, empowering him to lead Israel to military victory over <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H3573' clickHandler>Cushan-rishathaim</jLink> and establishing the paradigm for divine empowerment that would characterize the judges throughout this period. <jPara></jPara> The forty years of peace under <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H6274' clickHandler>Othniel</jLink>'s leadership represented both the reward for national repentance and a demonstration of God's faithfulness to the covenant relationship with Israel. This extended period of stability and rest served as the positive phase of the cyclical pattern documented throughout Judges, where divine deliverance through a chosen leader resulted in temporary restoration of proper worship and national security. <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H6274' clickHandler>Othniel</jLink>'s judgeship established important precedents for later deliverers, showing how God could use individuals from faithful families to restore Israel's fortunes and maintain covenant blessings when the people returned to exclusive loyalty to <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H3068G' clickHandler>Yahweh</jLink>.
events: 1363 BC: Judgeship of <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H6274' clickHandler>Othniel</jLink>, son of <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H7073I' clickHandler>Kenaz</jLink> and younger brother of <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H3612G' clickHandler>Caleb</jLink>, began.

ChronologyEntries.desc: <jChronDurationLink style='color:red'>▼</jChronDurationLink>Oppressed by <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H4124H' clickHandler>Moab</jLink> & <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H5700H' clickHandler>Eglon</jLink>
ChronologyEntries.article: 1328 BC:  The death of <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H6274' clickHandler>Othniel</jLink> in 1328 BC was followed immediately by renewed <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H3478' clickHandler>Israelite</jLink> apostasy, leading to eighteen years of oppression under <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H5700H' clickHandler>Eglon</jLink>, king of <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H4124H' clickHandler>Moab</jLink>, in alliance with the <jLink data-type='L' data-strong='H5983' clickHandler>Ammonites</jLink> and <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H6002' clickHandler>Amalekites</jLink> (Jdg.3:12-14). This coalition of traditional enemies successfully invaded and conquered strategic <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H3478' clickHandler>Israeli</jLink> territory, with <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H5700H' clickHandler>Eglon</jLink> establishing his headquarters in the City of Palms, commonly identified as <jLink data-type='L' data-strong='H3405G' clickHandler>Jericho</jLink>, the very city that had symbolized God's miraculous power during the initial conquest under <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H3091G' clickHandler>Joshua</jLink>. The choice of <jLink data-type='L' data-strong='H3405G' clickHandler>Jericho</jLink> as <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H5700H' clickHandler>Eglon</jLink>'s seat of power represented a particularly bitter irony, as the location where God had first demonstrated His ability to deliver <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H3667G' clickHandler>Canaan</jLink> to Israel now served as the center of foreign oppression due to Israel's covenant unfaithfulness. <jPara></jPara> The extended eighteen-year period of <jLink data-type='L' data-strong='H4124G' clickHandler>Moabite</jLink> domination illustrates the progressive deterioration of Israel's spiritual condition, as this oppression lasted significantly longer than the initial eight years under <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H3573' clickHandler>Cushan-rishathaim</jLink>. While archaeological evidence for <jLink data-type='L' data-strong='H4124G' clickHandler>Moabite</jLink> political control in <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H3667G' clickHandler>Canaan</jLink> during this specific period remains limited, with most securely identified <jLink data-type='L' data-strong='H4124G' clickHandler>Moabite</jLink> artifacts dating to later periods, the biblical narrative emphasizes how Israel's repeated cycles of apostasy resulted in increasingly severe consequences. This <jLink data-type='L' data-strong='H4124G' clickHandler>Moabite</jLink> oppression set the stage for God's next intervention through the judge <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H0164G' clickHandler>Ehud</jLink>, continuing the established pattern of divine discipline followed by deliverance when Israel acknowledged their need for covenant restoration.
events: 1328 BC: Death of <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H6274' clickHandler>Othniel</jLink>

1328 BC: Start of 18 year oppression by <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H5700H' clickHandler>Eglon</jLink>, king of <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H4124H' clickHandler>Moab</jLink>, in alliance with the <jLink data-type='L' data-strong='H5983' clickHandler>Ammonites</jLink> and <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H6002' clickHandler>Amalekites</jLink>

ChronologyEntries.desc: <jChronDurationLink style='color:black'>▼</jChronDurationLink><jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H0164G' clickHandler>Ehud</jLink> judge in Benjamin
ChronologyEntries.article: 1310 BC:  In 1310 BC, <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H0164G' clickHandler>Ehud</jLink>, a left-handed <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H1144G' clickHandler>Benjamite</jLink>, emerged as Israel's second judge and deliverer, ending eighteen years of <jLink data-type='L' data-strong='H4124G' clickHandler>Moabite</jLink> oppression under King <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H5700H' clickHandler>Eglon</jLink> (Jdg.3:15-31). Following the typical pattern of the judges period, the <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H3478' clickHandler>Israelites</jLink> had cried out to the Lord because of their suffering, and God raised up <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H0164G' clickHandler>Ehud</jLink> to execute a daring assassination plan that would liberate his people. <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H0164G' clickHandler>Ehud</jLink> crafted a double-edged sword approximately eighteen inches long, which he concealed under his clothing on his right thigh, and gained access to King <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H5700H' clickHandler>Eglon</jLink> by presenting tribute on behalf of Israel. In a private audience, <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H0164G' clickHandler>Ehud</jLink> declared he had "a message from God" for the king, then thrust his weapon so forcefully into <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H5700H' clickHandler>Eglon</jLink>'s obese body that the entire blade disappeared, and he escaped through the palace portico after locking the doors behind him. <jPara></jPara> The successful elimination of <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H5700H' clickHandler>Eglon</jLink> triggered a comprehensive military campaign in which <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H0164G' clickHandler>Ehud</jLink> rallied the <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H3478' clickHandler>Israelites</jLink> to seize the <jLink data-type='L' data-strong='H3383' clickHandler>Jordan</jLink> River fords, preventing <jLink data-type='L' data-strong='H4124G' clickHandler>Moabite</jLink> escape and killing approximately 10,000 <jLink data-type='L' data-strong='H4124G' clickHandler>Moabite</jLink> warriors, described as "vigorous and strong men". This decisive victory established <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H0164G' clickHandler>Ehud</jLink>'s authority as judge and inaugurated the longest period of peace recorded in the book of Judges—eighty years of tranquility that would extend through his lifetime.  <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H8044' clickHandler>Shamgar</jLink> receives a brief mention for the elimination of 600 <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H6430H' clickHandler>Philistines</jLink> using an oxgoad, a long-handled agricultural tool typically used for controlling and directing cattle. This reflects the ongoing challenge Israel faced in obtaining proper military equipment during periods of foreign domination, when access to iron weapons was often restricted by surrounding peoples.
events: 1310 BC: <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H0164G' clickHandler>Ehud</jLink> assassinated King <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H5700H' clickHandler>Eglon</jLink> of <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H4124H' clickHandler>Moab</jLink>
1310 BC: End of eighteen years of <jLink data-type='L' data-strong='H4124G' clickHandler>Moabite</jLink> oppression over Israel
1310 BC: <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H0164G' clickHandler>Ehud</jLink> led military campaign at <jLink data-type='L' data-strong='H3383' clickHandler>Jordan</jLink> River fords
1310 BC: <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H0164G' clickHandler>Ehud</jLink> established as Israel's second judge

ChronologyEntries.desc: <jChronDurationLink style='color:red'>▼</jChronDurationLink>Oppressed by <jLink data-type='L' data-strong='H3667A' clickHandler>Canaanites</jLink> & <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H2985H' clickHandler>Jabin</jLink>
ChronologyEntries.article: 1238 BC:  Following the death of <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H0164G' clickHandler>Ehud</jLink>, <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H8044' clickHandler>Shamgar</jLink>, and the conclusion of the eighty-year peace period, Israel again fell into apostasy, resulting in twenty years of severe oppression beginning in 1238 BC under King <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H2985H' clickHandler>Jabin</jLink> of <jLink data-type='L' data-strong='H2674G' clickHandler>Hazor</jLink> and his military commander <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H5516G' clickHandler>Sisera</jLink> (Jdg.4:2-3). This <jLink data-type='L' data-strong='H3667A' clickHandler>Canaanite</jLink> resurgence represents a significant shift from the <jLink data-type='L' data-strong='H4124G' clickHandler>Moabite</jLink> and <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H6430H' clickHandler>Philistine</jLink> threats of previous generations, as <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H2985H' clickHandler>Jabin</jLink> commanded a technologically superior force that included 900 iron chariots, giving his army decisive advantages on the plains and valleys where chariot warfare was most effective. Archaeological evidence from the thirteenth century BC confirms the presence of substantial <jLink data-type='L' data-strong='H3667A' clickHandler>Canaanite</jLink> urban centers with sophisticated military capabilities, including fortified cities like <jLink data-type='L' data-strong='H2674G' clickHandler>Hazor</jLink> that served as regional power bases with complex administrative and military structures. <jPara></jPara> The harsh nature of this oppression is emphasized in the biblical text, which records that Israel was "cruelly oppressed" for two decades, indicating systematic subjugation that affected daily life, economic activity, and religious practice throughout the affected territories. <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H5516G' clickHandler>Sisera</jLink>, operating from <jLink data-type='L' data-strong='H2800' clickHandler>Harosheth Hagoyim</jLink>, likely controlled key transportation routes and strategic locations, enabling sustained military pressure on <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H3478' clickHandler>Israelite</jLink> settlements. This extended period of <jLink data-type='L' data-strong='H3667A' clickHandler>Canaanite</jLink> dominance demonstrated the consequences of Israel's covenant unfaithfulness and set the stage for one of the most dramatic deliverances in the judges period, when God would raise up the prophetess <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H1683H' clickHandler>Deborah</jLink> to challenge this formidable enemy through unconventional leadership and divine intervention.
events: 1238 BC: The eighty-year peace period in Israel ended

1238 BC: King <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H2985H' clickHandler>Jabin</jLink> of <jLink data-type='L' data-strong='H2674G' clickHandler>Hazor</jLink> began twenty years of severe oppression over Israel
1238 BC: <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H5516G' clickHandler>Sisera</jLink> established military control from <jLink data-type='L' data-strong='H2800' clickHandler>Harosheth Hagoyim</jLink>

ChronologyEntries.desc: <jChronDurationLink style='color:black'>▼</jChronDurationLink> <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H1683H' clickHandler>Deborah</jLink> & <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H1301' clickHandler>Barak</jLink> in Ephraim & North
ChronologyEntries.article: 1218 BC:  In 1218 BC, <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H1683H' clickHandler>Deborah</jLink>, a prophetess who served as judge in Israel, summoned <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H1301' clickHandler>Barak</jLink> son of <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H0042' clickHandler>Abinoam</jLink> to lead a military campaign against <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H5516G' clickHandler>Sisera</jLink>'s forces, initiating events that would culminate in Israel's liberation from twenty years of <jLink data-type='L' data-strong='H3667A' clickHandler>Canaanite</jLink> oppression and the establishment of a forty-year period of peace (Jdg.4:4-5:31). <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H1683H' clickHandler>Deborah</jLink>'s unique role as both prophetess and judge represented an exceptional form of leadership in ancient Israel, and her strategic direction of the military campaign demonstrated the integration of spiritual authority with practical military planning. She instructed <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H1301' clickHandler>Barak</jLink> to assemble 10,000 warriors from the tribes of <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H5321G' clickHandler>Naphtali</jLink> and <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H2074' clickHandler>Zebulun</jLink> at Mount <jLink data-type='L' data-strong='H8396H' clickHandler>Tabor</jLink>, promising divine assistance in defeating <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H5516G' clickHandler>Sisera</jLink>'s technologically superior army, including his 900 iron chariots that had previously made <jLink data-type='L' data-strong='H3667A' clickHandler>Canaanite</jLink> forces virtually invincible in open warfare. <jPara></jPara> The decisive battle occurred when God caused a sudden rainstorm that turned the <jLink data-type='L' data-strong='H7028' clickHandler>Kishon</jLink> River valley into mud, neutralizing the effectiveness of <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H5516G' clickHandler>Sisera</jLink>'s chariots and enabling the <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H3478' clickHandler>Israelite</jLink> forces to achieve a complete victory in which the entire <jLink data-type='L' data-strong='H3667A' clickHandler>Canaanite</jLink> army was destroyed. <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H5516G' clickHandler>Sisera</jLink> fled on foot and sought refuge in the tent of <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H3278' clickHandler>Jael</jLink>, wife of <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H2268H' clickHandler>Heber</jLink> the <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H7017' clickHandler>Kenite</jLink>, where she killed him while he slept by driving a tent peg through his temple, fulfilling <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H1683H' clickHandler>Deborah</jLink>'s prophecy that the honor of victory would belong to a woman. This triumph is commemorated in both prose (Jdg.4) and poetry (Jdg.5), with the Song of <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H1683H' clickHandler>Deborah</jLink> being recognized by scholars as one of the oldest passages in the Hebrew Bible, providing valuable insights into early <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H3478' clickHandler>Israelite</jLink> society, tribal relationships, and religious thought. The resulting forty years of peace represented a significant restoration of Israel's covenant relationship with God and provided the nation with an extended period of stability under the leadership of these faithful judges.
events: 1218 BC: <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H1683H' clickHandler>Deborah</jLink> summoned <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H1301' clickHandler>Barak</jLink> son of <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H0042' clickHandler>Abinoam</jLink> to gather 10,000 warriors from <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H5321G' clickHandler>Naphtali</jLink> and <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H2074' clickHandler>Zebulun</jLink> at Mount <jLink data-type='L' data-strong='H8396H' clickHandler>Tabor</jLink>
1218 BC: <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H5516G' clickHandler>Sisera</jLink> mobilized his forces to <jLink data-type='L' data-strong='H7028' clickHandler>Kishon</jLink> River valley

1218 BC: <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H1301' clickHandler>Barak</jLink>'s forces completely defeated <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H5516G' clickHandler>Sisera</jLink>'s army, destroying the entire <jLink data-type='L' data-strong='H3667A' clickHandler>Canaanite</jLink> force

1218 BC: <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H5516G' clickHandler>Sisera</jLink> fled to the tent of <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H3278' clickHandler>Jael</jLink> wife of <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H2268H' clickHandler>Heber</jLink> the <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H7017' clickHandler>Kenite</jLink> who killed him with a tent peg
1218 BC: Twenty years of <jLink data-type='L' data-strong='H3667A' clickHandler>Canaanite</jLink> oppression ended and forty years of peace for Israel began

ChronologyEntries.desc: <jChronDurationLink style='color:red'>▼</jChronDurationLink>Oppressed by <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H4080G' clickHandler>Midian</jLink>/<jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H6159' clickHandler>Oreb</jLink> etc 7 yr
ChronologyEntries.article: 1183 BC:  The year 1183 BC marked the beginning of one of the most devastating seven-year periods of foreign oppression during the era of the Judges, as the <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H3478' clickHandler>Israelites</jLink> fell under the domination of a coalition led by the <jLink data-type='L' data-strong='H4080H' clickHandler>Midianites</jLink>, <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H6002' clickHandler>Amalekites</jLink>, and other eastern peoples (Jdg.6:1-6). This oppression followed the established cyclical pattern of the Judges period, where Israel's covenant unfaithfulness resulted in divine judgment through foreign subjugation. The <jLink data-type='L' data-strong='H4080H' clickHandler>Midianite</jLink> forces, under leaders including <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H6159' clickHandler>Oreb</jLink>, employed systematic tactics of economic warfare, timing their annual invasions to coincide with harvest seasons when they would destroy crops, seize livestock, and devastate the agricultural foundation of <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H3478' clickHandler>Israelite</jLink> society. <jPara></jPara> The severity of this oppression forced the <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H3478' clickHandler>Israelites</jLink> to abandon their normal settlements and seek refuge in mountain caves, dens, and strongholds throughout the hill country, creating a state of perpetual fear and impoverishment that lasted for seven years. The <jLink data-type='L' data-strong='H4080H' clickHandler>Midianites</jLink>, known from archaeological sources as nomadic peoples with presence in northwestern <jLink data-type='L' data-strong='H6152B' clickHandler>Arabia</jLink> and southern Transjordan, possessed superior mobility and military organization that enabled them to maintain sustained pressure on settled <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H3478' clickHandler>Israelite</jLink> communities until divine intervention through <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H1439' clickHandler>Gideon</jLink> would eventually break their power.
events: 1183 BC: Israel fell under domination by Midianite-led coalition
1183 BC: <jLink data-type='L' data-strong='H4080H' clickHandler>Midianite</jLink> forces under <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H6159' clickHandler>Oreb</jLink> began systematic economic warfare
1183 BC: First harvest season invasion by <jLink data-type='L' data-strong='H4080H' clickHandler>Midianites</jLink>

ChronologyEntries.desc: <jChronDurationLink style='color:black'>▼</jChronDurationLink><jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H1439' clickHandler>Gideon</jLink> judge in North
ChronologyEntries.article: 1176 BC:  In 1176 BC, following Israel's desperate cry for deliverance from seven years of <jLink data-type='L' data-strong='H4080H' clickHandler>Midianite</jLink> oppression, God raised up <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H1439' clickHandler>Gideon</jLink> (also called <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H1439' clickHandler>Jerubbaal</jLink>) as judge and deliverer, inaugurating a remarkable forty-year period of peace (Jdg.6:7-8:35). <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H1439' clickHandler>Gideon</jLink>'s calling began with a dramatic theophany at <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H6084I' clickHandler>Ophrah</jLink>, where the angel of the Lord commissioned him despite his protests about his clan's weakness and his own insignificance within his family. His initial act of destroying his father's Baal altar and <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H0842' clickHandler>Asherah</jLink> pole demonstrated the connection between Israel's spiritual restoration and their political deliverance, earning him the name <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H1439' clickHandler>Jerubbaal</jLink> meaning "let Baal contend against him". <jPara></jPara> The military campaign that followed showcased one of the most unconventional strategies in biblical warfare, as God instructed <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H1439' clickHandler>Gideon</jLink> to reduce his assembled army from 32,000 to merely 300 men to ensure that victory would be attributed to divine power rather than human strength. The decisive night attack employed psychological warfare tactics, with <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H1439' clickHandler>Gideon</jLink>'s 300 warriors surrounding the <jLink data-type='L' data-strong='H4080H' clickHandler>Midianite</jLink> camp armed with trumpets, empty jars containing concealed torches, and coordinated battle cries that created the illusion of a massive attacking force, causing panic and confusion that led the enemy to turn on each other in the darkness. This victory resulted in the pursuit and elimination of <jLink data-type='L' data-strong='H4080H' clickHandler>Midianite</jLink> leaders <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H6159' clickHandler>Oreb</jLink> and <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H2062' clickHandler>Zeeb</jLink>, effectively ending their capacity for organized resistance and establishing <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H1439' clickHandler>Gideon</jLink>'s authority as judge for four decades of unprecedented peace and prosperity.
events: 1176 BC: Seven years of <jLink data-type='L' data-strong='H4080H' clickHandler>Midianite</jLink> oppression of Israel ended
1176 BC: God raised up <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H1439' clickHandler>Gideon</jLink> as judge and deliverer of Israel
1176 BC: <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H1439' clickHandler>Gideon</jLink> assembled an army of 32,000 men
1176 BC: <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H1439' clickHandler>Gideon</jLink>'s night attack on the <jLink data-type='L' data-strong='H4080H' clickHandler>Midianite</jLink> camp

1176 BC: <jLink data-type='L' data-strong='H4080H' clickHandler>Midianite</jLink> leaders <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H6159' clickHandler>Oreb</jLink> and <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H2062' clickHandler>Zeeb</jLink> were eliminated

ChronologyEntries.desc: <jChronDurationLink style='color:black'>▼</jChronDurationLink><jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H0040G' clickHandler>Abimelech</jLink> civil war in Ephraim
ChronologyEntries.article: 1141 BC:  The year 1141 BC witnessed a dramatic departure from the established pattern of divinely appointed judges as <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H0040G' clickHandler>Abimelech</jLink>, one of <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H1439' clickHandler>Gideon</jLink>'s sons, orchestrated a brutal seizure of power that would result in three years of civil conflict (Jdg.9). Following his father's death, <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H0040G' clickHandler>Abimelech</jLink> convinced the citizens of <jLink data-type='L' data-strong='H7927G' clickHandler>Shechem</jLink> to support his claim to kingship by appealing to their tribal loyalties and financial interests, then used their monetary backing to hire "worthless and reckless men" who helped him massacre seventy of his brothers at <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H6084I' clickHandler>Ophrah</jLink>, with only <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H3147H' clickHandler>Jotham</jLink> escaping to deliver a prophetic parable condemning this fratricide. This unprecedented attempt to establish hereditary monarchy in Israel represented a fundamental rejection of theocratic governance and the judges system that God had ordained for the nation. <jPara></jPara> <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H0040G' clickHandler>Abimelech</jLink>'s reign proved to be marked by violence, treachery, and internal warfare that culminated in his death during the siege of <jLink data-type='L' data-strong='H8405' clickHandler>Thebez</jLink>, where a woman dropped a millstone on his head, leading him to have his armor-bearer kill him to avoid the disgrace of dying at a woman's hand. Significantly, this same tumultuous year marked the birth of <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H5941' clickHandler>Eli</jLink>, who would later serve as both priest and judge of Israel during a crucial transitional period in the nation's history.
events: 1141 BC: <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H1439' clickHandler>Gideon</jLink> died, ending his period as judge over Israel

1141 BC: <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H0040G' clickHandler>Abimelech</jLink> convinced citizens of <jLink data-type='L' data-strong='H7927G' clickHandler>Shechem</jLink> to support his claim to kingship
1141 BC: <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H0040G' clickHandler>Abimelech</jLink> received monetary backing from <jLink data-type='L' data-strong='H7927G' clickHandler>Shechem</jLink>
1141 BC: Seventy of <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H1439' clickHandler>Gideon</jLink>'s sons were massacred at <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H6084I' clickHandler>Ophrah</jLink>
1141 BC: <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H0040G' clickHandler>Abimelech</jLink>'s three-year civil conflict began

ChronologyEntries.desc: <jChronDurationLink style='color:black'>▼</jChronDurationLink><jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H8439H' clickHandler>Tola</jLink> judge in Ephraim
ChronologyEntries.article: 1138 BC:  Following the violent conclusion of <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H0040G' clickHandler>Abimelech</jLink>'s three-year reign in 1141 BC, <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H8439H' clickHandler>Tola</jLink> son of <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H6312G' clickHandler>Puah</jLink> from the tribe of <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H3485G' clickHandler>Issachar</jLink> emerged as judge in 1138 BC, providing much-needed stability and legitimate governance for twenty-three years (Jdg.10:1-2). His judgeship represented a return to the traditional pattern of divinely appointed leadership after the aberration of <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H0040G' clickHandler>Abimelech</jLink>'s self-proclaimed kingship, and his role was specifically described as "rising to save Israel," indicating both his defensive function against external threats and his restorative work in reestablishing proper covenant relationship and internal order. <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H8439H' clickHandler>Tola</jLink>'s leadership from his residence in <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H8069I' clickHandler>Shamir</jLink> in the hill country of <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H0669G' clickHandler>Ephraim</jLink> suggests a strategic location that enabled him to effectively govern the central regions of Israel while maintaining security against potential invasions. <jPara></jPara> The extended duration of <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H8439H' clickHandler>Tola</jLink>'s twenty-three-year judgeship reflects a period of sustained peace and effective administration that allowed Israel to recover from the trauma and instability of <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H0040G' clickHandler>Abimelech</jLink>'s civil war. While the biblical record provides limited details about specific events during his tenure, the absence of recorded conflicts or crises suggests that <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H8439H' clickHandler>Tola</jLink> successfully maintained both internal order and external security, fulfilling the essential functions of a judge in providing justice, military leadership when needed, and spiritual guidance to keep Israel faithful to their covenant obligations. His peaceful leadership served as a crucial bridge between the chaotic <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H0040G' clickHandler>Abimelech</jLink> period and the subsequent challenges that would arise under later judges, demonstrating how effective governance could provide stability and prosperity when rooted in legitimate divine authority rather than personal ambition.
events: 1138 BC: <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H8439H' clickHandler>Tola</jLink> son of <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H6312G' clickHandler>Puah</jLink> from the tribe of <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H3485G' clickHandler>Issachar</jLink> emerged as judge over Israel
1138 BC: Post-Abimelech instability and disorder in Israel ended
1138 BC: <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H8439H' clickHandler>Tola</jLink> established his residence and leadership base in <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H8069I' clickHandler>Shamir</jLink>

ChronologyEntries.desc: <jChronDurationLink style='color:black'>▼</jChronDurationLink><jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H2971I' clickHandler>Jair</jLink> judge in Gad
ChronologyEntries.article: 1115 BC:  Judge <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H2971I' clickHandler>Jair</jLink> began his twenty-two-year tenure as leader of Israel in 1115 BC, succeeding <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H8439H' clickHandler>Tola</jLink> (Jdg.10:3-6). <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H2971I' clickHandler>Jair</jLink>'s judgeship was distinguished by remarkable stability and prosperity, evidenced by his thirty sons who rode thirty donkeys—a sign of wealth and status in ancient Israel—and controlled thirty towns in <jLink data-type='L' data-strong='H1568G' clickHandler>Gilead</jLink>, which became known as Havvoth <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H2971I' clickHandler>Jair</jLink> (meaning "villages of <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H2971I' clickHandler>Jair</jLink>"). This period represents one of the longer peaceful eras during the tumultuous time of the Judges, suggesting effective leadership that maintained both internal order and external security throughout the Transjordanian territories. <jPara></jPara> The prominence of <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H2971I' clickHandler>Jair</jLink>'s family and their extensive territorial control in <jLink data-type='L' data-strong='H1568G' clickHandler>Gilead</jLink> indicates a decentralized form of governance typical of the Judges period, where local leaders exercised authority through clan and tribal networks rather than centralized state structures. Archaeological evidence from this period in the Late Bronze/Early Iron Age transition supports the existence of fortified settlements and urban centers in the Transjordanian region, consistent with the biblical description of multiple towns under <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H2971I' clickHandler>Jair</jLink>'s family's influence. His lengthy and apparently peaceful rule provided crucial stability before the devastating <jLink data-type='L' data-strong='H5983' clickHandler>Ammonite</jLink> oppression that would begin just three years after his tenure commenced.
events: 1115 BC: <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H8439H' clickHandler>Tola</jLink>'s judgeship over Israel ended
1115 BC: <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H2971I' clickHandler>Jair</jLink> began his twenty-two-year tenure as judge of Israel
1115 BC: Thirty sons of <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H2971I' clickHandler>Jair</jLink> took control of thirty towns in <jLink data-type='L' data-strong='H1568G' clickHandler>Gilead</jLink>
1115 BC: Period of stability and prosperity in Israel began

ChronologyEntries.article: 1111 BC:  The year 1111 BC marked the onset of one of the most severe periods of foreign oppression during the Judges era, as the <jLink data-type='L' data-strong='H5983' clickHandler>Ammonites</jLink>, in coalition with the <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H6430H' clickHandler>Philistines</jLink>, began an eighteen-year campaign of subjugation against Israel (Jdg.10:7-9). This oppression resulted directly from Israel's covenant unfaithfulness, as the biblical text explicitly states that "the <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H3478' clickHandler>Israelites</jLink> did evil in the eyes of the Lord," leading to divine judgment through foreign domination. The <jLink data-type='L' data-strong='H5983' clickHandler>Ammonites</jLink>, a Semitic people inhabiting the region east of the <jLink data-type='L' data-strong='H3383' clickHandler>Jordan</jLink> River with their capital at <jLink data-type='L' data-strong='H5983' clickHandler>Rabbah</jLink> (modern Amman), crossed the <jLink data-type='L' data-strong='H3383' clickHandler>Jordan</jLink> River to conduct systematic military campaigns against the tribes of Judah, <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H1144G' clickHandler>Benjamin</jLink>, and <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H0669G' clickHandler>Ephraim</jLink>, causing widespread distress throughout central and southern Israel. <jPara></jPara> The <jLink data-type='L' data-strong='H5983' clickHandler>Ammonite</jLink> military strategy appears to have involved organized raids and territorial expansion, utilizing their superior military organization and tribal coalition warfare typical of Late Bronze/Early Iron Age Levantine societies. Archaeological evidence suggests that <jLink data-type='L' data-strong='H5983' clickHandler>Ammonite</jLink> culture during this period was closely related to neighboring <jLink data-type='L' data-strong='H4124G' clickHandler>Moabite</jLink> and <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H3478' clickHandler>Israelite</jLink> societies, sharing similar material culture and religious practices centered on their deity <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H4432' clickHandler>Milkom</jLink> (Molech), though their military practices included the use of infantry-based forces equipped with spears, swords, and shields. This extended period of oppression would continue until 1093 BC when God would raise up <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H3316H' clickHandler>Jephthah</jLink> as deliverer, demonstrating the recurring cycle of apostasy, judgment, and deliverance that characterized the entire Judges period.
events: 1111 BC: The <jLink data-type='L' data-strong='H5983' clickHandler>Ammonites</jLink> in coalition with the <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H6430H' clickHandler>Philistines</jLink> began eighteen-year campaign of subjugation against Israel

1111 BC: Systematic military campaigns against tribes of Judah, <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H1144G' clickHandler>Benjamin</jLink>, and <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H0669G' clickHandler>Ephraim</jLink> began
1111 BC: Onset of severe foreign oppression marked the conclusion of the peaceful conditions that had existed under previous leadership

ChronologyEntries.desc: <jChronDurationLink style='color:black'>▼</jChronDurationLink><jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H3316H' clickHandler>Jephthah</jLink> judge in Gad
ChronologyEntries.article: 1093 BC:  In 1093 BC, after eighteen years of <jLink data-type='L' data-strong='H5983' clickHandler>Ammonite</jLink> oppression, God raised up <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H3316H' clickHandler>Jephthah</jLink>, a <jLink data-type='L' data-strong='H1568G' clickHandler>Gileadite</jLink> warrior, to serve as judge and deliver Israel from foreign domination (Jdg.10:10-12:7). <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H3316H' clickHandler>Jephthah</jLink>'s background as an outcast son of a prostitute who had been driven away by his legitimate brothers made his emergence as Israel's deliverer particularly remarkable, demonstrating God's use of unlikely leaders during the Judges period. Before engaging the <jLink data-type='L' data-strong='H5983' clickHandler>Ammonites</jLink> in battle, <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H3316H' clickHandler>Jephthah</jLink> made a fateful vow to the Lord, promising to offer as a burnt offering whatever came out of his house to greet him upon his victorious return—a vow that would result in tragic personal consequences when his only daughter emerged to celebrate his triumph. <jPara></jPara> The successful military campaign against the <jLink data-type='L' data-strong='H5983' clickHandler>Ammonites</jLink> effectively ended their eighteen-year oppression and established <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H3316H' clickHandler>Jephthah</jLink>'s authority as judge for six years until his death. However, his victory was overshadowed by the fulfillment of his vow regarding his daughter, which has generated extensive scholarly debate about whether this involved literal human sacrifice or dedication to lifelong service at the sanctuary. The narrative of <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H3316H' clickHandler>Jephthah</jLink>'s vow serves as a cautionary tale about rash promises to God and illustrates the tragic consequences that can result from attempting to manipulate divine favor through bargaining, while also raising important questions about the limits of human authority in religious matters and the dangers of adopting non-<jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H3478' clickHandler>Israelite</jLink> religious customs during this period of cultural syncretism.
events: 1093 BC: Eighteen years of <jLink data-type='L' data-strong='H5983' clickHandler>Ammonite</jLink> oppression over Israel ended

1093 BC: Elders of <jLink data-type='L' data-strong='H1568G' clickHandler>Gilead</jLink> summoned <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H3316H' clickHandler>Jephthah</jLink> to lead Israel against the <jLink data-type='L' data-strong='H5983' clickHandler>Ammonites</jLink>
1093 BC: <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H3316H' clickHandler>Jephthah</jLink> made a vow to the Lord before battle
1093 BC: <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H3316H' clickHandler>Jephthah</jLink> led successful military campaign against the <jLink data-type='L' data-strong='H5983' clickHandler>Ammonites</jLink>
1093 BC: <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H3316H' clickHandler>Jephthah</jLink> returned victorious from battle

ChronologyEntries.article: 1087 BC:  Judge <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H0078' clickHandler>Ibzan</jLink> of <jLink data-type='L' data-strong='H1035G' clickHandler>Bethlehem</jLink> assumed leadership of Israel in 1087 BC following <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H3316H' clickHandler>Jephthah</jLink>'s death, inaugurating a seven-year period of governance characterized by diplomatic alliance-building and social stability (Jdg.12:8-10). <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H0078' clickHandler>Ibzan</jLink>'s most notable achievement was his extensive family network, having thirty sons and thirty daughters whom he strategically married outside his clan, indicating a deliberate policy of forming political and social alliances with other tribal groups throughout Israel. This marriage diplomacy suggests that <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H0078' clickHandler>Ibzan</jLink> prioritized peaceful relations and internal cohesion over military conquest, representing a different leadership style from his predecessors who were primarily known for their military exploits against foreign oppressors. <jPara></jPara> The seven years of <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H0078' clickHandler>Ibzan</jLink>'s judgeship appear to have provided Israel with much-needed stability and social reconstruction following the trauma of the <jLink data-type='L' data-strong='H5983' clickHandler>Ammonite</jLink> oppression and <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H3316H' clickHandler>Jephthah</jLink>'s troubled leadership. His residence and burial in <jLink data-type='L' data-strong='H1035G' clickHandler>Bethlehem</jLink>, which may refer either to the famous <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H3057' clickHandler>Judahite</jLink> city or a lesser-known location in <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H2074' clickHandler>Zebulun</jLink> territory, reflects the continued decentralized nature of <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H3478' clickHandler>Israelite</jLink> governance during the Judges period, where leaders operated from their tribal bases rather than a unified capital. <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H0078' clickHandler>Ibzan</jLink>'s emphasis on external marriages and alliance-building demonstrates the ongoing challenges of maintaining tribal unity and suggests that his leadership focused on diplomatic solutions to potential conflicts, contributing to a period of relative peace that would continue under subsequent minor judges.
events: 1087 BC: <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H3316H' clickHandler>Jephthah</jLink> died, ending his six-year judgeship over Israel
1087 BC: <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H0078' clickHandler>Ibzan</jLink> of <jLink data-type='L' data-strong='H1035G' clickHandler>Bethlehem</jLink> assumed leadership as judge of Israel
1087 BC: <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H0078' clickHandler>Ibzan</jLink> established his residence and leadership base in <jLink data-type='L' data-strong='H1035G' clickHandler>Bethlehem</jLink>
1087 BC: Period of stability and social reconstruction for Israel began
1087 BC: Seven-year period of governance under <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H0078' clickHandler>Ibzan</jLink> initiated

ChronologyEntries.desc: <jChronDurationLink style='color:green'>▼</jChronDurationLink>Oppressed by <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H6430H' clickHandler>Philistines</jLink> while <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H5941' clickHandler>Eli</jLink> is HP
ChronologyEntries.article: 1082 BC:  In 1082 BC, <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H5941' clickHandler>Eli</jLink> served as both high priest and judge of Israel at <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H7886' clickHandler>Shiloh</jLink>, where the tabernacle and Ark of the Covenant were located (1Sa.1-4). This period marked a crucial transitional era in Israel's history, during which <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H5941' clickHandler>Eli</jLink> provided spiritual leadership while the nation faced increasing moral and spiritual decline. This year started one of the most prolonged and severe periods of foreign domination in Israel's pre-monarchic history, as the <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H6430H' clickHandler>Philistines</jLink> began a forty-year oppression of the <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H3478' clickHandler>Israelites</jLink> (Jdg.13:1) The <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H6430H' clickHandler>Philistines</jLink>, a technologically advanced people who had settled in the coastal regions of <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H3667G' clickHandler>Canaan</jLink>, possessed superior military capabilities including iron weapons and organized urban centers in their five major city-states: <jLink data-type='L' data-strong='H0795' clickHandler>Ashdod</jLink>, <jLink data-type='L' data-strong='H0831' clickHandler>Ashkelon</jLink>, <jLink data-type='L' data-strong='H6138' clickHandler>Ekron</jLink>, <jLink data-type='L' data-strong='H1661' clickHandler>Gath</jLink>, and <jLink data-type='L' data-strong='H5804' clickHandler>Gaza</jLink>. <jPara></jPara> Archaeological evidence from this period confirms substantial <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H6430H' clickHandler>Philistine</jLink> presence and cultural influence throughout the region, with distinctive pottery styles, architectural features, and material culture that demonstrate their dominance over fragmented <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H3478' clickHandler>Israelite</jLink> tribal territories. The <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H6430H' clickHandler>Philistine</jLink> oppression coincided with the beginning of <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H5941' clickHandler>Eli</jLink>'s priestly service and would continue throughout the tenures of subsequent judges, fundamentally altering Israel's political and social landscape. This period of foreign domination set the historical stage for the birth and ministry of <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H8123' clickHandler>Samson</jLink>, who would be divinely appointed to begin Israel's deliverance from <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H6430H' clickHandler>Philistine</jLink> control, though complete liberation would not be achieved until the establishment of the united monarchy under <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H1732' clickHandler>David</jLink>.
events: 1082 BC: <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H5941' clickHandler>Eli</jLink> served as both high priest and judge of Israel at <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H7886' clickHandler>Shiloh</jLink>
1082 BC: The <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H6430H' clickHandler>Philistines</jLink> began forty years of oppression over Israel
1082 BC: <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H6430H' clickHandler>Philistine</jLink> military dominance established in <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H3667G' clickHandler>Canaan</jLink>

ChronologyEntries.desc: <jChronDurationLink style='color:black'>▼</jChronDurationLink><jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H0356J' clickHandler>Elon</jLink> judge in North
ChronologyEntries.article: 1080 BC:  Judge <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H0356J' clickHandler>Elon</jLink> from the tribe of <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H2074' clickHandler>Zebulun</jLink> began his ten-year tenure as Israel's leader in 1080 BC, two years into the ongoing <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H6430H' clickHandler>Philistine</jLink> oppression, as briefly (Jdg.12:11-12).  <jPara></jPara>  Following his death, <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H0356J' clickHandler>Elon</jLink> was buried in <jLink data-type='L' data-strong='H0357' clickHandler>Aijalon</jLink> within the territory of <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H2074' clickHandler>Zebulun</jLink>.
events: 1080 BC: <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H0356J' clickHandler>Elon</jLink> of the tribe of <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H2074' clickHandler>Zebulun</jLink> began his ten-year judgeship over Israel

ChronologyEntries.article: 1077 BC:  <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H8050G' clickHandler>Samuel</jLink> was born to <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H2584' clickHandler>Hannah</jLink>, the previously barren wife of <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H0511H' clickHandler>Elkanah</jLink> from Ramathaim-zophim in the hill country of <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H0669G' clickHandler>Ephraim</jLink>, following her fervent prayer at the tabernacle in <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H7886' clickHandler>Shiloh</jLink>. <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H2584' clickHandler>Hannah</jLink> had made a solemn vow to the Lord that if He granted her a son, she would dedicate the child to lifelong service in the sanctuary, a promise that initially caused <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H5941' clickHandler>Eli</jLink> the high priest to mistake her silent, earnest prayer for drunkenness.
