After recognizing her sincere devotion, <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H5941' clickHandler>Eli</jLink> blessed <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H2584' clickHandler>Hannah</jLink>, and God answered her petition with the birth of <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H8050G' clickHandler>Samuel</jLink>, whose name means "heard of God" or "asked of God.". <jPara></jPara> Following <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H8050G' clickHandler>Samuel</jLink>'s weaning, <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H2584' clickHandler>Hannah</jLink> fulfilled her vow by bringing the young child to <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H5941' clickHandler>Eli</jLink> at <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H7886' clickHandler>Shiloh</jLink>, where she offered a magnificent prayer of thanksgiving that celebrates God's sovereignty and faithfulness to the humble. This dedication occurred during the same period when <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H5941' clickHandler>Eli</jLink>'s own sons, <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H2652' clickHandler>Hophni</jLink> and <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H6372H' clickHandler>Phinehas</jLink>, were bringing disgrace upon the priesthood through their corrupt practices, making <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H8050G' clickHandler>Samuel</jLink>'s pure devotion and future ministry a stark contrast to the spiritual decline at Israel's central sanctuary. <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H8050G' clickHandler>Samuel</jLink>'s birth and early consecration would prove pivotal for Israel's transition from the chaotic era of the Judges to the establishment of the monarchy, as he would eventually serve as prophet, priest, and the final judge of Israel.
events: 1077 BC: <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H8050G' clickHandler>Samuel</jLink> was born to <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H2584' clickHandler>Hannah</jLink> and <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H0511H' clickHandler>Elkanah</jLink> in Ramathaim-zophim, <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H0669G' clickHandler>Ephraim</jLink>

1077 BC: <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H2584' clickHandler>Hannah</jLink> dedicated <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H8050G' clickHandler>Samuel</jLink> to lifelong service at the sanctuary in <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H7886' clickHandler>Shiloh</jLink>
1077 BC: <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H2584' clickHandler>Hannah</jLink> offered a prayer of thanksgiving at <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H7886' clickHandler>Shiloh</jLink>

ChronologyEntries.desc: <jChronDurationLink style='color:black'>▼</jChronDurationLink><jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H5658H' clickHandler>Abdon</jLink> judge in Ephraim
ChronologyEntries.article: 1070 BC:  In 1070 BC, <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H5658H' clickHandler>Abdon</jLink>, son of <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H1985' clickHandler>Hillel</jLink> from <jLink data-type='L' data-strong='H6552' clickHandler>Pirathon</jLink> in the territory of <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H0669G' clickHandler>Ephraim</jLink>, assumed leadership as judge of Israel for an eight-year period (Jdg.12:13-15). <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H5658H' clickHandler>Abdon</jLink>'s administration was distinguished by remarkable family prosperity and extensive kinship networks, evidenced by his forty sons and thirty grandsons who collectively rode seventy donkeys—a clear indication of substantial wealth and high social status in ancient Near Eastern society, where donkey ownership represented significant economic resources and mobility. This impressive family structure suggests that <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H5658H' clickHandler>Abdon</jLink>'s leadership style may have emphasized diplomatic alliance-building and internal social cohesion rather than primarily military conquest, particularly significant given the ongoing <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H6430H' clickHandler>Philistine</jLink> oppression that continued throughout his tenure. <jPara></jPara> The eight years of <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H5658H' clickHandler>Abdon</jLink>'s judgeship (1070-1062 BC) occurred during the middle phase of the forty-year <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H6430H' clickHandler>Philistine</jLink> domination, indicating that his leadership focused on maintaining <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H3478' clickHandler>Israelite</jLink> community stability and prosperity despite external political constraints. His burial in <jLink data-type='L' data-strong='H6552' clickHandler>Pirathon</jLink> in the hill country of <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H0669G' clickHandler>Ephraim</jLink> reflects the continued pattern of localized leadership characteristic of the Judges period, where individual leaders operated from their tribal bases rather than establishing centralized national authority. <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H5658H' clickHandler>Abdon</jLink>'s legacy of family prosperity and peaceful administration provides a notable contrast to the more militaristic judges of this era, suggesting that effective leadership during foreign oppression could take multiple forms beyond direct military confrontation with external enemies.
events: 1070 BC: Judgeship of <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H0356J' clickHandler>Elon</jLink> ended

1070 BC: <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H5658H' clickHandler>Abdon</jLink> son of <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H1985' clickHandler>Hillel</jLink> from <jLink data-type='L' data-strong='H6552' clickHandler>Pirathon</jLink> in <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H0669G' clickHandler>Ephraim</jLink> became judge of Israel
1070 BC: <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H5658H' clickHandler>Abdon</jLink>’s forty sons and thirty grandsons rode seventy donkeys
1070 BC: <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H5658H' clickHandler>Abdon</jLink> established a kinship-based leadership style

ChronologyEntries.desc: Prophecies against <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H5941' clickHandler>Eli</jLink>'s sons
ChronologyEntries.article: 1067 BC:  A man of God delivered a severe prophetic judgment against <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H5941' clickHandler>Eli</jLink> and his household due to the corrupt behavior of his sons, <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H2652' clickHandler>Hophni</jLink> and <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H6372H' clickHandler>Phinehas</jLink>, who had shown contempt for the Lord's offerings and engaged in immoral conduct at the tabernacle entrance. These priestly sons had systematically abused their sacred positions by forcibly taking unauthorized portions of sacrificial offerings and committing sexual impropriety with the women who served at the sanctuary, actions that brought disgrace upon both the priesthood and the worship of <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H3068G' clickHandler>Yahweh</jLink>. Despite receiving direct warnings about his sons' behavior, <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H5941' clickHandler>Eli</jLink> had failed to exercise proper discipline or restraint, leading to divine condemnation of his entire family line. <jPara></jPara> The anonymous prophet declared that because <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H5941' clickHandler>Eli</jLink> had honored his sons above God by allowing their sacrilegious behavior to continue unchecked, the Lord would cut off his family's priestly inheritance and ensure that none of his descendants would reach old age. The prophecy included a specific sign: both of <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H5941' clickHandler>Eli</jLink>'s sons would die on the same day, confirming the certainty of God's judgment against the house of <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H5941' clickHandler>Eli</jLink>. Additionally, the prophet announced that God would raise up a faithful priest to replace <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H5941' clickHandler>Eli</jLink>'s corrupt lineage, a promise that would ultimately be fulfilled through the establishment of a new priestly line that would serve before God's anointed king, foreshadowing the eventual Davidic monarchy and its associated religious reforms.
events: 1067 BC: A man of God delivered a prophetic judgment against <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H5941' clickHandler>Eli</jLink> and his household, that both <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H2652' clickHandler>Hophni</jLink> and <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H6372H' clickHandler>Phinehas</jLink> dying on the same day
1067 BC: <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H5941' clickHandler>Eli</jLink> was rebuked for failing to restrain his sons' misconduct at the tabernacle
1067 BC: Promise that God would raise up a faithful priest to replace <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H5941' clickHandler>Eli</jLink>’s line

ChronologyEntries.desc: <jChronDurationLink style='color:black'>▼</jChronDurationLink><jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H8123' clickHandler>Samson</jLink> makes trouble in Judah
ChronologyEntries.article: 1062 BC:  <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H8123' clickHandler>Samson</jLink> officially began his twenty-year tenure as judge over Israel in 1062 BC, eighteen years after his birth and during the continuing period of <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H6430H' clickHandler>Philistine</jLink> oppression that had now persisted for two decades. His judgeship was characterized by extraordinary feats of physical strength derived from his <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H5139' clickHandler>Nazirite</jLink> vow and the Spirit of the Lord, which enabled him to wage a largely personal campaign of resistance against <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H6430H' clickHandler>Philistine</jLink> domination through dramatic individual exploits rather than organized military campaigns. <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H8123' clickHandler>Samson</jLink> "had led Israel twenty years" (Jdg.16:31). <jPara></jPara> Unlike previous judges who typically rallied tribal coalitions for coordinated military action, <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H8123' clickHandler>Samson</jLink>'s approach to delivering Israel involved spectacular personal confrontations with <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H6430H' clickHandler>Philistine</jLink> forces, often motivated by private grievances but serving the larger purpose of weakening enemy control over <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H3478' clickHandler>Israelite</jLink> territory. His judgeship coincided with the later years of <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H5941' clickHandler>Eli</jLink>'s priesthood at <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H7886' clickHandler>Shiloh</jLink> and the early development of <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H8050G' clickHandler>Samuel</jLink> as a prophetic voice, representing a period when Israel's leadership was transitioning from the traditional judge-deliverer model toward the more complex religious and political structures that would characterize the end of the Judges era and the beginning of the monarchy.
events: 1062 BC: <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H8123' clickHandler>Samson</jLink> began his twenty-year judgeship over Israel

ChronologyEntries.desc: <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H8123' clickHandler>Samson</jLink> marries & burns fields
ChronologyEntries.article: 1061 BC:  In 1061 BC, one year into his judgeship, <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H8123' clickHandler>Samson</jLink> initiated a marriage relationship with a <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H6430H' clickHandler>Philistine</jLink> woman from <jLink data-type='L' data-strong='H8553G' clickHandler>Timnah</jLink>, an action that distressed his parents but was part of divine providence to create opportunities for confrontation with Israel's oppressors. During the wedding celebration, <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H8123' clickHandler>Samson</jLink> posed a riddle to thirty <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H6430H' clickHandler>Philistine</jLink> companions, wagering thirty sets of garments on their ability to solve it, but when they threatened his bride to extract the answer, she revealed the solution, leading to <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H8123' clickHandler>Samson</jLink>'s angry departure after he killed thirty <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H6430H' clickHandler>Philistines</jLink> in <jLink data-type='L' data-strong='H0831' clickHandler>Ashkelon</jLink> to pay his debt. The woman's father subsequently gave her to <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H8123' clickHandler>Samson</jLink>'s best man, believing the marriage had been permanently dissolved. <jPara></jPara> When <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H8123' clickHandler>Samson</jLink> later returned with a young goat as a reconciliation gift and discovered his wife had been given to another man, he retaliated by capturing three hundred foxes, tying their tails together in pairs with torches, and releasing them into <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H6430H' clickHandler>Philistine</jLink> grain fields, vineyards, and olive groves. This agricultural terrorism destroyed the <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H6430H' clickHandler>Philistines</jLink>' harvest and provoked them to burn <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H8123' clickHandler>Samson</jLink>'s wife and her father, which in turn led to further escalation as <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H8123' clickHandler>Samson</jLink> "attacked them viciously and slaughtered many of them." These events established the pattern of personal conflict and cycles of revenge that would characterize <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H8123' clickHandler>Samson</jLink>'s entire career as judge, demonstrating how God used even flawed human motivations to accomplish His purposes of delivering Israel from foreign oppression.
events: 1061 BC: <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H8123' clickHandler>Samson</jLink> sought marriage with a <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H6430H' clickHandler>Philistine</jLink> woman from <jLink data-type='L' data-strong='H8553G' clickHandler>Timnah</jLink>
1061 BC: <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H8123' clickHandler>Samson</jLink> posed a riddle during his wedding feast in <jLink data-type='L' data-strong='H8553G' clickHandler>Timnah</jLink>

1061 BC: <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H8123' clickHandler>Samson</jLink> killed thirty <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H6430H' clickHandler>Philistines</jLink> in <jLink data-type='L' data-strong='H0831' clickHandler>Ashkelon</jLink>
1061 BC: <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H8123' clickHandler>Samson</jLink>’s wife was given to his best man by her father
1061 BC: <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H8123' clickHandler>Samson</jLink> retaliated by burning <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H6430H' clickHandler>Philistine</jLink> crops

ChronologyEntries.desc: <jChronDurationLink style='color:green'>▼</jChronDurationLink><jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H8050G' clickHandler>Samuel</jLink> leads in Benjamin;<jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H5941' clickHandler>Eli</jLink> & <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H8123' clickHandler>Samson</jLink> die;
ChronologyEntries.article: 1042 BC:  The year 1042 BC marked one of the most catastrophic periods in pre-monarchic <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H3478' clickHandler>Israelite</jLink> history, witnessing the simultaneous deaths of both <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H5941' clickHandler>Eli</jLink> the high priest and <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H8123' clickHandler>Samson</jLink> the judge, along with the unprecedented capture of the Ark of the Covenant by <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H6430H' clickHandler>Philistine</jLink> forces. The disaster began when Israel, having suffered defeat in battle against the <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H6430H' clickHandler>Philistines</jLink>, brought the sacred Ark from <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H7886' clickHandler>Shiloh</jLink> to their military camp, believing its presence would guarantee victory, but instead witnessed its capture along with the deaths of <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H5941' clickHandler>Eli</jLink>'s sons <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H2652' clickHandler>Hophni</jLink> and <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H6372H' clickHandler>Phinehas</jLink>, who had accompanied it as priests. Upon hearing news of both the Ark's capture and his sons' deaths, the elderly <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H5941' clickHandler>Eli</jLink> fell backward from his chair and died from a broken neck, fulfilling the earlier prophecy against his household and ending his forty-year tenure as judge and priest at <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H7886' clickHandler>Shiloh</jLink>. <jPara></jPara> Concurrently, <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H8123' clickHandler>Samson</jLink>'s twenty-year judgeship concluded with his dramatic death in <jLink data-type='L' data-strong='H5804' clickHandler>Gaza</jLink>, where he had been imprisoned by the <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H6430H' clickHandler>Philistines</jLink> after <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H1807' clickHandler>Delilah</jLink>'s betrayal revealed the secret of his strength. In a final act of defiance, <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H8123' clickHandler>Samson</jLink> prayed to God for restored strength and pushed apart the supporting pillars of a <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H6430H' clickHandler>Philistine</jLink> temple during a celebration honoring their god <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H1712' clickHandler>Dagon</jLink>, causing the structure to collapse and killing more <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H6430H' clickHandler>Philistines</jLink> in his death than during his entire lifetime. These devastating losses—the capture of Israel's most sacred object, the death of their high priest, and the end of their strongest judge—left the nation in spiritual and political crisis, but simultaneously marked the emergence of <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H8050G' clickHandler>Samuel</jLink> as the dominant prophetic voice who would guide Israel through this transitional period toward the eventual establishment of the monarchy under <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H7586G' clickHandler>Saul</jLink> and <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H1732' clickHandler>David</jLink>.
events: 1042 BC: <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H5941' clickHandler>Eli</jLink> the high priest and judge died at <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H7886' clickHandler>Shiloh</jLink>
1042 BC: The Ark of the Covenant was captured by the <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H6430H' clickHandler>Philistines</jLink>

1042 BC: <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H2652' clickHandler>Hophni</jLink> and <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H6372H' clickHandler>Phinehas</jLink> sons of <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H5941' clickHandler>Eli</jLink> died in battle
1042 BC: <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H1807' clickHandler>Delilah</jLink> betrayed <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H8123' clickHandler>Samson</jLink> leading to his imprisonment

1042 BC: <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H8123' clickHandler>Samson</jLink> destroyed the <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H6430H' clickHandler>Philistine</jLink> temple of <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H1712' clickHandler>Dagon</jLink> in <jLink data-type='L' data-strong='H5804' clickHandler>Gaza</jLink>

ChronologyEntries.article: 1040 BC:  <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H1732' clickHandler>David</jLink>, who would become Israel's second and most celebrated king, was born in 1040 BC in <jLink data-type='L' data-strong='H1035G' clickHandler>Bethlehem</jLink> to <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H3448' clickHandler>Jesse</jLink> of the tribe of Judah, during a period of continued <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H6430H' clickHandler>Philistine</jLink> pressure but increasing <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H3478' clickHandler>Israelite</jLink> recovery under <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H8050G' clickHandler>Samuel</jLink>'s prophetic leadership. His birth occurred just two years after the catastrophic events of 1042 BC that had seen the capture of the Ark of the Covenant and the deaths of both <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H5941' clickHandler>Eli</jLink> and <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H8123' clickHandler>Samson</jLink>, positioning him to grow up during <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H8050G' clickHandler>Samuel</jLink>'s efforts to restore Israel's spiritual condition and reorganize their resistance to foreign domination. <jPara></jPara> The timing of <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H1732' clickHandler>David</jLink>'s birth proved providential for Israel's future, as he would mature during the crucial decades when <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H8050G' clickHandler>Samuel</jLink> was establishing the monarchy through <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H7586G' clickHandler>Saul</jLink>'s anointing while simultaneously dealing with ongoing <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H6430H' clickHandler>Philistine</jLink> threats that had plagued the nation for decades. Archaeological evidence from this period suggests widespread destruction and rebuilding in <jLink data-type='L' data-strong='H3667A' clickHandler>Canaanite</jLink> cities, consistent with the biblical portrayal of continued conflict between various peoples in the region, while <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H1732' clickHandler>David</jLink>'s birth in <jLink data-type='L' data-strong='H1035G' clickHandler>Bethlehem</jLink>, a small <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H3057' clickHandler>Judahite</jLink> town, reflects the humble origins from which God would raise up Israel's greatest king and the ancestor of the promised Messiah.
events: 1040 BC: <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H1732' clickHandler>David</jLink> was born in <jLink data-type='L' data-strong='H1035G' clickHandler>Bethlehem</jLink> to <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H3448' clickHandler>Jesse</jLink> of the tribe of Judah

ChronologyEntries.desc: <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H8050G' clickHandler>Samuel</jLink> defeats the <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H6430H' clickHandler>Philistines</jLink>
ChronologyEntries.article: 1023 BC:  In 1023 BC, <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H8050G' clickHandler>Samuel</jLink> achieved a decisive victory over <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H6430H' clickHandler>Philistine</jLink> forces at <jLink data-type='L' data-strong='H4709G' clickHandler>Mizpah</jLink>, effectively ending their forty-one-year period of domination over Israel that had begun in 1082 BC. The victory followed a period of national repentance orchestrated by <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H8050G' clickHandler>Samuel</jLink>, who had called the <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H3478' clickHandler>Israelites</jLink> to abandon their foreign gods and return exclusively to the worship of <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H3068G' clickHandler>Yahweh</jLink>, demonstrating the connection between spiritual faithfulness and military success that characterized the covenant relationship. When the <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H6430H' clickHandler>Philistines</jLink> learned of the <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H3478' clickHandler>Israelite</jLink> assembly at <jLink data-type='L' data-strong='H4709G' clickHandler>Mizpah</jLink> and advanced to attack, <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H8050G' clickHandler>Samuel</jLink> offered a burnt sacrifice and cried out to the Lord on Israel's behalf, resulting in divine intervention through a great thunderstorm that threw the enemy forces into confusion and enabled the <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H3478' clickHandler>Israelites</jLink> to pursue and defeat them. <jPara></jPara> Following this supernatural victory, <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H8050G' clickHandler>Samuel</jLink> erected a stone monument called <jLink data-type='L' data-strong='H0072' clickHandler>Ebenezer</jLink> (meaning "stone of help") between <jLink data-type='L' data-strong='H4709G' clickHandler>Mizpah</jLink> and <jLink data-type='L' data-strong='H8129' clickHandler>Shen</jLink> to commemorate the Lord's assistance, declaring "Thus far the Lord has helped us". The triumph was so complete that the biblical text records the <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H6430H' clickHandler>Philistines</jLink> were subdued and did not invade <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H3478' clickHandler>Israelite</jLink> territory again during <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H8050G' clickHandler>Samuel</jLink>'s lifetime, while previously captured cities were restored to Israel's control. This victory represented a crucial turning point that established <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H8050G' clickHandler>Samuel</jLink>'s authority as both prophet and judge while providing Israel with the stability necessary for the eventual transition to monarchical government under <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H7586G' clickHandler>Saul</jLink>, whose anointing would occur within the following decade as Israel sought more permanent military leadership to face continuing external threats.
events: 1023 BC: <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H8050G' clickHandler>Samuel</jLink> calls Israel to repent at <jLink data-type='L' data-strong='H4709G' clickHandler>Mizpah</jLink> and worship <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H3068G' clickHandler>Yahweh</jLink>.

1023 BC: <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H6430H' clickHandler>Philistines</jLink> attack <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H3478' clickHandler>Israelites</jLink> gathered at <jLink data-type='L' data-strong='H4709G' clickHandler>Mizpah</jLink>.
1023 BC: <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H8050G' clickHandler>Samuel</jLink> offers sacrifice and prays at <jLink data-type='L' data-strong='H4709G' clickHandler>Mizpah</jLink>.
1023 BC: God sends thunderstorm, confusing <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H6430H' clickHandler>Philistines</jLink> at <jLink data-type='L' data-strong='H4709G' clickHandler>Mizpah</jLink>.
1023 BC: <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H3478' clickHandler>Israelites</jLink> defeat <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H6430H' clickHandler>Philistines</jLink>, ending domination since 1082 BC.

ChronologyEntries.desc: <jChronDurationLink style='color:black'>▼</jChronDurationLink><jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H7586G' clickHandler>Saul</jLink> anointed king. <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H8050G' clickHandler>Samuel</jLink> retires
ChronologyEntries.article: 1022 BC:  The year 1022 BC marked one of the most significant transitions in Israel's political history, as <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H7586G' clickHandler>Saul</jLink> became the nation's first king while <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H8050G' clickHandler>Samuel</jLink> retired from his role as judge, events (1Sa.8-12). This transformation occurred in response to the elders of Israel's request for a king "to judge us like all the nations," a demand that deeply troubled <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H8050G' clickHandler>Samuel</jLink>, who viewed it as a rejection of theocratic governance under divine rule. After seeking the Lord's counsel, <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H8050G' clickHandler>Samuel</jLink> received divine direction to grant the people's request while warning them about the burdens that monarchical rule would impose, including military conscription, taxation, and the seizure of property for royal use. The selection process involved both divine guidance and practical considerations, as God directed <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H8050G' clickHandler>Samuel</jLink> to anoint <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H7586G' clickHandler>Saul</jLink>, son of <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H7027G' clickHandler>Kish</jLink> from the tribe of <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H1144G' clickHandler>Benjamin</jLink>, a man of impressive physical stature who had come seeking his father's lost donkeys. <jPara></jPara> <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H7586G' clickHandler>Saul</jLink>'s coronation was confirmed through multiple stages, beginning with his private anointing by <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H8050G' clickHandler>Samuel</jLink>, followed by public validation through the casting of lots at <jLink data-type='L' data-strong='H4709G' clickHandler>Mizpah</jLink> where he was chosen from among all the tribes, and culminating in his military victory over the <jLink data-type='L' data-strong='H5983' clickHandler>Ammonites</jLink> at Jabesh-gilead, which solidified popular support for his kingship. <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H8050G' clickHandler>Samuel</jLink>'s retirement from active leadership represented the end of the judges period, though he continued serving as prophet and advisor to provide spiritual guidance during the monarchy's establishment. This transitional year established the foundation for Israel's royal institutions while maintaining the crucial role of prophetic authority to ensure that even kings remained accountable to divine law and covenant obligations.
events: 1022 BC: Elders ask <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H8050G' clickHandler>Samuel</jLink> at <jLink data-type='L' data-strong='H7414G' clickHandler>Ramah</jLink> for a king "like all the nations."
1022 BC: <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H8050G' clickHandler>Samuel</jLink> prays; God instructs him to grant and warn about monarchy.
1022 BC: <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H8050G' clickHandler>Samuel</jLink> warns Israel about burdens under a king.

1022 BC: <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H7586G' clickHandler>Saul</jLink> of <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H1144G' clickHandler>Benjamin</jLink> seeks <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H7027G' clickHandler>Kish</jLink>’s donkeys and meets <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H8050G' clickHandler>Samuel</jLink>.
1022 BC: <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H8050G' clickHandler>Samuel</jLink> privately anoints <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H7586G' clickHandler>Saul</jLink> as first king.

ChronologyEntries.desc: <jChronDurationLink style='color:green'>▼</jChronDurationLink>Ahimilech HP. <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H7586G' clickHandler>Saul</jLink>'s battle at <jLink data-type='L' data-strong='H1390H' clickHandler>Gibeah</jLink>
ChronologyEntries.article: 1021 BC:  King <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H7586G' clickHandler>Saul</jLink> faced his first major military test when <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H6430H' clickHandler>Philistine</jLink> forces threatened Israel at <jLink data-type='L' data-strong='H1390H' clickHandler>Gibeah</jLink>, an engagement that revealed both his leadership capabilities and the serious challenges facing the new monarchy (1Sa.13-14). The conflict began when <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H3083H' clickHandler>Jonathan</jLink>, <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H7586G' clickHandler>Saul</jLink>'s son, initiated hostilities by attacking a <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H6430H' clickHandler>Philistine</jLink> garrison, prompting a massive enemy response that included chariots, cavalry, and infantry forces "like the sand on the seashore in multitude." The <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H6430H' clickHandler>Philistines</jLink> established their base at <jLink data-type='L' data-strong='H4363' clickHandler>Michmash</jLink>, creating a strategic threat that paralyzed much of Israel, with many <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H3478' clickHandler>Israelites</jLink> hiding in caves, thickets, and cisterns, while others fled across the <jLink data-type='L' data-strong='H3383' clickHandler>Jordan</jLink> River to escape the approaching army. <jPara></jPara> The crisis deepened when <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H7586G' clickHandler>Saul</jLink>, waiting at <jLink data-type='L' data-strong='H1537G' clickHandler>Gilgal</jLink> for <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H8050G' clickHandler>Samuel</jLink> to offer the required pre-battle sacrifice, grew impatient as his forces began to scatter and assumed the priestly function himself, an unauthorized act that drew severe prophetic rebuke and foreshadowed future conflicts between royal authority and religious law. However, the military situation was dramatically reversed through <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H3083H' clickHandler>Jonathan</jLink>'s bold faith and initiative, as he and his armor-bearer launched a surprise assault on a <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H6430H' clickHandler>Philistine</jLink> outpost, killing approximately twenty men and creating panic that spread throughout the enemy camp. God intervened with an earthquake that intensified the confusion, causing the <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H6430H' clickHandler>Philistines</jLink> to turn on each other, while <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H7586G' clickHandler>Saul</jLink>'s reconnaissance revealed the enemy retreat and enabled him to rally his forces for a successful pursuit that drove the invaders from <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H3478' clickHandler>Israelite</jLink> territory, demonstrating that divine assistance remained available despite the king's earlier presumptuous behavior.
events: 1021 BC: <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H3083H' clickHandler>Jonathan</jLink> attacks <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H6430H' clickHandler>Philistine</jLink> garrison at <jLink data-type='L' data-strong='H1390H' clickHandler>Gibeah</jLink>.

1021 BC: <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H6430H' clickHandler>Philistines</jLink> assemble army at <jLink data-type='L' data-strong='H4363' clickHandler>Michmash</jLink> after <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H3083H' clickHandler>Jonathan</jLink>’s attack.

1021 BC: <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H3478' clickHandler>Israelites</jLink> hide or flee from <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H6430H' clickHandler>Philistines</jLink> across the <jLink data-type='L' data-strong='H3383' clickHandler>Jordan</jLink>.

1021 BC: <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H7586G' clickHandler>Saul</jLink> offers unauthorized sacrifice at <jLink data-type='L' data-strong='H1537G' clickHandler>Gilgal</jLink>, rebuked by <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H8050G' clickHandler>Samuel</jLink>.
1021 BC: <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H3083H' clickHandler>Jonathan</jLink> and armor-bearer kill about twenty <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H6430H' clickHandler>Philistines</jLink>.

ChronologyEntries.desc: <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H7586G' clickHandler>Saul</jLink> v. <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H6002H' clickHandler>Amalek</jLink>; God rejects him
ChronologyEntries.article: 1019 BC:  The decisive event that sealed King <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H7586G' clickHandler>Saul</jLink>'s fate was his partial obedience during the divinely commanded campaign against the <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H6002' clickHandler>Amalekites</jLink> resulted in God's permanent rejection of his kingship, as recorded in 1 <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H8050G' clickHandler>Samuel</jLink> 15. <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H8050G' clickHandler>Samuel</jLink> delivered explicit instructions from the Lord to "utterly destroy" the <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H6002' clickHandler>Amalekites</jLink> and all their possessions as divine judgment for their opposition to Israel during the wilderness wandering, emphasizing that nothing should be spared from this act of holy war. However, <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H7586G' clickHandler>Saul</jLink>'s execution of this command proved fatally flawed: while he achieved military victory and destroyed most of the <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H6002' clickHandler>Amalekite</jLink> population, he deliberately preserved King <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H0090H' clickHandler>Agag</jLink> alive and retained the best livestock and valuable goods, ostensibly for sacrificial purposes but actually representing a fundamental failure to trust and obey God's explicit instructions. <jPara></jPara> When confronted by <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H8050G' clickHandler>Samuel</jLink> about his disobedience, <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H7586G' clickHandler>Saul</jLink> offered justifications that revealed his failure to understand the paramount importance of obedience over ritual sacrifice, prompting <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H8050G' clickHandler>Samuel</jLink>'s famous declaration that "to obey is better than sacrifice, and to heed than the fat of rams". The prophet's subsequent announcement of divine rejection— "Because you have rejected the word of the Lord, He also has rejected you from being king"—marked the theological turning point of <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H7586G' clickHandler>Saul</jLink>'s reign and established the principle that Israel's monarchy remained subordinate to divine authority and covenant faithfulness. This decisive rejection occurred just three years into <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H7586G' clickHandler>Saul</jLink>'s reign and set the stage for <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H1732' clickHandler>David</jLink>'s eventual selection as his replacement, while <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H7586G' clickHandler>Saul</jLink>'s execution of <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H0090H' clickHandler>Agag</jLink> at <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H8050G' clickHandler>Samuel</jLink>'s command demonstrated that proper ritual action could not retroactively remedy the spiritual consequences of initial disobedience to divine commands.
events: 1019 BC: <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H8050G' clickHandler>Samuel</jLink> commands <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H7586G' clickHandler>Saul</jLink> to destroy <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H6002' clickHandler>Amalekites</jLink> and King <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H0090H' clickHandler>Agag</jLink>.

1019 BC: <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H7586G' clickHandler>Saul</jLink> defeats <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H6002' clickHandler>Amalekites</jLink> but spares <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H0090H' clickHandler>Agag</jLink> and best livestock.

1019 BC: <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H8050G' clickHandler>Samuel</jLink> confronts <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H7586G' clickHandler>Saul</jLink> at <jLink data-type='L' data-strong='H1537G' clickHandler>Gilgal</jLink> for disobedience.
1019 BC: <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H7586G' clickHandler>Saul</jLink> claims spared animals were for sacrifice to the Lord.
1019 BC: <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H8050G' clickHandler>Samuel</jLink> declares God’s rejection of <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H7586G' clickHandler>Saul</jLink> as king.

ChronologyEntries.desc: <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H1732' clickHandler>David</jLink> anointed; defeats <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H1555' clickHandler>Goliath</jLink>
ChronologyEntries.article: 1018 BC:  The pivotal year 1018 BC witnessed two foundational events in <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H1732' clickHandler>David</jLink>'s rise to prominence: his secret anointing by <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H8050G' clickHandler>Samuel</jLink> as Israel's future king and his dramatic victory over the <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H6430H' clickHandler>Philistine</jLink> champion <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H1555' clickHandler>Goliath</jLink>, both (1Sa.16-17). Following God's rejection of <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H7586G' clickHandler>Saul</jLink>, the Lord directed <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H8050G' clickHandler>Samuel</jLink> to <jLink data-type='L' data-strong='H1035G' clickHandler>Bethlehem</jLink> to anoint one of <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H3448' clickHandler>Jesse</jLink>'s sons as the new king, but the selection process confounded human expectations when God bypassed seven older brothers, including the impressive <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H0446I' clickHandler>Eliab</jLink>, to choose <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H1732' clickHandler>David</jLink>, the youngest son who was tending sheep in the fields. <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H8050G' clickHandler>Samuel</jLink>'s anointing of <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H1732' clickHandler>David</jLink> with oil was immediately followed by the Spirit of the Lord coming upon him in power, while simultaneously departing from <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H7586G' clickHandler>Saul</jLink> and being replaced by a distressing spirit that tormented the rejected king, creating a divine reversal that would define the remainder of both men's lives. <jPara></jPara> The confrontation between <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H1732' clickHandler>David</jLink> and <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H1555' clickHandler>Goliath</jLink> occurred when the <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H6430H' clickHandler>Philistine</jLink> giant challenged Israel's army for forty days from the Valley of <jLink data-type='L' data-strong='H0425L' clickHandler>Elah</jLink>, offering single combat to determine the outcome of the broader military conflict. <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H1732' clickHandler>David</jLink>, who had come to deliver food to his brothers serving in <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H7586G' clickHandler>Saul</jLink>'s army, volunteered to fight the nine-foot-tall warrior despite having no military experience or proper armor, declaring that "the Lord, who delivered me from the paw of the lion and from the paw of the bear, He will deliver me from the hand of this <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H6430H' clickHandler>Philistine</jLink>." Armed only with his shepherd's sling and five smooth stones from the brook, <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H1732' clickHandler>David</jLink> struck <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H1555' clickHandler>Goliath</jLink> in the forehead with a single stone, killing the champion instantly and triggering a complete <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H6430H' clickHandler>Philistine</jLink> retreat as their army fled in panic. This victory not only demonstrated God's power working through his chosen king but also established <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H1732' clickHandler>David</jLink>'s national reputation as a divinely blessed warrior, setting the foundation for his eventual rise to the throne while simultaneously intensifying <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H7586G' clickHandler>Saul</jLink>'s jealousy and paranoia.
events: 1018 BC: <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H8050G' clickHandler>Samuel</jLink> anoints <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H1732' clickHandler>David</jLink>, <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H3448' clickHandler>Jesse</jLink>’s youngest, as future king at <jLink data-type='L' data-strong='H1035G' clickHandler>Bethlehem</jLink>.
1018 BC: Spirit of the Lord comes upon <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H1732' clickHandler>David</jLink>.
1018 BC: Spirit of the Lord leaves <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H7586G' clickHandler>Saul</jLink>, who is tormented.
1018 BC: <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H1555' clickHandler>Goliath</jLink> challenges Israel at Valley of <jLink data-type='L' data-strong='H0425L' clickHandler>Elah</jLink> for forty days.
1018 BC: <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H1732' clickHandler>David</jLink> brings food to brothers at <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H7586G' clickHandler>Saul</jLink>’s camp.

ChronologyEntries.desc: <jChronDurationLink style='color:green'>▼</jChronDurationLink>Ahitub HP. <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H1732' clickHandler>David</jLink> flees from <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H7586G' clickHandler>Saul</jLink>
ChronologyEntries.article: 1017 BC:  King <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H7586G' clickHandler>Saul</jLink>'s escalating jealousy and paranoia transformed <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H1732' clickHandler>David</jLink>, the young hero of <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H1555' clickHandler>Goliath</jLink>, into a hunted exile (1 Sa.18-21). Following <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H1732' clickHandler>David</jLink>'s unprecedented popularity among the people, who sang "<jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H7586G' clickHandler>Saul</jLink> has slain his thousands, and <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H1732' clickHandler>David</jLink> his ten thousands," the king made repeated attempts to kill <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H1732' clickHandler>David</jLink>, first hurling a spear at him while he played the harp, then later setting impossible military tasks hoping he would die in battle against the <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H6430H' clickHandler>Philistines</jLink>. <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H1732' clickHandler>David</jLink>'s marriage to <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H7586G' clickHandler>Saul</jLink>'s daughter <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H4324G' clickHandler>Michal</jLink>, initially intended as a trap involving the dangerous bride-price of one hundred <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H6430H' clickHandler>Philistine</jLink> foreskins, instead provided him with a royal connection and an ally who would later save his life by helping him escape through a window while placing a household idol in his bed to deceive <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H7586G' clickHandler>Saul</jLink>'s messengers. <jPara></jPara> <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H1732' clickHandler>David</jLink>'s flight took him through multiple locations across ancient Israel, beginning with his escape to <jLink data-type='L' data-strong='H7414G' clickHandler>Ramah</jLink> where he sought counsel from the prophet <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H8050G' clickHandler>Samuel</jLink>, then to the priestly city of <jLink data-type='L' data-strong='H5011' clickHandler>Nob</jLink> where he received the consecrated bread and <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H1555' clickHandler>Goliath</jLink>'s sword from <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H0288G' clickHandler>Ahimelech</jLink>, and eventually to the <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H6430H' clickHandler>Philistine</jLink> city of <jLink data-type='L' data-strong='H1661' clickHandler>Gath</jLink> where he was forced to feign madness before King <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H0397' clickHandler>Achish</jLink> to avoid being recognized as Israel's champion. The year concluded with <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H1732' clickHandler>David</jLink>'s establishment of a stronghold in the cave of <jLink data-type='L' data-strong='H5725' clickHandler>Adullam</jLink>, where he began gathering a diverse group of followers including the distressed, indebted, and discontented, numbering approximately 400 men who would form the core of his future army. This period of exile, while traumatic, proved formative for <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H1732' clickHandler>David</jLink>'s leadership development and demonstrated his resourcefulness, strategic thinking, and ability to inspire loyalty even among society's marginalized members.
events: 1017 BC: <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H7586G' clickHandler>Saul</jLink> tries to kill <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H1732' clickHandler>David</jLink> with a spear in <jLink data-type='L' data-strong='H1390H' clickHandler>Gibeah</jLink>.

1017 BC: <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H7586G' clickHandler>Saul</jLink> sends <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H1732' clickHandler>David</jLink> on dangerous missions against <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H6430H' clickHandler>Philistines</jLink>.

1017 BC: <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H1732' clickHandler>David</jLink> marries <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H4324G' clickHandler>Michal</jLink> after bringing one hundred <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H6430H' clickHandler>Philistine</jLink> foreskins.

1017 BC: <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H4324G' clickHandler>Michal</jLink> helps <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H1732' clickHandler>David</jLink> escape from <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H7586G' clickHandler>Saul</jLink> in <jLink data-type='L' data-strong='H1390H' clickHandler>Gibeah</jLink>.

1017 BC: <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H1732' clickHandler>David</jLink> flees to <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H8050G' clickHandler>Samuel</jLink> at <jLink data-type='L' data-strong='H7414G' clickHandler>Ramah</jLink> for protection.

ChronologyEntries.desc: <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H1732' clickHandler>David</jLink> doesn't harm <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H7586G' clickHandler>Saul</jLink>
ChronologyEntries.article: 1015 BC:  During 1015 BC, <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H1732' clickHandler>David</jLink> demonstrated remarkable moral restraint and political wisdom by twice refusing to harm King <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H7586G' clickHandler>Saul</jLink> when presented with clear opportunities to eliminate his pursuer (1Sa.22-26). These would become defining moments in <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H1732' clickHandler>David</jLink>'s character development. The most famous incident occurred at En-gedi, where <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H1732' clickHandler>David</jLink> and his men were hiding in the depths of a cave when <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H7586G' clickHandler>Saul</jLink> unknowingly entered to relieve himself, providing <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H1732' clickHandler>David</jLink> with the perfect opportunity to kill the king; instead, <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H1732' clickHandler>David</jLink> secretly cut off a corner of <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H7586G' clickHandler>Saul</jLink>'s robe and later revealed this act to demonstrate his loyalty and restraint, declaring that he would never harm "the Lord's anointed". A second similar encounter took place in the wilderness of <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H2128J' clickHandler>Ziph</jLink>, where <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H1732' clickHandler>David</jLink> and his nephew <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H0052' clickHandler>Abishai</jLink> infiltrated <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H7586G' clickHandler>Saul</jLink>'s sleeping camp by night and could have easily killed the king, but <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H1732' clickHandler>David</jLink> again refused, taking only <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H7586G' clickHandler>Saul</jLink>'s spear and water jug as evidence of his proximity and restraint. <jPara></jPara> These acts of mercy occurred despite <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H1732' clickHandler>David</jLink>'s growing following and the increasing danger posed by <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H7586G' clickHandler>Saul</jLink>'s relentless pursuit, which had driven <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H1732' clickHandler>David</jLink> to seek refuge in various locations including the wilderness of <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H2128J' clickHandler>Ziph</jLink>, the forest of <jLink data-type='L' data-strong='H2802' clickHandler>Hereth</jLink>, and the fortified city of <jLink data-type='L' data-strong='H7084' clickHandler>Keilah</jLink>, where he had successfully defended the inhabitants against <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H6430H' clickHandler>Philistine</jLink> raiders only to learn that they would betray him to <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H7586G' clickHandler>Saul</jLink>. <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H1732' clickHandler>David</jLink>'s decision to spare <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H7586G' clickHandler>Saul</jLink>'s life on multiple occasions, despite encouragement from his followers to seize the throne by force, established important precedents regarding the sanctity of divinely appointed leadership and demonstrated his commitment to achieving power through legitimate means rather than assassination. This period also saw the tragic massacre of the priests of <jLink data-type='L' data-strong='H5011' clickHandler>Nob</jLink> by <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H1673' clickHandler>Doeg</jLink> the <jLink data-type='L' data-strong='H0123G' clickHandler>Edomite</jLink> on <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H7586G' clickHandler>Saul</jLink>'s orders, resulting in the deaths of eighty-five priests and their families, with only <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H0054' clickHandler>Abiathar</jLink> escaping to join <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H1732' clickHandler>David</jLink>, bringing the ephod that would prove invaluable for seeking divine guidance during the remainder of <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H1732' clickHandler>David</jLink>'s fugitive years.
events: 1015 BC: <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H1732' clickHandler>David</jLink> spares <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H7586G' clickHandler>Saul</jLink>’s life at En-gedi by cutting his robe but not harming him.

1015 BC: <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H1732' clickHandler>David</jLink> spares <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H7586G' clickHandler>Saul</jLink> again in the wilderness of <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H2128J' clickHandler>Ziph</jLink>, taking his spear and water jug.

1015 BC: <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H1732' clickHandler>David</jLink> rescues <jLink data-type='L' data-strong='H7084' clickHandler>Keilah</jLink> from <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H6430H' clickHandler>Philistine</jLink> raiders.
1015 BC: <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H1732' clickHandler>David</jLink> flees <jLink data-type='L' data-strong='H7084' clickHandler>Keilah</jLink> after learning of betrayal.

1015 BC: <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H1732' clickHandler>David</jLink> hides from <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H7586G' clickHandler>Saul</jLink> in <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H2128J' clickHandler>Ziph</jLink> and the forest of <jLink data-type='L' data-strong='H2802' clickHandler>Hereth</jLink>.

ChronologyEntries.desc: <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H8050G' clickHandler>Samuel</jLink> dies. <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H1732' clickHandler>David</jLink> meets <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H0026G' clickHandler>Abigail</jLink>
ChronologyEntries.article: 1012 BC:  Josephus' numbers imply <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H8050G' clickHandler>Samuel</jLink> overlapped with <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H7586G' clickHandler>Saul</jLink> for 18 years. He had retired from political leadership in 1022 BC when he annointed <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H7586G' clickHandler>Saul</jLink> as king. He also retired from any High Priestly duties, because <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H0288G' clickHandler>Ahimelech</jLink> was serving as High Priest during his retirement when <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H1732' clickHandler>David</jLink> ate the Showbread (1Sam.21.1) and when <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H7586G' clickHandler>Saul</jLink> faught at <jLink data-type='L' data-strong='H1390H' clickHandler>Gibeah</jLink> (1Sam.14.3,18 - where he is called <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H0281H' clickHandler>Ahijah</jLink>). He was still active as a prophet during <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H7586G' clickHandler>Saul</jLink>'s reign. His last recorded appearance was when <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H7586G' clickHandler>Saul</jLink> chased <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H1732' clickHandler>David</jLink> to <jLink data-type='L' data-strong='H7414G' clickHandler>Ramah</jLink> (1Sam.19.24). <jPara></jPara> After <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H8050G' clickHandler>Samuel</jLink>'s death, <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H1732' clickHandler>David</jLink>'s dispute with <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H5037' clickHandler>Nabal</jLink> introduced him to his wife <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H0026G' clickHandler>Abigail</jLink> (1Sam.25.1,3). When <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H5037' clickHandler>Nabal</jLink> died, <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H1732' clickHandler>David</jLink> married <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H0026G' clickHandler>Abigail</jLink> who has his first child. <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H1732' clickHandler>David</jLink> had already been married to <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H4324G' clickHandler>Michal</jLink>, the daughter of <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H7586G' clickHandler>Saul</jLink>, but when <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H1732' clickHandler>David</jLink> fled <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H7586G' clickHandler>Saul</jLink> gave her to <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H6406H' clickHandler>Palti</jLink> (1Sam.25.44). However, <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H1732' clickHandler>David</jLink> may have already married <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H0293H' clickHandler>Ahinoam</jLink> of <jLink data-type='L' data-strong='H3157G' clickHandler>Jezreel</jLink> (1Sam.25.42-43) because her son <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H0550G' clickHandler>Amnon</jLink> was <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H1732' clickHandler>David</jLink>'s firstborn (1Chron.3.1; 2Sam.3.2-3).
events: 1012 BC: <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H8050G' clickHandler>Samuel</jLink> dies and is buried at <jLink data-type='L' data-strong='H7414G' clickHandler>Ramah</jLink>.

1012 BC: <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H1732' clickHandler>David</jLink> disputes with <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H5037' clickHandler>Nabal</jLink> in <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H4584H' clickHandler>Maon</jLink>/<jLink data-type='L' data-strong='H3760G' clickHandler>Carmel</jLink> over provisions.

1012 BC: <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H5037' clickHandler>Nabal</jLink> dies after his conflict with <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H1732' clickHandler>David</jLink> and <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H0026G' clickHandler>Abigail</jLink>.

1012 BC: <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H1732' clickHandler>David</jLink> marries <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H0026G' clickHandler>Abigail</jLink> of <jLink data-type='L' data-strong='H3760G' clickHandler>Carmel</jLink>.

1012 BC: <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H1732' clickHandler>David</jLink> marries <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H0293H' clickHandler>Ahinoam</jLink> of <jLink data-type='L' data-strong='H3157G' clickHandler>Jezreel</jLink>, mother of <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H0550G' clickHandler>Amnon</jLink>.

ChronologyEntries.desc: <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H1732' clickHandler>David</jLink> flees to <jLink data-type='L' data-strong='H1661' clickHandler>Gath</jLink>
ChronologyEntries.article: 1011 BC:  In 1011 BC, facing the impossibility of indefinite flight within <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H3478' clickHandler>Israelite</jLink> territory and recognizing that "there is nothing better for me than that I should speedily escape to the land of the <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H6430H' clickHandler>Philistines</jLink>," <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H1732' clickHandler>David</jLink> made the strategic decision to seek asylum in <jLink data-type='L' data-strong='H1661' clickHandler>Gath</jLink> under King <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H0397' clickHandler>Achish</jLink>, bringing with him 600 men and their families in what represented a significant escalation of his separation from <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H7586G' clickHandler>Saul</jLink>'s kingdom. This move to <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H6430H' clickHandler>Philistine</jLink> territory, detailed in 1 <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H8050G' clickHandler>Samuel</jLink> 27, demonstrated <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H1732' clickHandler>David</jLink>'s political pragmatism and his understanding that <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H7586G' clickHandler>Saul</jLink> would not pursue him beyond Israel's borders, effectively ending the immediate threat to his life while positioning him in a location where he could continue building his military capabilities and political base. <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H0397' clickHandler>Achish</jLink>, perhaps recognizing <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H1732' clickHandler>David</jLink>'s value as both a military asset and a potential source of intelligence about <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H3478' clickHandler>Israelite</jLink> affairs, welcomed him warmly and eventually granted <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H1732' clickHandler>David</jLink>'s request for a residence outside the capital, assigning him the town of <jLink data-type='L' data-strong='H6860' clickHandler>Ziklag</jLink> in the <jLink data-type='L' data-strong='H5045G' clickHandler>Negev</jLink> as his personal domain. <jPara></jPara> From his base at <jLink data-type='L' data-strong='H6860' clickHandler>Ziklag</jLink>, <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H1732' clickHandler>David</jLink> conducted carefully calculated raids against the <jLink data-type='L' data-strong='H1650' clickHandler>Geshurites</jLink>, <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H1511' clickHandler>Girzites</jLink>, and <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H6002' clickHandler>Amalekites</jLink>—traditional enemies of Israel—while deliberately misleading <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H0397' clickHandler>Achish</jLink> about his targets by claiming to attack <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H3478' clickHandler>Israelite</jLink> settlements in the <jLink data-type='L' data-strong='H5045G' clickHandler>Negev</jLink> region. This deceptive strategy allowed <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H1732' clickHandler>David</jLink> to eliminate potential threats to Israel's southern border while accumulating substantial plunder and livestock, all while maintaining his cover as a loyal vassal of the <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H6430H' clickHandler>Philistine</jLink> king who believed <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H1732' clickHandler>David</jLink> had "made himself utterly abhorrent to his people Israel" and would therefore remain permanently in <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H6430H' clickHandler>Philistine</jLink> service. The sixteen-month period of <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H1732' clickHandler>David</jLink>'s residence in <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H6430H' clickHandler>Philistine</jLink> territory provided him with the security and resources necessary to strengthen his forces and prepare for his eventual return to claim Israel's throne, while his tactical deception ensured that he avoided genuine conflict with his own people and maintained his ultimate loyalty to Israel despite his temporary alliance with their traditional enemies.
events: 1011 BC: <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H1732' clickHandler>David</jLink> seeks asylum with King <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H0397' clickHandler>Achish</jLink> in <jLink data-type='L' data-strong='H1661' clickHandler>Gath</jLink>, taking 600 men and families.

1011 BC: <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H0397' clickHandler>Achish</jLink> gives <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H1732' clickHandler>David</jLink> <jLink data-type='L' data-strong='H6860' clickHandler>Ziklag</jLink> as his personal domain.
1011 BC: <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H1732' clickHandler>David</jLink> resides in <jLink data-type='L' data-strong='H6860' clickHandler>Ziklag</jLink> with his followers.

1011 BC: <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H1732' clickHandler>David</jLink> raids <jLink data-type='L' data-strong='H1650' clickHandler>Geshurites</jLink>, <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H1511' clickHandler>Girzites</jLink>, and <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H6002' clickHandler>Amalekites</jLink> from <jLink data-type='L' data-strong='H6860' clickHandler>Ziklag</jLink>.
1011 BC: <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H1732' clickHandler>David</jLink> deceives <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H0397' clickHandler>Achish</jLink> about the targets of his raids.

ChronologyEntries.desc: <jChronDurationLink style='color:black'>▼</jChronDurationLink><jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H1732' clickHandler>David</jLink> King in <jLink data-type='L' data-strong='H2275A' clickHandler>Hebron</jLink>; <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H7586G' clickHandler>Saul</jLink> dies.
ChronologyEntries.article: 1010 BC:  The catastrophic year 1010 BC witnessed the death of King <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H7586G' clickHandler>Saul</jLink> and his three sons, including <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H3083H' clickHandler>Jonathan</jLink>, during a devastating military defeat at Mount <jLink data-type='L' data-strong='H1533G' clickHandler>Gilboa</jLink>, where the <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H6430H' clickHandler>Philistines</jLink> achieved a decisive victory that effectively ended <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H7586G' clickHandler>Saul</jLink>'s reign and created the conditions for <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H1732' clickHandler>David</jLink>'s ascent to the throne. The battle, recorded in 1 <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H8050G' clickHandler>Samuel</jLink> 31 and 1 Chronicles 10, saw <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H7586G' clickHandler>Saul</jLink> critically wounded by <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H6430H' clickHandler>Philistine</jLink> archers and choosing to fall on his own sword rather than face capture and torture, while his armor-bearer followed suit, leaving Israel leaderless and demoralized. The <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H6430H' clickHandler>Philistines</jLink> subsequently beheaded <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H7586G' clickHandler>Saul</jLink>, stripped his body of armor, and displayed both his corpse and those of his sons on the walls of Beth-shan, until the valiant men of Jabesh-gilead retrieved the bodies under cover of darkness and gave them proper burial in their city. <jPara></jPara> Following news of <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H7586G' clickHandler>Saul</jLink>'s death, <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H1732' clickHandler>David</jLink> inquired of the Lord through the priest <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H0054' clickHandler>Abiathar</jLink> and was directed to go to <jLink data-type='L' data-strong='H2275A' clickHandler>Hebron</jLink>, the ancient patriarchal city in the hill country of Judah, where the elders of his own tribe anointed him as king over the house of Judah, initiating what would become a seven-year reign from this southern capital. <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H1732' clickHandler>David</jLink>'s coronation in <jLink data-type='L' data-strong='H2275A' clickHandler>Hebron</jLink> (2Sa.2:1-11) represented only partial fulfillment of his divine calling, as the northern tribes remained under the control of <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H0074' clickHandler>Abner</jLink>, who had proclaimed <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H0378' clickHandler>Ish-bosheth</jLink>, <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H7586G' clickHandler>Saul</jLink>'s surviving son, as king over Israel from his base in <jLink data-type='L' data-strong='H4266' clickHandler>Mahanaim</jLink> across the <jLink data-type='L' data-strong='H3383' clickHandler>Jordan</jLink> River. This division created a prolonged civil war between the house of <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H1732' clickHandler>David</jLink> and the house of <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H7586G' clickHandler>Saul</jLink>, during which <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H1732' clickHandler>David</jLink> gradually strengthened his position through military victories, strategic marriages, and the growing recognition that the Lord's blessing rested upon him rather than upon <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H7586G' clickHandler>Saul</jLink>'s remaining heirs, ultimately setting the stage for his eventual unification of all Israel under his rule from <jLink data-type='L' data-strong='H3389' clickHandler>Jerusalem</jLink>.
events: 1010 BC: <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H6430H' clickHandler>Philistines</jLink> defeat Israel at Mount <jLink data-type='L' data-strong='H1533G' clickHandler>Gilboa</jLink>, killing <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H7586G' clickHandler>Saul</jLink> and his sons, including <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H3083H' clickHandler>Jonathan</jLink>.
1010 BC: <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H7586G' clickHandler>Saul</jLink> commits suicide to avoid capture, and his armor-bearer follows.

1010 BC: <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H6430H' clickHandler>Philistines</jLink> behead <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H7586G' clickHandler>Saul</jLink> and display his and his sons’ bodies at Beth-shan.
1010 BC: Men of Jabesh-gilead recover and bury the bodies at <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H3003H' clickHandler>Jabesh</jLink>.

1010 BC: <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H1732' clickHandler>David</jLink> learns of <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H7586G' clickHandler>Saul</jLink>’s death through <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H0054' clickHandler>Abiathar</jLink>.

ChronologyEntries.desc: <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H3097G' clickHandler>Joab</jLink> & <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H0074' clickHandler>Abner</jLink> rivalry
ChronologyEntries.article: 1008 BC:  The year 1008 BC marked the intensification of a critical power struggle between two military commanders that would significantly shape Israel's path toward unification under <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H1732' clickHandler>David</jLink>'s rule. Following King <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H7586G' clickHandler>Saul</jLink>'s death at Mount <jLink data-type='L' data-strong='H1533G' clickHandler>Gilboa</jLink> in 1010 BC, the nation had become divided between the house of <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H1732' clickHandler>David</jLink>, ruling over Judah from <jLink data-type='L' data-strong='H2275A' clickHandler>Hebron</jLink>, and the house of <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H7586G' clickHandler>Saul</jLink>, led by <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H0074' clickHandler>Abner</jLink> who had installed <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H7586G' clickHandler>Saul</jLink>'s surviving son <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H0378' clickHandler>Ish-bosheth</jLink> as king over the northern tribes from his base in <jLink data-type='L' data-strong='H4266' clickHandler>Mahanaim</jLink> across the <jLink data-type='L' data-strong='H3383' clickHandler>Jordan</jLink> River. The rivalry between <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H3097G' clickHandler>Joab</jLink>, <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H1732' clickHandler>David</jLink>'s military commander and nephew, and <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H0074' clickHandler>Abner</jLink>, the experienced general who had served <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H7586G' clickHandler>Saul</jLink> faithfully, represented more than personal animosity—it embodied the fundamental tension between competing claims to Israel's throne and the challenge of reuniting a fractured nation. <jPara></jPara> The conflict became intensely personal when <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H0074' clickHandler>Abner</jLink> killed <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H3097G' clickHandler>Joab</jLink>'s younger brother <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H6214G' clickHandler>Asahel</jLink> during a pursuit following the battle at <jLink data-type='L' data-strong='H1391' clickHandler>Gibeon</jLink>, an event recorded in 2 <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H8050G' clickHandler>Samuel</jLink> 2 that would fuel <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H3097G' clickHandler>Joab</jLink>'s desire for vengeance throughout the subsequent civil war period. As the house of <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H1732' clickHandler>David</jLink> gradually strengthened while <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H7586G' clickHandler>Saul</jLink>'s house weakened, <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H0074' clickHandler>Abner</jLink> eventually quarreled with <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H0378' clickHandler>Ish-bosheth</jLink> and made overtures to <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H1732' clickHandler>David</jLink> about defecting and helping to unite all Israel under his rule. However, <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H3097G' clickHandler>Joab</jLink>'s assassination of <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H0074' clickHandler>Abner</jLink>, carried out under the pretense of private conversation but motivated by both personal revenge and political calculation, complicated <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H1732' clickHandler>David</jLink>'s efforts to achieve peaceful unification and cast suspicion on the future king's integrity, forcing <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H1732' clickHandler>David</jLink> to publicly mourn <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H0074' clickHandler>Abner</jLink> and distance himself from the murder to maintain his reputation among the northern tribes.
events: 1008 BC: Battle at <jLink data-type='L' data-strong='H1391' clickHandler>Gibeon</jLink> pits <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H3097G' clickHandler>Joab</jLink>’s forces (<jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H1732' clickHandler>David</jLink>) against <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H0074' clickHandler>Abner</jLink>’s (<jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H0378' clickHandler>Ish-bosheth</jLink>).
1008 BC: <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H0074' clickHandler>Abner</jLink> kills <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H6214G' clickHandler>Asahel</jLink> in battle.

1008 BC: <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H3097G' clickHandler>Joab</jLink> seeks revenge on <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H0074' clickHandler>Abner</jLink> for <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H6214G' clickHandler>Asahel</jLink>’s death.

1008 BC: <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H0074' clickHandler>Abner</jLink> defects to <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H1732' clickHandler>David</jLink> after quarreling with <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H0378' clickHandler>Ish-bosheth</jLink>.

1008 BC: <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H3097G' clickHandler>Joab</jLink> assassinates <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H0074' clickHandler>Abner</jLink> in <jLink data-type='L' data-strong='H2275A' clickHandler>Hebron</jLink>.

ChronologyEntries.desc: <jChronDurationLink style='color:black'>▼</jChronDurationLink><jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H1732' clickHandler>David</jLink> King of whole nation
ChronologyEntries.article: 1003 BC:  In 1003 BC, <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H1732' clickHandler>David</jLink> achieved one of the most significant milestones in Israel's political history when all the tribes of Israel came to <jLink data-type='L' data-strong='H2275A' clickHandler>Hebron</jLink> to anoint him as king over the entire nation, ending the seven-year division that had followed <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H7586G' clickHandler>Saul</jLink>'s death. The tribal representatives acknowledged their kinship with <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H1732' clickHandler>David</jLink> and recalled his leadership capabilities that had been evident even during <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H7586G' clickHandler>Saul</jLink>'s reign, recognizing that "in time past, when <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H7586G' clickHandler>Saul</jLink> was king over us, you were the one who led Israel out and brought them in". This unanimous recognition by the tribal elders represented more than political expediency—it reflected their understanding that <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H1732' clickHandler>David</jLink>'s kingship had been divinely ordained, as they explicitly stated, "The Lord said to you, 'You shall shepherd my people Israel, and you shall be ruler over Israel'". <jPara></jPara> The coronation ceremony at <jLink data-type='L' data-strong='H2275A' clickHandler>Hebron</jLink> was marked by the formal making of a covenant between <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H1732' clickHandler>David</jLink> and the representatives of all Israel, conducted "before the Lord" and culminating in <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H1732' clickHandler>David</jLink>'s anointing as king over the unified nation. This momentous occasion was attended by vast numbers of skilled warriors from every tribe who came to <jLink data-type='L' data-strong='H2275A' clickHandler>Hebron</jLink> with the express purpose of making <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H1732' clickHandler>David</jLink> king, demonstrating that "all Israel were of one mind" in their support for his leadership (1Ch.11:10-12:40). At thirty years of age, <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H1732' clickHandler>David</jLink> thus began what would become a forty-year reign—seven and a half years over Judah alone from <jLink data-type='L' data-strong='H2275A' clickHandler>Hebron</jLink>, and thirty-three years over all Israel and Judah from <jLink data-type='L' data-strong='H3389' clickHandler>Jerusalem</jLink>—establishing the foundation for Israel's golden age and the Davidic dynasty that would endure for centuries.
events: 1003 BC: All tribes assemble at <jLink data-type='L' data-strong='H2275A' clickHandler>Hebron</jLink> to meet <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H1732' clickHandler>David</jLink>.
1003 BC: <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H1732' clickHandler>David</jLink> and Israel’s elders make a covenant at <jLink data-type='L' data-strong='H2275A' clickHandler>Hebron</jLink>.
1003 BC: <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H1732' clickHandler>David</jLink> is anointed king over all Israel by the elders.
1003 BC: Vast numbers of warriors from every tribe attend <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H1732' clickHandler>David</jLink>’s coronation.
1003 BC: The division between Judah and the northern tribes ends.

ChronologyEntries.desc: <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H1732' clickHandler>David</jLink> conquers <jLink data-type='L' data-strong='H3389' clickHandler>Jerusalem</jLink>
ChronologyEntries.article: 1002 BC:  The conquest of <jLink data-type='L' data-strong='H3389' clickHandler>Jerusalem</jLink> in 1002 BC represented one of <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H1732' clickHandler>David</jLink>'s most strategically brilliant military and political achievements, transforming an ancient <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H2983G' clickHandler>Jebusite</jLink> stronghold into the eternal capital of Israel and establishing the geographic center of his unified kingdom. The city, known to its inhabitants as <jLink data-type='L' data-strong='H3389' clickHandler>Jebus</jLink>, was considered virtually impregnable by the <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H2983G' clickHandler>Jebusites</jLink>, who mockingly declared to <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H1732' clickHandler>David</jLink>'s approaching forces that "even the blind and lame" could defend their fortress. However, <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H1732' clickHandler>David</jLink>'s military commander <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H3097G' clickHandler>Joab</jLink>, son of <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H6870G' clickHandler>Zeruiah</jLink>, led a successful assault that captured the stronghold of Zion, an achievement that earned him promotion to chief commander and demonstrated that divine favor, rather than human fortifications, determined victory. <jPara></jPara> <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H1732' clickHandler>David</jLink>'s selection of <jLink data-type='L' data-strong='H3389' clickHandler>Jerusalem</jLink> as his capital proved to be a masterstroke of political wisdom, as the city had never belonged to any <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H3478' clickHandler>Israelite</jLink> tribe and thus represented neutral territory that could unite rather than divide the nation. Following the conquest, <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H1732' clickHandler>David</jLink> immediately began fortifying and expanding the city, establishing his residence there and transforming it from a modest <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H2983G' clickHandler>Jebusite</jLink> settlement into a worthy capital for his growing kingdom. The significance of this achievement extended far beyond military conquest, as 1 Chronicles 17 records God's promise to <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H1732' clickHandler>David</jLink> that his dynasty would endure forever and that his son would build a permanent house for the Lord in this very city, establishing <jLink data-type='L' data-strong='H3389' clickHandler>Jerusalem</jLink> not only as the political center of Israel but as the future site of the temple and the focal point of Israel's covenant relationship with <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H3068G' clickHandler>Yahweh</jLink>.
