events: 1002 BC: <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H1732' clickHandler>David</jLink> conquers <jLink data-type='L' data-strong='H3389' clickHandler>Jerusalem</jLink> (<jLink data-type='L' data-strong='H3389' clickHandler>Jebus</jLink>) and renames it the City of <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H1732' clickHandler>David</jLink>.
1002 BC: <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H3097G' clickHandler>Joab</jLink> leads the assault on <jLink data-type='L' data-strong='H3389' clickHandler>Jerusalem</jLink> and becomes chief commander.
1002 BC: <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H1732' clickHandler>David</jLink> establishes <jLink data-type='L' data-strong='H3389' clickHandler>Jerusalem</jLink> as the capital of Israel.
1002 BC: <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H1732' clickHandler>David</jLink> fortifies and expands <jLink data-type='L' data-strong='H3389' clickHandler>Jerusalem</jLink>.
1002 BC: God promises <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H1732' clickHandler>David</jLink> an everlasting dynasty and that his son will build the temple.

ChronologyEntries.desc: <jChronDurationLink style='color:green'>▼</jChronDurationLink><jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H6659G' clickHandler>Zadok</jLink> & <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H0054' clickHandler>Abiathar</jLink> HPs. Ark to <jLink data-type='L' data-strong='H3389' clickHandler>Jerusalem</jLink>
ChronologyEntries.article: 1000 BC:  The year 1000 BC witnessed one of the most spiritually significant events in Israel's history when King <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H1732' clickHandler>David</jLink> successfully transported the Ark of the Covenant to <jLink data-type='L' data-strong='H3389' clickHandler>Jerusalem</jLink>, establishing the city as the religious as well as political center of the unified nation. <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H1732' clickHandler>David</jLink>'s first attempt to bring the sacred Ark from <jLink data-type='L' data-strong='H7157' clickHandler>Kiriath-Jearim</jLink> had ended in tragedy when <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H5798A' clickHandler>Uzzah</jLink> was struck dead for touching it inappropriately, causing the king to temporarily house the Ark with <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H5654' clickHandler>Obed-Edom</jLink> the <jLink data-type='L' data-strong='H1661' clickHandler>Gittite</jLink>, where it brought divine blessing to his household. Learning from this sobering experience about the importance of proper reverence and ritual observance, <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H1732' clickHandler>David</jLink> carefully prepared for the second attempt by gathering the <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H3878' clickHandler>Levites</jLink> and priests, instructing them to sanctify themselves and transport the Ark according to the precise requirements established by <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H4872' clickHandler>Moses</jLink>. <jPara></jPara> The successful procession to <jLink data-type='L' data-strong='H3389' clickHandler>Jerusalem</jLink> was marked by extraordinary celebration, featuring elaborate musical accompaniment, regular sacrifices, and <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H1732' clickHandler>David</jLink>'s own exuberant dancing before the Ark, though his uninhibited display of joy drew criticism from his wife <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H4324G' clickHandler>Michal</jLink>, daughter of <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H7586G' clickHandler>Saul</jLink>. Upon the Ark's installation in the special tent <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H1732' clickHandler>David</jLink> had prepared in <jLink data-type='L' data-strong='H3389' clickHandler>Jerusalem</jLink>, the king established a regular system of <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H3878' clickHandler>Levitical</jLink> ministry before the sacred object, organizing ongoing worship, thanksgiving, and musical praise that would continue throughout his reign. The profound spiritual significance of this achievement was confirmed when the prophet <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H5416H' clickHandler>Nathan</jLink> delivered God's covenant promise to <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H1732' clickHandler>David</jLink>, declaring that while <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H1732' clickHandler>David</jLink> would not build the temple, his son would construct a permanent house for the Lord, and <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H1732' clickHandler>David</jLink>'s dynasty would endure forever—thus linking <jLink data-type='L' data-strong='H3389' clickHandler>Jerusalem</jLink>'s status as the dwelling place of the Ark with the eternal promises of the Davidic covenant.
events: 1000 BC: <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H1732' clickHandler>David</jLink> organizes the transport of the Ark of the Covenant from <jLink data-type='L' data-strong='H7157' clickHandler>Kiriath-Jearim</jLink> to <jLink data-type='L' data-strong='H3389' clickHandler>Jerusalem</jLink>.

1000 BC: <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H5798A' clickHandler>Uzzah</jLink> touches the Ark and is struck dead by God, so the Ark stays at <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H5654' clickHandler>Obed-Edom</jLink> the <jLink data-type='L' data-strong='H1661' clickHandler>Gittite</jLink>’s house.
1000 BC: <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H5654' clickHandler>Obed-Edom</jLink>’s household is blessed while the Ark resides there.

1000 BC: <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H1732' clickHandler>David</jLink> successfully brings the Ark to <jLink data-type='L' data-strong='H3389' clickHandler>Jerusalem</jLink> with <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H3878' clickHandler>Levites</jLink> and priests, celebrating.

1000 BC: <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H1732' clickHandler>David</jLink> dances exuberantly before the Ark, drawing criticism from <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H4324G' clickHandler>Michal</jLink>.

ChronologyEntries.desc: <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H1732' clickHandler>David</jLink> builds his palace
ChronologyEntries.article: 999 BC:  In 999 BC, King <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H1732' clickHandler>David</jLink> undertook the construction of his royal palace in <jLink data-type='L' data-strong='H3389' clickHandler>Jerusalem</jLink>, marking a significant milestone in the establishment and legitimation of his monarchy (1Ch.14:1-7). This ambitious building project was facilitated through diplomatic cooperation with <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H2438G' clickHandler>Hiram</jLink>, king of <jLink data-type='L' data-strong='H6865' clickHandler>Tyre</jLink>, who provided cedar logs, skilled carpenters, and experienced stonemasons, demonstrating the international recognition <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H1732' clickHandler>David</jLink>'s kingdom had achieved among neighboring powers. The use of imported cedar wood from <jLink data-type='L' data-strong='H3844G' clickHandler>Lebanon</jLink>, a luxury material highly prized throughout the ancient Near East, signified both <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H1732' clickHandler>David</jLink>'s growing wealth and his kingdom's integration into regional trade networks that characterized established monarchies of the period. <jPara></jPara> The palace construction represented more than mere royal accommodation; it served as a powerful symbol of centralized authority and the institutionalization of Israel's monarchy in accordance with ancient Near Eastern political norms. Archaeological evidence from contemporary civilizations suggests that royal palaces functioned as multi-purpose complexes containing administrative offices, audience halls, storage facilities, and residential quarters, all designed to project power and legitimacy to both subjects and foreign dignitaries. <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H1732' clickHandler>David</jLink>'s decision to build this palace in <jLink data-type='L' data-strong='H3389' clickHandler>Jerusalem</jLink>, just three years after capturing the city and establishing it as his capital, reflected his strategic vision of creating a permanent political center that would unite the northern and southern tribes under his unified rule.
events: 999 BC: <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H1732' clickHandler>David</jLink> begins constructing his royal palace in <jLink data-type='L' data-strong='H3389' clickHandler>Jerusalem</jLink>.

999 BC: <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H2438G' clickHandler>Hiram</jLink>, king of <jLink data-type='L' data-strong='H6865' clickHandler>Tyre</jLink>, sends cedar, carpenters, and stonemasons to help build the palace.

999 BC: <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H1732' clickHandler>David</jLink>’s alliance with <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H2438G' clickHandler>Hiram</jLink> of <jLink data-type='L' data-strong='H6865' clickHandler>Tyre</jLink> increases his kingdom’s international prestige.
999 BC: Imported cedar from <jLink data-type='L' data-strong='H3844G' clickHandler>Lebanon</jLink> is used for <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H1732' clickHandler>David</jLink>’s palace.

ChronologyEntries.article: 995 BC:  A series of decisive military campaigns established <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H1732' clickHandler>David</jLink> as the dominant power in the Levantine region, as detailed in 2 <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H8050G' clickHandler>Samuel</jLink> 8 and 1 Chronicles 18. These systematic conquests included the subjugation of the <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H6430H' clickHandler>Philistines</jLink>, effectively ending their centuries-long threat to Israel; the defeat of the <jLink data-type='L' data-strong='H4124G' clickHandler>Moabites</jLink>, resulting in their submission and payment of tribute; the destruction of <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H1909' clickHandler>Hadadezer</jLink> king of <jLink data-type='L' data-strong='H6678G' clickHandler>Zobah</jLink>'s forces, capturing substantial amounts of gold and bronze; and the conquest of the <jLink data-type='L' data-strong='H0123G' clickHandler>Arameans</jLink> of <jLink data-type='L' data-strong='H1834' clickHandler>Damascus</jLink>, leading to the establishment of <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H3478' clickHandler>Israelite</jLink> garrisons in strategic locations throughout <jLink data-type='L' data-strong='H0758I' clickHandler>Aram</jLink>. <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H1732' clickHandler>David</jLink>'s military success extended beyond mere conquest, as he systematically established administrative control over defeated territories while accumulating vast quantities of precious metals that would later be dedicated for the construction of the temple. <jPara></jPara> These victories transformed Israel from a recently unified tribal confederation into a regional empire controlling trade routes and collecting tribute from vassal states throughout the southern Levant. The strategic nature of <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H1732' clickHandler>David</jLink>'s campaigns demonstrates sophisticated military planning, as he systematically eliminated traditional enemies while securing Israel's borders and establishing buffer zones against future threats. Archaeological evidence from this period, while limited, suggests widespread destruction and rebuilding in <jLink data-type='L' data-strong='H3667A' clickHandler>Canaanite</jLink> cities, consistent with the biblical portrayal of extensive military activity that reshaped the political landscape of the ancient Near East and positioned Israel as a major power comparable to contemporary kingdoms in <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H4714H' clickHandler>Egypt</jLink> and <jLink data-type='L' data-strong='H0763G' clickHandler>Mesopotamia</jLink>.
events: 995 BC: <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H1732' clickHandler>David</jLink> defeats the <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H6430H' clickHandler>Philistines</jLink>, ending their threat to Israel.
995 BC: <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H1732' clickHandler>David</jLink> conquers the <jLink data-type='L' data-strong='H4124G' clickHandler>Moabites</jLink>, who pay tribute to Israel.

995 BC: <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H1732' clickHandler>David</jLink> defeats <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H1909' clickHandler>Hadadezer</jLink>, king of <jLink data-type='L' data-strong='H6678G' clickHandler>Zobah</jLink>, capturing gold and bronze.

995 BC: <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H1732' clickHandler>David</jLink> conquers the <jLink data-type='L' data-strong='H0123G' clickHandler>Arameans</jLink> of <jLink data-type='L' data-strong='H1834' clickHandler>Damascus</jLink>, installs garrisons, and collects tribute.
995 BC: <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H1732' clickHandler>David</jLink> dedicates gold, silver, and bronze from conquests for the temple.

ChronologyEntries.desc: <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H1732' clickHandler>David</jLink> and <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H4648G' clickHandler>Mephibosheth</jLink>
ChronologyEntries.article: 994 BC:  King <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H1732' clickHandler>David</jLink> demonstrated remarkable covenant faithfulness by seeking out surviving members of <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H7586G' clickHandler>Saul</jLink>'s family to show kindness for the sake of his beloved friend <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H3083H' clickHandler>Jonathan</jLink>, ultimately discovering and restoring <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H4648G' clickHandler>Mephibosheth</jLink>, <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H3083H' clickHandler>Jonathan</jLink>'s disabled son, as recorded in 2 <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H8050G' clickHandler>Samuel</jLink> 9. Through his servant <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H6717' clickHandler>Ziba</jLink>, <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H1732' clickHandler>David</jLink> learned that <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H4648G' clickHandler>Mephibosheth</jLink>, who had been crippled in both feet since childhood when his nurse dropped him during the flight from the news of <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H7586G' clickHandler>Saul</jLink> and <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H3083H' clickHandler>Jonathan</jLink>'s deaths at <jLink data-type='L' data-strong='H1533G' clickHandler>Gilboa</jLink>, was living in the house of <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H4353H' clickHandler>Machir</jLink> in <jLink data-type='L' data-strong='H3810' clickHandler>Lo-debar</jLink> in relative obscurity and poverty. <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H1732' clickHandler>David</jLink>'s response was both generous and politically significant: he restored all the land that had belonged to <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H7586G' clickHandler>Saul</jLink> to <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H4648G' clickHandler>Mephibosheth</jLink> and granted him the permanent privilege of eating at the king's table "like one of the king's sons," effectively treating <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H7586G' clickHandler>Saul</jLink>'s grandson as a member of his own royal household. <jPara></jPara> This act of magnanimity served multiple purposes beyond personal loyalty, demonstrating <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H1732' clickHandler>David</jLink>'s commitment to honoring his covenant with <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H3083H' clickHandler>Jonathan</jLink> while simultaneously displaying royal mercy that could help legitimize his rule among former supporters of <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H7586G' clickHandler>Saul</jLink>'s dynasty. The restoration of <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H7586G' clickHandler>Saul</jLink>'s property rights to his heir showed <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H1732' clickHandler>David</jLink>'s respect for traditional inheritance laws and his desire to demonstrate that his kingship represented continuity rather than revolutionary change, while <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H4648G' clickHandler>Mephibosheth</jLink>'s presence at the royal table provided both honor for <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H7586G' clickHandler>Saul</jLink>'s family and subtle assurance that potential rivals would remain under <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H1732' clickHandler>David</jLink>'s benevolent supervision. This episode reflects the complex political dynamics of ancient Near Eastern succession, where new dynasties often faced the challenge of neutralizing potential claims from previous royal families while maintaining legitimacy through displays of justice and mercy.
events: 994 BC: <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H1732' clickHandler>David</jLink> seeks surviving members of <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H7586G' clickHandler>Saul</jLink>’s family for <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H3083H' clickHandler>Jonathan</jLink>’s sake.

994 BC: <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H4648G' clickHandler>Mephibosheth</jLink>, <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H3083H' clickHandler>Jonathan</jLink>’s disabled son, is found in <jLink data-type='L' data-strong='H3810' clickHandler>Lo-debar</jLink>.

994 BC: <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H1732' clickHandler>David</jLink> restores <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H7586G' clickHandler>Saul</jLink>’s land to <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H4648G' clickHandler>Mephibosheth</jLink>.

994 BC: <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H4648G' clickHandler>Mephibosheth</jLink> is granted a permanent place at <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H1732' clickHandler>David</jLink>’s table in <jLink data-type='L' data-strong='H3389' clickHandler>Jerusalem</jLink>.

994 BC: <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H1732' clickHandler>David</jLink> appoints <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H6717' clickHandler>Ziba</jLink> and his sons to serve <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H4648G' clickHandler>Mephibosheth</jLink>.

ChronologyEntries.desc: <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H1732' clickHandler>David</jLink> defeats the <jLink data-type='L' data-strong='H5983' clickHandler>Ammonites</jLink>
ChronologyEntries.article: 991 BC:  The year 991 BC saw <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H1732' clickHandler>David</jLink> achieve a decisive military triumph over a formidable coalition led by the <jLink data-type='L' data-strong='H5983' clickHandler>Ammonites</jLink>, who had enlisted <jLink data-type='L' data-strong='H0123G' clickHandler>Aramean</jLink> mercenaries to strengthen their forces against Israel, as documented in 2 <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H8050G' clickHandler>Samuel</jLink> 10 and 1 Chronicles 19. The conflict originated when <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H1732' clickHandler>David</jLink> sent ambassadors to express condolences to <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H2586G' clickHandler>Hanun</jLink>, the new king of the <jLink data-type='L' data-strong='H5983' clickHandler>Ammonites</jLink>, following his father <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H5176H' clickHandler>Nahash</jLink>'s death, but these diplomatic envoys were shamefully mistreated—their beards half-shaved and their garments cut off at the buttocks—in a deliberate insult that essentially constituted a declaration of war. Recognizing the gravity of their provocation, the <jLink data-type='L' data-strong='H5983' clickHandler>Ammonites</jLink> hired <jLink data-type='L' data-strong='H0758I' clickHandler>Syrian</jLink> mercenaries from <jLink data-type='L' data-strong='H1050' clickHandler>Beth-rehob</jLink>, <jLink data-type='L' data-strong='H6678G' clickHandler>Zobah</jLink>, <jLink data-type='L' data-strong='H4601R' clickHandler>Maacah</jLink>, and <jLink data-type='L' data-strong='H2897' clickHandler>Tob</jLink>, creating a two-front military threat that required <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H1732' clickHandler>David</jLink>'s most experienced commanders to address. <jPara></jPara> <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H1732' clickHandler>David</jLink>'s response demonstrated sophisticated military strategy, as he dispatched <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H3097G' clickHandler>Joab</jLink> to command the regular army against the <jLink data-type='L' data-strong='H5983' clickHandler>Ammonite</jLink> forces at <jLink data-type='L' data-strong='H5983' clickHandler>Rabbah</jLink> while positioning <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H0052' clickHandler>Abishai</jLink> with select troops to counter the <jLink data-type='L' data-strong='H0123G' clickHandler>Aramean</jLink> allies, with both commanders agreeing to provide mutual support as battle conditions required. The campaign resulted in complete victory for Israel: the <jLink data-type='L' data-strong='H0123G' clickHandler>Aramean</jLink> mercenaries fled when confronted by <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H3097G' clickHandler>Joab</jLink>'s assault, prompting the <jLink data-type='L' data-strong='H5983' clickHandler>Ammonites</jLink> to retreat to their fortified city, while subsequent <jLink data-type='L' data-strong='H0123G' clickHandler>Aramean</jLink> attempts to rally additional forces were decisively defeated by <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H1732' clickHandler>David</jLink> himself, leading to their submission and the payment of tribute. This triumph not only secured Israel's eastern borders but also demonstrated to neighboring powers that <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H1732' clickHandler>David</jLink>'s kingdom possessed both the military capacity and strategic leadership necessary to defeat large coalitions, further consolidating his position as the dominant regional authority in the Levant.
events: 991 BC: <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H1732' clickHandler>David</jLink> sends ambassadors to <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H2586G' clickHandler>Hanun</jLink> of <jLink data-type='L' data-strong='H5983' clickHandler>Ammon</jLink> after <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H5176H' clickHandler>Nahash</jLink>’s death.
991 BC: <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H2586G' clickHandler>Hanun</jLink> humiliates <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H1732' clickHandler>David</jLink>’s envoys, provoking war.

991 BC: <jLink data-type='L' data-strong='H5983' clickHandler>Ammonites</jLink> hire <jLink data-type='L' data-strong='H0123G' clickHandler>Aramean</jLink> mercenaries from <jLink data-type='L' data-strong='H1050' clickHandler>Beth-rehob</jLink>, <jLink data-type='L' data-strong='H6678G' clickHandler>Zobah</jLink>, <jLink data-type='L' data-strong='H4601R' clickHandler>Maacah</jLink>, and <jLink data-type='L' data-strong='H2897' clickHandler>Tob</jLink>.

991 BC: <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H3097G' clickHandler>Joab</jLink> leads <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H3478' clickHandler>Israelite</jLink> forces against <jLink data-type='L' data-strong='H5983' clickHandler>Ammon</jLink> at <jLink data-type='L' data-strong='H5983' clickHandler>Rabbah</jLink>, with <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H0052' clickHandler>Abishai</jLink> against the <jLink data-type='L' data-strong='H0123G' clickHandler>Arameans</jLink>.

991 BC: The <jLink data-type='L' data-strong='H0123G' clickHandler>Aramean</jLink> mercenaries flee before <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H3097G' clickHandler>Joab</jLink>, so <jLink data-type='L' data-strong='H5983' clickHandler>Ammonites</jLink> retreat to their city.

ChronologyEntries.desc: <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H1732' clickHandler>David</jLink> and <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H1339' clickHandler>Bathsheba</jLink>
ChronologyEntries.article: 990 BC:  The year 990 BC marked one of the most tragic moral failures in King <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H1732' clickHandler>David</jLink>'s reign when he committed adultery with <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H1339' clickHandler>Bathsheba</jLink>, wife of <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H0223A' clickHandler>Uriah</jLink> the <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H2845' clickHandler>Hittite</jLink>, during the spring campaign season when "kings go out to battle," as recorded in 2 <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H8050G' clickHandler>Samuel</jLink> 11. While his army under <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H3097G' clickHandler>Joab</jLink>'s command was besieging <jLink data-type='L' data-strong='H5983' clickHandler>Rabbah</jLink>, the <jLink data-type='L' data-strong='H5983' clickHandler>Ammonite</jLink> capital, <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H1732' clickHandler>David</jLink> remained in <jLink data-type='L' data-strong='H3389' clickHandler>Jerusalem</jLink> where he observed <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H1339' clickHandler>Bathsheba</jLink> bathing from his palace rooftop. Despite learning that she was the wife of <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H0223A' clickHandler>Uriah</jLink>, one of his elite warriors known as "the Thirty," <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H1732' clickHandler>David</jLink> summoned her to the palace, and their encounter resulted in her pregnancy. When <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H1732' clickHandler>David</jLink>'s attempts to conceal the adultery by recalling <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H0223A' clickHandler>Uriah</jLink> from battle failed—as the loyal soldier refused to enjoy marital privileges while his comrades remained in the field—the king orchestrated <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H0223A' clickHandler>Uriah</jLink>'s death by instructing <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H3097G' clickHandler>Joab</jLink> to place him at the front of the fiercest fighting and then withdraw support, ensuring his demise. <jPara></jPara> This episode represents a catastrophic abuse of royal power, combining adultery, deception, and murder in a sequence that would have lasting consequences for <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H1732' clickHandler>David</jLink>'s household and kingdom. The parallel account focuses exclusively on the successful military campaign against <jLink data-type='L' data-strong='H5983' clickHandler>Rabbah</jLink> (1Ch.20:1-3), omitting the <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H1339' clickHandler>Bathsheba</jLink> narrative entirely, which suggests the Chronicler's emphasis on <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H1732' clickHandler>David</jLink>'s public achievements rather than his private failures. After <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H0223A' clickHandler>Uriah</jLink>'s death and <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H1339' clickHandler>Bathsheba</jLink>'s period of mourning, <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H1732' clickHandler>David</jLink> married her, attempting to legitimize their relationship, but the text ominously concludes that "the thing that <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H1732' clickHandler>David</jLink> had done displeased the Lord," foreshadowing the divine judgment that would follow.The <jLink data-type='L' data-strong='H5983' clickHandler>Ammonite</jLink> campaign reflects the broader pattern of <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H1732' clickHandler>David</jLink>'s territorial expansion in the Transjordan region.
events: 990 BC: <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H1732' clickHandler>David</jLink> commits adultery with <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H1339' clickHandler>Bathsheba</jLink> in <jLink data-type='L' data-strong='H3389' clickHandler>Jerusalem</jLink> while his army besieges <jLink data-type='L' data-strong='H5983' clickHandler>Rabbah</jLink>.
990 BC: <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H1339' clickHandler>Bathsheba</jLink> becomes pregnant by <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H1732' clickHandler>David</jLink>.

990 BC: <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H1732' clickHandler>David</jLink> tries and fails to conceal the affair by recalling <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H0223A' clickHandler>Uriah</jLink>, who refuses to visit <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H1339' clickHandler>Bathsheba</jLink>.

990 BC: <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H1732' clickHandler>David</jLink> arranges <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H0223A' clickHandler>Uriah</jLink>’s death in battle by <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H3097G' clickHandler>Joab</jLink>’s hand.
990 BC: <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H3097G' clickHandler>Joab</jLink> leads the siege of <jLink data-type='L' data-strong='H5983' clickHandler>Rabbah</jLink>.

ChronologyEntries.article: 989 BC:  The year 989 BC witnessed the fulfillment of divine judgment upon King <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H1732' clickHandler>David</jLink> through the prophet <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H5416H' clickHandler>Nathan</jLink>'s confrontation and the subsequent death of his first child with <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H1339' clickHandler>Bathsheba</jLink>, as detailed in 2 <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H8050G' clickHandler>Samuel</jLink> 12. <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H5416H' clickHandler>Nathan</jLink> approached <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H1732' clickHandler>David</jLink> with the famous parable of the rich man who stole the poor man's beloved ewe lamb, skillfully leading the king to pronounce judgment upon himself before revealing, "You are the man!". The prophet's indictment declared that because <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H1732' clickHandler>David</jLink> had "despised the commandment of the Lord" through his adultery with <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H1339' clickHandler>Bathsheba</jLink> and murder of <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H0223A' clickHandler>Uriah</jLink>, divine judgment would bring violence to his household, public shame, and the death of the child born from their illicit union. Despite <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H1732' clickHandler>David</jLink>'s immediate repentance—expressed in his heartfelt confession "I have sinned against the Lord"—<jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H5416H' clickHandler>Nathan</jLink> announced that while <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H1732' clickHandler>David</jLink>'s sin was forgiven and he would not die, the child would not survive. <jPara></jPara> The infant's illness prompted <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H1732' clickHandler>David</jLink>'s intense mourning, fasting, and supplication for seven days, as he lay on the ground pleading with God for the child's life, behavior that puzzled his servants who feared to inform him when the baby died. When <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H1732' clickHandler>David</jLink> learned of the death, he surprised everyone by washing, changing clothes, worshiping in the house of the Lord, and requesting food, explaining that while the child lived he hoped God might show mercy, but now that death had occurred, he could not bring the child back and would eventually join him in death. This episode demonstrates both the inevitable consequences of sin even after genuine repentance and <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H1732' clickHandler>David</jLink>'s mature understanding of divine sovereignty and the finality of death. The narrative serves as a pivotal moment illustrating the principle that while God's forgiveness removes the eternal penalty of sin, temporal consequences may still follow, and it establishes a theological framework for understanding divine justice and mercy that would influence Israel's understanding of covenant relationship throughout their history.
events: 989 BC: <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H5416H' clickHandler>Nathan</jLink> confronts <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H1732' clickHandler>David</jLink> in <jLink data-type='L' data-strong='H3389' clickHandler>Jerusalem</jLink>, exposing his sin with <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H1339' clickHandler>Bathsheba</jLink> and <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H0223A' clickHandler>Uriah</jLink>’s murder.

989 BC: <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H5416H' clickHandler>Nathan</jLink> pronounces God’s judgment: violence in <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H1732' clickHandler>David</jLink>’s house, public shame, and the death of <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H1339' clickHandler>Bathsheba</jLink>’s child.
989 BC: <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H1732' clickHandler>David</jLink> repents, confessing his sin to the Lord.
989 BC: <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H1732' clickHandler>David</jLink> and <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H1339' clickHandler>Bathsheba</jLink>’s first child dies after seven days.
989 BC: <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H1732' clickHandler>David</jLink> mourns, worships, and resumes normal life after the child’s death.

ChronologyEntries.article: 988 BC:  Following the death of their first child, <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H1732' clickHandler>David</jLink> and <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H1339' clickHandler>Bathsheba</jLink> welcomed the birth of <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H8010' clickHandler>Solomon</jLink>, whose name derives from the Hebrew word shalom meaning "peace," signifying God's restored favor and the child's destined role as a peaceful ruler (1Ch.22:9). The birth of <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H8010' clickHandler>Solomon</jLink> represented divine grace following judgment, as <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H5416H' clickHandler>Nathan</jLink> the prophet had previously delivered God's promise to <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H1732' clickHandler>David</jLink> that despite his sin, his dynasty would endure and his successor would build the temple that <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H1732' clickHandler>David</jLink> himself was not permitted to construct due to his involvement in warfare. According to the biblical account, God specifically declared that <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H8010' clickHandler>Solomon</jLink> would be "a man of rest" who would experience peace from all surrounding enemies, and that his reign would be characterized by peace and quietness in Israel during his lifetime. The timing of <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H8010' clickHandler>Solomon</jLink>'s birth, just one year after his brother's death, demonstrated God's mercy and the continuation of the Davidic covenant despite the king's moral failure. <jPara></jPara> <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H8010' clickHandler>Solomon</jLink>'s birth carried profound theological and political significance for the future of Israel, as he was divinely chosen not only to succeed <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H1732' clickHandler>David</jLink> as king but also to fulfill the promise of building the temple in <jLink data-type='L' data-strong='H3389' clickHandler>Jerusalem</jLink> that would serve as the permanent dwelling place for the Ark of the Covenant. The narrative emphasizes that <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H8010' clickHandler>Solomon</jLink>'s selection was not based on birth order or human preference but on divine election, establishing the principle that God's covenant promises transcend human failure and continue through successive generations. Archaeological evidence from the late tenth century BC suggests that the unified monarchy reached its zenith during <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H8010' clickHandler>Solomon</jLink>'s future reign, with monumental architecture and administrative complexity that align with biblical descriptions of his building projects and international trade relationships. The birth of this future king also fulfilled the broader promise that <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H1732' clickHandler>David</jLink>'s son would establish an everlasting throne, a theme that would later be interpreted messianically in Jewish and Christian traditions, making <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H8010' clickHandler>Solomon</jLink>'s birth a crucial link in the genealogical and theological chain connecting <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H1732' clickHandler>David</jLink> to the ultimate fulfillment of these royal promises.
events: 988 BC: <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H8010' clickHandler>Solomon</jLink> is born to <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H1732' clickHandler>David</jLink> and <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H1339' clickHandler>Bathsheba</jLink> in <jLink data-type='L' data-strong='H3389' clickHandler>Jerusalem</jLink>, marking God's restored favor and establishing <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H8010' clickHandler>Solomon</jLink> as heir.

988 BC: <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H1732' clickHandler>David</jLink> and <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H1339' clickHandler>Bathsheba</jLink>’s first son dies before <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H8010' clickHandler>Solomon</jLink>’s birth, signifying a transition from judgment to mercy.

988 BC: <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H5416H' clickHandler>Nathan</jLink> delivers God’s promise that <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H8010' clickHandler>Solomon</jLink> will succeed <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H1732' clickHandler>David</jLink> and build the temple in <jLink data-type='L' data-strong='H3389' clickHandler>Jerusalem</jLink>.

ChronologyEntries.desc: <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H0550G' clickHandler>Amnon</jLink> and <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H8559H' clickHandler>Tamar</jLink>
ChronologyEntries.article: 987 BC:  The year 987 BC witnessed the beginning of catastrophic internal strife within <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H1732' clickHandler>David</jLink>'s household when his eldest son <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H0550G' clickHandler>Amnon</jLink>, driven by obsessive desire, raped his half-sister <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H8559H' clickHandler>Tamar</jLink>, daughter of <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H1732' clickHandler>David</jLink> by <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H4601I' clickHandler>Maacah</jLink> and full sister to <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H0053' clickHandler>Absalom</jLink> (2Sa.13:1-22). <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H0550G' clickHandler>Amnon</jLink>'s crime was facilitated by his cunning friend <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H3122G' clickHandler>Jonadab</jLink>, son of <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H8093' clickHandler>Shimeah</jLink> (<jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H1732' clickHandler>David</jLink>'s brother), who devised a deceptive plan whereby <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H0550G' clickHandler>Amnon</jLink> would feign illness and request that <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H8559H' clickHandler>Tamar</jLink> come to prepare food for him in his private chambers. When the unsuspecting <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H8559H' clickHandler>Tamar</jLink> arrived and prepared bread cakes in <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H0550G' clickHandler>Amnon</jLink>'s presence, he dismissed all servants and forcibly assaulted her despite her reasoned pleas that he should properly request her hand in marriage from their father. Following the assault, <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H0550G' clickHandler>Amnon</jLink>'s passion immediately transformed into intense hatred, and he callously expelled <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H8559H' clickHandler>Tamar</jLink> from his house, compounding her trauma and public shame by having his servant lock the door behind her. <jPara></jPara> <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H8559H' clickHandler>Tamar</jLink>'s response to this violation—tearing her distinctive robe of many colors that marked her status as a virgin princess, placing ashes on her head, and crying aloud as she went—demonstrated both her grief and the social devastation this crime represented in ancient Near Eastern culture where a woman's honor was closely tied to family status. When <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H0053' clickHandler>Absalom</jLink> found his sister in distress, he discerned what had happened and took her into his household, advising her to remain quiet "for now" while he presumably planned his response, though the text notes that <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H8559H' clickHandler>Tamar</jLink> remained desolate in <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H0053' clickHandler>Absalom</jLink>'s house. King <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H1732' clickHandler>David</jLink>'s reaction was one of intense anger, but significantly, the biblical record indicates that he took no action to punish <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H0550G' clickHandler>Amnon</jLink>, possibly because of his own recent moral failure with <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H1339' clickHandler>Bathsheba</jLink> or because <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H0550G' clickHandler>Amnon</jLink> was his heir apparent. This failure of paternal and royal justice would have severe consequences, as <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H0053' clickHandler>Absalom</jLink>'s simmering resentment over his sister's dishonor and his father's inaction would eventually culminate in his murder of <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H0550G' clickHandler>Amnon</jLink> and subsequent rebellion against <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H1732' clickHandler>David</jLink>'s throne, demonstrating how unchecked sin within leadership creates cycles of violence and dysfunction that extend far beyond the original transgression.
events: 987 BC: <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H0550G' clickHandler>Amnon</jLink>, <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H1732' clickHandler>David</jLink>'s eldest son, rapes <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H8559H' clickHandler>Tamar</jLink> in <jLink data-type='L' data-strong='H3389' clickHandler>Jerusalem</jLink> with <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H3122G' clickHandler>Jonadab</jLink>’s help.
987 BC: <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H0550G' clickHandler>Amnon</jLink> expels <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H8559H' clickHandler>Tamar</jLink>, who publicly mourns and shames her loss.

987 BC: <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H0053' clickHandler>Absalom</jLink> shelters <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H8559H' clickHandler>Tamar</jLink> in his house and advises her to remain quiet.
987 BC: <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H1732' clickHandler>David</jLink> is angry about <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H0550G' clickHandler>Amnon</jLink>’s crime but takes no action.

987 BC: <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H0053' clickHandler>Absalom</jLink> develops a lasting grudge against <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H0550G' clickHandler>Amnon</jLink> for <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H8559H' clickHandler>Tamar</jLink>’s violation.

ChronologyEntries.desc: <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H0053' clickHandler>Absalom</jLink> kills <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H0550G' clickHandler>Amnon</jLink> and flees
ChronologyEntries.article: 985 BC:  In 985 BC, two years after <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H0550G' clickHandler>Amnon</jLink>'s assault on <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H8559H' clickHandler>Tamar</jLink>, <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H0053' clickHandler>Absalom</jLink> executed a carefully planned act of vengeance by murdering his half-brother during a sheep-shearing feast at <jLink data-type='L' data-strong='H1178' clickHandler>Baal-hazor</jLink> near <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H0669G' clickHandler>Ephraim</jLink> (2Sa.13:23-36). <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H0053' clickHandler>Absalom</jLink> invited all of <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H1732' clickHandler>David</jLink>'s sons to the celebration and specifically instructed his servants to strike down <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H0550G' clickHandler>Amnon</jLink> when he became intoxicated with wine, declaring "when <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H0550G' clickHandler>Amnon</jLink>'s heart is merry with wine, and when I say to you, 'Strike <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H0550G' clickHandler>Amnon</jLink>,' then kill him". The murder created immediate panic among the royal family, as all the king's sons except <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H0550G' clickHandler>Amnon</jLink> fled on their mules, while a false report initially reached <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H1732' clickHandler>David</jLink> claiming that <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H0053' clickHandler>Absalom</jLink> had killed all his brothers, causing the king to tear his clothes and lie on the ground in anguish until <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H3122G' clickHandler>Jonadab</jLink>, son of <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H8093' clickHandler>Shimeah</jLink>, clarified that only <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H0550G' clickHandler>Amnon</jLink> had died. <jPara></jPara> Following the assassination, <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H0053' clickHandler>Absalom</jLink> fled to <jLink data-type='L' data-strong='H1650' clickHandler>Geshur</jLink> in Aram-Damascus, seeking refuge with his maternal grandfather <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H8526H' clickHandler>Talmai</jLink>, son of <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H5989J' clickHandler>Ammihud</jLink>, king of <jLink data-type='L' data-strong='H1650' clickHandler>Geshur</jLink>, where he would remain in exile for three years. This act of fraternal murder represented both personal justice for his sister's dishonor and a strategic elimination of <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H1732' clickHandler>David</jLink>'s eldest son and heir apparent, though it also marked the beginning of the fulfillment of <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H5416H' clickHandler>Nathan</jLink>'s prophecy that violence would plague <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H1732' clickHandler>David</jLink>'s household as consequences for his sin with <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H1339' clickHandler>Bathsheba</jLink> and murder of <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H0223A' clickHandler>Uriah</jLink>. The sheep-shearing festival setting was culturally significant in ancient Near Eastern societies as occasions for hospitality and celebration, making <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H0053' clickHandler>Absalom</jLink>'s use of this traditional gathering for murder particularly shocking and demonstrating his calculated manipulation of social customs to achieve his vengeful purposes.
events: 985 BC: <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H0053' clickHandler>Absalom</jLink> murders <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H0550G' clickHandler>Amnon</jLink> at <jLink data-type='L' data-strong='H1178' clickHandler>Baal-hazor</jLink> during a feast.
985 BC: All of <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H1732' clickHandler>David</jLink>’s sons flee the feast in panic.

985 BC: A false report reaches <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H1732' clickHandler>David</jLink> in <jLink data-type='L' data-strong='H3389' clickHandler>Jerusalem</jLink> claiming all his sons are dead.
985 BC: <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H3122G' clickHandler>Jonadab</jLink> clarifies that only <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H0550G' clickHandler>Amnon</jLink> is dead.

985 BC: <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H0053' clickHandler>Absalom</jLink> flees to <jLink data-type='L' data-strong='H1650' clickHandler>Geshur</jLink> to seek refuge with <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H8526H' clickHandler>Talmai</jLink>, king of <jLink data-type='L' data-strong='H1650' clickHandler>Geshur</jLink>.

ChronologyEntries.desc: <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H0053' clickHandler>Absalom</jLink> returns to <jLink data-type='L' data-strong='H3389' clickHandler>Jerusalem</jLink>
ChronologyEntries.article: 982 BC:  After three years of exile in <jLink data-type='L' data-strong='H1650' clickHandler>Geshur</jLink>, <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H0053' clickHandler>Absalom</jLink> was permitted to return to <jLink data-type='L' data-strong='H3389' clickHandler>Jerusalem</jLink> in 982 BC through the diplomatic intervention of <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H3097G' clickHandler>Joab</jLink>, <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H1732' clickHandler>David</jLink>'s military commander, who orchestrated an elaborate scheme involving a wise woman from <jLink data-type='L' data-strong='H8620' clickHandler>Tekoa</jLink> to soften the king's heart (2Sa.14:1-27). Recognizing that "the king's heart longed for <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H0053' clickHandler>Absalom</jLink>," <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H3097G' clickHandler>Joab</jLink> arranged for the woman to present <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H1732' clickHandler>David</jLink> with a parable about her own family situation—claiming she was a widow whose surviving son faced death for killing his brother—to illustrate the importance of preserving remaining family members despite past wrongs. This indirect approach successfully convinced <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H1732' clickHandler>David</jLink> to recall his son, though the king's ambivalence about the situation led him to impose significant conditions upon <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H0053' clickHandler>Absalom</jLink>'s return, declaring "Let him return to his own house, but do not let him see my face". <jPara></jPara> <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H0053' clickHandler>Absalom</jLink>'s homecoming was marked by deliberate restrictions that prevented full reconciliation with his father while allowing him to reestablish his presence in <jLink data-type='L' data-strong='H3389' clickHandler>Jerusalem</jLink>'s political environment, creating a tension-filled situation where he remained physically present but officially estranged from the royal court. The text emphasizes <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H0053' clickHandler>Absalom</jLink>'s remarkable physical appearance upon his return, noting his exceptional beauty and his famous hair, which was cut annually and weighed two hundred shekels by the king's standard, making him "the most handsome man in all Israel". During this period, <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H0053' clickHandler>Absalom</jLink> had three sons and one daughter named <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H8559I' clickHandler>Tamar</jLink> (after his sister), suggesting that his exile had not prevented him from establishing his own household and continuing his family line, which would prove important for his future political ambitions and his desire to position himself as a legitimate heir to <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H1732' clickHandler>David</jLink>'s throne.
events: 982 BC: <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H3097G' clickHandler>Joab</jLink> arranges <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H0053' clickHandler>Absalom</jLink>’s return from <jLink data-type='L' data-strong='H1650' clickHandler>Geshur</jLink> by sending a wise woman from <jLink data-type='L' data-strong='H8620' clickHandler>Tekoa</jLink> to persuade <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H1732' clickHandler>David</jLink>.

982 BC: <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H0053' clickHandler>Absalom</jLink> returns to <jLink data-type='L' data-strong='H3389' clickHandler>Jerusalem</jLink> after three years in <jLink data-type='L' data-strong='H1650' clickHandler>Geshur</jLink>.

982 BC: <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H1732' clickHandler>David</jLink> allows <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H0053' clickHandler>Absalom</jLink> to return to his house but forbids him to see the king’s face.

982 BC: <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H0053' clickHandler>Absalom</jLink> lives in <jLink data-type='L' data-strong='H3389' clickHandler>Jerusalem</jLink>, noted for his appearance and his children, including daughter <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H8559I' clickHandler>Tamar</jLink>.

ChronologyEntries.desc: <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H0053' clickHandler>Absalom</jLink> reconciled with <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H1732' clickHandler>David</jLink>
ChronologyEntries.article: 980 BC:  In 980 BC, after spending two full years in <jLink data-type='L' data-strong='H3389' clickHandler>Jerusalem</jLink> without being permitted to see his father, <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H0053' clickHandler>Absalom</jLink> finally achieved reconciliation with King <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H1732' clickHandler>David</jLink> through persistent efforts that culminated in a face-to-face meeting orchestrated by <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H3097G' clickHandler>Joab</jLink> (2Sa.14:28-33). Growing frustrated with his continued estrangement despite being physically present in the capital, <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H0053' clickHandler>Absalom</jLink> twice summoned <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H3097G' clickHandler>Joab</jLink> to arrange an audience with <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H1732' clickHandler>David</jLink>, but when the military commander ignored these requests, <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H0053' clickHandler>Absalom</jLink> deliberately set fire to <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H3097G' clickHandler>Joab</jLink>'s barley field adjacent to his own property to force a confrontation. This provocative action successfully gained <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H3097G' clickHandler>Joab</jLink>'s attention, leading to a direct conversation where <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H0053' clickHandler>Absalom</jLink> demanded either to see the king's face or be sent back to <jLink data-type='L' data-strong='H1650' clickHandler>Geshur</jLink>, declaring "if there is iniquity in me, let him execute me". <jPara></jPara> The reconciliation meeting that followed represented a significant moment in the restoration of <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H1732' clickHandler>David</jLink>'s fractured family, as the king finally agreed to see his son after five years of separation—three years of exile in <jLink data-type='L' data-strong='H1650' clickHandler>Geshur</jLink> and two years of restricted residence in <jLink data-type='L' data-strong='H3389' clickHandler>Jerusalem</jLink>. When <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H0053' clickHandler>Absalom</jLink> came before <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H1732' clickHandler>David</jLink>, he bowed with his face to the ground in a gesture of submission and respect, and the king responded by kissing his son, symbolically restoring him to full family status and presumably to his position within the royal household. This reconciliation, while personally meaningful for both father and son, proved to be politically shortsighted on <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H1732' clickHandler>David</jLink>'s part, as it provided <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H0053' clickHandler>Absalom</jLink> with the legitimacy and access he would need to launch his rebellion just one year later. The five-year gap between <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H0550G' clickHandler>Amnon</jLink>'s murder and <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H0053' clickHandler>Absalom</jLink>'s restoration to favor had allowed underlying tensions and ambitions to develop, making this reconciliation the precursor to the most serious political crisis of <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H1732' clickHandler>David</jLink>'s reign.
events: 980 BC: <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H0053' clickHandler>Absalom</jLink> seeks <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H3097G' clickHandler>Joab</jLink>’s help to meet <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H1732' clickHandler>David</jLink> after two years in <jLink data-type='L' data-strong='H3389' clickHandler>Jerusalem</jLink>, but <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H3097G' clickHandler>Joab</jLink> ignores him.
980 BC: <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H0053' clickHandler>Absalom</jLink> sets fire to <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H3097G' clickHandler>Joab</jLink>’s barley field to get his attention.

980 BC: <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H3097G' clickHandler>Joab</jLink> arranges a meeting between <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H0053' clickHandler>Absalom</jLink> and <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H1732' clickHandler>David</jLink> at <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H0053' clickHandler>Absalom</jLink>’s insistence.

980 BC: <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H0053' clickHandler>Absalom</jLink> and <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H1732' clickHandler>David</jLink> reconcile as <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H1732' clickHandler>David</jLink> kisses <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H0053' clickHandler>Absalom</jLink>, restoring him to royal favor.

ChronologyEntries.article: 979 BC:  The year 979 BC marked the commencement of <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H0053' clickHandler>Absalom</jLink>'s systematic rebellion against his father <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H1732' clickHandler>David</jLink>, beginning with a calculated campaign to undermine the king's authority and win popular support throughout Israel, as detailed in 2 <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H8050G' clickHandler>Samuel</jLink> 15. <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H0053' clickHandler>Absalom</jLink>'s strategy involved positioning himself at the city gate early each morning with chariots, horses, and fifty men running before him—symbols of royal authority—where he would intercept individuals coming to <jLink data-type='L' data-strong='H3389' clickHandler>Jerusalem</jLink> seeking justice from the king. To each petitioner, <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H0053' clickHandler>Absalom</jLink> would express sympathy for their legal concerns while subtly criticizing the current administration, declaring "See, your matters are good and right; but there is no deputy of the king to hear you" and suggesting "Oh, that I were made judge in the land, and everyone who has any suit or cause would come to me; then I would give him justice". <jPara></jPara> This four-year campaign of political subversion culminated when <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H0053' clickHandler>Absalom</jLink> requested permission to travel to <jLink data-type='L' data-strong='H2275A' clickHandler>Hebron</jLink> ostensibly to fulfill a vow he had made to the Lord during his exile in <jLink data-type='L' data-strong='H1650' clickHandler>Geshur</jLink>, but actually to launch his coup attempt by declaring himself king in <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H1732' clickHandler>David</jLink>'s original capital. From <jLink data-type='L' data-strong='H2275A' clickHandler>Hebron</jLink>, <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H0053' clickHandler>Absalom</jLink> sent secret messengers throughout all the tribes of Israel announcing that when they heard the sound of the trumpet, they should proclaim "<jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H0053' clickHandler>Absalom</jLink> reigns in <jLink data-type='L' data-strong='H2275A' clickHandler>Hebron</jLink>," while simultaneously inviting two hundred men from <jLink data-type='L' data-strong='H3389' clickHandler>Jerusalem</jLink> to accompany him, though they went innocently without knowledge of his treacherous intentions. The rebellion gained significant momentum when <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H0302' clickHandler>Ahithophel</jLink> the <jLink data-type='L' data-strong='H1542' clickHandler>Gilonite</jLink>, <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H1732' clickHandler>David</jLink>'s trusted counselor and advisor, joined <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H0053' clickHandler>Absalom</jLink>'s conspiracy, providing the revolt with both political legitimacy and strategic expertise that transformed what might have been a mere family dispute into a serious threat to the Davidic dynasty. Archaeological evidence from this period suggests that <jLink data-type='L' data-strong='H2275A' clickHandler>Hebron</jLink> remained an important political center with symbolic significance as the place where <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H1732' clickHandler>David</jLink> had first been crowned king over Judah, making <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H0053' clickHandler>Absalom</jLink>'s choice of this location for his coronation a deliberate attempt to claim legitimacy through association with his father's own rise to power.
events: 979 BC: <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H0053' clickHandler>Absalom</jLink> campaigns for popular support at <jLink data-type='L' data-strong='H3389' clickHandler>Jerusalem</jLink>’s city gate, criticizing <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H1732' clickHandler>David</jLink>’s administration.

979 BC: <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H0053' clickHandler>Absalom</jLink> requests to visit <jLink data-type='L' data-strong='H2275A' clickHandler>Hebron</jLink> under false pretenses, claiming a vow.

979 BC: <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H0053' clickHandler>Absalom</jLink> launches his rebellion in <jLink data-type='L' data-strong='H2275A' clickHandler>Hebron</jLink>, sending secret messengers to declare him king.

979 BC: Two hundred men from <jLink data-type='L' data-strong='H3389' clickHandler>Jerusalem</jLink> accompany <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H0053' clickHandler>Absalom</jLink> to <jLink data-type='L' data-strong='H2275A' clickHandler>Hebron</jLink>, unaware of his plot.

979 BC: <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H0302' clickHandler>Ahithophel</jLink> the <jLink data-type='L' data-strong='H1542' clickHandler>Gilonite</jLink> joins <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H0053' clickHandler>Absalom</jLink>’s conspiracy, lending political credibility.

ChronologyEntries.article: 978 BC:  The year 978 BC witnessed the tragic climax and conclusion of <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H0053' clickHandler>Absalom</jLink>'s rebellion against his father King <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H1732' clickHandler>David</jLink> through a decisive battle fought in the forest of <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H0669G' clickHandler>Ephraim</jLink>, east of the <jLink data-type='L' data-strong='H3383' clickHandler>Jordan</jLink> River, as recorded in 2Sa.16-19. <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H1732' clickHandler>David</jLink>'s forces, commanded by the experienced generals <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H3097G' clickHandler>Joab</jLink>, <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H0052' clickHandler>Abishai</jLink>, and <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H0863G' clickHandler>Ittai</jLink> the <jLink data-type='L' data-strong='H1661' clickHandler>Gittite</jLink>, achieved a crushing victory over <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H0053' clickHandler>Absalom</jLink>'s army, with the difficult forest terrain contributing significantly to the defeat by claiming more lives than actual combat. During the retreat, <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H0053' clickHandler>Absalom</jLink> himself met his end when his head became entangled in the branches of a large oak tree as he rode his mule, leaving him suspended and defenseless. Despite <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H1732' clickHandler>David</jLink>'s explicit command to "deal gently with the young man <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H0053' clickHandler>Absalom</jLink>," <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H3097G' clickHandler>Joab</jLink> deliberately disobeyed the king's orders and killed the helpless prince by thrusting three javelins into his heart, with his armor-bearers completing the execution. <jPara></jPara> The aftermath of <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H0053' clickHandler>Absalom</jLink>'s death created a significant political crisis for <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H1732' clickHandler>David</jLink>, as the king's excessive mourning for his rebellious son demoralized his victorious troops and supporters who had risked their lives to preserve his throne. <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H3097G' clickHandler>Joab</jLink> confronted <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H1732' clickHandler>David</jLink> directly, warning that his public grief could alienate his loyal followers and potentially destabilize his rule, urging the king to publicly acknowledge and thank his forces. This <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H1732' clickHandler>David</jLink> eventually did, though the kingdom remained deeply divided, with tensions between the northern tribes of Israel and Judah becoming more pronounced during the process of <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H1732' clickHandler>David</jLink>'s restoration to <jLink data-type='L' data-strong='H3389' clickHandler>Jerusalem</jLink>, setting the stage for further unrest that would soon manifest in <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H7652A' clickHandler>Sheba</jLink>'s rebellion. The death of <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H0053' clickHandler>Absalom</jLink>, while ending the immediate threat to <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H1732' clickHandler>David</jLink>'s throne, thus marked the beginning of a period of continued political instability that would challenge the unity of the kingdom throughout the remaining years of <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H1732' clickHandler>David</jLink>'s reign.
events: 978 BC: <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H1732' clickHandler>David</jLink>’s forces led by <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H3097G' clickHandler>Joab</jLink> defeat <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H0053' clickHandler>Absalom</jLink>’s army in the forest of <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H0669G' clickHandler>Ephraim</jLink>.

978 BC: <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H0053' clickHandler>Absalom</jLink> is killed by <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H3097G' clickHandler>Joab</jLink> after being caught in an oak tree, ending his rebellion.
978 BC: With <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H0053' clickHandler>Absalom</jLink>’s death, <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H1732' clickHandler>David</jLink>’s kingship is preserved.
978 BC: <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H1732' clickHandler>David</jLink> mourns excessively for <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H0053' clickHandler>Absalom</jLink>, distressing his troops.
978 BC: <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H3097G' clickHandler>Joab</jLink> rebukes <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H1732' clickHandler>David</jLink> and urges him to support his followers.

ChronologyEntries.desc: <jLink data-type='L' data-strong='H7614J' clickHandler>Sheba</jLink> rebels against <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H1732' clickHandler>David</jLink>
ChronologyEntries.article: 977 BC:  Soon after <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H0053' clickHandler>Absalom</jLink>'s death, the underlying tribal tensions that had been exposed during the previous rebellion erupted again when <jLink data-type='L' data-strong='H7614J' clickHandler>Sheba</jLink>, a <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H1144G' clickHandler>Benjamite</jLink>, launched a separatist revolt against King <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H1732' clickHandler>David</jLink> by appealing directly to northern tribal grievances, as detailed in 2 <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H8050G' clickHandler>Samuel</jLink> 20. <jLink data-type='L' data-strong='H7614J' clickHandler>Sheba</jLink>'s rallying cry—"We have no share in <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H1732' clickHandler>David</jLink>, no part in <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H3448' clickHandler>Jesse</jLink>'s son! Every man to his tent, Israel!"—effectively capitalized on the northern tribes' sense of alienation and their perception that <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H1732' clickHandler>David</jLink> showed favoritism to his own tribe of Judah during his restoration to power. This inflammatory declaration quickly gained traction among the northern tribes, who withdrew their allegiance from <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H1732' clickHandler>David</jLink> while Judah remained loyal, demonstrating how fragile national unity had become in the aftermath of <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H0053' clickHandler>Absalom</jLink>'s rebellion. <jPara></jPara> <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H1732' clickHandler>David</jLink>'s response was swift and decisive, dispatching his military forces under <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H3097G' clickHandler>Joab</jLink>'s command to pursue the rebel leader before the insurrection could gain further momentum throughout the northern territories. The pursuit culminated at the fortified city of <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H1893' clickHandler>Abel</jLink> Beth <jLink data-type='L' data-strong='H0062' clickHandler>Maacah</jLink> in the far north, where <jLink data-type='L' data-strong='H7614J' clickHandler>Sheba</jLink> had sought refuge, and where <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H3097G' clickHandler>Joab</jLink> laid siege to the settlement. The crisis was resolved through the intervention of a "wise woman" from the city, who negotiated with <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H3097G' clickHandler>Joab</jLink> and persuaded the inhabitants to execute <jLink data-type='L' data-strong='H7614J' clickHandler>Sheba</jLink> themselves rather than face destruction, after which they threw his severed head over the wall to <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H3097G' clickHandler>Joab</jLink>, effectively ending the rebellion. Though <jLink data-type='L' data-strong='H7614J' clickHandler>Sheba</jLink>'s revolt was quickly crushed, it served as a clear indication of the persistent rivalry between Judah and the other tribes that would continue to threaten the stability of the united kingdom throughout the remainder of <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H1732' clickHandler>David</jLink>'s reign and would eventually contribute to the kingdom's permanent division after <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H8010' clickHandler>Solomon</jLink>'s death.
events: 977 BC: <jLink data-type='L' data-strong='H7614J' clickHandler>Sheba</jLink>, a <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H1144G' clickHandler>Benjamite</jLink>, incites the northern tribes to revolt, while Judah remains loyal to <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H1732' clickHandler>David</jLink>.

977 BC: <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H3097G' clickHandler>Joab</jLink> pursues <jLink data-type='L' data-strong='H7614J' clickHandler>Sheba</jLink> with <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H1732' clickHandler>David</jLink>’s forces after <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H6021G' clickHandler>Amasa</jLink> is slow to assemble the men.

977 BC: <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H3097G' clickHandler>Joab</jLink> kills <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H6021G' clickHandler>Amasa</jLink> near <jLink data-type='L' data-strong='H1391' clickHandler>Gibeon</jLink> and takes command.

977 BC: <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H3097G' clickHandler>Joab</jLink> besieges <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H1893' clickHandler>Abel</jLink> Beth <jLink data-type='L' data-strong='H0062' clickHandler>Maacah</jLink> where <jLink data-type='L' data-strong='H7614J' clickHandler>Sheba</jLink> takes refuge.
977 BC: A wise woman negotiates with <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H3097G' clickHandler>Joab</jLink> to end the siege.

ChronologyEntries.desc: Famine due to <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H1391' clickHandler>Gibeonites</jLink>
ChronologyEntries.article: 976 BC:  The year 976 BC marked the beginning of a severe three-year famine that afflicted the land of Israel, prompting King <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H1732' clickHandler>David</jLink> to seek divine guidance regarding its cause (2Sa.21:1-2). When <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H1732' clickHandler>David</jLink> inquired of the Lord, he received the sobering revelation that the prolonged agricultural crisis was divine judgment for King <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H7586G' clickHandler>Saul</jLink>'s violation of an ancient covenant with the <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H1391' clickHandler>Gibeonites</jLink>, whom <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H7586G' clickHandler>Saul</jLink> had attempted to annihilate in his "zeal for the children of Israel and Judah". This covenant dated back to the early period of Israel's conquest of <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H3667G' clickHandler>Canaan</jLink>, when the <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H1391' clickHandler>Gibeonites</jLink> had deceived <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H3091G' clickHandler>Joshua</jLink> and the tribal leaders by pretending to be distant travelers, resulting in a solemn oath sworn before the Lord that protected them from destruction despite their deceptive tactics. <jPara></jPara> The persistence of the famine for three consecutive years demonstrated the seriousness with which God regarded covenant violations, particularly those involving sworn oaths made in His name, even when the original agreement had been obtained through deception. <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H7586G' clickHandler>Saul</jLink>'s later attempt to eliminate the <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H1391' clickHandler>Gibeonites</jLink> represented not merely a policy decision but a fundamental breach of Israel's sacred obligations, illustrating how the sins of previous leaders could bring divine consequences upon subsequent generations. This episode reinforced important theological principles about covenant faithfulness and divine justice while simultaneously creating the conditions that would require <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H1732' clickHandler>David</jLink> to seek reconciliation with the surviving <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H1391' clickHandler>Gibeonites</jLink>, setting the stage for the dramatic events of 973 BC when blood atonement would be demanded to lift the curse from the land.
events: 976 BC: A three-year famine begins in Israel.
976 BC: <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H1732' clickHandler>David</jLink> seeks the Lord about the famine’s cause.

976 BC: God reveals the famine is due to <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H7586G' clickHandler>Saul</jLink>’s attempt to annihilate the <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H1391' clickHandler>Gibeonites</jLink>, violating a covenant.

ChronologyEntries.desc: <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H1391' clickHandler>Gibeonite</jLink> revenge. Fight <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H6430H' clickHandler>Philistines</jLink>.
ChronologyEntries.article: 973 BC:  In 973 BC, King <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H1732' clickHandler>David</jLink> resolved the three-year famine by making atonement to the <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H1391' clickHandler>Gibeonites</jLink>, who demanded retributive justice for <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H7586G' clickHandler>Saul</jLink>'s attempted genocide through the execution of seven male descendants from <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H7586G' clickHandler>Saul</jLink>'s household, a request that <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H1732' clickHandler>David</jLink> fulfilled by delivering them to the <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H1391' clickHandler>Gibeonites</jLink> for public execution (2Sa.21:3-22). The men executed included two sons of <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H7586G' clickHandler>Saul</jLink> by his concubine <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H7532' clickHandler>Rizpah</jLink>—<jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H0764' clickHandler>Armoni</jLink> and <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H4648G' clickHandler>Mephibosheth</jLink>—and five grandsons through his daughter <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H4764' clickHandler>Merab</jLink>, who had been married to <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H5741' clickHandler>Adriel</jLink> the <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H4259' clickHandler>Meholathite</jLink>. Following this act of blood atonement, which the <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H1391' clickHandler>Gibeonites</jLink> performed by impaling the seven men on a hill before the Lord during the beginning of barley harvest, the divine curse was lifted from the land, and the famine ended. The execution created a poignant scene when <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H7532' clickHandler>Rizpah</jLink>, mother of two of the victims, maintained a vigil over the corpses from harvest time until the autumn rains, protecting them from scavenging birds and wild animals until <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H1732' clickHandler>David</jLink> was moved to provide proper burial for all the remains alongside <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H7586G' clickHandler>Saul</jLink> and <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H3083H' clickHandler>Jonathan</jLink> in the tomb of <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H7027G' clickHandler>Kish</jLink> in <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H1144G' clickHandler>Benjamin</jLink>. The same year witnessed a series of military encounters with the <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H6430H' clickHandler>Philistines</jLink> that resulted in the defeat of several descendents of the giant <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H7497A' clickHandler>Rapha</jLink>. <jPara></jPara> King <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H1732' clickHandler>David</jLink> composed his final psalm and engaged in profound reflection upon his life and reign (2Sa.22-23). The psalm, which appears in duplicate as Psalm 18, serves as <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H1732' clickHandler>David</jLink>'s spiritual testament and theological reflection on God's faithfulness throughout his tumultuous career. Structured as a thanksgiving hymn, the composition recounts God's deliverance from enemies and expresses deep gratitude for divine intervention, featuring vivid imagery of God as rock, fortress, and deliverer. The psalm emphasizes themes of divine justice, covenant relationship, and God's sovereignty, concluding with a vision of universal praise among the nations that scholars interpret as foreshadowing messianic hope associated with the Davidic line.
events: 973 BC: <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H1732' clickHandler>David</jLink> asks the <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H1391' clickHandler>Gibeonites</jLink> how to atone for <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H7586G' clickHandler>Saul</jLink>’s covenant violation.

973 BC: Seven male descendants of <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H7586G' clickHandler>Saul</jLink>—<jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H0764' clickHandler>Armoni</jLink>, <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H4648G' clickHandler>Mephibosheth</jLink>, and five grandsons—are executed at <jLink data-type='L' data-strong='H1390H' clickHandler>Gibeah</jLink> during the barley harvest.
973 BC: <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H7532' clickHandler>Rizpah</jLink> mourns and guards her sons’ corpses from harvest until autumn rains.

973 BC: <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H1732' clickHandler>David</jLink> buries <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H7586G' clickHandler>Saul</jLink>, <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H3083H' clickHandler>Jonathan</jLink>, and the executed men in <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H7027G' clickHandler>Kish</jLink>’s tomb in <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H1144G' clickHandler>Benjamin</jLink>.
973 BC: The famine ends after the atonement and burials.

ChronologyEntries.article: 972 BC:  The year 972 BC witnessed one of the most controversial decisions of <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H1732' clickHandler>David</jLink>'s reign when he ordered a comprehensive census of Israel and Judah, an action that provoked divine displeasure and resulted in severe judgment upon the nation (2Sa.24:1-17; 1Ch.21:1-17). The biblical accounts present different perspectives on the motivation for this census: 2 <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H8050G' clickHandler>Samuel</jLink> attributes it to God's anger against Israel, while 1 Chronicles identifies <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H7854' clickHandler>Satan</jLink> as the instigator who incited <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H1732' clickHandler>David</jLink> to number the people. The census was conducted by <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H3097G' clickHandler>Joab</jLink>, <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H1732' clickHandler>David</jLink>'s military commander, who initially opposed the project and required nine months and twenty days to complete the enumeration, which revealed 800,000 fighting men in Israel and 500,000 in Judah according to 2 <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H8050G' clickHandler>Samuel</jLink>, though 1 Chronicles provides different figures. <jPara></jPara> Unlike typical administrative censuses common throughout the ancient Near East, this <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H3478' clickHandler>Israelite</jLink> census carried profound religious implications due to covenant requirements that any enumeration of God's people be accompanied by appropriate atonement measures. <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H1732' clickHandler>David</jLink>'s failure to observe these ritual requirements (Exo.30:11-16) constituted a fundamental breach of religious law that demonstrated overreliance on human military strength rather than trust in divine providence.
