The prophet <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H1410G' clickHandler>Gad</jLink> subsequently confronted <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H1732' clickHandler>David</jLink> with three options for divine punishment: seven years of famine, three months of military defeat, or three days of plague. <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H1732' clickHandler>David</jLink> chose the plague, trusting in God's mercy rather than human adversaries, but the resulting epidemic killed 70,000 <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H3478' clickHandler>Israelites</jLink> before divine intervention stopped the destroying angel at the threshing floor of <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H0771' clickHandler>Araunah</jLink> the <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H2983G' clickHandler>Jebusite</jLink> in <jLink data-type='L' data-strong='H3389' clickHandler>Jerusalem</jLink>.
events: 972 BC: <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H1732' clickHandler>David</jLink> orders <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H3097G' clickHandler>Joab</jLink> to conduct a census of Israel and Judah despite <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H3097G' clickHandler>Joab</jLink>’s objections.
972 BC: <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H3097G' clickHandler>Joab</jLink> completes the census, counting 800,000 in Israel and 500,000 in Judah.
972 BC: <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H1410G' clickHandler>Gad</jLink> offers <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H1732' clickHandler>David</jLink> three punishments: famine, defeat, or plague.
972 BC: <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H1732' clickHandler>David</jLink> chooses three days of plague as punishment.
972 BC: A plague kills 70,000 men across Israel.

ChronologyEntries.desc: Temple preparations. <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H7346' clickHandler>Rehoboam</jLink> born
ChronologyEntries.article: 971 BC:  Extensive preparations for the construction of the <jLink data-type='L' data-strong='H3389' clickHandler>Jerusalem</jLink> Temple were initiated when the prophet <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H1410G' clickHandler>Gad</jLink> instructed <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H1732' clickHandler>David</jLink> to build an altar on the threshing floor of <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H0771' clickHandler>Araunah</jLink> (<jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H0771' clickHandler>Ornan</jLink>) the <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H2983G' clickHandler>Jebusite</jLink> (2Sa.24:18-25; 1Ch.21:18-29:20). <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H1732' clickHandler>David</jLink> purchased this site upon which <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H8010' clickHandler>Solomon</jLink> would later construct the Temple. <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H1732' clickHandler>David</jLink> organized the <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H3878' clickHandler>Levites</jLink> and priests into their service divisions, appointed musicians and gatekeepers, and provided <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H8010' clickHandler>Solomon</jLink> with detailed architectural plans and instructions for the Temple's construction and ongoing worship services. The king encouraged Israel's leaders and citizens to contribute voluntarily to the project. <jPara></jPara> <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H7346' clickHandler>Rehoboam</jLink> was born to King <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H8010' clickHandler>Solomon</jLink>, as indicated by chronological calculations (1Ki.14:21). As <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H8010' clickHandler>Solomon</jLink>'s son by an <jLink data-type='L' data-strong='H5983' clickHandler>Ammonite</jLink> princess named <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H5279A' clickHandler>Naamah</jLink>, <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H7346' clickHandler>Rehoboam</jLink> represented the continuation of the Davidic dynasty, though his foreign maternal lineage would later contribute to religious and political tensions within the kingdom. His future refusal to moderate the heavy taxation and forced labor policies imposed by <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H8010' clickHandler>Solomon</jLink> would prompt the northern tribes to revolt under <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H3379G' clickHandler>Jeroboam</jLink>'s leadership, creating the kingdoms of Israel and Judah that would dominate the subsequent history of the Hebrew people.
events: 971 BC: <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H1732' clickHandler>David</jLink> buys <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H0771' clickHandler>Araunah</jLink>’s threshing floor in <jLink data-type='L' data-strong='H3389' clickHandler>Jerusalem</jLink>, builds an altar, and offers sacrifices.

971 BC: The site for the future <jLink data-type='L' data-strong='H3389' clickHandler>Jerusalem</jLink> Temple is established on <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H0771' clickHandler>Araunah</jLink>’s threshing floor.

971 BC: <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H1732' clickHandler>David</jLink> organizes <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H3878' clickHandler>Levites</jLink>, priests, musicians, and gatekeepers for Temple service.

971 BC: <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H1732' clickHandler>David</jLink> gives <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H8010' clickHandler>Solomon</jLink> plans and materials and worship materials for the Temple.
971 BC: <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H1732' clickHandler>David</jLink> encourages Israel’s leaders and people to contribute to Temple construction.

ChronologyEntries.desc: <jChronDurationLink style='color:black'>▼</jChronDurationLink><jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H8010' clickHandler>Solomon</jLink> King; <jChronDurationLink style='color:green'>▼</jChronDurationLink><jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H6659G' clickHandler>Zadok</jLink> HP. <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H1732' clickHandler>David</jLink> dies.
ChronologyEntries.article: 970 BC:  The year 970 BC marked the end of King <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H1732' clickHandler>David</jLink>'s forty-year reign over Israel when he died in <jLink data-type='L' data-strong='H3389' clickHandler>Jerusalem</jLink>, likely around seventy years of age, after ruling seven and a half years over Judah alone from <jLink data-type='L' data-strong='H2275A' clickHandler>Hebron</jLink> and thirty-three years over the unified kingdom from <jLink data-type='L' data-strong='H3389' clickHandler>Jerusalem</jLink>. <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H1732' clickHandler>David</jLink>'s final days were marked by palace intrigue, as his son <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H0138G' clickHandler>Adonijah</jLink> attempted to claim the throne with support from <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H3097G' clickHandler>Joab</jLink> the military commander and <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H0054' clickHandler>Abiathar</jLink> the priest, following the pattern of royal succession disputes common in ancient Near Eastern monarchies. However, <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H1732' clickHandler>David</jLink>'s chosen successor <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H8010' clickHandler>Solomon</jLink> was quickly proclaimed king through the intervention of <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H1339' clickHandler>Bathsheba</jLink>, <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H5416H' clickHandler>Nathan</jLink> the prophet, and <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H6659G' clickHandler>Zadok</jLink> the priest, who organized a counter-coronation at the <jLink data-type='L' data-strong='H1521' clickHandler>Gihon</jLink> spring that effectively ended <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H0138G' clickHandler>Adonijah</jLink>'s bid for power. <jPara></jPara> <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H6659G' clickHandler>Zadok</jLink> the priest played the crucial role in legitimizing <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H8010' clickHandler>Solomon</jLink>'s accession by anointing him with oil from the sacred tent, an act that demonstrated divine approval and priestly sanction for the new king. <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H1732' clickHandler>David</jLink>'s deathbed instructions to <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H8010' clickHandler>Solomon</jLink>, recorded in 1 Kings 2, emphasized the importance of faithfulness to the Mosaic Law while providing practical counsel about dealing with various political figures from his reign, including <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H3097G' clickHandler>Joab</jLink> and <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H8096I' clickHandler>Shimei</jLink>, who posed potential threats to the new monarchy. The transition represented not merely a change of rulers but the establishment of the <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H8010' clickHandler>Solomonic</jLink> dynasty that would continue the Davidic covenant promises, with <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H1732' clickHandler>David</jLink>'s final preparations for the Temple construction passing to his son along with detailed architectural plans and accumulated resources that would enable the great building project to commence.
events: 970 BC: <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H1732' clickHandler>David</jLink> dies in <jLink data-type='L' data-strong='H3389' clickHandler>Jerusalem</jLink> at about seventy, ending his forty-year reign.
970 BC: <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H1732' clickHandler>David</jLink>’s reign of seven and a half years over Judah and thirty-three over all Israel ends.

970 BC: <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H0138G' clickHandler>Adonijah</jLink>, with <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H3097G' clickHandler>Joab</jLink> and <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H0054' clickHandler>Abiathar</jLink>’s support, attempts to seize the throne.

970 BC: <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H8010' clickHandler>Solomon</jLink> is proclaimed and anointed king at <jLink data-type='L' data-strong='H1521' clickHandler>Gihon</jLink> by <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H6659G' clickHandler>Zadok</jLink>, <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H5416H' clickHandler>Nathan</jLink>, and <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H1339' clickHandler>Bathsheba</jLink>.
970 BC: <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H8010' clickHandler>Solomon</jLink>’s coronation ends <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H0138G' clickHandler>Adonijah</jLink>’s bid for the throne.

ChronologyEntries.desc: <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H8010' clickHandler>Solomon</jLink> establishes his kingdom
ChronologyEntries.article: 968 BC:  In 968 BC, King <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H8010' clickHandler>Solomon</jLink> undertook systematic efforts to establish firm control over his kingdom and eliminate potential threats to his reign, as detailed in 1 Kings 2-7 and 2 Chronicles 1-2. The young king's first priority involved addressing the political challenges inherited from his father's reign by dealing decisively with <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H0138G' clickHandler>Adonijah</jLink>, who had attempted to marry <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H0049' clickHandler>Abishag</jLink> the <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H8126' clickHandler>Shunammite</jLink> (<jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H1732' clickHandler>David</jLink>'s former concubine), an action <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H8010' clickHandler>Solomon</jLink> interpreted as a renewed claim to the throne that resulted in <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H0138G' clickHandler>Adonijah</jLink>'s execution. <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H8010' clickHandler>Solomon</jLink> also removed <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H0054' clickHandler>Abiathar</jLink> from the priesthood and exiled him to <jLink data-type='L' data-strong='H6068G' clickHandler>Anathoth</jLink>, fulfilling the ancient prophecy against <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H5941' clickHandler>Eli</jLink>'s house, while <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H3097G' clickHandler>Joab</jLink> was executed at the altar for his role in supporting <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H0138G' clickHandler>Adonijah</jLink> and for his previous murders of <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H0074' clickHandler>Abner</jLink> and <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H6021G' clickHandler>Amasa</jLink>. <jPara></jPara> Following these purges, <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H8010' clickHandler>Solomon</jLink> began establishing the administrative and diplomatic foundations that would characterize his reign, including the appointment of reliable officials and the initiation of marriage alliances with neighboring powers, most notably his union with <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H7895' clickHandler>Pharaoh</jLink>'s daughter. The king also demonstrated his commitment to proper worship by offering sacrifices at the high place in <jLink data-type='L' data-strong='H1391' clickHandler>Gibeon</jLink>, where the ancient tabernacle of <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H4872' clickHandler>Moses</jLink> was located, and it was there that God appeared to him in a dream and granted his request for wisdom rather than personal wealth or military victory. This wisdom is displayed in the works of Proverbs, Ecclesiastes and Song of Songs. This divine encounter established <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H8010' clickHandler>Solomon</jLink>'s reputation for wisdom and marked the beginning of a period of unprecedented peace and prosperity that would enable him to undertake the Temple construction project that his father <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H1732' clickHandler>David</jLink> had envisioned but was not permitted to complete.
events: 968 BC: <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H8010' clickHandler>Solomon</jLink> orders <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H0138G' clickHandler>Adonijah</jLink>’s execution over his request to marry <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H0049' clickHandler>Abishag</jLink>.
968 BC: <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H0054' clickHandler>Abiathar</jLink> is removed from the priesthood and exiled to <jLink data-type='L' data-strong='H6068G' clickHandler>Anathoth</jLink>.
968 BC: <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H3097G' clickHandler>Joab</jLink> is executed at the altar for past crimes and rebellion.
968 BC: <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H8096I' clickHandler>Shimei</jLink> is executed for breaking house arrest.
968 BC: <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H8010' clickHandler>Solomon</jLink> appoints key officials and organizes the kingdom’s administration.

ChronologyEntries.article: 966 BC:  The year 966 BC witnessed one of the most significant moments in Israel's religious history when King <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H8010' clickHandler>Solomon</jLink> laid the foundations of the First Temple in <jLink data-type='L' data-strong='H3389' clickHandler>Jerusalem</jLink>, formally beginning construction of the permanent dwelling place for the Ark of the Covenant (1Ki.6; 2Ch.3:2). The construction commenced in the second month (Ziv) of <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H8010' clickHandler>Solomon</jLink>'s fourth regnal year, precisely 480 years after the <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H3478' clickHandler>Israelites</jLink>' exodus from <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H4714H' clickHandler>Egypt</jLink> according to biblical chronology, on the site of the former threshing floor of <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H0771' clickHandler>Araunah</jLink> the <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H2983G' clickHandler>Jebusite</jLink> that <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H1732' clickHandler>David</jLink> had purchased following the devastating plague that ended his controversial census. The foundations were laid on Mount <jLink data-type='L' data-strong='H4179' clickHandler>Moriah</jLink>, traditionally identified with the location where <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H0085' clickHandler>Abraham</jLink> had prepared to sacrifice <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H3327' clickHandler>Isaac</jLink>, creating a theological connection between the patriarchal promises and the establishment of Israel's central sanctuary. <jPara></jPara> The Temple project represented the culmination of <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H1732' clickHandler>David</jLink>'s extensive preparations, including his accumulation of vast quantities of gold, silver, bronze, iron, and cedar wood, along with his detailed architectural plans and organization of priestly and <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H3878' clickHandler>Levitical</jLink> divisions for the future worship services. Archaeological evidence suggests that <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H8010' clickHandler>Solomon</jLink> employed <jLink data-type='L' data-strong='G5403' clickHandler>Phoenician</jLink> craftsmen and techniques in the Temple's construction, reflecting the international trade relationships and cultural exchanges that characterized his reign, while the building's dimensions and design followed ancient Near Eastern temple conventions adapted for <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H3478' clickHandler>Israelite</jLink> monotheistic worship. The laying of the foundations marked not only the beginning of a seven-year construction project but also the physical manifestation of God's promise to <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H1732' clickHandler>David</jLink> that his son would build a house for the divine name, establishing <jLink data-type='L' data-strong='H3389' clickHandler>Jerusalem</jLink> as the permanent religious center of Israel and fulfilling <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H4872' clickHandler>Moses</jLink>' prophecy about the place where God would choose to establish His dwelling among His people.
events: 966 BC: <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H8010' clickHandler>Solomon</jLink> lays the foundations of the First Temple on Mount <jLink data-type='L' data-strong='H4179' clickHandler>Moriah</jLink>, <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H0771' clickHandler>Araunah</jLink>’s former threshing floor, in his fourth year.
966 BC: Temple construction begins 480 years after the Exodus.
966 BC: <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H1732' clickHandler>David</jLink>’s Temple preparations are implemented during the building.

966 BC: <jLink data-type='L' data-strong='G5403' clickHandler>Phoenician</jLink> craftsmen and techniques are used, reflecting <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H8010' clickHandler>Solomon</jLink>’s alliance with <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H2438G' clickHandler>Hiram</jLink> of <jLink data-type='L' data-strong='H6865' clickHandler>Tyre</jLink>.

ChronologyEntries.article: 960 BC:  In 960 BC, the construction of <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H8010' clickHandler>Solomon</jLink>'s Temple was completed after seven years of intensive building activity, representing one of the ancient world's most magnificent architectural achievements and fulfilling the divine promises made to King <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H1732' clickHandler>David</jLink> (1Ki.6:38). The Temple was finished in the month of Bul (the eighth month) during <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H8010' clickHandler>Solomon</jLink>'s eleventh year as king, with every detail of the construction following the precise specifications that <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H1732' clickHandler>David</jLink> had received through divine revelation and passed on to his son. The completed structure featured a main sanctuary (the Holy Place) measuring sixty cubits long, twenty cubits wide, and thirty cubits high, with an inner sanctuary (the Holy of <jLink data-type='L' data-strong='H6944H' clickHandler>Holies</jLink>) forming a perfect twenty-cubit cube that would house the Ark of the Covenant, while the entire building was overlaid with pure gold and decorated with carved cherubim, palm trees, and flowers. <jPara></jPara> The Temple's completion marked a transformative moment in Israel's religious and political life, as it provided a permanent center for national worship and established <jLink data-type='L' data-strong='H3389' clickHandler>Jerusalem</jLink>'s status as the undisputed spiritual capital of the twelve tribes. The building incorporated the finest materials available in the ancient world, including cedar from <jLink data-type='L' data-strong='H3844G' clickHandler>Lebanon</jLink> provided by <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H2438G' clickHandler>Hiram</jLink> king of <jLink data-type='L' data-strong='H6865' clickHandler>Tyre</jLink>, massive stones quarried and fitted without the sound of hammer or chisel at the construction site, and enormous quantities of gold and precious metals that demonstrated the prosperity and international connections of <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H8010' clickHandler>Solomon</jLink>'s kingdom. While the Temple would not be dedicated until the following year, its completion in 960 BC represented the fulfillment of centuries of preparation dating back to <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H4872' clickHandler>Moses</jLink>' wilderness tabernacle, <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H1732' clickHandler>David</jLink>'s purchase of the threshing floor, and the divine covenant promises that linked Israel's worship to a central sanctuary where God would cause His name to dwell among His people forever.
events: 960 BC: <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H8010' clickHandler>Solomon</jLink>’s Temple is completed in the eighth month of his eleventh year, following <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H1732' clickHandler>David</jLink>’s specifications.

960 BC: The Temple is built with cedar from <jLink data-type='L' data-strong='H3844G' clickHandler>Lebanon</jLink>, quarried stones, and precious metals, showcasing <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H8010' clickHandler>Solomon</jLink>’s alliances and wealth.
960 BC: Architectural details include the Holy Place, Holy of <jLink data-type='L' data-strong='H6944H' clickHandler>Holies</jLink> for the Ark, and ornate gold-covered decorations.

ChronologyEntries.desc: <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H8010' clickHandler>Solomon</jLink> dedicates the Temple
ChronologyEntries.article: 959 BC:  In 959 BC, <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H8010' clickHandler>Solomon</jLink> dedicated the Temple in <jLink data-type='L' data-strong='H3389' clickHandler>Jerusalem</jLink>, marking one of the most significant religious events in Israel's history. The elaborate ceremony involved the transfer of the Ark of the Covenant into the newly completed Temple, accompanied by the assembly of Israel's elders, tribal leaders, and heads of families. <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H8010' clickHandler>Solomon</jLink> offered countless sheep and oxen as sacrifices, and the Ark was placed beneath the wings of the cherubim in the Most Holy Place (Holy of <jLink data-type='L' data-strong='H6944H' clickHandler>Holies</jLink>), containing only the two stone tablets of the Law given to <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H4872' clickHandler>Moses</jLink>. <jPara></jPara> The dedication was marked by extraordinary manifestations of divine approval. As recorded in 1 Kings 8 and 2Ch.5-7, the glory of the Lord filled the Temple in the form of a cloud, making it impossible for the priests to continue ministering inside. <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H8010' clickHandler>Solomon</jLink> delivered a lengthy dedicatory prayer asking God to hear prayers offered toward the Temple, followed by massive additional sacrifices of 22,000 oxen and 120,000 sheep. According to 2 Chronicles 7, fire descended from heaven to consume the burnt offering, further confirming divine acceptance. The celebration included a seven-day festival followed by a solemn assembly on the eighth day, establishing the Temple as the central place of worship for Israel.
events: 959 BC: <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H8010' clickHandler>Solomon</jLink> dedicates the Temple, assembling Israel’s leaders for the ceremony.
959 BC: The Ark of the Covenant is brought into the Holy of <jLink data-type='L' data-strong='H6944H' clickHandler>Holies</jLink> under the cherubim.
959 BC: The glory of the Lord fills the Temple as a cloud, preventing priestly service.
959 BC: <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H8010' clickHandler>Solomon</jLink> delivers a dedicatory prayer for the Temple.
959 BC: <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H8010' clickHandler>Solomon</jLink> and Israel offer 22,000 oxen and 120,000 sheep as sacrifices.

ChronologyEntries.desc: <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H8010' clickHandler>Solomon</jLink> builds his palace
ChronologyEntries.article: 947 BC:  In 947 BC, <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H8010' clickHandler>Solomon</jLink> began construction of his royal palace complex, an ambitious architectural project that required thirteen years to complete. The palace consisted of several magnificent buildings, including the House of the Forest of <jLink data-type='L' data-strong='H3844G' clickHandler>Lebanon</jLink> (notable for its extensive cedar pillars and beams), the Hall of Pillars, the Hall of the Throne (also called the Hall of Judgment where <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H8010' clickHandler>Solomon</jLink> administered justice), and the king's private residence (1Ki.7:1-12). The complex also included a separate residence for <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H7895' clickHandler>Pharaoh</jLink>'s daughter, <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H8010' clickHandler>Solomon</jLink>'s <jLink data-type='L' data-strong='H4714G' clickHandler>Egyptian</jLink> wife, reflecting the diplomatic importance of royal marriages in ancient Near Eastern politics. <jPara></jPara> The palace construction demonstrated <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H8010' clickHandler>Solomon</jLink>'s considerable wealth, power, and the architectural advancements achieved during his reign. The extensive use of cedar from <jLink data-type='L' data-strong='H3844G' clickHandler>Lebanon</jLink> and the scale of the project showcased Israel's prosperity and the king's ability to mobilize vast resources and skilled labor. Beyond serving as a royal residence, the palace complex functioned as a center for administration and governance, with the Hall of Judgment serving as the primary location where <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H8010' clickHandler>Solomon</jLink> exercised his renowned wisdom in legal matters. The project symbolized the stability and international prestige of <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H8010' clickHandler>Solomon</jLink>'s kingdom at the height of its power.
events: 947 BC: <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H8010' clickHandler>Solomon</jLink> began building his royal palace complex in <jLink data-type='L' data-strong='H3389' clickHandler>Jerusalem</jLink>, a thirteen-year project.

947 BC: The palace included the House of the Forest of <jLink data-type='L' data-strong='H3844G' clickHandler>Lebanon</jLink> with cedar from <jLink data-type='L' data-strong='H3844G' clickHandler>Lebanon</jLink>.
947 BC: The complex featured the Hall of Pillars and Hall of the Throne for justice.

947 BC: <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H8010' clickHandler>Solomon</jLink>’s palace had private quarters and a separate residence for <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H7895' clickHandler>Pharaoh</jLink>’s daughter.

ChronologyEntries.article: 939 BC:  <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H8010' clickHandler>Solomon</jLink> engaged in extensive administrative, commercial, and diplomatic activities that expanded Israel's influence and prosperity (1Ki.9:1-11:13; 2Ch.8-9). His building projects included fortifying strategic cities such as <jLink data-type='L' data-strong='H2674G' clickHandler>Hazor</jLink>, <jLink data-type='L' data-strong='H4023' clickHandler>Megiddo</jLink>, and <jLink data-type='L' data-strong='H1507' clickHandler>Gezer</jLink>, along with constructing storage cities, chariot cities, and facilities for his cavalry. <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H8010' clickHandler>Solomon</jLink> established sophisticated trade networks, developing a fleet of ships at <jLink data-type='L' data-strong='H6100' clickHandler>Ezion-Geber</jLink> near <jLink data-type='L' data-strong='H0359A' clickHandler>Elath</jLink> on the Red Sea in partnership with <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H2438G' clickHandler>Hiram</jLink>, king of <jLink data-type='L' data-strong='H6865' clickHandler>Tyre</jLink>, which sailed to <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H0211G' clickHandler>Ophir</jLink> bringing back gold, silver, ivory, apes, and peacocks. He also engaged in profitable trade with <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H4714H' clickHandler>Egypt</jLink>, importing horses and chariots and re-exporting them to other nations, making Israel a significant commercial hub in the region. <jPara></jPara> <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H8010' clickHandler>Solomon</jLink>'s diplomatic relations during this period included maintaining alliances through strategic marriages and hosting distinguished visitors, most notably the Queen of <jLink data-type='L' data-strong='H7614J' clickHandler>Sheba</jLink>, who came to test his wisdom and brought lavish gifts. However, this period also marked the beginning of spiritual decline, as <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H8010' clickHandler>Solomon</jLink>'s marriages to foreign women led to the introduction of idolatrous practices in Israel. The king used non-<jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H3478' clickHandler>Israelite</jLink> populations remaining in the land for forced labor in his construction projects, while his extensive building activities and trade ventures contributed to Israel's economic prosperity but also placed increasing burdens on the population through taxation and conscription. These developments, while showcasing Israel's power and wealth, ultimately contributed to the divine disfavor that would later manifest in political challenges to <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H8010' clickHandler>Solomon</jLink>'s rule.
events: 939 BC: <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H8010' clickHandler>Solomon</jLink> fortified <jLink data-type='L' data-strong='H2674G' clickHandler>Hazor</jLink>, <jLink data-type='L' data-strong='H4023' clickHandler>Megiddo</jLink>, <jLink data-type='L' data-strong='H1507' clickHandler>Gezer</jLink>, Lower Beth Horon, <jLink data-type='L' data-strong='H1191H' clickHandler>Baalath</jLink>, <jLink data-type='L' data-strong='H8412' clickHandler>Tadmor</jLink>, and built storage and chariot cities.

939 BC: He developed trade and a fleet at <jLink data-type='L' data-strong='H6100' clickHandler>Ezion-Geber</jLink> with <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H2438G' clickHandler>Hiram</jLink> of <jLink data-type='L' data-strong='H6865' clickHandler>Tyre</jLink>, sending ships to <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H0211G' clickHandler>Ophir</jLink> for gold, silver, ivory, apes, and peacocks.

939 BC: <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H8010' clickHandler>Solomon</jLink> imported horses and chariots from <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H4714H' clickHandler>Egypt</jLink> and exported them, making Israel a commercial hub.

939 BC: The Queen of <jLink data-type='L' data-strong='H7614J' clickHandler>Sheba</jLink> visited <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H8010' clickHandler>Solomon</jLink> in <jLink data-type='L' data-strong='H3389' clickHandler>Jerusalem</jLink>, testing his wisdom and bringing lavish gifts.

939 BC: <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H8010' clickHandler>Solomon</jLink> maintained alliances through marriages to <jLink data-type='L' data-strong='H4124G' clickHandler>Moabite</jLink>, <jLink data-type='L' data-strong='H5983' clickHandler>Ammonite</jLink>, <jLink data-type='L' data-strong='H0123G' clickHandler>Edomite</jLink>, Sidonian, and <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H2845' clickHandler>Hittite</jLink> princesses.

ChronologyEntries.desc: <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H8010' clickHandler>Solomon</jLink> fights <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H1908I' clickHandler>Hadad</jLink>. <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H3379G' clickHandler>Jeroboam</jLink> flees
ChronologyEntries.article: 935 BC:  <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H8010' clickHandler>Solomon</jLink> faced significant opposition from multiple adversaries, marking the beginning of the decline of his unified rule (1Ki.11:14-40). God raised up <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H1908I' clickHandler>Hadad</jLink> the <jLink data-type='L' data-strong='H0123G' clickHandler>Edomite</jLink>, a royal descendant who had fled to <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H4714H' clickHandler>Egypt</jLink> during <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H1732' clickHandler>David</jLink>'s conquest of <jLink data-type='L' data-strong='H0123G' clickHandler>Edom</jLink>, as a persistent threat to Israel's southern borders. Simultaneously, <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H7331' clickHandler>Rezon</jLink> son of <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H0450H' clickHandler>Eliada</jLink>, who had escaped from his master in <jLink data-type='L' data-strong='H6678G' clickHandler>Zobah</jLink>, established himself as ruler in <jLink data-type='L' data-strong='H1834' clickHandler>Damascus</jLink> and continuously harassed Israel's northern territories. These external conflicts represented divine judgment against <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H8010' clickHandler>Solomon</jLink> for his idolatry and marriages to foreign women, which had led him to build high places for pagan deities. <jPara></jPara> The most significant internal challenge came from <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H3379G' clickHandler>Jeroboam</jLink> son of <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H5028' clickHandler>Nebat</jLink>, an official in <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H8010' clickHandler>Solomon</jLink>'s administration who received a prophetic message from <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H0281H' clickHandler>Ahijah</jLink> the <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H8023' clickHandler>Shilonite</jLink> that he would rule over ten tribes of Israel. Following his rebellion against <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H8010' clickHandler>Solomon</jLink>'s authority, <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H3379G' clickHandler>Jeroboam</jLink> fled to <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H4714H' clickHandler>Egypt</jLink>, where he remained under the protection of <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H5224G' clickHandler>Pharaoh</jLink> <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H7895' clickHandler>Shishak</jLink> until <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H8010' clickHandler>Solomon</jLink>'s death. These adversaries collectively eroded <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H8010' clickHandler>Solomon</jLink>'s central authority and foreshadowed the division of the united monarchy that would occur after his death, with <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H3379G' clickHandler>Jeroboam</jLink> eventually leading the northern tribes (Israel) while <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H8010' clickHandler>Solomon</jLink>'s son <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H7346' clickHandler>Rehoboam</jLink> retained only Judah and <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H1144G' clickHandler>Benjamin</jLink>. These conflicts marked the beginning of the end of Israel's golden age under <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H8010' clickHandler>Solomon</jLink>, setting the stage for the political fragmentation that would define the subsequent period of <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H3478' clickHandler>Israelite</jLink> history.
events: 935 BC: <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H1908I' clickHandler>Hadad</jLink> the <jLink data-type='L' data-strong='H0123G' clickHandler>Edomite</jLink> returned from <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H4714H' clickHandler>Egypt</jLink> and became a persistent adversary to Israel’s south.

935 BC: <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H7331' clickHandler>Rezon</jLink> son of <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H0450H' clickHandler>Eliada</jLink> ruled <jLink data-type='L' data-strong='H1834' clickHandler>Damascus</jLink> and harassed Israel from the north.

935 BC: <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H3379G' clickHandler>Jeroboam</jLink> rebelled against <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H8010' clickHandler>Solomon</jLink> after <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H0281H' clickHandler>Ahijah</jLink> the <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H8023' clickHandler>Shilonite</jLink> prophesied he’d rule ten tribes.

935 BC: <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H3379G' clickHandler>Jeroboam</jLink> fled to <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H4714H' clickHandler>Egypt</jLink> under <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H5224G' clickHandler>Pharaoh</jLink> <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H7895' clickHandler>Shishak</jLink>’s protection until <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H8010' clickHandler>Solomon</jLink>’s death.

ChronologyEntries.desc: <jChronDurationLink style='color:black'>▼</jChronDurationLink><jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H7346' clickHandler>Rehoboam</jLink> K Judah; <jChronDurationLink style='color:blue'>▼</jChronDurationLink><jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H3379G' clickHandler>Jeroboam</jLink> K Israel
ChronologyEntries.article: 931 BC:  In 931 BC, the united monarchy of Israel permanently divided into two separate kingdoms following the ascension of <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H7346' clickHandler>Rehoboam</jLink>, <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H8010' clickHandler>Solomon</jLink>'s son, to the throne in <jLink data-type='L' data-strong='H3389' clickHandler>Jerusalem</jLink>. When the northern tribes assembled at <jLink data-type='L' data-strong='H7927G' clickHandler>Shechem</jLink> to confirm <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H7346' clickHandler>Rehoboam</jLink> as king, they requested relief from the heavy taxation and forced labor imposed during <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H8010' clickHandler>Solomon</jLink>'s reign. <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H7346' clickHandler>Rehoboam</jLink>, rejecting the counsel of older advisers and following the advice of younger men, harshly refused to lighten these burdens, declaring that he would make their yoke even heavier than his father's. This response prompted the ten northern tribes to rebel, proclaiming "What portion do we have in <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H1732' clickHandler>David</jLink>?" and establishing <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H3379G' clickHandler>Jeroboam</jLink>, who had returned from exile in <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H4714H' clickHandler>Egypt</jLink>, as their king over the newly formed Kingdom of Israel. <jPara></jPara> The division (1Ki.12-14; 2Ch.10-14) resulted in <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H7346' clickHandler>Rehoboam</jLink> retaining only the tribes of Judah and <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H1144G' clickHandler>Benjamin</jLink> in the southern Kingdom of Judah, with <jLink data-type='L' data-strong='H3389' clickHandler>Jerusalem</jLink> as its capital. To prevent his subjects from traveling to <jLink data-type='L' data-strong='H3389' clickHandler>Jerusalem</jLink> for worship, <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H3379G' clickHandler>Jeroboam</jLink> established alternative religious centers at <jLink data-type='L' data-strong='H1008G' clickHandler>Bethel</jLink> and <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H1835H' clickHandler>Dan</jLink>, complete with golden calves, marking the beginning of what biblical writers would consistently condemn as the "sin of <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H3379G' clickHandler>Jeroboam</jLink>." This division created lasting hostility between the two kingdoms and fundamentally altered the political and religious landscape of ancient Israel, ending the unified monarchy that had existed under <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H7586G' clickHandler>Saul</jLink>, <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H1732' clickHandler>David</jLink>, and <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H8010' clickHandler>Solomon</jLink>.
events: 931 BC: Israel split into the Kingdom of Judah (<jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H7346' clickHandler>Rehoboam</jLink>, <jLink data-type='L' data-strong='H3389' clickHandler>Jerusalem</jLink>) and the Kingdom of Israel (<jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H3379G' clickHandler>Jeroboam</jLink>).

931 BC: <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H7346' clickHandler>Rehoboam</jLink> was confirmed king in <jLink data-type='L' data-strong='H3389' clickHandler>Jerusalem</jLink> over Judah and <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H1144G' clickHandler>Benjamin</jLink>.

931 BC: At <jLink data-type='L' data-strong='H7927G' clickHandler>Shechem</jLink>, <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H7346' clickHandler>Rehoboam</jLink> rejected the northern tribes’ plea to lighten taxes and labor.
931 BC: Ten northern tribes rebelled, rejecting the Davidic dynasty’s rule.
931 BC: <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H3379G' clickHandler>Jeroboam</jLink> became king over the ten tribes, establishing a northern capital.

ChronologyEntries.article: 930 BC:  In 930 BC, King <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H8010' clickHandler>Solomon</jLink> died after a reign of forty years over the united kingdom of Israel (1Ki.11:41-43). <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H8010' clickHandler>Solomon</jLink>'s death marked the end of Israel's golden age, a period characterized by unprecedented prosperity, the construction of the First Temple in <jLink data-type='L' data-strong='H3389' clickHandler>Jerusalem</jLink>, extensive trade networks, and territorial expansion. His reign had begun with great promise, featuring divine wisdom, successful building projects, and diplomatic achievements including alliances with <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H4714H' clickHandler>Egypt</jLink> and <jLink data-type='L' data-strong='G5403' clickHandler>Phoenicia</jLink>. <jPara></jPara> However, <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H8010' clickHandler>Solomon</jLink>'s later years were marked by increasing religious compromise through marriages to foreign wives and the introduction of their idolatrous practices, as well as heavy taxation and forced labor policies that created widespread discontent among the northern tribes. The biblical account suggests that these failures led to divine judgment and the prophecy that the kingdom would be divided after his death, with only the tribe of Judah remaining loyal to the Davidic dynasty. <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H8010' clickHandler>Solomon</jLink>'s death thus represented not only the conclusion of a remarkable individual reign but also the beginning of a period of political fragmentation that would fundamentally reshape the history of ancient Israel.
events: 930 BC: King <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H8010' clickHandler>Solomon</jLink> died in <jLink data-type='L' data-strong='H3389' clickHandler>Jerusalem</jLink> after a forty-year reign.

930 BC: <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H7346' clickHandler>Rehoboam</jLink> succeeded <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H8010' clickHandler>Solomon</jLink> as king in <jLink data-type='L' data-strong='H3389' clickHandler>Jerusalem</jLink>.

ChronologyEntries.desc: <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H7895' clickHandler>Shishak</jLink> of <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H4714H' clickHandler>Egypt</jLink> raids <jLink data-type='L' data-strong='H3389' clickHandler>Jerusalem</jLink>
ChronologyEntries.article: 925 BC:  In 925 BC, during the fifth year of <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H7346' clickHandler>Rehoboam</jLink>'s reign over Judah, <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H5224G' clickHandler>Pharaoh</jLink> <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H7895' clickHandler>Shishak</jLink> (Sheshonq I) of <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H4714H' clickHandler>Egypt</jLink> launched a military campaign that culminated in the plundering of <jLink data-type='L' data-strong='H3389' clickHandler>Jerusalem</jLink> (1Ki.14:25-26; 2Ch.12:1-9). This invasion represented a dramatic reassertion of <jLink data-type='L' data-strong='H4714G' clickHandler>Egyptian</jLink> power in the Levant after a period of relative decline during <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H8010' clickHandler>Solomon</jLink>'s later years. The biblical account attributes this disaster to Judah's unfaithfulness to the Lord, with the prophet <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H8098A' clickHandler>Shemaiah</jLink> declaring that God had abandoned them because they had abandoned Him. <jPara></jPara> <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H7895' clickHandler>Shishak</jLink>'s forces seized the treasures of both the Temple and the royal palace, including the famous golden shields that <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H8010' clickHandler>Solomon</jLink> had made, forcing <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H7346' clickHandler>Rehoboam</jLink> to replace them with bronze substitutes. The raid demonstrated the vulnerability of the newly divided kingdom and marked a significant loss of the wealth and prestige that had accumulated during <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H8010' clickHandler>Solomon</jLink>'s prosperous reign. <jLink data-type='L' data-strong='H4714G' clickHandler>Egyptian</jLink> records from Karnak temple appear to corroborate this campaign, listing numerous cities in both Judah and Israel that were conquered. The event highlighted how the political fragmentation following <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H8010' clickHandler>Solomon</jLink>'s death had weakened both kingdoms, making them susceptible to foreign intervention and establishing a pattern of external powers exploiting the division between Israel and Judah.
events: 925 BC: <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H5224G' clickHandler>Pharaoh</jLink> <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H7895' clickHandler>Shishak</jLink> invaded Judah in <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H7346' clickHandler>Rehoboam</jLink>’s fifth year.

925 BC: <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H7895' clickHandler>Shishak</jLink>’s forces plundered <jLink data-type='L' data-strong='H3389' clickHandler>Jerusalem</jLink>, seizing Temple and royal treasures.

925 BC: <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H8010' clickHandler>Solomon</jLink>’s golden shields were taken; <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H7346' clickHandler>Rehoboam</jLink> replaced them with bronze shields.
925 BC: Prophet <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H8098A' clickHandler>Shemaiah</jLink> declared the disaster as judgment for Judah’s unfaithfulness.
925 BC: Judah suffered significant loss of wealth and prestige.

ChronologyEntries.desc: <jChronDurationLink style='color:black'>▼</jChronDurationLink><jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H0029I' clickHandler>Abijah</jLink> King of Judah
ChronologyEntries.article: 913 BC:  In 913 BC, <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H0029I' clickHandler>Abijah</jLink> ascended to the throne of Judah following the death of his father <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H7346' clickHandler>Rehoboam</jLink>, initiating a brief but notable reign that lasted approximately three years. <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H0029I' clickHandler>Abijah</jLink>'s kingship is primarily remembered for his military conflict with <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H3379G' clickHandler>Jeroboam</jLink>, king of the northern Kingdom of Israel (1Ki.15:1-8; 2Ch.13:1-2). Despite being significantly outnumbered—with <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H0029I' clickHandler>Abijah</jLink> commanding 400,000 men against <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H3379G' clickHandler>Jeroboam</jLink>'s 800,000—the king of Judah delivered a compelling speech before the battle in which he emphasized Judah's faithfulness to the Davidic covenant and the proper worship of <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H3068G' clickHandler>Yahweh</jLink> at the <jLink data-type='L' data-strong='H3389' clickHandler>Jerusalem</jLink> Temple, contrasting this with Israel's religious innovations and idolatrous practices. <jPara></jPara> The biblical account records that Judah achieved a decisive victory over Israel in this conflict, with Chronicles attributing the success to divine intervention rather than military superiority. <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H0029I' clickHandler>Abijah</jLink>'s triumph reinforced the legitimacy of the Davidic dynasty and the religious centrality of <jLink data-type='L' data-strong='H3389' clickHandler>Jerusalem</jLink>, while dealing a significant blow to <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H3379G' clickHandler>Jeroboam</jLink>'s authority in the north. Although <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H0029I' clickHandler>Abijah</jLink>'s reign was relatively short, his commitment to maintaining traditional worship practices and his successful defense of Judah's territorial integrity established important precedents for subsequent kings of Judah in their ongoing struggles with the northern kingdom.
events: 913 BC: <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H7346' clickHandler>Rehoboam</jLink> died, ending his reign in <jLink data-type='L' data-strong='H3389' clickHandler>Jerusalem</jLink>.
913 BC: <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H0029I' clickHandler>Abijah</jLink> became king of Judah in <jLink data-type='L' data-strong='H3389' clickHandler>Jerusalem</jLink>.
913 BC: <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H0029I' clickHandler>Abijah</jLink> fought <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H3379G' clickHandler>Jeroboam</jLink>, king of Israel, in a major battle.

913 BC: Before battle, <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H0029I' clickHandler>Abijah</jLink> emphasized Judah’s faithfulness to the Davidic covenant and the <jLink data-type='L' data-strong='H3389' clickHandler>Jerusalem</jLink> Temple.
913 BC: Judah, under <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H0029I' clickHandler>Abijah</jLink>, decisively defeated <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H3379G' clickHandler>Jeroboam</jLink>’s forces.

ChronologyEntries.desc: <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H0029I' clickHandler>Abijah</jLink> fights <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H3379G' clickHandler>Jeroboam</jLink>
ChronologyEntries.article: 912 BC:  In 912 BC, King <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H0029I' clickHandler>Abijah</jLink> of Judah engaged in a decisive military confrontation with <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H3379G' clickHandler>Jeroboam</jLink>, King of Israel (2Ch.13:3-22). This battle represented a crucial moment in the ongoing conflict between the divided kingdoms, with <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H0029I' clickHandler>Abijah</jLink> commanding approximately 400,000 select warriors against <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H3379G' clickHandler>Jeroboam</jLink>'s larger force of 800,000 chosen men. Despite being significantly outnumbered, Judah achieved a remarkable victory that the biblical narrative attributes to divine intervention and <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H0029I' clickHandler>Abijah</jLink>'s reliance on the Lord. <jPara></jPara> Before the battle commenced, <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H0029I' clickHandler>Abijah</jLink> delivered a compelling speech from Mount <jLink data-type='L' data-strong='H6787' clickHandler>Zemaraim</jLink> in the hill country of <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H0669G' clickHandler>Ephraim</jLink>, emphasizing Judah's faithfulness to the Davidic covenant and the legitimate worship of <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H3068G' clickHandler>Yahweh</jLink> at the <jLink data-type='L' data-strong='H3389' clickHandler>Jerusalem</jLink> Temple. He contrasted this with Israel's religious innovations, particularly <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H3379G' clickHandler>Jeroboam</jLink>'s establishment of golden calves at <jLink data-type='L' data-strong='H1008G' clickHandler>Bethel</jLink> and <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H1835H' clickHandler>Dan</jLink>, and his appointment of non-<jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H3878' clickHandler>Levitical</jLink> priests. The victory resulted in heavy casualties among the <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H3478' clickHandler>Israelite</jLink> forces and temporarily weakened <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H3379G' clickHandler>Jeroboam</jLink>'s authority in the north, while reinforcing the legitimacy of the Davidic dynasty and <jLink data-type='L' data-strong='H3389' clickHandler>Jerusalem</jLink>'s central role in Israel's religious life.
events: 912 BC: <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H0029I' clickHandler>Abijah</jLink> of Judah fought <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H3379G' clickHandler>Jeroboam</jLink> of Israel with 400,000 against 800,000 men.

912 BC: <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H0029I' clickHandler>Abijah</jLink> spoke at Mount <jLink data-type='L' data-strong='H6787' clickHandler>Zemaraim</jLink>, stressing Judah’s loyalty to the Davidic covenant and Temple worship.
912 BC: Judah achieved a decisive victory over Israel, attributed to divine intervention.
912 BC: Israel suffered heavy casualties in the battle.
912 BC: <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H3379G' clickHandler>Jeroboam</jLink>’s power in Israel was temporarily diminished.

ChronologyEntries.desc: <jChronDurationLink style='color:black'>▼</jChronDurationLink><jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H0609G' clickHandler>Asa</jLink> King of Judah
ChronologyEntries.article: 911 BC:  In 911 BC, <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H0609G' clickHandler>Asa</jLink> ascended to the throne of Judah, initiating what would become one of the most significant reformist reigns in the southern kingdom's history (1Ki.15:9-24; 2Ch.14:1-16:14). <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H0609G' clickHandler>Asa</jLink> immediately implemented comprehensive religious reforms that distinguished his forty-one-year reign, systematically removing idols from throughout Judah and repairing the altar of the Lord that had been damaged or neglected during previous administrations. These reforms included the removal of his grandmother <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H4601K' clickHandler>Maacah</jLink> from her position as queen mother due to her involvement in <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H0842' clickHandler>Asherah</jLink> worship, demonstrating his commitment to purifying Judah's religious practices regardless of family connections. <jPara></jPara> <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H0609G' clickHandler>Asa</jLink>'s reformist policies extended beyond mere idol removal to include positive measures that strengthened both the spiritual and military foundations of his kingdom. His efforts to restore proper worship and eliminate foreign religious influences contributed directly to a period of unprecedented peace and prosperity for Judah, allowing the kingdom to build fortified cities and maintain a well-equipped army. The biblical account presents <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H0609G' clickHandler>Asa</jLink>'s reign as a model of faithful leadership, where religious fidelity resulted in divine blessing and national stability, setting an important precedent for subsequent kings of Judah and establishing a period of relative security that would last for much of his four-decade rule.
events: 911 BC: <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H0029I' clickHandler>Abijah</jLink> died, ending his reign as king of Judah in <jLink data-type='L' data-strong='H3389' clickHandler>Jerusalem</jLink>.

911 BC: <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H0609G' clickHandler>Asa</jLink> became king of Judah in <jLink data-type='L' data-strong='H3389' clickHandler>Jerusalem</jLink>, beginning a forty-one-year reign.
911 BC: <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H0609G' clickHandler>Asa</jLink> implemented religious reforms in Judah, removing idols and restoring the Lord’s altar.

911 BC: <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H0609G' clickHandler>Asa</jLink> removed <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H4601K' clickHandler>Maacah</jLink> as queen mother due to her involvement in <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H0842' clickHandler>Asherah</jLink> worship.
911 BC: <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H0609G' clickHandler>Asa</jLink> restored proper worship in Judah, starting a period of peace and stability.

ChronologyEntries.desc: <jChronDurationLink style='color:blue'>▼</jChronDurationLink><jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H5070H' clickHandler>Nadab</jLink> King of Israel
ChronologyEntries.article: 910 BC:  In 910 BC, <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H5070H' clickHandler>Nadab</jLink> son of <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H3379G' clickHandler>Jeroboam</jLink> became the second king of the northern Kingdom of Israel, continuing his father's dynasty but maintaining the same religious and political policies that had characterized the kingdom since its inception (1Ki.15:25-32). <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H5070H' clickHandler>Nadab</jLink>'s reign lasted only two years and was marked by the biblical assessment that he "did evil in the eyes of the Lord," specifically continuing the sinful practices established by <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H3379G' clickHandler>Jeroboam</jLink>, particularly the worship at the golden calf shrines in <jLink data-type='L' data-strong='H1008G' clickHandler>Bethel</jLink> and <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H1835H' clickHandler>Dan</jLink>. His brief rule demonstrated the instability that would plague the northern kingdom throughout its history, as he failed to establish either religious legitimacy or political security. <jPara></jPara> The most significant event of <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H5070H' clickHandler>Nadab</jLink>'s short reign occurred while he and his army were besieging the <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H6430H' clickHandler>Philistine</jLink> city of <jLink data-type='L' data-strong='H1405' clickHandler>Gibbethon</jLink>, where <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H1201' clickHandler>Baasha</jLink> son of <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H0281H' clickHandler>Ahijah</jLink> from the tribe of <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H3485G' clickHandler>Issachar</jLink> conspired against him. <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H5070H' clickHandler>Nadab</jLink>'s assassination during this military campaign not only ended the brief <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H3379G' clickHandler>Jeroboam</jLink> dynasty but also established a pattern of violent succession that would characterize Israel's political landscape. His death fulfilled earlier prophetic warnings about the consequences of the religious innovations introduced by his father, and his inability to complete even basic military operations against traditional enemies like the <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H6430H' clickHandler>Philistines</jLink> demonstrated the weakness that had begun to characterize the northern kingdom's leadership.
events: 910 BC: <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H3379G' clickHandler>Jeroboam</jLink> died, ending his reign as Israel’s first king.
910 BC: <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H5070H' clickHandler>Nadab</jLink> became king of Israel, succeeding <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H3379G' clickHandler>Jeroboam</jLink>.

910 BC: <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H5070H' clickHandler>Nadab</jLink> continued worship of the golden calves at <jLink data-type='L' data-strong='H1008G' clickHandler>Bethel</jLink> and <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H1835H' clickHandler>Dan</jLink>, maintaining <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H3379G' clickHandler>Jeroboam</jLink>'s sinful practices.
910 BC: <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H5070H' clickHandler>Nadab</jLink> besieged <jLink data-type='L' data-strong='H1405' clickHandler>Gibbethon</jLink>, but the operation was left incomplete.

910 BC: <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H1201' clickHandler>Baasha</jLink> son of <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H0281H' clickHandler>Ahijah</jLink> assassinated <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H5070H' clickHandler>Nadab</jLink> during the siege.

ChronologyEntries.desc: <jChronDurationLink style='color:blue'>▼</jChronDurationLink><jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H1201' clickHandler>Baasha</jLink> King of Israel
ChronologyEntries.article: 909 BC:  In 909 BC, <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H1201' clickHandler>Baasha</jLink> son of <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H0281H' clickHandler>Ahijah</jLink> from the tribe of <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H3485G' clickHandler>Issachar</jLink> seized the throne of Israel after assassinating King <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H5070H' clickHandler>Nadab</jLink> during the siege of <jLink data-type='L' data-strong='H1405' clickHandler>Gibbethon</jLink>, establishing a new dynasty through violent means (1Ki.15:33-16:7). Upon assuming power, <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H1201' clickHandler>Baasha</jLink> immediately eliminated the entire house of <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H3379G' clickHandler>Jeroboam</jLink>, fulfilling the prophetic judgment pronounced against <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H3379G' clickHandler>Jeroboam</jLink>'s dynasty while simultaneously establishing his own authority through systematic elimination of potential rivals. His twenty-four-year reign would be characterized by continued conflict with the southern Kingdom of Judah and persistent idolatrous practices that perpetuated the religious corruption initiated by <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H3379G' clickHandler>Jeroboam</jLink>. <jPara></jPara> Despite his role in executing divine judgment against <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H3379G' clickHandler>Jeroboam</jLink>'s house, <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H1201' clickHandler>Baasha</jLink> himself provoked the Lord's anger by continuing the same sinful practices, particularly maintaining the golden calf worship centers and non-<jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H3878' clickHandler>Levitical</jLink> priesthood that had defined Israel's religious apostasy. The prophet <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H3058H' clickHandler>Jehu</jLink> son of <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H2607G' clickHandler>Hanani</jLink> delivered a scathing oracle against <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H1201' clickHandler>Baasha</jLink>, declaring that his house would meet the same fate as <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H3379G' clickHandler>Jeroboam</jLink>'s due to his persistence in leading Israel into sin. <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H1201' clickHandler>Baasha</jLink>'s reign thus exemplified the cyclical nature of judgment and rebellion that would characterize the northern kingdom, where each new dynasty, despite initially serving as an instrument of divine justice, would ultimately fall into the same patterns of idolatry and political instability that had destroyed their predecessors.
events: 909 BC: <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H1201' clickHandler>Baasha</jLink> assassinated <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H5070H' clickHandler>Nadab</jLink> during the siege of <jLink data-type='L' data-strong='H1405' clickHandler>Gibbethon</jLink>.
909 BC: <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H1201' clickHandler>Baasha</jLink> seized the throne of Israel, starting a new dynasty.

909 BC: <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H1201' clickHandler>Baasha</jLink> exterminated <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H3379G' clickHandler>Jeroboam</jLink>’s family, fulfilling prophetic judgment.
909 BC: <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H1201' clickHandler>Baasha</jLink> continued the siege of <jLink data-type='L' data-strong='H1405' clickHandler>Gibbethon</jLink> as king.

909 BC: <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H3058H' clickHandler>Jehu</jLink> son of <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H2607G' clickHandler>Hanani</jLink> prophesied destruction for <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H1201' clickHandler>Baasha</jLink>’s house due to his sins like <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H3379G' clickHandler>Jeroboam</jLink>’s.

ChronologyEntries.desc: <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H0609G' clickHandler>Asa</jLink> attacked. Turns back to God
ChronologyEntries.article: 897 BC:  In 897 BC, King <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H0609G' clickHandler>Asa</jLink> of Judah faced a major military threat when <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H2226K' clickHandler>Zerah</jLink> the <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H3568G' clickHandler>Cushite</jLink> launched an invasion with a massive army (2Ch.14:9-15:19). <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H2226K' clickHandler>Zerah</jLink>, likely a military leader from the <jLink data-type='L' data-strong='H3568A' clickHandler>Nubian</jLink> region south of <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H4714H' clickHandler>Egypt</jLink> (ancient <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H3568G' clickHandler>Cush</jLink>), brought what the biblical account describes as an enormous force against Judah. Rather than relying solely on military strategy, <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H0609G' clickHandler>Asa</jLink> turned to the Lord for assistance, crying out in prayer and acknowledging his dependence on divine help. This act of faith resulted in a decisive victory over the <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H3568G' clickHandler>Cushite</jLink> forces, with the Lord striking down the invaders before <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H0609G' clickHandler>Asa</jLink> and the men of Judah. <jPara></jPara> The victory over <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H2226K' clickHandler>Zerah</jLink> marked a pivotal moment in <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H0609G' clickHandler>Asa</jLink>'s reign, leading to significant religious and social reforms throughout Judah. Following the triumph, the prophet <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H5838M' clickHandler>Azariah</jLink> son of <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H5752H' clickHandler>Oded</jLink> encouraged <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H0609G' clickHandler>Asa</jLink> to continue seeking the Lord, which prompted comprehensive reforms including the removal of idols, the repair of the altar of the Lord, and a national covenant renewal ceremony. These reforms brought a period of peace and prosperity to Judah, with people from the northern kingdom of Israel even defecting to <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H0609G' clickHandler>Asa</jLink>'s territory because they recognized that the Lord was with him. The events of 897 BC thus established <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H0609G' clickHandler>Asa</jLink> as a reforming king and demonstrated the biblical principle that faithfulness to God results in divine blessing and military success.
events: 897 BC: <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H2226K' clickHandler>Zerah</jLink> the <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H3568G' clickHandler>Cushite</jLink> invaded Judah with a massive army.
897 BC: <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H0609G' clickHandler>Asa</jLink> prayed for divine help before the battle.
897 BC: <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H0609G' clickHandler>Asa</jLink> and Judah defeated <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H2226K' clickHandler>Zerah</jLink>’s forces with the Lord’s help.

897 BC: <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H5838M' clickHandler>Azariah</jLink> son of <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H5752H' clickHandler>Oded</jLink> encouraged <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H0609G' clickHandler>Asa</jLink> after the victory.
897 BC: <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H0609G' clickHandler>Asa</jLink> enacted religious reforms, removing idols and repairing the Lord’s altar.

ChronologyEntries.desc: <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H0609G' clickHandler>Asa</jLink> fights <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H1201' clickHandler>Baasha</jLink> of Israel
ChronologyEntries.article: 896 BC:  In 896 BC, King <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H0609G' clickHandler>Asa</jLink> of Judah confronted a serious strategic threat from <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H1201' clickHandler>Baasha</jLink>, King of Israel, who fortified the city of <jLink data-type='L' data-strong='H7414G' clickHandler>Ramah</jLink> to create an economic blockade preventing people from entering or leaving Judah's territory (1Ki.15:16-22; 2Ch.16:1-10). Faced with this challenge to Judah's security and trade, <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H0609G' clickHandler>Asa</jLink> chose to seek foreign military assistance rather than rely on divine intervention as he had done against <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H2226K' clickHandler>Zerah</jLink> the <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H3568G' clickHandler>Cushite</jLink> the previous year. He sent silver and gold from the temple and royal palace treasuries to <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H1130G' clickHandler>Ben-Hadad</jLink> I, king of <jLink data-type='L' data-strong='H0758I' clickHandler>Aram</jLink> (<jLink data-type='L' data-strong='H1834' clickHandler>Damascus</jLink>), requesting that he break his existing treaty with <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H1201' clickHandler>Baasha</jLink> and attack Israel's northern territories. <jPara></jPara> <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H1130G' clickHandler>Ben-Hadad</jLink> agreed to <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H0609G' clickHandler>Asa</jLink>'s proposal and launched attacks against several northern <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H3478' clickHandler>Israelite</jLink> cities, including <jLink data-type='L' data-strong='H5859' clickHandler>Ijon</jLink>, <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H1835H' clickHandler>Dan</jLink>, and <jLink data-type='L' data-strong='H0062' clickHandler>Abel-beth-maacah</jLink>, forcing <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H1201' clickHandler>Baasha</jLink> to abandon his fortification of <jLink data-type='L' data-strong='H7414G' clickHandler>Ramah</jLink> and return north to defend his own territory. <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H0609G' clickHandler>Asa</jLink> then mobilized all Judah to carry away the building materials <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H1201' clickHandler>Baasha</jLink> had left behind, using them to strengthen the fortifications of <jLink data-type='L' data-strong='H1387G' clickHandler>Geba</jLink> and <jLink data-type='L' data-strong='H4709G' clickHandler>Mizpah</jLink>. However, this apparent diplomatic success came with serious spiritual consequences, as the prophet <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H2607G' clickHandler>Hanani</jLink> rebuked <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H0609G' clickHandler>Asa</jLink> for relying on the king of <jLink data-type='L' data-strong='H0758I' clickHandler>Aram</jLink> instead of trusting in the Lord, warning that because of this decision, <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H0609G' clickHandler>Asa</jLink> would face wars for the remainder of his reign. <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H0609G' clickHandler>Asa</jLink>'s angry response to this prophetic rebuke—imprisoning <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H2607G' clickHandler>Hanani</jLink> and oppressing some of his people—marked the beginning of a spiritual decline that contrasted sharply with his earlier faithfulness during the invasion of <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H2226K' clickHandler>Zerah</jLink> the <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H3568G' clickHandler>Cushite</jLink>.
events: 896 BC: <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H1201' clickHandler>Baasha</jLink> fortified <jLink data-type='L' data-strong='H7414G' clickHandler>Ramah</jLink> to blockade Judah.

896 BC: <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H0609G' clickHandler>Asa</jLink> sought an alliance with <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H1130G' clickHandler>Ben-Hadad</jLink> of <jLink data-type='L' data-strong='H0758I' clickHandler>Aram</jLink> by sending him temple and palace treasures.

896 BC: <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H1130G' clickHandler>Ben-Hadad</jLink> attacked northern <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H3478' clickHandler>Israelite</jLink> cities, causing <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H1201' clickHandler>Baasha</jLink> to abandon <jLink data-type='L' data-strong='H7414G' clickHandler>Ramah</jLink>.

896 BC: <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H0609G' clickHandler>Asa</jLink> fortified <jLink data-type='L' data-strong='H1387G' clickHandler>Geba</jLink> and <jLink data-type='L' data-strong='H4709G' clickHandler>Mizpah</jLink> using materials from <jLink data-type='L' data-strong='H7414G' clickHandler>Ramah</jLink>.

896 BC: Prophet <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H2607G' clickHandler>Hanani</jLink> rebuked <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H0609G' clickHandler>Asa</jLink> for relying on <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H1130G' clickHandler>Ben-Hadad</jLink> instead of the Lord.

ChronologyEntries.desc: <jChronDurationLink style='color:blue'>▼</jChronDurationLink><jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H0425H' clickHandler>Elah</jLink> King of Israel
ChronologyEntries.article: 886 BC:  In 886 BC, <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H0425H' clickHandler>Elah</jLink> son of <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H1201' clickHandler>Baasha</jLink> ascended to the throne of Israel, beginning what would prove to be an exceptionally brief and troubled reign (1Ki.16:8-14). <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H0425H' clickHandler>Elah</jLink>'s two-year rule was characterized by the same idolatrous practices that had marked his father <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H1201' clickHandler>Baasha</jLink>'s reign, continuing the pattern of apostasy that the biblical writers consistently condemned in the northern kingdom's leadership. His reign demonstrated the political instability that increasingly plagued Israel, where royal authority was weak and military officials wielded significant independent power. <jPara></jPara> The defining moment of <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H0425H' clickHandler>Elah</jLink>'s reign came when he was assassinated by <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H2174A' clickHandler>Zimri</jLink>, one of his own military commanders who served as an officer in charge of half the royal chariot force. The assassination occurred while <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H0425H' clickHandler>Elah</jLink> was drinking heavily at the house of <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H0777' clickHandler>Arza</jLink>, the man in charge of his palace in <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H8656G' clickHandler>Tirzah</jLink>, highlighting both the king's vulnerability and the dissolute character of his court. <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H2174A' clickHandler>Zimri</jLink>'s successful coup not only ended <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H0425H' clickHandler>Elah</jLink>'s life and reign but also fulfilled the prophetic judgment that had been pronounced against the house of <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H1201' clickHandler>Baasha</jLink>, as <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H2174A' clickHandler>Zimri</jLink> proceeded to eliminate <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H1201' clickHandler>Baasha</jLink>'s entire family line, leaving no male descendants. This violent transition of power exemplified the cyclical pattern of divine judgment and political upheaval that would characterize the northern kingdom throughout its history, where each dynasty's sins led to its violent overthrow by the next.
events: 886 BC: <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H0425H' clickHandler>Elah</jLink> son of <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H1201' clickHandler>Baasha</jLink> became king of Israel in <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H8656G' clickHandler>Tirzah</jLink>.

886 BC: <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H2174A' clickHandler>Zimri</jLink> assassinated <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H0425H' clickHandler>Elah</jLink> while he drank at <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H0777' clickHandler>Arza</jLink>’s house in <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H8656G' clickHandler>Tirzah</jLink>.

886 BC: <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H2174A' clickHandler>Zimri</jLink>’s coup ended <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H1201' clickHandler>Baasha</jLink>’s dynasty by killing all male descendants.
886 BC: <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H0425H' clickHandler>Elah</jLink>’s death ended both his reign and <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H1201' clickHandler>Baasha</jLink>’s dynasty in Israel.

ChronologyEntries.desc: <jChronDurationLink style='color:blue'>▼</jChronDurationLink><jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H2174A' clickHandler>Zimri</jLink> then <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H8402' clickHandler>Tibni</jLink> + <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H6018G' clickHandler>Omri</jLink> Kings of Israel
ChronologyEntries.article: 885 BC:  In 885 BC, Israel experienced one of its most chaotic periods of political succession when <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H2174A' clickHandler>Zimri</jLink>, after assassinating King <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H0425H' clickHandler>Elah</jLink>, claimed the throne but ruled for only seven days before meeting his own violent end (1Ki.16:15-22). <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H2174A' clickHandler>Zimri</jLink>'s extremely brief reign was immediately challenged by <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H6018G' clickHandler>Omri</jLink>, the commander of Israel's army, who was besieging the <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H6430H' clickHandler>Philistine</jLink> city of <jLink data-type='L' data-strong='H1405' clickHandler>Gibbethon</jLink> when news of <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H0425H' clickHandler>Elah</jLink>'s assassination reached him. <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H6018G' clickHandler>Omri</jLink> and his forces immediately abandoned their siege and marched to <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H8656G' clickHandler>Tirzah</jLink>, the royal capital, where they besieged <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H2174A' clickHandler>Zimri</jLink> in the royal palace. Realizing that defeat was inevitable, <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H2174A' clickHandler>Zimri</jLink> set the royal palace on fire and perished in the flames, bringing his week-long usurpation to a dramatic end. <jPara></jPara> Following <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H2174A' clickHandler>Zimri</jLink>'s death, Israel became divided between two rival claimants to the throne: <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H6018G' clickHandler>Omri</jLink>, who had the support of the army, and <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H8402' clickHandler>Tibni</jLink> son of <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H1527' clickHandler>Ginath</jLink>, who apparently had backing from other segments of the population. This civil conflict persisted for several years, creating a period of instability and division within the northern kingdom. The struggle between these two pretenders to the throne represented more than a simple succession dispute; it reflected deeper divisions within <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H3478' clickHandler>Israelite</jLink> society about military versus civilian leadership. Eventually, <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H6018G' clickHandler>Omri</jLink>'s military backing and organizational skills proved decisive, and following <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H8402' clickHandler>Tibni</jLink>'s death, he became the undisputed king of Israel, establishing what would become one of the northern kingdom's most significant dynasties. The events of 885 BC thus marked both the end of the brief but violent house of <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H1201' clickHandler>Baasha</jLink> and the beginning of the <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H6018G' clickHandler>Omri</jLink>’s dynasty, which would play a crucial role in subsequent <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H3478' clickHandler>Israelite</jLink> history.
events: 885 BC: <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H2174A' clickHandler>Zimri</jLink> became king of Israel in <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H8656G' clickHandler>Tirzah</jLink> for seven days after killing <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H0425H' clickHandler>Elah</jLink>.

885 BC: <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H6018G' clickHandler>Omri</jLink> abandoned the siege of <jLink data-type='L' data-strong='H1405' clickHandler>Gibbethon</jLink> to confront <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H2174A' clickHandler>Zimri</jLink>.

885 BC: <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H6018G' clickHandler>Omri</jLink> besieged <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H8656G' clickHandler>Tirzah</jLink>, <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H2174A' clickHandler>Zimri</jLink> burned the palace and died.

885 BC: Civil war erupted between <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H6018G' clickHandler>Omri</jLink> and <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H8402' clickHandler>Tibni</jLink> son of <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H1527' clickHandler>Ginath</jLink> for the throne.

ChronologyEntries.desc: <jChronDurationLink style='color:blue'>▼</jChronDurationLink><jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H6018G' clickHandler>Omri</jLink> King alone over Israel
