ChronologyEntries.article: 880 BC:  In 880 BC, <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H6018G' clickHandler>Omri</jLink> finally achieved undisputed control over the northern Kingdom of Israel, ending a prolonged period of civil war and political instability that had plagued the nation since <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H2174A' clickHandler>Zimri</jLink>'s brief usurpation in 885 BC. Following years of conflict with his rival claimant <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H8402' clickHandler>Tibni</jLink> son of <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H1527' clickHandler>Ginath</jLink>, <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H6018G' clickHandler>Omri</jLink>'s military backing and organizational capabilities proved decisive in securing his position as the sole monarch of Israel. <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H6018G' clickHandler>Omri</jLink>'s supporters ultimately prevailed over those who followed <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H8402' clickHandler>Tibni</jLink> (1Ki.16:21-28), establishing what would become one of Israel's most significant dynasties and marking the end of the chaotic succession disputes that had characterized the northern kingdom since <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H3379G' clickHandler>Jeroboam</jLink>'s initial rebellion. <jPara></jPara> <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H6018G' clickHandler>Omri</jLink>'s consolidation of power represented a crucial turning point in <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H3478' clickHandler>Israelite</jLink> political history, as he successfully centralized royal authority and established governmental stability after nearly a decade of intermittent warfare and divided loyalties. His reign, though the biblical writers gave it relatively brief treatment, laid the foundation for significant developments in Israel's infrastructure, military organization, and international relations. Archaeological evidence suggests that <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H6018G' clickHandler>Omri</jLink>'s administrative reforms and building projects strengthened Israel's position among the surrounding nations, while his diplomatic initiatives would have lasting consequences for the kingdom's foreign policy under his successors.
events: 880 BC: <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H8402' clickHandler>Tibni</jLink> son of <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H1527' clickHandler>Ginath</jLink> died, removing <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H6018G' clickHandler>Omri</jLink>’s last rival.
880 BC: <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H6018G' clickHandler>Omri</jLink> became sole king of Israel, ending the civil war with <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H8402' clickHandler>Tibni</jLink>.
880 BC: <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H6018G' clickHandler>Omri</jLink> established the Omride dynasty in Israel.

ChronologyEntries.desc: <jLink data-type='L' data-strong='H8111' clickHandler>Samaria</jLink> becomes capital of Israel
ChronologyEntries.article: 876 BC:  In 876 BC, King <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H6018G' clickHandler>Omri</jLink> made the strategic decision to establish <jLink data-type='L' data-strong='H8111' clickHandler>Samaria</jLink> as the new capital of the northern Kingdom of Israel (1Ki.16:23-24), marking a pivotal moment in the nation's political and administrative development. <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H6018G' clickHandler>Omri</jLink> purchased the hill of <jLink data-type='L' data-strong='H8111' clickHandler>Samaria</jLink> from <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H8106A' clickHandler>Shemer</jLink> for two talents of silver and constructed a new royal city that would serve as Israel's seat of government for the remainder of the kingdom's existence. The location was strategically chosen for its defensive advantages, commanding an elevated position in the central hill country of <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H0669G' clickHandler>Ephraim</jLink> with excellent visibility and natural fortifications that made it nearly impregnable to ancient siege warfare. <jPara></jPara> The establishment of <jLink data-type='L' data-strong='H8111' clickHandler>Samaria</jLink> represented more than merely a change of royal residence; it symbolized <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H6018G' clickHandler>Omri</jLink>'s commitment to creating a permanent and distinctive identity for the northern kingdom, separate from both the traditional tribal centers and <jLink data-type='L' data-strong='H3389' clickHandler>Jerusalem</jLink>'s religious and political influence. The new capital provided centralized administrative control over Israel's territory while facilitating trade relationships with <jLink data-type='L' data-strong='G5403' clickHandler>Phoenician</jLink> cities and other <jLink data-type='L' data-strong='H1419J' clickHandler>Mediterranean</jLink> powers. <jLink data-type='L' data-strong='H8111' clickHandler>Samaria</jLink>'s construction demonstrated <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H6018G' clickHandler>Omri</jLink>'s considerable resources and organizational capabilities, as the project required significant manpower, materials, and technical expertise to transform the hilltop site into a functioning royal complex complete with palace buildings, defensive walls, and supporting infrastructure for the royal court and government officials.
events: 876 BC: <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H6018G' clickHandler>Omri</jLink> bought the hill of <jLink data-type='L' data-strong='H8111' clickHandler>Samaria</jLink> from <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H8106A' clickHandler>Shemer</jLink> for two talents of silver.
876 BC: <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H6018G' clickHandler>Omri</jLink> founded <jLink data-type='L' data-strong='H8111' clickHandler>Samaria</jLink> as Israel’s new capital.
876 BC: <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H6018G' clickHandler>Omri</jLink> built the city of <jLink data-type='L' data-strong='H8111' clickHandler>Samaria</jLink> with royal buildings and defenses.

ChronologyEntries.desc: <jChronDurationLink style='color:blue'>▼</jChronDurationLink><jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H0256G' clickHandler>Ahab</jLink> King of Israel
ChronologyEntries.article: 874 BC:  In 874 BC, <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H0256G' clickHandler>Ahab</jLink> son of <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H6018G' clickHandler>Omri</jLink> ascended to the throne of Israel, initiating a twenty-two-year reign that would prove to be one of the most controversial and consequential in the northern kingdom's history (1Ki.16:29-22:40). <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H0256G' clickHandler>Ahab</jLink>'s marriage to <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H0348' clickHandler>Jezebel</jLink>, daughter of <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H0856' clickHandler>Ethbaal</jLink> king of the <jLink data-type='L' data-strong='H6721H' clickHandler>Sidonians</jLink>, represented a significant diplomatic alliance with <jLink data-type='L' data-strong='G5403' clickHandler>Phoenicia</jLink> but introduced profound religious changes that would define his entire reign. Under <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H0348' clickHandler>Jezebel</jLink>'s influence, <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H0256G' clickHandler>Ahab</jLink> actively promoted the worship of Baal and <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H0842' clickHandler>Asherah</jLink>, constructing a temple and altar for Baal in <jLink data-type='L' data-strong='H8111' clickHandler>Samaria</jLink> and establishing what amounted to an official state religion centered on <jLink data-type='L' data-strong='G5403' clickHandler>Phoenician</jLink> deities rather than the worship of <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H3068G' clickHandler>Yahweh</jLink>. <jPara></jPara> These religious innovations provoked intense opposition from <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H3068G' clickHandler>Yahweh</jLink>'s prophets, most notably <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H0452G' clickHandler>Elijah</jLink> the <jLink data-type='L' data-strong='H8453B' clickHandler>Tishbite</jLink>, leading to dramatic confrontations that included the contest on Mount <jLink data-type='L' data-strong='H3760G' clickHandler>Carmel</jLink> and a three-year drought that demonstrated divine judgment against Israel's apostasy. <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H0256G' clickHandler>Ahab</jLink>'s reign was marked by military campaigns against <jLink data-type='L' data-strong='H0758I' clickHandler>Syria</jLink>, internal conflicts arising from his religious policies, and incidents such as his seizure of <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H5022' clickHandler>Naboth</jLink>'s vineyard that illustrated the moral corruption accompanying his spiritual compromise. Despite some military successes and continued prosperity in Israel, the biblical assessment of <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H0256G' clickHandler>Ahab</jLink>'s rule emphasizes that he "did more evil in the eyes of the Lord than any of those before him," establishing patterns of idolatry and royal misconduct that would have lasting consequences for the northern kingdom's relationship with God and its eventual destruction.
events: 874 BC: <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H6018G' clickHandler>Omri</jLink>’s reign as king of Israel ended with his death.

874 BC: <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H0256G' clickHandler>Ahab</jLink> son of <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H6018G' clickHandler>Omri</jLink> became king of Israel, beginning his twenty-two-year reign.

874 BC: <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H0256G' clickHandler>Ahab</jLink> married <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H0348' clickHandler>Jezebel</jLink>, daughter of <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H0856' clickHandler>Ethbaal</jLink>, king of the <jLink data-type='L' data-strong='H6721H' clickHandler>Sidonians</jLink>, forming a <jLink data-type='L' data-strong='G5403' clickHandler>Phoenician</jLink> alliance.

874 BC: <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H0256G' clickHandler>Ahab</jLink>, influenced by <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H0348' clickHandler>Jezebel</jLink>, promoted Baal and <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H0842' clickHandler>Asherah</jLink> worship in Israel.

874 BC: <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H0256G' clickHandler>Ahab</jLink> built a temple and altar for Baal in <jLink data-type='L' data-strong='H8111' clickHandler>Samaria</jLink>, establishing state-sanctioned worship of <jLink data-type='L' data-strong='G5403' clickHandler>Phoenician</jLink> deities.

ChronologyEntries.desc: <jChronDurationLink style='color:black'>▼</jChronDurationLink><jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H3092I' clickHandler>Jehoshaphat</jLink> reigns in Judah
ChronologyEntries.article: 873 BC:  In 873 BC, <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H3092I' clickHandler>Jehoshaphat</jLink> began his reign over the southern Kingdom of Judah, likely as co-regent alongside his aging father <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H0609G' clickHandler>Asa</jLink>, inaugurating a reign that would be remembered as one of the most reformist and militarily successful in Judah's history (1Ki.22:41-50; 2Ch.17:1-21:1). <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H3092I' clickHandler>Jehoshaphat</jLink> immediately implemented comprehensive religious reforms designed to eliminate idolatrous practices and strengthen adherence to <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H3068G' clickHandler>Yahweh</jLink> worship throughout his territory. He systematically removed the high places and <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H0842' clickHandler>Asherah</jLink> poles that had been established during previous reigns, while simultaneously organizing an innovative educational program that sent officials, <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H3878' clickHandler>Levites</jLink>, and priests throughout Judah to teach the people from the Book of the Law, thereby ensuring widespread knowledge of proper religious observances. <jPara></jPara> Beyond his religious reforms, <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H3092I' clickHandler>Jehoshaphat</jLink> undertook significant military and administrative improvements that strengthened Judah's defensive capabilities and internal organization. He fortified strategic cities throughout his kingdom, established a professional military force organized by tribal divisions, and implemented judicial reforms that included appointing qualified judges in the fortified cities of Judah with instructions to judge fairly without partiality or bribery. His reign marked a period of unprecedented peace and prosperity for Judah, as surrounding nations recognized the strength and stability of his kingdom, with some peoples bringing tribute and gifts rather than engaging in warfare. The biblical writers particularly commend <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H3092I' clickHandler>Jehoshaphat</jLink>'s early years for his commitment to seeking the Lord and following the ways of his ancestor <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H1732' clickHandler>David</jLink>, establishing him as a model of faithful kingship that contrasted sharply with the apostasy occurring simultaneously in the northern kingdom under <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H0256G' clickHandler>Ahab</jLink>.
events: 873 BC: <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H3092I' clickHandler>Jehoshaphat</jLink> began his reign over Judah, likely as co-regent with <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H0609G' clickHandler>Asa</jLink>.

873 BC: <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H3092I' clickHandler>Jehoshaphat</jLink> removed high places and <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H0842' clickHandler>Asherah</jLink> poles, promoting exclusive <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H3068G' clickHandler>Yahweh</jLink> worship in Judah.

873 BC: <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H3092I' clickHandler>Jehoshaphat</jLink> sent officials, <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H3878' clickHandler>Levites</jLink>, and priests to teach the Book of the Law throughout Judah.
873 BC: <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H3092I' clickHandler>Jehoshaphat</jLink> fortified cities and organized Judah’s military by tribal divisions.
873 BC: <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H3092I' clickHandler>Jehoshaphat</jLink> appointed qualified judges in fortified cities, instructing them to judge fairly.

ChronologyEntries.desc: <jChronDurationLink style='color:green'>▼</jChronDurationLink><jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H0452G' clickHandler>Elijah</jLink> prophesies a drought
ChronologyEntries.article: 872 BC:  In 872 BC, <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H0452G' clickHandler>Elijah</jLink> the <jLink data-type='L' data-strong='H8453B' clickHandler>Tishbite</jLink> confronted King <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H0256G' clickHandler>Ahab</jLink> of Israel with a dramatic prophetic declaration, announcing that there would be neither dew nor rain in the coming years except at his word (1Ki.17:1-6). This bold proclamation represented a direct theological challenge to the Baal worship that had been promoted throughout Israel under <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H0256G' clickHandler>Ahab</jLink>'s reign, particularly through the influence of Queen <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H0348' clickHandler>Jezebel</jLink>, his <jLink data-type='L' data-strong='G5403' clickHandler>Phoenician</jLink> wife. Since Baal was widely regarded as a storm and fertility god who controlled rainfall and agricultural productivity, <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H0452G' clickHandler>Elijah</jLink>'s drought prophecy asserted <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H3068G' clickHandler>Yahweh</jLink>'s supremacy over the elements and demonstrated the powerlessness of the foreign deities that had corrupted Israel's worship. <jPara></jPara> Following his confrontation with <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H0256G' clickHandler>Ahab</jLink>, <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H0452G' clickHandler>Elijah</jLink> obeyed divine instructions to hide by the brook <jLink data-type='L' data-strong='H3747' clickHandler>Cherith</jLink>, east of the <jLink data-type='L' data-strong='H3383' clickHandler>Jordan</jLink> River, where God sustained him through miraculous provision. Ravens brought him bread and meat each morning and evening, while he drank from the brook, demonstrating God's care for his faithful prophet during this period of national judgment. The drought served as divine judgment against Israel's apostasy and idolatry, fulfilling covenantal warnings found in the Torah where disobedience to God would result in ecological disaster. This event marked the beginning of a prolonged period of famine that would affect not only Israel but neighboring regions, exposing the vulnerability of the monarchy and the limitations of pagan religious authority while reinforcing the prophetic tradition as a counterbalance to royal power.
events: 872 BC: <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H0452G' clickHandler>Elijah</jLink> the <jLink data-type='L' data-strong='H8453B' clickHandler>Tishbite</jLink> told <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H0256G' clickHandler>Ahab</jLink> there would be no dew or rain in Israel except at his word.
872 BC: A severe drought began in Israel as a result of <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H0452G' clickHandler>Elijah</jLink>’s prophecy against Baal worship.

872 BC: <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H0452G' clickHandler>Elijah</jLink> hid by the brook <jLink data-type='L' data-strong='H3747' clickHandler>Cherith</jLink> east of the <jLink data-type='L' data-strong='H3383' clickHandler>Jordan</jLink> as God commanded.

872 BC: Ravens brought <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H0452G' clickHandler>Elijah</jLink> bread and meat, and he drank from the brook <jLink data-type='L' data-strong='H3747' clickHandler>Cherith</jLink> during the drought.

ChronologyEntries.article: 870 BC:  In 870 BC, King <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H0609G' clickHandler>Asa</jLink> of Judah died after one of the longest and most significant reformist periods in the southern kingdom's history (2Ch.16:12; 17:7-9). <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H0609G' clickHandler>Asa</jLink>'s final years were marked by a severe disease in his feet that afflicted him during the thirty-ninth year of his reign, and despite this illness, he sought help from physicians rather than seeking the Lord, representing a departure from the faith that had characterized his earlier years. His death marked the end of an era that had seen comprehensive religious reforms, military victories against foreign invaders, and a general period of peace and prosperity for Judah, though his later reliance on foreign alliances rather than divine assistance had brought prophetic rebuke and promised future conflicts. <jPara></jPara> Following <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H0609G' clickHandler>Asa</jLink>'s death, his son <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H3092I' clickHandler>Jehoshaphat</jLink> transitioned from co-regent to full king of Judah, immediately demonstrating his commitment to continuing and expanding his father's reformist policies. Early in his independent reign, <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H3092I' clickHandler>Jehoshaphat</jLink> implemented an innovative educational program by sending officials, <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H3878' clickHandler>Levites</jLink>, and priests throughout all the cities of Judah to teach the people from the Book of the Law of the Lord, ensuring widespread religious instruction and proper observance of Yahwistic worship. This systematic approach to religious education represented a significant advancement beyond his father's reforms, as it addressed not merely the removal of idolatrous practices but the positive establishment of proper covenantal knowledge throughout the kingdom. <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H3092I' clickHandler>Jehoshaphat</jLink>'s initiative strengthened Judah's religious foundation and contributed to the stability and prosperity that would characterize much of his twenty-five-year reign.
events: 870 BC: King <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H0609G' clickHandler>Asa</jLink> of Judah died after a forty-one-year reign.
870 BC: <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H3092I' clickHandler>Jehoshaphat</jLink> became full king of Judah following <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H0609G' clickHandler>Asa</jLink>’s death.

870 BC: <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H3092I' clickHandler>Jehoshaphat</jLink> sent officials, <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H3878' clickHandler>Levites</jLink>, and priests to teach the Book of the Law in Judah early in his reign.

ChronologyEntries.desc: <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H0452G' clickHandler>Elijah</jLink> feeds the widow at <jLink data-type='L' data-strong='H6886' clickHandler>Zarephath</jLink>
ChronologyEntries.article: 868 BC:  In 868 BC, during the prolonged drought that <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H0452G' clickHandler>Elijah</jLink> had prophesied two years earlier, the prophet experienced God's provision through a remarkable encounter with a widow in <jLink data-type='L' data-strong='H6886' clickHandler>Zarephath</jLink>, a <jLink data-type='L' data-strong='G5403' clickHandler>Phoenician</jLink> city (1Ki.17:7-24). The brook <jLink data-type='L' data-strong='H3747' clickHandler>Cherith</jLink> had dried up due to the continuing absence of rain, prompting divine direction for <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H0452G' clickHandler>Elijah</jLink> to journey to <jLink data-type='L' data-strong='H6886' clickHandler>Zarephath</jLink>, where God had commanded a widow to provide for him. When <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H0452G' clickHandler>Elijah</jLink> arrived, he found the widow gathering sticks and preparing what she believed would be the final meal for herself and her son, having only a handful of flour in a jar and a little oil in a jug remaining. Despite her desperate circumstances, <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H0452G' clickHandler>Elijah</jLink> requested that she make him a small cake first, promising that her jar of flour and jug of oil would not run dry until the drought ended and rain returned to the land. <jPara></jPara> The widow's obedience to <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H0452G' clickHandler>Elijah</jLink>'s request resulted in miraculous provision, as her household was sustained with food throughout the remainder of the drought period, with the flour jar and oil jug never becoming empty. However, a more dramatic miracle occurred when the widow's son became seriously ill and died, prompting her to question whether <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H0452G' clickHandler>Elijah</jLink>'s presence had brought divine judgment upon her household. <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H0452G' clickHandler>Elijah</jLink> took the dead child to the upper room where he was staying, stretched himself upon the boy three times, and prayed earnestly to the Lord for the child's life to return. God heard <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H0452G' clickHandler>Elijah</jLink>'s prayer and restored the boy to life, and when <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H0452G' clickHandler>Elijah</jLink> presented the living child to his mother, she declared her complete faith in <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H0452G' clickHandler>Elijah</jLink> as a man of God whose words were truly from the Lord.
events: 868 BC: The brook <jLink data-type='L' data-strong='H3747' clickHandler>Cherith</jLink> dried up, forcing <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H0452G' clickHandler>Elijah</jLink> to leave due to the drought.

868 BC: <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H0452G' clickHandler>Elijah</jLink> traveled to <jLink data-type='L' data-strong='H6886' clickHandler>Zarephath</jLink> in <jLink data-type='L' data-strong='G5403' clickHandler>Phoenicia</jLink> as God directed.
868 BC: <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H0452G' clickHandler>Elijah</jLink> met a widow in <jLink data-type='L' data-strong='H6886' clickHandler>Zarephath</jLink> gathering sticks for a final meal.
868 BC: <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H0452G' clickHandler>Elijah</jLink>’s request led to the widow’s jar of flour and jug of oil not running dry during the drought.
868 BC: The widow’s son died and <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H0452G' clickHandler>Elijah</jLink> prayed for him, and God restored the boy’s life.

ChronologyEntries.desc: <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H3088G' clickHandler>Jehoram</jLink> marries <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H6271G' clickHandler>Athaliah</jLink> of Israel
ChronologyEntries.article: 865 BC:  In 865 BC, <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H3088G' clickHandler>Jehoram</jLink>, the son of King <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H3092I' clickHandler>Jehoshaphat</jLink> of Judah, married <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H6271G' clickHandler>Athaliah</jLink>, daughter of King <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H0256G' clickHandler>Ahab</jLink> and Queen <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H0348' clickHandler>Jezebel</jLink> of Israel, establishing a significant political alliance between the divided kingdoms (2Ki.8:16-18; 2Ch.18:1). This marriage represented a strategic diplomatic initiative by <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H3092I' clickHandler>Jehoshaphat</jLink> to strengthen ties between Judah and Israel during a period of regional instability, when both kingdoms faced external threats from Aram-Damascus and other surrounding powers. The union was intended to reduce hostilities between the brother kingdoms and create a united front against common enemies, while also potentially facilitating trade relationships and military cooperation between the two monarchies. <jPara></jPara> However, this politically advantageous marriage carried profound religious and cultural consequences that would prove detrimental to Judah's spiritual integrity. <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H6271G' clickHandler>Athaliah</jLink> brought with her the influence of the northern kingdom's religious practices, including the Baal worship that had been promoted by her parents <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H0256G' clickHandler>Ahab</jLink> and <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H0348' clickHandler>Jezebel</jLink>, introducing these idolatrous elements into the Davidic royal line. The biblical narrative indicates that <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H3088G' clickHandler>Jehoram</jLink> "walked in the ways of the kings of Israel, as did the house of <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H0256G' clickHandler>Ahab</jLink>," demonstrating how <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H6271G' clickHandler>Athaliah</jLink>'s influence led him to adopt the corrupt practices associated with the northern kingdom's apostasy. This marriage alliance would have lasting dynastic implications, as <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H6271G' clickHandler>Athaliah</jLink> would later seize power in Judah after her son's death, attempting to eliminate the entire Davidic line and establishing Baal worship as the official religion, illustrating how such political marriages could disrupt traditional succession patterns and introduce religious syncretism that threatened the covenantal foundations of the southern kingdom.
events: 865 BC: <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H3088G' clickHandler>Jehoram</jLink> son of <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H3092I' clickHandler>Jehoshaphat</jLink> married <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H6271G' clickHandler>Athaliah</jLink> daughter of <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H0256G' clickHandler>Ahab</jLink> and <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H0348' clickHandler>Jezebel</jLink>, forming a political alliance between Judah and Israel.
865 BC: <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H3088G' clickHandler>Jehoram</jLink>’s marriage established an alliance between Judah and Israel.
865 BC: <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H6271G' clickHandler>Athaliah</jLink>’s arrival brought Baal worship influence and northern practices to the Davidic line in Judah.

865 BC: <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H3088G' clickHandler>Jehoram</jLink> adopted the ways of <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H0256G' clickHandler>Ahab</jLink>’s house under <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H6271G' clickHandler>Athaliah</jLink>’s influence.

ChronologyEntries.desc: <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H0452G' clickHandler>Elijah</jLink> challenges the prophets of Baal
ChronologyEntries.article: 864 BC:  The prophet <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H0452G' clickHandler>Elijah</jLink> orchestrated one of the most dramatic confrontations in biblical history when he challenged the prophets of Baal to a contest on Mount <jLink data-type='L' data-strong='H3760G' clickHandler>Carmel</jLink> (1Ki.18-19:18). This event occurred during the third year of a severe drought that <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H0452G' clickHandler>Elijah</jLink> had prophesied in 872 BC as divine judgment against Israel's apostasy under King <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H0256G' clickHandler>Ahab</jLink> and Queen <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H0348' clickHandler>Jezebel</jLink>'s promotion of Baal worship. The contest involved 450 prophets of Baal and 400 prophets of <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H0842' clickHandler>Asherah</jLink>, who had been supported by <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H0348' clickHandler>Jezebel</jLink>'s court, competing against <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H0452G' clickHandler>Elijah</jLink> alone to demonstrate whose deity possessed true power. The challenge required each side to prepare a sacrifice and call upon their respective gods to consume the offering with fire, with the understanding that the god who answered would be acknowledged as the true deity. <jPara></jPara> The prophets of Baal spent the entire day calling upon their storm and fertility god, engaging in frenzied rituals including dancing around their altar and cutting themselves with swords and spears, but received no response. When <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H0452G' clickHandler>Elijah</jLink>'s turn came, he repaired the Lord's altar that had been torn down, arranged the sacrifice, and dramatically increased the difficulty by having the offering doused with water three times. His simple prayer to the "Lord, the God of <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H0085' clickHandler>Abraham</jLink>, <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H3327' clickHandler>Isaac</jLink> and Israel" was immediately answered when fire fell from heaven, consuming not only the sacrifice but also the wood, stones, soil, and water in the trench. The assembled <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H3478' clickHandler>Israelites</jLink> fell on their faces declaring "The Lord—he is God!" and subsequently executed all the prophets of Baal at the <jLink data-type='L' data-strong='H7028' clickHandler>Kishon</jLink> Valley, after which <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H0452G' clickHandler>Elijah</jLink> prayed for rain and the drought ended with a tremendous downpour. However, Queen <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H0348' clickHandler>Jezebel</jLink>'s threat to kill <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H0452G' clickHandler>Elijah</jLink> within twenty-four hours forced the prophet to flee to <jLink data-type='L' data-strong='H0884' clickHandler>Beersheba</jLink> and eventually to Mount <jLink data-type='L' data-strong='H5514G' clickHandler>Horeb</jLink>, where he experienced God's presence in a "gentle whisper" and received new commissions for his ministry.
events: 864 BC: <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H0452G' clickHandler>Elijah</jLink> challenged 450 prophets of Baal and 400 prophets of <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H0842' clickHandler>Asherah</jLink> on Mount <jLink data-type='L' data-strong='H3760G' clickHandler>Carmel</jLink>; only the Lord answered with fire.

864 BC: <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H0452G' clickHandler>Elijah</jLink> repaired the Lord’s altar on Mount <jLink data-type='L' data-strong='H3760G' clickHandler>Carmel</jLink>, prepared the sacrifice, and drenched it with water.

864 BC: The Lord sent fire from heaven on Mount <jLink data-type='L' data-strong='H3760G' clickHandler>Carmel</jLink>, consuming <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H0452G' clickHandler>Elijah</jLink>’s sacrifice completely.

864 BC: <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H0452G' clickHandler>Elijah</jLink> ordered the execution of Baal’s prophets at the <jLink data-type='L' data-strong='H7028' clickHandler>Kishon</jLink> Valley.

864 BC: <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H0452G' clickHandler>Elijah</jLink> prayed on Mount <jLink data-type='L' data-strong='H3760G' clickHandler>Carmel</jLink>, and rain fell, ending the three-year drought in Israel.

ChronologyEntries.desc: <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H0452G' clickHandler>Elijah</jLink> calls <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H0477' clickHandler>Elisha</jLink>
ChronologyEntries.article: 859 BC:  Following <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H0452G' clickHandler>Elijah</jLink>'s dramatic victory over the prophets of Baal and his subsequent flight from Queen <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H0348' clickHandler>Jezebel</jLink>'s murderous threats, God directed the prophet to anoint <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H0477' clickHandler>Elisha</jLink> son of <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H8202H' clickHandler>Shaphat</jLink> as his successor (1Ki.19:19-21). This divine appointment represented a crucial moment in Israel's prophetic succession, occurring after <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H0452G' clickHandler>Elijah</jLink>'s profound spiritual experience at Mount <jLink data-type='L' data-strong='H5514G' clickHandler>Horeb</jLink> where he had encountered God's presence and received instructions to anoint new leaders for Israel, including <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H0477' clickHandler>Elisha</jLink> as prophet, <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H2371' clickHandler>Hazael</jLink> as king of <jLink data-type='L' data-strong='H0758I' clickHandler>Aram</jLink>, and <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H3058H' clickHandler>Jehu</jLink> as king of Israel. <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H0452G' clickHandler>Elijah</jLink> found <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H0477' clickHandler>Elisha</jLink> plowing a field with the twelfth pair of oxen in a team, indicating that his family possessed considerable wealth and that <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H0477' clickHandler>Elisha</jLink> held a position of responsibility in their agricultural operations. <jPara></jPara> The prophetic calling was symbolically communicated when <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H0452G' clickHandler>Elijah</jLink> threw his cloak (mantle) over <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H0477' clickHandler>Elisha</jLink>, a gesture that represented the transfer of prophetic authority and divine anointing. <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H0477' clickHandler>Elisha</jLink> immediately understood the significance of this act and requested permission to bid farewell to his parents, demonstrating both his respect for family obligations and his recognition of the gravity of the prophetic call. After <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H0452G' clickHandler>Elijah</jLink> granted this request with the cryptic response "Go back. What have I done to you?"—likely emphasizing that the call came from God rather than man—<jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H0477' clickHandler>Elisha</jLink> returned to slaughter his oxen, using the wooden farming equipment as fuel to cook the meat for a farewell feast with his community. This deliberate destruction of his means of livelihood symbolized the completeness of his commitment to the prophetic ministry, after which he left everything behind to follow <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H0452G' clickHandler>Elijah</jLink> and serve as his attendant, beginning the mentor-disciple relationship that would culminate in <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H0477' clickHandler>Elisha</jLink> receiving a double portion of <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H0452G' clickHandler>Elijah</jLink>'s spirit.
events: 859 BC: <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H0452G' clickHandler>Elijah</jLink> found <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H0477' clickHandler>Elisha</jLink> son of <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H8202H' clickHandler>Shaphat</jLink> plowing near <jLink data-type='L' data-strong='H0065' clickHandler>Abel-meholah</jLink>.

859 BC: <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H0452G' clickHandler>Elijah</jLink> threw his cloak over <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H0477' clickHandler>Elisha</jLink>, symbolically anointing him as prophetic successor.

859 BC: <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H0477' clickHandler>Elisha</jLink> asked to say goodbye to his parents, which <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H0452G' clickHandler>Elijah</jLink> permitted.
859 BC: <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H0477' clickHandler>Elisha</jLink> slaughtered his oxen, cooked the meat, and held a farewell feast.

859 BC: <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H0477' clickHandler>Elisha</jLink> left his family to follow <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H0452G' clickHandler>Elijah</jLink> and serve as his attendant.

ChronologyEntries.desc: <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H0256G' clickHandler>Ahab</jLink> defeats <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H1130G' clickHandler>Ben-Hadad</jLink> of <jLink data-type='L' data-strong='H0758I' clickHandler>Aram</jLink>
ChronologyEntries.article: 858 BC:  King <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H0256G' clickHandler>Ahab</jLink> of Israel faced a major military threat when <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H1130G' clickHandler>Ben-Hadad</jLink> I, king of Aram-Damascus, besieged <jLink data-type='L' data-strong='H8111' clickHandler>Samaria</jLink> with a coalition of thirty-two kings and their combined forces (1Ki.20:1-34). <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H1130G' clickHandler>Ben-Hadad</jLink> I initially made extreme demands for <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H0256G' clickHandler>Ahab</jLink>'s silver, gold, wives, and children, which <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H0256G' clickHandler>Ahab</jLink> accepted, but when the <jLink data-type='L' data-strong='H0123G' clickHandler>Aramean</jLink> king escalated his demands to allow his officials to search and seize anything of value from <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H0256G' clickHandler>Ahab</jLink>'s palace and his nobles' houses, the king of Israel refused after consulting with his elders. This rejection prompted <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H1130G' clickHandler>Ben-Hadad</jLink> to threaten the complete destruction of <jLink data-type='L' data-strong='H8111' clickHandler>Samaria</jLink>, to which <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H0256G' clickHandler>Ahab</jLink> replied with the proverbial response that one who puts on armor should not boast like one who takes it off. A prophet approached <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H0256G' clickHandler>Ahab</jLink> during this crisis, promising that the Lord would deliver the vast <jLink data-type='L' data-strong='H0123G' clickHandler>Aramean</jLink> army into his hands so that he would know that the Lord is God, demonstrating divine concern for Israel despite <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H0256G' clickHandler>Ahab</jLink>'s idolatrous practices. <jPara></jPara> The battle unfolded exactly as prophesied, with young <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H3478' clickHandler>Israelite</jLink> officers leading a surprise attack that routed <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H1130G' clickHandler>Ben-Hadad</jLink>'s forces while the <jLink data-type='L' data-strong='H0123G' clickHandler>Aramean</jLink> king and his allied rulers were drinking in their tents. <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H1130G' clickHandler>Ben-Hadad</jLink> I escaped on horseback with his cavalry, but the victory was so complete that the <jLink data-type='L' data-strong='H0123G' clickHandler>Arameans</jLink> fled back to their homeland in disarray. The following spring, <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H1130G' clickHandler>Ben-Hadad</jLink> I returned with a reorganized army, believing that Israel's God was only powerful in the hills, not in the plains, but again suffered a devastating defeat when 100,000 <jLink data-type='L' data-strong='H0123G' clickHandler>Aramean</jLink> foot soldiers were killed in a single day and the remainder fled to <jLink data-type='L' data-strong='H0663I' clickHandler>Aphek</jLink>, where a wall collapsed and killed 27,000 more. When <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H1130G' clickHandler>Ben-Hadad</jLink> sought mercy by approaching <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H0256G' clickHandler>Ahab</jLink> in sackcloth and ropes, the <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H3478' clickHandler>Israelite</jLink> king spared his life and made a covenant with him, allowing the <jLink data-type='L' data-strong='H0123G' clickHandler>Aramean</jLink> king to return <jLink data-type='L' data-strong='H1834' clickHandler>Damascus</jLink> and restoring cities that had been taken from Israel. However, this act of mercy toward <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H1130G' clickHandler>Ben-Hadad</jLink> was subsequently condemned by a prophet who declared that because <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H0256G' clickHandler>Ahab</jLink> had released a man whom God had devoted to destruction, <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H0256G' clickHandler>Ahab</jLink>'s life would be forfeit for <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H1130G' clickHandler>Ben-Hadad</jLink>'s life, and his people for <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H1130G' clickHandler>Ben-Hadad</jLink>'s people.
events: 858 BC: <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H1130G' clickHandler>Ben-Hadad</jLink> of Aram-Damascus and thirty-two kings besieged <jLink data-type='L' data-strong='H8111' clickHandler>Samaria</jLink>, demanding <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H0256G' clickHandler>Ahab</jLink>’s wealth, wives, and children.

858 BC: <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H0256G' clickHandler>Ahab</jLink> rejected <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H1130G' clickHandler>Ben-Hadad</jLink>’s escalated demand to search royal and noble houses.
858 BC: <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H1130G' clickHandler>Ben-Hadad</jLink> threatened to destroy <jLink data-type='L' data-strong='H8111' clickHandler>Samaria</jLink>, leading to a standoff.

858 BC: A prophet told <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H0256G' clickHandler>Ahab</jLink> the Lord would deliver the <jLink data-type='L' data-strong='H0123G' clickHandler>Aramean</jLink> coalition to Israel.

858 BC: <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H3478' clickHandler>Israelite</jLink> officers led a surprise attack, defeating <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H1130G' clickHandler>Ben-Hadad</jLink> at <jLink data-type='L' data-strong='H8111' clickHandler>Samaria</jLink> and forcing his escape.

ChronologyEntries.desc: <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H0256G' clickHandler>Ahab</jLink> takes <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H5022' clickHandler>Naboth</jLink>'s vineyard
ChronologyEntries.article: 856 BC:  King <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H0256G' clickHandler>Ahab</jLink> of Israel became embroiled in a notorious case of royal injustice involving <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H5022' clickHandler>Naboth</jLink> the <jLink data-type='L' data-strong='H3157G' clickHandler>Jezreelite</jLink>'s vineyard, an incident that exemplified the moral corruption of <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H0256G' clickHandler>Ahab</jLink>'s reign and provoked one of <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H0452G' clickHandler>Elijah</jLink>'s most severe prophetic condemnations, as recorded in 1 Kings 21. The vineyard was located near <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H0256G' clickHandler>Ahab</jLink>'s palace in <jLink data-type='L' data-strong='H3157H' clickHandler>Jezreel</jLink>, and the king desired to acquire it either through purchase or trade to convert it into a vegetable garden. However, <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H5022' clickHandler>Naboth</jLink> refused <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H0256G' clickHandler>Ahab</jLink>'s reasonable offer, declaring "The Lord forbid that I should give you the inheritance of my ancestors," thereby invoking the Mosaic law that prohibited the permanent alienation of ancestral land and maintained tribal and family inheritance rights. <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H0256G' clickHandler>Ahab</jLink>'s reaction to this refusal revealed his petulant character, as he returned home sullen and refused to eat, lying on his bed and turning his face to the wall like a spoiled child denied a desired toy. <jPara></jPara> Queen <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H0348' clickHandler>Jezebel</jLink>, observing her husband's distress, took matters into her own hands by orchestrating an elaborate judicial murder that demonstrated the extent of corruption in Israel's legal system. Using <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H0256G' clickHandler>Ahab</jLink>'s royal seal, she wrote letters to the elders and nobles of <jLink data-type='L' data-strong='H3157H' clickHandler>Jezreel</jLink>, instructing them to proclaim a fast and seat <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H5022' clickHandler>Naboth</jLink> in a prominent position among the people, then arrange for two scoundrels to falsely accuse him of cursing both God and the king—charges that carried the death penalty under Mosaic law. The plan was executed perfectly, resulting in <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H5022' clickHandler>Naboth</jLink>'s death by stoning along with his sons, ensuring no heir could claim the property. When <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H0348' clickHandler>Jezebel</jLink> informed <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H0256G' clickHandler>Ahab</jLink> that <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H5022' clickHandler>Naboth</jLink> was dead and he could now possess the vineyard, the king immediately went to take ownership. However, <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H0452G' clickHandler>Elijah</jLink> confronted <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H0256G' clickHandler>Ahab</jLink> in the vineyard with a devastating prophetic oracle, declaring that dogs would lick up <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H0256G' clickHandler>Ahab</jLink>'s blood in the very place where they had licked up <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H5022' clickHandler>Naboth</jLink>'s blood, that his dynasty would be cut off completely, and that dogs would devour <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H0348' clickHandler>Jezebel</jLink> by the wall of <jLink data-type='L' data-strong='H3157H' clickHandler>Jezreel</jLink>. The narrative notes that there was never anyone like <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H0256G' clickHandler>Ahab</jLink> who sold himself to do evil in the Lord's sight, urged on by <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H0348' clickHandler>Jezebel</jLink>, yet when <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H0256G' clickHandler>Ahab</jLink> humbled himself by tearing his clothes, putting on sackcloth, and walking humbly, God postponed the disaster until after <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H0256G' clickHandler>Ahab</jLink>'s death, bringing it upon his son's house instead.
events: 856 BC: <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H5022' clickHandler>Naboth</jLink> refused to sell his ancestral vineyard to <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H0256G' clickHandler>Ahab</jLink>, near his palace in <jLink data-type='L' data-strong='H3157H' clickHandler>Jezreel</jLink>.

856 BC: <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H0256G' clickHandler>Ahab</jLink> sulks in his <jLink data-type='L' data-strong='H3157H' clickHandler>Jezreel</jLink> palace after <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H5022' clickHandler>Naboth</jLink>’s refusal.

856 BC: <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H0348' clickHandler>Jezebel</jLink> uses <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H0256G' clickHandler>Ahab</jLink>’s seal to plot against <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H5022' clickHandler>Naboth</jLink> by writing to <jLink data-type='L' data-strong='H3157H' clickHandler>Jezreel</jLink>’s elders.

856 BC: <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H5022' clickHandler>Naboth</jLink> and his sons are falsely accused and stoned to death by <jLink data-type='L' data-strong='H3157H' clickHandler>Jezreel</jLink>’s people under <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H0348' clickHandler>Jezebel</jLink>’s orders.

856 BC: <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H0348' clickHandler>Jezebel</jLink> tells <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H0256G' clickHandler>Ahab</jLink> to take <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H5022' clickHandler>Naboth</jLink>’s vineyard, and he immediately claims it.

ChronologyEntries.desc: <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H0256G' clickHandler>Ahab</jLink> dies in battle
ChronologyEntries.article: 854 BC:  In 854 BC, King <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H0256G' clickHandler>Ahab</jLink> of Israel met his end at the battle of Ramoth-Gilead, fulfilling prophetic warnings and concluding one of the most controversial reigns in Israel's history (1Ki.22:1-40; 2Ch.18:1-19:3). The campaign began when <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H0256G' clickHandler>Ahab</jLink> allied with King <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H3092I' clickHandler>Jehoshaphat</jLink> of Judah to reclaim the strategically important city of Ramoth-Gilead from <jLink data-type='L' data-strong='H0123G' clickHandler>Aramean</jLink> control. Before the battle, the prophet <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H4321G' clickHandler>Micaiah</jLink> delivered a devastating prophecy against <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H0256G' clickHandler>Ahab</jLink>'s plans, declaring that he saw "all Israel scattered on the hills like sheep without a shepherd," directly contradicting the favorable messages from <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H0256G' clickHandler>Ahab</jLink>'s court prophets. <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H0256G' clickHandler>Ahab</jLink>'s hatred for <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H4321G' clickHandler>Micaiah</jLink> was evident in his statement: "I hate him because he never prophesies anything good about me, but always bad". <jPara></jPara> Despite <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H4321G' clickHandler>Micaiah</jLink>'s warning and his vision of a lying spirit deceiving the court prophets, <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H0256G' clickHandler>Ahab</jLink> proceeded with the attack, attempting to disguise himself while <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H3092I' clickHandler>Jehoshaphat</jLink> wore his royal robes. The disguise proved futile when "someone drew his bow at random" and struck <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H0256G' clickHandler>Ahab</jLink> between the sections of his armor. The mortally wounded king was propped up in his chariot facing the <jLink data-type='L' data-strong='H0123G' clickHandler>Arameans</jLink> throughout the day until he died at evening, with his blood pooling in the chariot. When the chariot was later washed at a pool in <jLink data-type='L' data-strong='H8111' clickHandler>Samaria</jLink>, dogs licked up <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H0256G' clickHandler>Ahab</jLink>'s blood, fulfilling <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H0452G' clickHandler>Elijah</jLink>'s earlier prophecy regarding <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H5022' clickHandler>Naboth</jLink>'s vineyard. <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H0256G' clickHandler>Ahab</jLink>'s death marked the end of twenty-two years of rule characterized by unprecedented prosperity, architectural achievements, but also spiritual apostasy through his marriage to the <jLink data-type='L' data-strong='G5403' clickHandler>Phoenician</jLink> princess <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H0348' clickHandler>Jezebel</jLink> and the promotion of Baal worship throughout Israel.
events: 854 BC: <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H0256G' clickHandler>Ahab</jLink> and <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H3092I' clickHandler>Jehoshaphat</jLink> ally to retake Ramoth-Gilead from <jLink data-type='L' data-strong='H0123G' clickHandler>Aramean</jLink> control.

854 BC: <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H4321G' clickHandler>Micaiah</jLink> prophesies <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H0256G' clickHandler>Ahab</jLink>’s defeat and exposes <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H0256G' clickHandler>Ahab</jLink>’s court prophets as false.

854 BC: <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H0256G' clickHandler>Ahab</jLink> disguises himself and enters battle at Ramoth-Gilead with <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H3092I' clickHandler>Jehoshaphat</jLink> in royal robes.
854 BC: A random <jLink data-type='L' data-strong='H0123G' clickHandler>Aramean</jLink> archer fatally wounds <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H0256G' clickHandler>Ahab</jLink> at Ramoth-Gilead.

854 BC: <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H0256G' clickHandler>Ahab</jLink>’s blood is licked by dogs at <jLink data-type='L' data-strong='H8111' clickHandler>Samaria</jLink>, fulfilling <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H0452G' clickHandler>Elijah</jLink>’s prophecy.

ChronologyEntries.desc: <jChronDurationLink style='color:black'>▼</jChronDurationLink><jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H3088G' clickHandler>Jehoram</jLink> of Judah. <jChronDurationLink style='color:blue'>▼</jChronDurationLink><jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H0274G' clickHandler>Ahaziah</jLink> K of Israel
ChronologyEntries.article: 853 BC:  In 853 BC, significant leadership changes occurred in both kingdoms of the divided monarchy, with <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H3088G' clickHandler>Jehoram</jLink> beginning his regency alongside his father King <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H3092I' clickHandler>Jehoshaphat</jLink> of Judah, while <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H0274G' clickHandler>Ahaziah</jLink> ascended to the throne of Israel following his father <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H0256G' clickHandler>Ahab</jLink>'s death in battle (1Ki.22:51-53; 2Ki.1:1-18; 2Ki.8:16-24; 2Ch.19-21). This period represented a crucial moment of political cooperation and alliance between the northern and southern kingdoms, building upon the marriage alliance established in 865 BC between <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H3088G' clickHandler>Jehoram</jLink> and <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H6271G' clickHandler>Athaliah</jLink> (daughter of <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H0256G' clickHandler>Ahab</jLink> and <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H0348' clickHandler>Jezebel</jLink>). <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H0274G' clickHandler>Ahaziah</jLink>'s brief two-year reign over Israel was marked by continuation of the idolatrous practices established by his parents, particularly the worship of Baal and the maintenance of <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H3379G' clickHandler>Jeroboam</jLink>'s golden calf shrines at <jLink data-type='L' data-strong='H1008G' clickHandler>Bethel</jLink> and <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H1835H' clickHandler>Dan</jLink>. <jPara></jPara> The establishment of <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H3088G' clickHandler>Jehoram</jLink> as co-regent with <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H3092I' clickHandler>Jehoshaphat</jLink> in Judah reflected the southern kingdom's stability and organized succession planning, contrasting sharply with the violent transitions that frequently characterized Israel's monarchy. However, this period also marked the beginning of spiritual decline in Judah, as <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H3088G' clickHandler>Jehoram</jLink>'s marriage to <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H6271G' clickHandler>Athaliah</jLink> introduced northern kingdom religious practices into the Davidic royal house. <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H0274G' clickHandler>Ahaziah</jLink>'s reign in Israel was notably brief and troubled, ending with his death after injuries sustained from falling through a lattice in his upper room chamber, an event that prompted him to consult <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H1176' clickHandler>Baal-Zebub</jLink>, the god of <jLink data-type='L' data-strong='H6138' clickHandler>Ekron</jLink>, rather than seeking the Lord of Israel. The prophet <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H0452G' clickHandler>Elijah</jLink>'s intervention in this incident demonstrated continued prophetic resistance to the royal family's apostasy, as he pronounced divine judgment against <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H0274G' clickHandler>Ahaziah</jLink> for seeking foreign deities rather than the God of Israel.
events: 853 BC: <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H0274G' clickHandler>Ahaziah</jLink> son of <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H0256G' clickHandler>Ahab</jLink> becomes king of Israel in <jLink data-type='L' data-strong='H8111' clickHandler>Samaria</jLink> after <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H0256G' clickHandler>Ahab</jLink>’s death.

853 BC: <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H3088G' clickHandler>Jehoram</jLink> son of <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H3092I' clickHandler>Jehoshaphat</jLink> becomes co-regent with his father in Judah.

853 BC: <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H4124H' clickHandler>Moab</jLink> rebels against Israel after <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H0256G' clickHandler>Ahab</jLink>’s death, challenging <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H0274G' clickHandler>Ahaziah</jLink>’s rule.

853 BC: <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H0274G' clickHandler>Ahaziah</jLink> is seriously injured after falling through a lattice in <jLink data-type='L' data-strong='H8111' clickHandler>Samaria</jLink>.

853 BC: <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H0274G' clickHandler>Ahaziah</jLink> sends messengers to consult <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H1176' clickHandler>Baal-Zebub</jLink>, god of <jLink data-type='L' data-strong='H6138' clickHandler>Ekron</jLink>, instead of the Lord.

ChronologyEntries.desc: <jChronDurationLink style='color:green'>▼</jChronDurationLink><jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H3141H' clickHandler>Joram</jLink> K of Israel; <jChronDurationLink style='color:blue'>▼</jChronDurationLink><jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H0477' clickHandler>Elisha</jLink> replaced <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H0452G' clickHandler>Elijah</jLink>.
ChronologyEntries.article: 852 BC:  In 852 BC, one of the most dramatic prophetic transitions in biblical history occurred when <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H0452G' clickHandler>Elijah</jLink> was taken up to heaven in a whirlwind and <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H0477' clickHandler>Elisha</jLink> inherited his prophetic ministry, while <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H3141H' clickHandler>Joram</jLink> (also called <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H3088G' clickHandler>Jehoram</jLink>) became king of Israel (2Ki.2:1-3:13; 9:14-26). The prophetic succession was marked by extraordinary supernatural events, beginning with <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H0452G' clickHandler>Elijah</jLink>'s journey from <jLink data-type='L' data-strong='H1537G' clickHandler>Gilgal</jLink> to <jLink data-type='L' data-strong='H1008G' clickHandler>Bethel</jLink>, then to <jLink data-type='L' data-strong='H3405G' clickHandler>Jericho</jLink>, and finally across the <jLink data-type='L' data-strong='H3383' clickHandler>Jordan</jLink> River, where he struck the waters with his rolled-up cloak, causing them to divide. Throughout this final journey, <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H0477' clickHandler>Elisha</jLink> demonstrated unwavering loyalty by refusing to leave <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H0452G' clickHandler>Elijah</jLink>'s side despite repeated attempts to dissuade him, declaring at each location, "As surely as the Lord lives and as you live, I will not leave you". When <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H0452G' clickHandler>Elijah</jLink> asked what he could do for <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H0477' clickHandler>Elisha</jLink> before his departure, <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H0477' clickHandler>Elisha</jLink> boldly requested "a double portion of your spirit," using the language of inheritance rights where the firstborn son received twice the portion of other heirs. <jPara></jPara> The dramatic climax occurred when a chariot of fire and horses of fire separated the two prophets, and <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H0452G' clickHandler>Elijah</jLink> was taken up to heaven in a whirlwind, leaving <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H0477' clickHandler>Elisha</jLink> to witness this unprecedented event and cry out, "My father! My father! The chariots and horsemen of Israel!". <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H0477' clickHandler>Elisha</jLink> immediately began his ministry by taking up <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H0452G' clickHandler>Elijah</jLink>'s fallen cloak, striking the <jLink data-type='L' data-strong='H3383' clickHandler>Jordan</jLink> River with it, and seeing the waters divide as they had for his predecessor, confirming the transfer of prophetic authority. His first miracle was purifying the bad water at <jLink data-type='L' data-strong='H3405G' clickHandler>Jericho</jLink>, followed by the incident where bears attacked forty-two youths who had mocked his baldness, establishing his authority as <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H0452G' clickHandler>Elijah</jLink>'s legitimate successor. King <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H3141H' clickHandler>Joram</jLink>'s accession to Israel's throne represented a slight improvement over his brother <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H0274G' clickHandler>Ahaziah</jLink> and father <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H0256G' clickHandler>Ahab</jLink>, as he removed the sacred stone of Baal that <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H0256G' clickHandler>Ahab</jLink> had made, though he continued to maintain <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H3379G' clickHandler>Jeroboam</jLink>'s golden calf worship and did not completely abandon the sins that had characterized the northern kingdom since its inception.
events: 852 BC: <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H0452G' clickHandler>Elijah</jLink> journeys with <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H0477' clickHandler>Elisha</jLink> from <jLink data-type='L' data-strong='H1537G' clickHandler>Gilgal</jLink> to <jLink data-type='L' data-strong='H1008G' clickHandler>Bethel</jLink>, <jLink data-type='L' data-strong='H3405G' clickHandler>Jericho</jLink>, and across the <jLink data-type='L' data-strong='H3383' clickHandler>Jordan</jLink>, parting its waters with his cloak.

852 BC: <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H0452G' clickHandler>Elijah</jLink> is taken up to heaven in a whirlwind by a chariot and horses of fire near the <jLink data-type='L' data-strong='H3383' clickHandler>Jordan</jLink>, witnessed by <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H0477' clickHandler>Elisha</jLink>.

852 BC: <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H0477' clickHandler>Elisha</jLink> picks up <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H0452G' clickHandler>Elijah</jLink>’s cloak, parts the <jLink data-type='L' data-strong='H3383' clickHandler>Jordan</jLink>, and is confirmed as prophetic successor.
852 BC: <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H0477' clickHandler>Elisha</jLink> heals <jLink data-type='L' data-strong='H3405G' clickHandler>Jericho</jLink>’s water supply as his first miracle.

852 BC: <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H0477' clickHandler>Elisha</jLink> curses mocking youths at <jLink data-type='L' data-strong='H1008G' clickHandler>Bethel</jLink>, and two bears maul forty-two of them.

ChronologyEntries.article: 851 BC:  King <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H4338' clickHandler>Mesha</jLink> of <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H4124H' clickHandler>Moab</jLink> launched a successful rebellion against <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H3478' clickHandler>Israelite</jLink> domination, leading to a dramatic military campaign by the allied forces of Israel, Judah, and <jLink data-type='L' data-strong='H0123G' clickHandler>Edom</jLink> (2Ki.3:14-27). <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H4124H' clickHandler>Moab</jLink> had been paying substantial tribute to Israel since the days of <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H1732' clickHandler>David</jLink>, providing 100,000 lambs and the wool of 100,000 rams annually, but following <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H0256G' clickHandler>Ahab</jLink>'s death, King <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H4338' clickHandler>Mesha</jLink> saw an opportunity to regain independence and ceased these payments. The rebellion prompted King <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H3141H' clickHandler>Joram</jLink> of Israel to seek military support from King <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H3092I' clickHandler>Jehoshaphat</jLink> of Judah and the king of <jLink data-type='L' data-strong='H0123G' clickHandler>Edom</jLink>, forming a coalition that approached <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H4124H' clickHandler>Moab</jLink> through the Desert of <jLink data-type='L' data-strong='H0123G' clickHandler>Edom</jLink> to launch a surprise attack from the south. The campaign initially appeared successful, with the allied forces devastating <jLink data-type='L' data-strong='H4124G' clickHandler>Moabite</jLink> cities, stopping up water sources, cutting down trees, and covering fertile land with stones. <jPara></jPara> The climax of the conflict came when the <jLink data-type='L' data-strong='H4124G' clickHandler>Moabite</jLink> forces were driven back to their final stronghold at Kir-hareseth, where King <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H4338' clickHandler>Mesha</jLink>, facing inevitable defeat, performed a desperate and shocking act by sacrificing his firstborn son and heir on the city wall as a burnt offering. This human sacrifice created "great indignation against Israel," leading to the immediate withdrawal of the coalition forces and effectively ending the campaign without achieving complete victory. The <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H4338' clickHandler>Mesha</jLink> Stele, discovered in the 19th century, provides archaeological corroboration of this rebellion from the <jLink data-type='L' data-strong='H4124G' clickHandler>Moabite</jLink> perspective, with King <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H4338' clickHandler>Mesha</jLink> crediting his god <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H3645' clickHandler>Chemosh</jLink> for delivering <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H4124H' clickHandler>Moab</jLink> from <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H3478' clickHandler>Israelite</jLink> oppression and describing his restoration of <jLink data-type='L' data-strong='H4124G' clickHandler>Moabite</jLink> cities and territory. This monument represents one of the few extra-biblical sources that directly parallels biblical historical narratives, confirming both the reality of <jLink data-type='L' data-strong='H4124G' clickHandler>Moabite</jLink> subjugation to Israel and the success of <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H4338' clickHandler>Mesha</jLink>'s independence movement, which permanently ended <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H3478' clickHandler>Israelite</jLink> control over <jLink data-type='L' data-strong='H4124G' clickHandler>Moabite</jLink> territory east of the Dead Sea.
events: 851 BC: <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H4338' clickHandler>Mesha</jLink> king of <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H4124H' clickHandler>Moab</jLink> rebels, ceasing tribute and seeking independence from Israel.

851 BC: <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H3141H' clickHandler>Joram</jLink> of Israel, <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H3092I' clickHandler>Jehoshaphat</jLink> of Judah, and the king of <jLink data-type='L' data-strong='H0123G' clickHandler>Edom</jLink> ally to suppress <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H4124H' clickHandler>Moab</jLink>’s rebellion.

851 BC: The coalition invades <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H4124H' clickHandler>Moab</jLink> through <jLink data-type='L' data-strong='H0123G' clickHandler>Edom</jLink>, launching a southern attack.
851 BC: The allied armies devastate <jLink data-type='L' data-strong='H4124G' clickHandler>Moabite</jLink> cities, water sources, trees, and farmland.
851 BC: <jLink data-type='L' data-strong='H4124G' clickHandler>Moabites</jLink> are driven back to Kir-hareseth, their final stronghold.

ChronologyEntries.desc: <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H0477' clickHandler>Elisha</jLink> miracles; <jLink data-type='L' data-strong='H8111' clickHandler>Samaria</jLink> besieged.
ChronologyEntries.article: 849 BC:  The prophet <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H0477' clickHandler>Elisha</jLink> performed a remarkable series of miracles that demonstrated divine provision and power during a time of crisis in the northern Kingdom of Israel. These miracles (2Ki.4:1-7:20) included multiplying oil for a widow to save her from debt slavery, raising the son of the <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H8126' clickHandler>Shunammite</jLink> woman from the dead, purifying a pot of poisoned stew to make it safe for consumption, feeding one hundred men with a small amount of food, and healing <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H5283I' clickHandler>Naaman</jLink>, the <jLink data-type='L' data-strong='H0123G' clickHandler>Aramean</jLink> military commander, from leprosy. These acts of divine intervention particularly benefited marginalized individuals—widows, foreigners, and the poor—reinforcing <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H0477' clickHandler>Elisha</jLink>'s role as a defender of the oppressed and demonstrating the continuity of prophetic authority following his predecessor <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H0452G' clickHandler>Elijah</jLink>. <jPara></jPara> During this same period, the city of <jLink data-type='L' data-strong='H8111' clickHandler>Samaria</jLink>, capital of Israel, endured a devastating siege by <jLink data-type='L' data-strong='H0123G' clickHandler>Aramean</jLink> forces that created severe famine conditions within the city. The siege was miraculously resolved when the <jLink data-type='L' data-strong='H0123G' clickHandler>Aramean</jLink> army inexplicably fled their camp after hearing what they believed to be the sound of a great approaching army, abandoning their supplies and provisions. The sudden departure allowed the starving inhabitants of <jLink data-type='L' data-strong='H8111' clickHandler>Samaria</jLink> to plunder the abandoned camp, immediately alleviating the famine and demonstrating divine intervention through psychological warfare. This deliverance reinforced <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H0477' clickHandler>Elisha</jLink>'s prophetic authority and illustrated the biblical theme that God's sovereignty extends over Israel's enemies, providing hope even in seemingly hopeless circumstances.
events: 849 BC: <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H0477' clickHandler>Elisha</jLink> multiplies oil for a widow in Israel to save her and her sons from debt slavery.

849 BC: <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H0477' clickHandler>Elisha</jLink> raises the <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H8126' clickHandler>Shunammite</jLink> woman’s son from the dead in <jLink data-type='L' data-strong='H7766' clickHandler>Shunem</jLink>.
849 BC: <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H0477' clickHandler>Elisha</jLink> purifies poisoned stew at <jLink data-type='L' data-strong='H1537G' clickHandler>Gilgal</jLink> for the prophets.
849 BC: <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H0477' clickHandler>Elisha</jLink> feeds one hundred men with twenty loaves and there is food left over.

849 BC: <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H0477' clickHandler>Elisha</jLink> heals <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H5283I' clickHandler>Naaman</jLink>, <jLink data-type='L' data-strong='H0123G' clickHandler>Aramean</jLink> commander, of leprosy after <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H5283I' clickHandler>Naaman</jLink> bathes in the <jLink data-type='L' data-strong='H3383' clickHandler>Jordan</jLink>.

ChronologyEntries.article: 848 BC:  In 848 BC, retired king <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H3092I' clickHandler>Jehoshaphat</jLink> of Judah died, ending a twenty-five-year reign that had been characterized by comprehensive religious reforms, military success, and general prosperity for the southern kingdom. <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H3092I' clickHandler>Jehoshaphat</jLink>'s death marked the conclusion of one of Judah's most reformist periods, during which he had systematically removed idolatrous practices, established an innovative educational program to teach the Law throughout his territory, and strengthened Judah's defensive capabilities through fortification projects and military organization. His son <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H3088G' clickHandler>Jehoram</jLink> continued on the throne as full King of Judah, having previously served as co-regent, but his accession marked a dramatic shift in the kingdom's spiritual and political direction. <jPara></jPara> <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H3088G' clickHandler>Jehoram</jLink>'s reign represented a significant departure from his father's righteous rule, primarily due to his marriage alliance with <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H6271G' clickHandler>Athaliah</jLink>, daughter of King <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H0256G' clickHandler>Ahab</jLink> and Queen <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H0348' clickHandler>Jezebel</jLink> of Israel. Upon securing his position, <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H3088G' clickHandler>Jehoram</jLink> murdered his brothers to eliminate potential rivals for the throne, demonstrating the moral corruption that would characterize his rule. Through <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H6271G' clickHandler>Athaliah</jLink>'s influence, idolatrous practices and the religious policies of the northern kingdom's house of <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H0256G' clickHandler>Ahab</jLink> were introduced into Judah, leading the southern kingdom away from the worship of <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H3068G' clickHandler>Yahweh</jLink> and toward the syncretistic practices that had plagued Israel. This political alliance, while potentially advantageous diplomatically, proved spiritually disastrous for Judah, entangling the Davidic royal house in the apostasy that would eventually bring divine judgment upon both kingdoms.
events: 848 BC: King <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H3092I' clickHandler>Jehoshaphat</jLink> of Judah dies in <jLink data-type='L' data-strong='H3389' clickHandler>Jerusalem</jLink> after a twenty-five-year reign.
848 BC: <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H3088G' clickHandler>Jehoram</jLink>, son of <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H3092I' clickHandler>Jehoshaphat</jLink>, becomes sole king of Judah.
848 BC: <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H3088G' clickHandler>Jehoram</jLink> kills his brothers to secure his rule over Judah.

ChronologyEntries.desc: <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H8126' clickHandler>Shunammite</jLink> widow's land restored
ChronologyEntries.article: 846 BC:  The <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H8126' clickHandler>Shunammite</jLink> woman who had previously shown hospitality to the prophet <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H0477' clickHandler>Elisha</jLink> returned to Israel after a seven-year sojourn in <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H6430H' clickHandler>Philistine</jLink> territory, undertaken at <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H0477' clickHandler>Elisha</jLink>'s warning of an impending famine. Upon her return, she discovered that her property had been appropriated during her absence and appealed directly to the king of Israel for restoration of her land and possessions. The timing of her appeal proved providential, as she arrived at the royal court precisely when <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H1522' clickHandler>Gehazi</jLink>, <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H0477' clickHandler>Elisha</jLink>'s servant, was recounting to the king the various miracles that <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H0477' clickHandler>Elisha</jLink> had performed, including the resurrection of her son. When <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H1522' clickHandler>Gehazi</jLink> identified her as the very woman whose son had been raised from the dead, the king was immediately convinced of her legitimate claim and ordered the complete restoration of her property. <jPara></jPara> The royal decree went beyond merely returning the <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H8126' clickHandler>Shunammite</jLink> woman's land, as the king commanded that she receive all the income that had been generated from her property during the seven years of her absence. This remarkable example of royal justice demonstrated both the lasting influence of <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H0477' clickHandler>Elisha</jLink>'s prophetic ministry and the principle of divine providence working through human institutions to protect the faithful. The incident illustrates how the prophet's earlier acts of kindness—raising her son from the dead—created a reputation that ultimately secured her material welfare when she faced potential destitution. The story serves as a biblical example of how faithfulness to God's servants and obedience to prophetic warnings can result in unexpected divine provision and protection, even through secular governmental channels.
events: 846 BC: The <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H8126' clickHandler>Shunammite</jLink> woman returns to Israel from <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H6430H' clickHandler>Philistine</jLink> territory after seven years, as <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H0477' clickHandler>Elisha</jLink> warned.
846 BC: Upon finding her land taken, the <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H8126' clickHandler>Shunammite</jLink> woman appeals to the king of Israel for restoration.

846 BC: The king of Israel restores the <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H8126' clickHandler>Shunammite</jLink>’s land and its income upon identification by <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H1522' clickHandler>Gehazi</jLink>.

ChronologyEntries.desc: <jChronDurationLink style='color:black'>▼</jChronDurationLink><jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H0274G' clickHandler>Ahaziah</jLink> K of Judah; <jChronDurationLink style='color:blue'>▼</jChronDurationLink><jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H3058H' clickHandler>Jehu</jLink> King of Israel
ChronologyEntries.article: 841 BC:  In 841 BC, the political landscape of the ancient Near East underwent dramatic transformation through a series of violent succession events that reshaped the kingdoms of <jLink data-type='L' data-strong='H0758I' clickHandler>Aram</jLink>, Israel, and Judah. <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H2371' clickHandler>Hazael</jLink> seized control of the <jLink data-type='L' data-strong='H0123G' clickHandler>Aramean</jLink> throne by assassinating King <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H1130H' clickHandler>Ben-Hadad</jLink> II, establishing himself as a formidable adversary who would dominate regional politics for decades. Simultaneously, <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H0274G' clickHandler>Ahaziah</jLink> ascended to the throne of Judah following his father <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H3088G' clickHandler>Jehoram</jLink>'s death, but his reign proved extremely brief as he became an unfortunate casualty of the violent revolution that erupted in the northern kingdom. The year's most significant political upheaval occurred when <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H3058H' clickHandler>Jehu</jLink>, a military commander in Israel, orchestrated a comprehensive coup that eliminated both King <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H3141H' clickHandler>Joram</jLink> of Israel and the visiting King <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H0274G' clickHandler>Ahaziah</jLink> of Judah, fulfilling earlier prophetic pronouncements against the house of <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H0256G' clickHandler>Ahab</jLink>. <jPara></jPara> <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H3058H' clickHandler>Jehu</jLink>'s revolution extended far beyond mere regime change, as he conducted a systematic and bloody purge designed to completely eradicate <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H0256G' clickHandler>Ahab</jLink>'s dynasty and its religious innovations.
