This violent campaign included the dramatic execution of Queen <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H0348' clickHandler>Jezebel</jLink>, who was thrown from a window and subsequently trampled by horses and devoured by dogs, fulfilling <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H0452G' clickHandler>Elijah</jLink>'s earlier prophecy, as well as the massacre of all seventy of <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H0256G' clickHandler>Ahab</jLink>'s sons and the elimination of <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H0256G' clickHandler>Ahab</jLink>'s officials, close friends, and priests. <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H3058H' clickHandler>Jehu</jLink>'s actions effectively ended <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H6018G' clickHandler>Omri</jLink>’s dynasty that had ruled Israel for nearly four decades, while simultaneously destabilizing Judah's royal succession and creating a power vacuum that would have lasting consequences. These interconnected political transitions of 841 BC represented a pivotal moment in the divided monarchy period, fundamentally altering the balance of power in the Levant and setting the stage for increased <jLink data-type='L' data-strong='H0123G' clickHandler>Aramean</jLink> pressure on both <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H3478' clickHandler>Israelite</jLink> kingdoms under <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H2371' clickHandler>Hazael</jLink>'s aggressive leadership.
events: 841 BC: <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H2371' clickHandler>Hazael</jLink> assassinates King <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H1130H' clickHandler>Ben-Hadad</jLink> in <jLink data-type='L' data-strong='H1834' clickHandler>Damascus</jLink> and becomes king of <jLink data-type='L' data-strong='H0758I' clickHandler>Aram</jLink>.
841 BC: <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H3088G' clickHandler>Jehoram</jLink>, king of Judah, dies, ending his reign.
841 BC: <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H0274G' clickHandler>Ahaziah</jLink>, son of <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H3088G' clickHandler>Jehoram</jLink>, becomes king of Judah.

841 BC: <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H3058H' clickHandler>Jehu</jLink>, anointed by a prophet sent by <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H0477' clickHandler>Elisha</jLink>, leads a coup against the house of <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H0256G' clickHandler>Ahab</jLink> in Israel.

841 BC: <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H3058H' clickHandler>Jehu</jLink> kills King <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H3141H' clickHandler>Joram</jLink> of Israel at <jLink data-type='L' data-strong='H3157G' clickHandler>Jezreel</jLink>, fulfilling prophecy.

ChronologyEntries.desc: <jChronDurationLink style='color:black'>▼</jChronDurationLink><jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H6271G' clickHandler>Athaliah</jLink> Queen of Judah
ChronologyEntries.article: 840 BC:  In 840 BC, <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H6271G' clickHandler>Athaliah</jLink>, daughter of the notorious King <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H0256G' clickHandler>Ahab</jLink> and Queen <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H0348' clickHandler>Jezebel</jLink> of Israel, seized control of the southern Kingdom of Judah following the death of her son King <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H0274G' clickHandler>Ahaziah</jLink>, who had been killed during <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H3058H' clickHandler>Jehu</jLink>'s violent revolution in Israel the previous year. Upon learning of <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H0274G' clickHandler>Ahaziah</jLink>'s death, <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H6271G' clickHandler>Athaliah</jLink> immediately moved to eliminate all potential rivals by ordering the systematic execution of the entire royal family, including her own grandchildren, in an unprecedented act of dynastic murder designed to secure her position as Judah's first and only reigning queen. However, her genocidal plan was thwarted when <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H3089' clickHandler>Jehosheba</jLink>, <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H0274G' clickHandler>Ahaziah</jLink>'s sister and wife of the high priest <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H3077H' clickHandler>Jehoiada</jLink>, courageously rescued the infant prince <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H3101I' clickHandler>Joash</jLink> (also called <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H3101J' clickHandler>Jehoash</jLink>) and secretly hid him in the Temple complex for six years. <jPara></jPara> <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H6271G' clickHandler>Athaliah</jLink>'s six-year reign represented a dark period for Judah, as she promoted the Baal worship that her parents had established in Israel, constructing temples and altars dedicated to <jLink data-type='L' data-strong='G5403' clickHandler>Phoenician</jLink> deities while systematically dismantling traditional Yahwistic worship practices. Her rule came to a dramatic end in the seventh year when <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H3077H' clickHandler>Jehoiada</jLink> the priest orchestrated a carefully planned coup, revealing the hidden prince <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H3101I' clickHandler>Joash</jLink> to the temple guards and the people, crowning him king in a public ceremony, and having <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H6271G' clickHandler>Athaliah</jLink> executed outside the Temple precincts. This restoration of the Davidic line was accompanied by comprehensive religious reforms that included the destruction of Baal temples, the execution of <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H4977G' clickHandler>Mattan</jLink> the priest of Baal, and the renewal of the covenant between the people and God, effectively ending the brief but devastating period of foreign religious influence that had threatened to permanently alter Judah's spiritual identity.
events: 840 BC: <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H6271G' clickHandler>Athaliah</jLink>, daughter of <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H0256G' clickHandler>Ahab</jLink> and <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H0348' clickHandler>Jezebel</jLink>, seizes Judah’s throne after <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H0274G' clickHandler>Ahaziah</jLink>’s death and becomes queen.
840 BC: <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H6271G' clickHandler>Athaliah</jLink> orders the execution of the royal family, including her grandchildren.

840 BC: <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H3089' clickHandler>Jehosheba</jLink> rescues infant <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H3101I' clickHandler>Joash</jLink> and hides him in the Temple for six years.

840 BC: <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H6271G' clickHandler>Athaliah</jLink> promotes Baal worship and builds temples and altars for <jLink data-type='L' data-strong='G5403' clickHandler>Phoenician</jLink> deities in Judah.

840 BC: <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H3077H' clickHandler>Jehoiada</jLink> the priest leads a revolt in the seventh year, reveals <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H3101I' clickHandler>Joash</jLink>, and crowns him king.

ChronologyEntries.desc: <jChronDurationLink style='color:black'>▼</jChronDurationLink><jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H3101J' clickHandler>Jehoash</jLink> King of Judah
ChronologyEntries.article: 835 BC:  In 835 BC, seven-year-old <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H3101I' clickHandler>Joash</jLink> (also known as <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H3101J' clickHandler>Jehoash</jLink>) was formally recognized as king of Judah, beginning what would become a forty-year reign under the initial guidance and mentorship of <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H3077H' clickHandler>Jehoiada</jLink> the high priest who had preserved his life and orchestrated his restoration to the throne. The young king's accession was marked by widespread popular support and religious revival (2Ki.11:21-12:21; 2Ch.23:16-24:27), with the people of Judah rejoicing at the restoration of the Davidic dynasty and the end of <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H6271G' clickHandler>Athaliah</jLink>'s oppressive rule. During his early years, <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H3101J' clickHandler>Jehoash</jLink> demonstrated remarkable faithfulness to God under <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H3077H' clickHandler>Jehoiada</jLink>'s wise counsel, implementing comprehensive religious reforms that included the systematic removal of idolatrous practices, the restoration of proper temple worship, and the reestablishment of <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H3878' clickHandler>Levitical</jLink> service according to Mosaic law. <jPara></jPara> The initial phase of <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H3101J' clickHandler>Jehoash</jLink>'s reign was characterized by peace, prosperity, and spiritual renewal, as <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H3077H' clickHandler>Jehoiada</jLink>'s influence ensured that the king followed righteous policies and maintained covenant faithfulness. However, the biblical narrative foreshadows the tragic transformation that would occur later in his reign, following <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H3077H' clickHandler>Jehoiada</jLink>'s death, when <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H3101J' clickHandler>Jehoash</jLink> would abandon the reforms and turn toward idolatry, ultimately leading to his assassination by his own officials. This period of <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H3101J' clickHandler>Jehoash</jLink>'s ascension demonstrates the crucial role that godly advisors play in royal leadership and illustrates how the preservation of a single righteous remnant—in this case, the infant <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H3101I' clickHandler>Joash</jLink>—could restore an entire nation's spiritual direction after a period of apostasy and foreign religious influence.
events: 835 BC: Seven-year-old <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H3101I' clickHandler>Joash</jLink> (<jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H3101J' clickHandler>Jehoash</jLink>) is crowned king of Judah in <jLink data-type='L' data-strong='H3389' clickHandler>Jerusalem</jLink>.
835 BC: <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H3077H' clickHandler>Jehoiada</jLink> the high priest acts as regent and advisor to <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H3101I' clickHandler>Joash</jLink>.

835 BC: <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H3101I' clickHandler>Joash</jLink>, under <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H3077H' clickHandler>Jehoiada</jLink>, implements religious reforms and restores temple worship.
835 BC: The <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H3878' clickHandler>Levitical</jLink> priesthood and temple service are reestablished as prescribed by Mosaic law.
835 BC: The people of Judah rejoice at the restoration of the Davidic dynasty and the end of <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H6271G' clickHandler>Athaliah</jLink>’s rule.

ChronologyEntries.desc: <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H0558G' clickHandler>Amaziah</jLink> of Judah born
ChronologyEntries.article: 821 BC:  In 821 BC, Prince <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H0558G' clickHandler>Amaziah</jLink> was born to King <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H3101J' clickHandler>Jehoash</jLink> of Judah, representing the continuation of the Davidic royal line that had been preserved through the dramatic events surrounding <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H6271G' clickHandler>Athaliah</jLink>'s usurpation and subsequent overthrow. This birth occurred during the period when <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H3101J' clickHandler>Jehoash</jLink> was still under the positive influence of <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H3077H' clickHandler>Jehoiada</jLink> the high priest, ensuring that the young prince would be raised in an environment of covenant faithfulness and proper worship practices (2Ch.24:2-3; 25:1). <jPara></jPara> <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H0558G' clickHandler>Amaziah</jLink>'s birth provided security for the Davidic succession and represented hope for Judah's future stability, particularly given the recent trauma of <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H6271G' clickHandler>Athaliah</jLink>'s attempt to exterminate the entire royal family just nineteen years earlier.
events: 821 BC: Prince <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H0558G' clickHandler>Amaziah</jLink> is born to King <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H3101J' clickHandler>Jehoash</jLink> (<jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H3101I' clickHandler>Joash</jLink>) of Judah, ensuring Davidic succession.

821 BC: King <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H3101J' clickHandler>Jehoash</jLink> follows the Lord under the guidance of <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H3077H' clickHandler>Jehoiada</jLink> the high priest.

ChronologyEntries.desc: <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H3101J' clickHandler>Jehoash</jLink> repairs the Temple
ChronologyEntries.article: 815 BC:  In 815 BC, <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H3101J' clickHandler>Jehoash</jLink> (also known as <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H3101I' clickHandler>Joash</jLink>), King of Judah, undertook comprehensive repairs of the <jLink data-type='L' data-strong='H3389' clickHandler>Jerusalem</jLink> Temple (2Ki.12:4-16; 2Ch.24:1-14). . The Temple had suffered from prolonged neglect and damage, necessitating this major restoration project. <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H3101J' clickHandler>Jehoash</jLink> organized a systematic collection of funds from the people, including regular offerings and dedicated money, to finance the repairs. He appointed priests and <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H3878' clickHandler>Levites</jLink> to oversee both the collection and management of these funds, ensuring that skilled workers were hired and the restoration work was properly supervised. The biblical accounts emphasize <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H3101J' clickHandler>Jehoash</jLink>'s commitment to using the funds honestly and efficiently for their intended purpose, resulting in the restoration of the Temple's structure and sacred vessels. <jPara></jPara>  This Temple restoration occurred during a period of relative political stability in Judah, following the violent upheavals that had marked <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H3101J' clickHandler>Jehoash</jLink>'s accession to the throne as a child after his grandmother <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H6271G' clickHandler>Athaliah</jLink>'s assassination. His early reign was heavily influenced by the high priest <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H3077H' clickHandler>Jehoiada</jLink>, who acted as regent and advisor, and this Temple project represented a broader effort to reinforce the centrality of <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H3068G' clickHandler>Yahweh</jLink> worship in Judah and restore religious orthodoxy. While the biblical narrative provides detailed descriptions of these events, no direct archaeological evidence has been discovered to corroborate the specific Temple repairs under <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H3101J' clickHandler>Jehoash</jLink>, largely due to the lack of systematic excavation on the Temple Mount itself. The repairs successfully revived the Temple's central role in Judah's religious life, though some local high places continued to be used for worship alongside the restored Temple.
events: 815 BC: King <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H3101J' clickHandler>Jehoash</jLink> orders major repairs of the <jLink data-type='L' data-strong='H3389' clickHandler>Jerusalem</jLink> Temple.
815 BC: <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H3101J' clickHandler>Jehoash</jLink> organizes systematic collection of funds from Judah for the temple restoration.
815 BC: Priests and <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H3878' clickHandler>Levites</jLink> are appointed to manage temple repair funds.
815 BC: Skilled workers are hired to restore the Temple and its sacred vessels.
815 BC: The <jLink data-type='L' data-strong='H3389' clickHandler>Jerusalem</jLink> Temple is successfully repaired and restored to central religious life.

ChronologyEntries.desc: <jChronDurationLink style='color:blue'>▼</jChronDurationLink><jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H3059G' clickHandler>Jehoahaz</jLink> King of Israel
ChronologyEntries.article: 814 BC:  In 814 BC, <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H3059G' clickHandler>Jehoahaz</jLink> son of <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H3058H' clickHandler>Jehu</jLink> ascended to the throne of Israel, beginning a seventeen-year reign marked by severe military and political oppression under <jLink data-type='L' data-strong='H0123G' clickHandler>Aramean</jLink> domination (2Ki.13:1-9). The <jLink data-type='L' data-strong='H0123G' clickHandler>Aramean</jLink> kingdom, likely under the aggressive leadership of <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H2371' clickHandler>Hazael</jLink> and later his son <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H1130I' clickHandler>Ben-Hadad</jLink> III, systematically devastated Israel's military capabilities, reducing the once-formidable <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H3478' clickHandler>Israelite</jLink> army to a mere fifty horsemen, ten chariots, and ten thousand foot soldiers—a catastrophic decline that left the northern kingdom virtually defenseless. This oppression was interpreted by the biblical writers as divine judgment for Israel's continued apostasy, particularly the persistence of idolatrous practices established during <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H3379G' clickHandler>Jeroboam</jLink>'s reign and perpetuated through successive dynasties. <jPara></jPara> Despite the severity of Israel's circumstances, <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H3059G' clickHandler>Jehoahaz</jLink>'s appeal to the Lord resulted in divine intervention, as God provided an unnamed deliverer who enabled Israel to escape from <jLink data-type='L' data-strong='H0123G' clickHandler>Aramean</jLink> control, at least temporarily. This pattern of oppression followed by deliverance upon repentance exemplified the cyclical nature of Israel's relationship with God during the divided monarchy period. <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H3059G' clickHandler>Jehoahaz</jLink>'s reign thus represented both the consequences of sustained disobedience and the possibility of divine mercy when the nation's leadership genuinely sought the Lord's favor, though the fundamental religious problems that had brought about the crisis remained unresolved throughout his rule.
events: 814 BC: <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H3059G' clickHandler>Jehoahaz</jLink>, son of <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H3058H' clickHandler>Jehu</jLink>, becomes king of Israel in <jLink data-type='L' data-strong='H8111' clickHandler>Samaria</jLink>.

814 BC: <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H2371' clickHandler>Hazael</jLink> and later <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H1130I' clickHandler>Ben-Hadad</jLink> of <jLink data-type='L' data-strong='H0758I' clickHandler>Aram</jLink> oppress Israel, devastating its army.
814 BC: <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H3059G' clickHandler>Jehoahaz</jLink> appeals to the Lord amid <jLink data-type='L' data-strong='H0123G' clickHandler>Aramean</jLink> oppression.

814 BC: God provides a deliverer in response to <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H3059G' clickHandler>Jehoahaz</jLink>’s prayer, freeing Israel temporarily from <jLink data-type='L' data-strong='H0758I' clickHandler>Aram</jLink>.

ChronologyEntries.desc: <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H2148w' clickHandler>Zechariah</jLink> the priest killed
ChronologyEntries.article: 799 BC:  In 799 BC, King <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H3101I' clickHandler>Joash</jLink> of Judah ordered the execution of <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H2148w' clickHandler>Zechariah</jLink> son of <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H3077H' clickHandler>Jehoiada</jLink> the priest, an act of shocking ingratitude and spiritual betrayal (2Ch.24:17-22). <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H2148w' clickHandler>Zechariah</jLink>, following in his father's prophetic tradition, had confronted <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H3101I' clickHandler>Joash</jLink> and the people of Judah for abandoning the Lord and returning to idolatrous practices after <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H3077H' clickHandler>Jehoiada</jLink>'s death. This confrontation came during a period when <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H3101I' clickHandler>Joash</jLink> had dramatically reversed the religious reforms that had characterized his early reign under <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H3077H' clickHandler>Jehoiada</jLink>'s guidance, allowing the reintroduction of <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H0842' clickHandler>Asherah</jLink> worship and other pagan practices that threatened Judah's covenant relationship with God. <jPara></jPara> The execution was particularly heinous because it was carried out in the temple courtyard by stoning, violating the sanctity of the sacred space, and represented a profound betrayal of the loyalty and kindness that <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H3077H' clickHandler>Jehoiada</jLink> had shown to <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H3101I' clickHandler>Joash</jLink> throughout his life. <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H3077H' clickHandler>Jehoiada</jLink> had not only saved <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H3101I' clickHandler>Joash</jLink>'s life as an infant during <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H6271G' clickHandler>Athaliah</jLink>'s murderous purge but had also served as his mentor and spiritual guide, orchestrating the religious reforms that had brought blessing and prosperity to Judah. <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H2148w' clickHandler>Zechariah</jLink>'s final words, "May the Lord see this and call you to account," proved prophetic, as <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H3101I' clickHandler>Joash</jLink>'s reign subsequently deteriorated through military defeat and internal conspiracy, ultimately ending in his assassination by his own officials who were appalled by his moral failures.
events: 799 BC: King <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H3101I' clickHandler>Joash</jLink> orders the stoning of <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H2148w' clickHandler>Zechariah</jLink> son of <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H3077H' clickHandler>Jehoiada</jLink> in the temple courtyard.

799 BC: Under <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H3101I' clickHandler>Joash</jLink>, Judah abandons reforms and returns to idolatry after <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H3077H' clickHandler>Jehoiada</jLink>’s death.
799 BC: <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H2148w' clickHandler>Zechariah</jLink>’s last words, "May the Lord see this and call you to account," are spoken as he is killed.

ChronologyEntries.desc: <jChronDurationLink style='color:blue'>▼</jChronDurationLink><jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H3101J' clickHandler>Jehoash</jLink> King of Israel; <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H0477' clickHandler>Elisha</jLink> dies.
ChronologyEntries.article: 798 BC:  In 798 BC, the prophet <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H0477' clickHandler>Elisha</jLink> died, ending an extraordinary ministry that had spanned approximately fifty years and included numerous miracles, political interventions, and guidance for multiple kings of Israel (2Ki.13:10-25). Even in death, <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H0477' clickHandler>Elisha</jLink>'s prophetic power remained evident when a dead man was accidentally thrown into the prophet's tomb and was immediately restored to life upon contact with <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H0477' clickHandler>Elisha</jLink>'s bones, demonstrating the enduring divine authority that had characterized his entire ministry. Before his death, <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H0477' clickHandler>Elisha</jLink> had provided crucial prophetic guidance to the newly-ascended King <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H3101J' clickHandler>Jehoash</jLink> of Israel, instructing him to shoot an arrow eastward as a symbol of victory over <jLink data-type='L' data-strong='H0758I' clickHandler>Aram</jLink> and then to strike the ground with arrows, with the number of strikes determining the extent of his future military success. <jPara></jPara> <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H3101J' clickHandler>Jehoash</jLink>'s reign began with the implementation of <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H0477' clickHandler>Elisha</jLink>'s final prophecy, as the new king achieved exactly three victories over the <jLink data-type='L' data-strong='H0123G' clickHandler>Arameans</jLink>, recovering cities that had been lost during his father <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H3059G' clickHandler>Jehoahaz</jLink>'s troubled rule when Israel had suffered under severe <jLink data-type='L' data-strong='H0123G' clickHandler>Aramean</jLink> oppression. These military successes represented a significant improvement in Israel's fortunes, allowing the northern kingdom to regain territorial control and reduce the crushing tribute payments that had characterized the previous decade. However, <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H0477' clickHandler>Elisha</jLink>'s earlier observation that <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H3101J' clickHandler>Jehoash</jLink> had struck the ground only three times rather than continuing more persistently proved accurate, as the king's victories, while significant, fell short of completely eliminating the <jLink data-type='L' data-strong='H0123G' clickHandler>Aramean</jLink> threat that would continue to plague Israel throughout the eighth century BC.
events: 798 BC: <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H0477' clickHandler>Elisha</jLink> dies in Israel, ending his fifty-year prophetic ministry.
798 BC: A dead man is revived after touching <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H0477' clickHandler>Elisha</jLink>’s bones in his tomb.

798 BC: <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H3101J' clickHandler>Jehoash</jLink> (<jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H3101I' clickHandler>Joash</jLink>) becomes king of Israel in <jLink data-type='L' data-strong='H8111' clickHandler>Samaria</jLink> after <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H3059G' clickHandler>Jehoahaz</jLink>.

798 BC: <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H0477' clickHandler>Elisha</jLink>’s final prophecy to <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H3101J' clickHandler>Jehoash</jLink> predicts victories over <jLink data-type='L' data-strong='H0758I' clickHandler>Aram</jLink> symbolized by shooting and striking arrows.

798 BC: <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H3101J' clickHandler>Jehoash</jLink> wins three battles against <jLink data-type='L' data-strong='H0758I' clickHandler>Aram</jLink>, regaining lost <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H3478' clickHandler>Israelite</jLink> cities.

ChronologyEntries.desc: <jChronDurationLink style='color:black'>▼</jChronDurationLink><jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H0558G' clickHandler>Amaziah</jLink> King of Judah
ChronologyEntries.article: 796 BC:  In 796 BC, <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H0558G' clickHandler>Amaziah</jLink> son of <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H3101I' clickHandler>Joash</jLink> became king of Judah at age twenty-five, initiating a twenty-nine-year reign that began with faithfulness to the Lord but ultimately ended in military defeat and political disaster (2Ki.14:1-22; 2Ch.25:1-28). Early in his reign, <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H0558G' clickHandler>Amaziah</jLink> demonstrated both justice and religious commitment by executing his father's assassins while sparing their children according to Mosaic law, and by achieving a significant military victory over <jLink data-type='L' data-strong='H0123G' clickHandler>Edom</jLink> in the Valley of Salt, where he killed ten thousand <jLink data-type='L' data-strong='H0123G' clickHandler>Edomites</jLink> and captured the city of <jLink data-type='L' data-strong='H5554' clickHandler>Sela</jLink>. This victory restored <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H3063G' clickHandler>Judean</jLink> control over important trade routes and demonstrated that the Davidic monarchy could still achieve military success when operating under divine blessing. <jPara></jPara> However, <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H0558G' clickHandler>Amaziah</jLink>'s initial faithfulness gave way to spiritual compromise and political miscalculation when he brought <jLink data-type='L' data-strong='H0123G' clickHandler>Edomite</jLink> idols back to <jLink data-type='L' data-strong='H3389' clickHandler>Jerusalem</jLink> and began worshipping them, provoking divine anger and prophetic rebuke. His subsequent challenge to <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H3101J' clickHandler>Jehoash</jLink> king of Israel resulted in a catastrophic defeat at <jLink data-type='L' data-strong='H1053G' clickHandler>Beth-shemesh</jLink>, where <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H0558G' clickHandler>Amaziah</jLink> was captured and forced to witness the partial destruction of <jLink data-type='L' data-strong='H3389' clickHandler>Jerusalem</jLink>'s walls and the plundering of the temple and royal treasuries. This humiliation marked the beginning of <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H0558G' clickHandler>Amaziah</jLink>'s downfall, as his later turn away from following the Lord led to internal opposition and ultimately his assassination by conspirators, illustrating the biblical principle that initial faithfulness without perseverance leads to divine judgment and political collapse.
events: 796 BC: <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H0558G' clickHandler>Amaziah</jLink>, son of <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H3101I' clickHandler>Joash</jLink>, becomes king of Judah at twenty-five.

796 BC: <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H0558G' clickHandler>Amaziah</jLink> executes his father <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H3101I' clickHandler>Joash</jLink>’s assassins but spares their children.

796 BC: <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H0558G' clickHandler>Amaziah</jLink> defeats <jLink data-type='L' data-strong='H0123G' clickHandler>Edom</jLink> in the Valley of Salt, killing ten thousand and capturing <jLink data-type='L' data-strong='H5554' clickHandler>Sela</jLink>.

796 BC: <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H0558G' clickHandler>Amaziah</jLink> brings <jLink data-type='L' data-strong='H0123G' clickHandler>Edomite</jLink> idols to <jLink data-type='L' data-strong='H3389' clickHandler>Jerusalem</jLink> and worships them.
796 BC: A prophet rebukes <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H0558G' clickHandler>Amaziah</jLink> for idolatry and warns of judgment.

ChronologyEntries.desc: <jChronDurationLink style='color:blue'>▼</jChronDurationLink><jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H3379G' clickHandler>Jeroboam</jLink> II reigns in Israel
ChronologyEntries.article: 793 BC:  In 793 BC, <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H3379G' clickHandler>Jeroboam</jLink> II son of <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H3101J' clickHandler>Jehoash</jLink> began his regency over the northern Kingdom of Israel, initiating what would become one of the longest and most prosperous reigns in Israel's history (2Ki.14:23-29). This regency likely commenced during the latter years of his father <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H3101J' clickHandler>Jehoash</jLink>'s rule, following the common ancient Near Eastern practice of establishing co-regencies to ensure smooth governmental transitions and continuity of royal authority. The biblical record indicates that <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H3379G' clickHandler>Jeroboam</jLink> II would eventually reign for forty-one years, making him one of Israel's most enduring monarchs, though the narrative notes that he "did evil in the sight of the Lord" by continuing the idolatrous practices established by <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H3379G' clickHandler>Jeroboam</jLink> I, particularly the golden calf worship at <jLink data-type='L' data-strong='H1008G' clickHandler>Bethel</jLink> and <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H1835H' clickHandler>Dan</jLink>. <jPara></jPara> Despite his spiritual shortcomings, <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H3379G' clickHandler>Jeroboam</jLink> II's regency marked the beginning of a remarkable period of territorial recovery and economic expansion for Israel. The biblical account credits him with restoring Israel's borders "from Lebo-hamath to the Sea of the <jLink data-type='L' data-strong='H6160G' clickHandler>Arabah</jLink>," fulfilling a prophecy delivered by <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H3124' clickHandler>Jonah</jLink> son of <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H0573' clickHandler>Amittai</jLink>, and achieving these victories because "the Lord saw the affliction of Israel" and chose to deliver them through <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H3379G' clickHandler>Jeroboam</jLink> II's military campaigns. This territorial expansion represented Israel's recovery from the devastating losses suffered during previous decades under <jLink data-type='L' data-strong='H0123G' clickHandler>Aramean</jLink> oppression, particularly during the reigns of <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H3059G' clickHandler>Jehoahaz</jLink> and the early years of <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H3101J' clickHandler>Jehoash</jLink>, when Israel's military forces had been reduced to a mere fraction of their former strength.
events: 793 BC: <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H3379G' clickHandler>Jeroboam</jLink> II, son of <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H3101J' clickHandler>Jehoash</jLink>, becomes regent in Israel, starting a long and prosperous reign.
793 BC: <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H3101J' clickHandler>Jehoash</jLink>’s sole rule ends as <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H3379G' clickHandler>Jeroboam</jLink> II becomes regent.

793 BC: Idolatrous worship at <jLink data-type='L' data-strong='H1008G' clickHandler>Bethel</jLink> and <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H1835H' clickHandler>Dan</jLink> continues under <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H3379G' clickHandler>Jeroboam</jLink> II.

ChronologyEntries.desc: <jChronDurationLink style='color:black'>▼</jChronDurationLink><jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H5818G' clickHandler>Uzziah</jLink> reigns in Judah
ChronologyEntries.article: 792 BC:  In 792 BC, <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H5818G' clickHandler>Uzziah</jLink> (also called <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H5818G' clickHandler>Azariah</jLink>) began his regency over the southern Kingdom of Judah at the remarkably young age of sixteen, following the assassination of his father <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H0558G' clickHandler>Amaziah</jLink> (2Ki.15:1-7; 2Ch.26:1-23). The people of Judah chose <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H5818G' clickHandler>Uzziah</jLink> as their king, demonstrating popular support for the Davidic dynasty despite the political instability that had characterized <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H0558G' clickHandler>Amaziah</jLink>'s later years. <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H5818G' clickHandler>Uzziah</jLink>'s early regency was marked by his commitment to seeking God, particularly during the period when he received guidance from <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H2148P' clickHandler>Zechariah</jLink>, who instructed him in the fear of the Lord, and the biblical narrative emphasizes that "as long as he sought the Lord, God gave him success". <jPara></jPara> <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H5818G' clickHandler>Uzziah</jLink>'s regency initiated what would become a fifty-two-year reign characterized by unprecedented military success, territorial expansion, and technological innovation in Judah. The Chronicles account details his victories over the <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H6430H' clickHandler>Philistines</jLink>, <jLink data-type='L' data-strong='H6152B' clickHandler>Arabs</jLink>, and <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H4586G' clickHandler>Meunites</jLink>, his fortification of <jLink data-type='L' data-strong='H3389' clickHandler>Jerusalem</jLink> with towers and defensive systems, and his development of agricultural infrastructure including cisterns and vineyards throughout Judah's territory. However, the biblical record also foreshadows the tragic conclusion of his reign, when pride led him to unlawfully enter the Temple to burn incense—a priestly prerogative—resulting in divine judgment through leprosy that would isolate him for his final years while his son <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H3147H' clickHandler>Jotham</jLink> assumed governmental responsibilities.
events: 792 BC: <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H5818G' clickHandler>Uzziah</jLink> (<jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H5818G' clickHandler>Azariah</jLink>) begins his regency over Judah at sixteen after <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H0558G' clickHandler>Amaziah</jLink>’s assassination.
792 BC: <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H0558G' clickHandler>Amaziah</jLink> is assassinated in <jLink data-type='L' data-strong='H3923' clickHandler>Lachish</jLink>, ending his reign.
792 BC: Judah chooses <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H5818G' clickHandler>Uzziah</jLink> as king, supporting the Davidic line.

792 BC: <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H2148P' clickHandler>Zechariah</jLink> instructs <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H5818G' clickHandler>Uzziah</jLink> in the fear of the Lord during his regency.

ChronologyEntries.desc: <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H3124' clickHandler>Jonah</jLink>’s prophecy to <jLink data-type='L' data-strong='H5210' clickHandler>Nineveh</jLink>
ChronologyEntries.article: 790 BC:  The prophetic ministry associated with the Book of <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H3124' clickHandler>Jonah</jLink> occurred during the stable period of <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H3379G' clickHandler>Jeroboam</jLink> II's reign, representing a unique moment in biblical prophecy when God's concern extended explicitly beyond Israel's borders to include the <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H1471G' clickHandler>Gentile</jLink> nations. The prophet <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H3124' clickHandler>Jonah</jLink> son of <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H0573' clickHandler>Amittai</jLink>, who had prophesied <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H3379G' clickHandler>Jeroboam</jLink> II's territorial victories (2Ki.14:25), received a divine commission to proclaim judgment against <jLink data-type='L' data-strong='H5210' clickHandler>Nineveh</jLink>, the capital city of the <jLink data-type='L' data-strong='H0804G' clickHandler>Assyrian</jLink> Empire. This mission challenged prevailing <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H3478' clickHandler>Israelite</jLink> attitudes toward their enemies and demonstrated the universal scope of divine mercy, as <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H3124' clickHandler>Jonah</jLink>'s reluctant obedience ultimately resulted in the repentance of an entire <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H1471G' clickHandler>Gentile</jLink> city and God's decision to relent from the threatened destruction. <jPara></jPara> The timing of <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H3124' clickHandler>Jonah</jLink>'s ministry during Israel's period of prosperity and territorial expansion under <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H3379G' clickHandler>Jeroboam</jLink> II created a theological tension that underlies the book's message about divine compassion transcending national boundaries. While Israel was experiencing unprecedented success and might have assumed exclusive divine favor, the <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H3124' clickHandler>Jonah</jLink> narrative emphasized God's willingness to extend mercy to Israel's most formidable enemy, the <jLink data-type='L' data-strong='H0804G' clickHandler>Assyrians</jLink>, when they demonstrated genuine repentance. This prophetic account served as both a critique of narrow nationalism and a prefiguring of the universal scope of God's redemptive plan, challenging Israel to understand that divine blessing carried with it responsibilities toward all nations rather than privileges for Israel alone.
events: 790 BC: <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H3124' clickHandler>Jonah</jLink> son of <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H0573' clickHandler>Amittai</jLink> is commissioned by God to proclaim judgment against <jLink data-type='L' data-strong='H5210' clickHandler>Nineveh</jLink>.
790 BC: <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H3124' clickHandler>Jonah</jLink> travels to <jLink data-type='L' data-strong='H5210' clickHandler>Nineveh</jLink> and delivers God’s warning.

790 BC: The people and king of <jLink data-type='L' data-strong='H5210' clickHandler>Nineveh</jLink> repent in response to <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H3124' clickHandler>Jonah</jLink>’s prophecy.
790 BC: God spares <jLink data-type='L' data-strong='H5210' clickHandler>Nineveh</jLink> after witnessing their repentance.

ChronologyEntries.article: 789 BC:  The prophet <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H3100T' clickHandler>Joel</jLink> delivered prophetic oracles that would be preserved as one of the Twelve Minor Prophets. <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H3100T' clickHandler>Joel</jLink>'s ministry occurred during a period of national crisis, as Judah faced devastating locust plagues and drought conditions that the prophet interpreted as divine judgment and a precursor to the "Day of the Lord". The prophet used vivid imagery of natural disasters to illustrate divine warning and emphasize the urgency of repentance, calling upon the people to "return to the Lord your God" with fasting, weeping, and mourning. <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H3100T' clickHandler>Joel</jLink>'s prophecies are notable for their liturgical tone and strong focus on Temple worship and the priesthood, suggesting a context in which the cultic life of Judah remained central to national identity and religious practice. <jPara></jPara> <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H3100T' clickHandler>Joel</jLink>'s ministry occurred during a period of relative political stability under the reigns of <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H5818G' clickHandler>Uzziah</jLink> in Judah and <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H3379G' clickHandler>Jeroboam</jLink> II in Israel. Dates proposed for his ministry range from the ninth to the fourth century BC. <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H3100T' clickHandler>Joel</jLink>'s primary themes of repentance, national lament, and hope for restoration if the people returned to God would prove influential for later prophetic literature. His promise that God would "pour out His Spirit on all flesh" and the imagery of cosmic signs preceding the Day of the Lord would become particularly significant in later biblical and theological development, making <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H3100T' clickHandler>Joel</jLink>'s brief prophetic book a crucial link between earlier covenant warnings and the more extensive prophetic literature that would emerge in the eighth century BC.
events: 789 BC: Prophet <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H3100T' clickHandler>Joel</jLink> delivers oracles to Judah during a crisis of locusts and drought as divine judgment.
789 BC: <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H3100T' clickHandler>Joel</jLink> calls Judah to repentance through fasting, weeping, and mourning.
789 BC: <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H3100T' clickHandler>Joel</jLink> emphasizes the central role of Temple worship and priesthood during the crisis.

ChronologyEntries.article: 782 BC:  In 782 BC, <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H3379G' clickHandler>Jeroboam</jLink> II transitioned from regent to full king of Israel, consolidating his authority and officially beginning his independent reign as the sovereign ruler of the northern kingdom. This transition from co-regency to sole monarchy represented the completion of governmental succession that had begun eleven years earlier, allowing <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H3379G' clickHandler>Jeroboam</jLink> II to exercise complete royal authority without the constraints of shared leadership. The formal assumption of full kingship enabled him to implement comprehensive policies for territorial expansion, economic development, and military reorganization that would characterize his reign as one of Israel's most successful periods in terms of material prosperity and international influence. <jPara></jPara> The establishment of <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H3379G' clickHandler>Jeroboam</jLink> II as full king marked the beginning of Israel's golden age of territorial control and economic prosperity, setting the stage for the prophetic ministries that would address the social and spiritual challenges accompanying this newfound wealth. Archaeological evidence suggests that this period saw significant urban development, increased trade relationships with surrounding nations, and the emergence of a prosperous merchant class, though these developments also created the social inequalities that would later be condemned by prophets such as <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H5986' clickHandler>Amos</jLink> and <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H1954J' clickHandler>Hosea</jLink>. <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H3379G' clickHandler>Jeroboam</jLink> II's successful transition to full kingship thus established the political stability necessary for both Israel's material achievements and the prophetic responses that would define the eighth century BC religious landscape.
events: 782 BC: Retired king <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H3101J' clickHandler>Jehoash</jLink> dies, endin his influence in Israel.
782 BC: <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H3379G' clickHandler>Jeroboam</jLink> II becomes full king of Israel, consolidating his authority.
782 BC: <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H3379G' clickHandler>Jeroboam</jLink> II implements policies for expansion, prosperity, and military reform.

ChronologyEntries.article: 780 BC:  The prophet <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H5986' clickHandler>Amos</jLink> delivered powerful oracles against social injustices and religious corruption in the northern Kingdom of Israel (Amo.1:3; 7:10-17). <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H5986' clickHandler>Amos</jLink>, a shepherd from <jLink data-type='L' data-strong='H8620' clickHandler>Tekoa</jLink> in Judah, was called by God to prophesy against Israel during a period when the northern kingdom was experiencing unprecedented prosperity under King <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H3379G' clickHandler>Jeroboam</jLink> II, yet this economic success was accompanied by severe moral decline, exploitation of the poor, and religious hypocrisy. His prophecies began with oracles against surrounding nations, including <jLink data-type='L' data-strong='H1834' clickHandler>Damascus</jLink> (Amo.1:3), before turning his attention to Israel's own sins, declaring divine judgment against those who "sell the righteous for silver, and the poor for a pair of sandals" and who had corrupted the worship of God with syncretistic practices. <jPara></jPara> The confrontation (Amo.7:10-17) illustrates the resistance <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H5986' clickHandler>Amos</jLink> faced from Israel's religious establishment, particularly from <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H0558J' clickHandler>Amaziah</jLink>, the priest of <jLink data-type='L' data-strong='H1008G' clickHandler>Bethel</jLink>, who attempted to silence the prophet and drive him back to Judah. This opposition highlighted the tension between prophetic authority and institutional religious power, as <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H5986' clickHandler>Amos</jLink> declared that he was "no prophet, nor a prophet's son," but rather a simple herdsman whom the Lord had taken "from following the flock" to deliver His message to Israel. <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H5986' clickHandler>Amos</jLink>'s ministry occurred during the same general period as the reigns of <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H5818G' clickHandler>Uzziah</jLink> in Judah and <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H3379G' clickHandler>Jeroboam</jLink> II in Israel, when both kingdoms enjoyed political stability and economic growth, yet his prophetic message emphasized that material prosperity without social justice and covenant faithfulness would inevitably lead to divine judgment and national disaster.
events: 780 BC: <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H5986' clickHandler>Amos</jLink>, a shepherd from <jLink data-type='L' data-strong='H8620' clickHandler>Tekoa</jLink>, is called to prophesy against Israel during <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H3379G' clickHandler>Jeroboam</jLink> II’s reign.

780 BC: <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H5986' clickHandler>Amos</jLink> delivers oracles against surrounding nations, beginning with <jLink data-type='L' data-strong='H1834' clickHandler>Damascus</jLink>.
780 BC: <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H5986' clickHandler>Amos</jLink> confronts social injustice and religious corruption in Israel.

780 BC: <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H0558J' clickHandler>Amaziah</jLink>, priest of <jLink data-type='L' data-strong='H1008G' clickHandler>Bethel</jLink>, opposes and tries to expel <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H5986' clickHandler>Amos</jLink>.
780 BC: <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H5986' clickHandler>Amos</jLink> asserts his prophetic calling despite not being from the prophetic establishment.

ChronologyEntries.article: 767 BC:  In 767 BC, <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H5818G' clickHandler>Uzziah</jLink> (also called <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H5818G' clickHandler>Azariah</jLink>) transitioned from co-regent to full king of Judah when his father, retired king <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H0558G' clickHandler>Amaziah</jLink>, died. This began his independent rule over the southern kingdom after twenty-five years of shared authority (2Ki.15:1-7; 2Ch.26:1-23). This transition marked the beginning of what would become one of Judah's most prosperous and militarily successful periods, as <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H5818G' clickHandler>Uzziah</jLink> demonstrated remarkable administrative and military capabilities that extended Judah's territorial control and international influence. His reign was characterized by significant military victories over the <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H6430H' clickHandler>Philistines</jLink>, <jLink data-type='L' data-strong='H6152B' clickHandler>Arabs</jLink>, and <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H4586G' clickHandler>Meunites</jLink>, extensive fortification projects in <jLink data-type='L' data-strong='H3389' clickHandler>Jerusalem</jLink> including the construction of defensive towers, and agricultural development throughout Judah's territory, including the digging of cisterns and the cultivation of vineyards. <jPara></jPara> <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H5818G' clickHandler>Uzziah</jLink>'s early success was attributed to his commitment to seeking God, particularly under the guidance of <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H2148P' clickHandler>Zechariah</jLink>, who instructed him in the fear of the Lord, and the biblical narrative emphasizes that "as long as he sought the Lord, God gave him success". However, his fifty-two-year reign would eventually end in tragedy when pride led him to unlawfully enter the Temple to burn incense—a privilege reserved exclusively for the priesthood—resulting in divine judgment through leprosy that would isolate him for his final years while his son <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H3147H' clickHandler>Jotham</jLink> assumed governmental responsibilities. <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H5818G' clickHandler>Uzziah</jLink>'s assumption of full kingship in 767 BC thus initiated a period that would demonstrate both the potential for righteous leadership to bring divine blessing and prosperity, and the dangers of pride and religious presumption that could lead even successful rulers to spiritual downfall.
events: 767 BC: Retired king <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H0558G' clickHandler>Amaziah</jLink> died.

767 BC: <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H5818G' clickHandler>Uzziah</jLink> (<jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H5818G' clickHandler>Azariah</jLink>) becomes full king of Judah after twenty-five years as co-regent.

767 BC: <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H5818G' clickHandler>Uzziah</jLink> begins military victories, fortifies <jLink data-type='L' data-strong='H3389' clickHandler>Jerusalem</jLink>, and develops agriculture.

ChronologyEntries.desc: <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H5986' clickHandler>Amos</jLink>' eclipse of the sun (15th June)
ChronologyEntries.article: 763 BC:  <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H0203' clickHandler>On</jLink> June 15, 763 BC, a total solar eclipse occurred that dramatically darkened the sky during midday, an astronomical event that has been precisely dated by modern calculations and provides one of the most reliable chronological anchors for biblical events during the eighth century BC. This eclipse is widely understood to be the fulfillment of the prophecy (Amo.8:9) where God declares, "And it shall come to pass in that day, that I will cause the sun to go down at noon, and I will darken the earth in the clear day". The timing of this dramatic celestial event aligned perfectly with <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H5986' clickHandler>Amos</jLink>'s prophetic ministry, lending powerful supernatural confirmation to his warnings of impending divine judgment against Israel's social injustices and religious corruption. <jPara></jPara> The eclipse served as a vivid and terrifying symbol that reinforced <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H5986' clickHandler>Amos</jLink>'s message about the coming "Day of the Lord," when God would intervene in human history to execute judgment against sin and unrighteousness. For the ancient peoples of Israel and surrounding nations, solar eclipses were interpreted as ominous signs from the gods, making this event particularly effective in capturing public attention and lending credibility to prophetic warnings. The precise dating of this eclipse to 763 BC also helps scholars establish the chronological framework for other biblical events during this crucial period, when both Israel and Judah were experiencing material prosperity under <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H3379G' clickHandler>Jeroboam</jLink> II and <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H5818G' clickHandler>Uzziah</jLink> respectively, yet facing the growing threat of <jLink data-type='L' data-strong='H0804G' clickHandler>Assyrian</jLink> expansion that would eventually lead to Israel's destruction and Judah's subjugation.
events: 763 BC: A total solar eclipse darkens the sky over Israel on June 15, 763 BC.
763 BC: <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H5986' clickHandler>Amos</jLink>’s prophecy is fulfilled as the sun is darkened at noon.

ChronologyEntries.article: 762 BC:  The prophet <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H1954J' clickHandler>Hosea</jLink> ministered to the northern Kingdom of Israel during a period of significant political instability and moral decline that would characterize the final decades of the kingdom's existence. <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H1954J' clickHandler>Hosea</jLink>'s prophetic message employed the powerful metaphor of his own troubled marriage to an unfaithful wife to illustrate Israel's spiritual adultery through idolatry and unfaithfulness to their covenant relationship with <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H3068G' clickHandler>Yahweh</jLink>. The Book of <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H1954J' clickHandler>Hosea</jLink>, which preserves his oracles, focuses on the central themes of infidelity, repentance, and redemption, demonstrating how Israel had pursued foreign gods and political alliances rather than maintaining exclusive loyalty to the Lord who had delivered them from <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H4714H' clickHandler>Egypt</jLink> and established them in the Promised Land. <jPara></jPara> Despite Israel's repeated transgressions and spiritual unfaithfulness, <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H1954J' clickHandler>Hosea</jLink>'s prophecies emphasized God's enduring love and willingness to forgive, calling the nation to genuine repentance and promising restoration if they would return to covenant faithfulness. The prophet's ministry occurred during the tumultuous period following the end of <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H3379G' clickHandler>Jeroboam</jLink> II's prosperous reign, when Israel faced increasing internal political chaos and the growing threat of <jLink data-type='L' data-strong='H0804G' clickHandler>Assyrian</jLink> expansion. <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H1954J' clickHandler>Hosea</jLink>'s personal experience of loving an unfaithful spouse provided a vivid illustration of God's persistent love for wayward Israel, making his prophecy one of the most emotionally powerful and theologically profound expressions of divine grace in the Hebrew Bible.
events: 762 BC: Prophet <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H1954J' clickHandler>Hosea</jLink> begins his ministry in Israel during political instability and moral decline.

762 BC: <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H1954J' clickHandler>Hosea</jLink>’s troubled marriage to <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H1586H' clickHandler>Gomer</jLink> symbolizes Israel’s unfaithfulness to <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H3068G' clickHandler>Yahweh</jLink>.
762 BC: <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H1954J' clickHandler>Hosea</jLink> calls Israel to repentance and warns of judgment for idolatry.

ChronologyEntries.desc: <jChronDurationLink style='color:blue'>▼</jChronDurationLink><jLink data-type='P' data-strong='G2197H' clickHandler>Zechariah</jLink> King of Israel
ChronologyEntries.article: 753 BC:  In 753 BC, <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='G2197H' clickHandler>Zechariah</jLink> son of <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H3379G' clickHandler>Jeroboam</jLink> II ascended to the throne of Israel, beginning what would prove to be the shortest reign in Israel's history at only six months (2Ki.15:8-12). <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='G2197H' clickHandler>Zechariah</jLink>'s brief rule continued the pattern of evil established by his predecessors, particularly maintaining the idolatrous practices instituted by <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H3379G' clickHandler>Jeroboam</jLink> I, including the golden calf worship at <jLink data-type='L' data-strong='H1008G' clickHandler>Bethel</jLink> and <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H1835H' clickHandler>Dan</jLink> that had characterized Israel's apostasy since the kingdom's founding. His reign represented the final generation of the <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H3058H' clickHandler>Jehu</jLink> dynasty, which had ruled Israel for nearly a century since <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H3058H' clickHandler>Jehu</jLink>'s violent revolution that eliminated the house of <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H0256G' clickHandler>Ahab</jLink> in 841 BC. <jPara></jPara> The end of <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='G2197H' clickHandler>Zechariah</jLink>'s reign came through assassination by <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H7967G' clickHandler>Shallum</jLink> son of <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H3003H' clickHandler>Jabesh</jLink>, who conspired against him and killed him in front of the people, fulfilling the prophecy given to <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H3058H' clickHandler>Jehu</jLink> that his descendants would occupy Israel's throne only until the fourth generation. This violent conclusion not only ended <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='G2197H' clickHandler>Zechariah</jLink>'s personal rule but also brought the entire <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H3058H' clickHandler>Jehu</jLink> dynasty to its prophesied termination, marking the beginning of an unprecedented period of political instability in Israel that would see multiple kings assassinated and dynasties rise and fall in rapid succession. The brevity of <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='G2197H' clickHandler>Zechariah</jLink>'s reign and the manner of his death exemplified the moral and political decay that would characterize Israel's final decades before its destruction by <jLink data-type='L' data-strong='H0804G' clickHandler>Assyria</jLink>.
events: 753 BC: Zachariah son of <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H3379G' clickHandler>Jeroboam</jLink> II becomes king of Israel.

753 BC: Zachariah continues <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H3379G' clickHandler>Jeroboam</jLink> I’s idolatry at <jLink data-type='L' data-strong='H1008G' clickHandler>Bethel</jLink> and <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H1835H' clickHandler>Dan</jLink>.
753 BC: Zachariah is the last king of <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H3379G' clickHandler>Jeroboam</jLink> II’s (<jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H3058H' clickHandler>Jehu</jLink>) dynasty.

753 BC: Zachariah is assassinated by <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H7967G' clickHandler>Shallum</jLink> son of <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H3003H' clickHandler>Jabesh</jLink> after six months.

753 BC: <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H7967G' clickHandler>Shallum</jLink> son of <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H3003H' clickHandler>Jabesh</jLink> kills Zachariah and takes the throne, fulfilling <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H3058H' clickHandler>Jehu</jLink>’s four-generation prophecy.

ChronologyEntries.desc: <jChronDurationLink style='color:blue'>▼</jChronDurationLink><jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H7967G' clickHandler>Shallum</jLink> then <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H4505' clickHandler>Menahem</jLink>+<jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H6492' clickHandler>Pekah</jLink> Ks of Israel
ChronologyEntries.article: 752 BC:  In 752 BC, the northern Kingdom of Israel experienced unprecedented political instability through a series of violent coups and assassinations that devastated royal authority and left the kingdom vulnerable to external threats (2Ki.15:13-22). <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H7967G' clickHandler>Shallum</jLink> son of <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H3003H' clickHandler>Jabesh</jLink>, who had assassinated King <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='G2197H' clickHandler>Zechariah</jLink> the previous year, managed to hold the throne for only one month before being killed by <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H4505' clickHandler>Menahem</jLink> son of <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H1424' clickHandler>Gadi</jLink>, demonstrating the complete breakdown of legitimate governmental succession. <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H4505' clickHandler>Menahem</jLink>'s seizure of power was accompanied by extreme brutality, including his savage attack on the city of <jLink data-type='L' data-strong='H8607H' clickHandler>Tiphsah</jLink>, where he killed all the inhabitants and ripped open pregnant women because the city had refused to acknowledge his authority. <jPara></jPara> <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H4505' clickHandler>Menahem</jLink>'s ten-year reign was characterized by oppression, cruelty, and the imposition of heavy tribute payments to secure his position against internal and external enemies. During this same period, <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H6492' clickHandler>Pekah</jLink> son of <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H7425' clickHandler>Remaliah</jLink>, a high-ranking military officer, began plotting against the royal house and would eventually assassinate <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H4505' clickHandler>Menahem</jLink>'s son <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H6494' clickHandler>Pekahiah</jLink> to establish his own dynasty. This rapid succession of violent regime changes in 752 BC marked the beginning of Israel's final period of political chaos, demonstrating how the kingdom's moral and spiritual decay had completely undermined stable governance and left the nation defenseless against the growing <jLink data-type='L' data-strong='H0804G' clickHandler>Assyrian</jLink> threat that would ultimately lead to Israel's destruction and exile.
events: 752 BC: <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H7967G' clickHandler>Shallum</jLink> son of <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H3003H' clickHandler>Jabesh</jLink> reigns as king of Israel for one month after killing Zachariah.

752 BC: <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H4505' clickHandler>Menahem</jLink> son of <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H1424' clickHandler>Gadi</jLink> kills <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H7967G' clickHandler>Shallum</jLink> and seizes Israel’s throne.

752 BC: <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H4505' clickHandler>Menahem</jLink> attacks <jLink data-type='L' data-strong='H8607H' clickHandler>Tiphsah</jLink>, killing all and ripping open pregnant women for resisting him.
752 BC: <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H4505' clickHandler>Menahem</jLink> begins a ten-year reign as king of Israel.
752 BC: <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H7967G' clickHandler>Shallum</jLink>’s brief reign ends, worsening royal succession in Israel.

ChronologyEntries.desc: <jChronDurationLink style='color:black'>▼</jChronDurationLink><jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H3147H' clickHandler>Jotham</jLink> reigns in Judah. <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H5818G' clickHandler>Uzziah</jLink> leprous
ChronologyEntries.article: 750 BC:  In 750 BC, <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H3147H' clickHandler>Jotham</jLink> son of <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H5818G' clickHandler>Uzziah</jLink> assumed the regency of Judah when his father's was afflicted with leprosy, which had resulted from <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H5818G' clickHandler>Uzziah</jLink>'s unlawful attempt to burn incense in the Temple (2Ki.15:32-38; 2Ch.27:1-9). <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H3147H' clickHandler>Jotham</jLink>'s appointment as regent ensured governmental continuity while respecting the religious requirements that isolated his leprous father from public life and Temple activities. The biblical record commends <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H3147H' clickHandler>Jotham</jLink> for doing what was right in the sight of the Lord, following the positive example established during his father's early reign when <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H5818G' clickHandler>Uzziah</jLink> had sought God and experienced unprecedented prosperity and military success. A stone tablet was discovered on the Mount of <jLink data-type='L' data-strong='H2132G' clickHandler>Olives</jLink> bearing an <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H0762' clickHandler>Aramaic</jLink> inscription: "Hither were brought the bones of <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H5818G' clickHandler>Uzziah</jLink>, king of Judah. Do not open," - suggesting that his leprous condition may have necessitated special burial arrangements. <jPara></jPara> <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H3147H' clickHandler>Jotham</jLink>'s regency was marked by significant construction projects that strengthened <jLink data-type='L' data-strong='H3389' clickHandler>Jerusalem</jLink> and extended Judah's defensive capabilities throughout the kingdom. He built the Upper Gate of the Temple complex, completed extensive work on the wall of <jLink data-type='L' data-strong='H6077' clickHandler>Ophel</jLink> (a fortified area of <jLink data-type='L' data-strong='H3389' clickHandler>Jerusalem</jLink>), and constructed cities in the hill country of Judah along with forts and towers in wooded areas. However, like his father, <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H3147H' clickHandler>Jotham</jLink> did not remove the high places where unauthorized worship continued, indicating that while the royal house maintained proper Temple worship, popular religious practices remained syncretistic. <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H3147H' clickHandler>Jotham</jLink>'s regency provided stability and prosperity for Judah during a period when the northern kingdom was experiencing violent political upheaval, demonstrating the benefits of righteous leadership and covenant faithfulness.
events: 750 BC: King <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H5818G' clickHandler>Uzziah</jLink> (<jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H5818G' clickHandler>Azariah</jLink>) of Judah tries to burn incense in the Temple, a priestly act.
750 BC: <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H5818G' clickHandler>Uzziah</jLink> becomes afflicted with leprosy and is isolated from public and Temple.

750 BC: <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H3147H' clickHandler>Jotham</jLink> son of <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H5818G' clickHandler>Uzziah</jLink> becomes co-regent of Judah when <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H5818G' clickHandler>Uzziah</jLink> becomes isolated.

750 BC: <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H3147H' clickHandler>Jotham</jLink> starts building projects: Upper Gate of the Temple, <jLink data-type='L' data-strong='H6077' clickHandler>Ophel</jLink> wall, and new cities, forts, and towers.

ChronologyEntries.desc: <jChronDurationLink style='color:blue'>▼</jChronDurationLink><jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H6494' clickHandler>Pekahiah</jLink>+<jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H6492' clickHandler>Pekah</jLink> Kings of Israel
ChronologyEntries.article: 742 BC:  In 742 BC, the northern Kingdom of Israel experienced another violent dynastic transition when <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H6494' clickHandler>Pekahiah</jLink> son of <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H4505' clickHandler>Menahem</jLink>, who had reigned for two years, was assassinated by <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H6492' clickHandler>Pekah</jLink> son of <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H7425' clickHandler>Remaliah</jLink>, one of his military officers (2Ki.15:23-26). <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H6494' clickHandler>Pekahiah</jLink>'s brief reign continued the pattern of apostasy that had characterized Israel since its founding, as he "did evil in the sight of the Lord" by maintaining the idolatrous golden calf worship established by <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H3379G' clickHandler>Jeroboam</jLink> I at <jLink data-type='L' data-strong='H1008G' clickHandler>Bethel</jLink> and <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H1835H' clickHandler>Dan</jLink>. The assassination occurred in the citadel of the royal palace in <jLink data-type='L' data-strong='H8111' clickHandler>Samaria</jLink>, where <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H6492' clickHandler>Pekah</jLink>, along with fifty <jLink data-type='L' data-strong='H1568G' clickHandler>Gileadites</jLink>, killed not only <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H6494' clickHandler>Pekahiah</jLink> but also his associates <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H0709H' clickHandler>Argob</jLink> and <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H0745' clickHandler>Arieh</jLink>, demonstrating the thoroughness of the coup and the involvement of regional military forces from <jLink data-type='L' data-strong='H1568G' clickHandler>Gilead</jLink> in the conspiracy. <jPara></jPara> <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H6492' clickHandler>Pekah</jLink>'s seizure of power represented another link in the chain of violent succession that had destabilized Israel since the end of <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H3379G' clickHandler>Jeroboam</jLink> II's prosperous reign, reflecting the kingdom's internal weakness as it faced mounting pressure from the expanding <jLink data-type='L' data-strong='H0804G' clickHandler>Assyrian</jLink> Empire under <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H8407' clickHandler>Tiglath-Pileser</jLink> III. Archaeological confirmation of <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H6492' clickHandler>Pekah</jLink>'s historical existence comes from <jLink data-type='L' data-strong='H0804G' clickHandler>Assyrian</jLink> annals, where he is mentioned as "Paqaha" of Israel, indicating that his reign was significant enough to warrant attention in international diplomatic and military records. This political instability in Israel occurred during the same period when Judah was experiencing its own royal crisis with <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H5818G' clickHandler>Uzziah</jLink>'s leprosy, highlighting how both kingdoms of the divided monarchy were struggling with leadership challenges that would make them increasingly vulnerable to foreign domination.
events: 742 BC: <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H6494' clickHandler>Pekahiah</jLink> son of <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H4505' clickHandler>Menahem</jLink> becomes king of Israel and continues <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H3379G' clickHandler>Jeroboam</jLink> I’s idolatry.

742 BC: <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H6494' clickHandler>Pekahiah</jLink> is assassinated in <jLink data-type='L' data-strong='H8111' clickHandler>Samaria</jLink> by <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H6492' clickHandler>Pekah</jLink> son of <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H7425' clickHandler>Remaliah</jLink> with fifty <jLink data-type='L' data-strong='H1568G' clickHandler>Gileadites</jLink>.

742 BC: <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H0709H' clickHandler>Argob</jLink> and <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H0745' clickHandler>Arieh</jLink> are killed during <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H6492' clickHandler>Pekah</jLink>’s coup.
742 BC: <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H6492' clickHandler>Pekah</jLink> son of <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H7425' clickHandler>Remaliah</jLink> takes Israel’s throne.

ChronologyEntries.desc: <jChronDurationLink style='color:black'>▼</jChronDurationLink><jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H5818G' clickHandler>Uzziah</jLink> dies <jChronDurationLink style='color:blue'>▼</jChronDurationLink><jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H6492' clickHandler>Pekah</jLink> sole K. <jChronDurationLink style='color:green'>▼</jChronDurationLink><jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H3470A' clickHandler>Isaiah</jLink>
ChronologyEntries.article: 740 BC:  In 740 BC, several pivotal developments shaped the political and religious landscape of both <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H3478' clickHandler>Israelite</jLink> kingdoms, most notably the formal beginning of <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H3470A' clickHandler>Isaiah</jLink>'s prophetic ministry through his dramatic vision of God's holiness in the Temple (Isa.6). This divine calling occurred during a year of significant transition, as King <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H5818G' clickHandler>Uzziah</jLink>'s death ended an era of <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H3063G' clickHandler>Judean</jLink> prosperity and military success, while his son <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H3147H' clickHandler>Jotham</jLink> transitioned from regent to full king of Judah. Meanwhile, <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H6492' clickHandler>Pekah</jLink> son of <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H7425' clickHandler>Remaliah</jLink> continued his twenty-year reign over Israel, maintaining the kingdom's apostasy while facing increasing pressure from <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H8407' clickHandler>Tiglath-Pileser</jLink> III of <jLink data-type='L' data-strong='H0804G' clickHandler>Assyria</jLink>, who would eventually invade Israel's northern territories and deport their inhabitants, demonstrating the fulfillment of prophetic warnings about the consequences of covenant unfaithfulness. <jPara></jPara> <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H3470A' clickHandler>Isaiah</jLink>'s early prophetic oracles (Isa.2-5) directly addressed the moral and spiritual crises that had precipitated both kingdoms' political instability, condemning Judah's pride, social injustice, and idolatrous practices that paralleled the very issues that had led to <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H5818G' clickHandler>Uzziah</jLink>'s downfall. The prophet's message emphasized reliance on God rather than human alliances or military strength, a theme that would prove particularly relevant as both kingdoms increasingly sought security through foreign partnerships rather than covenant faithfulness. <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H3147H' clickHandler>Jotham</jLink>'s assumption of full royal authority in Judah represented continuity with his father's earlier righteous policies, as he "did what was right in the sight of the Lord," though the persistence of unauthorized worship at high places indicated that fundamental religious problems remained unresolved despite royal leadership changes. This convergence of political transition, prophetic calling, and continued spiritual decline set the stage for the more dramatic crises that would characterize the following decade as <jLink data-type='L' data-strong='H0804G' clickHandler>Assyrian</jLink> pressure intensified throughout the Levant.
events: 740 BC: King <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H5818G' clickHandler>Uzziah</jLink> of Judah dies.
740 BC: <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H3147H' clickHandler>Jotham</jLink> son of <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H5818G' clickHandler>Uzziah</jLink> becomes full king of Judah.
740 BC: <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H3470A' clickHandler>Isaiah</jLink> son of <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H0531' clickHandler>Amoz</jLink> receives his prophetic calling in the Temple.
740 BC: <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H3470A' clickHandler>Isaiah</jLink> delivers early oracles against Judah’s pride and idolatry.

740 BC: <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H6492' clickHandler>Pekah</jLink> son of <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H7425' clickHandler>Remaliah</jLink> continues to rule Israel amid <jLink data-type='L' data-strong='H0804G' clickHandler>Assyrian</jLink> threats.

ChronologyEntries.desc: <jChronDurationLink style='color:black'>▼</jChronDurationLink><jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H0271G' clickHandler>Ahaz</jLink> reigns in Judah
ChronologyEntries.article: 735 BC:  In 735 BC, <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H0271G' clickHandler>Ahaz</jLink> son of <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H3147H' clickHandler>Jotham</jLink> assumed the regency of Judah, beginning a reign that would mark one of the darkest periods in the southern kingdom's spiritual history (2Ki.16:1-20; 2Ch.28:1-27). Unlike his righteous father <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H3147H' clickHandler>Jotham</jLink> and grandfather <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H5818G' clickHandler>Uzziah</jLink> (during his early years), <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H0271G' clickHandler>Ahaz</jLink> "did not do what was right in the sight of the Lord" but instead "walked in the ways of the kings of Israel," introducing unprecedented levels of idolatry including the construction of molten images for Baal worship and the horrific practice of child sacrifice, even burning his own son in fire according to the abominable practices of the nations whom the Lord had dispossessed. This dramatic spiritual apostasy coincided with severe military pressure, as <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H7526G' clickHandler>Rezin</jLink> king of Aram-Damascus and <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H6492' clickHandler>Pekah</jLink> king of Israel formed a coalition against Judah, besieging <jLink data-type='L' data-strong='H3389' clickHandler>Jerusalem</jLink> and inflicting heavy casualties, though they were unable to capture the city itself. <jPara></jPara> <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H0271G' clickHandler>Ahaz</jLink>'s response to this military crisis demonstrated his fundamental lack of faith, as he appealed to <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H8407' clickHandler>Tiglath-Pileser</jLink> III of <jLink data-type='L' data-strong='H0804G' clickHandler>Assyria</jLink> for assistance, sending silver and gold from both the Temple treasury and royal palace as tribute to secure <jLink data-type='L' data-strong='H0804G' clickHandler>Assyrian</jLink> intervention. This decision, while providing temporary military relief through <jLink data-type='L' data-strong='H0804G' clickHandler>Assyrian</jLink> attacks on <jLink data-type='L' data-strong='H1834' clickHandler>Damascus</jLink> and Israel, effectively reduced Judah to vassal status and introduced further religious corruption as <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H0271G' clickHandler>Ahaz</jLink> replaced the Temple's bronze altar with a copy of a pagan altar he had observed in <jLink data-type='L' data-strong='H1834' clickHandler>Damascus</jLink> during his submission to the <jLink data-type='L' data-strong='H0804G' clickHandler>Assyrian</jLink> king.
