The nation was simultaneously grappling with internal problems including rampant injustice, violence, and moral decay, which formed the backdrop for <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H2265' clickHandler>Habakkuk</jLink>'s unique prophetic dialogue with God. <jPara></jPara> The book of <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H2265' clickHandler>Habakkuk</jLink> is distinguished by candid questioning of divine justice and the problem of evil. The prophet boldly voiced concerns about why God permits the wicked to prosper while the righteous suffer, receiving the divine response that the <jLink data-type='L' data-strong='H0894' clickHandler>Babylonians</jLink> (<jLink data-type='L' data-strong='H3778' clickHandler>Chaldeans</jLink>) would serve as instruments of judgment against Judah's corruption, though they too would eventually face divine retribution for their violence and arrogance. The enduring theological contribution of <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H2265' clickHandler>Habakkuk</jLink>'s ministry is the declaration that "the righteous shall live by faith," emphasizing the necessity of steadfast trust in God's sovereignty even when His purposes appear mysterious or delayed.
events: 625 BC: <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H2265' clickHandler>Habakkuk</jLink> prophesies about Judah’s moral and spiritual crisis.
625 BC: <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H2265' clickHandler>Habakkuk</jLink> receives a divine response about the rise of <jLink data-type='L' data-strong='H0894' clickHandler>Babylon</jLink>.

ChronologyEntries.article: 624 BC:  The discovery of the Book of the Law in 624 BC represents one of the most pivotal moments in Judah's religious history (2Ki.22:3-23:25; 2Ch.34:3-35:19). During temple renovations commissioned by King <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H2977G' clickHandler>Josiah</jLink>, workers uncovered this ancient text, which was subsequently read to the king and profoundly impacted him. Upon hearing the contents, <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H2977G' clickHandler>Josiah</jLink> was deeply moved and alarmed by the warnings and commandments contained within the book, recognizing that the nation had significantly strayed from the covenantal requirements outlined in the text. <jPara></jPara> This momentous discovery served as the catalyst for <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H2977G' clickHandler>Josiah</jLink>'s sweeping religious reforms, prompting the king to implement comprehensive measures to purge Judah of idolatrous practices and restore proper worship according to the covenantal laws. The event led to a public renewal of the covenant with God, as <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H2977G' clickHandler>Josiah</jLink> committed the nation to follow the statutes and commandments detailed in the rediscovered text. The finding of the Book of the Law not only transformed Judah's immediate religious practices but also reinforced the centrality of written law in Jewish religious identity, setting the stage for the restoration of <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H6453' clickHandler>Passover</jLink> observance in the following year.
events: 624 BC: The Book of the Law is discovered during Temple renovations in <jLink data-type='L' data-strong='H3389' clickHandler>Jerusalem</jLink>.
624 BC: The Book of the Law is read to King <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H2977G' clickHandler>Josiah</jLink>.
624 BC: <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H2977G' clickHandler>Josiah</jLink> initiates sweeping religious reforms in Judah.
624 BC: A public renewal of the covenant is held in <jLink data-type='L' data-strong='H3389' clickHandler>Jerusalem</jLink>.

ChronologyEntries.article: 623 BC:  In 623 BC, King <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H2977G' clickHandler>Josiah</jLink> of Judah restored the observance of <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H6453' clickHandler>Passover</jLink> as a cornerstone of his comprehensive religious reforms, following the discovery of the Book of the Law during temple renovations. This restoration marked a significant return to the traditions and worship practices outlined in the Mosaic Law, which had been neglected for an extended period in Judah's history. The <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H6453' clickHandler>Passover</jLink> celebration was reinstated in strict accordance with the instructions found in the rediscovered scriptures, demonstrating <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H2977G' clickHandler>Josiah</jLink>'s commitment to aligning the nation's religious observances with biblical mandates and reversing the previous neglect of this fundamental festival. <jPara></jPara> The restoration of <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H6453' clickHandler>Passover</jLink> in 623 BC represents a pivotal moment in Judah's religious history, reflecting not only <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H2977G' clickHandler>Josiah</jLink>'s personal dedication to covenantal faithfulness but also the broader spiritual renewal taking place throughout the kingdom. This event was part of the larger reformation movement that began with the discovery of the Book of the Law, emphasizing the restoration of proper worship practices and the nation's renewed commitment to its covenant relationship with <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H3068G' clickHandler>Yahweh</jLink>. The successful reinstatement of <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H6453' clickHandler>Passover</jLink> observance demonstrated the effectiveness of <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H2977G' clickHandler>Josiah</jLink>'s reforms and marked a significant step toward spiritual restoration for the people of Judah.
events: 623 BC: <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H2977G' clickHandler>Josiah</jLink> commands restoration of the <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H6453' clickHandler>Passover</jLink> in <jLink data-type='L' data-strong='H3389' clickHandler>Jerusalem</jLink>.
623 BC: The <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H6453' clickHandler>Passover</jLink> is celebrated in <jLink data-type='L' data-strong='H3389' clickHandler>Jerusalem</jLink> according to Mosaic Law.
623 BC: <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H2977G' clickHandler>Josiah</jLink> leads nationwide religious reformation and covenant renewal.
623 BC: Priests and <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H3878' clickHandler>Levites</jLink> are organized to fulfill Temple duties as in the Book of the Law.
623 BC: Sacrificial offerings are provided for the <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H6453' clickHandler>Passover</jLink> celebration.

ChronologyEntries.desc: <jChronDurationLink style='color:black'>▼</jChronDurationLink><jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H3079' clickHandler>Jehoiakim</jLink> after brief <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H3059H' clickHandler>Jehoahaz</jLink> K of Judah
ChronologyEntries.article: 609 BC:  The Battle of <jLink data-type='L' data-strong='H4023' clickHandler>Megiddo</jLink> in 609 BC represents a decisive turning point in <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H3063G' clickHandler>Judean</jLink> history. This ended the nation's brief period of independence under the reforms of King <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H2977G' clickHandler>Josiah</jLink>. <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H5224G' clickHandler>Pharaoh Necho</jLink> II of <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H4714H' clickHandler>Egypt</jLink> killed King <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H2977G' clickHandler>Josiah</jLink> at the strategic fortress of <jLink data-type='L' data-strong='H4023' clickHandler>Megiddo</jLink> as <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H4714H' clickHandler>Egypt</jLink> sought to assist the declining <jLink data-type='L' data-strong='H0804G' clickHandler>Assyrian</jLink> Empire against the rising <jLink data-type='L' data-strong='H0894' clickHandler>Babylonian</jLink> threat. Following <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H2977G' clickHandler>Josiah</jLink>'s death, the people of the land installed his son <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H3059H' clickHandler>Jehoahaz</jLink> as king, but his reign lasted merely three months before <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H5224G' clickHandler>Pharaoh Necho</jLink> deposed him and carried him captive to <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H4714H' clickHandler>Egypt</jLink>, where he died. <jPara></jPara> <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H5224G' clickHandler>Necho</jLink> then placed <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H3079' clickHandler>Jehoiakim</jLink> (originally named <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H3079' clickHandler>Eliakim</jLink>), another son of <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H2977G' clickHandler>Josiah</jLink>, on the throne as <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H4714H' clickHandler>Egypt</jLink>'s vassal king. <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H3079' clickHandler>Jehoiakim</jLink>'s reign was characterized by heavy <jLink data-type='L' data-strong='H4714G' clickHandler>Egyptian</jLink> taxation imposed to pay tribute to <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H5224G' clickHandler>Pharaoh</jLink>, fundamentally altering Judah's political status from independence to foreign vassalage. This period witnessed the end of <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H2977G' clickHandler>Josiah</jLink>'s comprehensive religious reforms and the beginning of the political instability that would ultimately lead to <jLink data-type='L' data-strong='H0894' clickHandler>Babylonian</jLink> conquest. The prophet <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H3414L' clickHandler>Jeremiah</jLink> delivered urgent warnings during this time, recognizing that these events signaled the approaching divine judgment upon Judah for its covenant unfaithfulness.
events: 609 BC: King <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H2977G' clickHandler>Josiah</jLink> is killed by <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H5224G' clickHandler>Pharaoh Necho</jLink> II at the Battle of <jLink data-type='L' data-strong='H4023' clickHandler>Megiddo</jLink>.

609 BC: <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H3059H' clickHandler>Jehoahaz</jLink>, son of <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H2977G' clickHandler>Josiah</jLink>, is made king in <jLink data-type='L' data-strong='H3389' clickHandler>Jerusalem</jLink>.
609 BC: <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H3059H' clickHandler>Jehoahaz</jLink> reigns as king of Judah for three months.

609 BC: <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H5224G' clickHandler>Pharaoh Necho</jLink> II deposes <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H3059H' clickHandler>Jehoahaz</jLink> and takes him captive to <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H4714H' clickHandler>Egypt</jLink>.

609 BC: <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H5224G' clickHandler>Pharaoh Necho</jLink> II appoints <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H3079' clickHandler>Eliakim</jLink> (<jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H3079' clickHandler>Jehoiakim</jLink>) as king of Judah.

ChronologyEntries.desc: <jChronDurationLink style='color:green'>▼</jChronDurationLink><jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H1840G' clickHandler>Daniel</jLink> taken with 1st Captivity
ChronologyEntries.article: 605 BC:  In 605 BC, the first <jLink data-type='L' data-strong='H0894' clickHandler>Babylonian</jLink> captivity of Judah commenced following the decisive Battle of <jLink data-type='L' data-strong='H3751' clickHandler>Carchemish</jLink>, where <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H5019' clickHandler>Nebuchadnezzar</jLink> II of <jLink data-type='L' data-strong='H0894' clickHandler>Babylon</jLink> defeated the <jLink data-type='L' data-strong='H4714G' clickHandler>Egyptian</jLink> forces under <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H5224G' clickHandler>Pharaoh Necho</jLink> II. This victory established <jLink data-type='L' data-strong='H0894' clickHandler>Babylonian</jLink> dominance throughout the Near East and marked the end of <jLink data-type='L' data-strong='H4714G' clickHandler>Egyptian</jLink> influence over Judah (2Ki.24:7). Shortly after his triumph, <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H5019' clickHandler>Nebuchadnezzar</jLink> invaded Judah and initiated the subjugation of King <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H3079' clickHandler>Jehoiakim</jLink>, who became a vassal to <jLink data-type='L' data-strong='H0894' clickHandler>Babylon</jLink>. The prophet <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H3414L' clickHandler>Jeremiah</jLink> had long warned of this judgment in his oracles (Jer.25:3,8,29; 46:2), declaring that <jLink data-type='L' data-strong='H0894' clickHandler>Babylon</jLink> would serve as God's instrument of punishment against Judah for their persistent disobedience and refusal to heed prophetic warnings. This captivity fulfilled the earlier prophecy which foretold that descendants of the royal house would be taken to serve in the palace of the <jLink data-type='L' data-strong='H0894' clickHandler>Babylonian</jLink> king (Isa.39:7). <jPara></jPara>  During this first deportation, <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H1840G' clickHandler>Daniel</jLink> and other carefully selected young nobles from Judah's royal family and aristocracy were transported to <jLink data-type='L' data-strong='H0894' clickHandler>Babylon</jLink> (<jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H1835H' clickHandler>Dan</jLink>.1:1-17). These individuals were chosen for their exceptional intellect, physical appearance, and potential to serve effectively in the <jLink data-type='L' data-strong='H0894' clickHandler>Babylonian</jLink> court after receiving education in <jLink data-type='L' data-strong='H3778' clickHandler>Chaldean</jLink> literature and language. <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H1840G' clickHandler>Daniel</jLink>, along with his companions <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H2608T' clickHandler>Hananiah</jLink>, <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H4332I' clickHandler>Mishael</jLink>, and <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H5838Z' clickHandler>Azariah</jLink> (later renamed <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H1840G' clickHandler>Belteshazzar</jLink>, <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H2608T' clickHandler>Shadrach</jLink>, <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H4332I' clickHandler>Meshach</jLink>, and <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H5838Z' clickHandler>Abednego</jLink>), demonstrated remarkable faithfulness to their ancestral faith while adapting to their new circumstances in the royal court. The spiritual and political turmoil of this period is further reflected in <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H3414L' clickHandler>Jeremiah</jLink>'s continued prophetic ministry (Jer.26:20; 35; 36:9), where he persistently called for national repentance and warned of further exile if the people failed to submit to <jLink data-type='L' data-strong='H0894' clickHandler>Babylonian</jLink> authority. This captivity of 605 BC thus initiated the 1st start of the period of 70 years of captivity.
events: 605 BC: <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H5019' clickHandler>Nebuchadnezzar</jLink> II defeats <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H5224G' clickHandler>Pharaoh Necho</jLink> II at the Battle of <jLink data-type='L' data-strong='H3751' clickHandler>Carchemish</jLink>.

605 BC: <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H5019' clickHandler>Nebuchadnezzar</jLink> II invades Judah and subjugates <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H3079' clickHandler>Jehoiakim</jLink>, ending Judah’s independence.

605 BC: The <jLink data-type='L' data-strong='H0894' clickHandler>Babylonian</jLink> captivity begins with first deportation - of <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H1840G' clickHandler>Daniel</jLink> and other nobles.

605 BC: <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H1840G' clickHandler>Daniel</jLink> and companions are trained in the court of <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H5019' clickHandler>Nebuchadnezzar</jLink> II in <jLink data-type='L' data-strong='H0894' clickHandler>Babylon</jLink>.

605 BC: <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H3414L' clickHandler>Jeremiah</jLink> delivers prophecies in <jLink data-type='L' data-strong='H3389' clickHandler>Jerusalem</jLink> about <jLink data-type='L' data-strong='H0894' clickHandler>Babylonian</jLink> judgment.

ChronologyEntries.desc: <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H3079' clickHandler>Jehoiakim</jLink> burns the scroll and rebels
ChronologyEntries.article: 604 BC:  In 604 BC, King <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H3079' clickHandler>Jehoiakim</jLink> of Judah committed two significant acts of defiance that would seal his fate and that of his kingdom. The most dramatic of these occurred when <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H3079' clickHandler>Jehoiakim</jLink> burned the prophetic scroll written by <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H3414L' clickHandler>Jeremiah</jLink> (Jer.36). This scroll contained divine warnings about the impending judgment on Judah due to the nation's persistent disobedience and refusal to heed prophetic warnings. <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H3079' clickHandler>Jehoiakim</jLink>'s destruction of the scroll, cutting it piece by piece and casting it into the fire in his winter quarters, represented not merely personal contempt for <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H3414L' clickHandler>Jeremiah</jLink> but a direct rejection of God's word and prophetic authority during a period of critical political instability under <jLink data-type='L' data-strong='H0894' clickHandler>Babylonian</jLink> dominance. Shortly after this incident, <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H3079' clickHandler>Jehoiakim</jLink> rebelled against <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H5019' clickHandler>Nebuchadnezzar</jLink>, king of <jLink data-type='L' data-strong='H0894' clickHandler>Babylon</jLink>, after having served him as a vassal for three years (2Ki.24:1). <jPara></jPara>  The consequences of <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H3079' clickHandler>Jehoiakim</jLink>'s defiance were swift and severe as in the prophecy which declared that the king would die a disgraceful death "with the burial of a donkey" (Jer.22:19), reflecting divine judgment upon his rebellion and disregard for prophetic warning. Meanwhile, in <jLink data-type='L' data-strong='H0894' clickHandler>Babylon</jLink> during this same year, a parallel but contrasting event unfolded when <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H1840G' clickHandler>Daniel</jLink> interpreted <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H5019' clickHandler>Nebuchadnezzar</jLink>'s troubling dream in the king's second year of reign (<jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H1835H' clickHandler>Dan</jLink>.2:1, 36). This interpretation marked a pivotal moment in <jLink data-type='L' data-strong='H0894' clickHandler>Babylonian</jLink> history and demonstrated the stark contrast between <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H1840G' clickHandler>Daniel</jLink>'s faithfulness to God while serving in a foreign court and <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H3079' clickHandler>Jehoiakim</jLink>'s rebellious rejection of divine authority in his own kingdom. The events of 604 BC thus established the trajectory that would lead to <jLink data-type='L' data-strong='H3389' clickHandler>Jerusalem</jLink>'s destruction and the complete <jLink data-type='L' data-strong='H0894' clickHandler>Babylonian</jLink> conquest of Judah.
events: 604 BC: King <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H3079' clickHandler>Jehoiakim</jLink> burns <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H3414L' clickHandler>Jeremiah</jLink>’s prophetic scroll in <jLink data-type='L' data-strong='H3389' clickHandler>Jerusalem</jLink>.

604 BC: <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H3079' clickHandler>Jehoiakim</jLink> rebels against <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H5019' clickHandler>Nebuchadnezzar</jLink> II after three years of vassalage.
604 BC: Prophecy declares <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H3079' clickHandler>Jehoiakim</jLink> will die "with the burial of a donkey."

604 BC: <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H1840G' clickHandler>Daniel</jLink> interprets <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H5019' clickHandler>Nebuchadnezzar</jLink> II’s dream in <jLink data-type='L' data-strong='H0894' clickHandler>Babylon</jLink>, gaining prominence.

ChronologyEntries.desc: <jChronDurationLink style='color:black'>▼</jChronDurationLink><jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H3078' clickHandler>Jehoiachin</jLink> King of Judah
ChronologyEntries.article: 598 BC:  King <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H3078' clickHandler>Jehoiachin</jLink> ascended to the throne of Judah in 598 BC following the death of his father <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H3079' clickHandler>Jehoiakim</jLink>, inheriting a kingdom already under severe <jLink data-type='L' data-strong='H0894' clickHandler>Babylonian</jLink> pressure due to his father's rebellion four years earlier. The young king, who was eighteen years old (2Ki.24:8) (though 2Ch.36:9 states he was eight), faced the immediate crisis of a <jLink data-type='L' data-strong='H0894' clickHandler>Babylonian</jLink> siege that had intensified following <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H3079' clickHandler>Jehoiakim</jLink>'s continued resistance to <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H5019' clickHandler>Nebuchadnezzar</jLink>'s authority. <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H3078' clickHandler>Jehoiachin</jLink>'s brief reign of approximately three months and ten days was dominated entirely by the ongoing military crisis and diplomatic negotiations with the besieging <jLink data-type='L' data-strong='H0894' clickHandler>Babylonian</jLink> forces. <jPara></jPara> The political situation was further complicated by the broader geopolitical context, as <jLink data-type='L' data-strong='H0894' clickHandler>Babylon</jLink> was consolidating its control over the entire Levantine region following its victory over the Assyrian-Egyptian coalition. <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H3078' clickHandler>Jehoiachin</jLink>'s reign effectively marked the end of any meaningful <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H3063G' clickHandler>Judean</jLink> independence, as the kingdom's military capacity had been severely weakened by years of tribute payments and the gradual loss of territorial control to <jLink data-type='L' data-strong='H0894' clickHandler>Babylonian</jLink> administrative districts. Archaeological evidence from this period, including destruction layers in various <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H3063G' clickHandler>Judean</jLink> cities, confirms the intensification of <jLink data-type='L' data-strong='H0894' clickHandler>Babylonian</jLink> military pressure during <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H3078' clickHandler>Jehoiachin</jLink>'s brief rule, setting the stage for the dramatic events that would unfold in 597 BC with his capture and deportation.
events: 598 BC: King <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H3079' clickHandler>Jehoiakim</jLink> dies in <jLink data-type='L' data-strong='H3389' clickHandler>Jerusalem</jLink>, causing a succession crisis.
598 BC: <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H3078' clickHandler>Jehoiachin</jLink> becomes king of Judah at age eighteen (or eight).

598 BC: <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H5019' clickHandler>Nebuchadnezzar</jLink> II intensifies the <jLink data-type='L' data-strong='H0894' clickHandler>Babylonian</jLink> siege of <jLink data-type='L' data-strong='H3389' clickHandler>Jerusalem</jLink>.
598 BC: <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H3078' clickHandler>Jehoiachin</jLink> reigns about three months and ten days during the siege.

ChronologyEntries.desc: <jChronDurationLink style='color:black'>▼</jChronDurationLink><jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H6667H' clickHandler>Zedekiah</jLink> K of Judah. Temple ransacked
ChronologyEntries.article: 597 BC:  The year 597 BC witnessed the first major catastrophe in <jLink data-type='L' data-strong='H3389' clickHandler>Jerusalem</jLink>'s final crisis, and marks the 2nd start of the period of 70 years of captivity. King <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H3078' clickHandler>Jehoiachin</jLink> surrendered to <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H5019' clickHandler>Nebuchadnezzar</jLink> II, resulting in the capture of <jLink data-type='L' data-strong='H3389' clickHandler>Jerusalem</jLink> and the installation of <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H6667H' clickHandler>Zedekiah</jLink> as <jLink data-type='L' data-strong='H0894' clickHandler>Babylon</jLink>'s puppet ruler. Following <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H3078' clickHandler>Jehoiachin</jLink>'s surrender on the second day of <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H0143' clickHandler>Adar</jLink> (March 16, 597 BC, according to <jLink data-type='L' data-strong='H0894' clickHandler>Babylonian</jLink> records), <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H5019' clickHandler>Nebuchadnezzar</jLink> deported approximately 10,000 prominent citizens, including the royal family, court officials, skilled craftsmen, and military personnel, effectively removing Judah's political and intellectual leadership. The <jLink data-type='L' data-strong='H0894' clickHandler>Babylonian</jLink> king then placed <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H4983P' clickHandler>Mattaniah</jLink>, <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H3078' clickHandler>Jehoiachin</jLink>'s uncle, on the throne and changed his name to <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H6667H' clickHandler>Zedekiah</jLink>, symbolizing his complete dependence on <jLink data-type='L' data-strong='H0894' clickHandler>Babylonian</jLink> authority and the fundamental transformation of Judah's political status. <jPara></jPara> The Temple of <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H8010' clickHandler>Solomon</jLink> suffered its first major despoiling during this conquest, as the <jLink data-type='L' data-strong='H0894' clickHandler>Babylonians</jLink> removed treasures from both the temple and the royal palace, cutting up the golden vessels that <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H8010' clickHandler>Solomon</jLink> had made for the temple service (2Ki.24:13). This partial ransacking of the Temple represented not only economic exploitation but also a direct challenge to the religious foundations of <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H3063G' clickHandler>Judean</jLink> identity, as it demonstrated that neither the Davidic dynasty nor the sacred temple could provide security against foreign conquest. <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H6667H' clickHandler>Zedekiah</jLink>'s subsequent eleven-year reign would be marked by the constant tension between his obligations to <jLink data-type='L' data-strong='H0894' clickHandler>Babylon</jLink> and the nationalist pressures from <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H3063G' clickHandler>Judean</jLink> nobles who hoped to restore independence, ultimately leading to the complete destruction that would follow in 586 BC.
events: 597 BC: King <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H3078' clickHandler>Jehoiachin</jLink> surrenders <jLink data-type='L' data-strong='H3389' clickHandler>Jerusalem</jLink> to <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H5019' clickHandler>Nebuchadnezzar</jLink> II.
597 BC: The second deportation of the captivity - 10,000 people from <jLink data-type='L' data-strong='H3389' clickHandler>Jerusalem</jLink> .
597 BC: The Temple and palace are plundered, with treasures taken to <jLink data-type='L' data-strong='H0894' clickHandler>Babylon</jLink>.
597 BC: <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H3078' clickHandler>Jehoiachin</jLink>’s rule ends with his surrender and deportation.

597 BC: <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H5019' clickHandler>Nebuchadnezzar</jLink> II installs <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H4983P' clickHandler>Mattaniah</jLink> (<jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H6667H' clickHandler>Zedekiah</jLink>) as <jLink data-type='L' data-strong='H0894' clickHandler>Babylonian</jLink> vassal king.

ChronologyEntries.desc: <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H3414L' clickHandler>Jeremiah</jLink> writes to the exiles
ChronologyEntries.article: 596 BC:  The prophet <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H3414L' clickHandler>Jeremiah</jLink> sent a letter to the Jewish exiles in <jLink data-type='L' data-strong='H0894' clickHandler>Babylon</jLink> (Jer.29), providing crucial guidance during the early phases of the <jLink data-type='L' data-strong='H0894' clickHandler>Babylonian</jLink> deportations. This correspondence addressed the first wave of exiles who had been taken to <jLink data-type='L' data-strong='H0894' clickHandler>Babylon</jLink>, likely including members of the royal court, skilled craftsmen, and religious leaders who were considered valuable assets to the <jLink data-type='L' data-strong='H0894' clickHandler>Babylonian</jLink> administration. <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H3414L' clickHandler>Jeremiah</jLink>'s letter directly contradicted the optimistic predictions of false prophets who were promising the exiles a swift return to <jLink data-type='L' data-strong='H3389' clickHandler>Jerusalem</jLink> within two years. <jPara></jPara> The prophetic message advised the exiles to "build houses and live in them, plant gardens and eat their produce" and to "seek the welfare of the city where I have sent you into exile" (Jer.29:5,7). This counsel represented a revolutionary theological perspective, suggesting that God's presence and blessing could be experienced even in foreign lands outside the covenant territory of Israel. <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H3414L' clickHandler>Jeremiah</jLink>'s letter established the theological foundation for Jewish life in diaspora, emphasizing that the exile would last seventy years and that the exiles should integrate constructively into <jLink data-type='L' data-strong='H0894' clickHandler>Babylonian</jLink> society while maintaining their distinctive religious identity. This guidance proved essential for the development of <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='G2454' clickHandler>Judaism</jLink> during the exile period and influenced Jewish communities throughout subsequent history.
events: 596 BC: False prophets in <jLink data-type='L' data-strong='H0894' clickHandler>Babylon</jLink> promise a swift return.

596 BC: <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H3414L' clickHandler>Jeremiah</jLink> writes a letter from <jLink data-type='L' data-strong='H3389' clickHandler>Jerusalem</jLink> to Jewish exiles in <jLink data-type='L' data-strong='H0894' clickHandler>Babylon</jLink>, urging them to settle during their seventy-year exile.

ChronologyEntries.desc: <jChronDurationLink style='color:green'>▼</jChronDurationLink><jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H3168H' clickHandler>Ezekiel</jLink>'s prophecies to the exiles
ChronologyEntries.article: 595 BC:  In 595 BC, the prophet <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H3168H' clickHandler>Ezekiel</jLink> began his extraordinary ministry among the Jewish exiles by the river <jLink data-type='L' data-strong='H3529' clickHandler>Chebar</jLink> in <jLink data-type='L' data-strong='H0894' clickHandler>Babylon</jLink>, receiving his inaugural vision in the fifth year of King <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H3078' clickHandler>Jehoiachin</jLink>'s captivity. <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H3168H' clickHandler>Ezekiel</jLink>'s prophetic calling was marked by spectacular visions of divine glory, including the famous vision of the four living creatures and the divine chariot-throne, which established his authority as God's spokesperson to the exiled community. His early prophecies (Ezk.1-19) focused primarily on explaining the theological reasons for <jLink data-type='L' data-strong='H3389' clickHandler>Jerusalem</jLink>'s impending destruction and countering the false hope that the exile would be brief. <jPara></jPara> The prophet's message during this period employed vivid symbolic actions and allegories to communicate God's judgment against <jLink data-type='L' data-strong='H3389' clickHandler>Jerusalem</jLink>'s persistent idolatry and covenant unfaithfulness. <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H3168H' clickHandler>Ezekiel</jLink>'s prophecies complemented the <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H3414L' clickHandler>Jeremiah</jLink>'s messages which also addressed both the exiles and those remaining in <jLink data-type='L' data-strong='H3389' clickHandler>Jerusalem</jLink>, warning that further divine judgment was inevitable unless there was genuine repentance (Jer.27-28; 50-51). Unlike the false prophets who promised immediate restoration, <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H3168H' clickHandler>Ezekiel</jLink> proclaimed that <jLink data-type='L' data-strong='H3389' clickHandler>Jerusalem</jLink>'s destruction was certain and that the exiles should prepare for an extended period in <jLink data-type='L' data-strong='H0894' clickHandler>Babylon</jLink>. His ministry provided crucial theological interpretation of the exile, emphasizing individual responsibility for sin and offering hope for eventual restoration based on God's faithfulness to His covenant promises rather than human merit.
events: 595 BC: <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H3168H' clickHandler>Ezekiel</jLink> begins his prophetic ministry among exiles by the river <jLink data-type='L' data-strong='H3529' clickHandler>Chebar</jLink> in <jLink data-type='L' data-strong='H0894' clickHandler>Babylon</jLink>.

595 BC: <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H3168H' clickHandler>Ezekiel</jLink> delivers early prophecies and visions to the <jLink data-type='L' data-strong='H0894' clickHandler>Babylonian</jLink> exiles.

595 BC: <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H3168H' clickHandler>Ezekiel</jLink> uses symbolic actions to warn of <jLink data-type='L' data-strong='H3389' clickHandler>Jerusalem</jLink>’s judgment and destruction.

595 BC: <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H3414L' clickHandler>Jeremiah</jLink> continues to prophesy in <jLink data-type='L' data-strong='H3389' clickHandler>Jerusalem</jLink> and to <jLink data-type='L' data-strong='H0894' clickHandler>Babylonian</jLink> exiles, warning of ongoing judgment.

595 BC: <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H3414L' clickHandler>Jeremiah</jLink> prophesies <jLink data-type='L' data-strong='H0894' clickHandler>Babylon</jLink>’s eventual downfall and Israel’s restoration.

ChronologyEntries.desc: <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H6667H' clickHandler>Zedekiah</jLink> allies with <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H6547R' clickHandler>Hophra</jLink> of <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H4714H' clickHandler>Egypt</jLink>
ChronologyEntries.article: 594 BC:  King <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H6667H' clickHandler>Zedekiah</jLink> of Judah actively pursued a military alliance with <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H6547R' clickHandler>Pharaoh Hophra</jLink> (Apries) of <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H4714H' clickHandler>Egypt</jLink> in 594 BC, representing a desperate attempt to break free from <jLink data-type='L' data-strong='H0894' clickHandler>Babylonian</jLink> vassalage through <jLink data-type='L' data-strong='H4714G' clickHandler>Egyptian</jLink> military support. This diplomatic initiative was part of a broader anti-<jLink data-type='L' data-strong='H0894' clickHandler>Babylonian</jLink> coalition that likely included other Levantine states seeking to exploit any perceived weakness in <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H5019' clickHandler>Nebuchadnezzar</jLink>'s empire. The alliance negotiations were conducted despite explicit prophetic warnings from both <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H3414L' clickHandler>Jeremiah</jLink> and <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H3168H' clickHandler>Ezekiel</jLink>, who condemned reliance on <jLink data-type='L' data-strong='H4714G' clickHandler>Egyptian</jLink> assistance as both politically foolish and spiritually unfaithful. <jPara></jPara> The prophet <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H3168H' clickHandler>Ezekiel</jLink> delivered particularly severe condemnations of this <jLink data-type='L' data-strong='H4714G' clickHandler>Egyptian</jLink> alliance (Ezk.20-23) employing graphic metaphors to describe Judah's spiritual adultery in seeking foreign alliances rather than trusting in divine protection. <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H3414L' clickHandler>Jeremiah</jLink> similarly warned that <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H4714H' clickHandler>Egypt</jLink> would prove to be a "broken reed" that would pierce the hand of anyone who leaned upon it for support (Isa.36:6). Archaeological evidence suggests that this period saw increased <jLink data-type='L' data-strong='H4714G' clickHandler>Egyptian</jLink> diplomatic activity throughout the Levant, as <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H6547R' clickHandler>Pharaoh Hophra</jLink> attempted to reassert <jLink data-type='L' data-strong='H4714G' clickHandler>Egyptian</jLink> influence in the region that had been lost to <jLink data-type='L' data-strong='H0894' clickHandler>Babylonian</jLink> expansion. However, the alliance ultimately proved disastrous, as it provided <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H5019' clickHandler>Nebuchadnezzar</jLink> with justification for the brutal siege and destruction that would begin in 590 BC.
events: 594 BC: King <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H6667H' clickHandler>Zedekiah</jLink> seeks a military alliance with <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H6547R' clickHandler>Pharaoh Hophra</jLink> of <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H4714H' clickHandler>Egypt</jLink>.

594 BC: Judah, <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H4714H' clickHandler>Egypt</jLink>, and other states negotiate an anti-<jLink data-type='L' data-strong='H0894' clickHandler>Babylonian</jLink> coalition led by <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H6667H' clickHandler>Zedekiah</jLink>.
594 BC: <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H3168H' clickHandler>Ezekiel</jLink> prophesies against Judah’s alliance with <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H4714H' clickHandler>Egypt</jLink>.

594 BC: <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H3414L' clickHandler>Jeremiah</jLink> warns in <jLink data-type='L' data-strong='H3389' clickHandler>Jerusalem</jLink> that <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H4714H' clickHandler>Egypt</jLink> cannot save Judah from <jLink data-type='L' data-strong='H0894' clickHandler>Babylon</jLink>.

ChronologyEntries.desc: <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H3414L' clickHandler>Jeremiah</jLink> imprisoned. <jLink data-type='L' data-strong='H3389' clickHandler>Jerusalem</jLink> besieged
ChronologyEntries.article: 590 BC:  The year 590 BC marked the beginning of <jLink data-type='L' data-strong='H3389' clickHandler>Jerusalem</jLink>'s final siege as <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H5019' clickHandler>Nebuchadnezzar</jLink> II's armies encircled the city on the tenth day of the tenth month, initiating the brutal blockade that would ultimately lead to the city's destruction. This siege was <jLink data-type='L' data-strong='H0894' clickHandler>Babylon</jLink>'s direct response to <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H6667H' clickHandler>Zedekiah</jLink>'s continued rebellion and his alliance with <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H4714H' clickHandler>Egypt</jLink>, representing <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H5019' clickHandler>Nebuchadnezzar</jLink>'s determination to end <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H3063G' clickHandler>Judean</jLink> resistance permanently. The siege involved sophisticated military engineering, including the construction of siege ramps, battering rams, and a complete encirclement designed to starve the city into submission. <jPara></jPara> During this same period, the prophet <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H3414L' clickHandler>Jeremiah</jLink> was imprisoned by King <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H6667H' clickHandler>Zedekiah</jLink>'s officials for his persistent advocacy of surrender to the <jLink data-type='L' data-strong='H0894' clickHandler>Babylonians</jLink>, which was viewed as treasonous by the nationalist party in <jLink data-type='L' data-strong='H3389' clickHandler>Jerusalem</jLink>. <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H3414L' clickHandler>Jeremiah</jLink>'s imprisonment (Jer.37-38) occurred after he attempted to leave <jLink data-type='L' data-strong='H3389' clickHandler>Jerusalem</jLink> during a temporary lifting of the siege when <jLink data-type='L' data-strong='H4714G' clickHandler>Egyptian</jLink> forces approached, causing the <jLink data-type='L' data-strong='H0894' clickHandler>Babylonians</jLink> to withdraw briefly. The prophet's message remained consistent throughout his captivity: <jLink data-type='L' data-strong='H3389' clickHandler>Jerusalem</jLink>'s destruction was inevitable, and survival could only be achieved through submission to <jLink data-type='L' data-strong='H0894' clickHandler>Babylonian</jLink> authority. His imprisonment in the muddy cistern and subsequent rescue by the <jLink data-type='L' data-strong='H3568A' clickHandler>Ethiopian</jLink> eunuch <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H5663' clickHandler>Ebed-melech</jLink> demonstrated both the hostility <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H3414L' clickHandler>Jeremiah</jLink> faced from <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H3063G' clickHandler>Judean</jLink> leadership and the divine protection that preserved his prophetic ministry during these final critical months.
events: 590 BC: <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H5019' clickHandler>Nebuchadnezzar</jLink> II begins the final siege of <jLink data-type='L' data-strong='H3389' clickHandler>Jerusalem</jLink>.

590 BC: <jLink data-type='L' data-strong='H0894' clickHandler>Babylonian</jLink> armies encircle and blockade <jLink data-type='L' data-strong='H3389' clickHandler>Jerusalem</jLink> in response to <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H6667H' clickHandler>Zedekiah</jLink>’s rebellion.

590 BC: <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H3414L' clickHandler>Jeremiah</jLink> is imprisoned in <jLink data-type='L' data-strong='H3389' clickHandler>Jerusalem</jLink> for urging surrender to <jLink data-type='L' data-strong='H0894' clickHandler>Babylon</jLink>.

590 BC: <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H3414L' clickHandler>Jeremiah</jLink> is thrown into a muddy cistern, then rescued by <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H5663' clickHandler>Ebed-melech</jLink>.
590 BC: <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H3414L' clickHandler>Jeremiah</jLink> continues to prophesy <jLink data-type='L' data-strong='H3389' clickHandler>Jerusalem</jLink>’s inevitable destruction.

ChronologyEntries.article: 586 BC:  <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H0203' clickHandler>On</jLink> the ninth day of the fourth month in 586 BC, after an eighteen-month siege that brought the city to the brink of starvation, <jLink data-type='L' data-strong='H0894' clickHandler>Babylonian</jLink> forces breached <jLink data-type='L' data-strong='H3389' clickHandler>Jerusalem</jLink>'s walls and captured the city, marking the end of the Kingdom of Judah and the Davidic monarchy. This was the 3rd start of the period of 70 years of captivity. King <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H6667H' clickHandler>Zedekiah</jLink> attempted to flee through the royal garden gate but was captured near <jLink data-type='L' data-strong='H3405G' clickHandler>Jericho</jLink> and brought before <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H5019' clickHandler>Nebuchadnezzar</jLink> at <jLink data-type='L' data-strong='H7247H' clickHandler>Riblah</jLink>, where he was forced to witness the execution of his sons before being blinded and taken to <jLink data-type='L' data-strong='H0894' clickHandler>Babylon</jLink> in chains. The systematic destruction that followed was comprehensive: the Temple of <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H8010' clickHandler>Solomon</jLink> was burned, the city walls were demolished, and most of the population was deported to <jLink data-type='L' data-strong='H0894' clickHandler>Babylon</jLink>, leaving only the poorest inhabitants to serve as vinedressers and farmers. <jPara></jPara> The fall of <jLink data-type='L' data-strong='H3389' clickHandler>Jerusalem</jLink> represented a catastrophic theological crisis for the Jewish people, as it challenged fundamental beliefs about God's protection of <jLink data-type='L' data-strong='H3389' clickHandler>Jerusalem</jLink> and the permanence of the Davidic covenant. The Book of Lamentations, traditionally attributed to the prophet <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H3414L' clickHandler>Jeremiah</jLink>, provides a vivid literary response to this devastation, expressing the profound grief and spiritual bewilderment experienced by the survivors. Archaeological excavations have confirmed the biblical accounts with substantial evidence of destruction layers, burnt remains, and Babylonian-style arrowheads throughout <jLink data-type='L' data-strong='H3389' clickHandler>Jerusalem</jLink> and other <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H3063G' clickHandler>Judean</jLink> cities from this period. The exile that followed fundamentally transformed <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='G2454' clickHandler>Judaism</jLink>, leading to new theological developments, the preservation of scripture, and the eventual emergence of synagogue-based worship that could function without the Temple. This event thus marks not only the end of the First Temple period but also the beginning of formative developments that would shape Jewish religion and identity for centuries to come.
events: 586 BC: <jLink data-type='L' data-strong='H0894' clickHandler>Babylonian</jLink> forces under <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H5018' clickHandler>Nebuzaradan</jLink> breach <jLink data-type='L' data-strong='H3389' clickHandler>Jerusalem</jLink>’s walls and capture the city.

586 BC: King <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H6667H' clickHandler>Zedekiah</jLink> flees, is captured, blinded, and taken to <jLink data-type='L' data-strong='H0894' clickHandler>Babylon</jLink> after seeing his sons executed.

586 BC: The Temple of <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H8010' clickHandler>Solomon</jLink> and palace are burned and destroyed by <jLink data-type='L' data-strong='H0894' clickHandler>Babylonian</jLink> troops.
586 BC: <jLink data-type='L' data-strong='H3389' clickHandler>Jerusalem</jLink>’s walls are demolished by <jLink data-type='L' data-strong='H0894' clickHandler>Babylonian</jLink> forces.

586 BC: Most of <jLink data-type='L' data-strong='H3389' clickHandler>Jerusalem</jLink>’s people suffer the third deportation of the captivity to <jLink data-type='L' data-strong='H0894' clickHandler>Babylon</jLink>, leaving only the poor.

ChronologyEntries.article: 585 BC:  The prophet <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H5662R' clickHandler>Obadiah</jLink> delivered his brief but powerful oracle against the nation of <jLink data-type='L' data-strong='H0123G' clickHandler>Edom</jLink> after the <jLink data-type='L' data-strong='H0894' clickHandler>Babylonian</jLink> destruction of <jLink data-type='L' data-strong='H3389' clickHandler>Jerusalem</jLink>. His prophecy, recorded in the shortest book of the Old Testament, specifically condemns <jLink data-type='L' data-strong='H0123G' clickHandler>Edom</jLink> for its betrayal and violence against Judah during <jLink data-type='L' data-strong='H3389' clickHandler>Jerusalem</jLink>'s fall in 586 BC. The <jLink data-type='L' data-strong='H0123G' clickHandler>Edomites</jLink>, descendants of <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H6215G' clickHandler>Esau</jLink> and therefore considered "brothers" to the <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H3478' clickHandler>Israelites</jLink>, had apparently participated in the plundering of <jLink data-type='L' data-strong='H3389' clickHandler>Jerusalem</jLink> and may have prevented fleeing <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H3057' clickHandler>Judahites</jLink> from escaping the <jLink data-type='L' data-strong='H0894' clickHandler>Babylonian</jLink> forces, making their actions particularly grievous from a covenantal perspective. <jPara></jPara> <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H5662R' clickHandler>Obadiah</jLink>'s message centers on the principle of divine retribution, declaring that <jLink data-type='L' data-strong='H0123G' clickHandler>Edom</jLink> would experience the same devastation it had inflicted upon Judah. The prophet proclaims that <jLink data-type='L' data-strong='H0123G' clickHandler>Edom</jLink>'s pride and sense of security, bolstered by their mountainous terrain around Mount <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H8165B' clickHandler>Seir</jLink>, would not protect them from divine judgment. The oracle concludes with a vision of restoration for Israel and the establishment of God's kingdom, reflecting the broader biblical theme that nations opposing God's people will ultimately face judgment while Israel experiences restoration. Archaeological evidence suggests that <jLink data-type='L' data-strong='H0123G' clickHandler>Edom</jLink> did indeed suffer significant upheaval during the sixth century BC, possibly due to pressure from <jLink data-type='L' data-strong='H0694' clickHandler>Arab</jLink> tribes, which may correspond to the fulfillment of <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H5662R' clickHandler>Obadiah</jLink>'s prophecies.
events: 585 BC: <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H5662R' clickHandler>Obadiah</jLink> delivers his oracle against <jLink data-type='L' data-strong='H0123G' clickHandler>Edom</jLink> for betraying Judah during <jLink data-type='L' data-strong='H3389' clickHandler>Jerusalem</jLink>’s fall.

585 BC: <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H5662R' clickHandler>Obadiah</jLink> prophesies divine retribution on <jLink data-type='L' data-strong='H0123G' clickHandler>Edom</jLink> for plundering <jLink data-type='L' data-strong='H3389' clickHandler>Jerusalem</jLink>.

585 BC: <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H5662R' clickHandler>Obadiah</jLink> foretells Israel’s restoration and God’s kingdom, judging <jLink data-type='L' data-strong='H0123G' clickHandler>Edom</jLink> and vindicating Judah.

ChronologyEntries.article: 570 BC:  In 570 BC, King <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H5019' clickHandler>Nebuchadnezzar</jLink> II of <jLink data-type='L' data-strong='H0894' clickHandler>Babylon</jLink> experienced a significant dream involving a great tree that reached to heaven, providing shelter and sustenance to all creatures of the earth. This dream troubled the king, leading him to summon his court advisors and magicians for interpretation, though none could explain its meaning (<jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H1835H' clickHandler>Dan</jLink>.4). <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H1840G' clickHandler>Daniel</jLink>, known in the <jLink data-type='L' data-strong='H0894' clickHandler>Babylonian</jLink> court as <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H1840G' clickHandler>Belteshazzar</jLink>, was eventually called upon to interpret the dream, revealing that the tree represented <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H5019' clickHandler>Nebuchadnezzar</jLink> himself and his vast empire that extended across the known world. <jPara></jPara> <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H1840G' clickHandler>Daniel</jLink>'s interpretation warned that the king would be "cut down" like the tree due to his pride and failure to acknowledge the sovereignty of the Most High God. The prophecy foretold that <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H5019' clickHandler>Nebuchadnezzar</jLink> would lose his sanity and live like an animal in the wilderness for "seven times" (possibly seven years) until he recognized divine authority over human kingdoms. Historical records suggest this event occurred during the height of <jLink data-type='L' data-strong='H0894' clickHandler>Babylon</jLink>'s power, when <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H5019' clickHandler>Nebuchadnezzar</jLink> had completed major construction projects including the Ishtar Gate and possibly the Hanging Gardens. The fulfillment of this prophecy (<jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H1835H' clickHandler>Dan</jLink>.4:28-37), resulted in <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H5019' clickHandler>Nebuchadnezzar</jLink>'s eventual restoration and his public acknowledgment of God's sovereignty, providing a theological lesson about divine authority over even the greatest earthly rulers.
events: 570 BC: <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H5019' clickHandler>Nebuchadnezzar</jLink> II dreams of a great tree reaching heaven in <jLink data-type='L' data-strong='H0894' clickHandler>Babylon</jLink>.
570 BC: <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H5019' clickHandler>Nebuchadnezzar</jLink>’s advisors and magicians cannot interpret his dream.

570 BC: <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H1840G' clickHandler>Daniel</jLink> interprets <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H5019' clickHandler>Nebuchadnezzar</jLink>’s dream, revealing the tree symbolizes the king and empire.

570 BC: <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H1840G' clickHandler>Daniel</jLink> warns <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H5019' clickHandler>Nebuchadnezzar</jLink> he will lose his sanity until he acknowledges God.

ChronologyEntries.article: 562 BC:  Following the death of <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H5019' clickHandler>Nebuchadnezzar</jLink> II, his successor <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H0192' clickHandler>Evil-Merodach</jLink> (Amel-Marduk) released the exiled King <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H3078' clickHandler>Jehoiachin</jLink> of Judah from prison in 562 BC, marking a significant improvement in the former monarch's circumstances after thirty-seven years of captivity. This act of clemency occurred on the twenty-seventh day of the twelfth month in the year that <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H0192' clickHandler>Evil-Merodach</jLink> became king of <jLink data-type='L' data-strong='H0894' clickHandler>Babylon</jLink> (2Ki.25:27-30; Jer.52:31-34). <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H3078' clickHandler>Jehoiachin</jLink>, who had been taken captive in 597 BC at age eighteen during his brief three-month reign, was not only freed from imprisonment but also granted a position of honor above other captive kings residing in <jLink data-type='L' data-strong='H0894' clickHandler>Babylon</jLink>. <jPara></jPara> The release included significant privileges: <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H3078' clickHandler>Jehoiachin</jLink> was provided with new clothes to replace his prison garments, given a regular allowance for his daily needs, and permitted to dine at the king's table for the remainder of his life. This dramatic change in fortune may have been part of <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H0192' clickHandler>Evil-Merodach</jLink>'s broader political strategy to gain legitimacy by showing magnanimity toward prisoners of the previous regime. Archaeological discoveries, including cuneiform tablets from <jLink data-type='L' data-strong='H0894' clickHandler>Babylon</jLink> mentioning provisions for "<jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H3078' clickHandler>Jehoiachin</jLink>, king of the land of Judah," corroborate the biblical account and demonstrate the historical reliability of these records. This event provided hope for the Jewish exiles that their circumstances might improve and possibly foreshadowed the eventual restoration that would come under <jLink data-type='L' data-strong='H6539' clickHandler>Persian</jLink> rule.
events: 562 BC: <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H5019' clickHandler>Nebuchadnezzar</jLink> II dies, ending his rule.
562 BC: <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H0192' clickHandler>Evil-Merodach</jLink> (Amel-Marduk) becomes king of <jLink data-type='L' data-strong='H0894' clickHandler>Babylon</jLink>.

562 BC: <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H0192' clickHandler>Evil-Merodach</jLink> releases <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H3078' clickHandler>Jehoiachin</jLink> of Judah from prison after thirty-seven years.
562 BC: <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H3078' clickHandler>Jehoiachin</jLink> is honored above other captive kings and eats at the king’s table.

ChronologyEntries.desc: <jChronDurationLink style='color:red'>▼</jChronDurationLink>Persia attacks after <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H1112' clickHandler>Belshazzar</jLink>’s feast.
ChronologyEntries.article: 538 BC:  The year 538 BC witnessed one of the most significant political transitions in ancient Near Eastern history as the <jLink data-type='L' data-strong='H0894' clickHandler>Babylonian</jLink> Empire fell to the forces of <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H3566' clickHandler>Cyrus</jLink> the Great of <jLink data-type='L' data-strong='H6539' clickHandler>Persia</jLink>, ending nearly seven decades of <jLink data-type='L' data-strong='H0894' clickHandler>Babylonian</jLink> hegemony. The final night of <jLink data-type='L' data-strong='H0894' clickHandler>Babylonian</jLink> rule was marked by King <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H1112' clickHandler>Belshazzar</jLink>'s great feast, during which a mysterious hand appeared and wrote on the palace wall the cryptic message "MENE, MENE, TEKEL, UPHARSIN". <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H1840G' clickHandler>Daniel</jLink> interpreted this divine writing as a pronouncement of judgment: <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H1112' clickHandler>Belshazzar</jLink>'s kingdom was numbered and finished, he had been weighed and found wanting, and his empire would be divided between the <jLink data-type='L' data-strong='H4074H' clickHandler>Medes</jLink> and <jLink data-type='L' data-strong='H6539' clickHandler>Persians</jLink> (<jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H1835H' clickHandler>Dan</jLink>.5). That very night, <jLink data-type='L' data-strong='H0894' clickHandler>Babylon</jLink> fell without a siege, and <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H1112' clickHandler>Belshazzar</jLink> was killed, fulfilling the prophetic warnings (Isa.13; Jer.25, 50, 52; Hab.2). <jPara></jPara> Following <jLink data-type='L' data-strong='H0894' clickHandler>Babylon</jLink>'s conquest, <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H1867I' clickHandler>Darius</jLink> the <jLink data-type='L' data-strong='H4074H' clickHandler>Mede</jLink> assumed administrative control over the region (<jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H1835H' clickHandler>Dan</jLink>.6), while <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H3566' clickHandler>Cyrus</jLink> the Great emerged as the supreme ruler of the new <jLink data-type='L' data-strong='H6539' clickHandler>Persian</jLink> Empire. This transition fulfilled numerous biblical prophecies (Isa.44-45) which specifically names <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H3566' clickHandler>Cyrus</jLink> as God's "anointed" shepherd who would facilitate the return of the Jewish exiles and the rebuilding of <jLink data-type='L' data-strong='H3389' clickHandler>Jerusalem</jLink>'s temple. The fall of <jLink data-type='L' data-strong='H0894' clickHandler>Babylon</jLink> represented not merely a political shift but a theological vindication of prophetic warnings and divine sovereignty. Archaeological evidence, including the <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H3566' clickHandler>Cyrus</jLink> Cylinder, corroborates the biblical account by documenting <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H3566' clickHandler>Cyrus</jLink>'s policy of allowing displaced peoples to return to their homelands and restore their religious practices, setting the stage for the Jewish restoration that would begin immediately following these events.
events: 538 BC: <jLink data-type='L' data-strong='H0894' clickHandler>Babylon</jLink> falls to <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H3566' clickHandler>Cyrus</jLink> the Great of <jLink data-type='L' data-strong='H6539' clickHandler>Persia</jLink>, ending <jLink data-type='L' data-strong='H0894' clickHandler>Babylonian</jLink> rule.

538 BC: <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H1112' clickHandler>Belshazzar</jLink> of <jLink data-type='L' data-strong='H0894' clickHandler>Babylon</jLink> holds a feast where a mysterious hand writes on the wall.

538 BC: <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H1840G' clickHandler>Daniel</jLink> interprets the writing for <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H1112' clickHandler>Belshazzar</jLink>, declaring his kingdom will fall.

538 BC: <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H1112' clickHandler>Belshazzar</jLink> is killed the night <jLink data-type='L' data-strong='H0894' clickHandler>Babylon</jLink> falls to <jLink data-type='L' data-strong='H6539' clickHandler>Persia</jLink>.

538 BC: <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H1867I' clickHandler>Darius</jLink> the <jLink data-type='L' data-strong='H4074H' clickHandler>Mede</jLink> takes control of <jLink data-type='L' data-strong='H0894' clickHandler>Babylon</jLink> after its conquest.

ChronologyEntries.desc: <jChronDurationLink style='color:black'>▼</jChronDurationLink><jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H2216' clickHandler>Zerubbabel</jLink> sent to <jLink data-type='L' data-strong='H3389' clickHandler>Jerusalem</jLink> by <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H3566' clickHandler>Cyrus</jLink>
ChronologyEntries.article: 536 BC:  In 536 BC, <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H3566' clickHandler>Cyrus</jLink> the Great issued his famous decree permitting the Jewish exiles to return to <jLink data-type='L' data-strong='H3389' clickHandler>Jerusalem</jLink> and rebuild the temple, fulfilling the prophecies regarding the seventy-year exile (Jer.25:9-11). This is approximately 70 years after the 1st start of the period of exile in 607 BC. Prophecy  specifically named <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H3566' clickHandler>Cyrus</jLink> as the one who would facilitate <jLink data-type='L' data-strong='H3389' clickHandler>Jerusalem</jLink>'s restoration (Isa.44:28). This edict (Ezr.1-6) not only authorized the return but also provided financial support and the restoration of the sacred vessels that <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H5019' clickHandler>Nebuchadnezzar</jLink> had taken from <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H8010' clickHandler>Solomon</jLink>'s temple. <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H3566' clickHandler>Cyrus</jLink>'s decree represented a revolutionary departure from typical ancient Near Eastern conquest policies, reflecting the <jLink data-type='L' data-strong='H6539' clickHandler>Persian</jLink> administrative philosophy of allowing subject peoples to maintain their cultural and religious identities while remaining politically loyal to the empire. <jPara></jPara> <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H2216' clickHandler>Zerubbabel</jLink>, a descendant of King <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H1732' clickHandler>David</jLink> through the line of <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H3078' clickHandler>Jehoiachin</jLink>, was appointed to lead the first wave of returning exiles, numbering approximately 42,360 people according to the lists (Ezr.2; Neh.7). The returnees included not only <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H3057' clickHandler>Judahites</jLink> but also members of other tribes, priests, <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H3878' clickHandler>Levites</jLink>, temple servants, and various craftsmen necessary for the rebuilding project. Upon reaching <jLink data-type='L' data-strong='H3389' clickHandler>Jerusalem</jLink>, <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H2216' clickHandler>Zerubbabel</jLink> and the high priest <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H3442G' clickHandler>Jeshua</jLink> (<jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H3091J' clickHandler>Joshua</jLink>) immediately began organizing the restoration efforts, first rebuilding the altar to resume sacrificial worship and then laying the foundation of the new temple. This return marked the beginning of the Second Temple period and represented a crucial fulfillment of prophetic promises that had sustained Jewish hope throughout the exile, though the actual completion of the temple would not occur until 516 BC due to various political and economic challenges.
events: 536 BC: <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H3566' clickHandler>Cyrus</jLink> the Great issues a decree allowing Jewish exiles to return and rebuild the temple.

536 BC: <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H3566' clickHandler>Cyrus</jLink> restores sacred vessels from <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H8010' clickHandler>Solomon</jLink>’s temple to the Jewish exiles.

536 BC: <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H2216' clickHandler>Zerubbabel</jLink> and <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H3442G' clickHandler>Jeshua</jLink> lead the first group of returning exiles to <jLink data-type='L' data-strong='H3389' clickHandler>Jerusalem</jLink>.

536 BC: About 42,360 exiles return from <jLink data-type='L' data-strong='H0894' clickHandler>Babylon</jLink> to <jLink data-type='L' data-strong='H3389' clickHandler>Jerusalem</jLink> under <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H2216' clickHandler>Zerubbabel</jLink>.

536 BC: The altar is rebuilt and sacrifices resume under <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H3442G' clickHandler>Jeshua</jLink> and <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H2216' clickHandler>Zerubbabel</jLink>.

ChronologyEntries.desc: <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H1840G' clickHandler>Daniel</jLink>'s vision of the future
ChronologyEntries.article: 535 BC:  In 535 BC, during the third year of <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H3566' clickHandler>Cyrus</jLink>'s reign over the <jLink data-type='L' data-strong='H6539' clickHandler>Persian</jLink> Empire, the prophet <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H1840G' clickHandler>Daniel</jLink> received one of his most detailed and complex revelations concerning future events (<jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H1835H' clickHandler>Dan</jLink>.10-12). This vision, which came to <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H1840G' clickHandler>Daniel</jLink> while he was mourning and fasting by the <jLink data-type='L' data-strong='H2313' clickHandler>Tigris</jLink> River, was delivered through an angelic messenger who appeared in glorious form and provided extensive prophecies about future conflicts involving the kingdoms of <jLink data-type='L' data-strong='H6539' clickHandler>Persia</jLink>, <jLink data-type='L' data-strong='H3120H' clickHandler>Greece</jLink>, and the ultimate fate of Israel. The vision encompasses what scholars generally interpret as the <jLink data-type='L' data-strong='H6539' clickHandler>Persian</jLink> period, the conquests of Alexander the Great, the subsequent division of his empire among the Diadochi, and the conflicts between the Ptolemaic and Seleucid kingdoms that would directly impact the Jewish people. <jPara></jPara> The angelic revelation in <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H1835H' clickHandler>Dan</jLink>.11-12 provides remarkably detailed predictions about future rulers and conflicts, including references to the "king of the South" (<jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H4714H' clickHandler>Egypt</jLink>) and the "king of the North" (<jLink data-type='L' data-strong='H0758I' clickHandler>Syria</jLink>), culminating in prophecies about a period of great tribulation and the ultimate resurrection of the dead. These prophecies were given during a time when the Jewish restoration was beginning under <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H3566' clickHandler>Cyrus</jLink> but faced significant opposition (Ezr.4:5) where adversaries attempted to frustrate the rebuilding efforts throughout the reigns of <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H3566' clickHandler>Cyrus</jLink> and <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H1867G' clickHandler>Darius</jLink>. <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H1840G' clickHandler>Daniel</jLink>'s vision provided theological assurance that despite future conflicts and periods of persecution, God's people would ultimately be delivered and that divine sovereignty would prevail over all human kingdoms, offering hope and encouragement to the Jewish community as they navigated the challenges of restoration and rebuilding their national identity.
events: 535 BC: <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H1840G' clickHandler>Daniel</jLink> receives a prophetic vision by the <jLink data-type='L' data-strong='H2313' clickHandler>Tigris</jLink> River about future empires and Israel.
535 BC: <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H1840G' clickHandler>Daniel</jLink>’s revelation includes detailed prophecies of future rulers, wars, tribulation, and resurrection.

535 BC: Adversaries of the <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='G2454' clickHandler>Jews</jLink> attempt to frustrate the rebuilding of the Temple and <jLink data-type='L' data-strong='H3389' clickHandler>Jerusalem</jLink>.

ChronologyEntries.article: 529 BC:  The accession of <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H0325' clickHandler>Ahasuerus</jLink>, historically identified as Cambyses II, son of <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H3566' clickHandler>Cyrus</jLink> the Great, to the <jLink data-type='L' data-strong='H6539' clickHandler>Persian</jLink> throne in 529 BC marked the beginning of increased opposition to the Jewish rebuilding efforts in <jLink data-type='L' data-strong='H3389' clickHandler>Jerusalem</jLink> (Ezr.4:6). This is approximately 70 years after the 2nd start of the period of exile in 597 BC.  Formal accusations were filed against the inhabitants of Judah and <jLink data-type='L' data-strong='H3389' clickHandler>Jerusalem</jLink> by their adversaries. These opponents, likely including <jLink data-type='L' data-strong='H8111' clickHandler>Samaritan</jLink> officials and other regional administrators, wrote letters to the <jLink data-type='L' data-strong='H6539' clickHandler>Persian</jLink> court alleging that the returning <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='G2454' clickHandler>Jews</jLink> were engaging in rebellious activities and that the rebuilding of <jLink data-type='L' data-strong='H3389' clickHandler>Jerusalem</jLink> posed a threat to imperial interests. <jPara></jPara> Cambyses' reign was characterized by military campaigns, particularly his conquest of <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H4714H' clickHandler>Egypt</jLink> in 525 BC, which may have contributed to a more suspicious attitude toward potential sources of instability within the empire. The opposition during this period appears to have been successful in temporarily halting or significantly slowing the reconstruction work in <jLink data-type='L' data-strong='H3389' clickHandler>Jerusalem</jLink>, creating frustration among the returnees and testing their resolve. Archaeological evidence from this period shows limited construction activity in <jLink data-type='L' data-strong='H3389' clickHandler>Jerusalem</jLink>, supporting the biblical account of administrative challenges faced by the Jewish community. This opposition would continue into the subsequent reign, demonstrating the persistent political and ethnic tensions that complicated the restoration process and required divine intervention and prophetic encouragement to overcome. 597
events: 529 BC: <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H0325' clickHandler>Ahasuerus</jLink> (Cambyses II) succeeds <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H3566' clickHandler>Cyrus</jLink> the Great as king of <jLink data-type='L' data-strong='H6539' clickHandler>Persia</jLink>.
529 BC: Judah’s adversaries file accusations against the Jewish returnees to the <jLink data-type='L' data-strong='H6539' clickHandler>Persian</jLink> court.
529 BC: Opposition from regional officials slows or halts <jLink data-type='L' data-strong='H3389' clickHandler>Jerusalem</jLink>’s reconstruction.

ChronologyEntries.desc: Emperor <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H0783A' clickHandler>Artaxerxes</jLink> (<jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H1867H' clickHandler>Darius</jLink>)
ChronologyEntries.article: 522 BC:  In 522 BC, the <jLink data-type='L' data-strong='H6539' clickHandler>Persian</jLink> throne passed to <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H0783A' clickHandler>Artaxerxes</jLink>, historically identified with <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H1867H' clickHandler>Darius</jLink> I (<jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H1867H' clickHandler>Darius</jLink> the Great), who would prove instrumental in the eventual completion of the Jewish temple reconstruction project. This transition was marked by continued correspondence between the opponents of the Jewish restoration and the <jLink data-type='L' data-strong='H6539' clickHandler>Persian</jLink> administration, with letters being written in <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H0762' clickHandler>Aramaic</jLink> and translated for the court's consideration (Ezr.4:7). The political situation during <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H1867H' clickHandler>Darius</jLink>'s early reign was initially unstable, as he had to suppress several revolts throughout the empire, which may have made <jLink data-type='L' data-strong='H6539' clickHandler>Persian</jLink> officials more cautious about potential sources of unrest in their territories. <jPara></jPara> However, unlike his predecessors, <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H1867H' clickHandler>Darius</jLink> would eventually prove sympathetic to the Jewish cause, particularly after the prophetic ministry of <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H2292A' clickHandler>Haggai</jLink> and <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H2148v' clickHandler>Zechariah</jLink> encouraged the people to resume temple construction. The administrative challenges faced during the early years of his reign (Ezr.4:7) would eventually give way to active royal support for the temple project. <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H1867H' clickHandler>Darius</jLink>'s later search of the royal archives would uncover <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H3566' clickHandler>Cyrus</jLink>'s original decree authorizing the temple reconstruction, leading to renewed <jLink data-type='L' data-strong='H6539' clickHandler>Persian</jLink> backing for the project and its eventual completion in 516 BC. This period demonstrates the complex interplay between local opposition, imperial administration, and divine providence in the restoration of Jewish worship and identity during the <jLink data-type='L' data-strong='H6539' clickHandler>Persian</jLink> period.
events: 522 BC: <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H0783A' clickHandler>Artaxerxes</jLink> (<jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H1867H' clickHandler>Darius</jLink> I) becomes king of <jLink data-type='L' data-strong='H6539' clickHandler>Persia</jLink>.

522 BC: Opponents of Jewish restoration send <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H0762' clickHandler>Aramaic</jLink> letters to the <jLink data-type='L' data-strong='H6539' clickHandler>Persian</jLink> administration.
522 BC: <jLink data-type='L' data-strong='H6539' clickHandler>Persian</jLink> officials process opposition letters, causing administrative delays in reconstruction.

ChronologyEntries.desc: <jChronDurationLink style='color:green'>▼</jChronDurationLink><jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H2148v' clickHandler>Zechariah</jLink>; <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H2292A' clickHandler>Haggai</jLink>; <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H2216' clickHandler>Zerubbubel</jLink> & <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H3091J' clickHandler>Joshua</jLink>
ChronologyEntries.article: 520 BC:  The prophets <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H2292A' clickHandler>Haggai</jLink> and <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H2148v' clickHandler>Zechariah</jLink> initiated a crucial period of religious renewal among the Jewish community that had returned from <jLink data-type='L' data-strong='H0894' clickHandler>Babylonian</jLink> exile. The temple reconstruction in <jLink data-type='L' data-strong='H3389' clickHandler>Jerusalem</jLink>, which had stalled for several years, was reinvigorated through their prophetic messages recorded in the books of <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H2292A' clickHandler>Haggai</jLink> and the first half of <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H2148v' clickHandler>Zechariah</jLink> (Zec.1-8). <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H2216' clickHandler>Zerubbabel</jLink>, who served as the Persian-appointed governor of Judah, and <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H3091J' clickHandler>Joshua</jLink>, the high priest, emerged as the primary leaders coordinating the physical reconstruction efforts. <jPara></jPara> The prophetic exhortations of this year emphasized the spiritual and communal importance of completing the temple as the center of Jewish worship and identity. Under the relatively tolerant <jLink data-type='L' data-strong='H6539' clickHandler>Persian</jLink> administrative system, which allowed subject peoples to maintain their religious practices, these leaders successfully mobilized the returned exiles to resume construction work. This period represents a pivotal moment in post-exilic <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='G2454' clickHandler>Judaism</jLink>, when prophetic encouragement combined with political leadership to restore the central institution of Jewish religious life.
events: 520 BC: <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H2292A' clickHandler>Haggai</jLink> urges the <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='G2454' clickHandler>Jews</jLink> in <jLink data-type='L' data-strong='H3389' clickHandler>Jerusalem</jLink> to resume rebuilding the temple.

520 BC: <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H2148v' clickHandler>Zechariah</jLink> begins his prophetic ministry in <jLink data-type='L' data-strong='H3389' clickHandler>Jerusalem</jLink>, encouraging the people.
520 BC: <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H2216' clickHandler>Zerubbabel</jLink> and <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H3091J' clickHandler>Joshua</jLink> lead renewed efforts to rebuild the temple.
520 BC: The returned Jewish exiles resume temple construction in <jLink data-type='L' data-strong='H3389' clickHandler>Jerusalem</jLink>.

ChronologyEntries.desc: <jChronDurationLink style='color:black'>▼</jChronDurationLink><jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H0635' clickHandler>Esther</jLink> marries <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H0325' clickHandler>Ahasuerus</jLink> (Xerxes I)
ChronologyEntries.article: 519 BC:  The year 519 BC witnessed significant events in the <jLink data-type='L' data-strong='H6539' clickHandler>Persian</jLink> royal court involving Emperor <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H0325' clickHandler>Ahasuerus</jLink>, commonly identified by scholars with Xerxes I, and his queen <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H2060' clickHandler>Vashti</jLink> (Est.1-3). During a lavish royal banquet, Queen <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H2060' clickHandler>Vashti</jLink> refused the king's command to appear before his guests, an act that constituted a serious breach of <jLink data-type='L' data-strong='H6539' clickHandler>Persian</jLink> court protocol, which demanded absolute obedience to royal commands. This incident reflected the strict hierarchical nature of <jLink data-type='L' data-strong='H6539' clickHandler>Persian</jLink> court culture, where disobedience by even the highest-ranking royal consort was considered intolerable. <jPara></jPara> Following consultation with his legal advisors, as was customary in <jLink data-type='L' data-strong='H6539' clickHandler>Persian</jLink> administrative practice, <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H0325' clickHandler>Ahasuerus</jLink> removed <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H2060' clickHandler>Vashti</jLink> from her position as queen. This decision was formalized through an irreversible royal decree, demonstrating the legalistic nature of <jLink data-type='L' data-strong='H6539' clickHandler>Persian</jLink> governance and the influence of court counselors on imperial policy. The removal of <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H2060' clickHandler>Vashti</jLink> set in motion the events that would eventually lead to <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H0635' clickHandler>Esther</jLink>'s elevation to the throne, establishing the historical context for the subsequent narrative of Jewish survival within the <jLink data-type='L' data-strong='H6539' clickHandler>Persian</jLink> Empire.
events: 519 BC: Queen <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H2060' clickHandler>Vashti</jLink> refuses Emperor <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H0325' clickHandler>Ahasuerus</jLink>' (Xerxes I) command in <jLink data-type='L' data-strong='H7800' clickHandler>Susa</jLink>.
519 BC: <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H0325' clickHandler>Ahasuerus</jLink> deposes <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H2060' clickHandler>Vashti</jLink> by royal decree after legal consultation.

ChronologyEntries.article: 518 BC:  The temple building efforts experienced renewed momentum in 518 BC (Ezr.5:6; Zec.7-8). This was approximately 70 years after the 3rd start of the period of exile in 586 BC.
