Renewed commitment likely resulted from the continued prophetic encouragement of <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H2148v' clickHandler>Zechariah</jLink> and the successful organizational efforts of <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H2216' clickHandler>Zerubbabel</jLink> and <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H3091J' clickHandler>Joshua</jLink> established two years earlier. The <jLink data-type='L' data-strong='H6539' clickHandler>Persian</jLink> administration's ongoing support for local religious restoration projects provided the necessary political stability for the reconstruction to proceed effectively. <jPara></jPara> The renewal described in the biblical texts suggests that despite initial enthusiasm, the temple rebuilding faced practical challenges that required sustained prophetic and administrative attention. The prophetic messages (Zec.7-8) during this period addressed both the spiritual significance of the temple and practical concerns about religious observances, indicating that the project involved not only physical construction but also the restoration of proper liturgical practices within the post-exilic Jewish community. 586
events: 518 BC: <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H2216' clickHandler>Zerubbabel</jLink> and <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H3091J' clickHandler>Joshua</jLink> lead renewed temple rebuilding in <jLink data-type='L' data-strong='H3389' clickHandler>Jerusalem</jLink> with <jLink data-type='L' data-strong='H6539' clickHandler>Persian</jLink> support.

518 BC: <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H2148v' clickHandler>Zechariah</jLink> encourages temple reconstruction and spiritual renewal in <jLink data-type='L' data-strong='H3389' clickHandler>Jerusalem</jLink>.
518 BC: <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H2148v' clickHandler>Zechariah</jLink> addresses proper religious observances and the temple’s spiritual significance.

ChronologyEntries.article: 516 BC:  The dedication of the Second Temple in <jLink data-type='L' data-strong='H3389' clickHandler>Jerusalem</jLink> occurred in 516 BC, marking the completion of the reconstruction project that had been initiated decades earlier following the return from <jLink data-type='L' data-strong='H0894' clickHandler>Babylonian</jLink> exile. The Temple was finished "on the third day of the month of <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H0143' clickHandler>Adar</jLink>, in the sixth year of King <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H1867H' clickHandler>Darius</jLink>," and the <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H3478' clickHandler>Israelites</jLink> celebrated the dedication with great joy, offering sacrifices and reinstating the <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H6453' clickHandler>Passover</jLink> festival (Ezr.6:15-22). The priests representing the families who had returned from exile (Ezr.2:36-39), played central roles in reestablishing the sacrificial system and proper liturgical practices. <jPara></jPara> This dedication represented far more than the completion of a building; it symbolized the restoration of Jewish religious identity and the fulfillment of prophetic promises regarding the return from exile. The event provided a focal point for community cohesion among the returned exiles, involving priests, <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H3878' clickHandler>Levites</jLink>, and laypeople in ceremonies that reaffirmed their commitment to their ancestral faith and traditions. The successful completion of this project, which had faced various interruptions and challenges over the preceding decades, demonstrated the <jLink data-type='L' data-strong='H6539' clickHandler>Persian</jLink> Empire's tolerance for local religious practices while establishing <jLink data-type='L' data-strong='H3389' clickHandler>Jerusalem</jLink> once again as the center of Jewish worship and identity.
events: 516 BC: The Second Temple in <jLink data-type='L' data-strong='H3389' clickHandler>Jerusalem</jLink> is completed in the sixth year of King <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H1867H' clickHandler>Darius</jLink>.
516 BC: The <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H3478' clickHandler>Israelites</jLink> joyfully dedicate the completed Second Temple with sacrifices.
516 BC: Returned exiles celebrate <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H6453' clickHandler>Passover</jLink> at the newly dedicated temple.
516 BC: Priests resume sacrifices and liturgical duties at the Second Temple.

ChronologyEntries.article: 510 BC:  In 510 BC, the <jLink data-type='L' data-strong='H6539' clickHandler>Persian</jLink> Empire witnessed a significant crisis involving the Jewish population, known as the Plot of <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H2001' clickHandler>Haman</jLink> (Est.3-8). <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H2001' clickHandler>Haman</jLink>, who held the powerful position of vizier or chief minister under Emperor <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H0325' clickHandler>Ahasuerus</jLink>, orchestrated a comprehensive plan to annihilate the Jewish people throughout the empire, motivated by personal animosity toward <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H4782H' clickHandler>Mordecai</jLink>, a Jewish court official who refused to pay him homage. Utilizing his administrative authority and access to the royal seal, <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H2001' clickHandler>Haman</jLink> secured the king's approval for an empire-wide decree authorizing the destruction of the <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='G2454' clickHandler>Jews</jLink>, demonstrating both the significant power wielded by high-ranking <jLink data-type='L' data-strong='H6539' clickHandler>Persian</jLink> officials and the potential for personal grievances to influence imperial policy. <jPara></jPara> The plot was ultimately thwarted through the intervention of Queen <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H0635' clickHandler>Esther</jLink> and <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H4782H' clickHandler>Mordecai</jLink>, whose access to the king enabled them to expose <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H2001' clickHandler>Haman</jLink>'s scheme and secure a counter-decree allowing the <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='G2454' clickHandler>Jews</jLink> to defend themselves. This episode illustrates the volatile nature of <jLink data-type='L' data-strong='H6539' clickHandler>Persian</jLink> court politics, where personal relationships and proximity to the monarch could rapidly alter political fortunes. The successful resolution of this crisis led to the establishment of the festival of <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H6332' clickHandler>Purim</jLink> and highlighted both the precarious position of diaspora <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='G2454' clickHandler>Jews</jLink> within the <jLink data-type='L' data-strong='H6539' clickHandler>Persian</jLink> Empire and the potential for royal favor to dramatically affect their survival and prosperity.
events: 510 BC: <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H2001' clickHandler>Haman</jLink>, vizier under <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H0325' clickHandler>Ahasuerus</jLink> (Xerxes I), secured a royal decree in <jLink data-type='L' data-strong='H7800' clickHandler>Susa</jLink> to annihilate all <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='G2454' clickHandler>Jews</jLink> in the <jLink data-type='L' data-strong='H6539' clickHandler>Persian</jLink> Empire due to his conflict with <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H4782H' clickHandler>Mordecai</jLink>.

510 BC: <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H0325' clickHandler>Ahasuerus</jLink>, influenced by <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H2001' clickHandler>Haman</jLink>, issued an empire-wide decree to destroy the <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='G2454' clickHandler>Jews</jLink>.

510 BC: <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H0635' clickHandler>Esther</jLink> and <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H4782H' clickHandler>Mordecai</jLink> intervened at the <jLink data-type='L' data-strong='H6539' clickHandler>Persian</jLink> court in <jLink data-type='L' data-strong='H7800' clickHandler>Susa</jLink>, pleading with <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H0325' clickHandler>Ahasuerus</jLink> for the <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='G2454' clickHandler>Jews</jLink>’ protection.

510 BC: <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H2001' clickHandler>Haman</jLink> was executed in <jLink data-type='L' data-strong='H7800' clickHandler>Susa</jLink> by order of <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H0325' clickHandler>Ahasuerus</jLink> after his plot was revealed.

510 BC: A counter-decree was issued from <jLink data-type='L' data-strong='H7800' clickHandler>Susa</jLink> allowing <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='G2454' clickHandler>Jews</jLink> to defend themselves.

ChronologyEntries.article: 509 BC:  In 509 BC, the Jewish communities throughout the <jLink data-type='L' data-strong='H6539' clickHandler>Persian</jLink> Empire celebrated the first Feast of <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H6332' clickHandler>Purim</jLink>, commemorating their miraculous deliverance from the genocidal plot orchestrated by <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H2001' clickHandler>Haman</jLink>, the vizier of King <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H0325' clickHandler>Ahasuerus</jLink> (Xerxes). This celebration (Est.8:17), followed the successful intervention of Queen <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H0635' clickHandler>Esther</jLink> and <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H4782H' clickHandler>Mordecai</jLink>, who secured a royal counter-decree allowing the <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='G2454' clickHandler>Jews</jLink> to defend themselves against their enemies. The verse describes widespread "gladness and joy among the <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='G2454' clickHandler>Jews</jLink>, a feast and a holiday," while noting that "many from the peoples of the country declared themselves <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='G2454' clickHandler>Jews</jLink>, for fear of the <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='G2454' clickHandler>Jews</jLink> had fallen on them". <jPara></jPara> The establishment of <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H6332' clickHandler>Purim</jLink> in this year represents a pivotal moment in diaspora Jewish identity, creating an annual festival that would commemorate both divine providence and Jewish survival under foreign rule. This event occurred seventy years after the third captivity period, connecting it to broader patterns of exile and restoration in Jewish history. This celebration institutionalized the memory of how political access, courageous advocacy, and divine intervention could overturn seemingly hopeless circumstances for the Jewish people living under <jLink data-type='L' data-strong='H6539' clickHandler>Persian</jLink> administration.
events: 509 BC: Jewish communities across the <jLink data-type='L' data-strong='H6539' clickHandler>Persian</jLink> Empire celebrated the first <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H6332' clickHandler>Purim</jLink>, rejoicing in their deliverance.
509 BC: <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='G2454' clickHandler>Jews</jLink> throughout the empire experienced widespread joy, feasting, and festivity.

509 BC: Many <jLink data-type='L' data-strong='H6539' clickHandler>Persians</jLink> identified as <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='G2454' clickHandler>Jews</jLink> out of fear and respect following the <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='G2454' clickHandler>Jews</jLink>’ deliverance.

ChronologyEntries.desc: <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H0783A' clickHandler>Artaxerxes</jLink> I Longimanus of <jLink data-type='L' data-strong='H6539' clickHandler>Persia</jLink>
ChronologyEntries.article: 465 BC:  The year 465 BC marked the accession of <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H0783A' clickHandler>Artaxerxes</jLink> I Longimanus to the <jLink data-type='L' data-strong='H6539' clickHandler>Persian</jLink> throne, beginning a reign that would prove particularly significant for Jewish history and biblical events. His ascension to power established the political context for subsequent developments in <jLink data-type='L' data-strong='H3389' clickHandler>Jerusalem</jLink>, including major religious and administrative reforms that would be implemented under his authority. <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H0783A' clickHandler>Artaxerxes</jLink> I inherited the <jLink data-type='L' data-strong='H6539' clickHandler>Persian</jLink> Empire's generally tolerant policy toward subject peoples' religious practices, a stance that would directly benefit the Jewish community in their ongoing efforts to consolidate their post-exilic identity. <jPara></jPara> The new king's reign would later intersect with crucial biblical narratives, most notably through his decision to send <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H5830G' clickHandler>Ezra</jLink> the scribe to <jLink data-type='L' data-strong='H3389' clickHandler>Jerusalem</jLink> with extensive authority and resources for reform. This initial year of his rule thus set the stage for the significant religious and cultural developments that would unfold in subsequent decades, demonstrating how changes in imperial leadership could create new opportunities for subject communities to strengthen their religious and ethnic identities within the broader <jLink data-type='L' data-strong='H6539' clickHandler>Persian</jLink> administrative system.
events: 465 BC: <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H0783A' clickHandler>Artaxerxes</jLink> I Longimanus succeeded Xerxes I as king of the <jLink data-type='L' data-strong='H6539' clickHandler>Persian</jLink> Empire.

ChronologyEntries.desc: <jChronDurationLink style='color:black'>▼</jChronDurationLink><jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H5830G' clickHandler>Ezra</jLink> sent by <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H0783A' clickHandler>Artaxerxes</jLink>; <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H2148v' clickHandler>Zechariah</jLink> 9-14;
ChronologyEntries.article: 458 BC:  In 458 BC, two significant developments occurred that shaped the trajectory of post-exilic <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='G2454' clickHandler>Judaism</jLink>: the prophetic oracles (Zec.9-14) and King <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H0783A' clickHandler>Artaxerxes</jLink> I's commissioning of <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H5830G' clickHandler>Ezra</jLink> for a crucial mission to <jLink data-type='L' data-strong='H3389' clickHandler>Jerusalem</jLink>. <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H2148v' clickHandler>Zechariah</jLink>'s later prophecies, dating to this period, shifted from earlier messages encouraging Temple reconstruction to apocalyptic and messianic themes, including the coming of a humble king (often interpreted as messianic, Zec.9:9), the judgment of Israel's enemies, and visions of <jLink data-type='L' data-strong='H3389' clickHandler>Jerusalem</jLink>'s future purification and restoration. These oracles reflected the ongoing hopes and challenges of the Jewish community living under <jLink data-type='L' data-strong='H6539' clickHandler>Persian</jLink> rule, addressing both immediate concerns and ultimate expectations for divine intervention. <jPara></jPara> Also, <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H0783A' clickHandler>Artaxerxes</jLink> issued a decree authorizing <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H5830G' clickHandler>Ezra</jLink>, a priest and scribe, to lead a group of exiles back to <jLink data-type='L' data-strong='H3389' clickHandler>Jerusalem</jLink> with unprecedented authority to implement religious and administrative reforms. The king provided <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H5830G' clickHandler>Ezra</jLink> with resources, letters of support, and the power to enforce the Law of <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H4872' clickHandler>Moses</jLink> throughout Judah and <jLink data-type='L' data-strong='H3389' clickHandler>Jerusalem</jLink> (Ezr.7-9). <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H5830G' clickHandler>Ezra</jLink>'s mission focused particularly on addressing issues of intermarriage with surrounding peoples and strengthening adherence to Torah observance, reforms that aimed to preserve the distinctiveness of the returned exile community. This dual development of prophetic vision and practical reform work demonstrated how divine inspiration and imperial authorization could combine to strengthen Jewish religious identity in the post-exilic period.
events: 458 BC: <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H2148v' clickHandler>Zechariah</jLink> delivered apocalyptic and messianic prophecies in <jLink data-type='L' data-strong='H3389' clickHandler>Jerusalem</jLink>.

458 BC: <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H0783A' clickHandler>Artaxerxes</jLink> I commissioned <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H5830G' clickHandler>Ezra</jLink> to lead exiles from <jLink data-type='L' data-strong='H0894' clickHandler>Babylon</jLink> to <jLink data-type='L' data-strong='H3389' clickHandler>Jerusalem</jLink>.

458 BC: <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H5830G' clickHandler>Ezra</jLink> arrived in <jLink data-type='L' data-strong='H3389' clickHandler>Jerusalem</jLink> with imperial support to enforce the Law of <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H4872' clickHandler>Moses</jLink> and reforms.

458 BC: <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H5830G' clickHandler>Ezra</jLink> began religious reforms in <jLink data-type='L' data-strong='H3389' clickHandler>Jerusalem</jLink>, addressing intermarriage and Torah observance.

ChronologyEntries.article: 456 BC:  In 456 BC, <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H5830G' clickHandler>Ezra</jLink> the priest and scribe led the Jewish community in <jLink data-type='L' data-strong='H3389' clickHandler>Jerusalem</jLink> through a significant covenant renewal ceremony, as recorded in <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H5830G' clickHandler>Ezra</jLink> chapter 10. This covenant specifically addressed the widespread practice of intermarriage between <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H3478' clickHandler>Israelites</jLink> and foreign peoples, which was viewed as a serious violation of the Mosaic covenant and a threat to the community's religious and cultural identity. The crisis had emerged following <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H5830G' clickHandler>Ezra</jLink>'s arrival in <jLink data-type='L' data-strong='H3389' clickHandler>Jerusalem</jLink> two years earlier, when he discovered that many Jewish men, including priests, <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H3878' clickHandler>Levites</jLink>, and officials, had taken foreign wives and were raising children who did not follow Jewish law. <jPara></jPara> The covenant ceremony involved public confession, weeping, and a solemn commitment by the people to separate themselves from foreign influences and send away their non-Jewish wives and children. This drastic action, while causing personal hardship, was deemed necessary to preserve the distinctiveness of the Jewish community and ensure faithful adherence to the law of <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H4872' clickHandler>Moses</jLink>. The event represents a pivotal moment in post-exilic <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='G2454' clickHandler>Judaism</jLink>, establishing precedents for religious purity and community boundaries that would influence Jewish identity for centuries to come.
events: 456 BC: <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H5830G' clickHandler>Ezra</jLink> led a public covenant renewal ceremony in <jLink data-type='L' data-strong='H3389' clickHandler>Jerusalem</jLink>, addressing intermarriage.
456 BC: The Jewish community in <jLink data-type='L' data-strong='H3389' clickHandler>Jerusalem</jLink> publicly confessed intermarriage and repented.
456 BC: The people committed to end intermarriages to restore Mosaic law observance.

ChronologyEntries.desc: <jChronDurationLink style='color:black'>▼</jChronDurationLink><jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H5166H' clickHandler>Nehemiah</jLink> sent to rebuild walls
ChronologyEntries.article: 445 BC:  King <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H0783A' clickHandler>Artaxerxes</jLink> I of <jLink data-type='L' data-strong='H6539' clickHandler>Persia</jLink> authorized <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H5166H' clickHandler>Nehemiah</jLink>, his Jewish cupbearer, to return to <jLink data-type='L' data-strong='H3389' clickHandler>Jerusalem</jLink> in 445 BC with the crucial mission of rebuilding the city's fortification walls. This event, documented in <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H5166H' clickHandler>Nehemiah</jLink> (Neh.1-12) and referenced prophetically (<jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H1835H' clickHandler>Dan</jLink>.9:25), marked a significant phase in <jLink data-type='L' data-strong='H3389' clickHandler>Jerusalem</jLink>'s restoration following the <jLink data-type='L' data-strong='H0894' clickHandler>Babylonian</jLink> exile. <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H5166H' clickHandler>Nehemiah</jLink>'s appointment as governor came with royal backing, resources, and authority to organize the reconstruction project despite opposition from local adversaries such as <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H5571G' clickHandler>Sanballat</jLink> the <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H2772' clickHandler>Horonite</jLink> and <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H2900I' clickHandler>Tobiah</jLink> the <jLink data-type='L' data-strong='H5983' clickHandler>Ammonite</jLink>. <jPara></jPara> The wall reconstruction was completed in fifty-two days (Neh.6:15), representing both practical security for the vulnerable city and symbolic restoration of Jewish autonomy. Archaeological excavations in <jLink data-type='L' data-strong='H3389' clickHandler>Jerusalem</jLink> have uncovered Persian-period fortification remains consistent with this biblical account, including wall segments, towers, and gates constructed with rough-hewn stones and reused materials, reflecting the urgent nature of the project. Beyond the physical reconstruction, <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H5166H' clickHandler>Nehemiah</jLink> instituted important religious and social reforms, including the public reading of the law, celebration of festivals, and measures to address economic injustice within the community.
events: 445 BC: <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H0783A' clickHandler>Artaxerxes</jLink> I appointed <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H5166H' clickHandler>Nehemiah</jLink> governor and sent him to rebuild <jLink data-type='L' data-strong='H3389' clickHandler>Jerusalem</jLink>’s walls.

445 BC: <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H5166H' clickHandler>Nehemiah</jLink> arrived in <jLink data-type='L' data-strong='H3389' clickHandler>Jerusalem</jLink> with royal support for reconstruction.

445 BC: <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H5166H' clickHandler>Nehemiah</jLink> led the rebuilding of <jLink data-type='L' data-strong='H3389' clickHandler>Jerusalem</jLink>’s walls in fifty-two days despite opposition.
445 BC: <jLink data-type='L' data-strong='H3389' clickHandler>Jerusalem</jLink>’s wall was completed, restoring security and symbolic autonomy.

445 BC: <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H5830G' clickHandler>Ezra</jLink> and <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H5166H' clickHandler>Nehemiah</jLink> led a public reading of the Law, renewing the covenant.

ChronologyEntries.desc: <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H5166H' clickHandler>Nehemiah</jLink> revisits for a year
ChronologyEntries.article: 434 BC:  <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H5166H' clickHandler>Nehemiah</jLink> returned to <jLink data-type='L' data-strong='H3389' clickHandler>Jerusalem</jLink> in 434 BC for a year-long visit (Neh.13:6), to address significant lapses in the reforms he had previously implemented. During his absence, several problems had emerged within the Jewish community: the high priest <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H0475N' clickHandler>Eliashib</jLink> had provided lodging in the temple courts for <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H2900I' clickHandler>Tobiah</jLink> the <jLink data-type='L' data-strong='H5983' clickHandler>Ammonite</jLink> (<jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H5166H' clickHandler>Nehemiah</jLink>'s former opponent), the <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H3878' clickHandler>Levites</jLink> and singers had been neglected and forced to return to their fields, <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H7676' clickHandler>Sabbath</jLink> observance had deteriorated with merchants conducting business on the holy day, and intermarriage with foreign women had resumed, including among the descendants of the high priest. <jPara></jPara> <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H5166H' clickHandler>Nehemiah</jLink> responded decisively to these violations, throwing <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H2900I' clickHandler>Tobiah</jLink>'s belongings out of the temple chamber, restoring proper support for the <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H3878' clickHandler>Levites</jLink>, enforcing <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H7676' clickHandler>Sabbath</jLink> regulations by posting guards at the city gates, and confronting those who had married foreign women. His actions demonstrate the ongoing challenges faced by the post-exilic Jewish community in maintaining covenant faithfulness and the need for strong leadership to preserve religious and social reforms. This visit underscores the fragility of religious renewal and the constant vigilance required to maintain communal commitment to the law of <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H4872' clickHandler>Moses</jLink>.
events: 434 BC: <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H5166H' clickHandler>Nehemiah</jLink> returned to <jLink data-type='L' data-strong='H3389' clickHandler>Jerusalem</jLink> for a year-long visit to address reform lapses.

434 BC: <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H5166H' clickHandler>Nehemiah</jLink> expelled <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H2900I' clickHandler>Tobiah</jLink> the <jLink data-type='L' data-strong='H5983' clickHandler>Ammonite</jLink> from the temple chamber.

434 BC: <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H5166H' clickHandler>Nehemiah</jLink> restored support for <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H3878' clickHandler>Levites</jLink> and singers to enable temple service.

434 BC: <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H5166H' clickHandler>Nehemiah</jLink> enforced <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H7676' clickHandler>Sabbath</jLink> observance by closing city gates and posting guards.

434 BC: <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H5166H' clickHandler>Nehemiah</jLink> confronted and rebuked renewed intermarriage in <jLink data-type='L' data-strong='H3389' clickHandler>Jerusalem</jLink>.

ChronologyEntries.article: 400 BC:  Around 400 BC, <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H3110L' clickHandler>Johanan</jLink> (also known as <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H3110L' clickHandler>Jehohanan</jLink>) held the office of High Priest in <jLink data-type='L' data-strong='H3389' clickHandler>Jerusalem</jLink> during the <jLink data-type='L' data-strong='H6539' clickHandler>Persian</jLink> period. <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H3110L' clickHandler>Johanan</jLink> was part of the post-exilic priestly succession, being the son of <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H3111H' clickHandler>Joiada</jLink> and the grandson of <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H0475N' clickHandler>Eliashib</jLink>, thus continuing the legitimate priestly lineage established after the return from <jLink data-type='L' data-strong='H0894' clickHandler>Babylonian</jLink> exile (Neh.12:22). His tenure occurred during the reign of <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H1867G' clickHandler>Darius</jLink> the <jLink data-type='L' data-strong='H6539' clickHandler>Persian</jLink>, which in this historical context likely refers to <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H1867G' clickHandler>Darius</jLink> II (424-404 BC) or possibly the early years of <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H0783A' clickHandler>Artaxerxes</jLink> II (404-358 BC), when Judea functioned as a semi-autonomous province within the vast Achaemenid Empire. Under the <jLink data-type='L' data-strong='H6539' clickHandler>Persian</jLink> administrative system, the High Priest served not only as the chief religious authority but also as a key local political leader, responsible for both spiritual leadership and civil administration in <jLink data-type='L' data-strong='H3389' clickHandler>Jerusalem</jLink> and the surrounding region.  <jPara></jPara>  The most dramatic event of <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H3110L' clickHandler>Johanan</jLink>'s high priesthood involved a violent family conflict that brought <jLink data-type='L' data-strong='H6539' clickHandler>Persian</jLink> authorities directly into Jewish religious affairs. According to Josephus's Antiquities of the <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='G2454' clickHandler>Jews</jLink>, <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H3110L' clickHandler>Johanan</jLink> became embroiled in a bitter rivalry with his brother Joshua (also called <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='G2424G' clickHandler>Jesus</jLink>), who challenged him for the high priestly office. This dispute escalated to an unprecedented act of violence when <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H3110L' clickHandler>Johanan</jLink> killed his brother within the sacred precincts of the <jLink data-type='L' data-strong='H3389' clickHandler>Jerusalem</jLink> Temple, committing a grave sacrilege that shocked the Jewish community and drew immediate attention from <jLink data-type='L' data-strong='H6539' clickHandler>Persian</jLink> authorities. The <jLink data-type='L' data-strong='H6539' clickHandler>Persian</jLink> governor Bagoas, upon learning of the murder, imposed severe punishment by entering the Temple and forbidding the <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='G2454' clickHandler>Jews</jLink> from accessing the sanctuary until proper ritual purification had been completed. This episode demonstrates both the volatility of high priestly succession during the <jLink data-type='L' data-strong='H6539' clickHandler>Persian</jLink> era and the extent to which imperial authorities were willing to intervene in <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H3063G' clickHandler>Judean</jLink> religious life when internal conflicts threatened public order, establishing a precedent for foreign oversight of temple administration that would continue throughout the Second Temple period.
events: 400 BC: <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H3110L' clickHandler>Johanan</jLink> (<jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H3110L' clickHandler>Jehohanan</jLink>) served as High Priest in <jLink data-type='L' data-strong='H3389' clickHandler>Jerusalem</jLink> during <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H1867G' clickHandler>Darius</jLink> the <jLink data-type='L' data-strong='H6539' clickHandler>Persian</jLink>’s reign.

400 BC: <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H3110L' clickHandler>Johanan</jLink> killed his brother Joshua in the <jLink data-type='L' data-strong='H3389' clickHandler>Jerusalem</jLink> Temple during a dispute.
400 BC: <jLink data-type='L' data-strong='H6539' clickHandler>Persian</jLink> governor Bagoas intervened, banning Jewish access to the Temple until purification.

ChronologyEntries.article: 397 BC:  The prophet <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H4401' clickHandler>Malachi</jLink> provided the final prophetic voice recorded in the Old Testament canon. Writing during a period of spiritual decline and disillusionment following the initial enthusiasm of the post-exilic restoration, <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H4401' clickHandler>Malachi</jLink> addressed widespread religious apathy among both the people and the priesthood. His distinctive dialogical style presents a series of disputations between God and the people, highlighting issues such as corrupt sacrificial offerings (bringing blind, lame, and sick animals), priestly negligence in teaching the law, failure to pay tithes, social injustice including oppression of the vulnerable, and the prevalence of divorce. <jPara></jPara> <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H4401' clickHandler>Malachi</jLink>'s prophecies serve as both judgment and hope, calling the community to repentance while promising the coming "day of the Lord" that will bring purification and restoration. The book concludes with the promise of <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H0452G' clickHandler>Elijah</jLink>'s return before this great and terrible day, creating a bridge between Old Testament prophecy and later messianic expectations. His ministry addressed the disappointment that had set in when the rebuilt temple failed to bring the expected prosperity and divine presence, offering both critique of present failures and encouragement for future divine intervention. As the final voice of Old Testament prophecy, <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H4401' clickHandler>Malachi</jLink>'s message emphasizes the enduring importance of covenant faithfulness and proper worship.
events: 397 BC: <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H4401' clickHandler>Malachi</jLink> prophesied in <jLink data-type='L' data-strong='H3389' clickHandler>Jerusalem</jLink>, addressing religious apathy and social injustice.
397 BC: <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H4401' clickHandler>Malachi</jLink> rebuked priests and people for offering blemished animal sacrifices.
397 BC: <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H4401' clickHandler>Malachi</jLink> confronted priestly negligence in upholding and teaching the law.
397 BC: <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H4401' clickHandler>Malachi</jLink> called out the community for withholding tithes, affecting temple service.
397 BC: <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H4401' clickHandler>Malachi</jLink> condemned social injustice and widespread divorce.

ChronologyEntries.article: 350 BC:  Around 350 BC, <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H3037H' clickHandler>Jaddua</jLink> held the office of High Priest in <jLink data-type='L' data-strong='H3389' clickHandler>Jerusalem</jLink> during the reign of <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H0783A' clickHandler>Artaxerxes</jLink> III of <jLink data-type='L' data-strong='H6539' clickHandler>Persia</jLink> (358-338 BC). <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H3037H' clickHandler>Jaddua</jLink> was part of the post-exilic priestly lineage, being the son of Jonathan (also called <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H3110L' clickHandler>Johanan</jLink>), who was the son of <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H3111H' clickHandler>Joiada</jLink>, who was the son of <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H0475N' clickHandler>Eliashib</jLink> (Neh.12:11). Under the <jLink data-type='L' data-strong='H6539' clickHandler>Persian</jLink> administrative system, Judea functioned as a semi-autonomous province, with the High Priest serving as both the chief religious authority and a key local political leader responsible for maintaining order in <jLink data-type='L' data-strong='H3389' clickHandler>Jerusalem</jLink> and the surrounding region. This period represented a time of relative stability for the Jewish community under <jLink data-type='L' data-strong='H6539' clickHandler>Persian</jLink> rule, though they remained subject to the broader political developments of the empire. <jPara></jPara>  The most significant event of <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H3037H' clickHandler>Jaddua</jLink>'s early tenure involved a family crisis that would have lasting consequences for Jewish-Samaritan relations. According to Josephus's Antiquities of the <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='G2454' clickHandler>Jews</jLink>, <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H3037H' clickHandler>Jaddua</jLink>'s brother Manasseh, who was also a priest, married Nicaso, the daughter of <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H5571G' clickHandler>Sanballat</jLink>, the <jLink data-type='L' data-strong='H8111' clickHandler>Samaritan</jLink> governor. This union violated Jewish law prohibiting priests from marrying foreign women, creating intense controversy among the <jLink data-type='L' data-strong='H3389' clickHandler>Jerusalem</jLink> priesthood. When the elders and priests demanded that Manasseh either divorce his wife or relinquish his priestly office, he chose to maintain his marriage. Consequently, <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H5571G' clickHandler>Sanballat</jLink> promised to build a rival temple on Mount <jLink data-type='L' data-strong='H1630' clickHandler>Gerizim</jLink> in <jLink data-type='L' data-strong='H8111' clickHandler>Samaria</jLink> and install Manasseh as High Priest there, effectively establishing the <jLink data-type='L' data-strong='H8111' clickHandler>Samaritan</jLink> priesthood as a competing religious authority. Archaeology shows there already was a temple there, but he may have enlarged this, though there is no corroboration of this story in other histories or <jLink data-type='L' data-strong='H8111' clickHandler>Samaritan</jLink> traditions.
events: 350 BC: <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H3037H' clickHandler>Jaddua</jLink>, son of Jonathan (<jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H3110L' clickHandler>Johanan</jLink>), served as High Priest in <jLink data-type='L' data-strong='H3389' clickHandler>Jerusalem</jLink> under <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H0783A' clickHandler>Artaxerxes</jLink> III.

350 BC: Manasseh, <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H3037H' clickHandler>Jaddua</jLink>’s brother, married Nicaso, daughter of <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H5571G' clickHandler>Sanballat</jLink>, in <jLink data-type='L' data-strong='H3389' clickHandler>Jerusalem</jLink>.
350 BC: Elders and priests demanded Manasseh divorce Nicaso or relinquish his priesthood.

350 BC: Manasseh chose to keep Nicaso and left <jLink data-type='L' data-strong='H3389' clickHandler>Jerusalem</jLink> to become High Priest at Mount <jLink data-type='L' data-strong='H1630' clickHandler>Gerizim</jLink>, founding the <jLink data-type='L' data-strong='H8111' clickHandler>Samaritan</jLink> priesthood.

ChronologyEntries.article: 332 BC:  <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H3037H' clickHandler>Jaddua</jLink> served as the Jewish high priest when Alexander the Great approached <jLink data-type='L' data-strong='H3389' clickHandler>Jerusalem</jLink> during his conquest of the <jLink data-type='L' data-strong='H6539' clickHandler>Persian</jLink> Empire. Josephus recounts that as the <jLink data-type='L' data-strong='G3109' clickHandler>Macedonian</jLink> conqueror neared the city, <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H3037H' clickHandler>Jaddua</jLink>, clothed in his ceremonial priestly vestments and accompanied by fellow priests and citizens, went out to meet Alexander in a diplomatic gesture of submission. Rather than attacking <jLink data-type='L' data-strong='H3389' clickHandler>Jerusalem</jLink>, Alexander reportedly showed remarkable reverence toward <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H3037H' clickHandler>Jaddua</jLink>, allegedly influenced by a prophetic dream in which he had seen a figure resembling the high priest. This encounter resulted in Alexander granting favorable terms to the Jewish people, including the preservation of their religious freedoms and exemption from tribute payments during sabbatical years. This account of Alexander visiting <jLink data-type='L' data-strong='H3389' clickHandler>Jerusalem</jLink> is suspect because it is found no-where else, apart from some later rabbinic traditions which say Alexander met Simon I or II.  <jPara></jPara>  During this same period, Manasseh, who was <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H3037H' clickHandler>Jaddua</jLink>'s brother, became established as a <jLink data-type='L' data-strong='H8111' clickHandler>Samaritan</jLink> priest following his expulsion from the <jLink data-type='L' data-strong='H3389' clickHandler>Jerusalem</jLink> priesthood. The conflict arose from Manasseh's marriage to the daughter of <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H5571G' clickHandler>Sanballat</jLink>, the <jLink data-type='L' data-strong='H8111' clickHandler>Samaritan</jLink> governor, which violated Jewish law prohibiting intermarriage with non-<jLink data-type='P' data-strong='G2454' clickHandler>Jews</jLink>. Consequently, Manasseh was forced to leave his position in <jLink data-type='L' data-strong='H3389' clickHandler>Jerusalem</jLink> and accepted a priestly role among the <jLink data-type='L' data-strong='H8111' clickHandler>Samaritans</jLink>, who worshipped on Mount <jLink data-type='L' data-strong='H1630' clickHandler>Gerizim</jLink> where Manasseh said he would build a temple. However, this account may have been embellished or constructed to provide an explanation for the later Jewish-Samaritan religious divisions and to legitimize the origins of the <jLink data-type='L' data-strong='H8111' clickHandler>Samaritan</jLink> priesthood, because archaeology and <jLink data-type='L' data-strong='H8111' clickHandler>Samaritan</jLink> traditions point to a much earlier origin for both their temple and priesthood.
events: 332 BC: <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H3037H' clickHandler>Jaddua</jLink> met Alexander the Great.

332 BC: <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H4519G' clickHandler>Manasseh</jLink>, <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H3037H' clickHandler>Jaddua</jLink>’s brother, became the <jLink data-type='L' data-strong='H8111' clickHandler>Samaritan</jLink> priest.

ChronologyEntries.article: 331 BC:  Alexander the Great reached the zenith of his military conquests in 331 BC, most notably through his decisive victory at the Battle of Gaugamela, where his forces overwhelmed the <jLink data-type='L' data-strong='H6539' clickHandler>Persian</jLink> king <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H1867G' clickHandler>Darius</jLink> III and effectively collapsed <jLink data-type='L' data-strong='H6539' clickHandler>Persian</jLink> imperial power. This triumph established Alexander's dominance across the Near East, <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H4714G' clickHandler>Egypt</jLink>, and extending into <jLink data-type='L' data-strong='G0773' clickHandler>Asia</jLink>, fundamentally reshaping the political and cultural landscape of the ancient world. His conquests introduced <jLink data-type='L' data-strong='H3120H' clickHandler>Hellenistic</jLink> influence that would persist for centuries, affecting Jewish communities throughout the diaspora and in Judea itself. <jPara></jPara> Alexander the Great is described as a "mighty king" who would rule with great dominion but whose kingdom would ultimately be "broken and divided toward the four winds of heaven" after his death (<jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H1835H' clickHandler>Dan</jLink>.11:3-4). This prophecy accurately anticipated the fragmentation of Alexander's empire among his generals following his death in 323 BC, leading to the establishment of several <jLink data-type='L' data-strong='H3120H' clickHandler>Hellenistic</jLink> kingdoms that would significantly impact Jewish history, including the Ptolemaic and Seleucid dynasties that would later compete for control over Judea.
events: 331 BC: Alexander the Great defeated <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H1867G' clickHandler>Darius</jLink> III at Gaugamela, ending the <jLink data-type='L' data-strong='H6539' clickHandler>Persian</jLink> Empire.
331 BC: After Gaugamela, Alexander the Great became ruler over former <jLink data-type='L' data-strong='H6539' clickHandler>Persian</jLink> territories, including Judea.

331 BC: <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H1867G' clickHandler>Darius</jLink> III lost control of the <jLink data-type='L' data-strong='H6539' clickHandler>Persian</jLink> Empire after his defeat by Alexander at Gaugamela.

ChronologyEntries.desc: <jChronDurationLink style='color:red'>▼</jChronDurationLink><jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H4714H' clickHandler>Egypt</jLink> conquers under Ptolemy I
ChronologyEntries.article: 320 BC:  Ptolemy I, a former general under Alexander the Great and founder of the Ptolemaic dynasty in <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H4714G' clickHandler>Egypt</jLink>, captured <jLink data-type='L' data-strong='H3389' clickHandler>Jerusalem</jLink> in 320 BC during the chaotic period following Alexander's death when his generals vied for territorial control. This conquest marked a crucial transition from <jLink data-type='L' data-strong='H6539' clickHandler>Persian</jLink> to <jLink data-type='L' data-strong='H3120H' clickHandler>Hellenistic</jLink> rule over <jLink data-type='L' data-strong='H3389' clickHandler>Jerusalem</jLink> and Judea, introducing new administrative structures and cultural influences that would shape Jewish life for the subsequent centuries. The capture occurred as part of Ptolemy's strategic expansion beyond <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H4714G' clickHandler>Egypt</jLink> into the Levant, a region of significant economic and military importance. <jPara></jPara> The event initiated centuries of <jLink data-type='L' data-strong='H3120H' clickHandler>Hellenistic</jLink> governance in <jLink data-type='L' data-strong='H3389' clickHandler>Jerusalem</jLink> and set the stage for the later conflicts between the Ptolemaic and Seleucid empires over control of this strategically vital territory. Ptolemy's policies sometimes included population relocations to consolidate control, affecting Jewish communities and their religious practices. This conquest represents a pivotal moment that would influence the development of Second Temple <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='G2454' clickHandler>Judaism</jLink> under foreign rule and eventually contribute to the tensions that would culminate in the Maccabean Revolt over a century later.
events: 320 BC: Ptolemy I captured <jLink data-type='L' data-strong='H3389' clickHandler>Jerusalem</jLink> during his campaign to control the Levant.

320 BC: Ptolemy I’s conquest ended <jLink data-type='L' data-strong='H6539' clickHandler>Persian</jLink> rule and began <jLink data-type='L' data-strong='H3120H' clickHandler>Hellenistic</jLink> rule in <jLink data-type='L' data-strong='H3389' clickHandler>Jerusalem</jLink> and Judea.
320 BC: Ptolemy I’s population relocations affected the Jewish community in <jLink data-type='L' data-strong='H3389' clickHandler>Jerusalem</jLink> and Judea.

ChronologyEntries.desc: <jChronDurationLink style='color:green'>▼</jChronDurationLink><jLink data-type='P' data-strong='G3683' clickHandler>Onias</jLink> I  as High Priest
ChronologyEntries.article: 300 BC:  Around 300 BC, <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='G3683' clickHandler>Onias</jLink> I held the office of High Priest in <jLink data-type='L' data-strong='H3389' clickHandler>Jerusalem</jLink> during a period when Judea was under the control of the Ptolemaic Kingdom of <jLink data-type='L' data-strong='H4714G' clickHandler>Egypt</jLink>. According to the Jewish historian Josephus, <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='G3683' clickHandler>Onias</jLink> I was the son of <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H3037H' clickHandler>Jaddua</jLink>, whose name appears in the genealogical record of high priests (Neh.12:11). Josephus further notes that <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='G3683' clickHandler>Onias</jLink> I was a contemporary of Alexander the Great, who reigned from 336 to 323 BC, placing <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='G3683' clickHandler>Onias</jLink> I's tenure in the transitional period from Alexander's conquests to the establishment of <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H3120H' clickHandler>Hellenistic</jLink> kingdoms. This chronological positioning is supported by 1 Maccabees (1Ma.12:7, 8, 20), which records correspondence between <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='G3683' clickHandler>Onias</jLink> I and Areus I, the Spartan king who ruled from 309 to 265 BC, indicating diplomatic relations between the Jewish leadership and other <jLink data-type='L' data-strong='H1419J' clickHandler>Mediterranean</jLink> powers.  <jPara></jPara>  The succession following <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='G3683' clickHandler>Onias</jLink> I presents a textual challenge that reflects the complexities of ancient manuscript transmission. According to the Greek text of Sirach 50, Simon I was the son of <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='G3683' clickHandler>Onias</jLink> I, continuing the direct priestly lineage. However, the Hebrew text of the same passage identifies Simon as the son of Jonathan, creating uncertainty about the precise genealogical connection. Despite this discrepancy, historical sources agree that <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='G3683' clickHandler>Onias</jLink> I initiated a new line of High Priests that maintained both religious and political authority in <jLink data-type='L' data-strong='H3389' clickHandler>Jerusalem</jLink> until the disruption caused by Antiochus Epiphanes in the 2nd century BC, when temple worship was suspended. During this period, the High Priest served not only as the chief religious officer but also as the primary intermediary between the Jewish community and their Ptolemaic rulers, managing temple affairs, collecting taxes, and representing Jewish interests to the foreign administration.
events: 300 BC: <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H3037H' clickHandler>Jaddua</jLink>’s High Priesthood ended.
300 BC: <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='G3683' clickHandler>Onias</jLink> I, son of <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H3037H' clickHandler>Jaddua</jLink>, became High Priest.

ChronologyEntries.desc: <jChronDurationLink style='color:green'>▼</jChronDurationLink>Simon I (son of <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='G3683' clickHandler>Onias</jLink> I) as HP
ChronologyEntries.article: 280 BC:  Simon I, known as "the Just" according to the historian Josephus, served as High Priest around 280 BC and was a descendant of <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H6659G' clickHandler>Zadok</jLink>, maintaining the prestigious <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H6659G' clickHandler>Zadokite</jLink> priestly lineage that traced back to King <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H1732' clickHandler>David</jLink>'s time. His epithet "the Just" reflects his reputation for righteousness and effective spiritual leadership during a period of significant cultural and political transition as <jLink data-type='L' data-strong='H3120H' clickHandler>Hellenistic</jLink> influence continued to permeate Jewish society. Simon I's tenure was particularly important for preserving religious traditions and communal integrity while navigating the challenges posed by foreign rule and cultural pressures. <jPara></jPara> The High Priest's role during this period extended beyond religious duties to include significant political and administrative responsibilities, as the office served as the primary interface between the Jewish community and their Ptolemaic rulers. Simon I's just character and adherence to traditional Jewish law helped maintain stability and religious continuity during a time when many Jewish communities were experiencing pressure to adopt Greek customs and practices, establishing precedents for faithful leadership that would prove crucial during later periods of more intense <jLink data-type='L' data-strong='H3120H' clickHandler>Hellenistic</jLink> persecution.
events: 280 BC: Simon I, called "the Just," served as High Priest in <jLink data-type='L' data-strong='H3389' clickHandler>Jerusalem</jLink>, continuing the <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H6659G' clickHandler>Zadokite</jLink> line.
280 BC: Simon I represented the Jewish community to Ptolemaic rulers.

ChronologyEntries.article: 260 BC:  Eleazar succeeded his brother Simon I "the Just" as High Priest around 260 BC, continuing the <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H6659G' clickHandler>Zadokite</jLink> priestly lineage and the family tradition of faithful religious leadership during the Ptolemaic period. His appointment maintained the hereditary succession within this distinguished priestly family, ensuring continuity in temple worship and Jewish religious practices during ongoing <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H3120H' clickHandler>Hellenistic</jLink> influence in Judea. The brotherly succession reflects the importance of maintaining legitimate priestly lineage according to biblical requirements for temple service. <jPara></jPara> Eleazar's tenure as High Priest continued the policies and religious standards established by his predecessor, working to preserve traditional Jewish worship and community life under foreign rule. His leadership occurred during a relatively stable period of Ptolemaic governance, before the more intense conflicts that would arise when the Seleucid Empire gained control over Judea, suggesting that the brothers' combined leadership helped establish a strong foundation for Jewish religious identity that would prove essential during later periods of persecution and attempted forced Hellenization.
events: 260 BC: Simon I’s High Priesthood ended.
260 BC: Eliezar, Simon I’s brother, became High Priest.

ChronologyEntries.desc: <jChronDurationLink style='color:green'>▼</jChronDurationLink>Manasseh (brother of <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='G3683' clickHandler>Onias</jLink> I) as HP
ChronologyEntries.article: 245 BC:  Manasseh served as High Priest of <jLink data-type='L' data-strong='H3389' clickHandler>Jerusalem</jLink> in 245 BC, maintaining the <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H6659G' clickHandler>Zadokite</jLink> priestly lineage as the uncle of his predecessor <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H0499G' clickHandler>Eleazar</jLink>. His appointment continued the hereditary succession within the distinguished priestly family that had guided Jewish religious life since the post-exilic restoration. During this period, Judea remained under the control of the Ptolemaic dynasty of <jLink data-type='L' data-strong='H4714G' clickHandler>Egypt</jLink>, which generally allowed considerable religious autonomy for the Jewish community while maintaining political authority over the region. <jPara></jPara> Manasseh's tenure occurred during a relatively stable phase of Ptolemaic rule, when the High Priesthood functioned not only as a religious office but also as the primary political intermediary between the Jewish people and their foreign rulers. His role would have included overseeing Temple worship, maintaining adherence to the Mosaic law, and managing diplomatic relations with Ptolemaic administrators in <jLink data-type='L' data-strong='H4714G' clickHandler>Egypt</jLink>, thereby preserving both Jewish religious identity and communal stability during the ongoing influence of <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H3120H' clickHandler>Hellenistic</jLink> culture throughout the Near East.
events: 245 BC: Eliezar’s High Priesthood ended.
245 BC: Manasseh, <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='G3683' clickHandler>Onias</jLink> I’s brother, became High Priest.

ChronologyEntries.desc: <jChronDurationLink style='color:green'>▼</jChronDurationLink><jLink data-type='P' data-strong='G3683' clickHandler>Onias</jLink> II (son of Simon I) as HP
ChronologyEntries.article: 240 BC:  <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='G3683' clickHandler>Onias</jLink> II, son of Simon I "the Just," became High Priest around 240 BC but created significant diplomatic tension when he initially refused to pay the customary tribute to the Ptolemaic rulers of <jLink data-type='L' data-strong='H4714G' clickHandler>Egypt</jLink>. This refusal threatened the delicate relationship between the Jewish community and their Ptolemaic overlords, potentially exposing Judea to punitive measures that could have devastated the vulnerable population. The crisis demonstrated the complex challenges faced by High Priests who had to balance religious leadership with political responsibilities under foreign rule. <jPara></jPara> The diplomatic crisis was ultimately resolved through the intervention of Joseph son of Tobias, a relative of <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='G3683' clickHandler>Onias</jLink> II, who successfully negotiated with the Ptolemaic authorities to ensure the tribute was paid and preserve peace between Judea and <jLink data-type='L' data-strong='H4714G' clickHandler>Egypt</jLink>. This resolution maintained Judea's favorable standing within the Ptolemaic Empire and established important precedents for managing conflicts between religious convictions and political necessities. <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='G3683' clickHandler>Onias</jLink> II's initial resistance may have reflected growing Jewish concerns about foreign tribute obligations, while the eventual resolution demonstrated the importance of skilled diplomacy in preserving communal autonomy under imperial rule.
events: 240 BC: <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H4519G' clickHandler>Manasseh</jLink>’s High Priesthood ended.
240 BC: <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='G3683' clickHandler>Onias</jLink> II, son of Simon I, became High Priest.

ChronologyEntries.article: 218 BC:  Simon II, son of <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='G3683' clickHandler>Onias</jLink> II, served as High Priest around 218 BC and undertook significant repairs and fortifications of the <jLink data-type='L' data-strong='H3389' clickHandler>Jerusalem</jLink> Temple (Act.2:10; Sir.50; 2Ma; 3Ma). The most detailed account appears in Ecclesiasticus (Sirach) 50, which praises Simon II for fortifying the Temple and laying "the foundations for the high double walls, the high retaining walls for the Temple precincts," describing his comprehensive restoration work that strengthened both the religious and defensive capabilities of the sacred complex. These repairs occurred during continued Ptolemaic rule and reflected the ongoing need to maintain the Temple's structural integrity and ceremonial functions. <jPara></jPara> Simon II's restoration efforts enhanced the Temple's significance as the central institution of Jewish religious life, ensuring its continued importance for diaspora <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='G2454' clickHandler>Jews</jLink> who made pilgrimages to <jLink data-type='L' data-strong='H3389' clickHandler>Jerusalem</jLink> during major festivals (Act.2:10). His work represented not merely physical maintenance but also spiritual and communal renewal, strengthening Jewish identity during a period of increasing <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H3120H' clickHandler>Hellenistic</jLink> cultural influence. The biblical and apocryphal sources that commemorate his achievements suggest that Simon II's tenure was viewed as a golden age of temple stewardship, establishing standards for high priestly leadership that would influence subsequent generations facing even greater challenges to Jewish religious autonomy.
events: 218 BC: Simon II, son of <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='G3683' clickHandler>Onias</jLink> II, served as High Priest in <jLink data-type='L' data-strong='H3389' clickHandler>Jerusalem</jLink>.
218 BC: Simon II built high double walls and retaining walls around the Temple.

ChronologyEntries.desc: <jChronDurationLink style='color:green'>▼</jChronDurationLink><jLink data-type='P' data-strong='G3683' clickHandler>Onias</jLink> III (of Simon II) as HP
ChronologyEntries.article: 187 BC:  <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='G3683' clickHandler>Onias</jLink> III, son of Simon II, assumed the High Priesthood around 187 BC during a crucial transitional period when Judea had recently come under Seleucid control following Antiochus III's victory over the Ptolemies in the Fifth <jLink data-type='L' data-strong='H0758I' clickHandler>Syrian</jLink> War (concluded 198 BC). Unlike the relatively stable Ptolemaic period experienced by his predecessors, <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='G3683' clickHandler>Onias</jLink> III faced increasing pressure from Seleucid administrators and Hellenizing Jewish factions who sought to introduce Greek customs and practices into Jewish religious and social life. He distinguished himself through his firm opposition to Hellenization and his determined efforts to defend traditional Jewish religious practices against external cultural pressures. <jPara></jPara> <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='G3683' clickHandler>Onias</jLink> III's principled resistance to compromise with <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H3120H' clickHandler>Hellenistic</jLink> influences, while maintaining the sanctity and autonomy of the <jLink data-type='L' data-strong='H3389' clickHandler>Jerusalem</jLink> Temple, set important precedents but also created mounting tensions that would have far-reaching consequences. His unwavering commitment to Jewish law and Temple traditions placed him in direct conflict with those who favored accommodation with Seleucid policies, establishing the ideological foundations for the conflicts that would eventually erupt under Antiochus IV Epiphanes. The political and religious tensions that characterized <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='G3683' clickHandler>Onias</jLink> III's high priesthood thus served as a crucial prelude to the persecution of <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='G2454' clickHandler>Jews</jLink> and the subsequent Maccabean Revolt, making his tenure a pivotal moment in the preservation of Jewish religious identity during the Second Temple period.
events: 187 BC: <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='G3683' clickHandler>Onias</jLink> III, son of Simon II, became High Priest in <jLink data-type='L' data-strong='H3389' clickHandler>Jerusalem</jLink>.

187 BC: <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='G3683' clickHandler>Onias</jLink> III opposed Hellenizing <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='G2454' clickHandler>Jews</jLink> and Seleucid officials introducing Greek customs.

ChronologyEntries.article: 178 BC:  Seleucus IV Philopator, ruler of the Seleucid Empire, demanded money from the Temple treasury in <jLink data-type='L' data-strong='H3389' clickHandler>Jerusalem</jLink> in 178 BC (2 Maccabees 3:4). This unprecedented demand represented a significant escalation in Seleucid interference with Jewish religious affairs and marked a departure from the relative autonomy previously enjoyed by the Temple authorities. The financial pressure stemmed from the massive indemnities imposed by <jLink data-type='L' data-strong='G4514' clickHandler>Rome</jLink> following the defeat of Seleucus IV's father, Antiochus III, at the Battle of Magnesia in 190 BC, which left the Seleucid Empire in severe fiscal distress. <jPara></jPara> The attempt to extract wealth from the <jLink data-type='L' data-strong='H3389' clickHandler>Jerusalem</jLink> Temple treasury created considerable tension between the Seleucid administration and the Jewish population, as the Temple served not merely as a religious center but as a powerful symbol of Jewish identity and autonomy. This event established a dangerous precedent for future Seleucid rulers to view Jewish religious institutions as potential sources of revenue, contributing to the growing unrest that would characterize Jewish-Seleucid relations in subsequent decades and ultimately culminate in more severe persecution under Antiochus IV Epiphanes.
events: 178 BC: Seleucus IV Philopator demanded money from the <jLink data-type='L' data-strong='H3389' clickHandler>Jerusalem</jLink> Temple treasury.

ChronologyEntries.desc: <jChronDurationLink style='color:green'>▼</jChronDurationLink><jLink data-type='P' data-strong='G2394' clickHandler>Jason</jLink> (son of Simon II) as HP
ChronologyEntries.article: 175 BC:  <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='G2394' clickHandler>Jason</jLink>, son of the previous High Priest Simon II, assumed the office of High Priest in 175 BC through financial arrangements with Seleucid authorities rather than through traditional hereditary succession. His appointment marked a significant turning point in Jewish religious leadership, as <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='G2394' clickHandler>Jason</jLink> actively promoted the Hellenization of Jewish society, introducing Greek customs, language, and institutions into <jLink data-type='L' data-strong='H3389' clickHandler>Jerusalem</jLink>'s religious and cultural life. Most notably, he established a Greek-style gymnasium in the holy city, a move that represented a dramatic departure from traditional Jewish practices and values. <jPara></jPara> <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='G2394' clickHandler>Jason</jLink>'s Hellenization policies created profound internal conflict within the Jewish community, dividing those who embraced Greek culture from traditionalists who viewed these changes as threatening to Jewish religious identity. His tenure demonstrated how the High Priesthood had become subject to political manipulation and financial transactions rather than spiritual qualifications, undermining the sacred nature of the office. These policies, while intended to modernize <jLink data-type='L' data-strong='H3389' clickHandler>Jerusalem</jLink> and integrate it into the broader <jLink data-type='L' data-strong='H3120H' clickHandler>Hellenistic</jLink> world, instead deepened cultural and religious divisions that would contribute to future instability and persecution.
events: 175 BC: <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='G2394' clickHandler>Jason</jLink>, son of Simon II, became High Priest in <jLink data-type='L' data-strong='H3389' clickHandler>Jerusalem</jLink> by paying Seleucid authorities.
175 BC: <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='G2394' clickHandler>Jason</jLink> founded a Greek-style gymnasium in <jLink data-type='L' data-strong='H3389' clickHandler>Jerusalem</jLink>.
175 BC: The hereditary succession of the High Priesthood ended with <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='G2394' clickHandler>Jason</jLink>’s political appointment.

ChronologyEntries.article: 171 BC:  The office of High Priest in <jLink data-type='L' data-strong='H3389' clickHandler>Jerusalem</jLink> was sold to the highest bidder in 171 BC, representing a complete corruption of the traditional system whereby the position was passed down through hereditary succession within legitimate priestly families. This practice transformed the most sacred office in <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='G2454' clickHandler>Judaism</jLink> into a commodity subject to political maneuvering and financial manipulation, fundamentally undermining the religious authority and spiritual legitimacy that had traditionally characterized the High Priesthood. The sale of religious office reflected the broader <jLink data-type='L' data-strong='H3120H' clickHandler>Hellenistic</jLink> influence on Jewish institutions and the increasing secularization of what had previously been considered divinely appointed positions. <jPara></jPara> The consequences of this corruption extended far beyond mere administrative changes, creating political instability and internal divisions within the Jewish community while accelerating the process of forced Hellenization. Those who purchased the High Priesthood typically aligned themselves with Seleucid interests and promoted Greek customs, further alienating traditional <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='G2454' clickHandler>Jews</jLink> who viewed these developments as apostasy. This institutional corruption contributed directly to the broader context of unrest in <jLink data-type='L' data-strong='H3389' clickHandler>Jerusalem</jLink>, setting the stage for the severe persecution that would follow under Antiochus IV Epiphanes and ultimately providing part of the justification for the Maccabean Revolt.
events: 171 BC: <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='G2394' clickHandler>Jason</jLink> was deposed as High Priest in <jLink data-type='L' data-strong='H3389' clickHandler>Jerusalem</jLink>.

171 BC: Menelaus became High Priest in <jLink data-type='L' data-strong='H3389' clickHandler>Jerusalem</jLink> by outbidding <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='G2394' clickHandler>Jason</jLink> and buying the office from Seleucid authorities.

ChronologyEntries.desc: Antiochus Epiphanes attacks <jLink data-type='L' data-strong='H3389' clickHandler>Jerusalem</jLink>
ChronologyEntries.article: 168 BC:  Antiochus IV Epiphanes, the <jLink data-type='L' data-strong='H3120H' clickHandler>Hellenistic</jLink> ruler of the Seleucid Empire, launched a devastating attack on <jLink data-type='L' data-strong='H3389' clickHandler>Jerusalem</jLink> in 168 BC, as documented in both 1 Maccabees 1 and 2 Maccabees 5. This assault marked the beginning of an intense period of religious persecution for the Jewish people, during which Antiochus desecrated the <jLink data-type='L' data-strong='H3389' clickHandler>Jerusalem</jLink> Temple by erecting an altar to Zeus and forcing the sacrifice of pigs, actions that constituted the gravest possible offense to Jewish religious sensibilities. The king also banned fundamental Jewish practices including circumcision, <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H7676' clickHandler>Sabbath</jLink> observance, and Torah study, while compelling <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='G2454' clickHandler>Jews</jLink> to participate in pagan rituals and festivals. <jPara></jPara> The attack and subsequent persecution served as the immediate catalyst for the Maccabean Revolt, a determined Jewish uprising led by <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H6667H' clickHandler>Mattathias</jLink> and his sons that would eventually succeed in reclaiming the Temple and restoring Jewish religious freedom. The desecration of the Temple, known as the "abomination of desolation," lasted approximately three years until the Maccabees liberated <jLink data-type='L' data-strong='H3389' clickHandler>Jerusalem</jLink> and rededicated the Temple in 165 BC, an event commemorated annually in the Jewish festival of <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='G1456' clickHandler>Hanukkah</jLink>. Antiochus IV's assault on <jLink data-type='L' data-strong='H3389' clickHandler>Jerusalem</jLink> thus represents a pivotal moment in Jewish history, demonstrating both the depths of foreign oppression and the resilience of Jewish faith in the face of systematic attempts to destroy their religious and cultural identity.
events: 168 BC: Antiochus IV Epiphanes attacked <jLink data-type='L' data-strong='H3389' clickHandler>Jerusalem</jLink>.
168 BC: Antiochus IV desecrated the <jLink data-type='L' data-strong='H3389' clickHandler>Jerusalem</jLink> Temple by setting up an altar to Zeus and sacrificing pigs.
168 BC: Antiochus IV banned Jewish religious practices like circumcision, <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H7676' clickHandler>Sabbath</jLink>, and Torah study.

168 BC: <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='G2454' clickHandler>Jews</jLink> in <jLink data-type='L' data-strong='H3389' clickHandler>Jerusalem</jLink> were forced to join pagan rituals and festivals by decree.
168 BC: Menelaus seized the High Priesthood and collaborated with Antiochus IV during the persecution.

ChronologyEntries.article: 167 BC:  The Maccabean Revolt began in 167 BC when <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H6667H' clickHandler>Mattathias</jLink>, a Jewish priest from Modein, refused to comply with Seleucid orders to offer pagan sacrifices as mandated by King Antiochus IV Epiphanes. According to 1 Maccabees 2, <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H6667H' clickHandler>Mattathias</jLink> not only refused the royal decree but killed both a fellow Jew who was willing to sacrifice and the king's official who was enforcing the edict, declaring his unwavering commitment to the covenant of his ancestors. Following this act of defiance, <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H6667H' clickHandler>Mattathias</jLink> fled to the wilderness with his sons, including Judas, where they rallied supporters to their cause and initiated guerrilla warfare against Seleucid forces. <jPara></jPara> After <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H6667H' clickHandler>Mattathias</jLink> died, leadership of the revolt passed to his son Judas, who became known as "Maccabaeus" (possibly meaning "hammer"). As recorded in 2 Maccabees 8, Judas demonstrated exceptional military skill in organizing Jewish resistance fighters and conducting successful campaigns against the Seleucid army, providing crucial morale boosts to the oppressed Jewish population. This revolt emerged directly from the religious persecution instituted by Antiochus IV, who had desecrated the <jLink data-type='L' data-strong='H3389' clickHandler>Jerusalem</jLink> Temple, banned circumcision, <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H7676' clickHandler>Sabbath</jLink> observance, and Torah study, and attempted to force <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='G2454' clickHandler>Jews</jLink> to participate in pagan religious practices, making the Maccabean uprising fundamentally a struggle for religious freedom and Jewish identity.
events: 167 BC: <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H6667H' clickHandler>Mattathias</jLink>, a priest from Modein, refused Antiochus IV’s order to offer pagan sacrifices.
167 BC: <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H6667H' clickHandler>Mattathias</jLink> killed a compliant Jew and a Seleucid official, sparking rebellion.
167 BC: <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H6667H' clickHandler>Mattathias</jLink> and his sons fled to the wilderness and started guerrilla warfare against Seleucid forces.
167 BC: The Maccabean Revolt began in response to Antiochus IV’s religious persecution.
167 BC: After <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H6667H' clickHandler>Mattathias</jLink>’ death, his son Judas Maccabaeus led the revolt.

ChronologyEntries.article: 165 BC:  The <jLink data-type='L' data-strong='H3389' clickHandler>Jerusalem</jLink> Temple was cleansed and rededicated in 165 BC following the successful military campaigns of Judas Maccabaeus against the Seleucid forces, as detailed in 1 Maccabees 4 and 2 Maccabees 10. This rededication occurred approximately three years after Antiochus IV Epiphanes had desecrated the sacred site by erecting an altar to Zeus and compelling the sacrifice of pigs, acts that represented the gravest possible offense to Jewish religious sensibilities. The restoration involved the complete purification of the Temple precincts, the removal of all pagan elements, the construction of a new altar to replace the defiled one, and the renewal of proper sacrificial worship according to Mosaic law. <jPara></jPara> The Temple rededication established the festival of <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='G1456' clickHandler>Hanukkah</jLink>, which commemorates both the restoration of the Temple and the reestablishment of traditional Jewish religious observances after a period of severe persecution. This event marked a pivotal moment in Jewish history, demonstrating the successful resistance of Jewish religious identity against systematic attempts at cultural assimilation and religious suppression. The rededication represented not merely the physical restoration of a building but the spiritual renewal of the Jewish people and their renewed commitment to covenant faithfulness, providing a foundation for continued Jewish autonomy under the emerging Hasmonean dynasty.
events: 165 BC: Judas Maccabaeus and his followers recaptured <jLink data-type='L' data-strong='H3389' clickHandler>Jerusalem</jLink> from Seleucid forces.
165 BC: The <jLink data-type='L' data-strong='H3389' clickHandler>Jerusalem</jLink> Temple was cleansed and rededicated after Antiochus IV’s desecration.
165 BC: A new altar was built and proper Jewish sacrifices resumed in the Temple.
165 BC: <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='G1456' clickHandler>Hanukkah</jLink> was established to commemorate the Temple’s rededication.

ChronologyEntries.article: 160 BC:  Jonathan Maccabaeus assumed leadership of the Jewish resistance in 160 BC following the death of his brother Judas Maccabaeus in battle against Seleucid forces. According to 1 Maccabees 7-15, Jonathan successfully combined both political and religious authority by serving simultaneously as the civil ruler of Judea and as High Priest of the <jLink data-type='L' data-strong='H3389' clickHandler>Jerusalem</jLink> Temple, establishing a precedent for the dual leadership that would characterize the Hasmonean dynasty. This consolidation of power enabled Jonathan to strengthen Jewish autonomy and continue the struggle initiated by his father <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H6667H' clickHandler>Mattathias</jLink> and brother Judas, despite ongoing challenges from various Seleucid claimants and neighboring powers. <jPara></jPara> Jonathan's tenure marked a significant evolution in the Maccabean movement from a purely religious revolt to a more comprehensive political and military campaign for Jewish independence. His assumption of the High Priesthood, while controversial among some traditional <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='G2454' clickHandler>Jews</jLink> who questioned the legitimacy of a non-<jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H6659G' clickHandler>Zadokite</jLink> priestly appointment, provided the religious authority necessary to unite the Jewish population behind his leadership. Through diplomatic maneuvering and military skill, Jonathan successfully navigated the complex political landscape of the declining Seleucid Empire, securing greater autonomy for Judea and laying the groundwork for the complete independence that would be achieved under his successor.
events: 160 BC: Judas Maccabaeus died fighting Seleucid forces.
160 BC: Jonathan Maccabaeus took over leadership of the Jewish resistance.
160 BC: Jonathan Maccabaeus became both civil ruler of Judea and High Priest of the <jLink data-type='L' data-strong='H3389' clickHandler>Jerusalem</jLink> Temple.
160 BC: Jonathan continued the struggle for Jewish autonomy against the Seleucids and neighbors.

ChronologyEntries.article: 142 BC:  Simon Maccabaeus succeeded his brother Jonathan as leader of the Jewish people in 142 BC, assuming the dual roles of civil ruler and High Priest that had become established during the Hasmonean period. Simon's leadership proved particularly significant because he achieved complete political independence for the Jewish state, a milestone that distinguished his tenure from the qualified autonomy enjoyed by his predecessors under continuing Seleucid suzerainty. This achievement represented the culmination of the Maccabean struggle that had begun twenty-five years earlier with <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H6667H' clickHandler>Mattathias</jLink>'s revolt, finally securing the full sovereignty that the family had fought to establish. <jPara></jPara> Simon's rule is recognized as the foundational period of the Hasmonean dynasty, formally establishing a native Jewish ruling house that combined both secular and religious leadership under a single authority. His success in securing independence created a precedent for Jewish self-governance that would continue for several generations, though it also introduced tensions regarding the legitimacy of non-<jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H6659G' clickHandler>Zadokite</jLink> High Priests and the concentration of political and religious power in one family. The Hasmonean dynasty established under Simon would govern Judea until the Roman conquest, representing a unique period in Second Temple <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='G2454' clickHandler>Judaism</jLink> when <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='G2454' clickHandler>Jews</jLink> successfully maintained political autonomy through indigenous leadership.
events: 142 BC: Simon Maccabaeus succeeded Jonathan as Jewish leader.
142 BC: Simon Maccabaeus became both civil ruler and High Priest in <jLink data-type='L' data-strong='H3389' clickHandler>Jerusalem</jLink>.
142 BC: Simon Maccabaeus achieved Jewish political independence from the Seleucid Empire.
142 BC: Simon founded the Hasmonean dynasty, uniting secular and religious rule in Judea.

ChronologyEntries.article: 134 BC:  John Hyrcanus I assumed leadership of the Hasmonean dynasty in 134 BC following the death of his father Simon Maccabaeus, as referenced in 1 Maccabees 16. His accession marked the beginning of one of the most significant reigns in Hasmonean history, during which he successfully consolidated Jewish political and religious authority while dramatically expanding the territorial boundaries of the Jewish state.
