Unlike his predecessors who had achieved independence from Seleucid rule, John Hyrcanus I focused on territorial conquest and internal consolidation, transforming the modest Jewish territory into a substantial regional power that extended well beyond the traditional boundaries of Judea. <jPara></jPara> During his lengthy reign, John Hyrcanus I combined the roles of High Priest and civil ruler, establishing the institutional precedent that would characterize subsequent Hasmonean leadership. His military campaigns successfully conquered large portions of <jLink data-type='L' data-strong='H8111' clickHandler>Samaria</jLink>, <jLink data-type='L' data-strong='G2401' clickHandler>Idumea</jLink>, and Transjordan, forcing conquered populations to convert to <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='G2454' clickHandler>Judaism</jLink> and significantly expanding both the Jewish population and territorial control. These conquests, while enhancing Jewish political power, also introduced complex demographic and religious challenges that would influence Jewish society for generations, setting the foundation for the continued expansion and eventual internal conflicts that would characterize the later Hasmonean period.
events: 134 BC: Simon Maccabaeus was killed, ending his rule.
134 BC: John Hyrcanus I, Simon’s son, became both High Priest and Hasmonean ruler of Judea.

ChronologyEntries.article: 104 BC:  Aristobulus I became the first Hasmonean ruler to officially assume the dual titles of King and High Priest in 104 BC, formally establishing the monarchical character of Hasmonean rule. This unprecedented combination of royal and priestly authority represented a significant departure from traditional Jewish governance, where these roles had historically been separated, and created a new model of theocratic monarchy that would define Hasmonean leadership for the remainder of the dynasty. His decision to adopt the royal title reflected the growing political ambitions of the Hasmonean family and their desire to establish legitimacy comparable to other <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H3120H' clickHandler>Hellenistic</jLink> kingdoms in the region. <jPara></jPara> Despite the historical significance of his innovations, Aristobulus I's reign lasted only approximately one year, making it one of the briefest in Hasmonean history. His short tenure prevented him from implementing substantial policy changes or military campaigns, though his formal establishment of the dual monarchy created lasting institutional precedents for his successors. The brevity of his rule suggests internal instability or health issues, though specific details about the circumstances of his death remain unclear, and his primary historical importance lies in the constitutional precedent he established for combining royal and priestly authority under a single ruler.
events: 104 BC: <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='G2491G' clickHandler>John</jLink> Hyrcanus I’s rule ended.
104 BC: Aristobulus became High Priest and Hasmonean King.

ChronologyEntries.desc: Aristobulus I rules as High Priest

ChronologyEntries.article: 103 BC:  Alexander Jannaeus ascended to the combined offices of King and High Priest in 103 BC, continuing the institutional precedent established by his predecessor Aristobulus I and inaugurating one of the most militaristic and expansionist periods in Hasmonean history. His reign, lasting approximately twenty-seven years, was characterized by aggressive military campaigns aimed at further territorial expansion and the consolidation of Hasmonean power throughout the Levant. Unlike earlier Hasmonean leaders who had focused primarily on achieving and maintaining Jewish independence, Alexander Jannaeus pursued an ambitious agenda of conquest that extended Jewish control over numerous <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H1471G' clickHandler>Gentile</jLink> territories and populations. <jPara></jPara> Alexander Jannaeus's rule proved highly controversial due to his harsh policies toward internal Jewish opposition, particularly his conflicts with the <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='G5330' clickHandler>Pharisees</jLink>, who questioned both his religious legitimacy and his political methods. His reign witnessed significant civil strife, including open rebellion by Jewish factions who opposed his authoritarian rule and his perceived neglect of traditional Jewish religious sensibilities in favor of political and military objectives. These internal conflicts, combined with his extensive military campaigns, established patterns of political instability and religious tension that would characterize the later Hasmonean period and ultimately contribute to the dynasty's vulnerability to Roman intervention.
events: 103 BC: Aristobulus’ rule ended.
103 BC: Alexander Jannaeus became High Priest and Hasmonean King.

ChronologyEntries.desc: Aristobulus I rules as High Priest

ChronologyEntries.article: 67 BC:  Queen Alexandra (Salome Alexandra) assumed effective control of the Hasmonean kingdom in 67 BC by ruling through her son Hyrcanus II, who held the official title of High Priest while she exercised actual political authority. This arrangement represented a unique solution to the constitutional challenge posed by Jewish law, which prohibited women from serving as High Priest, while acknowledging Alexandra's political skills and experience gained during her previous marriage to Alexander Jannaeus. Her regency marked a notable period of relative stability and internal peace following the turbulent reign of her late husband, as she pursued policies of reconciliation with various Jewish factions that had been alienated during Alexander Jannaeus's authoritarian rule. <jPara></jPara> Alexandra's governance through Hyrcanus II demonstrated sophisticated political maneuvering within the constraints of Jewish religious law and Hasmonean institutional traditions. She successfully maintained the legitimacy of Hasmonean rule while managing competing interests among various Jewish religious and political factions, particularly working to restore favorable relations with the <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='G5330' clickHandler>Pharisees</jLink> who had been persecuted under Alexander Jannaeus. However, her arrangement also created potential succession complications, as her younger son Aristobulus II possessed greater military ambition and political support, setting the stage for the internal Hasmonean conflicts that would eventually provide <jLink data-type='L' data-strong='G4514' clickHandler>Rome</jLink> with opportunities for direct intervention in Jewish affairs.
events: 67 BC: Alexander Jannaeus’ rule ended.
67 BC: Queen Alexandra (Salome) began ruling the Hasmonean kingdom.
67 BC: Hyrcanus II, Alexandra’s son, was High Priest on her behalf.

ChronologyEntries.article: 63 BC:  Pompey the Great, the Roman general and member of the First Triumvirate, conquered <jLink data-type='L' data-strong='H3389' clickHandler>Jerusalem</jLink> in 63 BC, bringing an end to nearly eight decades of independent Hasmonean rule that had begun with the Maccabean Revolt. This conquest occurred during a period of internal Jewish conflict between the brothers Hyrcanus II and Aristobulus II, both sons of Queen Alexandra, who were competing for control of the kingdom following their mother's death in 67 BC. Pompey's intervention came at the request of delegations from both brothers, but he ultimately supported Hyrcanus II as High Priest while reducing the territorial boundaries of the Jewish state and imposing tribute payments to <jLink data-type='L' data-strong='G4514' clickHandler>Rome</jLink>. <jPara></jPara> The imposition of Roman rule fundamentally transformed Jewish governance, converting the previously independent Hasmonean kingdom into a client state subject to Roman oversight and intervention. Pompey's actions included the controversial decision to enter the Holy of <jLink data-type='L' data-strong='H6944H' clickHandler>Holies</jLink> in the <jLink data-type='L' data-strong='H3389' clickHandler>Jerusalem</jLink> Temple, an act that deeply offended Jewish religious sensibilities, though he reportedly took nothing from the sacred space. This conquest established precedents for Roman involvement in Jewish religious and political affairs that would characterize the region for the next several centuries, ultimately leading to the appointment of Roman governors and the eventual incorporation of Judea as a Roman province in 6 AD.
events: 63 BC: Pompey invaded and conquered <jLink data-type='L' data-strong='H3389' clickHandler>Jerusalem</jLink>.
63 BC: Pompey entered the Holy of <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H6944H' clickHandler>Holies</jLink>.
63 BC: Hasmonean rule over Israel ended with Roman occupation.
63 BC: Pompey confirmed Hyrcanus II as High Priest.

ChronologyEntries.article: 40 BC:  Antigonus, the son of Aristobulus II, assumed the dual titles of King and High Priest in 40 BC with crucial support from the <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='G3934' clickHandler>Parthian</jLink> Empire, which had invaded the Levant and sought to establish a buffer state against Roman expansion. His rise to power represented the final attempt by the Hasmonean dynasty to restore independent Jewish rule and reverse the Roman domination that had been imposed by Pompey in 63 BC. The <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='G3934' clickHandler>Parthians</jLink> captured Hyrcanus II, who had been serving as High Priest under Roman oversight, and mutilated his ears to disqualify him from future priestly service according to Jewish law, thereby clearing the way for Antigonus to claim legitimate religious authority. <jPara></jPara> Antigonus's reign was immediately contested by <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='G0493' clickHandler>Herod</jLink>, son of the <jLink data-type='L' data-strong='G2401' clickHandler>Idumean</jLink> Antipater, who had been appointed by the Roman Senate as King of the <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='G2454' clickHandler>Jews</jLink> and possessed superior Roman military backing. The conflict between Antigonus and <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='G0493' clickHandler>Herod</jLink> represented both a civil war within Jewish territory and a proxy war between the <jLink data-type='L' data-strong='G3934' clickHandler>Parthian</jLink> and Roman empires for control of this strategically important region. Despite his efforts to maintain Hasmonean rule and Jewish independence, Antigonus's reliance on foreign <jLink data-type='L' data-strong='G3934' clickHandler>Parthian</jLink> support ultimately undermined his legitimacy among many <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='G2454' clickHandler>Jews</jLink>, and his three-year reign would prove to be the last native Jewish monarchy until modern times.
events: 40 BC: Hyrcanus II’s High Priesthood ended when he was captured by the <jLink data-type='L' data-strong='G3934' clickHandler>Parthians</jLink>.
40 BC: Antigonus, son of Aristobulus II, became King and High Priest.
40 BC: <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='G0493' clickHandler>Herod</jLink> began his campaign to capture the throne.

ChronologyEntries.desc: <jChronDurationLink style='color:black'>▼</jChronDurationLink><jLink data-type='P' data-strong='G0067' clickHandler>Herod</jLink> the Great as King
ChronologyEntries.article: 37 BC:  <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='G0067' clickHandler>Herod</jLink> the Great captured <jLink data-type='L' data-strong='H3389' clickHandler>Jerusalem</jLink> in 37 BC after a prolonged siege, executing Antigonus and establishing his reign as King of the <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='G2454' clickHandler>Jews</jLink> under Roman authority. The son of Antipater the <jLink data-type='L' data-strong='G2401' clickHandler>Idumean</jLink>, <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='G0067' clickHandler>Herod</jLink> had been appointed King of the <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='G2454' clickHandler>Jews</jLink> by the Roman Senate in 40 BC but required three years of military campaigning, supported by Roman legions, to secure actual control of his kingdom. His victory marked the definitive end of Hasmonean rule and the beginning of the <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='G2265' clickHandler>Herodian</jLink> dynasty, which would govern Judea and surrounding territories under Roman oversight for approximately a century. <jPara></jPara> <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='G0067' clickHandler>Herod</jLink>'s early reign was characterized by efforts to consolidate power through the elimination of potential rivals, including members of the former Hasmonean royal family, and the initiation of ambitious building projects designed to legitimize his rule and demonstrate loyalty to <jLink data-type='L' data-strong='G4514' clickHandler>Rome</jLink>. Most notably, he began planning the massive expansion and beautification of the Second Temple in <jLink data-type='L' data-strong='H3389' clickHandler>Jerusalem</jLink>, a project that would continue for decades and transform the modest post-exilic structure into one of the architectural wonders of the ancient world. His complex relationship with <jLink data-type='L' data-strong='G4514' clickHandler>Rome</jLink> involved navigating shifting imperial politics, successfully transitioning his loyalty from <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='G3138' clickHandler>Mark</jLink> Antony to <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='G0828' clickHandler>Augustus</jLink> following the Battle of Actium in 31 BC, and serving as a reliable client king who maintained stability in a strategically crucial region of the Roman Empire.
events: 37 BC: <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='G0067' clickHandler>Herod</jLink> the Great captured <jLink data-type='L' data-strong='H3389' clickHandler>Jerusalem</jLink>, ending Hasmonean rule.
37 BC: <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='G0067' clickHandler>Herod</jLink> executed Antigonus, the last Hasmonean ruler.

37 BC: <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='G0067' clickHandler>Herod</jLink> began his reign as Roman-appointed King of the <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='G2454' clickHandler>Jews</jLink>, securing control with Roman military support.

37 BC: <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='G0067' clickHandler>Herod</jLink> started expanding and beautifying the Second Temple in <jLink data-type='L' data-strong='H3389' clickHandler>Jerusalem</jLink>.

37 BC: <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='G0067' clickHandler>Herod</jLink> shifted loyalty from <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='G3138' clickHandler>Mark</jLink> Antony to <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='G0828' clickHandler>Augustus</jLink> after Actium to remain <jLink data-type='L' data-strong='G4514' clickHandler>Rome</jLink>’s client king.

ChronologyEntries.article: 27 BC:  <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='G0828' clickHandler>Gaius Octavius</jLink>, was granted the title "<jLink data-type='P' data-strong='G0828' clickHandler>Augustus</jLink>" by the Roman Senate in 27 BC, marking the formal end of the Roman Republic and the establishment of the Roman Empire under his supreme authority. This constitutional settlement, known as the First Settlement, represented the culmination of decades of civil wars that had devastated the Roman world since the assassination of <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='G2457' clickHandler>Julius</jLink> Caesar in 44 BC. <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='G0828' clickHandler>Augustus</jLink> skillfully maintained the appearance of republican institutions while concentrating real power in his own hands through a combination of traditional offices and new imperial prerogatives, creating a political system that would endure for centuries. <jPara></jPara> The establishment of the Augustan principate had profound implications for Jewish communities throughout the Roman world, including those in Judea under King <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='G0493' clickHandler>Herod</jLink> the Great. <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='G0828' clickHandler>Augustus</jLink>'s policies generally favored religious tolerance and administrative stability, principles that benefited Jewish populations and their distinctive religious practices. His reign inaugurated the Pax Romana, a period of relative peace and prosperity that facilitated travel, trade, and communication throughout the <jLink data-type='L' data-strong='H1419J' clickHandler>Mediterranean</jLink> world, conditions that would prove crucial for the later spread of early Christianity and the development of diaspora Jewish communities in major urban centers across the empire.
events: 27 BC: <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='G0828' clickHandler>Gaius Octavius</jLink> was granted the title "<jLink data-type='P' data-strong='G0828' clickHandler>Augustus</jLink>" by the Roman Senate, becoming the first Roman Emperor.
27 BC: The Roman Republic ended and the Roman Empire began under <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='G0828' clickHandler>Augustus</jLink>.
27 BC: The First Settlement gave <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='G0828' clickHandler>Augustus</jLink> real power despite republican institutions.

ChronologyEntries.desc: <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='G2491G' clickHandler>John</jLink> the Baptist born
ChronologyEntries.article: 7 BC:  <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='G2491G' clickHandler>John</jLink> the Baptist was born to to <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='G2197H' clickHandler>Zechariah</jLink>, a priest of the division of <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H0029L' clickHandler>Abijah</jLink>, and his wife <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='G1665G' clickHandler>Elizabeth</jLink>, who was a descendant of <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H0175' clickHandler>Aaron</jLink>. The angel <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H1403' clickHandler>Gabriel</jLink> had appeared to <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='G2197H' clickHandler>Zechariah</jLink> while he was performing his priestly duties in the temple, announcing that despite their advanced age and previous childlessness, they would have a son who would be "great before the Lord" and filled with the Holy Spirit even before birth (Luk.1). When <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='G2197H' clickHandler>Zechariah</jLink> expressed doubt due to their old age, <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H1403' clickHandler>Gabriel</jLink> declared that he would remain mute until the prophecy was fulfilled. Upon <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='G2491G' clickHandler>John</jLink>'s birth, relatives expected the child to be named after his father, but <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='G1665G' clickHandler>Elizabeth</jLink> insisted on the name <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='G2491G' clickHandler>John</jLink>, which <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='G2197H' clickHandler>Zechariah</jLink> confirmed in writing, immediately restoring his speech and leading him to praise God. The prophecy declared that <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='G2491G' clickHandler>John</jLink> would go before the Lord "in the spirit and power of <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H0452G' clickHandler>Elijah</jLink>," preparing the people for the coming Messiah and turning many of the children of Israel to the Lord their God. <jPara></jPara>  During this same year, the birth of <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='G2424G' clickHandler>Jesus</jLink> was also promised (Luk.1:26; Mat.1:18-24). This occurred during the reign of <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='G2264G' clickHandler>Herod</jLink> the Great in Judea, under the broader authority of the Roman Empire led by <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='G0828' clickHandler>Augustus</jLink>. Some scholars have proposed that the year 7 BC aligns with a rare triple conjunction of <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='G2203' clickHandler>Jupiter</jLink> and Saturn in the constellation Pisces, which could potentially explain the astronomical phenomenon described as the Star of <jLink data-type='L' data-strong='H1035G' clickHandler>Bethlehem</jLink> in <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='G3156' clickHandler>Matthew</jLink>'s Gospel. The political landscape of this period was characterized by <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='G2264G' clickHandler>Herod</jLink>'s client kingship under Roman oversight and the stability of the Pax Romana, providing the historical backdrop for these foundational events in Christian history.
events: 7 BC: <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='G2491G' clickHandler>John</jLink> the Baptist was born to <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='G2197H' clickHandler>Zechariah</jLink> and <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='G1665G' clickHandler>Elizabeth</jLink> in Judea.
7 BC: <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='G2197H' clickHandler>Zechariah</jLink> regained his speech after confirming <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='G2491G' clickHandler>John</jLink>’s name.

7 BC: <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H1403' clickHandler>Gabriel</jLink> appeared to <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='G2197H' clickHandler>Zechariah</jLink> in the <jLink data-type='L' data-strong='H3389' clickHandler>Jerusalem</jLink> Temple to announce <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='G2491G' clickHandler>John</jLink>’s birth.

7 BC: <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H1403' clickHandler>Gabriel</jLink> announced <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='G2424G' clickHandler>Jesus</jLink>’ birth to <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='G3137G' clickHandler>Mary</jLink> in <jLink data-type='L' data-strong='G3478' clickHandler>Nazareth</jLink>.

7 BC: <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='G2501G' clickHandler>Joseph</jLink> was assured by an angel in a dream to marry <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='G3137G' clickHandler>Mary</jLink>, whose child was conceived by the Holy Spirit.

ChronologyEntries.desc: <jChronDurationLink style='color:green'>▼</jChronDurationLink><jLink data-type='P' data-strong='G2424G' clickHandler>Jesus</jLink> born; taken to temple
ChronologyEntries.article: 6 BC:  <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='G2424G' clickHandler>Jesus</jLink> was born in 6 BC during the reign of <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='G0745' clickHandler>Herod</jLink> the Great (Luk.2:1-40; Mat.1:25), with the birth occurring in <jLink data-type='L' data-strong='H1035G' clickHandler>Bethlehem</jLink> during a Roman census that required <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='G2501G' clickHandler>Joseph</jLink> and <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='G3137G' clickHandler>Mary</jLink> to travel from <jLink data-type='L' data-strong='G3478' clickHandler>Nazareth</jLink>. The Gospel of <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='G3065' clickHandler>Luke</jLink> provides the most detailed birth narrative, describing the angelic announcement to shepherds, their visit to the newborn Christ, and the subsequent events including <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='G2424G' clickHandler>Jesus</jLink>’ circumcision on the eighth day according to Jewish law. This dating allows sufficient time for the subsequent events described in the Gospels, including the visit of the Magi and the flight to <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H4714G' clickHandler>Egypt</jLink>, to occur before <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='G0745' clickHandler>Herod</jLink> the Great's death in 4 BC. <jPara></jPara>  Following Jewish custom, <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='G2424G' clickHandler>Jesus</jLink> was presented at the <jLink data-type='L' data-strong='H3389' clickHandler>Jerusalem</jLink> Temple when he was forty days old (Luk.2:22-39) where <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='G3137G' clickHandler>Mary</jLink> and <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='G2501G' clickHandler>Joseph</jLink> offered the prescribed sacrifice for purification and consecrated their firstborn son to the Lord. During this temple presentation, the aged <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='G4826G' clickHandler>Simeon</jLink> and the prophetess <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='G0451' clickHandler>Anna</jLink> both recognized <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='G2424G' clickHandler>Jesus</jLink> as the promised Messiah, with <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='G4826G' clickHandler>Simeon</jLink> declaring him to be "a light for revelation to the <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H1471G' clickHandler>Gentiles</jLink> and for glory to your people Israel" (Luk.2:32). This temple ceremony not only fulfilled Jewish religious obligations but also provided early public testimony to <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='G2424G' clickHandler>Jesus</jLink>’ messianic identity from devout <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='G2454' clickHandler>Jews</jLink> who had been waiting for Israel's redemption.
events: 6 BC: <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='G2424G' clickHandler>Jesus</jLink> was born in <jLink data-type='L' data-strong='H1035G' clickHandler>Bethlehem</jLink> to <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='G3137G' clickHandler>Mary</jLink> and <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='G2501G' clickHandler>Joseph</jLink>.

6 BC: Angels announced <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='G2424G' clickHandler>Jesus</jLink>’ birth to shepherds near <jLink data-type='L' data-strong='H1035G' clickHandler>Bethlehem</jLink>, who visited him.
6 BC: <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='G2424G' clickHandler>Jesus</jLink> was circumcised in <jLink data-type='L' data-strong='H1035G' clickHandler>Bethlehem</jLink> on the eighth day.

6 BC: <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='G3137G' clickHandler>Mary</jLink> and <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='G2501G' clickHandler>Joseph</jLink> presented <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='G2424G' clickHandler>Jesus</jLink> at the <jLink data-type='L' data-strong='H3389' clickHandler>Jerusalem</jLink> Temple forty days after his birth.

6 BC: <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='G4826G' clickHandler>Simeon</jLink> and <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='G0451' clickHandler>Anna</jLink> recognized <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='G2424G' clickHandler>Jesus</jLink> at the Temple.

ChronologyEntries.desc: Visit of the Magi; flight to <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H4714H' clickHandler>Egypt</jLink>
ChronologyEntries.article: 5 BC:  The Magi, likely <jLink data-type='L' data-strong='H6539' clickHandler>Persian</jLink> or <jLink data-type='L' data-strong='H0894' clickHandler>Babylonian</jLink> scholars skilled in astronomy and dream interpretation, arrived in <jLink data-type='L' data-strong='H3389' clickHandler>Jerusalem</jLink> in 5 BC following a significant celestial phenomenon they interpreted as announcing the birth of a new "king of the <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='G2454' clickHandler>Jews</jLink>". These wise men from the East first inquired at <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='G2264G' clickHandler>Herod</jLink>'s court, prompting the troubled king to consult Jewish religious leaders who identified <jLink data-type='L' data-strong='H1035G' clickHandler>Bethlehem</jLink> as the prophesied birthplace of the Messiah (Mat.2:1-12). The Magi subsequently found the child <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='G2424G' clickHandler>Jesus</jLink>, presented him with gifts of gold, frankincense, and myrrh, and departed by another route after being warned in a dream not to report back to <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='G2264G' clickHandler>Herod</jLink>. <jPara></jPara>  The Magi's visit triggered <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='G2264G' clickHandler>Herod</jLink> the Great's brutal response known as the Massacre of the Innocents, in which he ordered the killing of all male children in <jLink data-type='L' data-strong='H1035G' clickHandler>Bethlehem</jLink> aged two years and under (Mat.2:13-18). To escape this threat, <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='G2501G' clickHandler>Joseph</jLink> received an angelic warning in a dream and immediately fled with <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='G3137G' clickHandler>Mary</jLink> and <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='G2424G' clickHandler>Jesus</jLink> to <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H4714G' clickHandler>Egypt</jLink>, where they remained until <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='G2264G' clickHandler>Herod</jLink>'s death. This flight to <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H4714G' clickHandler>Egypt</jLink> fulfilled the prophetic expectation that the Messiah would be "called out of <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H4714G' clickHandler>Egypt</jLink>" (Mat.2:15, citing Hos.11:1), while <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H4714G' clickHandler>Egypt</jLink>'s substantial Jewish population and its location outside <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='G2264G' clickHandler>Herod</jLink>'s jurisdiction provided a logical refuge for the Holy Family during their exile.
events: 5 BC: The Magi arrived in <jLink data-type='L' data-strong='H3389' clickHandler>Jerusalem</jLink> seeking the newborn "king of the <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='G2454' clickHandler>Jews</jLink>."

5 BC: <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='G2264G' clickHandler>Herod</jLink> the Great consulted Jewish chief priests and scribes in <jLink data-type='L' data-strong='H3389' clickHandler>Jerusalem</jLink> about the Messiah's birthplace.
5 BC: The Magi visited <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='G2424G' clickHandler>Jesus</jLink> in <jLink data-type='L' data-strong='H1035G' clickHandler>Bethlehem</jLink> and presented gifts.
5 BC: Warned in a dream, the Magi departed by another route.

5 BC: <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='G2264G' clickHandler>Herod</jLink> the Great ordered the massacre of all boys two years and under in <jLink data-type='L' data-strong='H1035G' clickHandler>Bethlehem</jLink>.

ChronologyEntries.desc: <jChronDurationLink style='color:black'>▼</jChronDurationLink>H. <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='G0745' clickHandler>Archelaus</jLink>; <jChronDurationLink style='color:black'>▼</jChronDurationLink>H. <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='G0493' clickHandler>Antipas</jLink>; H. <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='G5376I' clickHandler>Philip</jLink> I;
ChronologyEntries.article: 4 BC:  <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='G2264G' clickHandler>Herod</jLink> the Great died in 4 BC after a reign of approximately thirty-three years, during which he had transformed Judea through massive building projects including the expansion of the Second Temple while maintaining Roman favor through political cunning and brutality. His death marked the end of unified rule over the Jewish territories and initiated a period of political fragmentation that would continue until the Roman annexation of Judea in 6 AD. Following <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='G2264G' clickHandler>Herod</jLink>'s death, his kingdom was divided among three of his surviving sons according to his will and with Roman approval, creating separate administrative regions that would each develop distinct political and religious characteristics.  <jPara></jPara>  The territorial division allocated Judea, <jLink data-type='L' data-strong='H8111' clickHandler>Samaria</jLink>, and <jLink data-type='L' data-strong='G2401' clickHandler>Idumea</jLink> to <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='G2264G' clickHandler>Herod</jLink> <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='G0745' clickHandler>Archelaus</jLink>, who received the title of ethnarch but proved so incompetent that <jLink data-type='L' data-strong='G4514' clickHandler>Rome</jLink> deposed him in 6 AD and converted Judea into a Roman province. <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='G2264G' clickHandler>Herod</jLink> <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='G0493' clickHandler>Antipas</jLink> became tetrarch of <jLink data-type='L' data-strong='H1551' clickHandler>Galilee</jLink> and Perea, a position he would hold for over forty years until his exile in 39 AD, making him the ruler who would later encounter both <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='G2491G' clickHandler>John</jLink> the Baptist and <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='G2424G' clickHandler>Jesus</jLink> during their ministries. <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='G5376I' clickHandler>Philip</jLink> received the northeastern territories including <jLink data-type='L' data-strong='G2542H' clickHandler>Caesarea</jLink> <jLink data-type='L' data-strong='G5375' clickHandler>Philippi</jLink> and ruled as tetrarch until his death in 34 AD, governing with considerably more competence than his brothers and maintaining relative stability in his region. <jPara></jPara> .
events: 4 BC: <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='G2264G' clickHandler>Herod</jLink> the Great died in <jLink data-type='L' data-strong='H3405G' clickHandler>Jericho</jLink>.
4 BC: <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='G2264G' clickHandler>Herod</jLink>’s kingdom was appointed by <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='G0828' clickHandler>Augustus</jLink> to his children

4 BC: <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='G0745' clickHandler>Archelaus</jLink>, son of <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='G2264G' clickHandler>Herod</jLink> the Great, became ethnarch of Judea, <jLink data-type='L' data-strong='H8111' clickHandler>Samaria</jLink>, and <jLink data-type='L' data-strong='G2401' clickHandler>Idumea</jLink>.
4 BC: Unrest and revolts broke out in Judea.

ChronologyEntries.desc: Return from <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H4714H' clickHandler>Egypt</jLink>. Live in <jLink data-type='L' data-strong='G3478' clickHandler>Nazareth</jLink>.
ChronologyEntries.article: 3 BC:  The family of <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='G2424G' clickHandler>Jesus</jLink> returned from <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H4714G' clickHandler>Egypt</jLink> after the death of <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='G2264G' clickHandler>Herod</jLink> the Great (Mat.2:19-23). According to the Gospel account, <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='G2501G' clickHandler>Joseph</jLink> received an angelic instruction in a dream to return to the land of Israel with <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='G3137G' clickHandler>Mary</jLink> and the child <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='G2424G' clickHandler>Jesus</jLink>, ending their exile that had begun to escape <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='G2264G' clickHandler>Herod</jLink>'s massacre of the innocents. However, upon learning that <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='G2264G' clickHandler>Herod</jLink>'s dangerous son <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='G0745' clickHandler>Archelaus</jLink> was now ruling over Judea, <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='G2501G' clickHandler>Joseph</jLink> was warned in another dream to avoid that region and instead traveled north to settle in the <jLink data-type='L' data-strong='H1551' clickHandler>Galilean</jLink> town of <jLink data-type='L' data-strong='G3478' clickHandler>Nazareth</jLink>. <jPara></jPara> This settlement in <jLink data-type='L' data-strong='G3478' clickHandler>Nazareth</jLink> fulfilled the prophetic expectation that the Messiah would be called a Nazarene, as <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='G3156' clickHandler>Matthew</jLink> notes in his Gospel. The return occurred during a period of significant political transition following <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='G2264G' clickHandler>Herod</jLink> the Great's death in 4 BC, when his kingdom was divided among his three surviving sons, according to his will and Roman approval. They settling in territory governed by the more competent <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='G2264G' clickHandler>Herod</jLink> <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='G0493' clickHandler>Antipas</jLink>, establishing <jLink data-type='L' data-strong='G3478' clickHandler>Nazareth</jLink> as the hometown where <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='G2424G' clickHandler>Jesus</jLink> would spend his childhood and early adult years.
events: 3 BC: <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='G2501G' clickHandler>Joseph</jLink> returned with <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='G3137G' clickHandler>Mary</jLink> and <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='G2424G' clickHandler>Jesus</jLink> from <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H4714G' clickHandler>Egypt</jLink> to Israel after <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='G2264G' clickHandler>Herod</jLink>’s death.

3 BC: <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='G2501G' clickHandler>Joseph</jLink> settled the Holy Family in <jLink data-type='L' data-strong='G3478' clickHandler>Nazareth</jLink>, <jLink data-type='L' data-strong='H1551' clickHandler>Galilee</jLink>, after being warned about <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='G0745' clickHandler>Archelaus</jLink>.

ChronologyEntries.desc: <jChronDurationLink style='color:red'>▼</jChronDurationLink>Coponius Prefect. H. <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='G0745' clickHandler>Archelaus</jLink> deposed.
ChronologyEntries.article: AD 6:  <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='G0745' clickHandler>Herod Archelaus</jLink> was deposed by the Roman authorities in AD 6, bringing an end to his troubled ten-year rule over Judea, <jLink data-type='L' data-strong='H8111' clickHandler>Samaria</jLink>, and <jLink data-type='L' data-strong='G2401' clickHandler>Idumea</jLink>. The ethnarch had proven incompetent and brutal in his governance, prompting complaints from both Jewish and <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H8111' clickHandler>Samaritan</jLink> delegations to Emperor <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='G0828' clickHandler>Augustus</jLink>, who ultimately decided to remove him from power and exile him to Gaul. This deposition marked a crucial transition from the <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='G2265' clickHandler>Herodian</jLink> client kingdom system to direct Roman provincial administration, as Judea was incorporated into the Roman Empire as a minor province under the oversight of the <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H0758I' clickHandler>Syrian</jLink> legate. <jPara></jPara> Concurrently with this administrative change, the Romans conducted the Census of <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='G2958' clickHandler>Quirinius</jLink> in AD 6, a major bureaucratic undertaking designed to establish taxation systems and assess the resources of the newly formed province. <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='G4196' clickHandler>Publius</jLink> Sulpicius <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='G2958' clickHandler>Quirinius</jLink>, serving as legate of <jLink data-type='L' data-strong='H0758I' clickHandler>Syria</jLink>, oversaw this census which catalogued property, population, and taxable assets throughout Judea. The census represented <jLink data-type='L' data-strong='G4514' clickHandler>Rome</jLink>'s systematic approach to provincial administration and taxation, though it also created resentment among the Jewish population who viewed it as a symbol of foreign domination and a violation of their traditional autonomy under the Mosaic covenant.
events: AD 6: <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='G0745' clickHandler>Herod Archelaus</jLink>’ rule ended.
AD 6: Coponius was installed as Prefect of the new Province of Judea.
AD 6: The <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='G2958' clickHandler>Quirinius</jLink> census determined taxation for Israel.

ChronologyEntries.desc: <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='G2424G' clickHandler>Jesus</jLink> in the Temple at age 12
ChronologyEntries.article: AD 7:  <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='G2424G' clickHandler>Jesus</jLink> visited the <jLink data-type='L' data-strong='H3389' clickHandler>Jerusalem</jLink> Temple at the age of twelve during the annual <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H6453' clickHandler>Passover</jLink> pilgrimage undertaken by his family (Luk.2:41-52). This visit occurred within the context of Jewish custom, as boys approaching the age of thirteen were increasingly incorporated into religious observances and Torah study in preparation for full religious responsibility. During the festival, <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='G2424G' clickHandler>Jesus</jLink> engaged in discussion with the teachers in the Temple courts, demonstrating remarkable understanding of spiritual matters that astonished both the religious scholars and his parents when they discovered him there after searching for him for three days. <jPara></jPara> The event highlights the intersection of Jewish religious tradition with <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='G2424G' clickHandler>Jesus</jLink>’ emerging spiritual identity, as his response to his parents' concerns—"Did you not know that I must be in my Father's house?"—reveals his growing awareness of his unique relationship with God. This Temple visit represents one of the few recorded incidents from <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='G2424G' clickHandler>Jesus</jLink>’ childhood, providing insight into his early spiritual development and his family's faithful adherence to Jewish religious customs. The account also demonstrates the importance of the <jLink data-type='L' data-strong='H3389' clickHandler>Jerusalem</jLink> Temple as the center of Jewish religious life during the Second Temple period, drawing pilgrims from throughout the Roman world for the major festivals.
events: AD 7: <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='G2424G' clickHandler>Jesus</jLink>, at age twelve, visited the <jLink data-type='L' data-strong='H3389' clickHandler>Jerusalem</jLink> Temple for <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H6453' clickHandler>Passover</jLink>.
AD 7: <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='G2424G' clickHandler>Jesus</jLink> stayed in the Temple courts, engaging with teachers.

AD 7: <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='G3137G' clickHandler>Mary</jLink> and <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='G2501G' clickHandler>Joseph</jLink> found <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='G2424G' clickHandler>Jesus</jLink> in the Temple after searching for three days.

ChronologyEntries.article: AD 9:  Marcus Ambivius was appointed as the Prefect of Judea in AD 9, succeeding Coponius in the direct Roman administration of the province that had been established following the deposition of <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='G0745' clickHandler>Herod Archelaus</jLink> three years earlier. As prefect, Ambivius exercised both civil and military authority over the province while reporting directly to the Roman legate of <jLink data-type='L' data-strong='H0758I' clickHandler>Syria</jLink>, reflecting Judea's status as a minor but significant administrative unit within the larger imperial structure. <jPara></jPara> The prefectural system under which Ambivius operated was specifically designed to ensure tighter Roman control over a region that had experienced considerable instability under <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='G2265' clickHandler>Herodian</jLink> rule. His responsibilities included maintaining public order, overseeing the collection of imperial taxes, and administering justice according to Roman law while respecting certain Jewish religious sensitivities. This administrative framework would remain in place for decades, with subsequent prefects including the more famous <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='G4091' clickHandler>Pontius Pilate</jLink>, establishing the governmental context within which <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='G2424G' clickHandler>Jesus</jLink>’ later ministry and crucifixion would occur.
events: AD 9: Coponius’ rule ended.
AD 9: Marcus Ambivius was appointed Prefect.

ChronologyEntries.article: AD 12:  Annius Rufus served as the third Roman Prefect of Judea in AD 12, succeeding Marcus Ambivius in the direct Roman administration that had been established following the deposition of <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='G0745' clickHandler>Herod Archelaus</jLink> in AD 6. <jPara></jPara> As prefect, Rufus exercised both civil and military authority over the province of Judea while reporting to the Roman legate of <jLink data-type='L' data-strong='H0758I' clickHandler>Syria</jLink>, continuing the administrative framework designed to maintain order and collect taxes in this strategically important region. His appointment represented the ongoing Roman effort to stabilize governance in Judea following the tumultuous final years of <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='G2265' clickHandler>Herodian</jLink> rule under the incompetent <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='G0745' clickHandler>Archelaus</jLink>.
events: AD 12: Ambivius’ rule ended.
AD 12: Annius Rufus was appointed Prefect.

ChronologyEntries.desc: <jChronDurationLink style='color:red'>▼</jChronDurationLink><jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H7557' clickHandler>Tiberias</jLink> as Roman Emperor
ChronologyEntries.article: AD 14:  <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='G5086' clickHandler>Tiberius</jLink> <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='G2804G' clickHandler>Claudius</jLink> <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='G3505' clickHandler>Nero</jLink>, stepson and adopted heir of <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='G0828' clickHandler>Augustus</jLink>, became Roman Emperor in AD 14 following <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='G0828' clickHandler>Augustus</jLink>'s death, inaugurating a reign that would last until AD 37 and significantly impact the development of early Christianity. Unlike his predecessor who had established the principate through charisma and political skill, <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='G5086' clickHandler>Tiberius</jLink> assumed power reluctantly and governed with a more austere and suspicious temperament that created tensions within the Roman political elite. His accession marked the first peaceful transfer of imperial power in Roman history, demonstrating the stability of the constitutional arrangements established by <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='G0828' clickHandler>Augustus</jLink> and ensuring continuity in Roman governance across the empire. <jPara></jPara> <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='G5086' clickHandler>Tiberius</jLink>'s reign proved crucial for Jewish communities throughout the Roman world, as his policies generally maintained the religious tolerance established by <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='G0828' clickHandler>Augustus</jLink> while strengthening imperial administration in the provinces. His appointment of capable governors and prefects, including <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='G4091' clickHandler>Pontius Pilate</jLink> in Judea (AD 26-36), created the political framework within which <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='G2491G' clickHandler>John</jLink> the Baptist's ministry and <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='G2424G' clickHandler>Jesus</jLink>’ crucifixion would occur. The emperor's focus on efficient provincial administration and his general reluctance to involve himself in local religious disputes provided a relatively stable environment for the emergence and early spread of Christianity throughout the eastern <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H1419J' clickHandler>Mediterranean</jLink>.
events: AD 14: Emperor <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='G0828' clickHandler>Augustus</jLink> died in <jLink data-type='L' data-strong='G4514' clickHandler>Rome</jLink>.

AD 14: <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='G5086' clickHandler>Tiberius</jLink> <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='G2804G' clickHandler>Claudius</jLink> <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='G3505' clickHandler>Nero</jLink> became Roman Emperor.

ChronologyEntries.article: AD 15:  Valerius Gratus was appointed as Roman Prefect of Judea in AD 15, succeeding Annius Rufus and serving in this capacity for eleven years until AD 26, when he was replaced by <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='G4091' clickHandler>Pontius Pilate</jLink>. His lengthy tenure represented one of the most stable periods of Roman administration in Judea during the early first century, providing continuity in governance that helped establish effective working relationships between Roman authorities and Jewish religious leaders. Gratus exercised the typical prefectural responsibilities of maintaining public order, collecting imperial taxes, and overseeing legal proceedings while respecting Jewish religious customs and the authority of the <jLink data-type='L' data-strong='H3389' clickHandler>Jerusalem</jLink> Temple priesthood. <jPara></jPara> During his administration, Gratus notably influenced Jewish religious affairs through his appointments and depositions of High Priests, demonstrating the extent to which Roman authority had penetrated traditional Jewish institutional structures. His manipulations of the High Priesthood, including the appointment of <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='G2533G' clickHandler>Caiaphas</jLink> who would later play a crucial role in <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='G2424G' clickHandler>Jesus</jLink>’ trial, reflected the Roman policy of controlling local religious leadership to ensure political stability. Gratus's eleven-year tenure established many of the administrative precedents and political relationships that would characterize Roman-Jewish relations during the subsequent governorship of <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='G4091' clickHandler>Pontius Pilate</jLink>, creating the institutional context for the pivotal events of <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='G2424G' clickHandler>Jesus</jLink>’ ministry and crucifixion.
events: AD 15: Rufus’ rule ended.
AD 15: Valerius Gratus became Roman Prefect.

ChronologyEntries.desc: <jChronDurationLink style='color:red'>▼</jChronDurationLink><jLink data-type='P' data-strong='G4091' clickHandler>Pilate</jLink>; <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='G2424G' clickHandler>Jesus</jLink>' ministry starts
ChronologyEntries.article: AD 26:  <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='G2491G' clickHandler>John</jLink> the Baptist's public ministry and the start of <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='G2424G' clickHandler>Jesus</jLink>’ earthly ministry is recorded across all four Gospels (Mat.3:1-4:11; Mrk.1:1-13; Luk.3:1-4:13; Jhn.1:19-2:11). <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='G2491G' clickHandler>John</jLink> the Baptist emerged in the wilderness of Judea, preaching a baptism of repentance for the forgiveness of sins and calling people to prepare for the coming of the Lord, fulfilling the prophetic expectation of one who would "prepare the way of the Lord" (Isa.40:3). His ministry drew large crowds from <jLink data-type='L' data-strong='H3389' clickHandler>Jerusalem</jLink>, Judea, and the surrounding regions to the <jLink data-type='L' data-strong='H3383' clickHandler>Jordan</jLink> River, where he baptized those who confessed their sins and committed to spiritual reform. <jPara></jPara> <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='G2424G' clickHandler>Jesus</jLink>’ baptism by <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='G2491G' clickHandler>John</jLink> the Baptist marked the formal inauguration of his public ministry, accompanied by the descent of the Holy Spirit and the divine declaration identifying <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='G2424G' clickHandler>Jesus</jLink> as God's beloved Son. Following his baptism, <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='G2424G' clickHandler>Jesus</jLink> underwent forty days of testing in the wilderness, during which he successfully resisted <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H7854' clickHandler>Satan</jLink>'s temptations, demonstrating his spiritual authority and readiness for his messianic mission. The year concluded with <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='G2424G' clickHandler>Jesus</jLink>’ first miracle at the wedding in <jLink data-type='L' data-strong='H7071H' clickHandler>Cana</jLink>, where he transformed water into wine (Jhn.2:1-11), and his initial gathering of disciples, establishing the foundation for his public ministry that would transform both <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='G2454' clickHandler>Judaism</jLink> and the broader ancient world. These events collectively represent the transition from the preparatory ministry of <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='G2491G' clickHandler>John</jLink> the Baptist to the active messianic ministry of <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='G2424G' clickHandler>Jesus</jLink>, fulfilling centuries of prophetic expectations and inaugurating the New Testament era.
events: AD 26: <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='G2491G' clickHandler>John</jLink> the Baptist began his public ministry in the wilderness of Judea.

AD 26: <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='G2424G' clickHandler>Jesus</jLink> was baptized by <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='G2491G' clickHandler>John</jLink> at the <jLink data-type='L' data-strong='H3383' clickHandler>Jordan</jLink> River.
AD 26: <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='G2424G' clickHandler>Jesus</jLink> was tempted by <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H7854' clickHandler>Satan</jLink> for forty days in the wilderness.
AD 26: <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='G2424G' clickHandler>Jesus</jLink> gathered his first disciples near the <jLink data-type='L' data-strong='H3383' clickHandler>Jordan</jLink>.

AD 26: <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='G2424G' clickHandler>Jesus</jLink> performed his first miracle at <jLink data-type='L' data-strong='H7071H' clickHandler>Cana</jLink> in <jLink data-type='L' data-strong='H1551' clickHandler>Galilee</jLink>.

ChronologyEntries.desc: Disciples, <jLink data-type='L' data-strong='H1551' clickHandler>Galilee</jLink>, <jLink data-type='L' data-strong='H8111' clickHandler>Samaria</jLink>, <jLink data-type='L' data-strong='H3389' clickHandler>Jerusalem</jLink>
ChronologyEntries.article: AD 27:  The transition from <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='G2491G' clickHandler>John</jLink> the Baptist's preparatory ministry to <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='G2424G' clickHandler>Jesus</jLink>’ public ministry ended with <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='G2491G' clickHandler>John</jLink> the Baptist's imprisonment by <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='G0493' clickHandler>Herod Antipas</jLink>. <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='G2424G' clickHandler>Jesus</jLink> withdrew from Judea to <jLink data-type='L' data-strong='H1551' clickHandler>Galilee</jLink> and began calling his first disciples, including <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='G4613G' clickHandler>Simon</jLink> <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='G4074G' clickHandler>Peter</jLink>, <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='G0406' clickHandler>Andrew</jLink>, <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='G2385G' clickHandler>James</jLink>, and <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='G2491G' clickHandler>John</jLink> from their fishing boats near <jLink data-type='L' data-strong='G2584' clickHandler>Capernaum</jLink> (Mat.4:12-22; Mrk.1:14-20). Having started his ministry in <jLink data-type='L' data-strong='H1551' clickHandler>Galilee</jLink>, <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='G2491G' clickHandler>John</jLink> records that <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='G2424G' clickHandler>Jesus</jLink> traveled to <jLink data-type='L' data-strong='H3389' clickHandler>Jerusalem</jLink> for the <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H6453' clickHandler>Passover</jLink> festival, where he dramatically cleansed the temple by driving out the money changers and merchants, declaring his zeal for his Father's house (Jhn.2:13-25). <jPara></jPara> During this foundational year, <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='G2424G' clickHandler>Jesus</jLink> engaged in crucial theological dialogues that established key themes of his ministry, including his nighttime conversation with <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='G3530' clickHandler>Nicodemus</jLink> about spiritual rebirth and the necessity of being "born again" (Jhn.3:1-21). His journey through <jLink data-type='L' data-strong='H8111' clickHandler>Samaria</jLink> resulted in the transformative encounter with the <jLink data-type='L' data-strong='H8111' clickHandler>Samaritan</jLink> woman at <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='G2384G' clickHandler>Jacob</jLink>'s well, where <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='G2424G' clickHandler>Jesus</jLink> revealed himself as the Messiah and demonstrated his mission to transcend traditional ethnic and religious barriers (Jhn.4:1-42). Returning to <jLink data-type='L' data-strong='H1551' clickHandler>Galilee</jLink>, <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='G2424G' clickHandler>Jesus</jLink> continued performing healing miracles and teaching in synagogues, establishing <jLink data-type='L' data-strong='G2584' clickHandler>Capernaum</jLink> as the center of his <jLink data-type='L' data-strong='H1551' clickHandler>Galilean</jLink> ministry while his reputation spread throughout the region (Mat.4:23-25; Luk.4:14-44). The year concluded with <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='G2424G' clickHandler>Jesus</jLink> attending an unspecified feast in <jLink data-type='L' data-strong='H3389' clickHandler>Jerusalem</jLink>, where he healed a paralytic at the pool of <jLink data-type='L' data-strong='G0964' clickHandler>Bethesda</jLink> and defended his authority to work on the <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H7676' clickHandler>Sabbath</jLink>, setting the stage for the growing opposition that would characterize subsequent years (Jhn.5:1-47).
events: AD 27: <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='G2491G' clickHandler>John</jLink> the Baptist was imprisoned by <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='G0493' clickHandler>Herod Antipas</jLink>.
AD 27: <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='G2424G' clickHandler>Jesus</jLink> withdrew to <jLink data-type='L' data-strong='H1551' clickHandler>Galilee</jLink> and began his public ministry.

AD 27: <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='G2424G' clickHandler>Jesus</jLink> called <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='G4613G' clickHandler>Simon</jLink> <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='G4074G' clickHandler>Peter</jLink>, <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='G0406' clickHandler>Andrew</jLink>, <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='G2385G' clickHandler>James</jLink>, and <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='G2491G' clickHandler>John</jLink> near <jLink data-type='L' data-strong='G2584' clickHandler>Capernaum</jLink>.

AD 27: <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='G2424G' clickHandler>Jesus</jLink> cleansed the <jLink data-type='L' data-strong='H3389' clickHandler>Jerusalem</jLink> Temple at <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H6453' clickHandler>Passover</jLink>.

AD 27: <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='G2424G' clickHandler>Jesus</jLink> met <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='G3530' clickHandler>Nicodemus</jLink> in <jLink data-type='L' data-strong='H3389' clickHandler>Jerusalem</jLink> and taught about rebirth.

ChronologyEntries.article: AD 28:  <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='G2424G' clickHandler>Jesus</jLink>’ public teaching ministry was characterized by his systematic proclamation of the Kingdom of God through both ethical instruction and parabolic teaching. The most significant theological contribution was the Sermon on the Mount, delivered on a hillside in <jLink data-type='L' data-strong='H1551' clickHandler>Galilee</jLink>, where <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='G2424G' clickHandler>Jesus</jLink> articulated the fundamental principles of Kingdom living through the Beatitudes, teachings on prayer including the Lord's Prayer, and radical ethical standards that challenged conventional religious practice (Mat.5-7; Luk.6:20-49). <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='G2424G' clickHandler>Jesus</jLink> formally appointed the Twelve Apostles—<jLink data-type='P' data-strong='G4613G' clickHandler>Simon</jLink> <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='G4074G' clickHandler>Peter</jLink>, <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='G0406' clickHandler>Andrew</jLink>, <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='G2385G' clickHandler>James</jLink>, <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='G2491H' clickHandler>John</jLink>, <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='G5376G' clickHandler>Philip</jLink>, <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='G0918' clickHandler>Bartholomew</jLink>, <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='G3156' clickHandler>Matthew</jLink>, <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='G2381' clickHandler>Thomas</jLink>, <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='G2385G' clickHandler>James</jLink> son of <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='G0256' clickHandler>Alphaeus</jLink>, <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='G2455G' clickHandler>Thaddaeus</jLink>, <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='G4613G' clickHandler>Simon</jLink> the Zealot, and <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='G2455H' clickHandler>Judas Iscariot</jLink>—commissioning them as his primary disciples and representatives for future ministry expansion (Mat.10:1-4; Mrk.3:13-19; Luk.6:12-16). <jPara></jPara> As <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='G2424G' clickHandler>Jesus</jLink>’ fame spread throughout <jLink data-type='L' data-strong='H1551' clickHandler>Galilee</jLink> and beyond, he increasingly encountered opposition from the religious establishment, particularly regarding his liberal interpretation of <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H7676' clickHandler>Sabbath</jLink> laws and his association with tax collectors and sinners. His extensive use of parables, included the famous parables of the sower, the mustard seed, and the hidden treasure, which revealed Kingdom truths to receptive hearers while concealing them from hostile audiences (Mat.13:1-52; Mrk.4:1-34; Luk.8:1-18). <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='G2424G' clickHandler>Jesus</jLink>’ rejection in his hometown of <jLink data-type='L' data-strong='G3478' clickHandler>Nazareth</jLink> where the residents' familiarity with his humble origins prevented them from accepting his prophetic authority, prompting <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='G2424G' clickHandler>Jesus</jLink> to observe that "a prophet is not without honor except in his hometown and among his relatives" (Mat.13:53-58; Mrk.6:1-6; Luk.4:16-30). This pattern of mixed reception—enthusiastic crowds alongside growing religious opposition—established the dynamic tension that would culminate in his eventual crucifixion.
events: AD 28: <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='G2424G' clickHandler>Jesus</jLink> delivered the Sermon on the Mount in <jLink data-type='L' data-strong='H1551' clickHandler>Galilee</jLink>.
AD 28: <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='G2424G' clickHandler>Jesus</jLink> formally appointed the twelve apostles.

AD 28: <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='G2424G' clickHandler>Jesus</jLink> taught crowds in <jLink data-type='L' data-strong='H1551' clickHandler>Galilee</jLink> using parables like the sower and mustard seed.

AD 28: <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='G2424G' clickHandler>Jesus</jLink> faced growing opposition from <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='G5330' clickHandler>Pharisees</jLink> and religious leaders in <jLink data-type='L' data-strong='H1551' clickHandler>Galilee</jLink>.
AD 28: <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='G2424G' clickHandler>Jesus</jLink> was rejected in his hometown of <jLink data-type='L' data-strong='G3478' clickHandler>Nazareth</jLink>.

ChronologyEntries.desc: Through <jLink data-type='L' data-strong='H0758I' clickHandler>Syria</jLink> & <jLink data-type='L' data-strong='H1551' clickHandler>Galilee</jLink> to <jLink data-type='L' data-strong='H3389' clickHandler>Jerusalem</jLink>
ChronologyEntries.article: AD 29:  The significant expansion of <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='G2424G' clickHandler>Jesus</jLink>’ ministry beyond the traditional boundaries of Jewish territory, with his travels extending into predominantly <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H1471G' clickHandler>Gentile</jLink> regions such as <jLink data-type='L' data-strong='H6865' clickHandler>Tyre</jLink> and <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H6721G' clickHandler>Sidon</jLink>, demonstrated the universal scope of his messianic mission. The feedings of thousands near the Sea of <jLink data-type='L' data-strong='H1551' clickHandler>Galilee</jLink>, not only provided physical sustenance for the multitude but also served as the foundation for <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='G2424G' clickHandler>Jesus</jLink>’ profound "Bread of Life" discourse, in which he declared himself the true bread from heaven who gives eternal life to the world (Jhn.6:1-71). This miraculous feeding, followed by <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='G2424G' clickHandler>Jesus</jLink> walking on water to reach his disciples' boat during a storm, further revealed his divine authority over both natural elements and human need (Mat.14:13-33; Mrk.6:30-52; Luk.9:10-17). <jPara></jPara> A theological climax occurred at <jLink data-type='L' data-strong='G2542H' clickHandler>Caesarea</jLink> <jLink data-type='L' data-strong='G5375' clickHandler>Philippi</jLink>, where <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='G4074G' clickHandler>Peter</jLink>'s confession of <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='G2424G' clickHandler>Jesus</jLink> as "the Christ, the Son of the living God" prompted <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='G2424G' clickHandler>Jesus</jLink>’ first explicit prediction of his coming suffering, death, and resurrection—a revelation that deeply disturbed his disciples who had expected a triumphant political messiah (Mat.16:13-28; Mrk.8:27-9:1; Luk.9:18-27). A few days later, the Transfiguration on a high mountain provided divine confirmation of <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='G2424G' clickHandler>Jesus</jLink>’ identity when <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H4872' clickHandler>Moses</jLink> and <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H0452G' clickHandler>Elijah</jLink> appeared with him, and the heavenly voice declared, "This is my beloved Son; listen to him" (Mat.17:1-13; Mrk.9:2-13; Luk.9:28-36). <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='G2424G' clickHandler>Jesus</jLink> began his final journey toward <jLink data-type='L' data-strong='H3389' clickHandler>Jerusalem</jLink>, teaching extensively about discipleship, forgiveness, and the cost of following him, while repeatedly predicting his passion to prepare his disciples for the events that would unfold in the coming year (Luk.9:51-19:27). This period established the theological foundation for understanding his death not as a tragic defeat but as the intended climax of his redemptive mission.
events: AD 29: <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='G2424G' clickHandler>Jesus</jLink> expanded his ministry to <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H1471G' clickHandler>Gentile</jLink> regions, including <jLink data-type='L' data-strong='H6865' clickHandler>Tyre</jLink> and <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H6721G' clickHandler>Sidon</jLink>.
AD 29: <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='G2424G' clickHandler>Jesus</jLink> fed thousands near the Sea of <jLink data-type='L' data-strong='H1551' clickHandler>Galilee</jLink>.
AD 29: <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='G2424G' clickHandler>Jesus</jLink> walked on water.

AD 29: <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='G4074G' clickHandler>Peter</jLink> confessed <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='G2424G' clickHandler>Jesus</jLink> as "the Christ" at <jLink data-type='L' data-strong='G2542H' clickHandler>Caesarea</jLink> <jLink data-type='L' data-strong='G5375' clickHandler>Philippi</jLink>.

AD 29: <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='G2424G' clickHandler>Jesus</jLink> was transfigured on a high mountain before <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='G4074G' clickHandler>Peter</jLink>, <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='G2385G' clickHandler>James</jLink>, and <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='G2491G' clickHandler>John</jLink>.

ChronologyEntries.desc: Palm Sunday to <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H6453' clickHandler>Passover</jLink> & <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H7620G' clickHandler>Pentecost</jLink>.
ChronologyEntries.article: AD 30:  The climactic events of <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='G2424G' clickHandler>Jesus</jLink>’ earthly ministry began with his triumphal entry into <jLink data-type='L' data-strong='H3389' clickHandler>Jerusalem</jLink> on Palm Sunday, when crowds welcomed him as the son of <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H1732' clickHandler>David</jLink> while spreading palm branches and cloaks on the road, fulfilling <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H2148v' clickHandler>Zechariah</jLink>'s prophecy of the coming king (Mat.21:1-11; Mrk.11:1-11; Luk.19:28-44; Jhn.12:12-19). During his final week, <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='G2424G' clickHandler>Jesus</jLink> cleansed the <jLink data-type='L' data-strong='H3389' clickHandler>Jerusalem</jLink> temple, taught daily in its courts, and engaged in intense debates with chief priests, scribes, and <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='G5330' clickHandler>Pharisees</jLink> who challenged his authority, while he responded with parables condemning their hypocrisy and predicting judgment upon the religious establishment (Mat.21-23; Mrk.11-12; Luk.19-21). His <jLink data-type='L' data-strong='H2132G' clickHandler>Olivet</jLink> Discourse delivered to his disciples on the Mount of <jLink data-type='L' data-strong='H2132G' clickHandler>Olives</jLink> provided detailed prophecies concerning the destruction of <jLink data-type='L' data-strong='H3389' clickHandler>Jerusalem</jLink>, the end times, and his second coming, preparing them for both immediate tribulation and future hope (Mat.24-25; Mrk.13; Luk.21:5-36). <jPara></jPara> During <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='G2424G' clickHandler>Jesus</jLink>’ final days he was anointed by <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='G3137J' clickHandler>Mary</jLink> at <jLink data-type='L' data-strong='G0963' clickHandler>Bethany</jLink> prefigured his burial, he shared the Last Supper established the new covenant in his blood, he was arrested in <jLink data-type='L' data-strong='G1068' clickHandler>Gethsemane</jLink> after agonized prayer, then led off to be tried by <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='G2533G' clickHandler>Caiaphas</jLink>, <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='G0452' clickHandler>Annas</jLink> and <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='G0493' clickHandler>Herod Antipas</jLink> before being crucified under <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='G4091' clickHandler>Pontius Pilate</jLink>'s authority (Mat.26-27; Mrk.14-15; Luk.22-23; Jhn.18-19). His resurrection on the third day, witnessed first by <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='G3137J' clickHandler>Mary</jLink> <jLink data-type='L' data-strong='G3093' clickHandler>Magdalene</jLink> and other women, transformed the disciples' despair into joy and confirmed his victory over death (Mat.28; Mrk.16; Luk.24; Jhn.20). Following forty days of post-resurrection appearances during which he taught about the Kingdom of God, <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='G2424G' clickHandler>Jesus</jLink> ascended to heaven from the Mount of <jLink data-type='L' data-strong='H2132G' clickHandler>Olives</jLink>, promising to return and commissioning his disciples to be his witnesses "to the end of the earth" (Act.1:1-11). The year concluded with the Day of <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H7620G' clickHandler>Pentecost</jLink>, when the Holy Spirit descended upon the gathered disciples, empowering <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='G4074G' clickHandler>Peter</jLink> to preach boldly about <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='G2424G' clickHandler>Jesus</jLink>’ resurrection and resulting in three thousand conversions, marking the birth of the Christian Church and the beginning of its rapid expansion throughout the Roman world (Act.2:1-47).
events: AD 30: <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='G2424G' clickHandler>Jesus</jLink> made his triumphal entry into <jLink data-type='L' data-strong='H3389' clickHandler>Jerusalem</jLink>.
AD 30: <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='G2424G' clickHandler>Jesus</jLink> cleansed the Temple in <jLink data-type='L' data-strong='H3389' clickHandler>Jerusalem</jLink>.
AD 30: <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='G2424G' clickHandler>Jesus</jLink> taught and debated daily in the temple courts.

AD 30: <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='G2424G' clickHandler>Jesus</jLink> delivered the <jLink data-type='L' data-strong='H2132G' clickHandler>Olivet</jLink> Discourse on the Mount of <jLink data-type='L' data-strong='H2132G' clickHandler>Olives</jLink>.

AD 30: <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='G3137J' clickHandler>Mary</jLink> anointed <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='G2424G' clickHandler>Jesus</jLink> at <jLink data-type='L' data-strong='G0963' clickHandler>Bethany</jLink>.

ChronologyEntries.article: AD 31:  The early Christian community quickly grew in <jLink data-type='L' data-strong='H3389' clickHandler>Jerusalem</jLink>, largely due to <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='G4074G' clickHandler>Peter</jLink>’s preaching, from 120 to thousands. They addressed internal organizational challenges in by appointing seven deacons to ensure fair distribution of food and resources, particularly to widows who had been overlooked in the daily ministrations. These seven men—<jLink data-type='P' data-strong='G4736' clickHandler>Stephen</jLink>, <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='G5376J' clickHandler>Philip</jLink>, <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='G4402' clickHandler>Prochorus</jLink>, <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='G3527' clickHandler>Nicanor</jLink>, <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='G5096' clickHandler>Timon</jLink>, <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='G3937' clickHandler>Parmenas</jLink>, and Nicolas—were chosen for their good reputation, wisdom, and spiritual maturity, with the apostles laying hands on them to commission their service (Act.6:1-7). <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='G4736' clickHandler>Stephen</jLink>, described as "full of faith and of the Holy Spirit," distinguished himself not only in practical service but also through performing "great wonders and signs among the people". <jPara></jPara> <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='G4736' clickHandler>Stephen</jLink>'s prominent ministry led to his arrest by members of the synagogue who could not withstand his wisdom and spiritual power when debating with him (Act.6:8-15). His lengthy defense before the Sanhedrin (Act.7:1-53) traced Israel's history from <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H0085' clickHandler>Abraham</jLink> through <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H8010' clickHandler>Solomon</jLink> while condemning the religious leaders for their persistent rejection of God's messengers. When <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='G4736' clickHandler>Stephen</jLink> declared his vision of <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='G2424G' clickHandler>Jesus</jLink> standing at the right hand of God, the enraged crowd dragged him outside <jLink data-type='L' data-strong='H3389' clickHandler>Jerusalem</jLink> and stoned him to death, making him the first Christian martyr. His final words, "Lord, do not hold this sin against them," echoed <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='G2424G' clickHandler>Jesus</jLink>’ own prayer from the cross, while a young man named <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H7586G' clickHandler>Saul</jLink> (later <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='G3972G' clickHandler>Paul</jLink>) witnessed and approved of his execution, setting the stage for future events in Christian history.
events: AD 31: The Christian community in <jLink data-type='L' data-strong='H3389' clickHandler>Jerusalem</jLink> rapidly grew from 120 to thousands due to the apostles, especially <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='G4074G' clickHandler>Peter</jLink>.

AD 31: Seven deacons—<jLink data-type='P' data-strong='G4736' clickHandler>Stephen</jLink>, <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='G5376J' clickHandler>Philip</jLink>, <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='G4402' clickHandler>Prochorus</jLink>, <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='G3527' clickHandler>Nicanor</jLink>, <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='G5096' clickHandler>Timon</jLink>, <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='G3937' clickHandler>Parmenas</jLink>, and Nicolas—were appointed to serve the community.

AD 31: <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='G4736' clickHandler>Stephen</jLink> performed wonders and signs among the people, and debated with synagogue members in <jLink data-type='L' data-strong='H3389' clickHandler>Jerusalem</jLink>.
AD 31: <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='G4736' clickHandler>Stephen</jLink> was arrested and tried before the Sanhedrin.
AD 31: <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='G4736' clickHandler>Stephen</jLink> was martyred outside <jLink data-type='L' data-strong='H3389' clickHandler>Jerusalem</jLink>.

ChronologyEntries.desc: Wider evangelism by <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='G4074G' clickHandler>Peter</jLink> & <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='G5376J' clickHandler>Philip</jLink>
ChronologyEntries.article: AD 32:  The persecution that followed <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='G4736' clickHandler>Stephen</jLink>'s martyrdom scattered the <jLink data-type='L' data-strong='H3389' clickHandler>Jerusalem</jLink> church beyond the city's boundaries, leading to unprecedented evangelistic expansion in AD 32 as described in Act.8. <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='G5376J' clickHandler>Philip</jLink>, one of the seven deacons, traveled north to <jLink data-type='L' data-strong='H8111' clickHandler>Samaria</jLink> where he proclaimed Christ and performed miraculous signs including healing the paralyzed and lame, resulting in "great joy in that city" as multitudes believed and were baptized. His ministry attracted the attention of <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='G4613G' clickHandler>Simon</jLink> the sorcerer, who had previously amazed the <jLink data-type='L' data-strong='H8111' clickHandler>Samaritans</jLink> with his magical arts but now believed and was baptized, though his subsequent attempt to purchase spiritual power revealed his incomplete understanding of the gospel. <jPara></jPara> When news of the <jLink data-type='L' data-strong='H8111' clickHandler>Samaritan</jLink> conversions reached <jLink data-type='L' data-strong='H3389' clickHandler>Jerusalem</jLink>, the apostles <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='G4074G' clickHandler>Peter</jLink> and <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='G2491G' clickHandler>John</jLink> traveled there to pray for the new believers to receive the Holy Spirit, demonstrating the unity between the original apostolic community and these first <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H1471G' clickHandler>Gentile</jLink> converts. <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='G5376J' clickHandler>Philip</jLink>'s ministry expanded further when an angel directed him southward on the desert road toward <jLink data-type='L' data-strong='H5804' clickHandler>Gaza</jLink>, where he encountered an <jLink data-type='L' data-strong='H3568A' clickHandler>Ethiopian</jLink> eunuch, a court official of Queen <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='G2582' clickHandler>Candace</jLink>, reading from the prophet <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H3470A' clickHandler>Isaiah</jLink>. <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='G5376J' clickHandler>Philip</jLink>'s explanation of <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H3470A' clickHandler>Isaiah</jLink> 53 and its fulfillment in <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='G2424G' clickHandler>Jesus</jLink> led to the eunuch's immediate baptism, symbolizing the gospel's reach to the ends of the earth as the eunuch returned to Africa as Christianity's first African convert. This year marked a crucial transition from the church's exclusively Jewish character to its emerging universal mission.
events: AD 32: Persecution scattered the <jLink data-type='L' data-strong='H3389' clickHandler>Jerusalem</jLink> church after <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='G4736' clickHandler>Stephen</jLink>’s martyrdom.
AD 32: <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='G5376J' clickHandler>Philip</jLink> preached Christ and performed miracles in <jLink data-type='L' data-strong='H8111' clickHandler>Samaria</jLink>.
AD 32: <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='G4613G' clickHandler>Simon</jLink> the Sorcerer was converted and baptized in <jLink data-type='L' data-strong='H8111' clickHandler>Samaria</jLink>.

AD 32: <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='G4074G' clickHandler>Peter</jLink> and <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='G2491G' clickHandler>John</jLink> visited <jLink data-type='L' data-strong='H8111' clickHandler>Samaria</jLink> and prayed for believers to receive the Holy Spirit.

AD 32: <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='G5376J' clickHandler>Philip</jLink> evangelized and baptized the <jLink data-type='L' data-strong='H3568A' clickHandler>Ethiopian</jLink> eunuch on the road to <jLink data-type='L' data-strong='H5804' clickHandler>Gaza</jLink>.
