ChronologyEntries.article: AD 33:  <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H7586G' clickHandler>Saul</jLink> of <jLink data-type='L' data-strong='G5019' clickHandler>Tarsus</jLink>, a zealous <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='G5330' clickHandler>Pharisee</jLink> and fierce persecutor of the early church, experienced a dramatic conversion on the road to <jLink data-type='L' data-strong='H1834' clickHandler>Damascus</jLink> that would transform both his life and the future of Christianity. <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H7586G' clickHandler>Saul</jLink> was traveling to <jLink data-type='L' data-strong='H1834' clickHandler>Damascus</jLink> with letters from the high priest authorizing him to arrest Christians when he was suddenly surrounded by a brilliant light from heaven and heard the voice of <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='G2424G' clickHandler>Jesus</jLink> asking, "<jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H7586G' clickHandler>Saul</jLink>, <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H7586G' clickHandler>Saul</jLink>, why do you persecute me?" This divine encounter left him temporarily blind and profoundly shaken, requiring his companions to lead him into <jLink data-type='L' data-strong='H1834' clickHandler>Damascus</jLink> where he remained without sight, food, or drink for three days (Act.9:1-7). <jPara></jPara> <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='G3972G' clickHandler>Paul</jLink> later described this experience as God's sovereign act of revelation, writing that God "was pleased to reveal his Son in me so that I might preach him among the <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H1471G' clickHandler>Gentiles</jLink>" (Gal.1:15-16). The significance of this conversion cannot be overstated, as it transformed Christianity's most dangerous enemy into its most effective missionary and theologian. <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='G3972G' clickHandler>Paul</jLink>'s dramatic transformation from <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H7586G' clickHandler>Saul</jLink> the persecutor to <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='G3972G' clickHandler>Paul</jLink> the apostle provided compelling evidence for the reality of Christ's resurrection and the truth of the Christian message. His subsequent ministry would carry the gospel throughout the Roman world, establish numerous churches, and contribute significantly to the New Testament through his letters.
events: AD 33: <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H7586G' clickHandler>Saul</jLink> of <jLink data-type='L' data-strong='G5019' clickHandler>Tarsus</jLink> traveled to <jLink data-type='L' data-strong='H1834' clickHandler>Damascus</jLink> to arrest Christians.
AD 33: <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H7586G' clickHandler>Saul</jLink> was dramatically converted on the road to <jLink data-type='L' data-strong='H1834' clickHandler>Damascus</jLink>.

AD 33: <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H7586G' clickHandler>Saul</jLink> was led blind into <jLink data-type='L' data-strong='H1834' clickHandler>Damascus</jLink> where <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='G0367G' clickHandler>Ananias</jLink> restored his sight and baptized him.

ChronologyEntries.desc: <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='G3972G' clickHandler>Paul</jLink> in <jLink data-type='L' data-strong='H1834' clickHandler>Damascus</jLink> and <jLink data-type='L' data-strong='H6152B' clickHandler>Arabia</jLink>
ChronologyEntries.article: AD 34:  Following his conversion, <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='G3972G' clickHandler>Paul</jLink> spent time in <jLink data-type='L' data-strong='H1834' clickHandler>Damascus</jLink> where the disciple <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='G0367G' clickHandler>Ananias</jLink>, despite initial reluctance due to <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='G3972G' clickHandler>Paul</jLink>'s reputation, obeyed a divine vision to restore <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='G3972G' clickHandler>Paul</jLink>'s sight and baptize him (Act.9:8-25). <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='G3972G' clickHandler>Paul</jLink> immediately began preaching in the <jLink data-type='L' data-strong='H1834' clickHandler>Damascus</jLink> synagogues, proclaiming <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='G2424G' clickHandler>Jesus</jLink> as the Son of God and astonishing those who knew of his previous persecution of Christians. His bold testimony and theological arguments proved so effective that he "increased all the more in strength, and confounded the <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='G2454' clickHandler>Jews</jLink> who dwelt in <jLink data-type='L' data-strong='H1834' clickHandler>Damascus</jLink>, proving that this <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='G2424G' clickHandler>Jesus</jLink> is the Christ," but this success also generated intense opposition from the local Jewish community. <jPara></jPara> <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='G3972G' clickHandler>Paul</jLink> did not immediately consult with the apostles in <jLink data-type='L' data-strong='H3389' clickHandler>Jerusalem</jLink> but instead "went into <jLink data-type='L' data-strong='H6152B' clickHandler>Arabia</jLink>, and returned again to <jLink data-type='L' data-strong='H1834' clickHandler>Damascus</jLink>," suggesting a period of withdrawal and spiritual preparation in the <jLink data-type='L' data-strong='H6152B' clickHandler>Arabian</jLink> desert (Gal.1:16-17). This sojourn in <jLink data-type='L' data-strong='H6152B' clickHandler>Arabia</jLink>, possibly lasting several months or even years, provided <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='G3972G' clickHandler>Paul</jLink> with time to process his revolutionary encounter with Christ and develop his theological understanding without human instruction. Upon returning to <jLink data-type='L' data-strong='H1834' clickHandler>Damascus</jLink>, his continued preaching intensified Jewish hostility to the point where they plotted to kill him, monitoring the city gates day and night. <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='G3972G' clickHandler>Paul</jLink>'s dramatic escape (Act.9:25; 2Co.11:32-33) involved his disciples lowering him in a basket through an opening in the city wall at night, as the governor under King <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='G0702' clickHandler>Aretas</jLink> was also seeking to arrest him.
events: AD 34: <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='G3972G' clickHandler>Paul</jLink> preached <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='G2424G' clickHandler>Jesus</jLink> as the Son of God in <jLink data-type='L' data-strong='H1834' clickHandler>Damascus</jLink> synagogues.

AD 34: <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='G3972G' clickHandler>Paul</jLink> withdrew to <jLink data-type='L' data-strong='H6152B' clickHandler>Arabia</jLink> and later returned to <jLink data-type='L' data-strong='H1834' clickHandler>Damascus</jLink>.

AD 34: The governor under King <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='G0702' clickHandler>Aretas</jLink> plotted to arrest <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='G3972G' clickHandler>Paul</jLink> in <jLink data-type='L' data-strong='H1834' clickHandler>Damascus</jLink>.
AD 34: <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='G3972G' clickHandler>Paul</jLink> dramatically escaped from <jLink data-type='L' data-strong='H1834' clickHandler>Damascus</jLink>.

ChronologyEntries.article: AD 36:  Marcellus assumed the position of Roman Procurator of Judea in AD 36, succeeding <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='G4091' clickHandler>Pontius Pilate</jLink> who had been recalled to <jLink data-type='L' data-strong='G4514' clickHandler>Rome</jLink> following increasing tensions with the local population. This transition occurred during Emperor <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='G5086' clickHandler>Tiberius</jLink>'s reign and represented <jLink data-type='L' data-strong='G4514' clickHandler>Rome</jLink>'s ongoing efforts to maintain stable governance in the strategically important province of Judea. The procuratorship system had been established in AD 6 when the incompetent ethnarch <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='G0745' clickHandler>Herod Archelaus</jLink> was deposed, converting Judea from a client kingdom into a directly administered Roman province under the oversight of the <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H0758I' clickHandler>Syrian</jLink> legate. <jPara></jPara> Marcellus's administration appears to have been relatively brief and uneventful compared to his predecessor's controversial tenure. The Roman administrative framework under procurators like Marcellus provided the legal and political context within which early Christian communities operated, navigated religious freedoms, and occasionally faced official opposition.
events: AD 36: <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='G4091' clickHandler>Pontius Pilate</jLink> was recalled to <jLink data-type='L' data-strong='G4514' clickHandler>Rome</jLink>.
AD 36: Marcellus became Roman Procurator of Judea.

ChronologyEntries.desc: <jChronDurationLink style='color:red'>▼</jChronDurationLink>Caligula; <jChronDurationLink style='color:black'>▼</jChronDurationLink><jLink data-type='P' data-strong='G0067' clickHandler>Agrippa</jLink> I; <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='G3972G' clickHandler>Paul</jLink> to <jLink data-type='L' data-strong='H3389' clickHandler>Jerusalem</jLink>
ChronologyEntries.article: AD 37:  <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='G3972G' clickHandler>Paul</jLink> made his first return to <jLink data-type='L' data-strong='H3389' clickHandler>Jerusalem</jLink> in AD 37, approximately three years after his conversion, seeking to join the Christian community there but initially meeting with suspicion and fear due to his notorious reputation as a former persecutor. The disciples were reluctant to accept him until <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='G0921G' clickHandler>Barnabas</jLink> courageously intervened, vouching for <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='G3972G' clickHandler>Paul</jLink>'s genuine conversion and describing his bold preaching in <jLink data-type='L' data-strong='H1834' clickHandler>Damascus</jLink> (Act.9:26-29). <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='G0921G' clickHandler>Barnabas</jLink>'s advocacy proved crucial in facilitating <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='G3972G' clickHandler>Paul</jLink>'s acceptance by the apostolic community and his integration into the broader Christian movement. <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='G3972G' clickHandler>Paul</jLink> stayed specifically with <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='G4074G' clickHandler>Peter</jLink> (Cephas) for fifteen days and met <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='G2385I' clickHandler>James</jLink>, the Lord's brother, but saw no other apostles during this brief visit (Gal.1:18-20). During his time in <jLink data-type='L' data-strong='H3389' clickHandler>Jerusalem</jLink>, <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='G3972G' clickHandler>Paul</jLink> engaged in theological debates with <jLink data-type='L' data-strong='H3120H' clickHandler>Hellenistic</jLink> <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='G2454' clickHandler>Jews</jLink>, demonstrating the same boldness that had characterized his ministry in <jLink data-type='L' data-strong='H1834' clickHandler>Damascus</jLink>, but this also provoked plots against his life that eventually forced his departure from the city. <jPara></jPara>  The political landscape of the region was shifting as <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='G0067' clickHandler>Herod Agrippa</jLink> I's territorial influence continued to expand, building upon the favor he had gained with Emperor <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='G5086' clickHandler>Tiberius</jLink> and later with Caligula who became emperor in AD 37. <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='G0067' clickHandler>Agrippa</jLink>'s growing power would eventually encompass most of the territory once ruled by his grandfather <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='G0067' clickHandler>Herod</jLink> the Great, creating new dynamics in Jewish-Roman relations that would significantly impact both traditional Jewish communities and the emerging Christian church in subsequent years.
events: AD 37: <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='G3972G' clickHandler>Paul</jLink> visited <jLink data-type='L' data-strong='H3389' clickHandler>Jerusalem</jLink> about three years after his conversion.
AD 37: <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='G0921G' clickHandler>Barnabas</jLink> vouched for <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='G3972G' clickHandler>Paul</jLink> to the apostles.

AD 37: <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='G3972G' clickHandler>Paul</jLink> stayed with <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='G4074G' clickHandler>Peter</jLink> and met <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='G2385I' clickHandler>James</jLink>, the Lord’s brother.

AD 37: <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='G3972G' clickHandler>Paul</jLink> debated <jLink data-type='L' data-strong='H3120H' clickHandler>Hellenistic</jLink> <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='G2454' clickHandler>Jews</jLink> in <jLink data-type='L' data-strong='H3389' clickHandler>Jerusalem</jLink>.
AD 37: Plots against <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='G3972G' clickHandler>Paul</jLink> forced his departure from <jLink data-type='L' data-strong='H3389' clickHandler>Jerusalem</jLink>.

ChronologyEntries.desc: <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='G4074G' clickHandler>Peter</jLink> ministers to <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='G2883' clickHandler>Cornelius</jLink> & <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H1471G' clickHandler>Gentiles</jLink>
ChronologyEntries.article: AD 39:  <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='G4074G' clickHandler>Peter</jLink>'s ministry to the Roman centurion <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='G2883' clickHandler>Cornelius</jLink> in AD 39 represents one of the most theologically significant events in early church history, marking the definitive inclusion of <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H1471G' clickHandler>Gentiles</jLink> in the Christian community without prior conversion to <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='G2454' clickHandler>Judaism</jLink>. This breakthrough occurred through coordinated divine visions: <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='G2883' clickHandler>Cornelius</jLink>, a devout God-fearer stationed in <jLink data-type='L' data-strong='G2542H' clickHandler>Caesarea</jLink>, received an angelic message instructing him to summon <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='G4074G' clickHandler>Peter</jLink>, while <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='G4074G' clickHandler>Peter</jLink> simultaneously experienced a threefold vision of various animals being declared clean by God's voice, challenging traditional Jewish dietary laws and ethnic boundaries (Act.10:1-11:18). <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='G4074G' clickHandler>Peter</jLink>'s interpretation of this vision—"God has shown me that I should not call any man common or unclean"—prepared him to accompany <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='G2883' clickHandler>Cornelius</jLink>'s messengers to <jLink data-type='L' data-strong='G2542H' clickHandler>Caesarea</jLink> despite Jewish prohibitions against entering <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H1471G' clickHandler>Gentile</jLink> homes. <jPara></jPara> When <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='G4074G' clickHandler>Peter</jLink> preached to <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='G2883' clickHandler>Cornelius</jLink>'s assembled household about <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='G2424G' clickHandler>Jesus</jLink> Christ as "Lord of all" and his death and resurrection, the Holy Spirit fell upon all the hearers, demonstrating through miraculous signs that God had granted <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H1471G' clickHandler>Gentiles</jLink> the same spiritual gifts received by Jewish believers at <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H7620G' clickHandler>Pentecost</jLink>. This unexpected divine intervention convinced <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='G4074G' clickHandler>Peter</jLink> and his Jewish companions that <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H1471G' clickHandler>Gentiles</jLink> could receive salvation directly through faith in Christ, leading to immediate baptisms and establishing a crucial precedent for the church's universal mission. Upon returning to <jLink data-type='L' data-strong='H3389' clickHandler>Jerusalem</jLink>, <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='G4074G' clickHandler>Peter</jLink> faced criticism from circumcision party believers but successfully defended his actions by recounting the divine visions and the undeniable evidence of the Holy Spirit's work among the <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H1471G' clickHandler>Gentiles</jLink>. This event fundamentally transformed the early church's understanding of the gospel's scope and prepared the way for <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='G3972G' clickHandler>Paul</jLink>'s later <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H1471G' clickHandler>Gentile</jLink> missions throughout the Roman world.
events: AD 39: <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='G2883' clickHandler>Cornelius</jLink> received a vision in <jLink data-type='L' data-strong='G2542H' clickHandler>Caesarea</jLink>.
AD 39: <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='G4074G' clickHandler>Peter</jLink> experienced a vision in <jLink data-type='L' data-strong='H3305' clickHandler>Joppa</jLink> declaring all animals clean.

AD 39: Messengers from <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='G2883' clickHandler>Cornelius</jLink> arrived in <jLink data-type='L' data-strong='H3305' clickHandler>Joppa</jLink> for <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='G4074G' clickHandler>Peter</jLink>.

AD 39: <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='G4074G' clickHandler>Peter</jLink> visited <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='G2883' clickHandler>Cornelius</jLink>’s household in <jLink data-type='L' data-strong='G2542H' clickHandler>Caesarea</jLink> and preached.
AD 39: The Holy Spirit fell on <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H1471G' clickHandler>Gentiles</jLink> in <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='G2883' clickHandler>Cornelius</jLink>’s house.

ChronologyEntries.desc: <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='G0493' clickHandler>Antipas</jLink> dies. <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='G0067' clickHandler>Agrippa</jLink> I  gains <jLink data-type='L' data-strong='H1551' clickHandler>Galilee</jLink>
ChronologyEntries.article: AD 40:  The expansion of Christian preaching to <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H1471G' clickHandler>Gentile</jLink> populations began in earnest, representing a pivotal shift from the church's predominantly Jewish character toward its universal mission. Believers who had been scattered by the persecution following <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='G4736' clickHandler>Stephen</jLink>'s martyrdom began proclaiming the gospel not only to <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='G2454' clickHandler>Jews</jLink> but also to Greeks in cities like <jLink data-type='L' data-strong='G0490G' clickHandler>Antioch</jLink>, <jLink data-type='L' data-strong='H3794H' clickHandler>Cyprus</jLink>, and <jLink data-type='L' data-strong='G2956' clickHandler>Cyrene</jLink> (Act.11:19-24). When news of this <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H1471G' clickHandler>Gentile</jLink> conversion reached the church in <jLink data-type='L' data-strong='H3389' clickHandler>Jerusalem</jLink>, they sent <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='G0921G' clickHandler>Barnabas</jLink> to investigate. Upon witnessing God's grace at work, <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='G0921G' clickHandler>Barnabas</jLink> encouraged the new believers to remain faithful to the Lord, and his ministry resulted in even more people being added to the faith.  <jPara></jPara>   The exile of <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='G0493' clickHandler>Herod Antipas</jLink> in AD 40 marked the end of his forty-three-year rule as tetrarch of <jLink data-type='L' data-strong='H1551' clickHandler>Galilee</jLink> and Perea. He had executed <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='G2491G' clickHandler>John</jLink> the Baptist at the request of <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='G2266G' clickHandler>Herodias</jLink> and had briefly encountered <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='G2424G' clickHandler>Jesus</jLink> during his trial before crucifixion. His territories were incorporated into the expanding realm of his nephew <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='G0493' clickHandler>Herod</jLink> <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='G0067' clickHandler>Agrippa</jLink> I, who had convinced Caligula that <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='G0493' clickHandler>Antipas</jLink> was plotting against the emperor. <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='G0067' clickHandler>Agrippa</jLink>'s enlarged kingdom now encompassed most of the territories broken up at the death of his grandfather <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='G0493' clickHandler>Herod</jLink> the Great in 4 BC.
events: AD 40: Christian preaching expanded to <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H1471G' clickHandler>Gentiles</jLink> in <jLink data-type='L' data-strong='G0490G' clickHandler>Antioch</jLink>, <jLink data-type='L' data-strong='H3794H' clickHandler>Cyprus</jLink>, and <jLink data-type='L' data-strong='G2956' clickHandler>Cyrene</jLink>.
AD 40: Many <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H1471G' clickHandler>Gentiles</jLink> were converted in <jLink data-type='L' data-strong='G0490G' clickHandler>Antioch</jLink>.

AD 40: <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='G0921G' clickHandler>Barnabas</jLink> was sent from <jLink data-type='L' data-strong='H3389' clickHandler>Jerusalem</jLink> to <jLink data-type='L' data-strong='G0490G' clickHandler>Antioch</jLink>.

AD 40: <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='G0921G' clickHandler>Barnabas</jLink> encouraged the <jLink data-type='L' data-strong='G0490G' clickHandler>Antioch</jLink> believers and many more joined the faith.
AD 40: <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='G0493' clickHandler>Herod Antipas</jLink> was exiled by order of Caligula.

ChronologyEntries.article: AD 41:  In AD 41, the Roman Empire experienced a dramatic crisis that threatened to ignite a major revolt in Judea. Emperor Caligula (Gaius) issued a decree ordering that his statue, fashioned in the likeness of <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='G2203' clickHandler>Jupiter</jLink>, be erected in the <jLink data-type='L' data-strong='H3389' clickHandler>Jerusalem</jLink> Temple—an act considered the ultimate sacrilege by the Jewish population. The emperor's motivation stemmed from his megalomaniacal desire to be worshipped as a god throughout the empire, and he was particularly angered by Jewish refusal to offer him divine honors. Petronius, the Roman governor of <jLink data-type='L' data-strong='H0758I' clickHandler>Syria</jLink>, was commanded to enforce this decree with military force. However, when Petronius advanced toward Judea, he encountered unprecedented Jewish resistance. According to Josephus's detailed accounts in Antiquities of the <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='G2454' clickHandler>Jews</jLink> (Book 18, Chapters 8-9) and The Jewish War (Book 2, Chapter 10), tens of thousands of <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='G2454' clickHandler>Jews</jLink> gathered to plead with Petronius, declaring their willingness to die rather than permit the desecration of their sacred Temple.  <jPara></jPara>  The crisis was averted when Caligula was assassinated by members of his own Praetorian Guard in January AD 41, before the statue could be installed. His uncle <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='G2804G' clickHandler>Claudius</jLink> was immediately proclaimed emperor by the Guard, bringing swift resolution to the Jewish crisis. <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='G2804G' clickHandler>Claudius</jLink>, demonstrating markedly different policies toward provincial peoples, immediately sent official letters throughout the empire confirming Jewish religious rights and explicitly forbidding the erection of any statues in their Temple. This decisive action by <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='G2804G' clickHandler>Claudius</jLink> restored peace to Judea and reaffirmed traditional Jewish privileges, averting what Josephus suggests could have been a catastrophic revolt. The events of AD 41 thus represent a pivotal moment when divine providence, through the timely death of Caligula, preserved both the Temple's sanctity and regional stability under the more tolerant rule of <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='G2804G' clickHandler>Claudius</jLink>.
events: AD 41: Caligula orders his statue, styled as <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='G2203' clickHandler>Jupiter</jLink>, to be erected in the <jLink data-type='L' data-strong='H3389' clickHandler>Jerusalem</jLink> Temple.
AD 41: Petronius, Roman governor of <jLink data-type='L' data-strong='H0758I' clickHandler>Syria</jLink>, advances toward Judea with military force to enforce Caligula’s decree.
AD 41: Mass Jewish resistance gathers to oppose the statue in the Temple.
AD 41: Caligula is assassinated by his Praetorian Guard in January AD 41.
AD 41: <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='G2804G' clickHandler>Claudius</jLink>, Caligula’s uncle, becomes emperor after Caligula’s death.

ChronologyEntries.desc: <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='G3972G' clickHandler>Paul</jLink> to <jLink data-type='L' data-strong='G0490G' clickHandler>Antioch</jLink>
ChronologyEntries.article: AD 42:  <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='G3972G' clickHandler>Paul</jLink>’s arrived in <jLink data-type='L' data-strong='G0490G' clickHandler>Antioch</jLink> started to establish it as one of the most important centers for early Christian mission and theological development (Act.11:25-26). <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='G0921G' clickHandler>Barnabas</jLink> had sought out <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='G3972G' clickHandler>Paul</jLink> in <jLink data-type='L' data-strong='G5019' clickHandler>Tarsus</jLink> and brought him to <jLink data-type='L' data-strong='G0490G' clickHandler>Antioch</jLink> to assist in teaching the rapidly growing Christian community there, which had emerged from the earlier evangelistic efforts to both <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='G2454' clickHandler>Jews</jLink> and <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H1471G' clickHandler>Gentiles</jLink>. For an entire year, <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='G3972G' clickHandler>Paul</jLink> and <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='G0921G' clickHandler>Barnabas</jLink> worked together in <jLink data-type='L' data-strong='G0490G' clickHandler>Antioch</jLink>, instructing large numbers of people and helping to establish doctrinal foundations for this predominantly <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H1471G' clickHandler>Gentile</jLink> church. It was in <jLink data-type='L' data-strong='G0490G' clickHandler>Antioch</jLink> that the followers of <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='G2424G' clickHandler>Jesus</jLink> were first called "Christians," a designation that distinguished them as a separate religious movement rather than merely a sect within <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='G2454' clickHandler>Judaism</jLink>. <jPara></jPara> The significance of <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='G3972G' clickHandler>Paul</jLink>'s ministry in <jLink data-type='L' data-strong='G0490G' clickHandler>Antioch</jLink> cannot be overstated, as this city became the launching point for his subsequent missionary journeys that would spread Christianity throughout the Roman world. The church's openness to <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H1471G' clickHandler>Gentile</jLink> believers and its emergence as a center for cross-cultural ministry provided <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='G3972G' clickHandler>Paul</jLink> with the practical experience and theological insights that would shape his understanding of the gospel's universal appeal. <jLink data-type='L' data-strong='G0490G' clickHandler>Antioch</jLink>'s role as a cosmopolitan commercial center with diverse populations made it an ideal location for developing and establishing patterns of missionary work that would characterize <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='G3972G' clickHandler>Paul</jLink>'s future evangelistic campaigns across <jLink data-type='L' data-strong='G0773' clickHandler>Asia</jLink> Minor, <jLink data-type='L' data-strong='H3120H' clickHandler>Greece</jLink>, and beyond.
events: AD 42: <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='G0921G' clickHandler>Barnabas</jLink> brings <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='G3972G' clickHandler>Paul</jLink> from <jLink data-type='L' data-strong='G5019' clickHandler>Tarsus</jLink> to help lead the church in <jLink data-type='L' data-strong='G0490G' clickHandler>Antioch</jLink>.

AD 42: <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='G3972G' clickHandler>Paul</jLink> and <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='G0921G' clickHandler>Barnabas</jLink> teach in <jLink data-type='L' data-strong='G0490G' clickHandler>Antioch</jLink> for a year.
AD 42: Disciples are first called "Christians" in <jLink data-type='L' data-strong='G0490G' clickHandler>Antioch</jLink>.

ChronologyEntries.desc: <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='G0013' clickHandler>Agabus</jLink>'s prediction of famine
ChronologyEntries.article: AD 43:  The prophet <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='G0013' clickHandler>Agabus</jLink> delivered a significant prophecy in AD 43, predicting through the Holy Spirit that a severe famine would occur throughout the entire Roman world (Act.11:27-28). <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='G0013' clickHandler>Agabus</jLink>, whose name appears to be of Hebrew origin possibly meaning "locust," was among a group of prophets who had traveled from <jLink data-type='L' data-strong='H3389' clickHandler>Jerusalem</jLink> to <jLink data-type='L' data-strong='G0490G' clickHandler>Antioch</jLink>, demonstrating the ongoing connection between the mother church and the growing <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H1471G' clickHandler>Gentile</jLink> Christian communities. His prophecy proved remarkably accurate, as historical sources confirm that significant famines did indeed affect various parts of the Roman Empire during the reign of Emperor <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='G2804G' clickHandler>Claudius</jLink> (AD 41-54), with particularly severe conditions reported in Judea around AD 46-48. <jPara></jPara> The practical response to <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='G0013' clickHandler>Agabus</jLink>'s prophecy revealed the early church's commitment to mutual aid and Christian solidarity across ethnic and geographic boundaries. Upon hearing this prediction, the disciples in <jLink data-type='L' data-strong='G0490G' clickHandler>Antioch</jLink> immediately began collecting relief funds to send to their fellow believers in Judea, with each contributing according to their ability. This organized relief effort represented one of the first recorded examples of systematic Christian charity between different church communities and demonstrated the universal nature of Christian fellowship that transcended traditional Jewish-Gentile divisions. The prophecy and subsequent response established important precedents for Christian disaster relief and highlighted the prophetic ministry's role in guiding practical church decisions during the apostolic period.
events: AD 43: Prophet <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='G0013' clickHandler>Agabus</jLink> predicts a great famine.
AD 43: Prophets from <jLink data-type='L' data-strong='H3389' clickHandler>Jerusalem</jLink> visit <jLink data-type='L' data-strong='G0490G' clickHandler>Antioch</jLink>.

ChronologyEntries.desc: <jChronDurationLink style='color:red'>▼</jChronDurationLink>Fadus; <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='G3972G' clickHandler>Paul</jLink> to <jLink data-type='L' data-strong='H3389' clickHandler>Jerusalem</jLink>. <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='G4074G' clickHandler>Peter</jLink> in prison
ChronologyEntries.article: AD 44:  The year AD 44 witnessed intense persecution of Christian leadership under <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='G0067' clickHandler>Herod Agrippa</jLink> I, culminating in the execution of <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='G2385G' clickHandler>James</jLink>, the brother of <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='G2491G' clickHandler>John</jLink> and son of <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='G2199G' clickHandler>Zebedee</jLink>, making him the first apostle to suffer martyrdom. <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='G0067' clickHandler>Agrippa</jLink> initiated this persecution to please certain Jewish leaders who opposed the growing Christian movement, ordering <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='G2385G' clickHandler>James</jLink> to be killed by the sword in a manner that demonstrated his determination to suppress Christian influence (Act.12:1-2). The execution proved so popular with hostile Jewish factions that <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='G0067' clickHandler>Agrippa</jLink> proceeded to arrest <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='G4074G' clickHandler>Peter</jLink> during the <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H6453' clickHandler>Passover</jLink> season, intending to bring him to public trial after the festival. However, <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='G4074G' clickHandler>Peter</jLink>'s miraculous escape from prison through angelic intervention (Act.12:3-17) thwarted <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='G0067' clickHandler>Agrippa</jLink>'s plans and provided compelling evidence of divine protection for the apostolic leadership. <jPara></jPara> The sudden death of <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='G0067' clickHandler>Herod Agrippa</jLink> I (Act.12:20-23) was regarded as divine judgment for accepting worship that belonged only to God. During a public assembly in <jLink data-type='L' data-strong='G2542H' clickHandler>Caesarea</jLink>, when the crowd acclaimed <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='G0067' clickHandler>Agrippa</jLink>'s speech as "the voice of a god, and not of man," an angel of the Lord immediately struck him down for not giving glory to God, and he was consumed by worms and died. This unexpected demise of Christianity's most powerful persecutor was interpreted by the early church as divine vindication and led to renewed growth and expansion of the Christian movement. <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='G3972G' clickHandler>Paul</jLink> had also traveled to <jLink data-type='L' data-strong='H3389' clickHandler>Jerusalem</jLink> during this tumultuous year, likely as part of the famine relief mission organized by the <jLink data-type='L' data-strong='G0490G' clickHandler>Antioch</jLink> church (Act.11.29-30), bringing aid from <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H1471G' clickHandler>Gentile</jLink> Christians to their Jewish brothers and demonstrating the practical unity that had developed between previously separated communities.
events: AD 44: <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='G2385G' clickHandler>James</jLink>, son of <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='G2199G' clickHandler>Zebedee</jLink>, is executed in <jLink data-type='L' data-strong='H3389' clickHandler>Jerusalem</jLink> by <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='G0067' clickHandler>Herod Agrippa</jLink> I.
AD 44: <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='G4074G' clickHandler>Peter</jLink> is arrested and imprisoned by <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='G0067' clickHandler>Herod Agrippa</jLink> I.
AD 44: <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='G4074G' clickHandler>Peter</jLink> miraculously escapes from prison.

AD 44: <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='G3972G' clickHandler>Paul</jLink> and <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='G0921G' clickHandler>Barnabas</jLink> deliver famine relief to <jLink data-type='L' data-strong='H3389' clickHandler>Jerusalem</jLink>.
AD 44: <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='G0067' clickHandler>Herod Agrippa</jLink> I dies in <jLink data-type='L' data-strong='G2542H' clickHandler>Caesarea</jLink>.

ChronologyEntries.desc: <jChronDurationLink style='color:red'>▼</jChronDurationLink>Alexander; <jChronDurationLink style='color:green'>▼</jChronDurationLink>Mission 1: <jLink data-type='L' data-strong='G0490G' clickHandler>Antioch</jLink> to <jLink data-type='L' data-strong='G3828' clickHandler>Pamphylia</jLink>
ChronologyEntries.article: AD 46:  <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='G3972G' clickHandler>Paul</jLink>'s first systematic missionary journey commenced when the Holy Spirit, speaking through prophets and teachers in the church at <jLink data-type='L' data-strong='G0490G' clickHandler>Antioch</jLink>, called for <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='G0921G' clickHandler>Barnabas</jLink> and <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H7586G' clickHandler>Saul</jLink> to be set apart for missionary work (Act.13:1-3). After prayer and fasting, the <jLink data-type='L' data-strong='G0490G' clickHandler>Antioch</jLink> church laid hands on them and sent them forth, marking the beginning of organized Christian evangelism beyond the immediate Palestinian region. Their journey first took them to <jLink data-type='L' data-strong='G4581' clickHandler>Seleucia</jLink>, then by ship to the island of <jLink data-type='L' data-strong='H3794H' clickHandler>Cyprus</jLink>, where they proclaimed the word of God in the synagogues of <jLink data-type='L' data-strong='G4529' clickHandler>Salamis</jLink> and traversed the entire island westward to <jLink data-type='L' data-strong='G3974' clickHandler>Paphos</jLink>. <jPara></jPara> At <jLink data-type='L' data-strong='G3974' clickHandler>Paphos</jLink>, <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='G3972G' clickHandler>Paul</jLink> (who began using his Roman name rather than his Hebrew name <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H7586G' clickHandler>Saul</jLink>) confronted the sorcerer <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='G0919' clickHandler>Bar-Jesus</jLink>, also called <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='G0919' clickHandler>Elymas</jLink>, who attempted to prevent the Roman proconsul <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='G4588' clickHandler>Sergius</jLink> Paulus from hearing the gospel (Act.13:6-12). When <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='G3972G' clickHandler>Paul</jLink>, filled with the Holy Spirit, struck <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='G0919' clickHandler>Elymas</jLink> with temporary blindness, the proconsul believed, being astonished at the teaching about the Lord. From <jLink data-type='L' data-strong='H3794H' clickHandler>Cyprus</jLink>, <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='G3972G' clickHandler>Paul</jLink> and his companions sailed north to <jLink data-type='L' data-strong='G4011' clickHandler>Perga</jLink> in <jLink data-type='L' data-strong='G3828' clickHandler>Pamphylia</jLink>, where <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='G2491G' clickHandler>John</jLink> <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='G3138' clickHandler>Mark</jLink> departed from them and returned to <jLink data-type='L' data-strong='H3389' clickHandler>Jerusalem</jLink> (Act.13:13), an action that would later cause disagreement between <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='G3972G' clickHandler>Paul</jLink> and <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='G0921G' clickHandler>Barnabas</jLink>. This first phase of <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='G3972G' clickHandler>Paul</jLink>'s missionary work established the pattern of preaching first in synagogues to <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='G2454' clickHandler>Jews</jLink> and God-fearers, then extending the message to <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H1471G' clickHandler>Gentiles</jLink> when Jewish opposition arose.
events: AD 46: <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='G0921G' clickHandler>Barnabas</jLink> and <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H7586G' clickHandler>Saul</jLink> are set apart for missionary work in <jLink data-type='L' data-strong='G0490G' clickHandler>Antioch</jLink>.

AD 46: <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='G3972G' clickHandler>Paul</jLink> and <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='G0921G' clickHandler>Barnabas</jLink> travel from <jLink data-type='L' data-strong='G0490G' clickHandler>Antioch</jLink> to <jLink data-type='L' data-strong='G4581' clickHandler>Seleucia</jLink> and <jLink data-type='L' data-strong='H3794H' clickHandler>Cyprus</jLink>.

AD 46: <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='G3972G' clickHandler>Paul</jLink> and <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='G0921G' clickHandler>Barnabas</jLink> cross <jLink data-type='L' data-strong='H3794H' clickHandler>Cyprus</jLink> to <jLink data-type='L' data-strong='G3974' clickHandler>Paphos</jLink> preaching the gospel.

AD 46: <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='G3972G' clickHandler>Paul</jLink> strikes <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='G0919' clickHandler>Bar-Jesus</jLink> (<jLink data-type='P' data-strong='G0919' clickHandler>Elymas</jLink>) blind and <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='G4588' clickHandler>Sergius</jLink> Paulus believes in <jLink data-type='L' data-strong='G3974' clickHandler>Paphos</jLink>.

AD 46: <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='G3972G' clickHandler>Paul</jLink> and companions sail from <jLink data-type='L' data-strong='G3974' clickHandler>Paphos</jLink> to <jLink data-type='L' data-strong='G4011' clickHandler>Perga</jLink> in <jLink data-type='L' data-strong='G3828' clickHandler>Pamphylia</jLink>.

ChronologyEntries.desc: - to <jLink data-type='L' data-strong='G0490H' clickHandler>Antioch</jLink>, <jLink data-type='L' data-strong='G2430' clickHandler>Iconium</jLink>, <jLink data-type='L' data-strong='G3082' clickHandler>Lystra</jLink>, <jLink data-type='L' data-strong='G1190' clickHandler>Derbe</jLink>
ChronologyEntries.article: AD 47:  <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='G3972G' clickHandler>Paul</jLink> and <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='G0921G' clickHandler>Barnabas</jLink> continued their missionary journey from <jLink data-type='L' data-strong='G3828' clickHandler>Pamphylia</jLink> to <jLink data-type='L' data-strong='G4099' clickHandler>Pisidian</jLink> <jLink data-type='L' data-strong='G0490H' clickHandler>Antioch</jLink>, where <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='G3972G' clickHandler>Paul</jLink> delivered his first recorded sermon, tracing God's dealings with Israel from the Exodus to the coming of <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='G2424G' clickHandler>Jesus</jLink> as the promised Savior (Act.13:14-41). When the <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='G2454' clickHandler>Jews</jLink> rejected their message, <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='G3972G' clickHandler>Paul</jLink> and <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='G0921G' clickHandler>Barnabas</jLink> declared their intention to turn to the <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H1471G' clickHandler>Gentiles</jLink>, quoting "I have set you to be a light for the <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H1471G' clickHandler>Gentiles</jLink>, that you may bring salvation to the ends of the earth" (Isa.49:6). Their success among the <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H1471G' clickHandler>Gentiles</jLink> provoked Jewish persecution, forcing them to leave for <jLink data-type='L' data-strong='G2430' clickHandler>Iconium</jLink>, where they spoke boldly in the synagogue and performed signs and wonders, dividing the city between those who supported them and those who opposed them (Act.14:1-7). <jPara></jPara> From <jLink data-type='L' data-strong='G2430' clickHandler>Iconium</jLink>, they fled to <jLink data-type='L' data-strong='G3082' clickHandler>Lystra</jLink> in <jLink data-type='L' data-strong='G3071' clickHandler>Lycaonia</jLink>, where <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='G3972G' clickHandler>Paul</jLink> healed a man lame from birth, prompting the crowds to acclaim <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='G0921G' clickHandler>Barnabas</jLink> as Zeus and <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='G3972G' clickHandler>Paul</jLink> as <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='G2060H' clickHandler>Hermes</jLink>, attempting to offer sacrifices to them (Act.14:8-18). However, <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='G2454' clickHandler>Jews</jLink> from <jLink data-type='L' data-strong='G0490H' clickHandler>Antioch</jLink> and <jLink data-type='L' data-strong='G2430' clickHandler>Iconium</jLink> arrived and turned the crowd against them, stoning <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='G3972G' clickHandler>Paul</jLink> and dragging him outside the city, believing him to be dead. After <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='G3972G' clickHandler>Paul</jLink> miraculously recovered, they traveled to <jLink data-type='L' data-strong='G1190' clickHandler>Derbe</jLink>, where they made many disciples before retracing their steps through <jLink data-type='L' data-strong='G3082' clickHandler>Lystra</jLink>, <jLink data-type='L' data-strong='G2430' clickHandler>Iconium</jLink>, and <jLink data-type='L' data-strong='G4099' clickHandler>Pisidian</jLink> <jLink data-type='L' data-strong='G0490H' clickHandler>Antioch</jLink> to strengthen the souls of the disciples, encouraging them to continue in the faith despite tribulations (Act.14:19-22). They appointed elders in every church through prayer and fasting before returning through <jLink data-type='L' data-strong='G3828' clickHandler>Pamphylia</jLink> to <jLink data-type='L' data-strong='G0825' clickHandler>Attalia</jLink> and sailing back to <jLink data-type='L' data-strong='G0490H' clickHandler>Antioch</jLink>, where they reported how God had "opened a door of faith to the <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H1471G' clickHandler>Gentiles</jLink>" (Act.14:23-28). <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='G3972G' clickHandler>Paul</jLink> later recalled the sufferings endured during this journey when writing to <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='G5095G' clickHandler>Timothy</jLink> about persecutions at "<jLink data-type='L' data-strong='G0490H' clickHandler>Antioch</jLink>, at <jLink data-type='L' data-strong='G2430' clickHandler>Iconium</jLink>, and at <jLink data-type='L' data-strong='G3082' clickHandler>Lystra</jLink>" (2Ti.3:11).
events: AD 47: <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='G3972G' clickHandler>Paul</jLink> and <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='G0921G' clickHandler>Barnabas</jLink> travel from <jLink data-type='L' data-strong='G4011' clickHandler>Perga</jLink> to <jLink data-type='L' data-strong='G4099' clickHandler>Pisidian</jLink> <jLink data-type='L' data-strong='G0490H' clickHandler>Antioch</jLink> and <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='G3972G' clickHandler>Paul</jLink> preaches in the synagogue.

AD 47: After Jewish opposition, <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='G3972G' clickHandler>Paul</jLink> and <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='G0921G' clickHandler>Barnabas</jLink> turn to the <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H1471G' clickHandler>Gentiles</jLink> in <jLink data-type='L' data-strong='G4099' clickHandler>Pisidian</jLink> <jLink data-type='L' data-strong='G0490H' clickHandler>Antioch</jLink>.

AD 47: <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='G3972G' clickHandler>Paul</jLink> and <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='G0921G' clickHandler>Barnabas</jLink> are expelled from <jLink data-type='L' data-strong='G4099' clickHandler>Pisidian</jLink> <jLink data-type='L' data-strong='G0490H' clickHandler>Antioch</jLink>.

AD 47: <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='G3972G' clickHandler>Paul</jLink> and <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='G0921G' clickHandler>Barnabas</jLink> preach and perform signs in <jLink data-type='L' data-strong='G2430' clickHandler>Iconium</jLink>.

AD 47: <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='G3972G' clickHandler>Paul</jLink> and <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='G0921G' clickHandler>Barnabas</jLink> flee threats in <jLink data-type='L' data-strong='G2430' clickHandler>Iconium</jLink> to <jLink data-type='L' data-strong='G3082' clickHandler>Lystra</jLink> and <jLink data-type='L' data-strong='G1190' clickHandler>Derbe</jLink>.

ChronologyEntries.article: AD 48:  The <jLink data-type='L' data-strong='H3389' clickHandler>Jerusalem</jLink> Council convened in AD 48 to address the crucial question of whether <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H1471G' clickHandler>Gentile</jLink> converts to Christianity were required to observe Jewish law, particularly circumcision, a controversy that had arisen following <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='G3972G' clickHandler>Paul</jLink> and <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='G0921G' clickHandler>Barnabas</jLink>'s successful <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H1471G' clickHandler>Gentile</jLink> evangelism (Act.15:1-35). The council, led by the apostles and elders in <jLink data-type='L' data-strong='H3389' clickHandler>Jerusalem</jLink>, heard testimony from <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='G3972G' clickHandler>Paul</jLink> and <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='G0921G' clickHandler>Barnabas</jLink> about the signs and wonders God had performed among the <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H1471G' clickHandler>Gentiles</jLink>, followed by <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='G2385I' clickHandler>James</jLink>'s decisive speech concluding that <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H1471G' clickHandler>Gentiles</jLink> should not be burdened with the Mosaic law but should abstain only from food sacrificed to idols, blood, meat from strangled animals, and sexual immorality. This landmark decision, communicated through a letter sent with chosen delegates, established that salvation through <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='G2424G' clickHandler>Jesus</jLink> Christ was available to all people through faith rather than adherence to Jewish ceremonial law, fundamentally shaping the universal character of Christianity. Following the council, <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='G3972G' clickHandler>Paul</jLink> began his second missionary journey, initially accompanied by <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='G0921G' clickHandler>Barnabas</jLink>, but they separated over a disagreement concerning <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='G2491G' clickHandler>John</jLink> <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='G3138' clickHandler>Mark</jLink>'s participation (Act.15:36-41). <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='G3972G' clickHandler>Paul</jLink> chose <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='G4609' clickHandler>Silas</jLink> as his companion and traveled through <jLink data-type='L' data-strong='H0758I' clickHandler>Syria</jLink> and <jLink data-type='L' data-strong='G2791' clickHandler>Cilicia</jLink>, strengthening the churches established during his previous journey. <jPara></jPara>  During this period, <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='G3972G' clickHandler>Paul</jLink> likely wrote his epistle to the Galatians, though this may also have been written a decade later. Galatians addresses the same theological issues debated at the <jLink data-type='L' data-strong='H3389' clickHandler>Jerusalem</jLink> Council and defending his apostolic authority against those who sought to impose Jewish law on <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H1471G' clickHandler>Gentile</jLink> believers. <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='G3972G' clickHandler>Paul</jLink> recounted his confrontation with <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='G4074G' clickHandler>Peter</jLink> at <jLink data-type='L' data-strong='G0490H' clickHandler>Antioch</jLink> over the issue of Jewish-Gentile fellowship (Gal.2:11-21), and established his credentials as an apostle called directly by <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='G2424G' clickHandler>Jesus</jLink> Christ rather than through human intermediaries (Gal.1:1-11). This letter provided a theological foundation for the principle of justification by faith alone, which would become central to Christian doctrine.
events: AD 48: The <jLink data-type='L' data-strong='H3389' clickHandler>Jerusalem</jLink> Council convenes to resolve <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H1471G' clickHandler>Gentile</jLink> observance of Jewish law.

AD 48: <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='G3972G' clickHandler>Paul</jLink> and <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='G0921G' clickHandler>Barnabas</jLink> testify to the council about God’s work among <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H1471G' clickHandler>Gentiles</jLink>.

AD 48: <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='G2385I' clickHandler>James</jLink> delivers the council’s decision limiting <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H1471G' clickHandler>Gentile</jLink> requirements.
AD 48: The council’s decision is sent to <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H1471G' clickHandler>Gentile</jLink> believers by letter and delegates.

AD 48: <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='G3972G' clickHandler>Paul</jLink> and <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='G0921G' clickHandler>Barnabas</jLink> dispute over <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='G2491G' clickHandler>John</jLink> <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='G3138' clickHandler>Mark</jLink> and separate; <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='G0921G' clickHandler>Barnabas</jLink> goes to <jLink data-type='L' data-strong='H3794H' clickHandler>Cyprus</jLink>, <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='G3972G' clickHandler>Paul</jLink> chooses <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='G4609' clickHandler>Silas</jLink>.

ChronologyEntries.desc: - to Phil., Thess., <jLink data-type='L' data-strong='G0960' clickHandler>Berea</jLink>, <jLink data-type='L' data-strong='G0116' clickHandler>Athens</jLink>, Cor.
ChronologyEntries.article: AD 49:  <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='G3972G' clickHandler>Paul</jLink>'s missionary activities in AD 49 marked Christianity's first systematic expansion into Europe when he responded to the <jLink data-type='L' data-strong='G3109' clickHandler>Macedonian</jLink> vision calling him to "come over to <jLink data-type='L' data-strong='G3109' clickHandler>Macedonia</jLink> and help us" (Act.16:9-10). Beginning in <jLink data-type='L' data-strong='G5375' clickHandler>Philippi</jLink>, a leading city of <jLink data-type='L' data-strong='G3109' clickHandler>Macedonia</jLink>, <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='G3972G' clickHandler>Paul</jLink> established Europe's first recorded Christian church, notable for the conversion of <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='G3070' clickHandler>Lydia</jLink>, a seller of purple goods, and her household (Act.16:11-15). His ministry in <jLink data-type='L' data-strong='G5375' clickHandler>Philippi</jLink> also included the dramatic conversion of the <jLink data-type='L' data-strong='G5375' clickHandler>Philippian</jLink> jailer following <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='G3972G' clickHandler>Paul</jLink> and <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='G4609' clickHandler>Silas</jLink>'s imprisonment, beating, and miraculous release through an earthquake, events that demonstrated divine power and led to multiple conversions despite official persecution (Act.16:16-34). <jPara></jPara> From <jLink data-type='L' data-strong='G5375' clickHandler>Philippi</jLink>, <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='G3972G' clickHandler>Paul</jLink> traveled to <jLink data-type='L' data-strong='G2332' clickHandler>Thessalonica</jLink>, where he preached in the synagogue for three consecutive <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H7676' clickHandler>Sabbaths</jLink>, reasoning from the Scriptures that Christ had to suffer and rise from the dead (Act.17:1-9). Although some <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='G2454' clickHandler>Jews</jLink> and many God-fearing Greeks believed, Jewish opposition forced <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='G3972G' clickHandler>Paul</jLink> to flee to <jLink data-type='L' data-strong='G0960' clickHandler>Berea</jLink>, where he found more receptive hearers who "examined the Scriptures daily to see if these things were so" (Act.17:10-15). His subsequent ministry in <jLink data-type='L' data-strong='G0116' clickHandler>Athens</jLink> included his famous <jLink data-type='L' data-strong='G0697' clickHandler>Areopagus</jLink> address to Greek philosophers, where he proclaimed the "unknown God" and preached about the resurrection, receiving mixed responses but gaining some converts including <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='G1354' clickHandler>Dionysius</jLink> the <jLink data-type='L' data-strong='G0697' clickHandler>Areopagite</jLink> (Act.17:16-34). The year concluded with <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='G3972G' clickHandler>Paul</jLink>'s arrival in <jLink data-type='L' data-strong='G2882' clickHandler>Corinth</jLink>, where he would establish one of the most significant early Christian communities. During this period, <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='G3972G' clickHandler>Paul</jLink> wrote both 1 Thessalonians and 2 Thessalonians to encourage and instruct the church he had established there, addressing their concerns about the day of the Lord and providing guidance for Christian living amid persecution (1Th.1:1, 2:2; 2Th.1:1).
events: AD 49: <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='G3972G' clickHandler>Paul</jLink> and companions sail from <jLink data-type='L' data-strong='G5174' clickHandler>Troas</jLink> to <jLink data-type='L' data-strong='G5375' clickHandler>Philippi</jLink> for the first Christian mission in Europe.
AD 49: <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='G3070' clickHandler>Lydia</jLink> and her household are converted and baptized in <jLink data-type='L' data-strong='G5375' clickHandler>Philippi</jLink>.

AD 49: <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='G3972G' clickHandler>Paul</jLink> and <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='G4609' clickHandler>Silas</jLink> are imprisoned and miraculously released in <jLink data-type='L' data-strong='G5375' clickHandler>Philippi</jLink>.

AD 49: <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='G3972G' clickHandler>Paul</jLink> and companions travel to <jLink data-type='L' data-strong='G2332' clickHandler>Thessalonica</jLink> and preach in the synagogue.

AD 49: <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='G3972G' clickHandler>Paul</jLink> and companions travel to <jLink data-type='L' data-strong='G0960' clickHandler>Berea</jLink>, where many diligently study the Scriptures.

ChronologyEntries.article: AD 50:  <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='G3972G' clickHandler>Paul</jLink> stayed in <jLink data-type='L' data-strong='G2882' clickHandler>Corinth</jLink> with <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='G4252' clickHandler>Priscilla</jLink> and <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='G0207' clickHandler>Aquila</jLink> who were fellow tent-makers. He wrote both First and Second Thessalonians in AD 50, which are widely regarded as the earliest surviving Christian epistles. These letters were addressed to the Christian community in <jLink data-type='L' data-strong='G2332' clickHandler>Thessalonica</jLink>, a major <jLink data-type='L' data-strong='G3109' clickHandler>Macedonian</jLink> city where <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='G3972G' clickHandler>Paul</jLink> had established a church during his second missionary journey before being forced to leave due to Jewish opposition. He sought to encourage and instruct the Thessalonian believers who were experiencing persecution and confusion about eschatological matters, particularly concerning the return of Christ and the fate of deceased believers. <jPara></jPara> The theological significance of these epistles extends far beyond their historical priority, as they established foundational Christian doctrines regarding sanctification, community ethics, and eschatology that would influence subsequent Christian thought for centuries. In 1 Thessalonians, <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='G3972G' clickHandler>Paul</jLink> commended the church's faithfulness amid persecution while providing ethical instruction on sexual morality and community relations, and clarified misunderstandings about the resurrection and the day of the Lord. The closely related 2 Thessalonians, written shortly thereafter, further addressed eschatological misconceptions by emphasizing that certain prophetic events must precede Christ's return, while also confronting problems of idleness and disorder within the community. These letters demonstrate <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='G3972G' clickHandler>Paul</jLink>'s pastoral care and theological precision during the formative period of Christianity's expansion into Europe.
events: AD 50: <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='G3972G' clickHandler>Paul</jLink> resides in <jLink data-type='L' data-strong='G2882' clickHandler>Corinth</jLink> with <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='G4252' clickHandler>Priscilla</jLink> and <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='G0207' clickHandler>Aquila</jLink> as tent-makers.
AD 50: <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='G3972G' clickHandler>Paul</jLink> writes 1 Thessalonians to encourage the Thessalonian church.
AD 50: <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='G3972G' clickHandler>Paul</jLink> writes 2 Thessalonians to address concerns about Christ’s return.

ChronologyEntries.desc: - expelled from <jLink data-type='L' data-strong='G2882' clickHandler>Corinth</jLink>. To <jLink data-type='L' data-strong='G2181' clickHandler>Ephesus</jLink>
ChronologyEntries.article: AD 51:  <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='G3972G' clickHandler>Paul</jLink>'s ministry in <jLink data-type='L' data-strong='G2882' clickHandler>Corinth</jLink> came to an abrupt end in AD 51 when he was brought before the Roman proconsul <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='G1058' clickHandler>Gallio</jLink> by hostile Jewish opponents (Act.18:12-17). Although <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='G1058' clickHandler>Gallio</jLink> dismissed the charges as internal Jewish religious disputes that fell outside Roman jurisdiction, the incident prompted <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='G3972G' clickHandler>Paul</jLink> to conclude his eighteen-month ministry in <jLink data-type='L' data-strong='G2882' clickHandler>Corinth</jLink>, during which he had established one of the most significant early Christian communities. His departure from <jLink data-type='L' data-strong='G2882' clickHandler>Corinth</jLink> marked the end of a particularly fruitful period during which he had worked alongside <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='G4252' clickHandler>Priscilla</jLink> and <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='G0207' clickHandler>Aquila</jLink> in tentmaking while preaching that <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='G2424G' clickHandler>Jesus</jLink> was the Christ, converting many Corinthians including <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='G2921' clickHandler>Crispus</jLink>, the ruler of the synagogue, and his entire household. <jPara></jPara> Following his expulsion from <jLink data-type='L' data-strong='G2882' clickHandler>Corinth</jLink>, <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='G3972G' clickHandler>Paul</jLink> sailed across the Aegean Sea to <jLink data-type='L' data-strong='G2181' clickHandler>Ephesus</jLink>, accompanied by <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='G4252' clickHandler>Priscilla</jLink> and <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='G0207' clickHandler>Aquila</jLink>, beginning what would become one of his most important and longest-lasting ministerial relationships with a single city. During this initial visit to <jLink data-type='L' data-strong='G2181' clickHandler>Ephesus</jLink>, <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='G3972G' clickHandler>Paul</jLink> briefly engaged with the Jewish community in their synagogue, where his teaching was received favorably enough that they requested him to stay longer. However, <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='G3972G' clickHandler>Paul</jLink> declined this invitation, promising to return "if God wills," and continued his journey to <jLink data-type='L' data-strong='H3389' clickHandler>Jerusalem</jLink> to observe a feast, likely one of the major Jewish festivals. This brief introduction to <jLink data-type='L' data-strong='G2181' clickHandler>Ephesus</jLink> established the groundwork for his future extensive ministry there, while his companions <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='G4252' clickHandler>Priscilla</jLink> and <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='G0207' clickHandler>Aquila</jLink> remained in the city, where they would soon encounter and instruct <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='G0625' clickHandler>Apollos</jLink> in Christian doctrine more accurately.
events: AD 51: <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='G3972G' clickHandler>Paul</jLink> is accused before <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='G1058' clickHandler>Gallio</jLink> in <jLink data-type='L' data-strong='G2882' clickHandler>Corinth</jLink>, but <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='G1058' clickHandler>Gallio</jLink> dismisses the case.
AD 51: <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='G3972G' clickHandler>Paul</jLink> concludes his eighteen-month ministry in <jLink data-type='L' data-strong='G2882' clickHandler>Corinth</jLink>.

AD 51: <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='G3972G' clickHandler>Paul</jLink> leaves <jLink data-type='L' data-strong='G2882' clickHandler>Corinth</jLink> with <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='G4252' clickHandler>Priscilla</jLink> and <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='G0207' clickHandler>Aquila</jLink> and sails to <jLink data-type='L' data-strong='G2181' clickHandler>Ephesus</jLink>.

AD 51: <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='G3972G' clickHandler>Paul</jLink> briefly teaches in the synagogue in <jLink data-type='L' data-strong='G2181' clickHandler>Ephesus</jLink> and promises to return.

AD 51: <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='G4252' clickHandler>Priscilla</jLink> and <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='G0207' clickHandler>Aquila</jLink> remain in <jLink data-type='L' data-strong='G2181' clickHandler>Ephesus</jLink> after <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='G3972G' clickHandler>Paul</jLink>’s departure.

ChronologyEntries.desc: <jChronDurationLink style='color:red'>▼</jChronDurationLink>Felix; Paul to <jLink data-type='L' data-strong='H3389' clickHandler>Jerusalem</jLink> & <jLink data-type='L' data-strong='G0490G' clickHandler>Antioch</jLink>.
ChronologyEntries.article: AD 52:  <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='G3972G' clickHandler>Paul</jLink> completed his second missionary journey in AD 52 by traveling from <jLink data-type='L' data-strong='G2181' clickHandler>Ephesus</jLink> to <jLink data-type='L' data-strong='G2542H' clickHandler>Caesarea</jLink>, then proceeding to <jLink data-type='L' data-strong='H3389' clickHandler>Jerusalem</jLink> to greet the church before returning to his home base in <jLink data-type='L' data-strong='G0490G' clickHandler>Antioch</jLink> (Act.18:22). This journey to <jLink data-type='L' data-strong='H3389' clickHandler>Jerusalem</jLink> likely fulfilled the vow he had made at <jLink data-type='L' data-strong='G2747' clickHandler>Cenchreae</jLink> (Act.18:18) and may correspond to another visit (Gal.2:1), though the chronological relationship between these references remains a matter of scholarly debate. His return to <jLink data-type='L' data-strong='G0490G' clickHandler>Antioch</jLink> provided an opportunity to report on the successes and challenges of his extended ministry in <jLink data-type='L' data-strong='G3109' clickHandler>Macedonia</jLink>, <jLink data-type='L' data-strong='G0882' clickHandler>Achaia</jLink>, and <jLink data-type='L' data-strong='G0773' clickHandler>Asia</jLink> Minor, while also preparing for his subsequent missionary endeavors that would focus primarily on the province of <jLink data-type='L' data-strong='G0773' clickHandler>Asia</jLink>. <jPara></jPara> During this same period, <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='G0625' clickHandler>Apollos</jLink>, an eloquent Jewish Christian from <jLink data-type='L' data-strong='G0222' clickHandler>Alexandria</jLink>, arrived in <jLink data-type='L' data-strong='G2882' clickHandler>Corinth</jLink> after having been more accurately instructed in Christian doctrine by <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='G4252' clickHandler>Priscilla</jLink> and <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='G0207' clickHandler>Aquila</jLink> in <jLink data-type='L' data-strong='G2181' clickHandler>Ephesus</jLink> (Act.18:24-19:1). <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='G0625' clickHandler>Apollos</jLink> possessed remarkable rhetorical skills and thorough knowledge of the Hebrew Scriptures, which enabled him to refute Jewish opponents publicly and demonstrate convincingly that <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='G2424G' clickHandler>Jesus</jLink> was the promised Messiah. His ministry in <jLink data-type='L' data-strong='G2882' clickHandler>Corinth</jLink> proved highly effective in strengthening the church that <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='G3972G' clickHandler>Paul</jLink> had established, though it also contributed to the development of factions within the community, as some believers began identifying themselves as followers of <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='G0625' clickHandler>Apollos</jLink> rather than <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='G3972G' clickHandler>Paul</jLink>. This situation would later require <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='G3972G' clickHandler>Paul</jLink>'s attention in his correspondence with the Corinthians, where he addressed the problem of divisions and emphasized that all Christian ministers are merely servants through whom people believe, with God alone providing the growth.
events: AD 52: <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='G3972G' clickHandler>Paul</jLink> travels from <jLink data-type='L' data-strong='G2181' clickHandler>Ephesus</jLink> to <jLink data-type='L' data-strong='G2542H' clickHandler>Caesarea</jLink>, ending his second missionary journey.
AD 52: <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='G3972G' clickHandler>Paul</jLink> visits the church in <jLink data-type='L' data-strong='H3389' clickHandler>Jerusalem</jLink>.
AD 52: <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='G3972G' clickHandler>Paul</jLink> returns to <jLink data-type='L' data-strong='G0490G' clickHandler>Antioch</jLink> to report and prepare for future missions.
AD 52: <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='G3972G' clickHandler>Paul</jLink> begins his third missionary journey from <jLink data-type='L' data-strong='G0490G' clickHandler>Antioch</jLink>.

AD 52: <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='G0625' clickHandler>Apollos</jLink> ministers in <jLink data-type='L' data-strong='G2882' clickHandler>Corinth</jLink> after instruction by <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='G4252' clickHandler>Priscilla</jLink> and <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='G0207' clickHandler>Aquila</jLink> in <jLink data-type='L' data-strong='G2181' clickHandler>Ephesus</jLink>.

ChronologyEntries.article: AD 53:  <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='G3972G' clickHandler>Paul</jLink> initiated his third and most extensive missionary journey in AD 53, departing from <jLink data-type='L' data-strong='G0490G' clickHandler>Antioch</jLink> and traveling through the <jLink data-type='L' data-strong='G1053' clickHandler>Galatian</jLink> region to strengthen the churches he had previously established, before proceeding to <jLink data-type='L' data-strong='G2181' clickHandler>Ephesus</jLink> for what would become a three-year residency (Act.18:23-19:1). His systematic progression through <jLink data-type='L' data-strong='G1053' clickHandler>Galatia</jLink> demonstrated his pastoral commitment to the ongoing spiritual development of Christian communities, as he encouraged believers and addressed doctrinal challenges that had arisen in his absence. Upon reaching <jLink data-type='L' data-strong='G2181' clickHandler>Ephesus</jLink>, <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='G3972G' clickHandler>Paul</jLink> encountered twelve disciples who had received only <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='G2491G' clickHandler>John</jLink>'s baptism, leading to their proper Christian baptism and reception of the Holy Spirit through the laying on of <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='G3972G' clickHandler>Paul</jLink>'s hands, establishing the theological precedent for complete Christian initiation. <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='G3972G' clickHandler>Paul</jLink>'s extended ministry in <jLink data-type='L' data-strong='G2181' clickHandler>Ephesus</jLink> during this period was marked by extraordinary signs and wonders, including healings performed through handkerchiefs and aprons that had touched his body, and the dramatic confrontation with the seven sons of <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='G4630' clickHandler>Sceva</jLink> that demonstrated the superiority of Christian spiritual authority over magical practices (Act.19:11-20). <jPara></jPara> From <jLink data-type='L' data-strong='G2181' clickHandler>Ephesus</jLink>, <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='G3972G' clickHandler>Paul</jLink> wrote 1 Corinthians to address multiple theological and practical issues that had developed in the <jLink data-type='L' data-strong='G2882' clickHandler>Corinthian</jLink> church, including divisions among believers, questions about marriage and celibacy, problems with sexual immorality, disputes about food sacrificed to idols, disorders in worship assemblies, and confusion about the resurrection of the dead. This epistle represents one of <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='G3972G' clickHandler>Paul</jLink>'s most comprehensive treatments of Christian ethics and church order, providing detailed instructions that would shape Christian practice for centuries while addressing the specific cultural challenges faced by a diverse urban Christian community in the cosmopolitan environment of Roman <jLink data-type='L' data-strong='G2882' clickHandler>Corinth</jLink>.
events: AD 53: <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='G3972G' clickHandler>Paul</jLink> begins his third missionary journey from <jLink data-type='L' data-strong='G0490G' clickHandler>Antioch</jLink> through <jLink data-type='L' data-strong='G1053' clickHandler>Galatia</jLink>.
AD 53: <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='G3972G' clickHandler>Paul</jLink> arrives in <jLink data-type='L' data-strong='G2181' clickHandler>Ephesus</jLink> and baptizes twelve disciples.
AD 53: <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='G3972G' clickHandler>Paul</jLink> performs extraordinary miracles in <jLink data-type='L' data-strong='G2181' clickHandler>Ephesus</jLink>.

AD 53: Seven sons of <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='G4630' clickHandler>Sceva</jLink> fail in an exorcism in contrast to <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='G3972G' clickHandler>Paul</jLink>’s ministry.
AD 53: Many Ephesians publicly burn magic books.

ChronologyEntries.desc: <jChronDurationLink style='color:red'>▼</jChronDurationLink>Nero; <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='G3972G' clickHandler>Paul</jLink> to <jLink data-type='L' data-strong='G2882' clickHandler>Corinth</jLink>? (painful visit)
ChronologyEntries.article: AD 54:  <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='G3972G' clickHandler>Paul</jLink> likely made an unscheduled visit to <jLink data-type='L' data-strong='G2882' clickHandler>Corinth</jLink> in AD 54 that he later described as a "painful visit" so that "I made up my mind that I would not make another painful visit to you" (2Co.2:1). This visit, which occurred between his initial founding of the <jLink data-type='L' data-strong='G2882' clickHandler>Corinthian</jLink> church and the writing of 2 Corinthians, appears to have been characterized by significant conflict and confrontation within the Christian community. The nature of this pain likely involved challenges to <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='G3972G' clickHandler>Paul</jLink>'s apostolic authority, moral issues within the congregation, or disputes that created emotional distress for both <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='G3972G' clickHandler>Paul</jLink> and the <jLink data-type='L' data-strong='G2882' clickHandler>Corinthian</jLink> believers. <jPara></jPara> <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='G3972G' clickHandler>Paul</jLink> refers to this being his "third time" coming to visit them, warning that he "will not spare those who have sinned" (2Co.13:1-2), suggesting the visit involved serious disciplinary matters that remained unresolved. This difficult encounter set the stage for <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='G3972G' clickHandler>Paul</jLink>'s subsequent correspondence with the Corinthians, including what scholars believe was a "severe letter" (now lost) and ultimately the composition of 2 Corinthians, where <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='G3972G' clickHandler>Paul</jLink> seeks reconciliation while addressing the aftermath of this troubled visit. The timing of this visit likely occurred while <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='G3972G' clickHandler>Paul</jLink> was still based in <jLink data-type='L' data-strong='G2181' clickHandler>Ephesus</jLink> during his extended three-year ministry there.
events: AD 54: <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='G3972G' clickHandler>Paul</jLink> makes a "painful visit" to <jLink data-type='L' data-strong='G2882' clickHandler>Corinth</jLink> to confront conflict.

AD 54: <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='G3972G' clickHandler>Paul</jLink> warns the <jLink data-type='L' data-strong='G2882' clickHandler>Corinthian</jLink> believers of disciplinary action on his next visit.

ChronologyEntries.desc: - <jLink data-type='L' data-strong='G2181' clickHandler>Ephesus</jLink> prison: Philp, Philm, Col.?
ChronologyEntries.article: AD 55:  <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='G3972G' clickHandler>Paul</jLink> appears to have experienced imprisonment in <jLink data-type='L' data-strong='G2181' clickHandler>Ephesus</jLink> though this detention is not explicitly recorded in the Acts narrative but is inferred from references in his letters (1Co.15:32; 2Co.1:8-10). In the latter passage, <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='G3972G' clickHandler>Paul</jLink> describes being "so utterly burdened beyond our strength that we despaired of life itself" while experiencing severe affliction in <jLink data-type='L' data-strong='G0773' clickHandler>Asia</jLink>, the Roman province containing <jLink data-type='L' data-strong='G2181' clickHandler>Ephesus</jLink>. His mention of fighting "wild beasts at <jLink data-type='L' data-strong='G2181' clickHandler>Ephesus</jLink>" in 1 Corinthians may refer metaphorically to fierce opposition or possibly literal imprisonment conditions, while 2 Corinthians speaks of receiving "the sentence of death" and being delivered by God who "raises the dead.". <jPara></jPara> During this period of imprisonment or severe hardship in <jLink data-type='L' data-strong='G2181' clickHandler>Ephesus</jLink>, <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='G3972G' clickHandler>Paul</jLink> possibly composed three of his Prison Epistles: Philippians, <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='G5371' clickHandler>Philemon</jLink>, and Colossians, though these letters may have been written in a <jLink data-type='L' data-strong='G2542H' clickHandler>Caesarean</jLink> or Roman prison. The evidence for <jLink data-type='L' data-strong='G2181' clickHandler>Ephesian</jLink> origin includes the expression of thanksgiving from prison (Php.1:3), the references to <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='G3972G' clickHandler>Paul</jLink>'s circumstances and companions including <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='G0708' clickHandler>Aristarchus</jLink> and <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='G3138' clickHandler>Mark</jLink> (Col.1:7; 4:7-12), and the request for lodging preparation in anticipation of release (Phm.1:22-23). These letters demonstrate <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='G3972G' clickHandler>Paul</jLink>'s continued pastoral concern and theological instruction even while facing personal danger, with Colossians addressing Christological heresies, Philippians encouraging joy amid suffering, and <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='G5371' clickHandler>Philemon</jLink> advocating for the runaway slave <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='G3682' clickHandler>Onesimus</jLink> who had apparently encountered <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='G3972G' clickHandler>Paul</jLink> during his imprisonment.
events: AD 55: <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='G3972G' clickHandler>Paul</jLink> suffers fierce opposition, severe affliction and likely imprisonment in <jLink data-type='L' data-strong='G2181' clickHandler>Ephesus</jLink>.
AD 55: <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='G3972G' clickHandler>Paul</jLink> writes Philippians possibly from this prison, expressing joy and urging steadfastness.
AD 55: <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='G3972G' clickHandler>Paul</jLink> writes Colossians possibly from this prison, addressing false teachings and Christ’s supremacy.

AD 55: <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='G3972G' clickHandler>Paul</jLink> writes <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='G5371' clickHandler>Philemon</jLink> possibly from this prison, appealing for <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='G3682' clickHandler>Onesimus</jLink> and requesting lodging.

ChronologyEntries.desc: - leaves <jLink data-type='L' data-strong='G2181' clickHandler>Ephesus</jLink>; 2Cor, Rom written?
