ChronologyEntries.article: AD 56:  <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='G3972G' clickHandler>Paul</jLink> was forced to leave <jLink data-type='L' data-strong='G2181' clickHandler>Ephesus</jLink> following a significant riot instigated by <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='G1216' clickHandler>Demetrius</jLink>, a silversmith who crafted shrines for the goddess <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='G0735' clickHandler>Artemis</jLink> (Act.19:23-41). The riot erupted because <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='G3972G' clickHandler>Paul</jLink>'s preaching had diminished the demand for silver shrines, threatening the livelihood of local craftsmen and the prestige of the famous Temple of <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='G0735' clickHandler>Artemis</jLink>. The crowd gathered in the theater of <jLink data-type='L' data-strong='G2181' clickHandler>Ephesus</jLink>, shouting "Great is <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='G0735' clickHandler>Artemis</jLink> of the Ephesians!" for about two hours until the town clerk finally dispersed them by warning of potential Roman intervention for unlawful assembly. After this tumultuous event, <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='G3972G' clickHandler>Paul</jLink> departed for <jLink data-type='L' data-strong='G3109' clickHandler>Macedonia</jLink> (Act.20:1-2), where he spent considerable time encouraging the churches before traveling to <jLink data-type='L' data-strong='H3120H' clickHandler>Greece</jLink>, likely <jLink data-type='L' data-strong='G2882' clickHandler>Corinth</jLink>, where he spent three months during the winter (Act.20:2-4). This year also coincided with a <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H7676' clickHandler>Sabbath</jLink> year in the Jewish calendar, when agricultural land remained fallow and debts were released, creating economic hardship that would have intensified the need for charitable support among Jewish Christians. <jPara></jPara>  During this transitional year, <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='G3972G' clickHandler>Paul</jLink> likely wrote 2 Corinthians while in <jLink data-type='L' data-strong='G3109' clickHandler>Macedonia</jLink> and Romans while in <jLink data-type='L' data-strong='G2882' clickHandler>Corinth</jLink>, though scholarly opinion varies on these precise timings. The emotional tone and geographical references in 2 Corinthians align with <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='G3972G' clickHandler>Paul</jLink>'s experiences after leaving <jLink data-type='L' data-strong='G2181' clickHandler>Ephesus</jLink>, particularly his anxiety about not finding <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='G5103' clickHandler>Titus</jLink> in <jLink data-type='L' data-strong='G5174' clickHandler>Troas</jLink> (2 Cor. 2:12-13) and his subsequent relief upon meeting him in <jLink data-type='L' data-strong='G3109' clickHandler>Macedonia</jLink> (2 Cor. 7:5-7, 13). Romans, traditionally dated to <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='G3972G' clickHandler>Paul</jLink>'s winter stay in <jLink data-type='L' data-strong='G2882' clickHandler>Corinth</jLink>, contains his mature theological exposition and includes significant discussion of his planned journey to <jLink data-type='L' data-strong='H3389' clickHandler>Jerusalem</jLink> with the collection for the saints (Rom. 15:25-27), demonstrating his commitment to Jewish-Gentile unity within the church. The epistle also mentions <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='G5402' clickHandler>Phoebe</jLink>, a deacon from <jLink data-type='L' data-strong='G2747' clickHandler>Cenchreae</jLink> near <jLink data-type='L' data-strong='G2882' clickHandler>Corinth</jLink>, whom <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='G3972G' clickHandler>Paul</jLink> commended as the letter's bearer (Rom. 16:1). Both epistles reflect <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='G3972G' clickHandler>Paul</jLink>'s passionate appeal for generosity toward the <jLink data-type='L' data-strong='H3389' clickHandler>Jerusalem</jLink> church, emphasizing how <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H1471G' clickHandler>Gentile</jLink> Christians should support their Jewish brethren who would experience particular hardship after the <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H7676' clickHandler>Sabbath</jLink> year of 56 CE. This bolstered both practical needs and theological principles of Christian unity across ethnic boundaries.
events: AD 56: <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='G1216' clickHandler>Demetrius</jLink> incites a riot in <jLink data-type='L' data-strong='G2181' clickHandler>Ephesus</jLink> over <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='G0735' clickHandler>Artemis</jLink> shrines.
AD 56: The town clerk disperses the <jLink data-type='L' data-strong='G2181' clickHandler>Ephesian</jLink> riot.

AD 56: <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='G3972G' clickHandler>Paul</jLink> departs <jLink data-type='L' data-strong='G2181' clickHandler>Ephesus</jLink> for <jLink data-type='L' data-strong='G3109' clickHandler>Macedonia</jLink> after the riot.

AD 56: <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='G3972G' clickHandler>Paul</jLink> spends time in <jLink data-type='L' data-strong='G3109' clickHandler>Macedonia</jLink> and <jLink data-type='L' data-strong='H3120H' clickHandler>Greece</jLink>, staying three months in <jLink data-type='L' data-strong='H3120H' clickHandler>Greece</jLink>.

AD 56: <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='G3972G' clickHandler>Paul</jLink> is anxious in <jLink data-type='L' data-strong='G5174' clickHandler>Troas</jLink> but relieved on finding <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='G5103' clickHandler>Titus</jLink> in <jLink data-type='L' data-strong='G3109' clickHandler>Macedonia</jLink>.

ChronologyEntries.desc: <jChronDurationLink style='color:green'>▼</jChronDurationLink>Paul arrested, addresses <jLink data-type='L' data-strong='H3389' clickHandler>Jerusalem</jLink> & <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='G5344' clickHandler>Felix</jLink>
ChronologyEntries.article: AD 57:  <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='G3972G' clickHandler>Paul</jLink> the Apostle undertook a significant journey to <jLink data-type='L' data-strong='H3389' clickHandler>Jerusalem</jLink> carrying a financial gift for the church there (Act.20:3-21:16). This gift was intended to provide relief during a particularly difficult economic period that followed a <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H7676' clickHandler>Sabbath</jLink> Year—the seventh year in the Jewish agricultural cycle when land remained fallow, often resulting in food shortages. He thus concluded his third missionary journey, with stops at several significant locations. His route took him through <jLink data-type='L' data-strong='G5375' clickHandler>Philippi</jLink>, where he celebrated <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H6453' clickHandler>Passover</jLink>, then to <jLink data-type='L' data-strong='G5174' clickHandler>Troas</jLink>, where he preached until midnight and miraculously raised <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='G2161' clickHandler>Eutychus</jLink> from the dead after the young man fell from a third-story window. <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='G3972G' clickHandler>Paul</jLink> continued through <jLink data-type='L' data-strong='G0789' clickHandler>Assos</jLink>, <jLink data-type='L' data-strong='G3412' clickHandler>Mitylene</jLink>, <jLink data-type='L' data-strong='G5508' clickHandler>Chios</jLink>, <jLink data-type='L' data-strong='G4544' clickHandler>Samos</jLink>, and <jLink data-type='L' data-strong='G3399' clickHandler>Miletus</jLink>, where he delivered his emotional farewell address to the <jLink data-type='L' data-strong='G2181' clickHandler>Ephesian</jLink> elders, warning them of future dangers to their church and commending them to God's grace. The journey continued through <jLink data-type='L' data-strong='G2972' clickHandler>Cos</jLink>, <jLink data-type='L' data-strong='G4499' clickHandler>Rhodes</jLink>, <jLink data-type='L' data-strong='G3959' clickHandler>Patara</jLink>, <jLink data-type='L' data-strong='H6865' clickHandler>Tyre</jLink>, and <jLink data-type='L' data-strong='G2542H' clickHandler>Caesarea</jLink>, with believers at multiple locations providing prophetic warnings about the suffering that awaited <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='G3972G' clickHandler>Paul</jLink> in <jLink data-type='L' data-strong='H3389' clickHandler>Jerusalem</jLink>. Despite these repeated warnings, including a dramatic prophecy by <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='G0013' clickHandler>Agabus</jLink> in <jLink data-type='L' data-strong='G2542H' clickHandler>Caesarea</jLink> who bound himself with <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='G3972G' clickHandler>Paul</jLink>'s belt to symbolize the apostle's coming imprisonment, <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='G3972G' clickHandler>Paul</jLink> remained resolute in his mission.  <jPara></jPara> In <jLink data-type='L' data-strong='H3389' clickHandler>Jerusalem</jLink>, he met with <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='G2385I' clickHandler>James</jLink> and the church elders, who advised him to participate in a purification rite at the temple with four other men to demonstrate his continued observance of Jewish law and counter rumors that he was teaching <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='G2454' clickHandler>Jews</jLink> living among the <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H1471G' clickHandler>Gentiles</jLink> to abandon <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H4872' clickHandler>Moses</jLink> and circumcision. While <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='G3972G' clickHandler>Paul</jLink> was completing the seven-day purification ritual in the temple, <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='G2454' clickHandler>Jews</jLink> from <jLink data-type='L' data-strong='G0773' clickHandler>Asia</jLink> who recognized him from <jLink data-type='L' data-strong='G2181' clickHandler>Ephesus</jLink> stirred up a violent riot, falsely accusing him of bringing <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H1471G' clickHandler>Gentiles</jLink> into the sacred precincts and defiling the holy place. The mob seized <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='G3972G' clickHandler>Paul</jLink> and would have killed him had not Roman soldiers under the command of a tribune intervened, arresting him and carrying him to the Antonia Fortress. From the barracks steps, <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='G3972G' clickHandler>Paul</jLink> addressed the angry crowd in <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H0762' clickHandler>Aramaic</jLink>, recounting his conversion experience on the <jLink data-type='L' data-strong='H1834' clickHandler>Damascus</jLink> road and his divine commission to preach to the <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H1471G' clickHandler>Gentiles</jLink>, but his mention of the <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H1471G' clickHandler>Gentile</jLink> mission only inflamed their opposition further. When Roman officials prepared to interrogate him under scourging, <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='G3972G' clickHandler>Paul</jLink> asserted his rights as a Roman citizen, preventing the flogging and causing considerable alarm among his captors. The following day, he appeared before the Sanhedrin, where his strategic mention of the resurrection of the dead divided the <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='G5330' clickHandler>Pharisees</jLink> and <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='G4523' clickHandler>Sadducees</jLink>, creating such dissension that the Roman tribune had to rescue him again. Learning of a plot by more than forty Jewish conspirators who had vowed to kill <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='G3972G' clickHandler>Paul</jLink>, the Romans transferred him under heavy guard to <jLink data-type='L' data-strong='G2542H' clickHandler>Caesarea</jLink>, where he appeared before the Roman governor Antonius <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='G5344' clickHandler>Felix</jLink> and eloquently defended himself against formal charges of sedition and temple desecration brought by the high priest <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='G0367G' clickHandler>Ananias</jLink> and the orator <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='G5061' clickHandler>Tertullus</jLink>

AD 57: <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='G3972G' clickHandler>Paul</jLink> gives a farewell address to <jLink data-type='L' data-strong='G2181' clickHandler>Ephesian</jLink> elders in <jLink data-type='L' data-strong='G3399' clickHandler>Miletus</jLink>.

AD 57: <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='G3972G' clickHandler>Paul</jLink> receives prophetic warnings en route to <jLink data-type='L' data-strong='H3389' clickHandler>Jerusalem</jLink>, including from <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='G0013' clickHandler>Agabus</jLink>.

ChronologyEntries.article: AD 58:  The date for the composition of the Epistle of <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='G2385I' clickHandler>James</jLink> remains uncertain. Evidence within the letter appears to reflect the specific social and economic conditions of Judea in the late 50s AD. The epistle's vivid depiction of wealthy landowners oppressing poor laborers and withholding wages (Jas.5:1-6) corresponds remarkably well with the economic hardship that would have followed the <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H7676' clickHandler>Sabbath</jLink> year of AD 56/57, when agricultural fields remained fallow and economic pressures intensified. Additionally, the letter's emphasis on patience in suffering and warnings against the rich align with the political instability and corruption characteristic of <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='G5344' clickHandler>Felix</jLink>'s governorship (AD 52-60), a period marked by social unrest, banditry, and the exploitation of the poor by the wealthy and powerful. If <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='G2385I' clickHandler>James</jLink>, the brother of <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='G2424G' clickHandler>Jesus</jLink>, authored the epistle bearing his name, this would fall within the possible timeframe before his martyrdom around AD 62,  <jPara></jPara>  However, there are both earlier and later alternatives. Some scholars argue for a date in the mid-40s AD, citing the epistle's primitive church structure, lack of developed ecclesiastical offices, and absence of references to <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H1471G' clickHandler>Gentile</jLink> inclusion controversies or advanced <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='G3972G' clickHandler>Pauline</jLink> theology. Conversely, other scholars advocate for a late first or early second century date, emphasizing the letter's sophisticated Greek literary style and possible dependence on other New Testament writings, suggesting pseudonymous authorship rather than composition by <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='G2385I' clickHandler>James</jLink>, the brother of <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='G2424G' clickHandler>Jesus</jLink>. The question mark associated with the AD 58 date in historical records reflects this ongoing scholarly uncertainty, with the epistle's actual date of composition remaining one of the more contested issues in New Testament studies.
events: AD 58: <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='G2385I' clickHandler>James</jLink> writes the Epistle of <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='G2385I' clickHandler>James</jLink> to address injustices in Judea.
AD 58: The Epistle of <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='G2385I' clickHandler>James</jLink> reflects current local hardship and unrest in Judea.

ChronologyEntries.desc: <jChronDurationLink style='color:red'>▼</jChronDurationLink><jLink data-type='P' data-strong='G5347' clickHandler>Festus</jLink> with <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='G3972G' clickHandler>Paul</jLink>.  Shipwreck
ChronologyEntries.article: AD 59:  <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='G3972G' clickHandler>Paul</jLink> faced crucial legal proceedings in <jLink data-type='L' data-strong='G2542H' clickHandler>Caesarea</jLink> before the Roman governor <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='G5347' clickHandler>Festus</jLink> and King <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='G0067' clickHandler>Agrippa</jLink> II, who had come to hear his case. During these trials, <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='G3972G' clickHandler>Paul</jLink> defended himself against accusations brought by Jewish leaders, presenting his testimony about his conversion and missionary work. Recognizing the political complexities of his situation and exercising his privilege as a Roman citizen, <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='G3972G' clickHandler>Paul</jLink> made the momentous decision to appeal his case directly to Caesar in <jLink data-type='L' data-strong='G4514' clickHandler>Rome</jLink>, seeking imperial judgment rather than risking transfer to <jLink data-type='L' data-strong='H3389' clickHandler>Jerusalem</jLink> where his life might be endangered. <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='G5347' clickHandler>Festus</jLink>, after conferring with <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='G0067' clickHandler>Agrippa</jLink> II, agreed to honor this legal appeal and arranged for <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='G3972G' clickHandler>Paul</jLink>'s transport to <jLink data-type='L' data-strong='G4514' clickHandler>Rome</jLink>. The Roman centurion <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='G2457' clickHandler>Julius</jLink> was assigned to escort <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='G3972G' clickHandler>Paul</jLink> and other prisoners, accompanied by <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='G3065' clickHandler>Luke</jLink> the physician who documented the voyage (Act.27:1-28:10). <jPara></jPara>  The ship initially sailed along the eastern <jLink data-type='L' data-strong='H1419J' clickHandler>Mediterranean</jLink> coast, stopping at <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H6721G' clickHandler>Sidon</jLink> where <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='G3972G' clickHandler>Paul</jLink> was allowed to visit friends, then continued to <jLink data-type='L' data-strong='G3460' clickHandler>Myra</jLink> in <jLink data-type='L' data-strong='G3073' clickHandler>Lycia</jLink> where they transferred to an Alexandrian grain ship bound for <jLink data-type='L' data-strong='G2482' clickHandler>Italy</jLink>. However, the voyage occurred during the dangerous autumn sailing season, after the Day of Atonement (late September/early October), when <jLink data-type='L' data-strong='H1419J' clickHandler>Mediterranean</jLink> weather patterns made navigation extremely hazardous due to the onset of violent storms and unpredictable winds. A storm drove their ship off course and ultimately caused it to run aground. Despite the severity of the disaster, all 276 people aboard the vessel survived the shipwreck, finding refuge on the island of <jLink data-type='L' data-strong='G3194' clickHandler>Malta</jLink>. During their three-month stay on the island during winter, <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='G3972G' clickHandler>Paul</jLink> demonstrated remarkable divine protection when he was bitten by a viper but suffered no harm, astonishing the local inhabitants who initially expected him to die from the venomous bite. This miraculous event, along with <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='G3972G' clickHandler>Paul</jLink>'s healing of <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='G4196' clickHandler>Publius</jLink>'s father and others on the island, established his reputation among the <jLink data-type='L' data-strong='G3194' clickHandler>Maltese</jLink> people and provided opportunities for ministry even in his circumstances as a prisoner. After wintering on <jLink data-type='L' data-strong='G3194' clickHandler>Malta</jLink>, <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='G3972G' clickHandler>Paul</jLink> continued his journey to <jLink data-type='L' data-strong='G4514' clickHandler>Rome</jLink>, where his appeal to Caesar would be heard, fulfilling both his legal obligation and his long-held desire to preach the gospel in the imperial capital.
events: AD 59: <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='G3972G' clickHandler>Paul</jLink>’s legal proceedings continue before <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='G5347' clickHandler>Festus</jLink> and <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='G0067' clickHandler>Agrippa</jLink> II in <jLink data-type='L' data-strong='G2542H' clickHandler>Caesarea</jLink>.
AD 59: <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='G3972G' clickHandler>Paul</jLink> appeals to Caesar in <jLink data-type='L' data-strong='G4514' clickHandler>Rome</jLink> as a Roman citizen.

AD 59: <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='G5347' clickHandler>Festus</jLink> and <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='G0067' clickHandler>Agrippa</jLink> II approve <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='G3972G' clickHandler>Paul</jLink>’s appeal to <jLink data-type='L' data-strong='G4514' clickHandler>Rome</jLink>.
AD 59: <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='G3972G' clickHandler>Paul</jLink> is placed under the custody of <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='G2457' clickHandler>Julius</jLink> the centurion.

AD 59: <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='G3972G' clickHandler>Paul</jLink>’s voyage to <jLink data-type='L' data-strong='G4514' clickHandler>Rome</jLink> begins with stops at <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H6721G' clickHandler>Sidon</jLink> and <jLink data-type='L' data-strong='G3460' clickHandler>Myra</jLink>.

ChronologyEntries.desc: - to <jLink data-type='L' data-strong='G4946' clickHandler>Syracuse</jLink>, <jLink data-type='L' data-strong='G4484' clickHandler>Rhegium</jLink>, <jLink data-type='L' data-strong='G4223' clickHandler>Puteoli</jLink>, <jLink data-type='L' data-strong='G4514' clickHandler>Rome</jLink>
ChronologyEntries.article: AD 60:  After wintering on <jLink data-type='L' data-strong='G3194' clickHandler>Malta</jLink>, <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='G3972G' clickHandler>Paul</jLink> resumed his journey to <jLink data-type='L' data-strong='G4514' clickHandler>Rome</jLink>, traveling aboard another Alexandrian ship that had also weathered the winter on the island (Act.28:11-16). The ship, identified by its figurehead of the Twin Brothers (Castor and Pollux), carried <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='G3972G' clickHandler>Paul</jLink>'s party northward through the traditional <jLink data-type='L' data-strong='H1419J' clickHandler>Mediterranean</jLink> shipping route, making strategic stops at major ports that connected the eastern and western regions of the Roman Empire. Their first destination was <jLink data-type='L' data-strong='G4946' clickHandler>Syracuse</jLink>, the principal city of Sicily and former Greek colony that served as a major commercial and naval center, where they remained for three days before continuing northward. <jPara></jPara> From <jLink data-type='L' data-strong='G4946' clickHandler>Syracuse</jLink>, the ship sailed to <jLink data-type='L' data-strong='G4484' clickHandler>Rhegium</jLink> at the southern tip of the Italian peninsula, a strategically located Roman city that controlled the narrow Strait of Messina between Sicily and mainland <jLink data-type='L' data-strong='G2482' clickHandler>Italy</jLink>. After one day at <jLink data-type='L' data-strong='G4484' clickHandler>Rhegium</jLink>, favorable south winds carried them to <jLink data-type='L' data-strong='G4223' clickHandler>Puteoli</jLink>, the primary port serving <jLink data-type='L' data-strong='G4514' clickHandler>Rome</jLink> before the later development of Ostia, located on the Bay of Naples and renowned as a bustling commercial hub handling grain imports and luxury goods from across the empire. At <jLink data-type='L' data-strong='G4223' clickHandler>Puteoli</jLink>, <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='G3972G' clickHandler>Paul</jLink> found Christian believers who invited him to stay seven days, demonstrating the widespread establishment of Christian communities throughout the Roman world by this period. The final stage of the journey proceeded overland along the famous Via Appia, with Roman Christians from the capital traveling south to meet <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='G3972G' clickHandler>Paul</jLink> at Appii Forum and Three Taverns, providing encouragement that prompted <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='G3065' clickHandler>Luke</jLink> to observe that <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='G3972G' clickHandler>Paul</jLink> "thanked God and took courage" upon seeing these fellow believers who had journeyed to welcome him despite his status as a prisoner.
events: AD 60: <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='G3972G' clickHandler>Paul</jLink> departs <jLink data-type='L' data-strong='G3194' clickHandler>Malta</jLink> after winter on an Alexandrian ship.
AD 60: <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='G3972G' clickHandler>Paul</jLink> and companions stay three days at <jLink data-type='L' data-strong='G4946' clickHandler>Syracuse</jLink>.

AD 60: <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='G3972G' clickHandler>Paul</jLink> arrives at <jLink data-type='L' data-strong='G4223' clickHandler>Puteoli</jLink> and stays with Christians for seven days.
AD 60: <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='G3972G' clickHandler>Paul</jLink> travels overland along the Via Appia to <jLink data-type='L' data-strong='G4514' clickHandler>Rome</jLink>.

ChronologyEntries.desc: <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='G3972G' clickHandler>Paul</jLink> imprisoned in <jLink data-type='L' data-strong='G4514' clickHandler>Rome</jLink>. 1Pet written?
ChronologyEntries.article: AD 61:  <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='G3972G' clickHandler>Paul</jLink> continued his imprisonment in <jLink data-type='L' data-strong='G4514' clickHandler>Rome</jLink> under house arrest (Act.28:17-31) marking the second year of his detention following his appeal to Caesar around AD 57. Living in his own rented quarters with a Roman guard, <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='G3972G' clickHandler>Paul</jLink> maintained an active ministry, welcoming all visitors and teaching about <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='G2424G' clickHandler>Jesus</jLink> Christ with remarkable freedom despite his circumstances. Shortly after his arrival, <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='G3972G' clickHandler>Paul</jLink> had summoned the local Jewish leaders to explain his situation, declaring that he was bound with chains not for any crime against the Jewish people or ancestral customs, but "because of the hope of Israel". When these leaders expressed interest in hearing his views, <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='G3972G' clickHandler>Paul</jLink> spent an entire day expounding the kingdom of God and trying to convince them about <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='G2424G' clickHandler>Jesus</jLink> from both the Law of <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H4872' clickHandler>Moses</jLink> and the Prophets, though the response was divided—some believed while others rejected his message. Before dismissing them, <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='G3972G' clickHandler>Paul</jLink> declared that "this salvation of God has been sent to the <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H1471G' clickHandler>Gentiles</jLink>; they will listen" (quoting Isa.6:9-10). <jPara></jPara>  This is also a possible date for the composition of the First Epistle of <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='G4074G' clickHandler>Peter</jLink>, though this date remains uncertain. If <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='G4074G' clickHandler>Peter</jLink> wrote his first letter during this period, it would coincide with increasing tensions between Christians and Roman authorities, as the epistle addresses themes of suffering, persecution, and maintaining hope amid trials. The letter's recipients, described as "exiles of the Dispersion" scattered throughout <jLink data-type='L' data-strong='G0773' clickHandler>Asia</jLink> Minor (modern-day Turkey), were experiencing various forms of social ostracism and possibly official harassment for their faith. The epistle's emphasis on Christ as the cornerstone, believers as a chosen people, and the call to honor governing authorities while remaining faithful to God would have provided crucial guidance for early Christian communities navigating the complex relationship between their faith and Roman citizenship during the reign of Emperor <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='G3505' clickHandler>Nero</jLink> (54-68 AD)
events: AD 61: <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='G3972G' clickHandler>Paul</jLink> is under house arrest in <jLink data-type='L' data-strong='G4514' clickHandler>Rome</jLink>.

AD 61: <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='G3972G' clickHandler>Paul</jLink> summons local Jewish leaders in <jLink data-type='L' data-strong='G4514' clickHandler>Rome</jLink> and declares that salvation through <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='G2424G' clickHandler>Jesus</jLink> is also for <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H1471G' clickHandler>Gentiles</jLink>.
AD 61: <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='G3972G' clickHandler>Paul</jLink> continues open ministry while under house arrest.

AD 61: <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='G4074G' clickHandler>Peter</jLink> possibly writes 1 <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='G4074G' clickHandler>Peter</jLink> to exiles in <jLink data-type='L' data-strong='G0773' clickHandler>Asia</jLink> Minor.
AD 61: The Great Boudican Revolt led by Queen Boudica devastates Roman Britain.

ChronologyEntries.article: AD 62:  The martyrdom of <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='G2385I' clickHandler>James</jLink>, the brother of <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='G2424G' clickHandler>Jesus</jLink> and a prominent leader of the <jLink data-type='L' data-strong='H3389' clickHandler>Jerusalem</jLink> church, occurred in AD 62 during a period of increasing tension between early Christian communities and Jewish religious authorities. According to early Christian historians such as Hegesippus (preserved by Eusebius) and the Jewish historian Josephus, <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='G2385I' clickHandler>James</jLink> was executed by stoning after being accused of breaking Jewish law. Josephus specifically refers to him as "<jLink data-type='P' data-strong='G2385I' clickHandler>James</jLink>, the brother of <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='G2424G' clickHandler>Jesus</jLink> who was called Christ," indicating his significance both within the Christian movement and as a recognized figure in <jLink data-type='L' data-strong='H3389' clickHandler>Jerusalem</jLink> society. <jPara></jPara> This martyrdom represents a pivotal moment in early Christian history, as <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='G2385I' clickHandler>James</jLink> had served as a crucial bridge between the Jewish heritage of Christianity and its emerging gentile mission. His death likely intensified the growing divide between traditional <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='G2454' clickHandler>Judaism</jLink> and the nascent Christian movement, contributing to the increasing persecution that would characterize the following years. The execution occurred during the brief period when Ananus served as high priest, suggesting that <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='G2385I' clickHandler>James</jLink>'s death may have been part of a broader crackdown on Christian leadership in <jLink data-type='L' data-strong='H3389' clickHandler>Jerusalem</jLink>.
events: AD 62: <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='G5347' clickHandler>Festus</jLink>’ rule ends.
AD 62: Albinus becomes Procurator of Judea.
AD 62: <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='G2385I' clickHandler>James</jLink>, brother of <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='G2424G' clickHandler>Jesus</jLink>, is martyred.

ChronologyEntries.desc: Eph, Tit, 1Ti, 2Ti, Heb, 2Pe, <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='G2455I' clickHandler>Jude</jLink> ?
ChronologyEntries.article: AD 63:  Several significant New Testament writings can be plausibly dated to <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='G3972G' clickHandler>Paul</jLink>’s imprisonment in <jLink data-type='L' data-strong='G4514' clickHandler>Rome</jLink>. This includes possibly Philippians, <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='G5371' clickHandler>Philemon</jLink> and Colossians, and perhaps Ephesians, <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='G5103' clickHandler>Titus</jLink>, 1 <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='G5095G' clickHandler>Timothy</jLink> and 2 <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='G5095G' clickHandler>Timothy</jLink>. In some traditions 1 <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='G5095G' clickHandler>Timothy</jLink> and <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='G5103' clickHandler>Titus</jLink> were written from <jLink data-type='L' data-strong='G3109' clickHandler>Macedonia</jLink> while <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='G3972G' clickHandler>Paul</jLink> was released for a while, before being imprisoned in <jLink data-type='L' data-strong='G4514' clickHandler>Rome</jLink> again from where he wrote 2 <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='G5095G' clickHandler>Timothy</jLink>. <jPara></jPara>  This may also have been about the time that <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H5680' clickHandler>Hebrews</jLink>, 1&2 <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='G4074G' clickHandler>Peter</jLink>, and <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='G2455I' clickHandler>Jude</jLink> were written but this is very uncertain.
events: AD 63: <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='G3972G' clickHandler>Paul</jLink> may have written Ephesians during his imprisonment in <jLink data-type='L' data-strong='G4514' clickHandler>Rome</jLink>.

AD 63: <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='G3972G' clickHandler>Paul</jLink> may have been released and written <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='G5103' clickHandler>Titus</jLink>, 1 <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='G5095G' clickHandler>Timothy</jLink>, 2 <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='G5095G' clickHandler>Timothy</jLink> from <jLink data-type='L' data-strong='G3109' clickHandler>Macedonia</jLink>.
AD 63: <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H5680' clickHandler>Hebrews</jLink> may have been written around this time.
AD 63: 2 <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='G4074G' clickHandler>Peter</jLink> may have been written in this year.
AD 63: <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='G2455I' clickHandler>Jude</jLink> may also have been written around this year.

ChronologyEntries.desc: <jChronDurationLink style='color:red'>▼</jChronDurationLink>Florus. Martyrdom of <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='G3972G' clickHandler>Paul</jLink> and <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='G4074G' clickHandler>Peter</jLink> ?
ChronologyEntries.nonBibleRefs: 1Clem.5.5-7; Eus.His.2.25.5-8; Acts of Peter; Acts of Paul
ChronologyEntries.article: AD 64:  <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='G3972G' clickHandler>Paul</jLink> and <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='G4074G' clickHandler>Peter</jLink> may have been martyred during the violent persecution initiated by Emperor <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='G3505' clickHandler>Nero</jLink> following the Great Fire of <jLink data-type='L' data-strong='G4514' clickHandler>Rome</jLink>. After the devastating fire that destroyed much of <jLink data-type='L' data-strong='G4514' clickHandler>Rome</jLink>, <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='G3505' clickHandler>Nero</jLink> sought to deflect blame from himself by targeting the Christian community, which was already viewed with suspicion by many Romans. This persecution marked a significant escalation in the Roman government's hostility toward Christianity, transforming it from a largely ignored religious movement to an actively persecuted sect. <jPara></jPara> <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='G3972G' clickHandler>Paul</jLink>, the prolific missionary and writer of numerous New Testament letters, had spent years spreading Christianity throughout the <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H1419J' clickHandler>Mediterranean</jLink> world, while <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='G4074G' clickHandler>Peter</jLink>, regarded as one of <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='G2424G' clickHandler>Jesus</jLink>’ closest disciples and a foundational church leader, had been instrumental in establishing the early Christian community. Their deaths symbolized both the intense opposition faced by the early church under Roman rule and the willingness of Christian leaders to maintain their faith unto death, setting a precedent for countless martyrs who would follow.
events: AD 64: Possible martyrdom of <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='G3972G' clickHandler>Paul</jLink>.
AD 64: Possible martyrdom of <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='G4074G' clickHandler>Peter</jLink>.
AD 64: Fire in <jLink data-type='L' data-strong='G4514' clickHandler>Rome</jLink>.
AD 64: <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='G3505' clickHandler>Nero</jLink>'s persecution of Christians.

ChronologyEntries.article: AD 65:  The Roman procurator Gessius Florus seized seventeen talents of gold from the sacred treasury of the <jLink data-type='L' data-strong='H3389' clickHandler>Jerusalem</jLink> temple, claiming the funds were owed to the emperor. This sacrilegious act outraged the Jewish population, who responded with a public demonstration of contempt by parading through the streets with baskets, collecting coins as if for the supposedly impoverished procurator, thereby highlighting his greed and publicly shaming him before the community. The mockery represented not merely a protest against financial exploitation, but a profound violation of Jewish religious sensibilities, as the temple treasury was considered sacred and inviolable under Jewish law. <jPara></jPara>  Florus's violent retaliation escalated the crisis to unprecedented levels when he ordered his soldiers to plunder the upper market of <jLink data-type='L' data-strong='H3389' clickHandler>Jerusalem</jLink> and commanded the crucifixion of numerous citizens, including individuals of Roman equestrian rank—a shocking breach of Roman legal protections that alarmed both local residents and Roman observers. Despite the intervention and pleas of Queen Berenice, who was present in <jLink data-type='L' data-strong='H3389' clickHandler>Jerusalem</jLink> and attempted to restrain the procurator's brutality, Florus ignored her appeals and continued the violent suppression. According to Josephus, these events served as the immediate catalyst for the outbreak of the First Jewish-Roman War (AD 66-73), as Florus's theft from the temple and subsequent brutal reprisals inflamed tensions between the Jewish population and Roman authorities to the point where peaceful resolution became impossible
events: AD 65: Procurator Gessius Florus steals Temple funds.
AD 65: Jewish anti-Roman riots violently suppressed.

ChronologyEntries.article: AD 66:  The First Jewish-Roman War commenced in AD 66 when widespread Jewish uprisings erupted throughout Judea against Roman rule. The revolt was precipitated by a combination of factors including oppressive taxation, cultural and religious tensions with Roman authorities, and specific incidents of Roman administrative abuse that inflamed Jewish sentiment. Initial success came to the Jewish rebels when they managed to expel Roman forces from <jLink data-type='L' data-strong='H3389' clickHandler>Jerusalem</jLink> and several other key locations, demonstrating the serious nature of the uprising and the depth of popular discontent with Roman governance. <jPara></jPara> The outbreak of this revolt represented a decisive break between the Jewish population and Roman imperial authority, transforming simmering tensions into open warfare. Various Jewish factions united in their opposition to <jLink data-type='L' data-strong='G4514' clickHandler>Rome</jLink>, though they would later fracture into competing groups during the course of the conflict. This uprising set in motion the catastrophic events that would follow over the next four years, ultimately leading to the destruction of <jLink data-type='L' data-strong='H3389' clickHandler>Jerusalem</jLink> and the Second Temple, fundamentally altering the trajectory of both Jewish history and early Christianity.
events: AD 66: Jewish war against Roman occupation begins.

ChronologyEntries.desc: <jChronDurationLink style='color:red'>▼</jChronDurationLink>3 Emperors; <jLink data-type='L' data-strong='H3389' clickHandler>Jerusalem</jLink> surrounded.
ChronologyEntries.article: AD 68:  The Roman Empire entered a period of unprecedented political instability following the suicide of Emperor <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='G3505' clickHandler>Nero</jLink> in June, ending the Julio-Claudian dynasty. This initiated what became known as the "Year of the Four Emperors," beginning with the succession of three emperors in rapid order: Servius Sulpicius Galba, who was proclaimed emperor by his troops in Hispania Tarraconensis and recognized by the Senate; Marcus Salvius Otho, who conspired against Galba with Praetorian Guard support in late 68; and Aulus Vitellius, who was declared emperor by the Germanic legions and began his march on <jLink data-type='L' data-strong='G4514' clickHandler>Rome</jLink>. This imperial crisis created widespread uncertainty throughout the empire, coinciding with the ongoing First Jewish-Roman War (66-73 AD) that was devastating Judea.  <jPara></jPara>  During this turbulent period, the Christian community in <jLink data-type='L' data-strong='H3389' clickHandler>Jerusalem</jLink> made a decisive exodus to Pella, a city in the <jLink data-type='L' data-strong='G1179' clickHandler>Decapolis</jLink> region east of the <jLink data-type='L' data-strong='H3383' clickHandler>Jordan</jLink> River. According to Eusebius (History 3.5.3), the <jLink data-type='L' data-strong='H3389' clickHandler>Jerusalem</jLink> Christians received a divine revelation commanding them to leave the city before the impending Roman siege. This flight was understood by early Christians as a direct fulfillment of <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='G2424G' clickHandler>Jesus</jLink>' prophetic warning (Mat.24.16, which instructed his followers to "flee to the mountains" when they saw <jLink data-type='L' data-strong='H3389' clickHandler>Jerusalem</jLink> surrounded by armies. The migration to Pella proved providential, as it allowed the <jLink data-type='L' data-strong='H3389' clickHandler>Jerusalem</jLink> church to survive the destruction that would befall the holy city in AD 70.
events: AD 68: <jLink data-type='L' data-strong='H3389' clickHandler>Jerusalem</jLink> Christians flee to Pella in the <jLink data-type='L' data-strong='G1179' clickHandler>Decapolis</jLink>.
AD 68: Death of Emperor <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='G3505' clickHandler>Nero</jLink> by suicide in <jLink data-type='L' data-strong='G4514' clickHandler>Rome</jLink>.
AD 68: Servius Sulpicius Galba proclaimed emperor in Hispania Tarraconensis.
AD 68: Marcus Salvius Otho conspires against Galba with Praetorian support.
AD 68: Aulus Vitellius declared emperor by Germanic legions.

ChronologyEntries.article: AD 69:  During AD 69, as the Roman siege of <jLink data-type='L' data-strong='H3389' clickHandler>Jerusalem</jLink> became imminent and the city's destruction appeared inevitable, a group of prominent Jewish rabbis led by Yohanan ben Zakkai went to the Roman camp. According to tradition, he prophesied that the Roman commander Vespasian would become emperor, just before messengers arrived with this news. Vespasian therefore granted his request to establish an academy in Javneh. <jPara></jPara> The establishment of the rabbinical center at Javneh proved to be one of the most consequential developments in Jewish history, as it provided institutional continuity for Jewish religious life after the Temple's destruction. At Javneh, the rabbis would later reconstitute the Sanhedrin, codify Jewish law, and develop the framework for Rabbinic <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='G2454' clickHandler>Judaism</jLink> that would sustain the Jewish people through centuries of diaspora. This strategic withdrawal ensured that Jewish scholarly tradition and religious authority would survive the catastrophic events of AD 70, transforming <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='G2454' clickHandler>Judaism</jLink> from a Temple-centered religion into a text-centered faith capable of existing without a geographical center.
events: AD 69: Vespasian receives news in <jLink data-type='L' data-strong='H3389' clickHandler>Jerusalem</jLink> that he is named Emperor.
AD 69: Yohanan ben Zakkai is permitted to start an academy at Javneh (Jamnia).

ChronologyEntries.article: AD 70:  The siege of <jLink data-type='L' data-strong='H3389' clickHandler>Jerusalem</jLink> in AD 70 marked the climactic conclusion of the Jewish revolt that had begun four years earlier, as Roman forces under the command of <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='G5103' clickHandler>Titus</jLink> systematically encircled and devastated the city. The siege was characterized by extreme brutality, with the Romans constructing a wall around <jLink data-type='L' data-strong='H3389' clickHandler>Jerusalem</jLink> to prevent escape and supplies from reaching the inhabitants, leading to widespread famine and internal conflict among the various Jewish factions defending the city. The prolonged siege resulted in catastrophic loss of life, with the Jewish historian Josephus reporting massive casualties among both combatants and civilians trapped within the city walls. <jPara></jPara> The siege culminated in the complete destruction of <jLink data-type='L' data-strong='H3389' clickHandler>Jerusalem</jLink> and the Second Temple, an event that fundamentally transformed both Jewish and Christian history. The Temple's destruction ended the sacrificial system that had been central to Jewish religious practice for centuries and dispersed the Jewish population throughout the Roman Empire, beginning what would become known as the diaspora. For early Christianity, the destruction of <jLink data-type='L' data-strong='H3389' clickHandler>Jerusalem</jLink> validated <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='G2424G' clickHandler>Jesus</jLink>' prophetic warnings about the city's fate (Mat.24:1-2; Luk.21:20-24) and marked the definitive separation of Christianity from its Jewish Temple-centered origins, accelerating the religion's expansion into the broader <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H1471G' clickHandler>Gentile</jLink> world.
events: AD 70: Roman forces under <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='G5103' clickHandler>Titus</jLink> besiege <jLink data-type='L' data-strong='H3389' clickHandler>Jerusalem</jLink>.
AD 70: Famine and internal conflict devastate <jLink data-type='L' data-strong='H3389' clickHandler>Jerusalem</jLink>.
AD 70: Complete destruction of <jLink data-type='L' data-strong='H3389' clickHandler>Jerusalem</jLink> and the Temple by Roman troops.

ChronologyEntries.desc: <jChronDurationLink style='color:red'>▼</jChronDurationLink><jLink data-type='P' data-strong='G5103' clickHandler>Titus</jLink> Emperor. Ignores Christians.
ChronologyEntries.article: AD 79:  <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='G5103' clickHandler>Titus</jLink> became Roman Emperor in AD 79 following the death of his father Vespasian, inaugurating a brief but significant reign that lasted until his death in AD 81. Having previously commanded the Roman forces that destroyed <jLink data-type='L' data-strong='H3389' clickHandler>Jerusalem</jLink> in AD 70, <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='G5103' clickHandler>Titus</jLink> brought considerable military experience to his imperial role. His administration is historically characterized by relative moderation in religious policy, including what appears to have been a tolerant approach toward Christian communities throughout the empire. <jPara></jPara> Unlike the harsh persecutions that would characterize later reigns, <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='G5103' clickHandler>Titus</jLink>'s policies toward Christians seem to have been marked by benign neglect rather than active suppression. This period of relative peace allowed Christian communities to consolidate and expand, particularly in urban centers throughout the <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='H1419J' clickHandler>Mediterranean</jLink> world. <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='G5103' clickHandler>Titus</jLink>'s reign, though tragically cut short by his unexpected death, provided a crucial breathing space for the early church between the traumatic events of the Jewish War and the more systematic persecutions that would follow under subsequent emperors.
events: AD 79: Vespasian’s rule ends.
AD 79: <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='G5103' clickHandler>Titus</jLink> becomes Roman Emperor.

ChronologyEntries.article: AD 81:  Domitian ascended to the imperial throne in AD 81 following the sudden death of his brother <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='G5103' clickHandler>Titus</jLink>, marking the beginning of a fifteen-year reign that would become synonymous with autocratic rule and systematic persecution of Christians. Unlike his predecessors, Domitian demanded to be addressed as "Dominus et Deus" (Lord and God), a requirement that created immediate theological conflict with Christian monotheistic beliefs and their refusal to participate in imperial cult worship. This incompatibility, combined with Domitian's increasingly paranoid and authoritarian tendencies, led to widespread persecution of Christian communities throughout the empire, representing a significant escalation from the relatively tolerant policies of previous emperors. <jPara></jPara> The persecution under Domitian was particularly severe and systematic, extending beyond Christians to include members of his own family and the senatorial class who were suspected of disloyalty
events: AD 81: <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='G5103' clickHandler>Titus</jLink>’ rule ends.
AD 81: Domitian becomes Roman Emperor.

ChronologyEntries.article: AD 90:  Around AD 90, the three epistles attributed to <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='G2491G' clickHandler>John</jLink> the Apostle—1 <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='G2491G' clickHandler>John</jLink>, 2 <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='G2491G' clickHandler>John</jLink>, and 3 <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='G2491G' clickHandler>John</jLink>—were likely composed, representing important pastoral responses to challenges facing Christian communities in <jLink data-type='L' data-strong='G0773' clickHandler>Asia</jLink> Minor. These letters emerged during a critical period in early church history when Christian communities were grappling with internal doctrinal disputes, questions of fellowship, and leadership conflicts that threatened church unity. The epistles address themes central to Christian living: 1 <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='G2491G' clickHandler>John</jLink> emphasizes love, truth, and fellowship within the Christian community while warning against false teachings that denied Christ's incarnation; 2 <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='G2491G' clickHandler>John</jLink>, a brief pastoral letter, focuses on walking in truth and love while warning against deceivers and false teachers, likely addressed to a specific local church community; 3 <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='G2491G' clickHandler>John</jLink> centers on issues of hospitality and support for traveling Christian missionaries, addressing conflicts within church leadership and commending faithful believers like <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='G1050J' clickHandler>Gaius</jLink> for their service. <jPara></jPara> The Book of Revelation was perhaps also written within the latter years of Emperor Domitian's reign, when persecution of Christians intensified. Christian tradition holds that it was during Domitian's reign that the apostle <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='G2491G' clickHandler>John</jLink> was exiled to the island of <jLink data-type='L' data-strong='G3963' clickHandler>Patmos</jLink>, where he received the prophetic visions recorded in the Book of Revelation, with its vivid imagery of imperial oppression and divine judgment against <jLink data-type='L' data-strong='G4514' clickHandler>Rome</jLink> (Rev.1:9, 2:10, 13:7). The emperor's reign of terror created an atmosphere of fear throughout the empire that would ultimately contribute to his assassination in AD 96.
events: AD 90: Christians persecuted under Emperor Domitian, especially in <jLink data-type='L' data-strong='G0773' clickHandler>Asia</jLink> Minor.

AD 90: <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='G2491G' clickHandler>John</jLink> likely writes 1 <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='G2491G' clickHandler>John</jLink> in <jLink data-type='L' data-strong='G0773' clickHandler>Asia</jLink> Minor.

AD 90: <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='G2491G' clickHandler>John</jLink> likely writes 2 <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='G2491G' clickHandler>John</jLink> to a specific church in <jLink data-type='L' data-strong='G0773' clickHandler>Asia</jLink> Minor.

AD 90: <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='G2491G' clickHandler>John</jLink> likely writes 3 <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='G2491G' clickHandler>John</jLink> addressing church leadership and commending <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='G1050J' clickHandler>Gaius</jLink>.
AD 90: <jLink data-type='P' data-strong='G2491G' clickHandler>John</jLink> likely writes Revelation while exiled on <jLink data-type='L' data-strong='G3963' clickHandler>Patmos</jLink>.
